Hence I.E.’s comment.</i> There is a secret meaning to the Midrashic statement to the effect that the world will exist for six thousand years.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 97a.</i> Once it is stated that God called the light “day,” it is impossible to maintain that the evening, too, is considered part of the day.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. takes issue with those who maintain that the evening is part of the day. According to I.E. day refers only to daylight. For the implications of this comment see Weiser.</i> 
The correct interpretation of <i>And there was evening and there was morning, one day</i> is that evening passed and the morning of the first day also came. If the intention of this verse is to teach that evening and morning make a day, then what is the meaning of <i>And there was evening and there was morning, a second day</i> (v. 8)?<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">If the intention of Scripture is to teach us that evening and morning make a day, why keep on repeating this with regard to the subsequent days? Hence Scripture is only describing what happened (Kaputa).</i>

Verse 6

AND GOD SAID. Saadiah Gaon says things about the firmament that are not so.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Saadiah says that the waters are congealed on the firmament in a manner similar to the albumen of an egg. Saadiah also identifies the firmament with heaven (Krinsky).</i> The correct interpretation of firmament (<i>raki’a</i>) is something spread out, as in <i>And they did beat</i> (va-yirakke’u) <i>the gold into thin plates</i> (Ex. 39:3); <i>Then did I beat them</i> (erka’em) (II Sam. 22:43); and similarly, <i>And spreadeth them out as a tent to dwell in</i> (Is. 40:22). How precious are the words of he who said that the firmament begins at the point where the sun and the ocean merge.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Reading <i>ketzot ha-shamayim</i>, as in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38, for <i>ketzot ha-shemesh</i>. Cf. <i>Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer</i>, Chap. III.</i> The firmament is the air because when the light shone very strongly upon the earth and a wind dried off from the earth, the flame turned into the firmament.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. apparently alludes here to “the light as the medium whereby the chaotic base elements were progressively transformed into their present form” (Levine). Fire was believed to be one of the primeval elements out of which the world was created. I.E. believed that this element “changed and became the <i>raki’a</i> (firmament)” (Cohen).</i> Similarly<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Ps. 104:2 describes the heaven (firmament) as being “stretched out like a curtain,” which agrees with I.E.’s interpretation that the firmament is “something spread out.” Furthermore, Psalm 104, like Gen. 1:6-10, first describes the creation of the sky and then that of the dry land.</i> the Psalmist states, <i>Who stretchest out the heavens like a curtain; Who layest the beams of Thine upper chambers in the waters</i> (Ps. 104:2 and 3). The Psalmist then makes mention of the clouds and the wind and the establishment of the earth. The latter is above the waters. We thus read, <i>For He hath founded it (the earth) upon the seas</i> (Ps. 24:2), and <i>To Him that spread forth the earth above the waters</i> (Ps. 136:6). Similarly whoever goes to the ocean is said to be going down.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">For the earth is above the waters. Cf. Ps. 107:23.</i> The meaning of <i>(He) That calleth for the waters of the sea, And poureth them out upon the face of the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Which implies that the waters are above the earth.</i> (Amos 5:8) is that God commands the waters of the sea to give birth to clouds, and, afterward, <i>And (He) poureth them out upon the face of the earth</i>.

Verse 7

AND GOD MADE. Dividing one thing from another is expressed by placing the preposition <i>ben</i> (between) before the first object and a <i>lamed</i> before the second, as in <i>And let it divide</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: <i>and let it divide between</i>.</i> <i>the waters</i> (ben mayim) <i>from the waters</i> (la-mayim) (Gen. 1:6) and <i>between the holy</i> (ben kodesh) <i>and the common</i> (le-chol) (Ezek. 44:23). It may also be expressed by placing the preposition (<i>ben</i>) before each one of the objects, as in our verse <i>and divided the waters</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: <i>and God divided between the waters</i>.</i> (ben ha-mayim) <i>which were under the firmament from the waters</i> (u-ven ha-mayim) <i>which were above the firmament</i>. And it is found with the word <i>ben</i> repeated and a <i>lamed</i> before the second object, as in <i>But your iniquities have separated Between you</i> (benekhem) <i>and your God</i> (le-ven elohekhem) (Is. 59:2).
[AND IT WAS SO.] This phrase is connected to the verse which follows it: <i>When it was so, God called the firmament heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And it was so</i> is out of place following <i>And God made the firmament</i>. If he made it, then obviously it was so. Hence it does not apply to verse 7 but is connected to verse 8; viz., after the firmament came into being God called it heaven (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 8

AND GOD CALLED. There are five things which God named because there was then no man to name them. They are: light, darkness, heaven, earth and the seas. In addition, God named man.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture explicitly tells us that God named the Light, the Darkness, etc. I.E. points out that God also named Adam, even though this is not expressly stated in our chapter.</i>

Verse 9

AND GOD SAID. I believe that this chapter is connected to the one preceding it<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">In the Hebrew Bible verses 6-8 and 9-13 form separate chapters. According to I.E. verse 9 does not start the account of the third day of creation, but is a continuation of verse 8. See note 99.</i> because the firmament did not come into being until the land dried.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Thus land was created on the second day and not on the third day.</i> Proof of this is Scripture’s statement, <i>In the day that the Lord God made earth (dry land) and heaven (the firmament)</i> (Gen. 2:4). Thus they were made on the same day. The revelation of something which had previously been hidden (the land) or the gathering of something which was scattered (the water) into one place is not a creation.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Hence Scripture (Gen. 2:4) states, <i>the Lord God made earth and heaven</i>, rather than the Lord God created earth and heaven. I.E. had previously commented that only one thing was created on each day. He therefore explains that the making of the firmament and dry land on one day does not constitute the creation of two things on the same day, for the drying of the land was not a creation.</i> The meaning of our verse is: now God had said, <i>Let the waters under the heaven be gathered</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And God said</i> is to be understood as a pluperfect. Verses 8 and 9 are to be read as one verse and understood as follows: And God called the firmament heaven…for God had said, Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place (Cohen).</i> There are hundreds of similar instances in the Torah. I will offer two examples from the portion of <i>Bereshit</i>. One is: <i>And the Lord God planted a garden eastward, in Eden; and there He put the man whom He had formed</i> (Gen. 2:8). After stating this, Scripture goes on to say, <i>And out of the ground made the Lord God to grow every tree that is pleasant to the sight</i> (v. 9). However, God caused vegetation and trees to sprout before the creation of man.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">According to Gen. 1:11,12, vegetation was created before man. Therefore the meaning of Gen. 2:9 is: And out of the ground the Lord God had previously made to grow every tree that is pleasant to the sight.</i> The second example is when God commanded man not to eat from the tree of knowledge (Gen. 2:16). However, immediately after this it is written, <i>And out of the ground the Lord God formed every beast of the field, and every fowl of the air; and brought them unto the man</i>, etc. (Gen. 2:19).<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The implication is that the beasts of the field were created after man. However, Gen. 1:25 tells us that man was created after the beasts of the field. Hence the meaning of <i>formed</i> in Gen. 2:19 is had formed, i.e., before creating man God had formed the beasts of the field and every fowl of the air.</i> The meaning of <i>formed</i> thus is had formed. According to this interpretation it follows that <i>And God saw that it was good</i> (Gen. 1:10) is connected to the act of creation which took place on the second day.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The account describing the making of the sky and the earth concludes with Gen. 1:10, <i>And God saw that is was good</i>.</i> The account of the creation which took place on the third day thus begins with <i>And God said: Let the earth put forth grass</i> (Gen. 1:11).
[LET…BE GATHERED.] The meaning of <i>yikkavu</i> is let them come together. <i>Ve-nikvu</i> in <i>At that time they shall call Jerusalem the throne of the Lord; and all nations shall be gathered</i> (ve-nikvu) <i>unto it</i> (Jer. 3:17) is similar.

Verse 10

[SEAS.] Scripture employs the term seas (<i>yammim</i>) because there is no one name for the sea that surrounds all of the earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra, in line with other medievalists, believed that there is one sea covering most of the earth. Thus he was faced with the problem of why Scripture doesn’t say God called the gathering of the waters “sea.” His guess was that the sea had different names in different places. Hence Scripture refers to it as seas. For an alternate interpretation see Filwarg.</i>

Verse 11

AND GOD SAID. Scripture states, <i>Let the earth put forth grass</i> (Gen. 1:11); <i>Let the waters swarm with swarms of living creatures</i> (Gen. 1:20); <i>Let the earth bring forth the living creature after its kind</i> (Gen. 1:24). This teaches that God placed in the earth and in the water the power to bring forth these things at God’s command. These are the generations (offspring) of the heaven and the earth (Gen. 2:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Filwarg. For an alternate interpretation see Krinsky.</i>
[LET THE EARTH PUT FORTH GRASS.] <i>Tadshe</i> means let it put forth.
WHEREIN IS THE SEED THEREOF. Wherein the seed is in the fruit and each one produces its own kind.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND GOD SAID. <i>Yehi</i> (let there be) is short for <i>yiheyeh</i>. Due to the frequency with which this term is used, it is employed before both the singular and the plural.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Luminaries is a plural, so Scripture should have used the plural <i>yiheyu</i>, rather than the singular <i>yehi</i>.</i> It is also employed in Scripture with the feminine as in, <i>If there be a damsel</i> (yiheyeh) <i>that is a virgin</i> (Deut. 22:23).<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Since damsel is a feminine, the verb <i>tiheyeh</i>, rather than <i>yiheyeh</i> (which is masculine), should have been used. I.E. points out that there is a tendency toward uniformity when a word is employed frequently.</i>
FOR SIGNS AND FOR SEASONS. <i>For signs</i>, i.e., for minutes, <i>and for seasons</i>, i.e., for hours. <i>For signs</i> may also be interpreted as referring to the eclipse of the moon and the sun and also to shooting stars. The last-mentioned phenomena are to be included among the signs produced by the lights of the firmament because they are caused by the stars. This meaning of signs is like signs in <i>And be not dismayed at the signs (omens) of heaven</i> (Jer. 10:2). Anyone who explains the <i>lamed</i> of <i>le-otot</i> (for signs) as superfluous is mistaken.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that the <i>lamed</i> is a preposition.</i>
AND LET THEM BE FOR SIGNS. A prominent Spanish sage<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Janah (Krinsky).</i> stated that the firmament is divided into eight parts, seven for the seven spheres of the seven stars and one for the constellations.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The eighth sphere is a sphere of the constellations. The seven “planets” are the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn. Each “planet” has its own sphere (Krinsky). Hence the firmament consists of eight parts. Heaven consists of the seven planets and the constellations. Thus according to the Spanish sage the firmament and heaven are identical.</i> However, this cannot be so because we know there is no body above the sphere of the constellations. Behold, Scripture explicitly states, <i>And God set them in the firmament of the heaven</i>, which clearly indicates that there is a heaven above the firmament. <i>The heaven of heavens</i> (Nehemiah 9:6) and <i>To Him that rideth upon the heaven of heavens, which are of old</i> (kedem) (Ps. 68:34) are similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">The term <i>heaven of heavens</i> refers to the heaven above the firmament. It is I.E.’s belief that the planets and constellations are above the firmament (see note 40).</i> Note that the word <i>kedem</i> in the verse quoted above does not mean east but ancient.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kedem</i> may also mean east, but not here. If the verse alluded to the eastern sky it could not refer to the heaven above the firmament (the ancient heaven) which is invisible.</i> Indeed, Rabbi Saadiah Gaon, may the righteous be remembered for a blessing, was afraid to comment on this verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>kedem</i> means old. It implies that they are older than the earth and may even be eternal. Hence Saadiah refrains from commenting on this verse. See Krinsky.</i> It appears to me that the sun, the moon and other luminaries are called <i>lights in the firmament</i> because they are visible there.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the luminaries are not in the firmament. They are above it. Nevertheless, Scripture states that God placed them in the firmament because they shine through the firmament and thus appear to be there.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16

AND GOD MADE. The sun and the moon are called the great lights in contradistinction to the stars.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The term “two great lights” implies that both lights were of equal size, hence I.E.’s comment. Cf. Rashi’s comment on this verse.</i> Similarly the first three sons of Jesse are called the elders, in contrast to their younger brothers.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously only one of them was the eldest.</i> In reality, Eliab, the first born, was the oldest of them all. As to the Midrash, which states <i>One was not greater than the other</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">That is, both the sun and the moon were the same size at creation. Cf. <i>Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer</i>, Chap. VI.</i> there is a secret meaning to it.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrashic statement is not to be taken literally.</i>
[TO RULE THE DAY.] The sun rules during the day and not at night because it is not seen. Conversely, the light of the moon and stars are not seen during the day. One may ask, do not the astronomers teach that Jupiter and all the stars, with the exception of Mercury and Venus, are larger than the moon? Why, then, is it written <i>the great lights</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">The implication from Scripture is clearly that the moon is larger than the stars.</i> The answer is that the term great does not refer to size but to light, and the light of the moon is many times greater than their light because of its proximity to the earth. Thus we see that Scripture describes them as lights.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture calls the sun and the moon lights because it refers to the light given off by them and not to their physical size.</i>

Verse 17

AND GOD SET. Do not be surprised that Scripture states, <i>And God set</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">If the stars are above the firmament, why does Scripture state, <i>And God set them in the firmament</i> (Filwarg). According to Weiser the question is, “If the stars are set in the sky then why are they not visible there at all times?”</i> for the Bible also says, <i>I have set My bow in the cloud</i> (Gen. 9:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">The rainbow only appears to be in the cloud (Krinsky). Weiser interprets, “The rainbow is not always visible there.” Even so Scripture states, <i>I have set My bow in the cloud</i> (Gen. 9:13).</i>

Verse 18

AND TO RULE. The day spoken of in the Torah begins at sunrise and lasts until sunset. Night begins when the stars are first visible. Those who say that night begins with the appearance of three stars are correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Talmud (<i>Sabbath</i> 35b), night begins with the appearance of three stars.</i> Know that evening begins at sunset and lasts for one and a third hours, during which time a light-like appearance is seen in the clouds. Similarly morning dawns before sunrise.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Morning dawns one and a third hours before sunrise (Krinsky).</i> When the light of the sun shines during the day and the light of the moon at night, they separate between the light and the dark.<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>and to divide the light from the darkness</i> refers to both the sun and the moon.</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

AND GOD SAID. <i>Yishritzu</i> (let it swarm) is a transitive verb, as is <i>sharatz</i> (swarm) in <i>And the river shall bring forth swarms of frogs</i> (ve-sharatz) (Ex. 7:28).<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In Gen. 9:7 and Ex. 1:7 swarm is intransitive. I.E. points out that here and in Exodus it is transitive. Therefore swarm may be either a transitive or an intransitive verb (Weiser).</i> The meaning of <i>Let the waters bring forth swarms of living creatures and let fowl fly above the earth</i> is that the waters shall produce living beings that will immediately fly.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Filwarg.</i> The verse <i>And let fowl fly…in the open firmament of heaven</i> proves my interpretation of the firmament.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the firmament is the air or atmosphere, not heaven. See I.E.’s comments on verse 6. The birds fly in the air, not among the spheres; thus <i>raki’a</i> cannot be the domain of the spheres (Cherez).</i> Saadiah Gaon<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Filwarg explains that according to Saadiah the stars are in the firmament which is in motion. Thus the fowl fly along with the firmament. It should be noted that Saadiah identifies the firmament with heaven.</i> explains <i>al pene</i> (in the open) to mean with the face of. Hence, according to the Gaon, the heavens face down.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture says that the birds fly on the face of the firmament. Since, according to Saadiah, the fowl fly along with the face of the firmament (heaven), then the firmament (heaven) faces down. This is absurd and shows how wrong Saadiah is.</i> The <i>feh</i> of <i>ye’ofef</i> (let fly) is doubled like the <i>nun</i> in <i>yekhonen</i> (till He establish) (Is. 62:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">An <i>ayin vav</i> has its final letter doubled in the <i>pi’el</i>. The root of <i>ye’offe</i> f is <i>ayin</i>, <i>vav, peh</i>. The root of <i>yekhonen</i> is <i>caf, vav, nun</i>.</i>

Verse 21

AND GOD CREATED. The meaning of <i>romeset</i> (creepeth) is walks. Some are of the opinion that the <i>sin</i> of <i>romeset</i> is in place of a <i>samekh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>resh mem samekh</i> means to tread. Thus <i>romes</i> with a <i>sin</i> means the same as <i>romes</i> with a <i>samekh</i>.</i>

Verse 22

AND GOD BLESSED. The meaning of <i>Be fruitful, and multiply</i> is, “You shall be fruitful and you shall multiply.” <i>And die in the mount</i> (Deut. 32:50) is similar because it is not in one’s power to determine the time of one’s death.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And die in the mount</i> is to be rendered: and you shall die in the mount. For we cannot determine the time of our death. Similarly one can have intercourse but one cannot guarantee conception. Hence <i>Be fruitful, and multiply</i>, like <i>and die</i>, is not an imperative.</i>

Verse 23



Verse 24

AND GOD SAID. <i>Living creature</i> is a general term for what the fire, water and earth gave birth to.<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The basic elements according to medieval scientific belief.</i> It also includes man.
CATTLE. Domesticated beasts that are utilized by man for their needs, for riding and for food.
AND CREEPING THING. Small animals that walk upon the earth.
AND BEAST OF THE EARTH. Animals that are in the wilderness where there are no human settlements. The <i>vav</i> at the end of <i>ve-chayeto</i> (and beast of) is superfluous. It is like the <i>vav</i> of <i>le-mayeno</i> (into a fountain) in <i>into a fountain</i> (le-mayeno) of <i>waters</i> (Ps. 114:8), and the <i>vav</i> in <i>the son of</i> (beno) <i>Beor</i> (Num. 24:3).

Verse 25



Verse 26

LET US MAKE MAN. Some are of the opinion that <i>na’aseh</i> (let us make) is a <i>nifal</i> participle<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Na’aseh</i> is not a first person plural future <i>kal</i> but rather a <i>nifal</i> participle. This interpretation eliminates the problem of God using a plural form when speaking of Himself. The verse is to be read as follows: <i>And God said, Let a man be made</i> (Cherez).</i> and is to be compared to the same word in <i>Now that which was prepared</i> (na’aseh) <i>for one day</i> (Neh. 5:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Here <i>na’aseh</i> is definitely a <i>nifal</i> form.</i> They further say that <i>in our image, after our likeness</i> are the words of Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">They interpret the verse as follows: God said, “Let a man be made.” Moses added: “in our image after our likeness,” i.e., in human form. This eliminates the problem of God having a human form.</i> They also explain the pronominal suffix “his” in <i>And God created man in His own image</i> (v. 27) as referring to man,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is to be explained as God created man in man’s own image.</i> and connect God (in Gen. 9:6) to <i>made</i> rather than to <i>image</i>. They read this verse as follows: “For God made man in an image,” rather than “for in the image of God made He man.”<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">They read the verse, <i>ki be-tzelem, Elohim asah et ha-adam</i>. The usual and correct reading is, <i>ki be-tzelem Elohim, asah et ha-adam</i>. Cherez notes that the same interpretation applies to verse 27, i.e., <i>be-tzelem, Elohim bara oto</i>.</i> Now this interpretation is absurd. According to it the first quoted verse should have read, “Let a man be made.”<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>na’aseh adam</i> means “Let (<i>yehi</i>) a man be made,” then the text should read <i>yehi na’aseh adam</i>.</i> Similarly Scripture should have read, “He made him in his image.”<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is either to Gen. 9:6 (Netter) or 1:27 (Cherez). I.E.’s point is, why use such roundabout language to say that God made man in his (human) image when the Bible could have said this directly (Cherez). <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, “It should have stated, He made him in our image”; i.e., if “our image” relates to man’s image, 9:6 and 1:27 should have so read.</i> Furthermore, how can the <i>his</i> in <i>His image</i> (v. 27) refer to man? If this were the case then man had an image before he was created.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">If man was created in man’s image, then man had an image before he was created. This is obviously an impossibility.</i> Finally, what sense would there be to <i>Whoso sheddeth man’s blood, by man shall his blood be shed</i> (Gen. 9:6), if the reason for the above is that man was made in an image? All living things have an image.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">The verse stresses man’s uniqueness; i.e., he was created in God’s image. But if the verse speaks only of man having an image, animals, too, have an image. Wherein is the uniqueness of man?</i> Saadiah Gaon explains <i>in our image, after our likeness</i> as referring to the dominion man exercises on earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Man rules over the world just as God rules over the universe (Weiser).</i> He explains <i>His image</i><sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Reading <i>His image</i> for image (Filwarg).</i> as the image that God in His wisdom chose for man because He saw that this image was good for man. The Gaon further notes that Scripture connects image to God (<i>be-tzelem Elohim</i>) to stress man’s glorified state.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">In the image of God (<i>be-tzelem Elohim</i>) means in the image chosen by God. A very precious image.</i> Similarly Scripture states, <i>and are gone forth out of His land</i> (Ezek. 36:20). The Bible says this to emphasize the importance of the land of Israel because, in reality, <i>The earth is the Lord’s, and the fullness thereof</i> (Ps. 24:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">All of the earth is in reality His land. There is thus no reason to call Israel “His land.” Hence the Torah calls the land of Israel “His land” in order to stress its importance.</i> The Gaon also says that the word <i>na’aseh</i> (let us make) has the meaning of the singular even though it is in the plural because it is the plural of majesty.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore <i>Let us make</i> really means: I will make.</i> He offers as proof, <i>and we will give thee the other also</i> (Gen. 29:27); <i>and we will tell the interpretation thereof before the king (Daniel 2:36); peradventure I shall prevail, that we may smite</i> (nakkeh) <i>them</i> (Num. 22:6). However, these witnesses are false witnesses.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">These verbs are not examples of the plural of Majesty.</i> First of all, <i>and we will give thee</i> (ve-nittenah) (Gen. 29:27) is a <i>nifal</i> and its meaning is “the other will also be given thee.”<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">It is not a first person plural <i>kal</i>.</i> It is like the word <i>nittenah</i> (is given) in <i>and the city is given</i> (nittenah) (Jer. 32:24). The <i>vav</i> conversive changes <i>nittenah</i> (she was given) to “she will be given (<i>ve-nittenah</i>),” as is the case with every verb in the perfect which becomes an imperfect when a <i>vav</i> conversive is prefixed to it. Similarly <i>nakkeh bo</i> (we may smite them) (Num. 22:6) means, “I and my army will smite them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>nakkeh</i> is not a plural of majesty.</i> Further, <i>nakkeh</i> may be a <i>pi’el</i> infinitive<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>nun</i> of <i>nakkeh</i> (smite) is not the <i>nun</i> of the first person plural but is part of the root of the word <i>nakkeh</i>. The meaning of the word thus is <i>to smite</i>, rather than <i>we will smite</i>.</i> meaning to smite, like <i>nakeh</i> (destroy)<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nakkeh</i> is a <i>pi’el</i> infinitive.</i> in <i>But will not utterly destroy thee</i> (ve-nakkeh lo anakkekah) (Jer. 46:28). The latter interpretation is supported by the fact that Scripture employs the phrase <i>lo nukku</i> (were not smitten) (Ex. 9:32), and a verb cannot come in the <i>pu’a</i> l unless it also comes in the <i>pi’el</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nukku</i> (were smitten) is a <i>pu’al</i>. <i>Pu’al</i> is the passive of <i>pi’el</i>. If a verb is found in the <i>pu’al</i> it can also come in the <i>pi’el</i>, Hence smite can be a <i>pi’el</i> (Meijler). For alternate interpretations see Krinsky and Filwarg.</i> Rabbi Moses Ha-kohen, the Spaniard, errs in his book.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moses ben Samuel Gikatila, an 11th century Bible commentator. It is not clear what error I.E. is referring to. Cf. Filwarg. Perhaps R. Moses also interpreted <i>nakkeh</i> as the plural of majesty.</i> Similarly <i>we will tell</i> (Dan. 2:36) is Aramaic.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">It is not a plural of majesty but the normal way of speaking in Aramaic (Krinsky).</i> For if <i>we will tell</i> is a plural of majesty, how would Daniel dare to speak in such haughty terms before Nebuchadnezzar who was the “King of Kings”?I will now explain. Note that all the works of creation came into being by God’s command for the sake of man. Scripture relates that the earth and water brought forth plants and all living creatures. After all plants and living creatures had been created, God said to the angels, <i>Let us make man</i>; i.e., We, rather than the earth and water, will occupy ourselves with his creation. We know that the Torah spoke the language of man,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berekhot</i> 31b.</i> for it was given to humans who speak and hear. Now a human being cannot speak of things above or below him without employing human terminology. Hence Scripture uses such terms as the mouth of the earth (Num. 16:30), <i>the hand of the Jordan</i> (Num. 13:29),<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates: the side of the Jordan.</i> and <i>the head</i><sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates: beginning.</i> <i>of the dust of the world</i> (Proverbs 8:26). Far be it from us to believe that God has an image.<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">On the basis of our verses reading, <i>in our image, after our likeness</i>.</i> Scripture clearly refutes such a notion by stating, <i>To whom then will you liken Me, that I should be equal</i> (Is. 40:25). It is because man’s upper soul is eternal and is compared in its existence to God and because man’s soul is incorporeal and fills the body, which is a microcosm, in the same way that God fills the universe that Scripture states, <i>in our image, after our likeness</i>. May God’s name be blessed. He commenced with the macrocosm and concluded with the microcosm.<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Man. The account of creation begins with the creation of the “large world,” the universe, and concludes with the creation of the “small world,” man. “Man is a microcosm, a universe in little, for like the great universe he consists of a body animated by a soul” (Husik, p. 191).</i> The prophet also says that he saw God’s glory appear in human form (Ezek. 1:26).<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Hence Ezekiel, like Moses, employed human terminology in speaking of God (Weiser).</i> God is one. He is the creator of all. He is all. I cannot explain further.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. “seems to favor the idea of eternal creation and maintenance of the universe, the relation of which to God is as the relation of speech to the speaker, which exists only so long as the speaker speaks. The moment he ceases speaking the sounds cease to exist” (Husik, p. 190). The mystery of God being “All” is difficult to comprehend and lends itself to misinterpretation. It might lead one to believe in pantheism.</i> Man was originally created with two faces;<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Hence there is no contradiction in Scripture stating, <i>created He him</i>, and then saying, <i>created He them</i> (Meijler). Weiser explains that I.E.’s interpretation is in keeping with the Rabbinic tradition that man was originally androgynous (<i>Erubin</i> 18a). Levine (p. 135) suggests that I.E. speaks of man’s dual nature; i.e., he has a body and a soul.</i> man is thus one but also two. <i>In the image of God</i> means in the image of the angels. Man was created both male and female.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">The angels are of only one sex, man is of two. Nevertheless, man was created in the image of the angels.</i> The words <i>Be fruitful, and multiply</i> are a blessing not a command,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">According to the rabbis of the Talmud there is a commandment to “be fruitful and multiply.” Cf. <i>Kiddushin</i> 35a.</i> just as they are with regard to the creatures brought forth by the waters (Gen. 1:22).<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously no command is addressed to animals.</i> Nevertheless, there is in fact a commandment to be fruitful and multiply transmitted by our sages, of blessed memory, which they attached to this verse in order to remember the commandment.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. when a Rabbinic interpretation is not in keeping with the literal meaning of the verse, then the verse is to be interpreted literally, and the Rabbinic interpretation accepted as true in itself but not as being derived from the verse. The verse merely serves as a peg on which to attach an authentic tradition.</i>

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

AND GOD SAID: BEHOLD I HAVE GIVEN YOU. God permitted mankind and every living thing to eat all herbs. He also permitted man to eat the fruits of the trees and limited the animals and creeping things to green herbs. At this point in time the consumption of flesh was not permitted. That came after the flood.

Verse 30



Verse 31

THE SIXTH DAY. Some say that the word <i>yom</i> (day) is in the construct with sixth,<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">If sixth were an adjective then <i>yom</i> should have a definite article prefixed to it, i.e., <i>ha-yom ha-shishi</i> rather than <i>yom ha-shishi</i>, as in Deut. 3:25 <i>ha-har ha-tov</i> (that goodly hill-country); or both <i>yom</i> and <i>shishi</i> should be written without a <i>heh</i>, as in <i>yom sheni</i> (a second day). Hence <i>yom ha-sheshi</i> means the day of the sixth (Filwarg).</i> and the meaning of <i>yom ha-shishi</i> (the sixth day) is the day of the sixth sphere.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the day when the sixth heavenly sphere (the sphere of Jupiter) exerts an astrological influence on the earth.</i> They say the same with regard to <i>yom ha-shevi’i</i> (the seventh day). However, they are wrong. Proof of their error is found in the teaching of the astrologers who tell us who the lord<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the dominant sphere.</i> of the sixth day is.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">The astrologers say that the sphere of Venus is dominant on the sixth day (Weiser). Venus is the third sphere (Cherez). It should be noted that in the Romance languages Friday is called Venus’s day. Thus in Italian, Friday is known as venerdi and in French as vendredi.</i> The meaning of <i>yom ha-shishi</i>, then, is the sixth day from day one. This is also the meaning of the seventh day. We similarly find<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Where the noun is not preceded by a <i>heh</i> and the adjective is (Filwarg).</i> <i>ish ha-yisraeli</i> (the Israelite man) (Leviticus 24:10)<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates: <i>a man of Israel</i>, taking man to be in the construct with Israel.</i> and many such cases, among them <i>reki’a ha-shamayim</i> (Gen. 1:20),<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. renders: <i>firmament of heaven</i>, taking firmament to be in the construct with heaven.</i> which should be rendered as “the firmament which is heaven.”

Chapter 2



Verse 1

WERE FINISHED. <i>Va-yekhullu</i> is a <i>pu’al</i>. It follows the paradigm of <i>va-yekhussu</i> (were covered) in <i>and all the high mountains…were covered</i> (Gen. 7:19). Its meaning is: were finished. The earth includes the oceans since they form one entity.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Hence Scripture states, <i>And the heaven and the earth were finished</i>, rather than, And the heaven, the earth and the oceans were finished.</i>

Verse 2

AND ON THE SEVENTH DAY GOD FINISHED. Some say<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And on the seventh day God finished</i> implies that God created something on the seventh day. The question is what?</i> that the days are created entities, and with the creation of the seventh day God’s work was finished. However, this interpretation is unpalatable. Others say that the <i>bet</i> may indicate before, as in <i>Thou shalt not muzzle the ox when he treadeth out</i> (be-disho) <i>the corn</i> (Deut. 25:4), and in <i>howbeit the first day</i> (ba-yom ha-rishon) <i>ye shall put away leaven out of your houses</i> (Ex. 12:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And on the seventh day God finished</i> is to be translated as <i>And by the seventh day God had finished His work which He had made</i>. They similarly translate Deut. 25:4, <i>Thou shalt not muzzle the ox before he treadeth out the corn</i>, and render Ex. 12:15 as <i>howbeit before the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses</i>.</i> However, why go through all this trouble<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Why give the <i>bet</i> a novel meaning (before) when in fact “finished” does not imply that any work was done on the Sabbath.</i> when finishing work does not constitute an act. Saying God finished is equivalent to saying God did no work. This is the meaning of <i>God finished</i> and of <i>and He rested</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Both mean God did no work.</i>
<i>His work which He had made</i> refers to the work that he had done on Friday prior to the onset of the Sabbath. 
<i>And He rested on the seventh day from all His work</i> pertains to all creations that God brought into being.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">In other words part A of verse 2 refers to Friday, part B to the six days of creation. This also explains the reason why part A of the verse reads, <i>His work</i> and part B, <i>all His work</i>. Thus part B complements part A and is not redundant (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 3

AND GOD BLESSED. A blessing means an increase in well being. On the Sabbath the body is blessed with a renewal of its reproductive strength and the soul with an increase in its intellectual and reasoning capabilities.
AND HALLOWED IT. No work was done on the Sabbath, in contrast to the other six days.
[WHICH GOD IN CREATING HAD MADE.] Its meaning is: God placed in the root of all the species the power to reproduce themselves.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains <i>asher bara Elohim la’asot</i> (which God in creating had made) as follows: God created (<i>bara</i>) his creation in such a way that they would do (<i>la’asot</i>), i.e., reproduce themselves in the future. That is why <i>bara</i> is a perfect and <i>la’asot</i> is an infinitive (Cherez).</i> I disagree with the person who explains <i>la’asot</i> (had made) as having the same meaning as made<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">They interpret <i>asher bara Elohim la’asot</i> to mean, which God created and made. They maintain that <i>la’asot</i>, an infinitive, is to be interpreted as <i>asah</i>, a perfect (Filwarg). They also do not differentiate between <i>bara</i> and <i>asah</i>, and interpret “made” in verse 2 as created (Filwarg, Krinsky). For I.E.’s interpretation of <i>bara</i> see Gen. 1:1; for <i>asah</i> see verse 4.</i> and who, furthermore, insists that created and made are synonymous. Saadiah Gaon explains that the blessing and the holiness spoken of in this verse refer to those who observe the Sabbath.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">According to Saadiah the blessing refers not to the Sabbath but rather to those who observe the Sabbath. We have translated according to Nachmanides’ rendering of I.E., which had a <i>vav</i> before sanctified.</i> They will be blessed and sanctified.

Verse 4

THESE ARE THE GENERATIONS. These are what they gave birth to.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. usually renders <i>toledot</i> as “accounts of.” Cf. Gen. 6:9; 37:1. Here <i>toledot</i> refers to what heaven and earth produced: trees, living creatures, man.</i>
WHEN THEY WERE CREATED. When the firmament came into being and the earth became visible.
[IN THE DAY THAT THE LORD GOD MADE.] <i>Be-yom asot</i> means in the day that God fixed.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that <i>asah</i> (make) means “to fix in its final form.” When the firmament and the earth received their final form, God commanded them to produce offspring (<i>toledot</i>).</i> Proof of this can be seen in <i>and He hastened to dress it</i> (la-asot oto) (Gen. 18:7), and in <i>Whom I have created</i> which is then followed by <i>I have formed him</i>, and finally by <i>yea, I have made him</i> (asitiv) (Is. 43:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The prophet first speaks of creation (<i>berativ</i>) and last, of fixing in final form (<i>asitiv</i>).</i>

Verse 5

SHRUB. <i>Si’ach</i> (shrub) means a tree: so, too, in <i>Among the bushes</i> (sichim) <i>they bray</i> (Job 30:7). In my opinion <i>si’ach</i> refers to a fruit-bearing tree, because Scripture compares man to a tree.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture compares man to a fruit bearing tree. Cf. Ps. 1:1-3, <i>Happy is the man…And he shall be like a tree planted by streams of water, That bringeth forth its fruit in its season</i>.</i> Behold, Scripture employs such terms as tree (<i>si’ach</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew word for speech is <i>si’ach</i>. Speech is the fruit of the mouth. Hence the tree to which it is compared, <i>si’ach</i>, must be a fruit-bearing tree (Filwarg).</i> fruit,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 1:12.</i> bough,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Ps. 119:113.</i> limb,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Job 18:13.</i> top of a tree<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 26:18. See I.E. on the latter verse.</i> and branch<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Ps. 94:19.</i> when speaking of man.

Verse 6

A MIST. <i>Ed</i> (mist) means smoke.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. reads <i>ashan</i> (smoke). That is, a smoke-like substance went up from the earth. Weiser suggests reading <i>anan</i> (cloud) because smoke is out of place here since I.E. speaks of clouds.</i> <i>The day of their calamity</i> (yom edom) is similar (Deut. 32:35). An evil day is called a cloudy day and a day of thick darkness.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>yom ed</i> means a cloudy day, i.e., a dark day or day of calamity.</i> The meaning of our verse is that via the power of the lights a mist arose from the earth and watered it and caused it to bring forth vegetation. Saadiah Gaon explains as follows: “And no mist yet went up from the earth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">According to Saadiah the word <i>lo</i> found in verse 5 also applies to this verse.</i>

Verse 7

THEN THE LORD GOD FORMED. Via the power of the lights.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is omitted in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. It has been suggested that a scribe mistakenly copied it from the previous note (Weiser).</i>
[FORMED.] <i>Va-yitzer</i> (formed) is a <i>kal</i>. It belongs to those verbs whose first root letter is a <i>yod</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The root of this verb is therefore <i>yod, tzadi, resh</i>.</i> It is like <i>va-yiketz</i> in <i>And Noah awoke</i> (va-yiketz no’ach) (Gen. 9:24).
The meaning of <i>and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life</i> is that man lives through the nostrils. They remove the air heated by the heart and replace it with fresh air. Scripture says man became <i>nefesh chayyah</i> (a living soul)<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">This very term is also used in describing the creation of animals. Cf. Gen. 1:24.</i> because like the animals he was immediately able to walk, and thus differed from babies subsequently born.

Verse 8

AND THE LORD GOD PLANTED. God had previously planted a garden in the eastern section of the world in a place called Eden. He now placed the man there.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., <i>va-yitta</i> (planted) is a pluperfect.</i> The <i>bet</i> of <i>be-eden</i> (in Eden) in <i>in Eden the garden of God</i> (Ezek. 28:13) governs not only Eden but also garden.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. is trying to solve the following problem. In Genesis, Scripture refers to a “garden” in Eden (<i>gan be-eden</i>). However, in Ezek. 28:13 the Bible states, <i>in Eden the garden of God</i>. The former implies that the garden is located in Eden, the latter that Eden is located in the garden, hence I.E.’s comment (Filwarg).</i> Its meaning thus is, in Eden, in the garden of God. <i>Even by the God</i> (me’el) of <i>thy father, who shall help thee and by</i> (ve-et) <i>the Almighty, who shall bless thee</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>mem</i> of <i>me’el</i> is also to be placed before <i>ve’et</i> and it is to be read as if written <i>u-me’et</i>. Thus this verse is to be rendered: Even by the God (<i>me’el</i>) of thy father who shall help thee, and even by (<i>u-me’et</i>) the Almighty who shall bless thee.</i> (Gen. 49:25) is similar. There are many other such instances in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The technical term used by I.E. for this is <i>mesharet</i> (or <i>moshekh</i>) <i>atzmo ve-acher immo</i>. Friedlander explains this phrase as follows: “one word which stands for two” (literally, the word draws itself and another with it).</i>
[THE MAN.] There is a secret meaning as to why the definite article has been placed in front of Adam.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Adam is a proper noun and a proper noun does not have a definite article placed in front of it. As to the secret alluded to by I.E., Filwarg comments, “I do not understand what secret he is hinting at.” However, it appears that I.E. is hinting that “Adam” is a collective noun meaning mankind, the secret being that God placed mankind in the Garden of Eden. I.E. will later elaborate on this theme when he speaks of the secret meaning of the garden (Kaputa). Abravanel writes, “Ibn Ezra stirred the world by saying that the definite article which precedes the word “Adam” contains a secret. By this he means… (that) Adam should be understood as a noun designating the genus of mankind rather than an individual.”</i> The definite article is also found prefixed to <i>Menasheh</i> in <i>the half tribe of Manasseh</i> (shevet ha-menasheh)<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">According to Krinsky, I.E. is noting that a proper name which later becomes the name of a group may have a definite article placed in front of it. Thus Adam, although originally a proper noun, became a collective noun.</i> (Deut. 3:13) and before the word <i>Araunah</i> in <i>of Araunah the Jebusite</i> (II Sam. 24:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>araunah</i> is a collective noun.</i> It is also possible that the definite article is placed before Adam because the word <i>adam</i> is derived from the word used for ground (<i>adamah</i>). Hence the name Adam may be a proper name or an adjective.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">See Kimchi, II Sam. 24:16. In our case it is an adjective meaning the one taken from the ground, and thus has a definite article prefixed to it.</i>

Verse 9

AND OUT OF THE GROUND MADE THE LORD TO GROW. When God made the trees grow from the ground throughout the world he did the same in the Garden of Eden, but there he placed two trees not found anywhere else in the world.
AND THE TREE OF THE KNOWLEDGE. In my opinion the phrase <i>and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil</i> is to be understood as if written, “And the tree of the knowledge, knowledge of good and evil,” because the word knowledge has a definite article prefixed to it and thus cannot be in the construct.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">A word in the construct cannot have a definite article placed before it.</i> <i>The ark of the covenant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Ark has a definite article placed in front of it. Hence the phrase is to be read as if written, the ark, ark of the covenant.</i> (Josh. 3:14) and <i>even the prophecy of Oded the prophet</i> (II Chronicles 15:8)<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Prophecy has a definite article prefixed to it. Hence the phrase is to be read as if written, even the prophecy, prophecy of Oded the prophet.</i> are similar. There are many other similar instances in Scripture.

Verse 10

AND A RIVER. Before man was created the river watered the garden on all sides.
[HEADS.] The <i>alef</i> in the word <i>roshim</i> (heads) is a root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">However, it is silent. There are times when the <i>alef</i> is not a root letter, e.g., <i>the tillage of the poor</i> (rashim) (Prov. 13:23). The <i>alef</i> of <i>rashim</i> (the poor) is not part of the word’s stem (Filwarg).</i> In <i>marashotekhem</i> (headtires)<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser. For other readings and the problems inherent in them see Filwarg.</i> (Jer. 13:18) the <i>alef</i> is enunciated. The meaning of <i>marashotekhem</i> is your headtires.

Verse 11

THE NAME OF THE FIRST. Saadiah Gaon identifies Pishon with the Nile. But it is known that the Gihon<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The second river flowing out of the garden.</i> is close to the land of Israel, for Scripture states, <i>And bring him (Solomon)…down to Gihon…and…anoint him there king over Israel</i> (I Kings 1:33,34). It (the Gihon) flows from southeast of the land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The Garden of Eden is located in the east (v. 8). Furthermore, according to I.E. the Garden of Eden lies south of the equator and the land of Israel is north of the equator. Thus the Gihon flows from the southeast of the land of Israel (Krinsky). Actually the Gihon is not a river but a spring located in the valley of Jehoshaphat. Here as in other places in his commentary I.E. errs with regard to geographical knowledge of the land of Israel.</i> The same is true of the Euphrates (Perat), which marks the furthermost eastern boundary of the land of Israel. The commentaries also tell us that the Tigris (Chiddekel) is another river, in addition to the Euphrates, that flows through Baghdad. Thus these three rivers (the Gihon, the Euphrates and the Tigris) lie east of the land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, in contradistinction to the Gaon, the Pishon, too, must lie east of the land of Israel (Krinsky). However, the Nile is west of the land of Israel.</i> Furthermore, the source of the Nile is in the mountain of Frankincense far south of the equator. Proof of this can be seen by the fact that its waters swell in the summer.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">“For when it is summer time in the northern hemisphere, it is the time of the rainy season in the southern hemisphere. Thus the Nile, the source of which is in the southern hemisphere, swells during the summer” Chevel, <i>Ramban, Commentary on the Torah</i>, Vol. I, p. 86, note 414.</i> We know that the Garden of Eden is below the equator where day and night are always equal. Fools question this and ask, how is this possible?<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">For day and night to be equal.</i> However, there is positive proof that this is so. Thus according to Saadiah one must believe that the Pishon (the Nile) flows from the Garden of Eden, which is in the east, toward the mountain of Frankincense, which is in the southwest, and then flows north.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The Nile flows from the south to the north. The Garden of Eden is south of the equator toward the east. Thus if the source of the Nile is in the garden it must make this circuit.</i> There is, in fact, no proof that the Pishon is the Nile. Indeed, Saadiah translates the <i>land of Havilah</i> which the Pishon compasses to fit in with his translation of the Pishon as being the Nile. The fact of the matter is that he had no tradition concerning these things. He did the same with families, states, animals, fowl and precious stones.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Whenever Saadiah came across an unfamiliar term he translated it as he saw fit. He explained Havilah as referring to Egypt because he translated Pishon as the Nile.</i> Perhaps these things were revealed to him in a dream. He definitely erred in a number of them as I will point out in their proper place.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E., Ex. 28:9 and Lev. 11:13.</i> So we will not rely on his dreams. Perhaps he did so out of respect for the honor of God, for he translated the Torah into Arabic language and script and he did not want the Arabs to think that there are parts of Scripture<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Most texts of I.E. have the word <i>mitzvot</i> (commandments) instead of <i>millot</i> (words).</i> which we do not understand. Scripture mentions that there is gold in the land of Havilah in order to glorify the river coming out of the Garden of Eden.

Verse 12

AND THE GOLD. Saadiah Gaon renders <i>bedolach</i> (bedellium) as pearls. He compares manna to them. However, Scripture merely says that manna had the color of <i>bedolach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Not that it was identical to it. Saadiah says that <i>bedolach</i> resembles manna. As manna is round, so are <i>bedolach</i> round. This strengthens his interpretation that <i>bedolach</i> means pearls, for the Bible says that the appearance of the manna was like <i>bedolach</i> (Cherez).</i> (Num. 11:7). The Gaon also says that <i>shoham</i> (onyx) is a precious clear white stone. The fact of the matter is that we do not know the precise meaning of either of these two items.

Verse 13



Verse 14

[TOWARD THE EAST OF ASSHUR.] The <i>tav</i> of <i>kidmat</i> (toward the east of) is in place of a <i>heh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>kidmat</i> is <i>kedemah</i> in the construct.</i> The difference between <i>kedem</i> and <i>kedemah</i> is that the <i>heh</i> suffixed to <i>kedemah</i> is in place of the preposition “to” (<i>el</i>), which is vocalized with a <i>segol</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In other words <i>kedemah</i> means to the east, <i>kedem</i>, east.</i> Similarly in <i>and Abram went down into Egypt</i> (mitzraymah) (Gen. 12:10), <i>mitzraymah</i> means “to Egypt.” <i>Kidmat asshur</i> thus means <i>toward the east of Asshur</i>. Note that from the first verse of the Torah until the word <i>made</i> (Gen. 2:3), Scripture refers to the Deity as <i>Elohim</i>. Afterward, the honored and revered name (the Tetragrammaton) is coupled with it. How precious are the words of the ancients of blessed memory who said that the complete name of God is used over a complete world. Prior to the completion of creation there was no power to receive this name.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Creation came to an end with the making of man. The use of the Tetragrammaton is proper only with reference to man. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 4:1 and Gen. 1:26.</i> If God grants me life I will explain the secret of the Tetragrammaton when I comment upon the first Torah portion of the book of Exodus. I will then explain its meaning in the absolute and in the construct. Note that the location of the ground from which Adam was created was close to the Garden of Eden.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Hence man was not created in the garden. The commentaries assume that man walked to the Garden of Eden. According to Rabbinic tradition man came to the garden on the very day that he was created, hence I.E.’s comment that Adam was created close to the Garden of Eden (Krinsky).</i> I note this because some say that Adam was created out of the ground of the land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>The Kuzari</i>, 2:14.</i> They have overlooked <i>And it came to pass, as they journeyed east</i> (Gen. 11:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, <i>From the east</i>. The garden was located in the east (v. 8). The tower of Babel was built after the survivors of the flood journeyed from the east (Gen. 11:2). We know that the ark rested on Mt. Ararat (Gen. 8:4); thus Mt. Ararat lies in the east (See I.E. on Gen. 11:2). Mt. Ararat (in the east) is far from the borders of Israel. Hence the Garden of Eden (in the east), too, must be far from the land of Israel.</i>

Verse 15

INTO THE GARDEN OF EDEN. <i>Gan</i> (garden) can be both masculine and feminine,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The pronominal suffixes of the verbs <i>to toil</i> and <i>to keep</i> are in the feminine.</i> hence the plurals <i>gannim</i> and <i>gannot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">For the feminine plural form of garden see Eccles. 2:5. For the masculine plural form see Cant. 4:15. <i>Gannim</i> is masculine plural; <i>gannot</i>, feminine plural.</i> We ask those who maintain that the words <i>to till (dress) it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates “to dress it.” The literal meaning of <i>le-ovedah</i> is to till it. Till fits in better with I.E.’s comment.</i> <i>and to keep it</i> (le-ovdah u-le-shomrah) refer to the ground (<i>adamah</i>), how it is possible to till and keep a large area from a small one.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">If Adam’s task was to till and keep the soil outside the garden, then how was it possible for Adam to do this while he was in the garden? The land outside of the garden obviously extended for many miles. It would thus be impossible for Adam to live in the garden and tend the land outside of the garden. The pronominal suffixes (it) of <i>le-ovdah</i> and of <i>le-shomrah</i> are in the feminine. Those who say that these words refer to the ground do so because they believe <i>gan</i> to be masculine while ground is feminine. However, I.E. maintains that <i>gan</i> can be either masculine or feminine. Thus <i>le-ovdah u-le-shomrah</i> can refer to <i>gan</i>.</i> Furthermore, after Adam sinned God expelled him from the garden and commanded him to till the soil. But according to their interpretation he was already tilling the soil while he was living in the Garden of Eden.
<i>To till it</i> (le-ovdah) therefore refers to the garden of whose fruit he ate. It was only after he sinned that he had to eat the grass of the ground, i.e., bread. <i>To till it</i> means to water it. <i>To keep it</i> means to guard the garden so that no animals enter therein and befoul it. Some say that <i>le-ovdah</i> means to serve God’s commandment.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Targum Yerushalmi</i> on this verse. The root of the word till, <i>ayin, bet, dalet</i>, is also used in reference to worship (Deut. 6:13; 10:20).</i> However, a commandment is not served.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">While the root <i>ayin, bet, dalet</i> is used in referring to worship, it is not used in Scripture as a technical term for the practice of a precept. The term used for the latter is <i>lishmor</i> (to keep) (Deut. 8:1; 10:13). One serves (<i>oved</i>) God and observes (<i>shomer</i>) the commandments. One cannot be said to serve the commandments, hence I.E.’s objection to this interpretation.</i>

Verse 16

AND THE LORD GOD COMMANDED THE MAN. The verb <i>tzivvah</i> (command) with the preposition <i>al</i> (upon) implies a prohibition. We similarly read, <i>I will also command</i> (atzavveh) <i>the clouds</i> (al he-avim) <i>That they rain no rain upon it</i> (Is. 5:6).

Verse 17

[THOU SHALT NOT EAT OF IT.] Even though I (God) permitted you to eat of the fruit of the trees of the garden, do not eat of the fruit of the tree of knowledge.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew term implies a commandment to eat of the other trees in the garden, hence I.E.’s comment (Krinsky).</i> One might ask, What need is there for the term <i>of it</i> after having stated <i>but of the tree of the knowledge…thou shalt not eat</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it</i>. It would have sufficed to state, but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat.</i> The answer is that the Bible elaborates. We find a similar case in <i>And she opened it, and saw it, even the child</i> (Ex. 2:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture should have stated, <i>And she opened it and saw the child</i>. The elaboration is there for emphasis (Weiser).</i> It is also possible that the term <i>of it</i> means even a part of it. You will find the exact grammatical explanation of the term <i>mi-mennu</i> (of it) in the <i>Sefer ha-yisod</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">A Hebrew grammar composed by I.E. The book survives only in fragments.</i> Note that Adam was an intelligent being, for God would not direct commands to one who was unintelligent. He was deficient in the knowledge of <i>good and evil</i> of only one thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Sexual desire. See I.E.’s comment on 3:6.</i> Don’t you see that Adam named every animal and fowl according to the nature of each of their respective species? Thus he was extremely intelligent. If Adam was unintelligent, God, knowing this, would not have brought His creatures to him to see what name he would give to each one of them. God also showed Adam the tree of knowledge, for his wife knew that it was in the midst of the garden.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture does not explicitly tell us that God told Adam exactly where the tree was. However, from Eve’s action we may surmise that He did. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 3:6.</i>

Verse 18

AND THE LORD GOD SAID. <i>It is not good</i> means it is not good for the man.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: <i>And the Lord God said, it is not good, being the man alone</i>, hence I.E.’s comment. Cherez suggests that I.E. is negating an interpretation which holds it is not good for creation that man be alone lest it be said that he is a god on earth. Cf. Rashi.</i>
A HELP MEET. <i>Help meet</i> should be understood in the light of <i>Two are better than one</i> (Eccles. 4:9).

Verse 19

[WHATSOEVER THE MAN WOULD CALL.] The <i>lamed</i> (to) in the clause <i>and whatsoever the man would call</i> also applies<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: and, whatsoever the man would call it (<i>lo</i>) every living creature.</i> to the phrase <i>living creature</i>. Our clause is to be read as follows: <i>and whatsoever the man would call to it, to every living creature, that was to be the name thereof</i>. The verse elaborates,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">That is, it repeats the object <i>to it, to every living creature</i> (Shadal). See note 62.</i> as in <i>And she opened it, and saw it, even the child</i> (Ex. 2:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">See note 63.</i> There are many other such instances.

Verse 20

[TO ALL CATTLE.] <i>Le-khol</i> (to all) also governs two words,<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 29. According to I.E. <i>le-khol</i> (to all), which is prefaced to <i>cattle</i>, also governs <i>fowl</i>.</i> for the meaning of our verse is: <i>And the man gave names to all cattle, and to all the fowl of the air</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates, <i>And the man gave names to all cattle, and to the fowl of the air</i>.</i> <i>In that his men become few</i> (Deut. 33:6)<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">It should be read as if written, In that his men not become few. In other words, the word <i>ve-al</i> in the first part of the verse also governs <i>yehi</i> (let).</i> and <i>And I have not learned wisdom</i> (Prov. 30:3)<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally concludes, <i>And I have knowledge of the Holy One</i>. The <i>not</i> of the first part also applies to the second part. Thus the above should read: And I do not have knowledge of the Holy One. Thus <i>not</i> governs two words.</i> are similar. There are many other such instances.
[BUT FOR ADAM.] The meaning of <i>but for Adam he did not find a help meet</i> is that Adam did not find a helpmeet for himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates, <i>but for Adam there was not found a help meet</i>. However, the literal reading of the verse is: <i>but for Adam he did not find a help meet</i>. The question is, to whom does “he” refer? I.E. suggests it refers to Adam, not God. I.E. points out that the Bible occasionally uses a proper noun in instances where a reflexive pronoun is expected. Cf. David Kimchi’s commentary on this verse.</i> This is the way of the Hebrew language. Thus we find Samuel saying, <i>And the Lord sent Jerubbaal, and Bedan, and Jephthah, and Samuel</i> (I Sam. 12:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than saying “and me,” Samuel says, “and Samuel.” Here, too, rather than saying “but for himself he did not find a help meet” the Bible says, <i>but for Adam</i>.</i> It appears farfetched to me that <i>he did not find a help meet</i> refers to God. Scripture says here that the fowl were created out of the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">See verse 19.</i> However, it states above that they were created out of the water.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 1:20.</i> This is so because the fowl were created out of both earth and water.

Verse 21

AND THE LORD GOD CAUSED A DEEP SLEEP TO FALL. <i>Va-yappel</i> (caused to fall) is a <i>hifil</i>, as is <i>va-yashev</i> (drove away) in <i>and Abram drove them away</i> (Gen. 15:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Both <i>va-yashev</i> and <i>va-yappel</i> are <i>hifils</i> whose first root letter is a <i>nun</i>. The root of the former is <i>nun, shin, bet</i> and of the latter, <i>nun, peh, lamed</i>.</i>
A DEEP SLEEP. <i>Tardemah</i> is a deeper sleep than <i>shenah</i>, and <i>shenah</i> is a deeper sleep than <i>tenumah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">There are a number of Hebrew terms for sleep, <i>tardemah, shenah</i> and <i>tenumah</i>.</i> The <i>tav</i> of <i>tardemah</i> (deep sleep) is not part of its root.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The root being <i>resh, dalet, mem</i>.</i>
ONE OF HIS RIBS. Adam had two sides.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates <i>tzela</i> as rib, I.E. as side.</i> <i>Tzela</i> here is like <i>tzela</i> (side) in <i>and for the second side</i> (tzela) <i>of the tabernacle</i> (Ex. 26:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s comment is in keeping with the Rabbinic view (<i>Erubin</i> 18a) that man was originally created male and female. God then separated the one female side from the male side (Krinsky).</i> <i>Tzela</i> is a feminine noun. It means a side.
INSTEAD THEREOF. <i>Tachtennah</i> means in its place. <i>Tachtennah</i> (instead thereof) spelled with a superfluous <i>nun</i> is in the singular. <i>Tachtehah</i> is its plural form. <i>Tachteni</i> (under me) and <i>tachtai</i> (under me)<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. II Sam. 22:40; Ps. 18:40.</i> are similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tachteni</i>, the singular form, has the superfluous <i>nun</i>; <i>tachtai</i>, its plural form, does not (Weiser).</i>

Verse 22

MADE HE. <i>Va-yiven</i> (made me) is a <i>hifil</i> conjugation.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This comment is difficult. <i>Va-yiven</i> is a <i>kal</i> conjugation. Krinsky and Weiser suggest deleting it. Indeed, some versions do. If it is retained then it must be explained as follows: <i>Va-yiven</i> (from the root <i>bet, nun, heh</i>) is short for <i>va-yivneh</i>. I.E. notes that this type of short form of a <i>lamed heh</i> root is found in the <i>hifil</i> and in the <i>kal</i> (Weiser). <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, <i>va-yiven</i> is a <i>kal</i>, as is <i>va-yifen</i>. This appears to be the correct reading.</i> We find similar instances with the <i>kal</i> conjugation in <i>va-yifen</i> (and he turned) (Ex. 7:23) and <i>va-yiken</i> (and he bought) (Gen. 33:19).
AND BROUGHT HER. When Adam awoke from his sleep he thought that the woman was brought<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The word brought is not to be taken literally. The woman was created next to Adam as he slept; thus she could not have been brought to Adam.</i> before him as the animals were brought before him. Scripture speaks of Adam’s thoughts. Similarly, <i>And the men pursued after them</i> (Josh. 2:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The men thought that they were pursuing the Israelite spies. In reality they were not, for the spies were hidden by Rahab.</i> It is also possible that the woman was created outside of the garden and then was brought to Adam. When he looked around he knew that she had been cut from him, for one of his sides with its flesh was missing and he felt that it had been closed with other flesh.

Verse 23

AND THE MAN SAID. Then Adam said, “This time I have found a help meet like me for me, for this being came out of me.” The tradition concerning Lilith is a homily.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">There is a Rabbinic tradition that before the creation of Eve, Adam lived with the female demon Lilith. Hence he said, “This one, in contradistinction to Lilith, is bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh.” Cf. L. Ginsberg, <i>Legends of the Jews</i>, Vol. I., p. 65.</i>
<i>Le-zot</i> (she) means because of this.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>lamed</i> in front of a word usually means to. <i>Zot</i> means this. Thus <i>le-zot</i> should be rendered to this. However, I.E. points out that the <i>lamed</i> may also mean because. The meaning of our verse then is: because of this; i.e., because she is bone of my bone and flesh of my flesh she shall be called woman,</i> <i>Say of me:</i> (li)<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, <i>say to me</i>. Here, too, <i>li</i> does not mean to me but about me or of me.</i> <i>He is my brother</i> (Gen. 20:13) is similar.
[WOMAN.] The <i>shin</i> in the word <i>ishah</i> (woman) receives a <i>dagesh</i> in place of the inaudible <i>yod</i> which is found in the word <i>ish</i> (man).<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>dagesh</i> makes up for the <i>yod</i> which is missing in <i>ishah</i> (woman).</i> However, it is possible that <i>ishah</i> (woman) receives a <i>dagesh</i> to distinguish it from <i>ishah</i> (her husband) for at times the <i>dagesh</i> in the suffixed pronominal <i>heh</i> in <i>ishah</i> (her husband)<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">When the pronominal <i>heh</i> is sounded there is no doubt that the speaker intends to say <i>her husband</i>.</i> is not pronounced. The plural <i>nashim</i> (women) is derived from the words <i>enosh</i> (man) and <i>anashim</i> (men).<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">The feminine plural is formed by adding a <i>vav</i> and a <i>tav</i> to the singular. However, the word for women (<i>nashim</i>) is not formed in this manner. It is not the word for woman (<i>ishah</i>) plus the plural ending, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>
[SHALL BE CALLED.] This refers to the name of the woman.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads, <i>yikkare ishah</i>. <i>Yikkare</i> (shall be called) is masculine and cannot refer to the woman. It refers to <i>shem</i> (name) which is masculine.</i>
[SHE WAS TAKEN.] The <i>dagesh</i> is omitted in the <i>kof</i> of <i>lukachah</i> (she was taken) in order to simplify its enunciation. This word is a <i>pu’al</i> conjugation even though we do not find it conjugated in the <i>pi’el</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pu’al</i> is the passive of <i>pi’el</i>. Thus if we find a word in the <i>pu’al</i> we would expect to find it in the <i>pi’el</i>. However, the root <i>lamed, kof, chet</i> is not found in the <i>pi’el</i>, hence I.E.’s comment. According to Hebrew grammer a <i>dagesh</i> is placed in the second radical of a <i>pu’al</i>.</i>
[AND THEY SHALL BE ONE FLESH.] This means they shall live together as if they were one flesh, or let them once again be one flesh.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Man and woman were originally one flesh.</i> Some say they will be one flesh through the child they will produce. However, this interpretation is farfetched.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Animals also produce offspring, yet they are not said to be “one flesh.”</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25

NAKED. <i>Arummim</i> (naked) is an adjective. <i>And stripped the naked</i> (arummim) <i>of their clothing</i> (Job 22:6) is similar. Some say that <i>arum</i> (prudent) in <i>A prudent man</i> (arum) <i>seeth the evil and hideth himself</i> (Prov. 22:3) has essentially the same meaning. What the verse means is that the mind of the wise is uncovered (<i>arum</i>) and open to everything like the eye.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, a wise man is called <i>arum</i> because his mind is open (naked) to everything (Weiser).</i>
AND WERE NOT ASHAMED. <i>Yitboshashu</i> (ashamed) is related to the word <i>boshet</i> (shame). It is an <i>ayin</i>, <i>vav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">The root of the word is <i>bet, vav, shin</i>.</i> The last letter of the root is doubled.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The last letter of an <i>ayin, vav</i> root is doubled when conjugated in the <i>hitpa’el</i>.</i> It is like the verb <i>yitbonen</i> (he will consider) (Job 11:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>bet, yod, nun</i>. The <i>nun</i> is doubled.</i> A <i>kamatz</i> is placed beneath the first <i>shin</i> because the word ends a verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">The first <i>shin</i> is usually vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>, viz., <i>yitbosheshu</i>.</i>

Chapter 3



Verse 1

NOW THE SERPENT. Some say that the woman understood and knew the language of the animals. They interpret <i>And the serpent said</i> as meaning, that the serpent spoke through signs.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the serpent did not actually speak. He conveyed his intentions through signs; i.e., he went to the tree and pantomimed the eating of the fruit thereof.</i> Others say that the serpent was in reality Satan.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Satan took the form of the serpent.</i> Now why don’t they look at what Scripture states at the close of this chapter (v. 14 and 15)? How is Satan to crawl upon his belly or eat the dust of the ground?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Satan is incorporeal and consequently cannot crawl on the ground or eat dust.</i> Furthermore, what meaning is there to the curse <i>they shall bruise thy head</i> if the reference is to Satan?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Man does not bruise Satan’s head. Hence the reference must be to a real serpent.</i> Many err and inquire why the serpent was cursed. They ask, was the serpent fully intelligent?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">God would not punish a dumb animal.</i> Was he commanded by God to refrain from beguiling the woman?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">There is a Rabbinic dictum, “One who is not warned is not punished.”</i> Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says since we know that only humans are intelligent and capable of speaking, we must conclude that neither the serpent nor Balaam’s ass spoke. He argues that in reality an angel spoke for them.
