However, Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni took issue with him.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni held that the serpent actually spoke. Some editions read: “with them,” i.e., with Saadiah and the others who do not interpret that the serpent actually spoke.</i> On the other hand, Rabbi Solomon ibn Gabirol, the great Spanish scholar and poet who wrote metered verse, arose and disagreed with Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni. It appears to me that we are to interpret the account of the serpent literally. The serpent spoke and walked in an upright position. The One who gave intelligence to man also gave it to the serpent. Scripture itself bears witness that the serpent, although not as intelligent as man, <i>was more subtle</i> (arum) <i>than any beast of the field</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1. Hence the serpent was responsible for his actions.</i> The meaning of <i>arum</i> (subtle) is wise, i.e., one who conducts his affairs intelligently. Now do not be surprised that Scripture uses the term <i>arum</i> (subtle, in v. 1) after <i>arummim</i> (naked in Gen. 2:25) when each of these words has a different meaning. Scripture is being poetic. Similarly, <i>With the jawbone of an ass</i> (ha-chamor), <i>heaps upon heaps</i> (chamor chamoratayim) (Judges 15:16), and <i>on thirty ass colts</i> (ayarim), <i>and they had thirty cities</i> (ayarim) (Jud. 10:4). Furthermore, if an angel spoke via the mouth of the serpent, then the serpent did not sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Why, then, was the serpent punished? I.E. now offers arguments against Saadiah’s interpretation.</i> This angel could not be God’s messenger.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">God would not send an angel to induce Adam and Eve to sin.</i> Neither does an angel rebel against God.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The angel would not beguile the woman on his own accord, for angels do not rebel against God.</i> Those who ask, how did the serpent find the woman,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">There were no animals in the garden. See I.E.’s comment on 2:15.</i> are not asking a valid question.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The serpent may have encountered the woman at the gate of the garden and engaged her in conversation there (Krinsky), or she may have left the garden briefly and met the serpent outside.</i>
The use of the term <i>af ki</i> (yea) shows that the serpent spoke other things to the woman and that at the end of his conversation with her said, “yea much more so (<i>af ki</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. argues that <i>af ki</i> (yea) is a technical term used in a <i>kal ve-chomer</i>, an argument from a minor to a major premise. Cf. Job 25:6. Hence a conversation had to precede this final point. See Rashi.</i> now that God said: <i>Ye shall not eat of any tree of the garden</i> (v. 1).”The serpent did not mention the revered and feared name of God<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton. The serpent employed Elohim when referring to God.</i> because he did not know it. The woman also added to God’s commandment, <i>neither shall ye touch it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">God said, <i>thou shalt not eat of it</i>, (Gen. 2:17). The woman said, <i>God hath said: Ye shall not eat of it, neither shall ye touch it, lest ye die</i>.</i> The wife of Manoah did the same when she quoted the angel as saying, <i>for the child shall be a Nazirite unto God from the womb to the day of his death</i> (Jud. 13:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The angel had told her: <i>For the child shall be a Nazirite unto God from the womb</i> (Jud. 13:5). He did not mention <i>to the day of his death</i>.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

AND YE SHALL BE AS GOD. As angels.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 1:1.</i>

Verse 6

AND WHEN THE WOMAN SAW. In her heart.
AND THAT THE TREE WAS TO BE DESIRED. Because it had the power to make one wise, and her eyes would “open.”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>lamed</i> of <i>le-haskil</i> has the meaning of because. Therefore <i>le-haskil</i> (to make one wise) is to be interpreted “because it made one wise” (Krinsky). Her eyes would open is to be interpreted metaphorically. See verses 5 and 7.</i>
[UNTO HER HUSBAND WITH HER.] The meaning of <i>with her</i> is that they ate together of the fruit and that she disclosed to him the secret that the serpent had revealed to her. Adam thus did not sin unwittingly and was therefore punished for violating God’s command. Many commentators say that the tree of knowledge was a fig tree. They base their assertion on <i>and they sewed fig-leaves together, and made themselves girdles</i> (v. 7).<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Sanhedrin</i> 70b, <i>By the very thing with which they sinned were they rectified</i>.</i> However, if this interpretation were correct, the Bible would say, “And they sewed leaves of the tree of the knowledge.” Many others say that it was a wheat plant.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berakhot</i> 40a and <i>Sanhedrin</i> 70b.</i> However, in my opinion the two trees in the midst of the garden were unique species not found anywhere else on the face of the earth. One of them, the tree of knowledge, possessed the power to instill sexual desire. Therefore the man and woman covered their nakedness. The meaning of <i>va-yitperu</i> (sewed) is well-known.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">It means sewn.</i> <i>Tafarti</i> in <i>I have sewed</i> (tafarti) <i>sackcloth upon my skin</i> (Job 16:15) is similar. Those who ask where Adam and Eve got a needle (to sew their girdle) emit hot air. Adam and Eve could have used a sharp piece of wood. Upon eating of the tree of knowledge, Adam knew (<i>yada</i>) his wife. <i>Yada</i> (knew) is a euphemism for sexual intercourse. Sexual intercourse is called “knowledge” because sexual desire came from the tree of knowledge. Moreover, a young man begins to have sexual desire at the age at which he begins to “know” good and evil.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the tree that implanted this new knowledge is called “the tree of knowledge of good and evil.”</i>
The <i>tree of life</i> extended life so that by partaking of it man would live for many years. <i>Le-olam</i> (v. 22) does not mean forever. We find this to be the case with the term <i>olam</i> in <i>and he shall serve him for ever</i> (le-olam) (Ex. 21:6),<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Talmud it means until the jubilee. Cf. <i>Kiddushin</i> 15a.</i> and in <i>and there abide for ever</i> (I Sam. 1:22)<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">It can only mean for us as long as he lives. Therefore <i>va-chai le-olam</i> (and live forever, v. 22) is to be rendered, “and he will live for a very long time.”</i> and in many other verses,Some commentators insist that the verse <i>for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die</i> (Gen. 2:17) indicates that man was created immortal and that he became mortal as a punishment for his sin. Many ask, what sin did Adam’s children commit that they were punished with death? Now this is absurd. Man and beast both share a common spirit (life force) through which they live and experience sensations in this world. As animals are destined to die, so must man die. The advantage of man over beast lies in the portion from above (the soul) which man has been granted. A Greek physician has proved beyond a shadow of a doubt that it is impossible for man to live forever.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Galen, <i>Third section of the use of limbs</i> as quoted by Maimonides, <i>Guide to the Perplexed</i>, Part III, Chap. XII. I.E. maintains that man was not originally created immortal.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

AND THEY HEARD THE VOICE OF THE LORD GOD WALKING. They heard the voice of God walking toward evening, at the time of the day when the breeze blows. Scripture employs the term <i>holekh</i> (walking) when referring to a voice as seen in <i>The sound thereof shall go</i> (yelekh) <i>like the serpent’s</i> (Jer. 46:22), and <i>And when the voice of the horn waxed</i> (holekh) <i>louder and louder</i> (Ex. 19:19). However, the Spanish grammarian, Rabbi Jonah ibn Janah, says that this verse is to be interpreted as follows: And they heard the voice of God as man was walking in the garden. He also interprets <i>the day</i> referred to in <i>for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die</i> (Gen. 2:17)<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The problem with this verse is that Adam did not die on the day that he ate of the tree of knowledge.</i> as meaning a thousand years, as the Midrash does.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash states that a day of God is a thousand years. Thus what God was telling Adam was, “If you eat of the tree of knowledge you will die at the end of a thousand years.” Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 19:14.</i> Others say that Adam was created on a Friday and died on a Friday.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Thus he actually did die on the day that he ate of the tree of knowledge.</i> Others say that the meaning of <i>for in the day…thou shalt surely die</i> is that on that day you will incur the death penalty. Still others say that die at times means punishment, as seen in the verse <i>the man that hath done this deserveth to die</i> (II Sam. 12:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The man who took his neighbor’s sheep did not commit a capital crime.</i> Still others say the meaning of this verse is that on the day you eat of this tree you will begin to die. They bring proof from a child.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">A cryptic comment. It is suggested that I.E. draws a parallel to a child who grows to sexual maturity and then begins to decline in physical strength (Krinsky). Filwarg rejects this interpretation by noting that physical decline does not set in with sexual maturity. However, it should be noted that medieval man believed that the emission of semen weakened the body and hastened its decline (see Maimonides, <i>Mishneh Torah, Hilkhot De’ot</i>, Chap. 4). Thus man’s decline sets in with his sexual maturity. Since, according to I.E., man’s sexual maturity came with the eating of the fruit of the tree of knowledge, his decline, too, started at this time.</i> According to my thinking the correct interpretation of this verse is to be found in the words of the Rabbinic sages who said that Adam repented.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Had Adam not repented, he would have died on the day he ate of the tree of knowledge. But he repented and thus was spared.</i> Their interpretation is in keeping with the words of Jeremiah who says, <i>At one instant I may speak concerning a nation…to destroy it, but if that nation turn from their evil.. J repent of the evil that I thought to do unto it</i> (Jer. 18:7, 8).

Verse 9

AND THE LORD GOD CALLED. <i>Where art thou</i> was a means of starting a conversation. Similarly, <i>Where is Abel thy brother</i>? (Gen. 4:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">God thus knew what happened to Abel. Hence <i>Where is Abel thy brother</i> was a means of starting a conversation. Similarly God knew where Adam was, and <i>Where art thou</i> was a means of starting a conversation.</i> Behold, Cain denied his brother’s whereabouts, but God responded, <i>the voice of thy brother’s blood crieth unto Me from the ground</i> (Gen. 4:10).

Verse 10



Verse 11

SHOULDEST NOT. <i>Bilti</i> with a <i>lamed</i> prefixed to it (<i>le-vilti</i>) means “not to.” Without this <i>lamed</i> (<i>bilti</i>) it means “only.”
EAT. <i>Akhol</i> (eat) is an infinitive. It is like <i>shemor</i> (keep) in<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shemor</i> also is an infinitive.</i> <i>in not keeping</i> (shemor) <i>His commandments</i> (Deut. 8:11).

Verse 12

WHOM THOU GAVEST TO BE WITH ME. Thou gavest to me one who gave me the fruit to eat. The word <i>immadi</i> (to be with me) means the same as <i>immi</i> (with me). Its meaning is: to be with me in the garden. However, <i>immadi</i>, in contradistinction to <i>immi</i>, is found only in the first person singular.
AND I DID EAT. The <i>alef</i> of <i>va-okhel</i> (and I did eat) is a first person imperfect prefix. Its vowel (a <i>cholam</i>) takes the place of the <i>alef</i> of the root that has been dropped. The <i>khaf</i> is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> because <i>and I did eat</i> comes at the end of a verse. A <i>vav</i> prefixed to a participle is always vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>, and never with a <i>kamatz</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that <i>va-okhel</i> is a first person perfect and not a participle. I.E. makes this point because a participle is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i> over the first radical and a <i>tzere</i> beneath the second radical. Hence <i>va-okhel</i> at first glance appears to be a participle. I.E. points out that this is not so. As a participle it would not have a <i>vav</i> with a <i>kamatz</i> affixed to it since a connective <i>vav</i> is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>. Since the <i>vav</i> of <i>va-okhel</i> has a <i>kamatz</i> beneath it, it must be a <i>vav</i> conversive, changing <i>okhal</i>, an imperfect, to <i>va-okhal</i>, a perfect. However, because <i>va-okhal</i> comes at the end of a sentence it is vocalized <i>va-okhel</i>.</i>

Verse 13

BEGUILED ME. Persuaded me.

Verse 14

CURSED. The serpent was cursed with a short life.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Just as blessing is an addition of the good (see I.E. on Gen. 2:3), curse is a diminution of the good. According to this interpretation <i>cursed art thou</i> refers to the serpent’s life span.</i> However, the correct interpretation is that the serpent was cursed in manner of locomotion.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">He lost his legs and consequently could no longer walk erect. According to this interpretation <i>cursed art thou</i> refers to the serpent’s means of locomotion.</i>
UPON THY BELLY. <i>Gechonekha</i> (thy belly) means thy chest. We cannot determine if the <i>nun</i> of <i>gakhon</i> (thy belly) is part of the root of this word, as the <i>nun</i> of <i>adon</i> (lord) is, or if it is a paradigm <i>nun</i> like the <i>nun</i> of <i>zadon</i> (insolence).<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zadon</i> (insolence) comes from the root <i>zayin, vav, dalet</i>; therefore the <i>nun</i> of <i>zadon</i> is not part of its root.</i> Those who say that <i>gakhon</i> is so called because of the air that rushes forth from it<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>gimel, vav, chet</i>, meaning to burst forth. They explained Gihon to mean the dashing river, Perat as the river whose waters are fruitful and multiply, and Pishon as the gamboling river.</i> are indulging in homiletics. They similarly explain Gihon (Gen. 2:13). They also say that Pishon (Gen. 2:11) comes from the same root as <i>tafushu</i> (ye gambol) in <i>Because ye gambol</i> (tafushu) <i>as a heifer</i> (Jer. 50:11). Also, they say that Perat (the Euphrates, Gen. 2:14) comes from the same roots as <i>Be fruitful</i> (peru), <i>and multiply</i> (u-revu) (Gen. 1:28). But they are unable to cross the great river, the Chiddeckel (the Tigris) (Gen. 1:28), which stood before them.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">They were unable to derive it from one root.</i> They decided that it is made up of two words, <i>chad</i> (swift) and <i>kal</i> (light), and means the river whose waters are swift and light.

Verse 15

AND I WILL PUT ENMITY…THEY SHALL BRUISE THY HEAD. Her children shall smite thee upon thy head. <i>Yeshufeni</i> (bruise) in <i>He that would break me</i> (yeshufeni) <i>with a tempest</i> (Job 9:17) is similar to <i>yeshufekha</i> (shall bruise thee). Look at what follows and you will see that it is so.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The second part of the verse quoted from Job reads, <i>And multiply my wounds without cause</i>. This proves that the verb <i>yeshufeni</i> means he will bruise me, or smite me. Since <i>yeshufekha</i> and <i>yeshufeni</i> come from one root, they have one meaning. Hence <i>yeshufekha</i> means shall bruise thee.</i> A <i>bet</i> has been omitted from the word <i>rosh</i> (head) in <i>they shall bruise thy head</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads, <i>They shall bruise thee head</i>. With a <i>bet</i> it reads, <i>They shall bruise thee upon the head</i>. The <i>bet</i> is to be supplied by the reader.</i> We find the same in <i>into the house</i> (bet) <i>of the Lord</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The verse should read, <i>be-vet Adonai</i>. However, it reads, <i>bet Adonai</i>.</i> (II Kings 12:17).
HEEL. <i>Ekev</i> means the foot. If the head symbolizes the first, then the heel symbolizes the last. <i>Akevo</i> in <i>their rear</i> (akevo) <i>lying in wait on the west</i> (Josh. 8:13), is similar.

Verse 16

I WILL GREATLY MULTIPLY. <i>Harbah</i> (multiply) is an infinitive.
THY PAIN. The pain a woman suffers when she is deflowered.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 34:12. The Bible speaks of pain and conception rather than conception and pain. Hence the pain spoken of by Scripture precedes the conception.</i>
AND THY TRAVAIL. The <i>nun</i> of <i>ve-heronekh</i> (and thy travail) is not a root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The root of conceive is <i>heh, resh, heh</i>. <i>Herayon</i> refers to pregnancy and childbirth.</i> Pregnancy is considered by our verse to be a punishment because it and childbirth are a burden to women.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Elsewhere in Scripture pregnancy is considered to be a blessing, as seen in the verse <i>Blessings…of the womb</i> (Gen. 49:25).</i>
THY DESIRE. Thy obedience.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Perhaps I.E. understood <i>thy desire</i> to mean your husband’s desire will be your desire. Weiser suggests that the woman’s desire for her husband will be so strong that she will listen to everything that he commands her.</i> This means you will obey whatever your husband commands you for you are under his authority to do his will.

Verse 17

AND UNTO ADAM…CURSED IS THE GROUND. It will not yield much produce.
IN TOIL THOU SHALT EAT OF IT. This is short for thou shalt eat of its produce.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads, <i>thou shalt eat it (the ground)</i>. However, man does not eat the ground. Therefore I.E. says that our verse is abridged (Weiser).</i> <i>And let them be of those that eat at thy table</i> (I Kings 2:7)<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads, <i>and let them be of those who eat thy table</i>. The words “the food of” must be supplied by the reader.</i> is similar.

Verse 18

THORNS ALSO AND THISTLES. <i>Kotz</i> refers to large thorns. <i>Dardar</i> (thistles) are smaller than thorns. Its root is <i>dalet, resh</i> (<i>dar</i>). The other two letters of the word are not root letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">They indicate that the word is a diminutive, i.e., <i>dar</i> a thistle, <i>dardar</i> a small thistle (Filwarg). For alternate interpretations see Weiser. I.E. literally reads, <i>He lives</i> (dar) <i>alone, for his brother is missing</i> (ne’edar).</i>
[IN TOIL.] Thou shalt toil in opening, harrowing and sowing.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Is. 28:24.</i> In addition to this, man will also suffer the sick evil of finding thorns growing amidst the produce of the field.
[THE HERB OF THE FIELD.] Bread. For prior to this, man sustained himself with the fruits of the Garden of Eden.

Verse 19

[IN THE SWEAT OF THY FACE SHALT THOU EAT BREAD]. Unlike the animals, you will have to work at winnowing, grinding, kneading and cooking before you can eat. The meaning of <i>ze’at</i> (sweat of) can be ascertained from Rabbinic sources.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbis often employ the term <i>ze’ah</i> for sweat.</i> It follows the paradigm of <i>shenah</i> (sleep). Its root is <i>yod, zayin, ayin</i>. <i>Ba-yazah</i> in <i>they shall not gird themselves with anything that causeth sweat</i> (ba-yazah) (Ezek. 44:18) is similar. The meaning of the verse is, they shall not come to sweat. We know that man is created out of the four elements. What, then, does Scripture mean by <i>for out of it (dust) was thou taken</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The four elements are: fire, air, water and earth. Why does Scripture only mention dust (earth)? At man’s death his body decomposes into all four elements (Krinsky).</i> The answer is that man’s skeletal frame is created out of earth (dust). Hence the bones are heavy<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Earth is the heaviest element. The Bible refers to the body as bones (Gen. 50:25) because they form man’s frame. Man is said to come from the earth because his bones are created out of dust.</i> and lack sensation. The skeletal frame is the foundation of the body. Look, Scripture states, <i>and the bones came together, bone to its bone</i> (Ezek. 37:7). The bones are like the frame of a house. Thus after the bones came together <i>and, lo, there were sinews upon them, and flesh came up, and skin covered them above</i> (Ezek. 37:8). Similarly Scripture states, <i>and ye shall carry up my bones from hence</i> (Gen. 50:25).

Verse 20

EVE. The <i>yod</i> and <i>vav</i> are interchangeable.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible says that the woman was called <i>Chavvah</i> because she was the mother of all <i>chai</i>. If this is the case then she should have been called <i>chayyah</i>. Thus I.E. points out that the <i>vav</i> and <i>yod</i> interchange and that <i>chayyah</i> and <i>chavvah</i> are one and the same.</i> We thus find <i>hoyah</i> and <i>hoveh</i> interchanged in <i>behold, the hand of the Lord is upon</i> (hoyah) <i>thy cattle</i> (Ex. 9:3), and in <i>and thou wouldest be</i> (hoveh) <i>be their king</i> (Neh. 6:6). The reason she was called Chavvah and not Chayyah is to distinguish her name from the noun meaning animal (<i>chayyah</i>).
THE MOTHER OF ALL LIVING. Humans.

Verse 21

GARMENTS OF SKIN. Some say that Adam and Eve originally consisted of bone and flesh, and God now covered them with skin.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The problem which the commentaries found in this verse is, where did the skins to cover them come from? No animal was yet killed or had died so that its skin would be available for use as material for clothes (Filwarg).</i> Others say <i>garments of skin</i> means garments for their skin.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The garments were not made out of skin. They were garments for their skin. These commentators interpret as if written <i>le-or</i>.</i> Still others say that there exists an animal which has a form similar to that of man, and God commanded that it shed its skin.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the skin. The skin garments thus fitted man perfectly.</i> However, one should in reality not bother to inquire into this matter. We ought to believe that God made garments of skin for Adam and Eve. Who can recount all of God’s mighty acts? Who can tell of all of his wonders? There is no end to God’s greatness.

Verse 22

AND THE LORD GOD SAID…AS ONE OF US. When one (<i>echad</i>) is in the absolute, it has a cantillical note which indicates the foregoing and it is vocalized with a <i>segol</i> beneath the <i>alef</i>. However, when it is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> beneath the <i>alef</i> (<i>achad</i>) it is in the construct. Similarly, <i>As one of</i> (ke-achad) <i>the tribes of Israel</i> (Gen. 49:16). Hence, according to the rules of grammar, the word <i>ke-achad</i> (as one of) cannot have the meaning of as one.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos interpreted <i>ke-achad</i> in this way: “Man has become one on earth.” Cf. Rashi. Man is one on earth as I am one in heaven. I.E. disagrees, for <i>ke-achad</i> is in the construct.</i> Additionally, if <i>ke-achad</i> is in the absolute, then it is meaningless.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>ke-achad</i> is in the absolute, then Scripture reads, man is like one. This is a meaningless statement.</i> Furthermore, if <i>ke-achad</i> is in the absolute, the notes should have connected <i>mi-mennu</i> (of us) to <i>la-da’at</i> (to know).<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Not to <i>ke-achad</i>. A word in the absolute is not connected by a cantillical note to the word that follows. Since <i>ke-achad</i> is connected to <i>mi-mennu</i> it must be in the construct.</i> <i>Mi-mennu</i> is a plural,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos translates <i>mi-mennu</i> as a singular. 
The word <i>mi-mennu</i> can be rendered <i>of us</i> or <i>of him</i>.</i> as in <i>ish mi-mennu</i> (none of us) (Gen. 23:6). I have already explained in <i>The Book of Foundation</i> why the <i>nun</i> of <i>mi-mennu</i> receives a <i>dagesh</i> when in the plural.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>mi-mennu</i> should have been spelled with two <i>nuns</i>. The <i>dagesh</i> makes up for the missing <i>nun</i> (Weiser). I.E. makes this point here because the word <i>mi-mennu</i> has a <i>dagesh</i>. He does not want one to think mistakenly that it is a singular because of this <i>dagesh</i>. See next note.</i> The Babylonian grammarians who do not place a <i>dagesh</i> in it are in error.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The Babylonian grammarians, in contradistinction to the Palestinian grammarians, place a <i>dagesh</i> in <i>mi-mennu</i> when it is singular and omit the <i>dagesh</i> when it is plural. I.E. says that the Palestinians who place a <i>dagesh</i> in both instances are correct.</i> The meaning of the verse (v. 22) is the same as <i>ye shall be as God, knowing good and evil</i> (v. 5).<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Man has become like an angel. See I.E.’s comments on verse 5.</i> On the other hand, God might be saying what was in Adam’s mind.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Adam now thinks that he has become as one of us.</i> The use of the term <i>of us</i> presents no problem. It is similar to <i>Let us make man in our image</i> (Gen. 1:26) and <i>Come, let us go down</i> (Gen. 11:7). God in all these cases is addressing the angels.

Verse 23

THEREFORE THE LORD GOD SENT HIM FORTH. When the word <i>shelach</i> (sent forth) is followed by a <i>mem</i>, it has a negative connotation and means banished, as in <i>cast them out</i> (shalach) of <i>My sight</i> (Jer. 15:1). The great Spanish scholar who interpreted <i>sent him forth</i> in our verse in a positive way, as in <i>and Abraham went with them to bring them</i> (le-shallecham) <i>on the way</i> (Gen. 18:16), and in <i>and he hath sent him away</i> (va-yeshallechehu), <i>and he is gone in peace</i> (II Sam. 3:23), erred. For if he was right then the place Adam was going to was a better place than the Garden of Eden. If this sage should ask, if the meaning of <i>sent him forth</i> is he banished him, then why does Scripture go on to say, <i>So He drove out the man</i> (v. 24)?<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>sent forth</i> means <i>drove out</i>, then Scripture is being redundant.</i> The answer is that when man was driven from the garden (v. 4), God placed the cherubim at the east of the Garden of Eden.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">It does not relate that man was driven out, but rather tells that when man was driven out God did the following. It thus does not repeat verse 24.</i>
[THE CHERUBIM.] Some say that cherubim means like images of youths,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Hagigah</i> 13b. The Talmud says that the Hebrew word <i>keruv</i> is like the Aramaic <i>ke-ravyah, ke</i> (like), <i>ravyah</i> (a child).</i> which is the translation of the Aramaic <i>ke-ravyah</i>. However, I believe that the word is a general term for any image. Ezekiel, who first says that he saw the image of an ox (Ezek. 1:10) and later speaks of a cherub (Ezek. 10:14), refers to one and the same image. The image was not changed from that of an ox to that of a cherub because an ox would be a reminder of the sin of the golden calf, as this sin was not committed in Ezekiel’s day.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hagigah</i> 13b states, “One verse says…<i>and they had the face of an ox</i> (Ezek. 1:10). Elsewhere it is written…<i>the face of a cherub</i> (Ezek. 10:14). Resh Lakish said: Ezekiel entreated concerning it and changed it into a cherub. He said before Him, Lord of the Universe, shall an accuser become an advocate.” I.E. notes that the Talmudic interpretation is not in keeping with the literal meaning of the Bible.</i> When Ezekiel speaks of <i>the</i> cherub (10:14) he has in mind the image he had mentioned previously (the image of an ox in 1:10). Therefore every image of an ox is a cherub, but not every cherub is an image of an ox. Proof of this is that Ezekiel refers to all images that he had seen as cherubim (10:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The image of a man, lion, ox and eagle</i> Our verse speaks of <i>the cherubim</i>, which implies the cherubim known to all, i.e., angels.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The form of the cherubim was known to Biblical man (Krinsky).</i> They had a flaming two-edged sword in their hands. The meaning of <i>which turned every way</i> is that the sword had two edges. Those who say that the flaming sword refers to the sun are incorrect.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Those who put forward this interpretation hold that the phrase refers to the great heat of the sun which guarded the garden (Weiser).</i>

Verse 24

AT THE EAST. <i>Mi-kedem</i> means at the east.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The entrance to the garden was at the east (Weiser).</i> Note, the story of the garden of Eden is to be interpreted literally. There is no doubt that it happened exactly as described in Scripture. Nevertheless, it also has a secret meaning.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">This comment of I.E. is cryptic in the extreme. Our translation follows Weiser’s interpretation. Levine puts this comment of I.E. in the context of the latter’s philosophy. He writes that according to I.E., “wise persons recognize that their mission is to fulfill their soul’s will to return to the heavenly realm. Thus the will of a man controls the future of his soul. The will is not perfectly pure. Although man’s well being is contingent upon his making the correct choices, volition (<i>chefetz</i>, desire) frequently acts contrary to the intellect, due to the paradox of various faculties within man struggling for control. Volition (desire) is animated by the intellectual faculty but it is opposed by lust which originates from the appetitive and sensitive dimensions (Gen. 3:24).” Man’s goal in life is thus to seek “knowledge of God” and to subdue “all interfering passions” (p. 14).</i> It alludes to the following: Intellect (the Garden of Eden)<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Man’s intellect is his Garden of Eden (Kaputa).</i> gave birth to desire (the tree of knowledge). Desire gave birth to man’s actions. It is via his actions that man can elevate himself, for the force that propels his desire is in front of him.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The sexual organs, the source of man’s desire, is in front of man (Weiser). Perhaps what I.E. means by “his desire is in front of him” is that man can control himself.</i> The fig leaves prove this.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">They cover man’s sexual organs.</i> Man’s actions are also called the testing ground, for by them man is tried. Intellect and desire are only potential.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Man’s actions are actual. They show whether man is guided by his desires or by his intellect.</i> The one who understands the secrets of the tree of knowledge will understand the secret of the four rivers that divided into four parts (Gen. 2:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">According to some medieval philosophers, man’s brain is divided into four parts, each governing a different aspect of man’s mental life, i.e., sensation, imagination, judgment and memory. According to Kaputa, I.E. held similar ideas. What he is saying is that all these functions have one source, man’s intellect, his Garden of Eden.</i> This is the secret of the Garden of Eden and the garments of skin.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Man must control his desires.</i> There is also an allusion in all of this to man’s potential immortality (the tree of life). The intelligent will understand that this is the ultimate purpose of man’s life on earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Man is to live a life guided by his intellect so that he will attain immortality.</i>

Chapter 4



Verse 1

AND THE MAN. When Adam realized that he would not live forever he saw the need of perpetuating the human race. Eve concurred and therefore exclaimed, upon giving birth to a child, <i>I have gotten a man with the help of the Lord</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">God wanted the human race to go on. By producing a child Eve was doing God’s will, hence her remark (Krinsky).</i> Eve used the Tetragrammaton, and not the term <i>Elohim</i>, because the Lord’s spirit now rested upon the earth via the human race even as it does on the heavenly bodies.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Man is the only being on earth upon whom the Tetragrammaton rests. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:26 and 2:12. The continuity of the human species insured that God’s spirit would rest upon the earth.</i> The term good<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s comment “the term good” is difficult. According to Krinsky, I.E. refers to Gen. 3:22, “To know good and evil.” Meijler emends <i>millat</i> (term or word) to <i>milleh</i> (filled). This would give: God filled the whole with good.</i> refers to creation as a whole. We thus read, <i>And God saw everything that He had made, and, behold, it was very good</i> (Gen. 1:31). Evil is found only in a part of creation.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">According to Netter, Krinsky, Cherez and Weiser, I.E.’s point is to tell us that good refers only to the species; i.e., the species is eternal; however, the individual must die. Cf. Maimonides, <i>Guide for the Perplexed</i>, Part III, Chap. 10, and I.E.’s introduction to Ecclesiastes. In the latter I.E. maintains that the little evil found in the world is overshadowed by the preponderance of good in creation.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND IN PROCESS OF TIME. That Cain tilled the soil, he brought an offering to the place that he had set aside for his devotions. I disagree with those who say that he brought an offering to his father.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Adam had the status of a high priest, and bringing him a gift was equivalent to bringing an offering to God (Krinsky).</i> There is support for the notion that Cain did not bring his offering from the first of the fruits of the ground in Scripture’s stating that <i>And Abel, he also brought of the firstlings of his flock and of the fat thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture does not mention the same with regard to Cain. Cf. Rashi’s comment on this verse.</i>

Verse 4

AND THE LORD HAD RESPECT. <i>Va-yisha</i> (and he had respect) follows the paradigm of <i>va-yichar</i> (and he was wroth) in <i>And Cain was very wroth</i> (va-yichar).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">They are both shortened forms of the verb. The final <i>heh</i> of the root is dropped and the first root letter is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because it precedes a root letter (Filwarg). See notes to 3:22.</i> <i>Va-yisha</i> means, and he accepted. <i>She’u</i> in <i>Look away</i> (she’u) <i>from me</i> (Is. 22:4) is close in meaning to it. They brought offerings in keeping with the secret meaning of the sacrificial ritual.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comment on Lev. 1:1. Weiser explains that I.E. believed that sacrifices were offered to gain some benefit. Cf. I.E. on Ex. 12:7.</i> It is possible that a fire came down from heaven and consumed Abel’s sacrifice but not Cain’s.I believe that <i>yamim</i> (time) (v. 3) means a full year. Scripture similarly states, <i>for a full year</i> (yamim) <i>shall he have the right of redemption</i> (Lev. 25:29). A year is called <i>yamim</i> (days) because it indicates that the full cycle of days, both long and short, has been completed. <i>From year to year</i> (mi-yamim yamimah) (Ex. 13:10) is similar. The meaning of <i>shenatayim yamim</i> (two full years) (Gen. 41:1) is two complete years from day to day. Had Scripture read <i>shenatayim</i> (two years), then it would possibly not have meant two full years from day to day.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">It could have meant close to two years, two years being a round number.</i> Similarly <i>ad chodesh yamim</i> (but a whole month) (Num. 11:20) refers to a complete cycle of the moon. I therefore maintain that when the prophet Daniel prophesied <i>a thousand, two hundred and ninety days</i> (yamim) (Dan. 12:11), he meant days and not years. I say this because the days (<i>yamim</i>) are enumerated.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">When the word <i>yamim</i> stands by itself, it means a complete year (all the days). When numbers are given it refers to days. Otherwise one could not know whether <i>sheloshah yamim</i> means three years or three days (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

SHALL IT NOT. Many commentators explain <i>se’et</i> (be lifted up) to mean thy sins will be forgiven.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Se’et</i> means forgiveness as in <i>noseh avon</i> (forgiving iniquity) (Ex. 34:7). Cf. Onkelos and Kimchi.</i> However, it appears to me that <i>se’et</i> means thy face will be lifted up. For it is previously written, <i>and his countenance fell</i> (v. 5). <i>And his countenance fell</i> indicates shame, as in <i>how then should I hold up my face</i> (esah panai) (II Sam. 2:22).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Which shows that one who is ashamed cannot hold his face up.</i> The meaning of our verse is: if you will do good, then you will lift up your face. <i>Surely then shalt thou lift up thy face</i> (tissa fanekha) <i>without spot</i> (Job 11:15) is similar.
SIN COUCHETH. Some say that <i>chattat</i> (sin) is used here in place of <i>avon</i> (iniquity).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture writes, <i>Sin coucheth</i> (chattat rovetz). The problem is that sin is a feminine noun and <i>rovetz</i> is a masculine verb. The phrase should read <i>chattat rovetzet</i>, hence the comment that <i>chattat</i> has been substituted for <i>avon</i>. They mean the same thing (Krinsky). The printed texts have <i>chet</i>. However, the Bible has <i>chattat, Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 has <i>chattat</i>, and we have followed suit.</i> There are also those who explain this clause to mean that thy iniquity (sin) will couch over thy grave at the day of judgment. They further explain the pronominal suffix of <i>teshukato</i> (its desire) as referring to Abel. Its meaning is, why are you wroth that I accepted Abel’s sacrifice since he is obligated to obey thee (<i>ve-elekha teshukato</i>), and thou art a ruler over him?<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains <i>teshukah</i> as meaning obedience. See his comment on Gen. 3:16. Cain was a “ruler” over Abel because he was the older brother. One cannot explain <i>and unto thee is its desire</i> as referring to iniquity since iniquity is not a person.</i> Others say that the pronominal suffix of <i>teshukato</i> (its desire) refers to the impulse (<i>yetzer</i>) even though this impulse (<i>yetzer</i>) is not mentioned in this verse. These commentators explain <i>sin coucheth at the door</i> as meaning that your sin lies in wait at the door of your house and is always with you. Others interpret door (<i>petach</i>) as referring to the door of the mouth, as in <i>Keep the doors</i> (pitche) <i>of thy mouth</i> (Micah 7:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Man can sin even with his mouth (Filwarg).</i> However, in my opinion the word <i>chattat</i> (sin) in <i>sin coucheth at the door</i> is in the construct, and it is the impulse of man’s heart that “coucheth” with him.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chattat</i> is in the construct with <i>yetzer</i> (impulse). However, the word <i>yetzer</i> is not in the text and has to be supplied by the reader. In other words, <i>chattat</i> is short for <i>chattat ha-yetzer</i>. This eliminates the problem of a feminine noun (<i>chattat</i>) having a masculine verb (<i>rovetz</i>). The clause should thus be understood: the sin of the impulse of your heart coucheth at the door; that is, it is always with you.</i>
AND UNTO THEE IS ITS DESIRE. If you will it, then your impulse (<i>yetzer</i>) will obey you.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains <i>teshukah</i> (desire) as obedience (see note 14). Hence <i>its desire</i> means its obedience, the “it” referring to <i>yetzer</i> (impulse).</i> Additionally, you have the power to rule over it.

Verse 8

AND CAIN SPOKE. It appears to me that Cain related to Abel the full account of the rebuke with which God had reproached him. Those born on a dark day ask, how did Cain kill Abel since no swords were yet in existence? This is a foolish question. He could have choked him or killed him with a stone or a piece of wood inasmuch as there were thousands of stones and chunks of wood around.

Verse 9

[WHERE.] <i>Ay</i>(where) means the same as <i>ayeh</i>. The word <i>ayfo</i> (where) is a combination of two words.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Where (<i>ayeh</i>) and here (<i>poh</i>), i.e., in what place.</i>

Verse 10

CRIETH UNTO ME. <i>Crieth unto Me</i> is not connected to voice of (<i>kol</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">It is connected to <i>thy brother’s blood</i>. <i>Kol</i> (voice) is singular, <i>tzo’akim</i> (crieth out) is a plural; thus <i>tzo’akim</i> cannot refer to <i>kol</i>. It is thus connected to <i>blood of</i>, which is a plural (Krinsky).</i> Similarly in <i>Hark, my beloved</i> (kol dodi)! <i>behold, he cometh</i>, (Cant. 2:8), <i>he cometh</i> is connected to <i>my beloved</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than to voice of (<i>kol</i>). <i>Cometh</i> is connected to <i>my beloved</i> because it is the beloved who leaps and skips, not the voice; the voice neither leaps nor skips (Krinsky). <i>Hinneh zeh ba</i> can be translated as, behold, he cometh, or behold it cometh.</i> as I have pointed out in my commentary on Canticles. The meaning of our verse is: I have heard the cry of your brother’s blood that was poured out upon the ground. However, Onkelos interprets <i>thy brother’s blood</i> as referring to the potential descendants of Abel.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the plural <i>deme</i> (blood of). Cf. Rashi.</i>

Verse 11

AND NOW CURSED ART THOU FROM THE GROUND. Cain, a tiller of the soil, suffered a loss with regard to the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. interprets curse to mean a diminution of the good. See his comment on 3:14.</i> He sowed and planted but the earth no longer yielded fruits or harvest. Cain was forced to wander far from the dwelling place of his father, Adam, who lived close to the Garden of Eden. He was never to find rest in one place but was constantly to be on the move.

Verse 12

[AND A WANDERER.] Some explain <i>nad</i> (wanderer) to mean a mourner, as in <i>to bemoan</i> (la-nud) <i>him</i> (Job 2:11). However, my opinion is that <i>nad</i> is a synonym for <i>na</i> (fugitive). <i>Nedod</i> (wander) in <i>Lo, then would I wander</i> (nedod) <i>far off</i> (Ps. 55:8) is analogous.

Verse 13

[MY PUNISHMENT<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, <i>avoni</i> (my sin).</i> IS GREATER THAN I CAN BEAR.] All the commentaries explain this to mean that Cain confessed his sin. They say that the meaning of <i>neso</i> (bear) is forgiveness, as in <i>forgiving iniquity</i> (noseh avon) (Ex. 34:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">These commentators translate <i>avon</i> literally and render our clause as: my iniquity (<i>avon</i>) is beyond (<i>gadol</i>) forgiveness (<i>mi-neso</i>).</i> However, I disagree. In Hebrew reward is called <i>ekev</i> (heel), and the harsh punishment which comes as a result of iniquity is occasionally referred to as “sin.” Similarly we find, <i>for the iniquity</i> (avon) <i>of the Amorite is not yet full</i><sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The time of their punishment has not arrived.</i> (Gen. 15:16); <i>there shall no punishment</i> (avon) <i>happen to thee</i> (I Sam. 28:10); <i>For the iniquity</i> (avon) <i>of the daughter of my people is greater than the sin of Sodom</i> (Lamentations 4:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>avon</i> (iniquity) should be rendered punishment. The verse thus means: the punishment of my people is severer than the punishment of Sodom (Krinsky).</i> The meaning of our verse thus is: my punishment (<i>avon</i>) is greater than I can bear (<i>mi-neso</i>). The next verse substantiates this interpretation.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Cain in verse 14 complains of his unfortunate plight. This shows that verse 13 is to be similarly interpreted.</i>
<i>Patzetah</i> (v.11) is to be rendered opened. <i>Yiftzeh</i> (doth open) in <i>But Job doth open</i> (yiftzeh) <i>his mouth in vanity</i> (Job 35:16) is similar.

Verse 14

[AND FROM THY FACE SHALL I BE HID.] All the world is full of God’s glory. Nevertheless, there are places more receptive to God’s power, and His might is seen there.

Verse 15

SEVENFOLD. Until seven generations, for <i>shivatayim</i> (sevenfold) does not mean fourteen,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Some render <i>shivatayim</i> as seven multiplied by two. They consider it a dual form like <i>shenatayim</i>, (two years) which is <i>shanah</i> (a year) multiplied by two.</i> nor does it mean three hundred and forty-three.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Some render <i>shivatayim</i> as seven multiplied by seven, multiplied by seven.</i> Proof that <i>shivatayim</i> means sevenfold is that the prophet states, <i>And the light of the sun shall be sevenfold</i> (shivatayim) and then explains his words, viz., <i>as the light of the seven days</i> (Is. 30:26).<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>shivatayim</i> means seven days or seven times as much.</i>
[VENGEANCE SHALL BE TAKEN ON HIM.] The meaning of <i>yukkam</i> (vengeance shall be taken on him) is that vengeance shall be exacted from him. <i>He shall not be punished</i> (yukkam) (Ex. 21:21) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, vengeance shall not be taken on him.</i> The meaning of our verse is that God held back his anger and waited seven generations before punishing Cain.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is to be understood as follows: Cain shall be punished after seven generations.</i> Don’t ask, how could Cain’s life span extend for seven generations? Behold, his brother Seth lived many years with Noah.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Noah was the tenth generation from Adam. Thus Seth lived for more than seven generations.</i> It is also possible that Cain’s descendants are called Cain after their patriarch in the same way that Jews are called Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of the verse being: Cain’s descendants would bear his guilt.</i> Some say that the sign the Lord set for Cain was a horn. Others say God removed fear from Cain’s heart and gave him courage to face the world. It appears to me that God gave Cain a sign that no harm would befall him.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">As he did to Gideon. Cf. Jud. 6.</i> Cain finally believed God because of the sign.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">As Gideon did.</i> Scripture, however, does not tell us what the sign was.

Verse 16

IN THE LAND OF NOD. The land of Nod is so called because it was in that land that Cain was a wanderer and a fugitive.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">See verse 12.</i>
ON THE EAST SIDE OF EDEN. East of Eden and north of the garden.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra held that the inhabited world developed north of Eden. See Chap. II, note 37.</i> 

Verse 17

[ENOCH.] The city was called after Enoch, the son of Cain. Similarly the city of Samaria was called after Shemer (I Kings 16:24) and Egypt (<i>mitzraim</i>) was named for Mitzraim, son of Ham.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 10:6. This is not explicitly stated in Scripture. I.E. assumes that it was so (Weiser).</i> 

Verse 18

Lamech was the seventh generation from Adam and the sixth from Cain.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it was from Lamech’s children that vengeance would be exacted for Abel’s murder.</i> 

Verse 19

[ADAH AND…ZILLAH.] Do not pay attention to Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation of Biblical names. Even if we knew Hebrew perfectly, how would we be able to ascertain the events which they commemorate? If the Bible did not state why Moses was named Moses, or Issaschar, Issaschar, would we be able to surmise the meaning of these names?<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">A literal translation of a Biblical name does not reveal its meaning.</i>

Verse 20

[THE FATHER OF SUCH AS DWELL IN TENTS.] The meaning of <i>avi</i> (father of) is first. The same is true of the word <i>av</i> (father)<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The father (<i>av</i>) is first, i.e., is born before his son.</i> and the word (<i>aviv</i>) (spring).<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The first fruits appear in <i>aviv</i> (spring).</i> When the word for father is in the construct it always has a <i>yod</i> suffixed to it. The same is true with the word for brother.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Singulars in the construct usually do not have a <i>yod</i> suffixed to them, hence I.E.’s comment that father of is <i>avi</i>, brother of is <i>achi</i>.</i>

Verse 21

THE HARP AND PIPE. Harp and pipe (<i>kinnor ve-ugav</i>) are types of musical instruments. The ability to play these instruments requires great wisdom.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The ancients considered music not only a skill but a wisdom, or what we would call an art.</i>

Verse 22

THE FORGER. <i>Lotesh</i> (the forger) means the sharpener. <i>Li-litosh</i> in <i>to sharpen</i> (li-litosh) <i>every man his plowshare</i> (I Sam. 13:20) is similar.

Verse 23

[AND LAMECH SAID…] Note, this <sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 23 and 24. The reason is that I.E. understands verses 23 and 24 to be an attempt by Lamech to induce his wives to cohabit with him. However, verses 20 through 22 tell us that they in fact did so. Hence verses 23 and 24 must describe what happened before verses 20-22. Its meaning is that Lamech had already said to Adah and Zillah. <i>Va-yomer</i> is thus a pluperfect (Krinsky).</i> should have appeared earlier. I have already noted two similar examples of this in my earlier comments.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 1:9.</i> Three additional examples are: <i>that the man took a golden ring</i> (Gen. 24:22);<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">This is followed by: <i>and said: Whose daughter art thou</i> (Gen. 24:23). Now, would the servant give a golden ring to the girl before asking her who she was? Therefore Gen. 24:23 must be rendered: And he already said, Whose daughter art thou (Krinsky).</i> <i>And the Lord said unto Moses, say unto the children of Israel: Ye are a stiff-necked people</i> (Ex. 33:5);<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">This is preceded by: <i>And when the people heard these evil tidings</i> (v. 4). However, the evil tidings are reported in verse 5. Thus verse 5 should precede verse 4. Hence the meaning of <i>And when the people heard</i> (v. 4) is: and when the people had heard; i.e., when they heard the following, namely what is reported in the next verse (Meijler).</i> and <i>And I besought the Lord at that time</i> (Deut. 3:23).<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comment on Deut. 3:23. What is reported in this verse took place before Deut. 3:21, viz., <i>And I commanded Joshua</i>, etc. Moses besought God before he commanded Joshua not to fear the kings of Canaan. Hence Deut. 3:23 is to be rendered as <i>And I had besought the Lord</i>. Ibid. I. E.’s commentary.</i> As to our verse, it is to be interpreted as our sages did. The rabbis tell us that Adah and Zillah were afraid to bear children because they feared that their offspring, who were the seventh generation from Cain, would die or be killed as punishment for Cain’s sin. Therefore Lamech said to them, “I am in truth the seventh generation<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">From Cain. However, in truth Lamech lied to them. He was the sixth and not the seventh generation from Cain (Filwarg).</i> and if a man would wound me or a child bruise me, then I would kill them.” <i>I have slain</i> is used in place of <i>I will slay</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Haragti</i> is a perfect.</i> Similar examples are: <i>I will give</i> (natati)<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, I gave.</i> <i>the price of the field</i> (Gen. 23:13), and <i>which I took out</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E., I took (<i>lakachti</i>) means I will take.</i> <i>of the hand of the Amorite</i> (Gen. 48:22). There are many similar instances.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that the Bible occasionally uses a perfect in place of an imperfect.</i> 
Lamech said to his wives, <i>If Cain shall be avenged sevenfold, Truly Lamech seventy and sevenfold</i> because Cain deliberately murdered and he, Lamech, did not.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">If Cain, who committed willful murder, had his punishment deferred for seven generations, I who did not kill anyone shall not be punished for a very long time (Krinsky). Hence you have nothing to fear from having children with me.</i> In other words, Lamech told his wives that the decree upon Cain was annulled. However, the fact of the matter is that Lamech’s children and all his seed perished in the deluge. Thus Cain’s name was wiped out because he murdered his brother.

Verse 24



Verse 25

[INSTEAD OF ABEL.] That is, in place of Abel.

Verse 26

[BEGAN TO CALL.] <i>Huchal</i> (began) belongs to those verbs whose second and third root letters are identical.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>chet, lamed, lamed</i>.</i> If the <i>chet</i> were not a guttural, it would receive a <i>dagesh</i>. <i>Huchal</i> comes from the same root as <i>techil’ah</i> (first). The meaning of the clause <i>then began</i> (huchal) <i>men to call upon the name of the Lord</i> is: then men first started praying. If <i>huchal</i> were derived from <i>chillul</i> (profane),<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi: “<i>Huchal</i> is an expression of profaneness.”</i> then <i>the name of the Lord</i> would follow profane.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>huchal</i> means to profane, the verse reads as follows: then was it profaned to call the name of God. An impossible sentence. If <i>huchal</i> means profaned, the verse should read: then was God’s name profaned.</i>

Chapter 5



Verse 1

THIS IS THE BOOK OF THE GENERATIONS OF ADAM. The children and grandchildren that he begot.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Toledot</i> (generations) comes from the root <i>yod, lamed, dalet</i>. In the <i>hifil</i> it means to give birth to.</i> Adam and only Adam had no human parents, for he was created by God in the likeness of God.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that <i>in the likeness of God made He him</i> (Adam) indicates that in contrast to his descendants Adam had no human parents but was created directly by God.</i> 

Verse 2



Verse 3

Scripture notes that Adam <i>begat a son in his own likeness, after his image</i> (v. 3)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">All living creatures produce offspring that resemble them. Therefore, why mention that Adam produced offspring resembling him?</i> to teach us that God implanted in Adam the power to reproduce his God like image so that his work would be like that of God.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The image and likeness spoken of in the verse refer not to man’s physical image but to his God-like image. The Bible notes that Adam, like God, was able to produce children in the image of God.</i> Scripture does not say the same with regard to Cain and Abel, nor does it state how long Cain lived or how old Cain was when he begot his son Enoch. It omits the above clause because the former was murdered and the latter’s descendants perished in the deluge.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The lines of both Cain and Abel were wiped out. But the Bible notes these things with regard to Seth because Noah was descended from him.</i> The Torah tells the story of the murderer Cain to stress God’s righteousness. God was long-suffering with Cain but he ultimately punished him. This is in keeping with <i>and that (God) will by no means clear the guilty</i> (Ex. 34:7).

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

ENOCH. Son of Jared. Scripture says about Enoch, <i>And Enoch walked with God</i>. The meaning of this is the same as the meaning of <i>After the Lord your God shall ye walk</i> (Deut. 13:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Live righteously. Similarly Enoch lived righteously.</i> The same thing is stated concerning Noah, namely, <i>Noah walked with God</i> (Gen. 6:9). Others say that <i>Noah walked with God</i> means he trained himself to walk with God.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Walked (<i>hithal’ekh</i>) is in the <i>hitpa’el</i>. The latter is a reflexive; thus <i>hithal’ekh</i> means he made himself walk; i.e., he trained himself to walk. These commentaries say the same with regard to Enoch (I.E.’s fragmentary commentary on Genesis).</i>

Verse 23



Verse 24

AND HE WAS NOT; FOR GOD TOOK HIM. That is, he died. So, too, <i>take, I beseech Thee, my life from me</i> (Jonah 4:3). Scripture similarly states, <i>I take away from thee the desire of thine eyes</i> (Ezek. 24:16) and then explains its meaning, namely, his wife died (Ezek. 24:18). The Bible does not state with regard to Enoch’s being taken that Enoch died, nor is there any reference to a plague causing his death. The meaning of <i>took him</i> in our verse is similar to <i>take me</i> in the psalm of Asaph, <i>And afterward take me with glory</i> (Ps. 73:24), and <i>He shall take me</i>, in the psalm of the sons of Korach, <i>But God will redeem my soul from the power of the netherworld; For He shall take me</i> (Ps. 49:16). The intelligent will understand this.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">God gave immortality to Enoch. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Ps. 49:16: “taking…refers to the union of the soul of the pious with the heavenly beings who are incorporeal and immortal.”</i>

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

[THIS SAME SHALL COMFORT US.] Lamech was informed by Adam, who was a prophet, that through his newborn child the land would live. Or perhaps they learned the aforementioned through astrology. And so it was, for it was through Noah that the world was preserved. Furthermore, Noah was, as the Bible explicitly states, an expert in agriculture (Gen. 9:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">This is I.E.’s explanation of <i>ish ha’adamah</i> (a husbandman). Cf. his comments on Gen. 9:20. Krinsky explains that Noah introduced agricultural implements and other advances in working the soil. This is an additional example of Noah giving “life” to the land</i> It is also possible that he got this name after<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">He originally had another name.</i> his agricultural successes. We find the same with Jerubbaal.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">His original name was Gideon but he was subsequently called Jerubbaal after breaking the alter of Baal (Jud. 6:32).</i> Noah (rest) is the opposite of toil (<i>etzavon</i>). The meaning of our verse is, this one will comfort us and we will rest (<i>nanu’ach</i>) from the toil of our hands. Moreover, comfort is a relaxation of the heart’s pain.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible tells us that Noah was so called because Lamech said, <i>This one should comfort us</i>. However, if this was the case he should have named his son Menachem or Nahum which comes from the root <i>nun, chet, mem</i>, meaning to comfort. Noah comes from the root <i>nun, vav, chet</i>, meaning rest, hence I.E.’s comment that he was called Noah because comfort and rest are related.</i> The Hebrews are more concerned with the idea expressed by a word than with its etymology. Proof of the above is the fact that Jerubbaal is referred to as Jerubbesheth.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Gideon was called Jerubbaal, meaning “Let Baal contend against him” (Jud. 6:32). In II Sam. 11:21 he is called Jerubbesheth. <i>Boshet</i> is Hebrew for shame. This was an undignified way of referring to Baal. Nevertheless, Jerubbaal and Jerubbesheth express the same idea. In the same way Noah expresses the same idea as Menachem.</i> Those who ask whom Cain and Seth married raise a worthless question. Scripture tells us that Adam begot sons and daughters. The same is true of all of them.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The antediluvian patriarchs prior to Lamech all married their sisters.</i>

Chapter 6



Verse 1

[BEGAN.] <i>Hechel</i> (began) is a <i>hifil</i>. It is a denominative of <i>techillah</i> (beginning).
TO MULTIPLY. <i>La-rov</i> (to multiply) is an infinitive.

Verse 2

THE SONS OF GOD. The term <i>bene Elohim</i> (the sons of god) refers to the sons of the judges who dispensed God’s (<i>Elohim</i>) justice.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 1:1.</i> Others say that <i>Elohim</i> refers to God Himself and the sons of God are holy ones (saints) living on earth. They are called <i>sons of God</i> in the sense of <i>Ye are the children of the Lord your God</i> (Deut. 14:1). Others say that <i>the sons of God</i> refers to the children of Seth<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Concerning whom it is written that he was created in God’s image. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 5:1.</i> and that <i>the daughters of man</i> refers to women of Cain’s family.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Concerning whom it was not written that he was created in the image of God. See previous note.</i> However, it appears to me that <i>the sons of God</i> refers to those who know the will of the most High. These men chose women who matched them astrologically and physically. Hence they produced mighty men. It is possible that they took women even against their will.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And they took them wives</i> implies they took women against their will. If, according to astrology, a given women was fit for a man, he took her even against her will (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 3

MY SPIRIT SHALL NOT ABIDE. Some say that <i>yadon</i> (shall abide) is like the word <i>nedanah</i> (sheath thereof), as in <i>and he put up his sword back into the sheath thereof</i> (nedanah) (I Chron. 21:27), for the body serves as a sheath for the spirit.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of the phrase is: my spirit will not forever be in its sheath (the human body); i.e., man will die (Kimchi).</i> Proof of this is found in <i>my spirit was pained in the midst of my body</i> (nidneh) (Dan. 7:15). Nevertheless, <i>nadan</i> and <i>yadon</i> come from different roots.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yadon</i> (shall abide) comes from the root <i>dalet, vav, nun</i>. <i>Nadan</i> comes from the root <i>nun, dalet, nun</i>.</i> We find the same with the words <i>nasah</i> (lifted) and <i>si’o</i> (his excellency). We read, <i>Though his excellency</i> (si’o) <i>mount up to the heavens</i> (Job 20:6). The root of <i>si’o</i> is <i>sin, vav, alef</i>. Nevertheless, a word derived from <i>nasah</i> (lifted) (whose root is <i>nun, sin, alef</i>) would have a similar meaning. There are many examples of this. Others say that <i>yadon</i> follows the paradigm of <i>ve-yashov</i> (returneth), as in <i>And the dust returneth</i> (ve-yashov) <i>to the earth as it was</i> (Eccles. 12:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">An <i>ayin, vav</i> is usually vocalized with a <i>shuruk</i>, as in <i>yakum</i> (he will arise). <i>Yadon</i> is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>. I.E. points out that the same is true with <i>returneth</i>. It, too, is vocalized <i>ve-yashov</i>, rather than <i>ve-yashuv</i>. <i>Ve-yashov</i> comes from the root <i>shin, vav, bet</i>. It, too, is an <i>ayin, vav</i>.</i> They say that <i>yadon</i> comes from the same root as <i>din</i> (to judge) because the spirit judges the body.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Man’s spirit (<i>ru’ach</i>) ultimately determines how man will act. God said that this “judge” will not remain united with the body; i.e., man would die. Krinsky explains it differently. He says the meaning of the verse is: my spirit (the spirit which I placed in man) will not judge man; i.e., man follows his evil inclinations. He acts without discernment. He follows the way of the flesh rather than that of the spirit. It appears that he will continually do so, therefore… Cherez explains, God’s spirit judges man. The meaning of the verse is: my spirit will not judge men forever; i.e., I have decided on their punishment.</i>
FOR THAT HE IS ALSO. In the word <i>be-shaggam</i> (for that also) the <i>shin</i> placed before <i>gam</i> (also) has the same meaning as the <i>shin</i> placed before <i>kakhah</i> (thus).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">It means that. The <i>shin</i> of <i>be-shaggam</i> is a particle of relation, short for <i>asher</i>. In other words, there is no such word as <i>shaggam</i>. I.E. makes this point because the <i>shin</i> which means <i>that</i> is usually vocalized with a <i>segol</i>, while the <i>shin</i> of <i>shaggam</i> is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>.</i> The term <i>My spirit refers to God’s spirit, for man’s spirit comes from God</i>. Similarly, <i>And the spirit returneth unto God who gave it</i> (Eccles. 12:7). The spirit spoken of by Ecclesiastes refers only to the spirit in man. The meaning of the verse is: My spirit shall not abide in man because of his violent ways and because he is (<i>be-shaggem</i>) made of flesh, grows until he achieves maturity, and then due to his sexual activity begins his decline.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky and Weiser. This is the second time I.E. has noted that the man begins his decline with sexual maturity (cf. Gen. 3:8). Perhaps I.E. held to the medieval belief that emission of semen weakens the body.</i>
THEREFORE SHALL HIS DAYS BE A HUNDRED AND TWENTY YEARS. Some explain that this refers to man’s life span.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Henceforth man’s life span will be limited to 120 years.</i> If we find some living longer than this,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Chap. 11 lists the descendants of Noah. All of them lived more than 120 years and were born subsequent to this decree (Cherez).</i> they are but a few. Our verse speaks of most people. However, this interpretation is not correct. Behold, Shem lived for six hundred years. Also, the generations that followed him lived many, many years beyond a hundred and twenty. It was only in the days of Peleg (Gen. 10:25) that the life span was shortened. From the days of King David onward it has been limited to seventy or eighty years. The correct meaning of <i>therefore shall his days be a hundred and twenty years</i> is as Onkelos explained, namely, that God set a time for mankind to repent. We see the same idea in <i>Yet forty days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown</i> (Jonah 3:4). God gave them one hundred and twenty years in which to repent and save themselves, or to remain unrepentant and perish. Scripture’s statement, <i>And Noah was five hundred years old, and Noah begot Shem, Ham and Japheth</i> (Gen. 5:32), should not disturb you,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 5:32 tells us that Noah was 500 years old when he had his children. Gen. 6:3 tells us, according to I.E., that man has 120 years in which to repent. Gen. 7:6 tells us that the flood came in the 600th year of Noah’s life. Thus between the statement in Gen. 6:3 and the flood there is at the very most 100 years (cf. Rashi), hence I.E.’s interpretation that Gen. 6:3 occurred before Gen. 5:32.</i> because the Bible is not in chronological sequence.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, Gen. 6:3 deals with events that came before those dealt with in Gen. 5:32.</i> Note, the Torah states, <i>and Terah died in Haran</i> (Gen. 11:32), then goes on to say, <i>Now the Lord said unto Abram: Get thee out of thy country</i> (Gen. 12:1). However, we know that Terah did not die until Isaac was thirty-five years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Many years after Abraham left his country. Terah, who lived to be 205 years, was 70 when Abraham was born (Gen. 11:26). Abraham was a hundred when Isaac was born (Gen. 21:5). Thus Terah was 170 when Isaac was born, and 205 when Isaac was 35.</i> There are many other similar instances in Scripture.

Verse 4

[THE NEPHILIM.] They were so named because anyone who saw them lost heart at their huge stature.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>nun, feh, lamed</i>, meaning to fall.</i>
[AFTER THAT.] After the flood. Behold, the sons of Anak (Num. 13:33) were originally from the family of <i>the sons of God</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Thus we see that the descendants of the <i>nephilim</i> lived on after the flood.</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6

AND IT REPENTED THE LORD. The Torah spoke in the language of men,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>And it repented</i> is an anthropomorphism.</i> for we know that God is not a man that he should repent. This term is used because if a human being acted in the way God did, destroying his creation, it would be said of him that he repented.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides terms this an attribute of action. Cf. <i>Guide To the Perplexed</i>, Part I, Chap. 52.</i>
[AND IT GRIEVED HIM AT HIS HEART.] This verse is the opposite of <i>Let the Lord rejoice in His works</i> (Ps. 104:31). God is said to be happy when his creatures benefit from his acts of kindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">And is described as being grieved when He must punish them. In other words, happy and sad are anthropomorphisms.</i> Others say that <i>va-yinnachem</i> (and it repented) should be rendered as set a time,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra uses an Arabic term which Krinsky translates as setting a time. This eliminates the anthropomorphism in the verse. However, this interpretation is problematic. For the problems inherent in it see Weiser.</i> as in <i>doth comfort</i> (mitnachem) <i>himself, purposing to kill thee</i> (Gen. 27:42).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Which should be rendered: Esau has set a time to kill you. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 27:42.</i> They also say that <i>His heart</i> does not refer to the heart of God but to the heart of the prophet.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">They felt uncomfortable with a verse that speaks of God’s heart. Hence they interpreted this verse to mean God told the prophet that he wanted to destroy mankind and the prophet was grieved.</i> However, if this were the case Scripture should not have read: and it grieved “at” (<i>el</i>) His heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">It should have read, and it grieved His heart, i.e., His prophet.</i> Secondly, where do we find a prophet called a heart?

Verse 7

AND THE LORD SAID. In His heart, or to the angels; others say, to Noah. However, it appears to me that <i>And the Lord said</i> is connected to <i>His heart</i> of the previous verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. argues that the meaning of <i>And the Lord said</i> is the Lord said in his heart. However, in his heart is missing in this verse, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>

Verse 8

GRACE. <i>Chen</i> (grace) means mercy. From it we get the word <i>techinnah</i> (supplication).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The supplicant seeks mercy. Also, the word <i>techinnah</i> is used in the sense of mercy in Ezra 9:8. Grace usually implies beauty, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> <i>Chen</i> follows the paradigm of <i>ketz</i> (end); both have roots whose second and third letters are the same.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketz</i> (end) comes from a three letter double root (<i>kefulim</i>), <i>kaf, tzadi, tzadi</i>. <i>Chen</i> (grace) similarly comes from a double root, <i>chet, nun, nun</i>. Both <i>ketz</i> and <i>chen</i> drop the final letter of the root.</i> The meaning of <i>found grace (mercy or pity) in the eyes of the Lord</i> is like <i>No eye pitied thee</i> (Ezek. 16:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Finding grace in God’s eyes means that God took pity on a person (Filwarg). I.E. shows that the Bible connects mercy with the eye. The eye is said to take or not to take pity.</i>

Verse 9

THESE ARE THE GENERATIONS. <i>Toledot</i> (generations) means the events that transpired during his lifetime, as in <i>what a day may bring forth</i> (yeled) (Prov. 27:1). <i>These are the generations of Jacob</i> (Gen. 37:2) is similar.
A MAN RIGHTEOUS. In his deeds.
AND WHOLE-HEARTED. In his heart. <i>Tamim</i> (wholehearted) is an adjective. It belongs to those roots whose second and third letters are the same. All three letters of the root remain in this word.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The root of wholehearted is <i>taf, mem, mem</i>. This root gives birth both to <i>tam</i> (wholehearted) and <i>tamim</i> (wholehearted). In the former, a <i>mem</i> is dropped. In the latter, the whole root is found in the word. I.E. employs a pun. He says <i>tamim</i> is <i>tamim</i>. According to I.E. <i>tamim</i> is an adjective modifying man (Filwarg, Krinsky and Cherez).</i>
[IN HIS GENERATIONS.] At the time of the flood, and in the generations after the flood. For Noah lived till the fifty-eighth year of Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Seder Olam</i>, Chap. I. Noah was 600 at the time of the flood. Shem begat Arpachshad two years after the flood. From Arpachshad’s birth to Abraham’s birth was 290 years. Noah lived to be 950. Thus Abraham was 58 when Noah died.</i> Let this be a mnemonic device, our father Abraham was the age of Noah (58)<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">A play on words. <i>Noah</i> (<i>nun, chet</i>) is numerically equivalant to 58. Hence <i>ben Noah</i> means 58 years old. Abraham was the age Noah (58) when Noah died.</i> when Noah died.

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND THE EARTH WAS CORRUPT. The people of the earth were corrupt. Similarly, <i>when a land sinneth against Me</i> (Ezek. 14:13), and <i>And all countries came into Egypt</i> (Gen. 41:57).
[BEFORE GOD.] Some say this means they sinned in public. Others say it means people were privately corrupt with regard to secret affairs so that only God was aware of their sins. In my opinion, the Torah speaks the language of men so that people will understand what is being said. The meaning of <i>before God</i> is that they acted like a servant, who in the presence of his master, disobeys him and thereby shows that he does not fear him. Those who say that <i>Elohim</i> (God) does not refer to the Almighty are speaking nonsense.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">They say that Elohim refers to judges.</i>
VIOLENCE. Theft, oppression and taking women against their will. 

Verse 12
