Our sages are correct in interpreting <i>for all flesh had corrupted their way</i> to mean that all flesh engaged in unnatural and perverted sexual acts. Indeed, how precious is their interpretation to the effect that they corrupted with water<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">An allusion to semen. Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 108b.</i> and were punished by God with water. Just as they placed their waters above and below,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">An allusion to homosexuality (Krinsky).</i> so God punished them by a flood whose waters came from above and below.

Verse 13

AND GOD SAID UNTO NOAH: THE END OF ALL FLESH. All bodies.
[IS COME BEFORE ME.] The time of their calamity has arrived.
WITH THE EARTH. <i>Et ha’aretz</i> (with the earth) means from the earth. Similarly, <i>As soon as I am gone out of the city</i> (et ha’ir) (Ex. 9:29). It may also be rendered, with the earth, as in <i>with Jacob</i> (et Yaakov) <i>every man came with his household</i> (Ex. 1:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Et</i> is usually the sign of the accusative. Thus this clause should be rendered: I will destroy them, the earth. This translation is impossible, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It appears to me that <i>mashchitam</i> (I will destroy them) stands for two words. Similarly, the word <i>God</i> in <i>O God of hosts</i> (Ps. 80:8) and <i>thy throne</i> in <i>thy throne God</i> (Ps. 45:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Gen. 2:19, <i>mosekh atzmo</i>, etc. Ps. 80:8 reads, <i>Elohim Tzeva’ot</i> (literally, God hosts). It should read, <i>Elohe Tzeva’ot</i> (God of hosts). Hence <i>Elohim</i> is to be read as if written twice, <i>Elohim Elohe Tzeva’ot</i> (God, God of hosts). Similarly <i>kisakha Elohim</i> (Ps. 45:7) is ungrammatical. It must be read, <i>kisakhakha kisse Elohim</i> (Thy throne, God’s throne).</i> The meaning of our verse is: And, behold, I will destroy them and destroy the earth.

Verse 14

GOPHER. Gopher is the name of a wood that rides lightly upon the water. It is mentioned nowhere else in Scripture.
ROOMS. So that each animal, cattle and fowl would be alone with its mate.
[ARK.] The Bible uses the term ark and not ship, for it did not have the shape of a ship nor did it have oars.
AND SHALT PITCH IT. Some say that <i>ve-khafarta</i> (and shalt pitch) comes from the same root as <i>kapporet</i> (cover) (Ex. 25:17), the meaning of <i>and shalt pitch it</i> being you shall cover it by coating it. [PITCH.] Some say that <i>kofer</i> is a pitch-like substance. Others say that a certain clay with pitch-like qualities is found in the ground and is to be identified with the <i>kofer</i> in our verse. Others identify it with a substance similarly called in Arabic while noting that in Arabic it is spelled with a <i>kof</i> rather than a <i>caf</i>. In reality, <i>ve-khafarta</i> (and shalt pitch) is a denominative of <i>kofer</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Hebrew has many such verbs. According to I.E., <i>ve-khafarta</i> does not mean to merely cover (as claimed by the earlier opinion who connected it to <i>kappore</i> t) but to cover with <i>kofer</i>, whatever it is.</i>
WITHIN. On the inside.

Verse 15

AND THIS IS HOW THOU SHALT MAKE IT. These are the dimensions which you shall make it. Its height was a tenth of its length, so that it would be able to float on the water and not be overturned by the wind.

Verse 16

A LIGHT. <i>Tzohar</i> (a light) means an opening through which light would enter. It comes from the same root as <i>tzohorayim</i> (noon).<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The time of the day when light is at its fullest.</i> The opening was made in the usual place, on top of the ark.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Hence Scripture does not tell us where it was placed.</i> Scripture tells us that the top of the ark was a cubit in length.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>and to a cubit shalt thou finish it upward</i> applies to the top of the roof of the ark. See Rashi.</i> We gather from this that it was a sixth of a cubit wide.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The width of the ark was one-sixth the length.</i> The ark was triangular in shape.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">According to Luzzato, this applies only to the roof of the ark. See Luzzato’s commentary on the Pentateuch, p. 42. However, a literal reading of I.E. does not support this view.</i> Its top came to a point, and so did its corners. Therefore it did not overturn. The door was on one side<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Unlike other ships which are entered through the deck (Krinsky).</i> and was reached by climbing a ladder.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The door was on the third top of the ark (Krinsky).</i> Now, we know that the ark was very large.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it was able to contain representatives of all species.</i> Furthermore, it is possible that Noah was much taller than we, for the cubits mentioned with regard to the ark are Noah’s cubits.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">A cubit is the span from shoulder to fingertips. Since Noah was taller than we, his cubits were longer. The ark was thus even larger than a superficial reading of Scripture indicates.</i> It is also possible, since the ark was divided into three stories, that the bottom story was ten cubits high.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">And similarly each of the other two stories (Weiser).</i> Some say that the ark had many stories and that Scripture abridged the number.
LOWER, SECOND AND THIRD. These are all adjectives. Those who ask why <i>shelishim</i> (third) is not written <i>selishiyyim</i> have eyes but do not see.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tachtiyyim</i> (lower) and <i>sheniyyim</i> (second) are written with a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>yod</i>; <i>shelishim</i> is not. The question arises, why not? The <i>dagesh forte</i> doubles the letter.</i> Can’t they see that forgiving, archer and thief are adjectives,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sallach</i> (forgiving), <i>kashat</i> (archer) and <i>gannav</i> (thief) follow the paradigm of <i>pattach, kamatz</i>. For a comment on I.E.’s grammatical usage, see Chap. 1, note 33.</i> as are prince, deputy, pious,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nagid</i> (prince), <i>pakid</i> (deputy) and <i>chasid</i> (pious) follow the paradigm of <i>kamatz, chirik</i>.</i> wise<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chacham</i> (wise) follows the paradigm of <i>kamatz, kamatz</i>.</i> and understanding?<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Navon</i> (understanding) follows the paradigm of <i>kamatz, cholam</i>.</i> Nevertheless, each of these words is vocalized according to its own pattern and form. <i>Shelishim</i> (third) follows the paradigm of <i>negidim</i> (princes) and <i>chasidim</i> (pious). This is so because the singular of <i>shelishim</i> is <i>shalish</i>, as the singular of <i>chasidim</i> is <i>chasid</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>shalish</i> belongs to the same group as <i>chasid</i> and <i>nagid</i> and its plural takes their form. Hence <i>shalish</i> follows a different paradigm than does <i>tachat</i> and <i>sheni</i> and this is why it does not have a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>yod</i>.</i> It is also possible that the <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>yod</i> of <i>sheniyyim</i> (second) also<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">See above note 48.</i> applies to the <i>yod</i> of <i>shelishim</i> (third).<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">It now has a <i>dagesh</i>. It is thus to be pronounced <i>shelishiyyim</i>.</i> Perhaps this will satisfy those who raised the question.

Verse 17

AND I. Some say that the <i>dagesh</i> in <i>mabbul</i> (flood) is in place of a missing <i>nun</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>mabbul</i> is <i>nun, bet, lamed</i>. The <i>nun</i> is thus missing.</i> as in the word <i>mabbua</i> (fountain).<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>mabbu’a</i> (fountain) is <i>nun, bet, ayn</i>. The <i>dagesh</i> is in place of the missing <i>nun</i>.</i> They note that the word <i>mabbul</i> comes from the same root as <i>navelah</i> (fadeth)<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Naval</i> means to fade, wither or fall. According to this, <i>mabbul</i> comes from the root <i>nun, bet, lamed</i> and means a destruction.</i> in <i>The earth fainteth and fadeth</i> (navelah) <i>away</i> (Is. 24:4). Others say that <i>mabbul</i> comes from the same root as <i>balul</i> (mingled) in <i>mingled</i> (belulah) <i>with oil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In other words the root of flood is <i>bet, lamed, lamed</i>. The word <i>mabbul</i> thus means a mixing or confounding.</i> and that it should have followed the paradigm of <i>maslul</i> (highway) (Is. 35:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>maslul</i> (highway) is <i>samekh, lamed, lamed</i>. Similarly the word for flood should be <i>mavlul</i>.</i> The word <i>massor</i> (saw) (Is. 10:15)<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Which comes from the root <i>sin, resh, resh</i> (cf. Is. 15:10) and does not follow the paradigm of <i>maslul</i>. Hence <i>mabbul</i> is similar to <i>massor</i> (Cherez). For alternate interpretations see Weiser and Krinsky.</i> with a <i>shuruk</i> and a <i>cholam</i><sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>mabbul</i> and <i>massor</i> are alike then both should be vocalized either with a <i>cholam</i> or a <i>shuruk</i>.</i> interchanging is analogous.
[THE FLOOD OF WATERS.] This is an abridged phrase. It should be read as follows: The flood, a flood of waters.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads <i>ha-mabbul mayim</i>. <i>Ha-mabbul</i> cannot be in the construct with waters because a word with a definite article cannot be in the construct, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> Similarly the meaning of <i>since the day it was founded</i> (Ex. 9:18) is: since the day, the day it was founded.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, <i>ha-yom</i> (the day), which has a definite article, cannot be in the construct with <i>hivvasedah</i> (it was founded).</i>

Verse 18

BUT I WILL ESTABLISH MY COVENANT. This indicates, although not previously mentioned, that God had sworn earlier to Noah that he and his children would not die in the flood.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>But I will establish my covenant</i> means I will keep my promise. Hence a promise was already made.</i> We find a similar instance in Deuteronomy, viz., <i>Let us send men before us, that they may search the land for us</i> (Deut. 1:22).<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Of Scripture omitting a fact and then mentioning it later, see Num. 13:2.</i> <i>But I will establish</i> means I will keep my oath. However, it appears to me that the covenant alludes to the covenant that would be made at the time God set the rainbow in the sky.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">In contradistinction to what I.E. had just noted, he now suggests that the covenant does not refer to a previous covenant but to one yet to be made.</i> Covenant means an agreement and a thing which two sides choose. It comes from the same root as <i>beru</i> (choose) in <i>choose</i> (beru) <i>you a man for you</i> (I Sam. 17:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Brit</i> (covenant) comes from the root <i>bet, resh, resh</i>, meaning to choose.</i> The word for covenant (<i>brit</i>) has this form and vocalization both in the absolute and in the construct. We find the same thing with the word <i>shevit</i> (captivity). We thus read, <i>Thou hast turned the captivity of Jacob</i> (shevit Yaakov) (Ps. 85:2), and <i>And his daughters into captivity</i> (ba-shevit) (Num. 21:29). Others say that a <i>brit</i> (covenant) is a cut boundary.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>brit</i> is an agreement with conditions (boundaries) which cannot be violated. <i>Brit</i> has the letters <i>bet, resh, tav</i>. These letters can be rearranged <i>bet, tav, resh</i>, meaning to cut (see Gen. 15:10) (Weiser). Others say it comes from <i>bara</i> (to cut), the <i>tav</i> taking the place of the <i>ale</i> f (Cherez). According to this opinion <i>brit</i> comes from the word cut and not from choose.</i> 

Verse 19

[TWO OF EVERY SORT.] After stating two, Scripture goes on to explain that this refers to male and female.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Two of every sort</i> can be taken to mean any two of every sort, two males or two females.</i> After stating generally, <i>And of every living thing of all flesh</i>, the Bible then explains that this refers to <i>Of the fowl after their kind, and of the cattle after their kind, of every creeping thing of the ground after its kind</i> (v. 20). This includes<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">A general statement followed by particulars is qualified by the particulars. Thus fish cannot be included in <i>And of every living thing of all flesh</i> because the particulars include only land animals.</i> all animals of the field and all large and small animals that are born via sexual intercourse. It excludes living things not born<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Medieval man believed that certain animals are born through spontaneous generation; i.e., they do not couple. Noah did not have to bring these types of animals to the ark because the verse tells us that that he was to bring <i>male and female</i>, that is, animals that couple.</i> by coupling, and marine animals. Fish are excluded although they are considered “flesh.”<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Since fish are considered “flesh” the command <i>And of every living thing of all flesh</i> would apply to them. However, since the Bible goes on to say, of <i>every creeping thing of the ground</i>, fish are excluded.</i> Proof of this can be seen in the words of Moses: <i>and yet Thou hast said, I will give them flesh, that they may eat a whole month. If flocks and herds be slain for them…or if all the fish of the sea be gathered for them, will they suffice them</i> (Num. 11:21,22).
[SHALT THOU BRING INTO THE ARK.] This is a command to Noah not to desert these creatures but to bring them into the ark with him in order to preserve the seed of each species.

Verse 20

[SHALL COME UNTO THEE.] They will come by themselves. Noah therefore did not have to search for them on islands; neither did he have to hunt for all sorts of fowl. God commanded Noah to prepare food for all the animals in the ark. Foolish ones ask, what did birds of prey eat? What did carnivorous animals such as lions who live on meat eat? Their questions are invalid. One who cannot find meat will eat grass or fruit when hungry. The saying found in Rabbinic literature that there exists a large animal that consumes the grazing of one thousand mountains daily is a good story.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer</i>, Chap. 11. The problem is, where did Noah get food for this beast? I.E. answers that the statement concerning this beast is not to be taken literally.</i> Similarly the tradition concerning a bird that blocks out the sun with its wings has a secret meaning to it and is not to be taken literally.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yikra Rabbah</i>, Chap. 22.</i> God commanded Noah to make the ark many years before the flood. When the flood approached, God the glorious commanded Noah and his family to go to the ark. God the glorious commanded Noah to take seven males and seven females from every clean animal and fowl because they were needed for sacrifices.

Chapter 7



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4

FOR YET SEVEN DAYS. On the seventh day the rain will fall without letup for forty days. The Lord told this to Noah on the tenth day of the second month.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The flood began on the 17th of the second month. Therefore God’s command (to go into the ark) was given to Noah on the 10th, seven days prior to the fall of the rain.</i> At the end of the forty days from the start of the flood the sun returned to its proper place vis-a-vis the moon.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">And the flood ceased. I.E., who believed in astrology, held that the flood came about as a result of an impropitious conjunction of the sun and moon (Weiser).</i> The latter is a secret.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The uninitiated might suspect that I.E. denies divine providence by giving an astrological explanation to the flood (Krinsky).</i>
[LIVING SUBSTANCE.] The word <i>yekum</i> (living substance) is found in the Bible only in our chapter.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">In our verse and in verse 23. Filwarg points out that it is found in Deut. 11:6. Weiser suggests that I.E. means, it is not found having the same meaning as here. Krinsky claims that I.E. simply erred.</i> It is a <i>peh, yod</i> and follows the paradigm of the word <i>keruv</i> (cherub).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>yod, kof, mem</i>, and like the word <i>keruv it</i> is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i> beneath the first letter and a <i>shuruk</i> following the second letter.</i> Others say that <i>yekum</i> is an inverted <i>ayin, vav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>kof, vav, mem</i>. The <i>vav</i> becomes a <i>yod</i> and the <i>yod</i> is placed before the <i>kof</i>. Thus <i>kof, vav, mem</i> equals <i>yod, kof, mem</i>. Hence the <i>ayin vav</i> becomes a <i>peh yod</i> (Weiser).</i> It is like the word <i>yerivai</i> in <i>Strive</i> (riv) <i>O Lord, with them that strive with me</i> (yerivai) (Ps. 35:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The root of strive is <i>resh, vav, bet</i>. The root of <i>yervai</i> appears to be <i>yod, resh, bet</i>. However, it is <i>resh, vav, bet</i> transformed into a <i>peh yod</i>.</i> <i>Living substance</i> is a general term for every living thing that is upon the face of the earth.

Verse 5

AND NOAH DID. As he was commanded. He and his family came to the vicinity of the ark.

Verse 6



Verse 7

BECAUSE OF THE WATERS OF THE FLOOD. Because of fear of the waters of the flood. In these seven days many of the clean animals and fowl came of their own volition to the vicinity of the ark. From the others and from everything that creeps, a pair consisting of a male and female of each kind came to the ark.

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

WERE ALL THE FOUNTAINS OF THE GREAT DEEP BROKEN UP. <i>Mayenot</i> (fountains of) is in the construct. In <i>When there were no fountains</i> (mayanot) (Prov. 8:24), <i>mayanot</i> is in the absolute.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mayenot</i> in our verse has a <i>sheva</i> beneath the <i>yod. Mayanot</i> in Prov. 8:24 has a <i>kamatz</i> beneath the <i>yod</i>.</i>
DEEP. The word <i>tehom</i> (deep) may be either masculine or feminine.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tehom</i> in our verse is in the feminine (<i>tehom rabbah</i>). Elsewhere (Habakkuk 3:10) <i>natan tehom kolo</i> is in the masculine, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> Similarly <i>tehom</i> in <i>The deep</i> (tehom) <i>made it grow</i> (Ezek. 31:4), is in the feminine. The Bible does not mention the streams because their waters come from the fountains. When the fountains of the deep broke up, their waters gushed upward and the windows of the heavenly storehouse of water were opened and their contents poured down upon the earth. The earth was confounded; there was no way of telling day from night. Proof of the latter is God’s promise to Noah after the flood that <i>and day and night shall not cease</i> (Gen. 8:22). When the rain ceased falling from the heavens, Noah knew that forty days and forty nights had passed, for God revealed to him this secret.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">How long it would rain (verse 4).</i>
AND THE WINDOWS OF HEAVEN. The word <i>arubbot</i> (windows) has the same meaning as <i>arubbot</i> (window) in <i>Behold, if the Lord should make windows</i> (arubbot) <i>in heaven</i> (II Kings 7:2). The term window or storehouse (Deut. 28:12) when referring to heaven is in keeping with human language and practice.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See above. Gen. 1:26.</i> Some say that the <i>alef</i> of <i>arubbot</i> (windows) is a root letter<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The root being <i>alef, resh, bet</i>.</i> and that <i>arubbot</i> is similar to <i>kevudot</i> (riches).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Ps. 45:14. That is, it follows a paradigm where the first root letter is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>, in our case a <i>chataf pattach</i> because of the <i>alef</i>, and the second with a <i>shuruk</i> or a <i>kubbutz</i>.</i> Others say that the <i>alef</i> of <i>arubbot</i> is not a root letter. It is similar to the <i>alef</i> in <i>agorat</i> (piece of) (I Sam. 2:36).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Agorat</i> (a piece) comes from the root <i>gimel, resh, resh</i>. The <i>alef</i> is added to the root. Similarly <i>arubbot</i> (windows) comes from the root <i>resh, bet, bet</i>.</i> Both <i>arubbot</i> and <i>agorat</i> come from roots whose last two letters are the same.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See note 14.</i> On the seventeenth day of the second month, the day the flood started, Noah and his family entered the ark. At that time Noah brought into the ark the animals, cattle and the creeping things and fowl. <i>Bird</i> is a general term for a winged creature.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads, all birds (<i>kol tzippor</i>), all wings (<i>kol kanaf</i>). I.E. notes that <i>kol kanaf</i> explains <i>kol tzippor</i>; i.e., a <i>tzippor</i> is a being with a <i>kanaf</i> (Weiser).</i> The great miracle was that they all came two by two of their own volition.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

AND THEY THAT WENT IN, WENT IN MALE AND FEMALE. The meaning of <i>And they that went in</i> is: and they that went into the ark.
[AND THE LORD SHUT HIM IN.] The term <i>shut him in</i> in our verse has a positive connotation. It has to be so interpreted because being shut in at that time was preferable to not being shut in. However, elsewhere it has a negative implication. Thus we read, <i>He shutteth up a man</i> (Job 12:14), and <i>And whom God hath hedged in</i> (Job 3:23). That it has a negative connotation is obvious from the first half of the verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Job 3:23 opens with <i>To a man whose way is hid</i>; similarly Job 12:14 opens with <i>Behold, He breaketh down</i>.</i> Noah closed the door of the ark and God helped him in that no part of the ark cracked open, for had any part opened, then all would have immediately died. Why state, <i>and the flood was forty days upon the earth</i> (v. 17), after having said, <i>And the rain was upon the earth forty days and forty nights</i> (v. 12)? The way to read the verse (v. 17) is as follows: After the flood was forty days upon the earth, <i>the waters increased and bore up the ark, and it was lifted up above the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 does not intend to teach us that there was a flood upon the earth; verse 12 does that. Verse 17 teaches that after 40 days of flood…the ark was lifted up above the earth.</i> This verse shows that for the first forty days the ark did not move.

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

EXCEEDINGLY. The word <i>me’od</i> (exceedingly) is repeated in the text in order to stress that the waters prevailed to their maximum potential. Why state, <i>and the mountains were covered</i> (v. 20), after having said, <i>and all the high mountains that were under the whole heaven were covered</i> (v. 19)? Its meaning is: All the high mountains were covered with water (v. 19), and these mountains were covered by fifteen cubits of water (v. 20).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 should be understood as follows: 15 cubits did the waters prevail, so that the mountains (mentioned in v. 19) were covered (by 15 cubits of water).</i> There are those who maintain that there is a very tall mountain in Greece that the waters did not cover.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky.</i> However, we believe the words of our God and we put aside the foolish nonsense of man.

Verse 20



Verse 21

[AND ALL FLESH PERISHED.] The meaning of <i>And all flesh perished</i> is: and all flesh had perished.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Perished is a pluperfect. All flesh obviously perished before the mountains were covered by 15 cubits of water.</i> There are many such instances in Scripture, such as <i>And I besought the Lord</i> (Deut. 3:23), and the true meaning of <i>And He caused manna to rain upon them for food</i> (Ps. 78:24).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Although <i>va-yamter</i> (and he caused to rain) does not appear to be a pluperfect, it is, (and he had caused to rain). Similarly <i>va-etchannan</i> is to be read: and I had besought it.</i>
[PERISHED.] <i>Va-yigva</i> (perished) means died. I will explain the exact meaning of this term when I comment on <i>And Abraham expired</i> (va-yigva), <i>and died</i> (Gen. 25:8). It is clear<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">From verse 21. I.E.’s point is that <i>ha-romes</i> is a general term. The verse then goes on to enumerate exactly what <i>ha-romes</i> includes.</i> that <i>remes</i> (creeping thing) is a general term that includes fowl, cattle, animals, small thin swarming things and man. It is possible that <i>all in whose nostrils was the breath of the spirit of life</i> (v. 22) refers to <i>every man</i> (v. 21),<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 thus explains only <i>every man</i>, i.e., those who had a <i>neshamat ru’ach chayyim</i>. According to Cherez, this interpretation postulates that <i>remes</i> does not include man.</i> as we do not find the expression <i>neshamah</i> (breath)<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Neshamah</i> is the term for soul.</i> used in reference to any creature except man. Many say that the soul is termed <i>neshamah</i> because it comes from the heaven (<i>shamayim</i>). The fact that <i>shamayim</i> and <i>neshamah</i> have differing roots does not refute the latter interpretation because there are other similar instances.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Neshamah</i> comes from the root <i>nun, shin, mem. Shamayim</i> comes from the root <i>shin, mem, mem</i> (Weiser).</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23

AND THEY WERE BLOTTED OUT. Their names were erased from the earth because they left no descendants. [AND NOAH ONLY WAS LEFT.] Only Noah and those with him were left. This verse proves how wrong are some of our ignorant brethren who maintain that the flood did not cover the entire earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Some say this alludes to those who maintain that a certain high mountain in Greece was not covered by the flood; others, to the Rabbinic sages who said that the land of Israel was not covered by the flood. See <i>Zebahim</i> 113b; <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 33:9. However, Weiser doubts that I.E. would express himself so strongly against the Rabbinic sages. Others say that I.E. directed his barb against those who take the Rabbinic statement literally.</i>

Verse 24

AND THE WATERS PREVAILED UPON THE EARTH A HUNDRED AND FIFTY DAYS. This was so because the fountains were broken up (v. 11) and it rained for a day and stopped for a day for, <i>and I will cause it to rain upon the earth forty days and forty nights</i> (v. 4) means it will rain for a period of forty days and forty nights without letup. That it did in fact also rain after the first forty days were over is evident from <i>and the rain from heaven was restrained</i> (Gen. 8:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The rain was now fully restrained, which implies that prior to this it was only partially restrained.</i>

Chapter 8



Verse 1

AND GOD REMEMBERED NOAH. This includes his children and the women. Noah alone is mentioned because he was the most important of them.
AND EVERY LIVING THING. A general term for beasts of the field, fowl that fly, and for everything that swarms upon the earth.<i>And God remembered</i> means God remembered the oath that he had sworn to Noah.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 6:18.</i>
AND GOD MADE A WIND TO PASS OVER THE EARTH. The wind blew continuously.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Until the earth dried. Cf. Weiser.</i>
AND THE WATERS ASSUAGED. They rested and no longer prevailed. <i>Then was the king’s wrath assuaged</i> (Esther 7:10) is similar. Assuaged in our verse and in Esther is in the <i>kal</i>. However, in our verse the <i>caf</i> receives a <i>dagesh</i> to make up for the missing middle root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>shin, caf, caf</i>. One <i>caf</i> is missing in <i>va-yashokku</i> (assuaged) in our verse, unlike in the Book of Esther, where all three radicals are present in assuaged (<i>shakhakhah</i>).</i>

Verse 2

WERE STOPPED. <i>Va-yissakheru</i> (were stopped) is synonymous with <i>va-yissageru</i> (were closed). Although both of these words mean the same, they come from different roots.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yissakheru</i> comes from the root <i>samekh, caf, resh</i>; <i>va-yissageru</i> comes from the root <i>samekh, gimel, resh</i>.</i> They do not come from one root with the <i>caf</i> and <i>gimel</i> interchanging, for these two letters do not interchange. The only letters that interchange are the <i>yod, heh, vav</i> and <i>alef</i>, and the <i>sin</i> and <i>shin</i>.
AND THE RAIN FROM HEAVEN WAS RESTRAINED. It was restrained in the storehouse of rain.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 7:11.</i>

Verse 3

AND THE WATERS RETURNED. The waters returned at the end of one hundred and fifty days to their reservoirs beneath the earth where they are normally stored. Noah knew that it took one hundred and fifty days for this to happen, for he was a prophet.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">There was no way of telling day from night during the flood. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 7:11.</i> They err who maintain that since Scripture speaks of one hundred and fifty days making up five months,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The 150 days commenced on the 17th of the second month (when the flood started) and lasted till the 17th of the seventh month, a period of five months.</i> it must be referring to solar months, for five solar months come to one hundred and fifty-two days.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Solar months alternate between 30 and 31 days. In a five-month period there must be at least two months of 31 days.</i> Also anyone who maintains that Noah followed a calendar of intercalated<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">That is, lunar months alternating between months of 29 and 30 days. (Cheshvan and Kislev can each have 29 or 30 days. See note 36.)</i> lunar months, with Cheshvan being the second month<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This is the opinion of this commentator. I.E. maintains that Iyyar was the second month. Cf. verse 5.</i> and the year full, misses the mark.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Even if Cheshvan and Kislev had 30 days each, the year being full (<i>shelemah</i>), the number of days in the five lunar months comes to 148. The flood started on the 17th of Cheshvan, the five months end on the 17th of Nisan. They include 13 days in Cheshvan, 30 days in Kislev, 29 days in Tevet, 30 in Shevat, 29 in Adar and 17 in Nisan: a total of 148 days (Krinsky).</i> Why go to all this trouble? Even if the Bible explicitly stated that Noah employed solar months or that he counted the months from Tishri<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Making Chesvan the second month as the previously quoted second opinion held.</i> this would have no effect on Jewish law, for the laws governing the establishment of the seasons were not given by Noah.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">But by Moses. He established the Jewish calendar and taught the Jews to use a lunar calendar and count the months from Nisan.</i> It is also possible to say many things concerning the ark’s coming to rest.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Contra Rashi, verse 4 (Krinsky). Rashi calculates by exactly how much the waters receded each day until the ark finally rested on <i>terra firma</i>. For other interpretations see Weiser, Cherez and Netter.</i> However, such speculations “cannot profit nor deliver, for they are vain” (I Sam. 12:21).

Verse 4



Verse 5

IN THE TENTH MONTH, ON THE FIRST DAY OF THE MONTH, WERE THE TOPS OF THE MOUNTAINS SEEN. Noah established the first day of the month even though he did not see the new moon, for he had not as yet opened the window of the ark.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Hence he could not see the new moon. Kimchi suggests that Noah had instruments by which he determined the date.</i> Noah sent out the raven on the tenth day of Shevat. From that day on the raven continuously went to and fro until Noah left the ark, for Scripture states that <i>it went forth to and fro, until the waters were dried up from off the earth</i>. On the day that the earth dried, Noah and all that were with him left the ark. Seven days after sending the raven, Noah sent the dove. The latter event took place on the seventeenth day of Shevat, which was the tenth month from the start of the flood. Noah observed the quarterly watch.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The month is divided into quarters (watches). At the end of each watch, that day signifies a change in nature and fate (Weiser). Hence Noah waited seven days (a watch) between the raven and the dove; similarly with the dove itself.</i> <i>And he stayed yet other seven days; and again he sent forth the dove</i> (v. 10) is proof of the above.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">That Noah waited seven days before sending the dove the first time (Krinsky).</i> 

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

[AND HE STAYED.] <i>Va-yachel</i> (and he stayed) is, I believe, derived from the word <i>techillah</i> (beginning).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>chet, lamed, lamed</i>. Cf. <i>Targum Yerushalmi, And he began to count</i>.</i> For if it came from the same root as <i>tochelet</i> (hope),<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>yod, chet, lamed</i>. This root connotes waiting with hope, as in <i>la-meyachalim le-chasdo</i> (toward them that wait for His mercy) (Ps. 33:18).</i> it should have been vocalized <i>va-yichel</i>, as is the case with <i>va-yiketz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 9:24.</i> (and he awoke), or vocalized <i>va-yechel</i>, as in the case of <i>va-yeshev</i> (and he dwelt).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The point is, if <i>va-yachel</i> is a <i>peh yod</i> then it would be vocalized like a word of this classification, i.e., like <i>va-yiketz</i> or <i>va-yeshev</i>, both of which are <i>peh yods</i>. The vocalization <i>va-yachel</i> shows that it belongs to the <i>kefulim</i>, those roots whose second and third radicals are identical.</i> However, it is possible it is an irregular verb.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">It comes from the root <i>yod, chet, lamed</i>, meaning to stay, wait with hope, but is vocalized as if it came from the root <i>chet, lamed, lamed</i> (Krinsky).</i>
AND AGAIN HE SENT FORTH THE DOVE OUT OF THE ARK. On the twenty-fourth day of Shevat.

Verse 11

IN HER MOUTH AN OLIVE-LEAF FRESHLY PLUCKED. Some say that Scripture employs two words with one meaning,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Aleh</i> (leaf) and <i>taraf</i> (freshly plucked) mean the same. The verse thus reads, an olive-leaf, a frond in its mouth. Similarly in Daniel <i>adamah</i> (earth) and <i>afar</i> (dust) mean the same and the Bible could have employed only one word.</i> as it does in <i>the dust of the earth</i> (Dan. 12:2). They interpret <i>taraf</i> (freshly plucked) as leaf. <i>All its sprouting leaves</i> (tarpe tzimchah) (Ezek. 17:9) is similar. That <i>taraf</i> is a noun is evident from the long <i>kamatz</i> beneath the <i>resh</i>. It is like <i>zahav</i> (gold) and <i>ashan</i> (smoke). However, in my opinion the <i>bet</i> of <i>be-fihah</i> (mouth) is superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. says that the phrase should read <i>taraf-pihah</i> (its mouth had plucked). He thus insists that the <i>bet</i> is superfluous. According to this interpretation <i>taraf</i> is a verb.</i> It is like the <i>bet</i> of <i>be-rucho</i> (by his breath) in <i>By His breath the heavens are serene</i> (Job 26:13)<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>bet</i> (by) is superfluous.</i> and the <i>bet</i> of <i>ve-echad</i> (at one with Himself) (Job 23:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">This should be read <i>echad</i>.</i> In this case <i>taraf</i> is a verb meaning plucked and is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> beneath the second radical like <i>taraf</i> (torn) in <i>For He hath torn</i> (taraf) (Hos. 6:1)<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taraf</i> (torn) has a <i>kamatz</i> beneath the second radical. A third person <i>kal</i> perfect usually has a <i>pattach</i> beneath the second radical. Hence I.E. points out that there are instances where it has a <i>kamatz</i> beneath the second radical.</i> and <i>sha’ag</i> (hath roared) in <i>The lion hath roared</i> (sha’ag) (Amos 3:8)<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sha’ag</i> has a <i>kamatz</i> under the second radical.</i> and other similar cases. It is also possible that <i>taraf</i> (freshly plucked) is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> because it is an adjective like <i>chacham</i> (wise). It means the same as <i>taruf</i> (torn), for an adjective may resemble an active or passive participle.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taraf</i> resembles the active, <i>taruf</i> the passive (Krinsky). According to this interpretation <i>taraf</i> is an adjective meaning plucked.</i>

Verse 12

AND HE STAYED. <i>Va-yiyyachel</i> (and he stayed) is a <i>nifal</i> and is penultimately accented<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Because of the <i>vav</i> conversive (Weiser).</i> like <i>va-yillachem</i> (and he fought) (Num. 21:1) and <i>va-yitzamed</i> (and he was joined) (Num. 25:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Both are <i>nifal</i> forms and are penultimately accented because of the <i>vav</i> conversive.</i> However, there are instances when corresponding <i>nifals</i> are accented on the last syllable,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>nifals</i> with the <i>vav</i> conversive.</i> as in <i>va-yippaked</i> (was empty) in <i>that David’s place was empty</i> (I Sam. 20:27). The entire root appears in <i>And he stayed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">There are two <i>yods</i> in <i>va-yiyyachel</i> (and he stayed); one is the first letter of the root <i>yod, chet, lamed</i>, the other is the sign of the third person future. In such cases the root <i>yod</i> usually changes into a <i>vav</i>, hence I.E.’s comment (Cherez).</i> as it does in <i>shot through</i> (yiyyareh) (Ex. 19:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yiyyareh</i> from the root <i>yod, resh, heh</i>.</i>
[AND SENT FORTH THE DOVE.] Noah sent out the dove on the first day of Adar. This time it no longer returned to him as it was wont to.
ANY MORE. <i>Od</i> (anymore) means forever. <i>Od</i> in <i>his uncleanness is yet</i> (od) <i>upon him</i> (Num. 19:13) and <i>While the earth remaineth</i> (od kol yeme ha-aretz) (Gen. 8:22) is similar.

Verse 13

THE WATERS WERE DRIED UP FROM OFF THE EARTH. Only the surface of the earth dried; the soil itself was swampy and hence not yet firm enough to walk upon. The earth did not fully dry until later. Those who insist that Noah used a lunar calendar because Scripture tells us that he spent a year and ten days in the ark and the ten days refer to the excess of the solar year over a lunar year are pressing a point.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">A lunar year plus 10 days equals a solar year. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i>, Chap. 33:7, and Rashi’s commentary, which states that the flood and its aftermath lasted a solar year. Noah entered the ark on the 17th day of the second month and left it on the 27th day of the second month of the following year.</i> First of all, for this to be so the year had to be “full.”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">A solar year has 365 days; a lunar year may have 353, 354 or 355 days, called, respectively, <i>shanah chasera</i> (defective year), <i>shanah ki-sidra</i> (regular year), and <i>shenah shelemah</i> (a full year). In the first instance Cheshvan and Kislev have 29 days each; in the second Cheshvan has 29 days and Kislev 30; in the third both Cheshvan and Kislev have 30 days each. To make the lunar year equal the solar year, the lunar year had to be “full” plus 10 days.</i> Furthermore, there is no reason to assume that Noah spent a year in the ark.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Why say that the year and 10 days that Noah spent in the ark was the equivalent of a solar year and Noah employed a lunar calendar, when it could just as well have been a solar year plus 10 days?</i> He could equally have been in it for a solar year plus ten days.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that we do not know what sort of calendar Noah used. Elsewhere I.E. comments that Noah could have employed Egyptian or Persian calendars. As to Jewish law, the calendar to be followed is the one legislated by Moses.</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

BRING FORTH. <i>Haytze</i> (bring forth) is written as if it came from a root whose radicals remain unchanged in conjugation.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">In reality it is a <i>peh yod</i>, and in <i>hifil</i> the <i>yod</i> should change to a <i>vav</i> (Filwarg).</i> <i>Hayshar</i> (make straight) in <i>Make Thy way straight before my face</i> (Ps. 5:9) is similar.
THAT THEY MAY SWARM. Reproduce.

Verse 18



Verse 19

AFTER THEIR FAMILIES. After their kind. Some say that the animals bred in the ark.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">In contradistinction to the rabbis who said that the animals did not engage in intercourse in the ark. Therefore they had “families,” each of which left the ark by itself. According to the first interpretation they did not breed in the ark. Hence they had no “families.” Thus they interpret “families” as kinds.</i> Each family then left the ark by itself and did not intermingle with any other. This interpretation is not farfetched.

Verse 20

EVERY CLEAN BEAST. There are ten kinds of clean beasts.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The 10 are mentioned in Deut. 14:4,5.</i> We do not know the number of clean fowl because the Bible lists only the unclean ones since the clean fowl are more numerous than the unclean. Noah built the altar on one of the mountains of Ararat.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">He brought an offering of each of the clean animals and fowl before they dispersed (Weiser).</i>

Verse 21

SMELLED. <i>Va-yarach</i> (smelled) follows the paradigm of <i>va-yanach</i> (rested) in <i>and rested</i> (va-yanach) <i>in all the borders of Egypt</i> (Ex. 10:14). The <i>resh</i> is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because the <i>chet</i> which follows it is a guttural. This is in keeping with the rules of Hebrew grammar. Heaven forbid that one conclude from our verse that God smells. Neither does He eat, as <i>Who did eat the fat of their sacrifices</i> (Deut. 32:38)<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is not to be taken literally, for the Torah employed human language (Kaputa).</i> states. The meaning of our verse is that God accepted the burnt offering and it pleased Him. It may be compared to a human being who smells a pleasant scent and enjoys it.
THE SWEET SAVOUR. <i>Nicho’ach</i> (sweet savour) comes from the same root as <i>menuchah</i> (rest).<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>nun, vav, chet</i>.</i> The <i>chet</i> is doubled in <i>nicho’ach</i> as the final <i>peh</i> of the root of <i>ve-na’afufe’ah</i> (and her adulteries) is doubled (Hos. 2:4). Its meaning is that the sweet odor assuaged God’s anger, or that it caused a power from on high to rest on man.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Compare, <i>to cause a blessing to rest</i> (le-hani’ach) <i>on thy house</i> (Ezek. 44:30).</i>
IN HIS HEART. <i>El libbo</i> means in His heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads, to his heart, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> He then revealed His secret to Noah who was a prophet.
[I WILL NOT AGAIN CURSE THE GROUND.] As I did on account of Adam, as it is written, <i>cursed is the ground for thy sake</i> (Gen. 3:17).
THE IMAGINATION. <i>Yetzer</i> (the imagination) refers to the nature that man was created with.
NEITHER WILL I AGAIN SMITE. Via a flood.
[AGAIN.] <i>Od</i> means forever,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on verse 12.</i> or again. <i>And wept on his neck a good while</i> (od) (Gen. 46:29) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Which should be rendered, according to I.E., “And wept on his neck a second time.”</i>

Verse 22

WHILE THE EARTH REMAINETH. This indicates that an end has been fixed for the earth. The Rabbinic interpretation of <i>It shall be eighteen thousand reeds round about</i> (Ezek. 48:38) is very precious. However, even one in a thousand does not know what it means.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">According to the sage Rava, <i>it shall be eighteen thousand reeds round about</i> indicates that the world will come to an end after 18,000 generations. Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 97b; <i>Sukkah</i> 45b.</i>
SEED TIME AND HARVEST. The year is divided into two periods<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">From an agricultural point of view, they are planting time and harvest time.</i> and then into four: cold, the antithesis of heat, and summer, the antithesis of winter, corresponding to the four seasons of the year.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible does not list the four seasons in order because it wants to stress their antithetical nature (Cherez).</i> The four periods are all divided into day and night, for when the days are short the nights are long, and as the nights get shorter the days get longer until both are equal.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the natural cycles do not cease.</i>

Chapter 9



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND THE DREAD OF YOU. The root of <i>ve-chittechem</i> (and the dread of you) is <i>chet, tav, tav</i>. It comes from the same root as <i>chatat</i> (terror) in <i>Ye, see a terror</i> (chatat) (Job 6:21). <i>Chittechem</i> is synonymous with <i>chatattekhem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chatat</i> (terror or dread) with the pronominal suffix would read <i>chatattekhem</i> (your dread). In <i>chittekhem</i> a <i>tav</i> is missing; in <i>chatattechem</i> the whole root is present.</i>
AND UPON ALL WHEREWITH THE GROUND TEEMETH. It means everything which creeps upon the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Interpreting <i>tirmos ha’adamah</i> as <i>tirmos al ha’adamah</i>.</i> Or, <i>ha’adamah</i> (the ground) is the subject.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>be-khol asher tirmos ha’adamah</i> means, upon all creeping things which the ground will bring forth (Weiser). In the former, ground (<i>adamah</i>) is the object, in the latter the subject. According to the second interpretation, <i>tirmos</i> means will give birth to creeping things.</i>
INTO YOUR HAND ARE THEY DELIVERED. This is to be read as if written, “because” into your hand are they delivered.
[AND UPON ALL.] Some say that the <i>bet</i> of <i>be-khol</i> (and upon all) and of <i>u-ve-khol</i> (and upon all) are in place of a <i>vav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>be-khol</i>, and <i>u-ve-khol</i> should be read as if written <i>ve-khol</i> (and all). According to this interpretation the second half of our verse is an independent clause stating: and all wherewith the ground teemeth and all the fish of the sea; into your hand are delivered. According to this interpretation we do not have to add the word “because” before <i>into your hand are they delivered</i>. However, it should be noted that this comment is difficult. <i>U-ve-khol</i> has a <i>vav</i>. Weiser suggests interpreting I.E.: and the <i>bet</i> of <i>u-ve-khol</i> is superfluous. Cf. Weiser and Cherez.</i> However, it is more likely that this clause is connected to <i>And the fear of you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation the <i>bet</i> has the meaning of on; <i>be-khol</i> thus means <i>upon all</i> rather than <i>and all</i> as in the former interpretation. The same is true for <i>u-ve-khol</i> (Weiser). According to this explanation the second half of the verse is a continuation of the first half. The entire verse should be read as follows: And the fear of you and the dread of you shall be upon every beast of the earth… and upon all (<i>be-khol</i>) wherewith the ground teemeth, and upon all (<i>u-ve-khol</i>) the fish of the sea; because into your hand are they delivered. According to this interpretation “because” has to be added to the text (Cherez).</i>

Verse 3

EVERY MOVING THING. <i>Remes</i> (moving thing) is a general term for wild and domesticated animals and for all fowl and fish. Man was now permitted to kill and eat them all.
AS THE GREEN HERB. <i>Yerek</i> (green) can be vocalized in two ways.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">It is vocalized either with two <i>segolim</i> (<i>yerek</i>) or two <i>kematzim</i>. The point is that green and smoke can follow either of two paradigms, <i>pe’el</i> (two <i>segolim</i>) or <i>pa’al</i> (two <i>kematzim</i>).</i> The same is true with smoke. We thus find, <i>behold a smoking</i> (ashan)<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Vocalized with two <i>kematzim</i> (<i>ashan</i>).</i> <i>furnace</i> (Gen. 15:17), and <i>as the smoke</i> (ke-eshen)<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Vocalized with two <i>segolim</i> (<i>eshen</i>).</i> <i>of a furnace (Ex</i>. 19:18).

Verse 4

ONLY FLESH WITH THE LIFE THEREOF, WHICH IS THE BLOOD THEREOF, SHALL YE NOT EAT. The meaning of this verse is that you shall not eat flesh with its life (<i>nefesh</i>), which is its blood, as in <i>and thou shalt not eat the life</i> (nefesh, i.e., the blood) <i>with the flesh</i> (Deut. 12:23), and <i>For as to the life</i> (nefesh) <i>of all flesh, the blood thereof is all one with the life</i> (nefesh) <i>thereof</i> (Lev. 17:14). The <i>nefesh</i> (life) which moves and feels is the body.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>nefesh</i> does not here refer to soul; it means body. However, by extension it also refers to the blood which gives life to the body. Krinsky has an alternate reading: the <i>nefesh</i> spoken of here refers to that which moves and feels within the body, i.e., the blood. According to Cherez, I.E. uses the term body for the blood.</i>

Verse 5

AND SURELY YOUR BLOOD OF YOUR LIVES WILL I REQUIRE. I have permitted you to shed the blood of all living creatures. However, I have prohibited you the spilling of the blood of your lives because you are human. On the contrary, I will avenge that blood (<i>edreshennu</i>), as in <i>For He that avengeth</i> (doresh) <i>blood</i> (Ps. 9:13). Scripture first lays down a general rule, <i>And surely your blood of your lives will I require</i>, and then goes into detail and tells us whom God will punish for taking human life. AND AT THE HAND OF MAN. If many people kill one person or if one man kills another person (even at the hand of every man’s brother), I will avenge that death. I will also punish a beast that kills a man by having another animal kill it.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This explains, <i>at the hand of every beast will I require it</i>.</i> Thus man is permitted to kill animals but animals are prohibited from killing humans. In my opinion it is farfetched to maintain that <i>and surely your blood of your lives</i> refers to suicide.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Baba Kama</i> 91b. This verse teaches that a person is prohibited from harming himself. See also Rabbi B. Epstein, <i>Torah Temimah</i> on this verse.</i> 

Verse 6

[WHOSO SHEDDETH MAN’S BLOOD, BY MAN SHALL HIS BLOOD BE SHED.] This is a further elaboration.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">On <i>at the hand of man, even at the hand of every man’s brother, will I require the life of man</i>. God will see to it that the murderers will somehow be killed by another person (Filwarg).</i> It may also be taken, and this appears most likely, as a command to the sons of Noah to execute murderers. The term <i>ba-adam</i> (by man) can be interpreted in one of three ways: in front of witnesses;<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>bet</i> meaning in front of; <i>ba-adam</i>, in front of people, i.e. witnesses or in public. The verse thus reads, <i>Whoso sheddeth man’s blood</i> before witnesses (or before many people), his blood shall be shed.</i> in front of people; or because a man was killed. There are many other such instances.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Taking the <i>bet</i> to mean because (Krinsky). The verse thus reads, <i>Whoso sheddeth man’s blood</i>, because he killed a man, his blood shall be shed.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

AND GOD SPOKE UNTO NOAH, AND TO HIS SONS. God spoke to Noah’s sons through Noah. It is also possible that they were all prophets and God addressed all four of them.

Verse 9

AND WITH YOUR SEED. <i>Ve-et zarakhem</i> is to be rendered: and with your seed.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>et</i> here has the meaning of <i>im</i> (with).</i> The third <i>with you</i> (v. 10) is to be interpreted as meaning: that were <i>with you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ittekhem</i> (with your) appears three times in verses 9 and 10. The third <i>with you</i>, i.e., <i>and every beast of the earth with you</i>, appears redundant because it follows <i>and with every living creature that is with you, the fowl, the cattle</i>. Hence I.E. interprets the former to mean that were with you in the Ark.</i> It is also possible that <i>with you</i> is repeated for additional explanation.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible repeats itself in order to further explain itself; i.e., the beasts spoken of are those that are with you.</i> The covenant spoken of is that all flesh not be cut off anymore by the waters of the flood (v. 11).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 reads, <i>And I will establish My covenant with you; neither shall</i>, etc. Hence it appears that a covenant was made and then God promised <i>neither shall</i>, etc. I.E. points out that <i>neither shall</i> opens the covenant (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

[NEITHER SHALL ALL FLESH BE CUT OFF.] Flesh refers to the body. The body is so designated because flesh senses and the bones do not. The covenant is a promise that all bodies will never again be destroyed by a flood. God included in His covenant a pledge not to bring a comparable deluge ever again because the first part of His promise, <i>neither shall all flesh be cut off any more by the waters of the flood</i>, may be taken to imply that there will be other floods but that God will save humanity. It is concerning this covenant that the prophet says, <i>For as I have sworn that the waters of Noah Should no more go over the earth</i> (Is. 54:9).

Verse 12

THE TOKEN. <i>Ot</i> (token) may be either masculine or feminine.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Here it is feminine. In Ex. 3:12 it is masculine.</i>

Verse 13

MY BOW. Behold, I now set a bow in the clouds. Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation that the rainbow was previously in existence is incorrect.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The past tense <i>natati</i> (I have set) is employed, hence Saadiah’s interpretation.</i>

Verse 14

WHEN I BRING CLOUDS OVER THE EARTH. The <i>nun</i> of <i>be-aneni</i> (when I bring clouds) does not have a <i>dagesh</i> even though it is a <i>pi’el</i> and therefore should have a <i>dagesh</i> in the middle radical of the root, as in <i>when I speak</i> (be-dabberi) <i>with thee</i> (Ex. 19:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>bet</i> of <i>dabberi</i> has a <i>dagesh</i>. I.E. reads, <i>be-dabberi ittakh</i>. However, Ex. 19:9 <i>reads, be-dabberi immakh</i>. According to <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 the reference is to Ezek. 3:27. However, here, too, the quote is not exact. If not a scribal error, it shows that I.E. quoted verses from memory.</i>
AND THE BOW IS SEEN IN THE CLOUDS. If we would believe what the Greek scholars tell us, that the rainbow is produced by the sun’s flames, then we must assume that after the flood God strengthened the sun’s light.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the rainbow was created after the flood. Hence he believes that God now strengthened the sun’s power so that its rays would produce a rainbow.</i> This is the way that a person who understands the sciences will interpret this verse.

Verse 15

[AND THE WATERS SHALL NO MORE BECOME.] The use of the singular <i>yiheyeh</i> (shall become) with <i>mayim</i> (waters) does not prove that <i>mayim</i> is singular.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 1:14.</i> We find the same word used with a plural in <i>But there were</i> (va-yehi)<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yehi</i> is singular.</i> <i>certain men</i> (Num. 9:6).

Verse 16

[AND THE BOW SHALL BE IN THE CLOUD.] The bow is always hidden in the cloud and there seen by God.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Even when man does not see the bow, God sees it and remembers his covenant. When man does not see the bow it is hidden in the clouds.</i>

Verse 17

AND GOD SAID UNTO NOAH. This is <i>the covenant</i> that I disclosed to you and this is the oath <i>which I have established</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>which I have established</i> does not refer to sign because a sign is not established. It is made. Hence he interprets <i>established</i> as referring to an oath not to bring a flood (Meijler).</i>

Verse 18

AND HAM IS THE FATHER OF CANAAN. This teaches that both Ham and Canaan were wicked, and as the father does, so do the children. Canaan and not Cush<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Cush was Ham’s first-born (Gen. 10:6). Thus he, rather than Canaan, the youngest, should have been mentioned in this verse.</i> is mentioned in this verse because Canaan was going to be cursed. This chapter<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Telling of what Canaan did, and that Noah cursed him.</i> was written to inform us that all Canaanites, both male and female, bear a curse from the time of Noah. Abraham thus commanded his servant, <i>thou shalt not take a wife for my son of the daughters of the Canaanites</i> (Gen. 24:3). Rebecca similarly said, <i>If Jacob takes a wife of the daughters of Heth…what good shall my life do me</i> (Gen. 27:46). Should someone ask, what sins were the Hittites guilty of, let him open his eyes; the Hittites and the Amorites and the others are all descendants of Canaan.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 10:15,16.</i> We therefore read, <i>unto the land of Canaan</i> (Josh. 22:32).<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">It was inhabited by the Hittites, Amorites and other nations. It was known as the land of Canaan because they were all decended from Canaan.</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

AND NOAH…BEGAN. <i>Va-yachel</i> (began) is derived from <i>techillah</i> (beginning). It belongs to those roots whose second and third letters are identical.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>chet, lamed, lamed</i>.</i> It is a <i>hifil</i>, similar to <i>va-yasekh</i> (shut up) in <i>Or who shut up</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>samekh, caf, caf</i>, and it is also in the <i>hifil</i>.</i> (va-yasekh) <i>the sea with doors</i> (Job 38:8).
THE HUSBANDMAN. A skilled agriculturalist, agriculture being a great science. The Rabbinic statement that Noah drank from his vineyard on the day he planted it is not to be taken literally.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 36:7.</i> There is a secret meaning to it. Similarly <i>and the woman conceived, and bore a son</i> (Ex. 2:2) did not take place on one and the same day.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The women obviously did not conceive and bear on the same day. Similarly <i>and he planted a vineyard And he drank</i> did not take place on the same day.</i>

Verse 21

AND HE WAS UNCOVERED. <i>Va-yitgal</i> (and he was uncovered) comes from the root <i>gimel, lamed, heh</i>, meaning to uncover. It is a <i>hitpa’el. Yital</i> (lift himself up) in <i>And let him lift himself up</i> (yital) (Jer. 51:3)<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">It, too, is a <i>hitpa’el</i> and a <i>lamed heh</i>. Its root is <i>ayin, lamed, heh</i>.</i> is similar.
[HIS TENT.] The <i>heh</i> of <i>oholoh</i> (his tent) is in place of a <i>vav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The masculine pronominal suffix is usually a <i>vav</i>.</i> The <i>heh</i> of <i>be-re’oh</i> (as they shouted), in <i>the noise of the people as they shouted</i> (be-re’oh) (Ex. 32:17), and the <i>heh</i> of <i>fera’oh</i> (let them loose) in <i>for Aaron had let them loose</i> (fera’oh) (Ex. 32:25), are similar.

Verse 22



Verse 23

UPON BOTH THEIR SHOULDERS. Each one placed an edge of the blanket on his shoulders. <i>Shekhem</i> (shoulders) does not come in the plural.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The word for shoulder is <i>shekhem</i>. The plural in the construct would be <i>shikhme</i>. The Bible employs the singular (<i>shekhem</i>) because the word does not appear in the plural.</i>
BACKWARD. Opposite of the normal way of walking, which is to go forward.

Verse 24

AND NOAH AWOKE. Scripture does not reveal what was done to Noah. Be that as it may, Canaan was the culprit. The sequence of events was as follows: Ham saw his father’s nakedness and unlike his brothers did not cover him. On the contrary, he revealed what he saw. Canaan heard that Noah was lying naked in his tent and did something to Noah. However, the Bible does not tell us what he did to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The sages of the Talmud are divided as to what was done to Noah. Some say that he was castrated. Others say that he was sodomized. Cf. <i>San</i>. 70a.</i> 
The meaning of the verse <i>and (Noah) knew what his youngest son had done unto him</i> is proof<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Ham was not Noah’s youngest son; therefore <i>his youngest son</i> cannot refer to him. Canaan was a youngest son and the verse can thus apply to him.</i> that Canaan was the culprit, for we read, <i>And the sons of Ham: Cush, and Mizraim, and Put, and Canaan</i> (Gen. 10:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that Canaan was Ham’s youngest son.</i> Furthermore, the <i>his</i> in <i>his youngest son</i> refers to Ham, who is previously mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The verse should be understood as follows: And Noah knew what Ham’s youngest son had done to him.</i> That is why Noah cursed Canaan. The one who says that Ham was the culprit, and that Canaan was cursed because Noah did not want to curse his son (Ham) because God had blessed Noah’s sons, is indulging in Midrash.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 31:11.</i>

Verse 25

A SERVANT OF SERVANTS. <i>Eved avadim</i> (a servant of servants) means a servant like all other servants.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>eved avadim</i> means a member of the servant class.</i> If Scripture meant a servant to servants then it would have read <i>eved ha-avadim</i>. Proof of this is: <i>it is most holy</i> (kodesh kodashim) (Lev. 6:18), and <i>In a most holy place</i> (be-kodesh ha-kodashim) (Num. 18:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment to Lev. 6:18 where I.E. points out that <i>kodesh kodashim</i> means holy (<i>kodesh</i>) as one of the holy objects (<i>kodashim</i>). When Scripture wants to say most holy it uses the term <i>kodesh ha-kodashim</i>. Similarly had Scripture read <i>eved ha-avadim</i>, it would have meant a servant of (to) servants.</i>
[UNTO HIS BRETHREN.] To Cush, Mizraim and Put, the sons of Ham his father. There are some who say that the Cushites are enslaved because Noah cursed Ham. However, they have forgotten that the first king to rule after the flood was a Cushite. Thus it is written, <i>and Cush begot Nimrod…And the beginning of his kingdom was Babel, and Erech, and Accad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar</i> (Gen. 10:8-10).<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the curse was put on the Canaanites and not on all of Ham’s descendants.</i>

Verse 26

BLESSED BE THE LORD, THE GOD OF SHEM. We are duty-bound to be bountiful in praise of the Lord, who is the God of Shem, for He will make Canaan a servant of God and Shem.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s paraphrase of our verse.</i> The meaning of our verse is, God will compel Canaan to serve Shem, for <i>lamo</i> (their) has the same meaning as <i>la-hem</i> (to them).<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The second half of the verse literally reads, and let Canaan be a servant to them (<i>lamo</i>). I.E. points out that <i>lamo</i> means to them (<i>la-hem</i>) and refers to God and Shem who are mentioned in the first half of the verse.</i> The <i>vav</i> of <i>lamo</i> is superfluous and is similar to the <i>vav</i> of <i>tevi’emo</i> (<i>Thou bringest them in</i>) (Ex. 15:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>vav</i> of <i>tevi’emo</i> is also superfluous.</i> Therefore the term “to them” is not encountered in Scripture, spelled either without a <i>heh</i> or a <i>vav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Since the term for them is either <i>la-hem</i> or <i>lamo</i>, the term <i>lam</i> is not found in Scripture (Netter).</i> The Tetragrammaton is invoked in connection with Shem to honor Shem.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">The ancestor of the Israelites who worshiped the Lord (Krinsky).</i> It is not employed with regard to Japheth because he was not his brother’s equal. Saadiah Gaon says that <i>Cursed be Canaan</i> is short for cursed be Canaan’s father.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This answers the question: Why was Canaan cursed when it was in fact Ham who allowed his father to lie naked at the doorway of the tent?</i> He says that <i>In the presence of Hanamel my uncle</i> (Jer. 32:12) is similar, as Hanamel was really Jeremiah’s uncle’s son.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Jer. 32:8. We thus see that Scripture employs such abridgments.</i> However, it is possible that Hanamel was older than Jeremiah and the latter referred to him as “my uncle” because it was an honor for him to be called by his father’s title.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that Jeremiah wanted to honor his cousin who was older than he. He did so by calling him uncle. Hence Saadiah cannot offer proof from this verse that Scripture employs this type of abridgment.</i> Similarly one’s father’s brother’s wife is called aunt in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">An uncle is a <i>dod</i>, his wife is a <i>dodah</i>. She is so called in order to honor her, because she is married to one’s uncle. See I.E. to Lev. 18:14. Similarly Lot is called Abraham’s brother, rather than his nephew (Gen. 14:14).</i> However, in our case there is no reason to refer to Ham by the name of his son.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">What honor is there to Ham if he is referred to as Canaan?</i> 

Verse 27

[ENLARGE.] Saadiah also explains the word <i>yaft</i> (enlarge) as coming from the Hebrew word for beautiful (<i>yafeh</i>). However, his comment is not beautiful (<i>yafeh</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">A sarcastic pun, telling us that Saadiah is wrong.</i> <i>Yaft</i> means he will enlarge.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yafte</i>. Compare Deut. 12:20.</i> The Aramaic word for <i>He shall enlarge</i> (Deut. 12:20) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders <i>ki yarchiv</i> as <i>are yafte</i> (Deut. 12:20).</i> <i>Yaft</i> (enlarge) is a <i>hifil</i>. It is like <i>yard</i> in <i>And maketh him rule</i> (yard) <i>over kings</i> (Is. 41:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that <i>yaft</i>, like <i>yard</i>, is an abridged word. <i>Yaft</i> is short for <i>yafteh</i> and <i>yard</i> for <i>yardeh</i>.</i> Both Shem and Japheth were blessed in this verse, for the meaning of <i>And he shall dwell in the tents of Shem</i> is: may God dwell in the tents of Shem. The previous verse (v. 26) relates the blessing with which Noah blessed God.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">God rather than Shem is the object of the blessing. Hence in verse 26 Noah blessed God. In verse 27 he blessed Shem and Japheth. Thus the blessing of Shem in verse 27 is not redundant.</i>
AND LET CANAAN BE THEIR SERVANT. To Shem, to Japheth and also to his brothers. Thus Canaan was to be a slave to all of the world, for from Shem, Japheth and Canaan’s brothers all of humanity is descended. This came to pass many years after the flood.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">According to Krinsky, I.E.’s words apply to the blessing and curse uttered by Noah, namely, that God would dwell in the tents of Shem, that he would enlarge Japheth, and that Canaan would be a slave.</i>

Chapter 10



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4

KITTIM. <i>Kittim</i> is the name of one of Javan’s sons.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Even though it is in the plural.</i> I therefore explain in my comments on the Book of Daniel that Greeks and Romans<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. maintains that the brass sections of the giant statue dreamed of by Nebuchadnezzar allude to the Greek and Roman empires. See Daniel, Chap. 2 and Ibn Ezra’s comment there on verse 39. I.E. identifies the Kittim with the Romans. (See his comments on Gen. 27:40). Since Kittim (the Romans) was the son of Javan (the Greeks) one symbol stands for both of them.</i> constitute one kingdom.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Nebuchadnezzar dreamed of a statue whose head was of fine gold, its breast and its arms of silver, its belly and its thighs of brass, its legs of iron, its feet partly of iron and partly of clay (Dan. 2:32, 34). Each of these metals symbolizes a kingdom. I.E. identifies the brass with the Greeks and the Romans, whom he considers one kingdom because they are one race.</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

NIMROD. Do not attempt to ascertain the meaning of any names encountered in the Bible if Scripture itself does not explain them.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbis connect Nimrod with the word <i>marad</i> (to rebel). They tell us that Nimrod was so called because he caused people to rebel against God. See <i>Erubin</i> 53a.</i> 
Nimrod was the first to display man’s power over the wild beasts for he was a mighty hunter. 

Verse 9

The meaning of <i>before the Lord</i> (v. 9) is that Nimrod built altars and offered the animals he hunted as whole offerings to God. This is the literal meaning of the verse. However, its Midrashic interpretation is totally different.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi. He ensnared men with his words and caused them to rebel against God. See also Nahmanides: “Ibn Ezra’s words do not appear to be correct, for our rabbis know by tradition of Nimrod’s wickedness.”</i>
WHEREFORE IT IS SAID. This proverb was also used in the days of Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the use of the present form, <i>it is said</i>, that is, we say today, today being the age in which the Torah was written.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

[OUT OF THAT LAND WENT FORTH ASSHUR.] Asshur was the son of Japheth.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">This comment is extremely difficult; Scripture nowhere says this. Indeed, in I.E.’s alternate commentary to Genesis he writes, “We do not know who was the father of Asshur.” Some suggest that our text is corrupt, and on the basis of verse 22 emend it to: son of Shem (Weiser).</i> The events related in this verse took place after the dispersion following the building of the Tower of Babel. Nimrod was the first king over Babel.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">There was no Babel before the dispersion. Thus Nimrod’s rule over Babel had to be after the dispersion. Hence what Scripture relates about Asshur had to happen after the dispersion (Netter).</i> According to <i>Seder Olam</i>, Nimrod was king over the seventy who built the tower, and it was in his time that the dispersion took place.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">This is not found in our editions of the <i>Seder Olam</i>. Krinsky points out that there are many citations quoted in the early sources from this work that are missing in our edition of the <i>Seder Olam</i>. From the fact that Nimrod was king during the time of the dispersion we see that what Asshur did happened later.</i>

Verse 12

THE SAME IS THE GREAT CITY. It appears to me that this is connected to <i>and builded Nineveh</i>. However, it is also possible that it is connected to Resen or Calah.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Three cities are mentioned in the verse. Hence <i>the same is the great city</i> may be taken to refer to any one of them.</i>

Verse 13

AND MIZRAIM BEGOT LUDIM. In my opinion, these are the names of countries, each of which was populated by a particular family. This is why all the names (in verses 13 and 14) are in the plural. Proof of this is the name <i>Pathrusim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14. The land itself was called the “country of Pathros” (Jer. 44:1), and its inhabitants called “Pathrusim.” The same applies to all the names in verses 13 and 14. Hence, Pathros is the name of a place. Similarly all the names in verses 13 and 14 refer to names of places, their inhabitants taking the name of the place wherein they lived.</i> Additional and definite proof that this interpretation is correct is the phrase <i>whence went forth</i> (v. 14), for the word <i>whence</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew <i>mi-sham</i> indicates a place.</i> alludes to a place.

Verse 14

[AND CAPHTORIM.] Mizraim also begat the Caphtorim.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And Caphtorim</i> is not to be connected to <i>whence went forth the Philistines</i>, but to <i>And Mizraim begot</i>.</i> The term begat is used in Scripture when referring to the father because the child comes from the strength and power of the father<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">An allusion to semen. The word <i>yalad</i> (begot) actually means to give birth and it is used when referring to the father (<i>yalad</i>) as well as the mother (<i>yaledah</i>) for the reason noted by I.E. (Netter).</i> and is in his likeness and image.

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

AS THOU GOEST TOWARD GERAR. The word <i>gerarah</i> means to Gerar.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>heh</i> at the end of the name of a place is in place of an <i>el</i> (to) before it. Hence <i>gerarah</i> means <i>el</i> Gerar, to Gerar (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 20

THESE ARE THE SONS OF HAM, AFTER THEIR FAMILIES, AFTER THEIR TONGUES. Scripture says the same concerning the children of Japheth<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 10:5.</i> and the children of Shem.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 10:31.</i>

Verse 21
