[THE FATHER OF ALL THE CHILDREN OF EBER.] Scripture informs us that Shem was the father of the Hebrews for no one was greater than he, and the Lord was his God. Similarly it is written, <i>Thus saith the Lord, the God of the Hebrews</i> (ivrim) (Ex. 10:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. identifies the children of Eber (<i>ever</i>) with the Hebrews (<i>ivrim</i>).</i> On the other hand, the Bible tells us that Ham was the father of Canaan<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The text reads, Canaan was the father of Ham. The text is obviously corrupt. Ham was the father of Canaan. <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, <i>u-khena’an aviv cham</i>. The <i>vav</i> of <i>aviv</i> was dropped in transmission. Thus <i>aviv</i> (his father) became <i>avi</i> (father of).</i> for no one was baser that he. It is unfitting for the holy and profane to intermingle. 
Scripture notes that Shem was <i>the brother of Japheth the elder</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This is the literal meaning of <i>achi yefet ha-gadol</i>. From the text it is not clear whether Japheth or Shem was the elder; the grammatical construction is such that elder may apply to either. I.E. is trying to explain why Scripture tells us that Shem was Japheth’s brother, but does not say the same about Ham.</i> to teach us that Japheth, too, was a worthy person. The Bible lists Shem, who was the youngest, before Japheth,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible lists Noah’s sons as Shem, Ham and Japheth (Gen. 5:32; 6:10). According to I.E. the order of their birth was Japheth, Ham and Shem (Krinsky).</i> who was the elder,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra assumes that elder applies to Japheth (see note 20).</i> out of respect to Shem. Proof that Japheth was the elder lies in Scripture’s stating that Noah was five hundred years old when he begat his first son.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 5:32.</i> There is no room for argument, for it is clear that Noah had no children prior to reaching the age of five hundred. The flood came when Noah was six hundred years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 7:6.</i> Therefore if Shem was the eldest he would be one hundred and one years old when Noah and his sons came out of the ark.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The flood lasted a year.</i> However, Scripture tells us <i>Shem was a hundred years old, and begot Arpachshad two years after the flood</i> (Gen. 11:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Hence Shem reached the age of 100 two years after the flood and could not have been begotten by Noah when the latter was 500 years old. Therefore Shem was not Noah’s eldest son. Japheth was. Thus the elder in verse 21 refers to Japheth.</i> Others say that Shem was <i>the elder brother of Japheth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">This interpretation explains <i>achi yefet ha-gadol</i> to mean the elder brother of Japheth. According to this interpretation Shem is the eldest.</i> and it is for this reason that Shem is mentioned first. They explain that Shem was born a few days after Noah entered his five hundredth year, for even a day in a year is considered a year.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Thus 499 years plus a few days is considered 500 years.</i> They say that Noah was born in Iyyar<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Noah was 499 years old in Iyyar.</i> and Shem in Sivan.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Shem was thus born in Noah’s 500th year.</i> When the flood came Noah was five hundred and ninety-nine plus a number of days old.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, Noah was in his 600th year when the flood began.</i> Hence Shem was not a full ninety-nine years old when the flood started and was a hundred and one years plus a number of months old when his son Arpachshad was born. The meaning of <i>two years after the flood</i> (Gen. 11:10) therefore is to be interpreted as meaning that Arpachshad was born in the second year following the beginning of the flood. There are also those who maintain that the wife of Shem conceived five months after the start of the flood when the waters started decreasing.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Arpachshad was born two years after the flood, i.e., in the second year following the start of the flood.</i> Shem was thus one hundred years old when Arpachshad was born.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Those who put forth this interpretation agree with the second interpretation. However, they are bothered by one problem. If Shem was 100 years plus some months when Arpachshad was born, why does Scripture say that Shem was 100 years old at the time? It should consider him to be 101 since part of a year is considered a year. They solve this problem by assuming that Shem’s wife conceived in the ark five months after the start of the flood, i.e., in Tishri, and gave birth to Arpachshad the following Sivan, some days before Shem’s 100th birthday. Shem, according to this interpretation, was born in Sivan. Scripture thus tells us that Shem was a hundred years old when Arpachshad was born, i.e., 99 years plus. The Bible is thus consistent in listing the years (Cherez).</i> There are ten similar instances in the Book of Kings.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Where part of a year is considered a year. Krinsky lists the 10 places as: I Kings 15:1, 2, 9; 22:52; II Kings 1:17; 3:1; 8:16; 9:29; 13:10; 14:23; 15:1; 17:1.</i>

Chapter 11



Verse 1

ONE LANGUAGE. When the word one in the feminine is in the absolute it is vocalized with a <i>segol</i> beneath the <i>alef</i> (<i>echat</i>). However, when it is in the construct it is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> beneath the <i>alef</i> (<i>achat</i>). In my book on grammar I have explained why the <i>dalet</i> is missing in the feminine word for one.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The masculine word for one is <i>echad</i>; hence the feminine should be <i>achdat</i>.</i> A logical reading of Scripture indicates that the dispersion took place one hundred years after the flood, and that Peleg, which means divided, was so named because at the time of his birth the earth was divided (Gen. 10:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">People were named for events that occurred at the time of their birth. A careful computation of the years from the flood to the birth of Peleg comes to about 100 years. Arpachshad was born two years after the flood; 35 years later he had Shelah. Shelah was 30 when he begot Eber; Eber was 34 when he begot Peleg. Therefore the dispersion took place about 100 years after the flood (Weiser).</i> <i>Peleg</i> is similar to <i>palga</i>, the Aramaic word for half. <i>Palge</i> (rivers) in <i>rivers of water</i> (palge mayim) (Ps. 119:136) is identical. It refers to the branches into which the river divides. The names given to Ichabod (I Sam. 4:21)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And she named the child Ichabod, saying: ‘The glory is departed from Israel,’ because the ark of God was taken, and because of her father-in-law and her husband</i> (I Sam. 4:21).</i> and Immanuel,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Therefore the Lord Himself shall give you a sign: behold, the young woman shall conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel (God is with us)</i> (Is. 7:14).</i> who was the son of the prophet Isaiah (Is. 7:14), are similar. Nevertheless, the words of the <i>Seder Olam</i> are also correct, and we will rely upon them.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">To the effect that the dispersion took place at the end of Peleg’s life. <i>Seder Olam</i>, Chap. 1.</i> If this is so, then Abraham was one of the builders of the tower of Babel.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">According to the <i>Seder Olam</i>, Abraham was 48 years old when the dispersion took place (Chap. 1). Abraham was a descendant of Peleg. If Peleg was born at the time of the dispersion, this would of course preclude Abraham’s being at the tower of Babel. However, if Peleg was so named because the dispersion took place at the end of his life, which consisted of 239 years (v. 18 and 19), then by computing the years listed in verses 18-26 we conclude that Abraham was 48 years old at the time of the building of the tower of Babel. The computation is as follows: Peleg was born 239 years before the dispersion since the latter took place at the end of his life. Peleg was 30 when he begat Reu. Reu was 32 when he begat Serug. Serug was 30 when he begat Nahor. Nahor was 29 when he begat Terah. Terah was 70 when he begat Abraham. We thus have a total of 191. Two hundred thirty-nine minus 191 is 48. Hence Abraham was 48 at the time of the dispersion.</i> Do not be amazed at this,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">That is, that Abraham would participate in such a venture. Noah and Shem also took part in it. It is I.E.’s belief that the builders of the Tower did not commit any sin. I.E. will elaborate on this later on in his commentary.</i> for Noah and Shem were also there.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">They, too, were saintly men and yet participated in the building of the tower.</i> Indeed, Shem didn’t die till Jacob was over fifty.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">According to the <i>Seder Olam</i>, Chap. 1, Jacob studied Torah with Shem for 50 years.</i> The meaning of <i>safah echat</i> is one language. It appears to me that the one language was Hebrew. Proof of this are the names Adam, Eve, Cain, Seth and Peleg.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">All of these are derived from Hebrew roots.</i>
[AND OF ONE SPEECH.] Unlike today, when there are words which not everybody speaking a given language will understand, the learned and the ignorant in those days spoke alike.<i>Achadim</i> (one) is the plural of <i>echad</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Sometimes the word <i>achadim</i> has the meaning of few. Cf. Gen. 27:44, <i>yamim achadim</i> (a few days). I.E. emphasizes that here it means one.</i> 

Verse 2

[AS THEY JOURNEYED EAST.] This verse shows that the mountains of Ararat are in the east.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: as they journeyed from the east, i.e., from Mt. Ararat or its vicinity. This shows that Mt. Ararat is in the east (Krinsky).</i>
[THAT THEY FOUND A PLAIN.] Its meaning is, they searched for a good place to build a state. Eventually they found this plain. The meaning of <i>bikah</i> (plain) is a flat area; it is the opposite of <i>the rough places</i> (Is. 40:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Is. 40:4 reads, <i>And the rough places (shall be made) a plain</i> (le-vikah). We thus see that <i>bikah</i> is the opposite of rough places. Hence it must refer to a level area.</i> <i>As the cattle go down into the valley</i> (Ba-bikah) (Is. 63:14) is similar. <i>Bikah</i> possibly refers to a plain between mountains because a valley appears to be a split in the hills.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Baka</i> means split. Thus <i>bikah</i> (valley) means a split in the mountains.</i>

Verse 3

LET US MAKE BRICK. <i>Nilbenah</i> (let us make brick) comes from the same root as <i>levenim</i> (bricks). Even though <i>levenim</i> ends in a <i>mem</i>, it is a feminine word.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">A feminine plural ends in a <i>vav, tav</i>. The singular of <i>levenim</i> is <i>levenah</i>, hence the feminine <i>va-tehi</i> in conjunction with <i>ha-levenah</i>.</i> Such irregular feminine plural endings are also found in the words <i>nashim</i> (women) and <i>pilagshim</i> (concubines). They baked the bricks until they became hard. A building made from such material is very strong and will not dissolve in water or fall apart when burned.
AND THEY HAD BRICK FOR STONE. In place of stone.
AND SLIME. In place of mortar. The meaning of <i>chemar</i> (slime) is the same as its Arabic cognate.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chamarah</i> in Arabic is a red earthen substance (Weiser).</i> The builders of the tower were not fools to believe that they could actually ascend the heavens. Neither were they afraid that God would bring another flood, for Noah and his children, to whom the Almighty swore never to bring another deluge, were there and being descendents of Noah and his children they were subservient to them.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If their intention was to rebel against God, then Noah and Shem would have stopped them. I.E. rejects the notion that the builders of the tower wanted to ascend the heavens and wage war with God. Cf. <i>San</i>. 109a.</i> Scripture reveals their intention and ultimate goal. They wanted to build a great city to dwell in, and a very tall tower to ensure their fame and glory and to serve as a sign indicating the place of the city to those outside it, such as shepherds. The tower, as long as it stood, would also perpetuate their names after their deaths. This is the meaning of <i>and let us make us a name</i>. 

Verse 4

The word <i>havah</i> (come) means give;<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>yod, heh, bet</i> means give. Cf. Rashi on Gen. 38:16: “The expression <i>havah</i> denotes preparation except where it is to be rendered giving, and even in those instances where <i>havah</i> denotes preparation it is close in meaning to giving.”</i> its root is <i>yod, heh, bet</i>, as is clear from <i>Cast thy burden</i> (yehavecha) <i>upon the Lord</i> (Ps. 55:23). Because <i>haveh</i> is used often, it remains the same in both the feminine and the plural. Compare, <i>come</i> (havah),<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Strictly speaking, since many are being addressed, <i>havu</i> should be used.</i> <i>let us deal wisely with them</i> (Ex. 1:10), and <i>Come</i> (havah),<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Since a female is being addressed <i>havi</i> should be used.</i> <i>I pray thee, let me come in unto thee</i> (Gen. 38:16). 
Do not be surprised at the phrase <i>with its top in heaven</i>. Moses similarly said, <i>the cities are great and fortified up to heaven</i> (Deut. 1:28).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The words of Moses are definitely not to be taken literally. Similarly neither is <i>with its top in heaven</i>.</i> The builders of the tower hoped that their city and tower would prevent them from dispersing, but this was not God’s will. However, they did not know this.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">They did not intend to rebel against God. They were merely ignorant of His will.</i>

Verse 5

[AND THE LORD CAME DOWN.] The Bible states this because all things on earth below are dependent upon the powers on high; all actions are arranged from heaven. Therefore God is referred to as the One <i>Who rideth upon the heaven</i> (Deut. 33:26) and the One who is <i>enthroned in the heavens</i> (Ps. 123:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">“God cannot come into contact with the material and changeable” (Husik, p. 191). He rules the lower world via the heavenly beings. “Ibn Ezra holds that the events of the sublunar world are governed by the positions and motions of the heavenly bodies, which in turn are determined by the intelligences or angels” (<i>Ibid</i>., p. 192).</i> The use of the term <i>And the Lord came down</i> is an anthropomorphism.

Verse 6

AND THE LORD SAID: BEHOLD, THEY ARE ONE PEOPLE. God said this to the angels. This took place before <i>And the Lord came down</i>. Its meaning is: And the Lord came down because he said, <i>Behold, they are one people, and they have all one language</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">It is unlikely that God would first go down and then say, <i>Come, let us go down</i> (Filwarg). In other words, verse 5 belongs after verse 7 (Cherez). Our translation follows Filwarg who reads <i>terem</i> in place of <i>ta’am</i>.</i>
ONE PEOPLE. They have one religion. Different religions create jealousy and hatred among people. The same is true with regard to different languages. That is why the king of Persia and Media commanded <i>that every man should bear rule in his own house, and speak according to the language of his people</i> (Es. 1:22).<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The use of only one language per household would prevent strife in that family.</i> The <i>heh</i> of <i>hachillam</i> (what they begin) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because of the <i>chet</i> which follows it.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">
The <i>heh</i> should have been vocalized with a <i>chataf pattach</i> as is the rule concerning all double roots in the <i>hifil</i> perfect.</i> The <i>heh</i> of <i>hachiloti</i> (I have begun) (Deut. 2:31) is similarly vocalized.
[WITHHOLDEN.] <i>Yibbatzer</i> means will be withholden. <i>Betzurot</i> (fortified) in <i>fortified</i> (betzurot) <i>cities</i> (Deut. 3:5)<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Cities so constructed that they hold back any enemy from entering.</i> is like it. The meaning of our verse is: If I permit them to go on, they will think that they can do whatever they wish.
[THEY PURPOSE.] <i>Yazemu</i> (they purpose) has the same meaning as <i>zamemu</i> (devised).<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Deut. 19:19. <i>Yazemu</i> comes from the root <i>yod, zayin, mem</i>; <i>zamemu</i> from the root, <i>zayin, mem, mem</i>.</i> However, they come from different roots.

Verse 7

COME, LET US GO DOWN. This is what God said to the angels.
[AND THERE CONFOUND THEIR LANGUAGE.] All the grammarians claim that <i>ve-navelah</i> (and confound) is a <i>nifal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>ve-navelah sham sefatam</i> (and there confound their language) means, and their language will be there confounded, the <i>nun</i> of <i>ve-navelah</i> being the <i>nun</i> of the <i>nifal</i>.</i> They compare it to <i>ve-navekah</i> (and shall be made empty) in <i>And the spirit of Egypt shall be made empty</i> (ve-navekah) (Is. 19:3) and to <i>navelah</i> (fadeth) in <i>The earth fainteth and fadeth away</i> (navelah) (Is. 24:4). However, their interpretation is farfetched. Why would the Bible say: Come, let us go down and their language will be confounded, when their language was not confounded because God and the angels went down?<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">God’s going down did not in itself confound their language.</i> <i>Ve-navelah</i> can only be interpreted as an active verb.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, and we will confound, its <i>nun</i> not being the sign of the <i>nifal</i> but of a first person plural imperfect prefix.</i> Proof of this is Scripture’s stating at the close of this incident, <i>because the Lord did there confound the language of all the earth</i> (v. 9). The following is then the grammatical explanation of <i>ve-navelah</i>. It is a <i>hifil</i>. Scripture should have employed the entire root and read <i>ve-navlilah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">This is the way a double root is conjugated in the <i>hifil</i>. The root of <i>ve-navelah</i> is <i>bet, lamed, lamed</i>.</i> or <i>ve-navellah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">This is the way a double root is conjugated in the <i>hifil</i> when one of the letters of the double root is dropped (swallowed) in the conjugation. In this case <i>ve-navelah</i> has a <i>tzere</i> beneath the <i>bet</i> and a <i>dagesh forte</i> in the <i>lamed</i>. The <i>dagesh</i> doubles the <i>lamed</i> and thus compensates for the missing <i>lamed</i>.</i> if one of the two <i>lameds</i> of its double root was swallowed. In the latter case it would have followed the paradigm of <i>ve-nasebbah</i> (let us bring back)<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The root of which is <i>samekh, bet, bet</i></i> in <i>and let us bring back</i> (ve-nasebbah) <i>the ark of our God</i> (I Chron. 13:3). Our word reads <i>ve-navelah</i> because one of the <i>lameds</i> of the root was dropped without the remaining <i>lamed</i> receiving a <i>dagesh forte</i> to make up for it. The sages who translated the Torah into Greek correctly rendered <i>ve-navelah</i> as I will confound,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The sages thus understood <i>ve-navelah</i> as an active form, <i>we will confound</i>.</i> rather than we will confound.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">They did this so that the readers of their translation would not think there are many gods. Cf. <i>Megillah</i> 9a.</i> If the above mentioned grammarians are correct, why did the sages omit the <i>nun</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>ve-navelah</i> is passive (<i>nifal</i>), meaning it will be confounded, why did the sages who translated the Bible into Greek change <i>ve-navelah</i> to <i>ve-avelah</i>? Obviously the sages saw it as active, meaning we will confound, hence the change from the plural to the singular.</i> Some say that the people building the tower started hating each other and each one invented a new language. Others say that the One who grants knowledge to man caused them to forget their language. In my opinion, they were first scattered. After their dispersion Nimrod ruled over Babel and other kings arose. With the passage of time and the death of the first generation to be scattered, the original language was forgotten.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the confounding of the language did not take place at one time; it was a slow process. God first dispersed them. This led to the eventual confounding of the original language.</i> God scattered the people for their own benefit. He similarly said, <i>and replenish the earth</i> (Gen. 1:28).<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">That is, populate all of the earth, not merely one area of it.</i>

Verse 8

[AND THEY LEFT OFF TO BUILD THE CITY.] Its meaning is: they left off from completing the city because part of the city and the tower had by this time been built. This is so for Scripture reads, <i>the city and the tower, which the children of men builded</i> (v. 5).<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 tells us that God <i>came down to see the city and the tower, which the children of men builded</i>. This indicates that some part of the tower and city had already been completed.</i> It is also possible that the meaning of <i>which the children of men builded</i> is: which the children of men intended to build.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation verse 5 should be interpreted to mean: God came down to see the tower and city which the children of men intended to build. He stopped them before they commenced building.</i> <i>Then Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab, arose and fought against Israel</i> (Josh. 24:9)<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Balak never fought Israel. The meaning of the verse is: then Balak…arose and intended to fight Israel.</i> is similar. The first of these interpretations appeals to me.

Verse 9

BABEL. <i>Bavel</i> (Babel) is made up of the words <i>ba</i> (came) and <i>bel</i> (confusion),<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>bel</i> is a noun from the root <i>bet, lamed, lamed</i> (Weiser). <i>Bavel</i> thus means a confusion came.</i> with the <i>alef</i> missing. <i>Bagad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>alef</i> of <i>ba</i> in <i>bagad</i> is missing. <i>Bagad</i> is a compound of <i>ba</i> and <i>gad</i>.</i> (Fortune is come) (Gen. 30:11) and <i>Bamah</i> (high place) (Ezek. 20:29)<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Ezek. 20:29 explains the word <i>bamah</i> (a high place) as coming from the word <i>ba</i> (visit) and <i>mah</i> (what). Thus the <i>alef</i> is missing.</i> are similar.

Verse 10

[TWO YEARS AFTER THE FLOOD.] I have already explained the meaning of this in the verse <i>the elder brother of Japheth</i> (Gen. 10:21).<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">In his comments on Gen. 10:32, I.E. explains that two years after the flood means a year and some days into the second year following the flood.</i> It is possible that Peleg was given this name on the day of his death, the reason for this being as follows: Shem lived for five hundred years following the flood, Arpachshad lived for four hundred and thirty-eight years, his son Shelah lived four hundred and thirty-three years, and his son Eber four hundred and sixty-four years. Now Peleg lived two hundred and thirty-nine years. Thus Peleg’s life span was half that of his ancestors. Reu, the son of Peleg, similarly lived to the same age as Peleg. Reu’s son Serug also lived about the same number of years as Peleg and Reu.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">For textual proof of these life spans see verses 11-23.</i> This, then, is the general rule: no one after Peleg, aside from his son, ever lived to be two hundred and thirty-nine years.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. suggests that Peleg was so called at his death because in his time the life span of man was cut in half. Peleg, as I.E. notes above (Gen. 10:25), means half. He now interprets <i>for in his days was the earth divided</i> (10:25) to mean in his days was the life span of the earth’s inhabitants cut in half.</i> Some say that those who built the tower numbered seventy and hence were divided into seventy languages upon their dispersion.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rabbinic tradition there are 70 primary languages.</i> If you count the sons of Shem, Japheth and Ham you will find them to be seventy.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Listed in Chap. 10 of Genesis. Those who put forward this interpretation did this.</i> However, they are incorrect. First of all <i>Pathrusim</i> and <i>Casluhim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Listed among the descendants of Ham in Gen. 10:14.</i> are not the names of two individuals.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">They are the names of nations. Hence they can’t count as two people. Thus we already have more than 70.</i> Furthermore, they neglect to include in the seventy Noah and his sons.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Who were alive at the time of the building of the tower. Again we have more than 70.</i> According to the <i>Seder Olam</i> the builders of the tower numbered thousands and ten thousands.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">According to the <i>Seder Olam</i> the dispersion took place when Abraham was 48 years old. By then the world’s population had grown to the number indicated by I.E. (Weiser).</i>

Verse 12

Verse 16

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

[AND BEGOT ABRAM.] Abraham was born in a place called Ur of the Chaldees. <i>Therefore glorify ye the Lord in the regions of light</i> (be-urim) (Is. 24:15)<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">In Isaiah, I.E. offers two definitions of the word <i>urim</i>: (a) boundaries, i.e., countries or regions; (b) valleys. According to (a) the verse reads: in the regions, honor God. According to (b) the verse should read: In the valleys honor God. The same apparently applies to the term <i>Ur Chasdim</i>. Hence <i>Ur Chasdim</i> means the land of the Chaldees, or the valley of the Chaldees. In Isaiah, I.E. prefers interpretation (a).</i> is like it. It appears to me that at the time of Abraham’s birth Ur of the Chaldees had another name since the Chaldees are descended from Nahor, the brother of Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Via his son Chesed. Cf. Gen. 22:22.</i> and that in writing the Torah Moses used the name in vogue in his time when he cited Ur of the Chaldees. Proof that Abraham was born in Ur of the Chaldees can be found in the fact that Haran died there and Scripture says, <i>And Haran died…in the land of his nativity, in Ur of the Chaldees</i> (v. 20).<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. interprets <i>his nativity</i> as referring to the entire family of Terah (Krinsky).</i> It is also possible that the Chaldees made a flame (altar) and the place thereof was called Ur (the flame, altar) of the Chaldees. In this instance Ur has the meaning of fire, as in <i>whose fire</i> (ur) <i>is in Zion</i> (Is. 31:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. earlier explains <i>Ur</i> as meaning a region or valley (see note 55). He now interprets it to mean a fire (altar).</i> 

Verse 27



Verse 28

[IN THE PRESENCE OF.] In front of his father; i.e., Terah witnessed his death. <i>In the presence of Aaron their father</i> (Num. 3:4)<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">The texts literally state: before the face of. I.E. interprets this to mean in the presence of. Thus Haran died in the presence of Terah. Similarly Aaron witnessed the death of Nadab and Abihu (Krinsky).</i> is analogous.

Verse 29

[AND THE NAME OF NAHOR’S WIFE, MILCAH.] The Bible gives the name of Nahor’s wife in order to let us know the pedigree of Rebekah, Rachel and Leah.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">See Gen. 22:20-23.</i> Our sages, of blessed memory, identified Iscah with Sarah.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 69b.</i> If this is a tradition we will accept it.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">There is no proof from Scripture that it is so; hence if it is an exegetical point we may dispute it. However, if it is a tradition passed on to the Talmudic sages, we must accept it.</i> Those who say that Abraham rather than Sarah was sterile are saying the opposite of what Scripture says.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture explicitly states in verse 30, <i>And Sarai was barren</i>.</i> Additional proof that they are wrong is the fact that Abraham sired Ishmael and had children with Keturah.I do not find the explanation of those who say that Sarah was Abraham’s sister to be acceptable.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">They base themselves on Abraham’s statement: <i>And moreover she (Sarai) is indeed my sister, the daughter of my father</i> (Gen. 20:12). I.E. in his comment on Gen. 20:12 argues that Abraham invented a fact in order to excuse his actions.</i> If Sarah was really Abraham’s sister, Scripture would have stated,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">In verse 31.</i> And Terah took Abram his son, and Sarai his daughter, the wife of Abram his son. Similarly if Sarah was the sister of Lot<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">If we identify Sarai with Iscah, then Sarai is Lot’s sister, since Haran was the father of both Lot and Iscah (v. 29 and 31) (Cherez).</i> the Bible would have stated, “and Sarai the daughter of his son,” as it does in the case of Lot.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible states with regard to Lot, <i>And Terah took…Lot the son of Haran, his son’s son</i> (v. 31). It does not say the same with regard to Sarai. It merely says, <i>and Sarai his daughter-in-law</i>.</i> It is possible that Terah’s son Nahor left for Haran before his father. On the other hand he may have left for Haran after his father went there.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible doesn’t mention that Terah took Nahor as it does with regard to Abraham. However, we find Nahor’s children living in Haran. Thus it appears that he, too, journeyed there, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It appears to me that the portion containing the command, <i>Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father’s house, unto the land that I will show thee</i> (Gen. 12:1), was conveyed to Abraham before what is recorded in the verse reading, <i>And Terah took Abram…Lot…Sarai…to go into the land of Canaan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 12:1 occurred before Gen. 11:31.</i> Similarly elsewhere the Pentateuch states, <i>And the Lord spoke unto Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the tent of meeting, on the first day of the second month, in the second year after they were come out of the land of Egypt</i> (Num. 1:1); and then, <i>And it came to pass in the first month in the second year</i> (Ex. 40:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Prima facie</i> this is a difficult comment. Num. 1:1 follows Ex. 40:17; hence the verses are in chronological sequence. I.E. probably intended to cite Num. 9:1, rather than Ex. 40:17. The former literally reads: In the second year…in the first month. He apparently cited from memory and misquoted. Perhaps he wanted to note that Num. 7 records the setting up of the Tabernacle and the sacrifices then offered by the princes of the tribes. However, Ex. 40:17 tells us that the tabernacle was erected on the first day of the first month in the second year following the Exodus. We thus see that what is described in Num. 1 occurred after what is described in Num. 7 (Krinsky).</i> Proof of the above<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">That <i>Get thee out</i>, etc., was told to Abraham before <i>And Terah took</i>, etc. If God had not yet told Abraham to go to Canaan, why did Terah take his family there? I.E. apparently believes that the impetus behind Terah’s journey to Canaan was God’s command to Abraham, recorded in Gen. 12:1 (Weiser).</i> is found in <i>And they went forth…to go into the land of Canaan</i> (v. 31). When Terah came to Haran, the place found favor in his eyes. He settled there and eventually died there. The general rule thus is that the Bible does not always list events in chronological order.

Chapter 12



Verse 1

GET THEE OUT. God commanded Abraham while he was yet in Ur of the Chaldees to leave his country, his place of birth and also his father’s house. The reason God told Abraham to leave his father’s house is that the Lord knew that, although he set out for Canaan, Terah would settle in Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra implies that had Terah gone to Canaan then God would not have commanded Abraham to separate himself from his father.</i> Terah did not die until sixty years after Abraham left his father’s house in Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Terah was 70 when Abraham was born (Gen. 11:26). Abraham was 75 when he left Haran (Gen. 12:4). Terah was thus 145 when Abraham left him. Terah lived 205 years (Gen. 11:32). Hence Terah lived another 60 years after Abraham left Haran. Thus the command “Get thee out” could not have come after Terah’s death, as a cursory reading of Scripture would indicate (Krinsky).</i> However, the Bible does not tell us how old he was when he left Ur of the Chaldees.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>He</i> refers to Abraham (Cherez). The Bible tells us how old Abraham was when he left Haran (v. 4) but does not tell us his age when he left Ur of the Chaldees. Had the Bible told us this, we would then know how long Abraham dwelt in Haran. Weiser explains <i>he</i> as referring to Terah. I.E.’s point remains the same.</i> After telling Abraham to go <i>unto the land that I will show thee</i>, God revealed his secret to him,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">He told him which land He had in mind.</i> for we read: <i>and they went forth to go into the land of Canaan</i> (v. 5). It is also possible <i>that I will show thee</i> refers to <i>for all the land which thou seest, to thee will I give it</i> (Gen. 13:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of the phrase is: the land which I will show thee will I give to thee (Cohen). Abraham went from place to place. When he came to Canaan God then told him, this is the land that I have chosen for you (Cherez). According to this interpretation God did not at this point reveal to Abraham his ultimate destination.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

THEM THAT BLESS THEE. This word is in the plural.
AND HIM THAT CURSETH THEE. This word is in the singular.

Verse 4



Verse 5

THEIR SUBSTANCE. Their cattle.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The term used by Ibn Ezra is <i>mikneh</i>, which includes cows, sheep, asses and camels.</i> <i>Rekhusham</i> (their substance) in <i>And the land was not able to bear them…for their</i> (rekhusham) <i>substance</i> (i.e., their cattle) <i>was great</i> (Gen. 13:6) is similar.
AND THE SOULS THAT THEY HAD GOTTEN IN HARAN. Servants born into their household.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Had gotten</i> thus means: were born to them (Weiser).</i> It is also possible that <i>had gotten</i> means bought.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Previously Ibn Ezra explained <i>gotten</i> as meaning born. He now explains it to mean bought (Weiser).</i> <i>Hath gotten</i> in <i>My power and the might of my hand hath gotten me this wealth</i> (Deut. 8:17) is similar. Others say that <i>the souls that they had gotten in Haran</i> refers to the people to whom Abraham showed the truth, to worship God.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 39:14. Cf. Rashi.</i>
[AND THEY WENT FORTH TO GO.] To the place that God had told them to go.

Verse 6

[SHECHEM.] Shechem<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Like Ur of the Chaldees.</i> was the name used by Moses because it was the name by which the city was known in his time. Shechem was not yet born in Abraham’s day.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ibn Ezra, Shechem was named after Shechem son of Hamor. Cf. Gen. 34:2.</i>
TEREBINTH. <i>Elon</i> (terebinth) has the same meaning as <i>elah</i> (terebinth).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Is. 6:13 and Hos. 4:13. <i>Elon</i> is a type of <i>elah</i> (Krinsky).</i> They are trees. Others say that <i>elon</i> means a field,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the field of Paran, as seen from Gen. 14:6. See also Onkelos on this verse.</i> as in <i>unto El paran</i> (Gen. 14:6).
MOREH. Some identify him with Mamre, the confederate of Abraham. However, it is possible they are not to be so identified and Elon Moreh is the name of a place.
AND THE CANAANITE WAS THEN IN THE LAND. It is possible that the Canaanites seized the land of Canaan from some other tribe at that time.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The Canaanite was then, not before this, in the land. Cf. Rashi: “The Canaanite was then engaged in conquering the land of Israel from the seed of Shem.”</i> Should this interpretation be incorrect, then there is a secret meaning to the text. Let the one who understands it remain silent.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The verse implies that the Canaanite was in the land then but not now (Krinsky). Since the Canaanite was in the land during the days of Moses, this clause would appear to be post-Mosaic.</i>

Verse 7

AND THE LORD APPEARED. In a prophetic vision. <i>Va-yera</i> (appeared) is a <i>nifal</i>. It is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> to make up for the <i>dagesh</i> which should have been placed in the <i>resh</i> as compensation for the missing <i>nun</i> of the <i>nifal</i> conjugation.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>nun</i> of the <i>nifal</i> is omitted in the imperfect. Hence all imperfect <i>nifal</i> forms have a <i>dagesh</i> in the first letter of the root, i.e., <i>yikkatev</i>, rather than <i>yikhatev</i>. However, the <i>resh</i> of <i>ra’ah</i> (saw), from the root <i>resh, alef, heh</i>, cannot receive a <i>dagesh</i>. Hence it is preceded by a <i>tzere</i>, rather than a <i>chirik</i>. <i>Va-yera</i> is an imperfect changed into a perfect by the <i>vav</i> conversive.</i>
WHO APPEARED UNTO HIM. <i>Nireh</i> is a participle belonging to the above-mentioned conjugation (<i>nifal</i>). <i>Na’aseh</i> (prepared) in <i>Now that which was prepared</i> (na’aseh) <i>for one day</i> (Neh. 5:18) is similar.

Verse 8

AND HE REMOVED. <i>Va-yatek</i> (and he removed) is a transitive verb, in the <i>hifil</i>. However, <i>ve-yetak</i> (removed) in <i>Or shall the rock be removed</i> (ve-yetak) <i>out of its place</i> (Job 18:4) is intransitive. The object of <i>And he removed</i> is <i>his tent</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>va-yatek</i> (and he removed) is transitive, it does not mean he removed himself but he removed his tent.</i> <i>His tent</i> is also the object of <i>he pitched</i>. The meaning (of <i>va-yatek</i>) is: he caused to move. <i>Va-yet</i> (he pitched) is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> to make up for the missing <i>nun</i> which is the first root letter of <i>va-yet</i> (he pitched).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>va-yet</i> (pitched) is <i>nun, tet, ayin</i>. We would have expected the word to be vocalized with a <i>chirik</i>. Compare, <i>va-yitteh</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> <i>Ve-yez</i> (is dashed) in <i>And their lifeblood is dashed</i> (ve-yez) (Is. 63:3) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>ve-yez</i> (is dashed) is <i>nun, zayin, heh</i>.</i> Both are transitive verbs.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yatek</i> and <i>va-yet</i> (Krinsky) or <i>va-yet</i> and <i>ve-yez</i> (Cherez).</i>
[ON THE WEST.] The word <i>mi-yam</i> means on the west. <i>Yam</i> (sea) means west because the great Spanish Sea (<i>yam</i>, i.e., the Mediterranean) is the western border of the land of Israel. The latter sea is not the Atlantic, the Atlantic being far from the aforementioned country. Abraham journeyed from east of Beth-el westward until Ai was east of his camp.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. assumes that Abraham journeyed from east to west. He crossed over Ai but stopped before Beth-el. Thus Beth-el was on his west and Ai on his east. However, the interpretation presents a problem. Shechem lies north of Beth-el and Ai. Thus Abraham traveled south not west.</i>
[AND CALLED UPON THE NAME OF THE LORD.] This means he prayed there. It may also mean that he called upon men to worship the Lord.

Verse 9

TOWARD THE SOUTH. <i>Negev</i> means south and it means the same in Aramaic.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that <i>negev</i> is an Aramaic word.</i> <i>Negev</i> in Aramaic means dry as we see from Onkelos, who renders <i>the waters were dried up</i> (Gen. 8:13) as <i>negivu mayya</i>. The south is called <i>Negev</i> (dry) because it is hot there, and the heat parches the land. This is the way <i>for that thou hast set me in the Southlands</i> (eretz ha-negev)<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>eretz ha-negev</i> means a dry land.</i> <i>give me therefore springs of water</i> (Josh. 15:19) should be understood.

Verse 10

AND THERE WAS A FAMINE IN THE LAND. In the land of Canaan.

Verse 11

WHEN HE WAS COME NEAR. When he caused his camp to come near.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. takes <i>hikriv</i> (he came near) to be a transitive verb, its meaning being: when he caused to come near, i.e., when he caused his camp to come near.</i> On the other hand, <i>hikriv</i> (when he came near) may be intransitive.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In this case <i>hikriv</i> is to be rendered, when he came near.</i> These two interpretations are possible because there are verbs which can be transitive and intransitive.
[NOW.] <i>Na</i> means now. <i>Na</i> in <i>Behold now</i> (na), <i>I am old</i> (Gen. 27:2), and <i>Woe</i> (na) <i>unto us</i> (Lam. 5:16)<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ibn Ezra this should be rendered: woe now unto us.</i> are similar. The reverse of Hebrew is the case in Arabic.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The Arabic word for now is <i>malan</i>, rather than <i>malna</i> (Weiser).</i>
[BEHOLD NOW, I KNOW.] There were women as beautiful as Sarah in her native country,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture emphasizes <i>now I know</i>, i.e., before I didn’t. This is so because in the country from which she came there were other beautiful women. In Egypt Sarah’s beauty stood out.</i> but in Egypt and the southern land there was none as beautiful. The reason for this is that people’s appearance is shaped by the climate.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the climate of southern countries is not conducive to the development of beautiful women.</i>
[BUT THEE THEY WILL KEEP ALIVE.] They will provide for all of your needs. Abraham said this because those were days of famine.

Verse 12



Verse 13

[THOU ART MY SISTER.] <i>Achoti</i> (my sister) is penultimately accented<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Ordinarily the accent would be placed on the last syllable.</i> because the word which follows it, <i>at</i> (thou), is accented on the first letter. <i>Kara laylah</i> (he called night) (Gen. 1:5) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Ordinarily the accent would be placed on the last syllable of <i>kara</i>.</i> The preceding is a general rule in Hebrew grammar.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">When the cantillical notes connect two words and the second word is penultimately accented, so is the first word even though it is ordinarily ultimately accented.</i> The <i>tav</i> of <i>at</i> (thou) receives a <i>dagesh</i> to make up for the missing <i>nun</i>, for the word <i>at</i> (thou) comes from the same root as <i>ani</i> (I).<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Hence thou in the feminine should be <i>ant</i>, in the masculine <i>antah</i> (Netter). The printed editions read, the word <i>attah</i> comes from the same root as <i>ani. Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, the word <i>at</i> comes from the same root as <i>ani</i>. Since I.E. deals with the feminine, the reading of Vat. Ebr. 38 is to be preferred.</i>
BECAUSE OF THEE. <i>Bi-glalekh</i> (because of thee) and <i>ba-avurekh</i> (for thy sake) always have a <i>bet</i> prefixed to each.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The forms <i>gelalekh</i> (<i>gelal</i>) or <i>avurekh</i> (<i>avur</i>) are not used.</i> The poet who omits this <i>bet</i> errs.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, turns aside from discretion. Ibn Ezra uses a term from Prov. 11:22, <i>As a ring of gold in a swine’s snout, So is a fair woman that turneth aside from discretion</i>. He implies that the poet who deliberately misuses language is like a fair woman who turns aside from discretion. The reference might be to Rabbi Simon ben Isaac of Mayence, an eleventh century liturgical poet who wrote, <i>avur ki fanah yom</i> (now that the day has declined). He should have written <i>ba-avur fanah yom</i>. Rabbi Simon’s composition is found in the concluding service of the Day of Atonement (Cherez). It should be noted that I.E. employs a pun. <i>Shar</i> is a poet. <i>Sar</i> means tumeth aside, hence <i>ha-shar sar</i>, the poet turneth aside.</i>
[THAT IT MAY BE WELL WITH ME.] They will give me gifts and presents. And so it is written, <i>And he dealt well with Abram for her sake; and he had sheep, and oxen, and he-asses, and men-servants, and maid-servant, and she-asses, and camels</i> (v. 16).

Verse 14



Verse 15

[AND PRAISED]. The <i>dagesh</i> which should have been placed in the first <i>lamed</i> of <i>va-yehalelu</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yehalelu</i> (they praised) is a <i>pi’el</i>. According to the rules of Hebrew grammar a <i>dagesh</i> is placed in the middle letter of the root in a verb conjugated in the <i>pi’el</i>.</i> (and praised) is omitted in order to simplify the word’s pronunciation.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yehalelu</i> is, as noted above, a <i>pi’el</i> and should thus have a <i>dagesh</i> in its middle root letter. However, a <i>dagesh</i> would double the <i>lamed</i>. Thus the word would read as if there were three <i>lameds</i> in it, viz., <i>va-yehallelu</i>, and complicate its pronunciation.</i> <i>Va-etpalelah</i> (and I prayed) (Dan. 9:4) is identical.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-etpalelah</i> is in the <i>hitpa’el</i>. Here, too, a <i>dagesh</i> is placed in the middle root letter. However, it is omitted in our word for the reasons indicated in note 37.</i>
AND THE WOMAN WAS TAKEN. <i>Va-tukkach</i> (and she was taken) is a <i>hofal</i>. This is so even though it is not found in the <i>hifil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hofal</i> is the passive form of <i>hifil</i>. If a word is found in the passive voice we would expect it to be found in the active voice as well. However, this is not the case with the root <i>lamed, kof, chet</i>, which is found in the <i>hofal</i> and not in the <i>hifil</i>.</i> <i>Va-tushlekhi</i> (but thou wast cast out) (Ezek. 16:5) is an example of a <i>hofal</i> wherein the entire root is present.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">In the root <i>lamed, kof, chet</i> (take) the <i>lamed</i> drops out in the imperfect. In <i>shin, lamed, caf</i> (cast) no letter drops out. It belongs to those verbs classified as <i>shelemim</i>, whole roots.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17

AND THE LORD PLAGUED PHARAOH…BECAUSE OF SARAI. The term <i>al devar</i> means because. <i>Al devar</i>’s meaning is <i>al zeh ha-davar</i> (on account of this thing).<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>al devar</i> means because. According to the Midrash <i>al devar Sarai</i> means according to Sarah’s word. (Cf. Rashi.) Hence I.E.’s comment.</i>

Verse 18

[THOU TELL ME.] The root of <i>higgadta</i> (thou tell) is <i>nun, gimel, dalet</i>.

Verse 19

[SO I TOOK HER TO BE MY WIFE.] This indicates that Pharaoh took her to be his wife, to sleep with her. God brought plagues upon him to prevent him from touching her. The Lord sent these plagues to protect the wife of the one whom he loved. The plagues were so severe that Pharaoh was unable to touch Sarah. The following is analogous: <i>When thou goest forth to battle against thine enemies…and seest among the captives a woman of goodly form, and thou hast a desire unto her, and takest her to thee to wife</i>. The Bible then says, <i>then thou shalt bring her home to thy house; and she shall shave her head</i>. It then concludes, <i>and after that thou mayest go in unto her</i> (Deut. 21:10-13).<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra argues that wife here has the meaning of a sexual partner as it does in Deuteronomy. For it first says, “and takest her to thee to wife” and concludes with “thou mayest go into her” (Weiser). Krinsky and Cherez argue that I.E. was disturbed by the term <i>took her</i> which implies that Pharaoh had intercourse with Sarah. Hence I.E. points out that Scripture is merely relating Pharaoh’s intentions; i.e., he <i>took her</i> to be his wife but God intervened before he had a chance to sleep with her. I.E. quotes Deut 21:10 where “and thou takest her to wife” similarly does not mean “and sleeps with her” because one cannot have intercourse with a captive woman until certain procedures described in Deut. 21 are first undergone.</i>
[AND GO THY WAY.] The <i>vav</i> of <i>va-lekh</i> (and go thy way) is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>vav</i> would ordinarily be vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>.</i> because it is prefixed to a word with a cantillical note that ends a phrase. The <i>vav</i> of <i>va-yayin</i> (and wine) in <i>bread and wine</i> (Gen. 14:18) is similar.

Verse 20

AND THEY BROUGHT HIM ON THE WAY. They honorably escorted him.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yeshallechu oto</i> (and they brought him on the way) might conceivably be translated as they sent him away; i.e., they expelled him, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> <i>And Abraham went with them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham obviously did not expel the angels, he accompanied them out of respect.</i> <i>to bring them on the way</i> (Gen. 18:16) is similar.
[AND PHARAOH GAVE MEN CHARGE CONCERNING HIM.] It appears to me that this clause indicates that Pharaoh issued a command to his people concerning Abraham. He warned and charged that it be announced that no one harm Abraham and his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>gave men charge concerning him</i> is not to be connected to <i>and they brought him on the way</i>. <i>Gave men charge</i>, etc., means he issued commands that Abraham not be molested; <i>and they brought him on the way</i> means they escorted him. I.E. interprets this verse thus because he believes that the word <i>tzivvah</i> (commanded, charged) with the preposition <i>al</i> (on) involves a prohibition. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 2:16 (Filwarg).</i>

Chapter 13



Verse 1

[AND ABRAM WENT UP.] I have grammatically explained the word <i>va-ya’al</i> (and went up) in my <i>Book of Foundation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-ya’al</i> (and he went up) is short for <i>va-ya’aleh</i>.</i>

Verse 2

AND ABRAM WAS VERY RICH. <i>Ve-avram kaved me’od</i> (literally, Abram was very heavy) means that Abraham had great wealth. Whoever is laden with riches moves heavily (with difficulty).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the use of the term <i>kaved</i> (heavy) for rich.</i> Don’t you see that the Hebrew word for honor (<i>kavod</i>) comes from the same root as the word for heavy (<i>koved</i>) in <i>A stone is heavy</i> (koved even) (Prov. 27:3). Conversely, the word for shame (<i>kalon</i>) comes from the same root as the word for light (<i>kal</i>). Compare, <i>light of foot</i> (kal beraglav) (II Sam. 2:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the root <i>caf, bet, dalet</i> in its various forms means heavy. <i>Kavod</i> (honor) really means heavy with glory. Similarly <i>kaved</i> means heavy with possessions. Conversely, <i>kalon</i> comes from “light,” i.e., not burdened with glory.</i> Abraham possessed herds of cattle and a large amount of gold and silver.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the Bible describes Abraham as being <i>kaved</i>, heavy because of his possessions (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 3

ON HIS JOURNEYS. Abraham made many stops on his journey from the south to Beth-el which is in the north. He came <i>unto the place of the altar</i> (v. 4) to give thanks to God for ensuring his safe return.

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND TENTS. I believe that <i>ohel</i> (tent), in the singular, follows the paradigm of <i>kodesh</i> (holy). It is always found in Scripture following this form.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kodesh</i> is vocalized <i>cholam, segol</i>. Similarly, <i>ohel</i>. The latter is the term used in the Bible for tent.</i> In the plural, its <i>alef</i> is vocalized with a <i>chataf kamatz</i>, as in the verse <i>ye shall dwell in tents</i> (Jer. 35:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The plural of <i>kodesh</i> is similarly vocalized with a <i>chataf kamatz</i> beneath the <i>kof</i>.</i> It is vocalized like the word <i>kodashim</i> in <i>he shall not eat of the holy things</i> (ba-kodashim) (Lev. 22:4). However, when the <i>alef</i> of the Hebrew plural for tents is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>, the singular is vocalized like <i>goral</i> (lot).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Vocalized <i>cholam kamatz</i>. In our verse tents (<i>ohalim</i>) is vocalized with a cholam. Hence its singular cannot be <i>ohel</i>, for the singular of <i>ohalim</i> is <i>ohal</i> (<i>cholam kamatz</i>). I. E.’s point is that the Hebrew word for tent can come in two forms, <i>ohel</i> or <i>ohal</i>.</i> The latter is so even though this form for tent (<i>ohal</i>) is not found in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">If this is so, we would expect to find the form <i>ohal</i> in Scripture. However, it does not appear there. Nevertheless, I.E. insists that what he says is so.</i>

Verse 6

TOGETHER. <i>Yachdav</i> (together) can refer to two (as in our verse) or to many, as in <i>And all the people answered together</i> (yachdav) (Ex. 19:8). This word does not follow the rules of Hebrew grammar.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">It does not have a <i>yod</i> between the <i>chet</i> and the <i>vav</i> as do all other similar plural forms (Weiser).</i> <i>Yachdav</i> is not synonymous with <i>yachad</i> (together). <i>Yachdav</i> means acting like one person.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">That is, their individuality is blended, as in <i>And all the people answered together</i> (yachdav) (Ex. 19:8), which means that all the people answered as if they were one person. <i>Yachad</i> implies two people acting at the same time, but each one by himself (Weiser).</i> 

Verse 7

[AND THE CANAANITE AND THE PERIZZITE DWELT THEN IN THE LAND.] This is to be understood as its counterpart (Gen. 12:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">That is, I.E.’s comments on <i>And the Canaanite was then in the land</i> (Gen. 12:6) also apply here.</i> It is possible that Perizzi was a son of Canaan and was included in the list of Canaan’s sons under a different name. He, like the prophet Samuel’s son<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">I Sam. 8:2 states, <i>Now the name of his (Samuel’s) first-born was Joel</i>. However, I Chron. 6:13 states, <i>And the sons of Samuel: the first-born Vashni</i>. Thus Samuel’s first-born had two names.</i> and grandfather,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The name of Samuel’s great grandfather is given as Elihu (I Sam. 1:1), Eliab (I Chron. 6:12) and Eliel (I Chron. 6:19). Thus he had three names. All these sources agree that Samuel’s grandfather’s name was Jeroham. Therefore I.E. must have meant Samuel’s great-grandfather rather than his grandfather. Krinsky and Weiser suggest that grandfather is short for great-grandfather.</i> had two names.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 10:15-18 lists the 10 sons of Canaan. The Perizzites are not mentioned. I.E. surmises that he is mentioned under a different name.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9

THEN I WILL GO TO THE RIGHT. <i>Ve-e’minah</i> (I will go to the right) comes from the same root as <i>yamin</i> (right).
[THEN I WILL GO TO THE LEFT.] The <i>alef</i> of the noun <i>semol</i> (left) is enunciated in the verb <i>ve-asme’ilah</i> (then I will go to the left). Now this <i>alef</i> is missing in the word <i>hasmili</i> (direct thyself to the left) in <i>Go thee one way to the right, or direct thyself to the left</i> (Ezek. 21:21). Thus, we cannnot determine whether the <i>alef</i> is part of the root of <i>semol</i> or not.

Verse 10

THE PLAIN OF THE JORDAN. <i>Kikkar</i> (plain) means an area with plants. The <i>caf</i> is doubled in <i>kikkar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The word for an area with plants being <i>kar</i>, as in Is. 30:23. Our word reads <i>kikkar</i> because the <i>caf</i> is doubled.</i> On the other hand, it is possible that one <i>caf</i> has been dropped in <i>kar nirchav</i> (large pastures) (Is. 30:23).<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The basic word being <i>kikkar</i>.</i> Similarly <i>bat</i> (apple of) in <i>bat ayin</i> (the apple of the eye) (Ps. 17:8) is short for <i>bavat</i> in <i>bavat eno</i> (the apple of his eye) (Zechariah 2:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>bet</i> has been dropped in <i>bat</i>, for the full word is <i>bavat</i>, with two <i>bets</i> (Krinsky). Others interpret: “Similarly we do not know whether a <i>bet</i> has been dropped out in <i>bat</i>, or a <i>bet</i> is doubled in <i>bavat</i>” (Weiser, Cherez). The text supports Krinsky.</i>
WELL WATERED. <i>Mashkeh</i> (watered) is masculine; <i>khullah</i> (well) is feminine.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">If Scripture were consistent the phrase would have read <i>khullah mashkah</i>.</i> <i>A fire not blown by man shall consume him</i> (Job 20:26)<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Te’okhlehu</i> (shall consume him) is feminine; <i>nuppach</i> (blown) is masculine. Hence Scripture uses both a masculine and feminine word in reference to the same thing (fire). It does the same in our verse with regard to <i>kikkar</i>.</i> is similar.
BEFORE THE LORD DESTROYED SODOM AND GOMORRAH. <i>Shachet</i> (destroyed) is an infinitive in the <i>pi’el</i>. The meaning of <i>li-fene shachet</i> is: before the Lord destroyed.

Verse 11

AND LOT JOURNEYED. From the east,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This is I.E.’s translation of <i>va-yissa lot mi-kedem</i> (and Lot journeyed east). According to I.E., Lot journeyed west to Sodom, away from Abraham who was in Beth-el. The problem with I.E.’s interpretation is that Sodom lies east, not west of Beth-el. Because of this difficulty the Midrash homiletically interprets the clause to mean: He removed himself from the ancient one (<i>mi-kedem</i>) of the universe saying, I desire neither Abraham or his God (<i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 41:7). As to the problem raised by Sodom lying east of Beth-el, Weiser suggests that in order to reach Sodom from Beth-el one had to journey westward first and then eastward. However, this interpretation is forced. M.S. Siegal in his commentary on Genesis suggests that <i>mi-kedem</i> here has the meaning of eastward, or that <i>mi-kedem</i> is short for <i>mi-kedem levet-el</i>; i.e., Lot journeyed east of Beth-el, where Abram had pitched his tent. As to I.E., he most probably was not aware that Sodom lies east and not west of Beth-el.</i> for Sodom is west of Beth-el.

Verse 12

AND MOVED HIS TENT. Pitched his tent.

Verse 13

NOW THE MEN OF SODOM WERE WICKED. To their fellow man. This is stated in Ezekiel, viz., <i>neither did she (Sodom) strengthen the hand of the poor and needy</i> (Ezek. 16:49).

Verse 14



Verse 15

FOR ALL THE LAND WHICH THOU SEEST, TO THEE WILL I GIVE IT. By word.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham did not take actual possession of Canaan.</i> <i>And he shall put them (Israel’s sins and transgressions) upon the head of the goat</i> (Lev. 16:21) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the term “give” can be applied to a verbal statement (Weiser).</i> 

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

In this chapter Scripture informs us that the terebinths of Mamre are located in Hebron.

Chapter 14



Verse 1

KING OF GOIIM. Goiim like Elam<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Which is also mentioned in our verse.</i> is the name of a state. Elam must be the name of a state because <i>shushan ha-birah</i>, which means <i>Shushan the palace</i>, was located in it.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Dan 8:2 reads: <i>I was in shushan the castle</i> (shushan ha-birah) <i>which is in the province of Elam</i>. We thus see that Elam was the name of the state and Shushan the name of the palace.</i> On the other hand, <i>king of Goiim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Goy</i> in Hebrew means a nation.</i> may be rendered as king of nations, Scripture not stating their names. The meaning of the verse is that Tidal was king over nations other than Shinar, Ellasar and Elam.

Verse 2



Verse 3

ALL THESE CAME AS ALLIES. <i>Chaveru</i> (came as allies) is in the <i>kal</i>.
THE VALE OF SIDDIM. <i>Siddim</i> means the same<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sid</i> means lime, whitewash or plaster. Hence the valley of Siddim means the valley of plaster. It was so called because of the plaster pits found there.</i> as <i>sid</i> (plaster) in <i>and plaster them with plaster</i> (ba-sid)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Spelled <i>sin, yod, dalet</i>. I.E.’s point is that <i>siddim</i> means the same as <i>sid</i>. However, they come from different roots. <i>Sid</i> in Deut. 27:2 comes from the root <i>sin, vav, dalet</i>. <i>Siddim</i> comes from <i>sin, dalet, dalet</i>, which is also the root of the word <i>sad</i> in Job 13:27. <i>Siddim</i> cannot be the plural of <i>sid</i> (Deut. 27:2) because it is spelled without a <i>yod</i> and has a <i>dagesh</i> in its <i>dalet</i>. I.E.’s point is that <i>sad</i> and <i>sid</i> mean the same although they come from different roots (Weiser).</i> (Deut. 27:2) and <i>sad</i> (plaster) in <i>Thou puttest my feet also in the plaster</i> (ba-sad)<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">This is I.E.’s interpretation of the verse. In Job he explains the verse to mean God had plastered Job’s feet with whitewash so that He could follow Job’s every step. I.E. points out that <i>siddim</i> is the plural of <i>sad</i> in Job. The <i>sin</i> and <i>samach</i> interchange.</i> (Job 13:27). <i>Sad, siddim</i>, is like <i>pat</i> (morsel of bread), <i>pittim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">We would expect the plural of <i>sad</i> (Job. 13:27) to be <i>saddim</i>. I.E. points out that this is not necessarily so. Thus the plural of <i>pat</i> is <i>pittim</i> and not <i>pattim</i>. Similarly the plural of <i>sad</i> is <i>siddim</i> and not <i>saddim</i> (Krinsky and Cherez).</i>
VALE. The word vale is to be understood as if written twice. It is like the word <i>al</i> (not) in <i>O Lord, rebuke me not</i> (al) <i>in Thine anger; Neither</i> (ve-al) <i>chasten me in Thy wrath</i> (Ps. 6:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, the word <i>al</i> is to be read as if written twice. It should be noted that the word <i>al</i> does appear twice in our verse. I.E. probably had Ps. 38:2 in mind. There the text literally reads, <i>O, Lord, rebuke me not</i> (al) <i>in Thine anger, chasten me in Thy wrath</i>. I.E. says that the verse should be read, O Lord rebuke me not (<i>al</i>) in Thine anger, chasten me not (<i>al</i>) in Thy wrath. I.E. probably cited from memory and misquoted.</i> Our verse should be read as follows: All these came as allies unto the vale of Siddim, the same is the vale of the Salt Sea.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The text literally reads: <i>the vale of Siddim, the same is the Salt Sea</i>.</i>

Verse 4

[AND IN THE THIRTEENTH YEAR THEY REBELLED.] <i>U-shelosh esreh</i> (and the thirteenth) should be interpreted <i>u-ve-shelosh esreh</i> (and in the thirteenth).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: <i>U-shelosh esreh shanah</i> (and thirteen years). I.E. says, <i>u-shelosh esreh</i> should be read as if a <i>bet</i> were prefixed to <i>shelosh</i>, i.e., <i>u-ve-shelosh esreh</i>.</i> It is similar to the word <i>sheshet</i> (six) in <i>for in six</i> (sheshet) <i>days the Lord made the heaven and earth</i> (Ex. 20:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: <i>for six days the Lord made heaven and earth</i>. Thus <i>sheshet</i> is to be read as if written <i>ve-sheshet</i> (in six).</i> However, the author of the <i>Seder Olam</i> did not interpret it this way. He combined the years mentioned in our verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Seder Olam</i> I. The <i>Seder Olam</i> interprets <i>u-shelosh esreh shanah</i> to mean, and 13 years; i.e., they rebelled 13 years. It adds these 13 years to the 12 years mentioned previously in our verse and claims that the Bible deals with a 25-year period, 12 of service and 13 years of rebellion.</i> His mind was greater than ours.

Verse 5

THE REPHAIM. They were called <i>Rephaim</i> (ghosts) because their appearance was so terrifying that whoever saw them died and was considered to be one of the <i>Rephaim</i>, one of the dead.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Rephaim has the meaning of dead, shades or ghosts. Cf. Is. 14:9. They were called <i>Rephaim</i> because those who saw them were frightened to death. <i>Rephaim</i> were thus considered to be death-inducing.</i>
THE EMIM. They were so called because they were frightening.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Emah</i> means fear.</i>

Verse 6

IN THEIR MOUNT SEIR. <i>Be-hareram</i> (in their mount) is in the <i>pi’el</i>. Its meaning is: when they went up to Mount Seir.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that <i>be-hareram</i> is not a noun with a pronominal suffix meaning their mountain. He holds that it is a verb with the pronominal suffix.</i> It is like the word <i>be-dabberam</i> (when they spoke) (Ex. 7:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Which is a <i>pi’el</i> verb with a pronominal suffix.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

AGAINST CHEDORLAOMER. With Chedorlaomer.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew has <i>et Chedorlaomer</i>. <i>Et</i> usually indicates the object, hence I.E.’s comment that <i>et</i> here has the meaning of <i>im</i> (with).</i>

Verse 10

PITS. <i>Be’er</i> (pit) in the Bible means a bubbling well. Its (pits) vocalization is exceptional because it is in the construct.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">With <i>chemar</i> (slime). <i>Be’er</i> is vocalized <i>sheva tzere</i>. In our verse it is vocalized <i>segol, chataf segol</i>. I.E. points out that this is so because the word is in the construct with <i>chemar</i> (slime). In other words, when <i>be’er</i> refers to live wells it is vocalized <i>sheva tzere</i>; when it refers to pits it is vocalized <i>segol, chataf segol</i> (Krinsky, Netter, Cherez). Or what I.E. means is that the word’s vowels change because it is in the construct (Filwarg).</i>
AND THEY FELL THERE. They deliberately fell there, in their desire to escape.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">That is, they hid themselves.</i> <i>And when Moses heard it, he fell upon his face</i> (Num. 16:4) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Moses willingly fell on his face.</i>
FLED TO THE MOUNTAIN. The phrase <i>herah nasu</i> is to be rendered: fled to the mountain. The word <i>herah</i> (to the mountain) is an irregular form.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">We would expect <i>he-harah</i> (Weiser).</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12

WHO DWELT IN SODOM. Lot was dwelling in Sodom on that day.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">His tent was usually outside of Sodom, cf. Gen. 13:12 (Weiser). Krinsky suggests that I.E. intends to say that Lot’s tent was close to Sodom on that day, or by that day he had become a dweller in Sodom. On the other hand, Filwarg suggests that I.E. is trying to explain why <i>yoshev</i> (dwelt; literally, dwells) is in the present when all the verbs pertaining to this incident are in the past. I.E.’s point is that “dwelling” is to be understood as: was dwelling.</i> 

Verse 13

[AND THERE CAME ONE THAT HAD ESCAPED.] <i>Palit</i> (one that had escaped) refers to a Sodomite who escaped and saved himself. <i>Palit</i> in <i>one that had escaped</i> (palit) <i>out of Jerusalem came unto me</i> (Ezek. 33:21) is similar. There is a Midrashic interpretation concerning the escapee.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash identifies the escapee as Og, King of Bashan, the same individual who escaped the flood by hanging on to Noah’s ark. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 42:8.</i>

Verse 14

HE LED FORTH HIS TRAINED MEN. He armed them.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>va-yarek</i> (he led forth) means he armed.</i> Compare, <i>ve-harek</i> (arm) in, <i>Arm</i> (ve-harek) <i>with the spear</i> (Ps. 35:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s translation of this verse.</i> Others say that <i>va-yarek</i> refers to the unsheathing of the sword. Compare, <i>They empty themselves</i> (yariku) <i>upon the earth</i> (Eccles. 11:3), and <i>emptied</i> (merikim) <i>their sacks</i> (Gen. 42:35).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>va-yarek et chanikhav</i> (he led forth his trained men) means, he gave his trained men unsheathed swords (Krinsky).</i> A spear also has a sheath.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>ve-harek chanit</i> (Ps. 35:3) may be rendered as unsheath the spear.</i>
HIS TRAINED MEN. Abraham had trained them many times for battle. This is the meaning of the term <i>chanikhav</i> (his trained men) even though Scripture does not previously note that Abraham trained young men for war. Those who identify Abraham’s trained men with his servant Eliezer on the basis of the numerical value of the latter’s name are indulging in Midrash,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Interpreted numerically, Eliezer comes to 318. Hence the Midrash identifies him with the 318 men mentioned in our verse. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 43:2, 44:9.</i> as Scripture does not speak in <i>gematria</i> (numericals). With this type of interpretation one can interpret any name as he wishes, both in a positive and a negative manner. Eliezer is to be taken literally.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">It is a proper name and not to be interpreted numerically.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

AND MELCHIZEDEK. He was so called because he was king (<i>melech</i>) over a righteous (<i>tzedek</i>) place.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Salem is Jerusalem. Jerusalem is known as <i>the city of righteousness</i> (Is. 1:26).</i> Some identify Melchizedek with Shem.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 56; <i>Nedarim</i> 32b.</i>
SALEM. This is Jerusalem. <i>In Salem also is set His tabernacle, And His dwelling place in Zion</i> (Ps. 76:3) is proof of this.
AND HE WAS PRIEST. This is be rendered as Onkelos does.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">He ministered.</i> Similarly, every time the word “priest” (<i>kohen</i>) is found in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">It means ministers (Cherez).</i> <i>That they may minister unto Me</i> (ve-khihanu li) (Ex. 28:41) is proof of this. The meaning of <i>al divrati Malkitzedek</i> (after the manner of Melchizedek) (Ps. 110:4) will be found in my commentary on Psalms.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra in Ps. 110:4 explains that God promised David that Israel would wage war and David would receive a tithe of the spoils as Melchizedek did (i.e., after the manner of Melchizedek).</i> Melchizedek spoke properly and did the right thing in first blessing Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Before blessing God.</i> because he volunteered to rescue the captives.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Talmud <i>Nedarim</i> 32b, Melchizedek acted improperly in blessing Abraham before God and was punished for it by having the priesthood taken away from his descendants. The Talmud derives this from <i>al divrati Melchizedek</i>, which it interprets to mean because of the improper words spoken by Melchizedek. I.E. hints that the latter phrase cannot be explained this way because Melchizedek spoke and acted properly.</i> He then blessed God for aiding Abraham and delivering Abraham’s adversaries into his hands.

Verse 19



Verse 20

HATH DELIVERED. <i>Miggen</i> (hath delivered) means handed over. <i>Temaggeneka</i> (will she bestow on thee) in <i>A crown of glory will she bestow on thee</i> (temaggeneka) (Prov. 4:9) is similar. The <i>mem</i> of <i>miggen</i> is a root letter. Abraham gave a tithe out of respect for God. He found no one worthier than Melchizedek to bestow his tithe on.

Verse 21



Verse 22

I HAVE LIFTED UP MY HAND. This indicates an oath. It is like, <i>For I lift up my hand to heaven</i>, etc. (Deut. 32:40).
[GOD MOST HIGH.] For behold, I have used the same name for God in my oath as this priest (Melchizedek) when he blessed me.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra explains why Abraham referrred to the Lord as <i>God Most High</i> (El Elyon). He did this out of respect for Melchizedek, who used the term <i>El Elyon</i> in referring to God.</i>

Verse 23

THAT I WILL NOT TAKE A THREAD. That with which garments are sewn.
A SHOE-LATCHET. A strap used to tie a shoe.

Verse 24

SAVE ONLY. Save only that which the young men took. This refers to what Abraham’s servants ate.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Young men</i> thus refers to Abraham’s servants (Weiser).</i>

Chapter 15



Verse 1

IN A VISION. A prophetic vision.
[I AM THY SHIELD.] I was your shield and saved you from the kings. I will also reward you because, of your own free will, leading a small force and relying on Me, you saved your nephew.

Verse 2

[CHILDLESS.] The <i>yod</i> of <i>ariri</i> (childless) is like the <i>yod</i> of <i>achzari</i> (cruel).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">It indicates a state (Weiser). It is not a root letter (Krinsky).</i> The <i>yod</i> is dropped in the plural. Compare, <i>they shall be childless</i> (aririm)<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The plural is <i>aririm</i>, not <i>aririyyim</i> (Weiser). The point is, even though childless is always written <i>ariri</i> and never <i>arir</i>, the second <i>yod</i> never appears in the plural (Krinsky).</i> (Lev. 20:21). Its meaning is as Onkelos explains it.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos translates <i>ariri</i> as childless.</i>
