HE THAT SHALL BE POSSESSOR OF MY HOUSE. <i>Meshek</i> (possessor of) follows the paradigm of <i>meches</i> (levy) (Num. 31:28). It has a root whose second and third letters are identical. It comes from the same root as <i>shokek</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>shin, kof, kof</i>.</i> (leap) in <i>leap upon it</i> (Is. 33:4). It means the same as the word <i>devek</i> (glue)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meshek</i> is like <i>devek</i>; both indicate attachment and both are vocalized <i>segol, segol</i>. According to Cherez, I.E. similarly understands <i>shokek</i> in Is. 33:4. In Zephaniah 2:9, I.E. explains <i>ben meshek</i> as one who never leaves the house.</i> and is also vocalized with a <i>segol</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">It should be noted that <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 omits “with a <i>segol</i>.” It reads: it means the same as glue.</i> The word <i>ben</i> is to be read as if written twice. The verse is to read as follows: <i>and he that shall be possessor of my house</i> (ben meshek beti) is Eliezer, a native of Damascus (<i>ben damesek Eliezer</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: <i>he Damascus Eliezer</i>. I.E. suggests that the word <i>ben</i> be placed before Damascus.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4

OF THY OWN BOWELS. A euphemism for the sexual organ. Bowels is used as a euphemism because the male member is close to them.

Verse 5



Verse 6

RIGHTEOUSNESS. Compare, <i>And it shall be righteousness unto us</i> (Deut. 6:25). <i>Tzedakah</i> (righteousness) is a synonym for justice.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">God considered Abraham’s action as just and right.</i> However, in Rabbinic literature <i>tzedakah</i> has a different meaning.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">There it has the meaning of charity.</i>

Verse 7

THAT BROUGHT THEE OUT OF UR OF THE CHALDEES. This verse proves what I have earlier noted, that God’s command to Abraham, <i>Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred</i>, etc., was given in Ur of the Chaldees, not in Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comment on Gen. 12:1.</i> 
Abraham had complete faith in God’s word that he would beget a son who would be his heir. It was only with regard to the possession of the land that he asked for a sign. He acted like Gideon.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Jud. 6:37. Gideon, also, although he had faith in God, asked Him for a sign (Krinsky). Cherez explains that inheriting the land entailed expelling the Canaanites. The latter were expelled because of their sinfulness (v. 16). As there was a possibility that the Canaanites might repent, Abraham asked for a sign that regardless of what the Canaanites might do, his children would inherit the land. Similarly Gideon asked for a sign that he would be victorious even if the Midianites repented.</i> Furthermore, all prophecies are conditional. God’s oaths, on the other hand, are unconditional.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">God’s initial word to Abraham was prophetic. Hence it was conditional. Had God sworn an oath, Abraham would not have asked for a sign (Krinsky).</i> Hence Abraham did not sin in requesting that a covenant be made between God and himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">That the land of Canaan be unconditionally given to his descendants. I.E.’s view is in contradistinction to a Midrashic view which held that Abraham sinned in asking for a sign. Cf. <i>Nedarim</i> 32a.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9

A SHE-GOAT OF THREE YEARS OLD. Some render <i>ez meshuleshet</i> as three she-goats.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos, Rashi.</i> However, it appears to me that the correct translation of the phrase is: a she-goat three years old.
AND A RAM. A full grown male sheep.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">A ram is a male sheep older than a year (Krinsky).</i>
AND A YOUNG PIGEON. <i>Gozal</i> is a young dove.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>gozal</i> can also be translated as a fledgling. It can thus refer to any bird. Cf. Deut. 32:11.</i> It is to be rendered this way because burnt offerings and other sacrifices were brought only from among the animals and birds mentioned here.

Verse 10

AND DIVIDED THEM IN THE MIDST. He cut them up and separated the pieces. <i>Bater</i> (split) in <i>Upon the split mountains</i> (hare bater)<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s rendering, i.e., mountains that are split or divided by valleys. Cf. Segel’s commentary on Canticles.</i> (Cant. 2:17) and <i>betarav</i> (parts of) in <i>between the parts thereof</i> (betarav) (Jer. 34:18) are analogous to <i>va-yevater</i> (and divided them).
AND LAID EACH HALF OVER AGAINST THE OTHER. Note that the word <i>ish</i> (each)<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ish</i> usually means a man. However, our verse reads, <i>ish bitro</i> (each half) and deals with animals. Hence I.E. explains that <i>ish</i> does not necessarily mean man. Here it refers to animals. Its meaning is, the half of each animal.</i> means the same as <i>ba’al</i>, which means the thing itself. Similarly, <i>ish</i> (man) in <i>The Lord is a man</i> (ish) of <i>war</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">We cannot translate <i>ish milchamah</i> as a man of war, as God is not a man. It must mean: the Lord is a being who wages war (Cherez).</i> (Ex. 15:3); and <i>ish</i> (man) in <i>the man</i> (ve-ha-ish) <i>Gabriel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Gabriel is an angel. Therefore the phrase cannot mean the man Gabriel, but rather Gabriel himself.</i> (Dan. 9:21); and <i>ish</i> (fellow) in <i>a base fellow</i> (ish beliyya’al) (II Sam. 20:1). In the latter verse it is in the construct.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser. This is a most difficult comment. It is hard to understand what I.E. is trying to say. Obviously <i>ish</i> is in the construct with <i>beliyya’al</i>. Cherez writes that he does not understand this comment at all. Filwarg emends <i>ish beliyya’al</i> to <i>ish-ba’al</i> (II Kings 1:8), the point being that we find <i>ish</i> and <i>ba’al</i> in apposition; i.e., <i>ish</i> and <i>ba’al</i> mean the same. Thus <i>ish-ba’al</i> is similar to <i>admat-afar</i> in Dan. 12:2, where <i>admat</i> means the same as <i>afar</i>.</i> <i>Ish</i> is also used in reference to the living creatures seen by Ezekiel,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Their wings were joined one</i> (ishah) <i>to another</i> (Ezek. 1:9).</i> and to the curtains of the Tabernacle, viz., <i>Five curtains shall be coupled together one</i> (ishah) <i>to another</i> (Ex. 26:3). The meaning of our clause is that he placed the piece of each one (<i>ish</i>) over against its counterpart. The term <i>ish</i> is to be so interpreted because man and beast are two different beings.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ish</i> must be interpreted as meaning a thing, the very thing. Otherwise it could not refer both to man and beast since they are totally different beings.</i>
BUT THE BIRDS DIVIDED HE NOT. The turtle dove and the young dove. <i>Tzippor</i> (birds) is a general term.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>tzippor</i> refers both to the turtle dove and to the young dove.</i>

Verse 11

THE BIRDS OF PREY. <i>Ayit</i> (birds of prey) is a type of bird. <i>Ayit</i> (bird of prey) in <i>Is my heritage unto Me as a speckled bird of prey</i> (ha-ayit) (Jer. 12:9) is similar.
UPON THE CARCASSES. On the lifeless bodies.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture uses the term <i>pegarim</i> (carcasses) and not <i>betarim</i> (pieces). The reference is to the carcasses of the turtle dove and the young dove (Krinsky).</i>
AND ABRAM DROVE THEM AWAY. <i>Va-yashev</i> (drove away) has a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>shin</i> to make up for a missing <i>nun</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Its root being <i>nun, shin, bet</i>.</i> He drove them and sent them off the carcasses.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Them</i> (otom) refers to the <i>birds of prey</i>. It should be noted that <i>ayit</i> (birds of prey) is in the singular. I.E. takes it as a collective noun.</i> <i>Yashev</i> (he caused to blow) in <i>He causeth His wind to blow</i> (yashev rucho) (Ps. 147:18) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>nun, shin, bet</i> means to blow. Similarly in our verse Abraham drove the birds off by causing a wind to blow over them, i.e., by flapping at them.</i> On the other hand, he may have flapped at the carcasses to drive the bird of prey off them.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation the <i>them</i> refers to the carcasses and <i>ayit</i> refers to one bird. The verse is to be interpreted as follows: the bird of prey came down…and Abraham flapped at the carcasses and drove “it” off.</i>

Verse 12

AND IT CAME TO PASS, THAT, WHEN THE SUN WAS GOING DOWN. This clause indicates that Abraham <i>took him all these</i> (v. 10) during the day after he awoke from his prophetic vision.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The vision in which Abraham was told to set aside the animals occurred at night (v. 5). He took the animals on the next day, after awakening from his vision. When the sun came down there transpired what our verse describes (Cherez, Krinsky).</i>

Verse 13

THAT THY SEED SHALL BE A STRANGER IN A LAND THAT IS NOT THEIRS. In Hebrew a person who has a family is likened to a branch attached to its source. Therefore such an individual is called an <i>ezrach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Ex. 12:49. Cf. Lev. 16:29, 18:26, 19:34, 24:16; Num. 9:14. Ps. 37:35 has been rendered in accordance with I.E.’s interpretation in Psalms. <i>Ezrach</i> means native-born. According to I.E. one born in the land is called an <i>ezrach</i> because he is like a branch attached to its tree. It should be added that I.E. points out in his comments on Gen. 2:25 that the Bible compares man to a tree.</i> for the meaning of <i>ezrach</i> is a branch, as in <i>a sprouting tree with many branches</i> (ke-ezrach ra’anan) (Ps. 37:35). On the other hand, a stranger is termed <i>ger</i> in Hebrew from the word <i>gargir</i> (berry), for he is like a berry plucked from a branch. There are some unintelligent people who find this explanation farfetched. However, if they knew the meaning of each letter and its form then they would recognize the truth.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra discusses the meaning and form of letters in his <i>Sefer Ha-Tzachot</i>. He explains that <i>gimel</i> means finished, or weaned (<i>gamal</i>), and <i>resh</i> cut. A poor person is called a <i>rash</i> because he is cut off from his sources. <i>Ger</i> is spelled <i>gimel, resh</i>; it thus means a person weaned and cut off from his family (Cherez, Netter).</i>
FOUR HUNDRED YEARS. Until the end of this period (four hundred years) starting from this very day.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">In Ex. 12:40, I.E. writes that the 400 years started with the birth of Isaac. Some versions have “from Isaac’s birth” in our text.</i>

Verse 14

WHOM THEY SHALL SERVE. Whose slaves they shall be.

Verse 15

BUT THOU SHALT GO TO THY FATHERS. A euphemism for a natural death.
[IN PEACE.] Unlike your enslaved descendants, you will die in dignity.

Verse 16

AND IN THE FOURTH GENERATION THEY SHALL COME BACK HITHER. Many of the commentaries misunderstood the meaning of the word <i>dor</i> (generation).<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">They explain generations as a specific number of years. Cf. I.E.’s commentary on Job 42:16 in which he notes, <i>Isaac the windbag erred in saying that a generation spans 35 years</i>. In Deut. 7:9 he quotes an opinion that a generation is 36 years.</i> The sages of the Talmud said there were ten generations from Adam to Noah.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 5:2. The sages speak of generations in terms of people, not years. Each one of those mentioned had a life span that differed from the other. Hence <i>dor</i> cannot refer to a fixed number of years.</i> We also find, <i>to a thousand generations</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">If a generation is a fixed number of years then a thousand generations is a thousand times that number. In Deut. 7:9, I.E. argues that it cannot be so. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Deut. 7:9.</i> (Deut. 7:9) and Job speaks of four generations (Job 42:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">In Job the four generations come to 140 years. We thus see that a generation is not a fixed number of years, for each time it is encountered it does not refer to the same number of years.</i> In my opinion the meaning of <i>dor</i> (generation) is dwells. Compare <i>dur</i> (dwell) in <i>Than to dwell</i> (mi-dur) <i>in the tents of wickedness</i> (Ps. 84:11). A generation is measured by a person’s life span. Some are long and some are short. Our verse refers to the fourth generation starting from the first that lived as strangers in Egypt. Thus it is written, <i>thou shalt not abhor an Egyptian, because thou wast a stranger in his land</i> (Deut. 23:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">This verse spells out that the Hebrews were strangers in Egypt.</i> And so it was: Kohath, Amram, Moses and Aaron were strangers in Egypt. Their children, who were the fourth generation, returned to the land of Canaan.
FOR THE INIQUITY OF THE AMORITE IS NOT YET FULL. I have explained the meaning of <i>iniquity</i> in my comments on <i>My punishment is greater than I can bear</i> (Gen. 4:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Iniquity at times means punishment. That is its meaning in this verse; i.e., I have not yet finished punishing them (Cherez).</i> The Amorites are singled out because they were the most powerful of the Canaanite peoples.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Actually this verse refers to all the inhabitants of Canaan.</i> Behold, the great kings whom Moses slew were Amorites.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 2:24-36; 4:47. The Bible singles out these kings as being mighty (Weiser).</i> Furthermore, it was five Amorite kings who united to fight Joshua.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Josh. 10:5.</i> There are other proofs.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">In Scripture that the Amorites were the most powerful inhabitants of Canaan.</i> Similarly the prophet says concerning the Amorites, <i>Whose height was like the height of the cedars, And he was strong as the oaks</i> (Am. 2:9). Whoever says that <i>Emori</i> (Amorite) comes from the same root as <i>amar</i> (saying) does not contribute anything.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash interprets <i>the iniquity of the Amorite</i> (avon ha’emori) to mean the sin for saying (<i>avon ha-amirah</i>): O Lord God, whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it. <i>Pesikta Zutarta</i>, Gen. 15:16.</i>

Verse 17

AND IT CAME TO PASS, THAT WHEN THE SUN WENT DOWN. Until now the sun had not yet set. It is similarly written, <i>when the sun was about to go down</i> (v. 12).<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">This is the literal meaning of <i>va-yehi ha-shemesh la-vo</i> (when the sun was going down). We thus see that what transpired until now took place before the sun went down.</i>
THICK DARKNESS. <i>Alatah</i> (thick darkness) means darkness. The word <i>alatah</i> is also found in Ezekiel (12:6, 7, 12). It means a cloudy night. It might also refer to the darkness that sets in as soon as the last light has disappeared in the clouds.
BEHOLD A SMOKING FURNACE, AND A FLAMING TORCH. An image of a smoking furnace with a flaming torch in it.
BETWEEN THESE PIECES. <i>Ben ha-gezarim</i> means between the pieces. This<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The passing of the smoking furnace with the flaming torch inside it between the pieces.</i> was the actual taking of the oath. <i>The words of the covenant which they made before Me, when they cut the calf in twain and passed between the parts thereof</i> (Jer. 34:18) is similar. We thus read in the next verse, <i>In that day the Lord made a covenant with Abram, saying, ‘Unto thy seed have I given this land,’</i> etc.

Verse 18

FROM THE RIVER OF EGYPT. This refers to the Shihor, and not the Nile.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Josh. 13:3; Jer. 2:18. Josh. 13:3 says that the Shihor lies before Egypt The Nile is in Egypt.</i>

Verse 19

THE KENITE, AND THE KENIZZITE AND THE KADMONITE. These are children of Canaan. Each one had two names.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Each one had another name and was listed under the other name in Gen. 10:15-18, in which the children of Canaan are enumerated. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 13:7.</i>

Verse 20

AND THE REPHAIM. This is what <i>That also is accounted a land of Rephaim</i> (Deut. 2:20) refers to.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The point of I.E.’s comment is that <i>Rephaim</i> in our verse refers to the land of Rephaim and not to the Rephaim per se, since the latter were not Canaanites (Weiser). However, Krinsky explains that the Rephaim were a branch of the Canaanites.</i> Do not be surprised that Scripture lists the Canaanite and after him the Jebusite.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Canaan was the father of these nations. Why, then, list him between the Kenites and Jebusites (Meijler)?</i> Note: Each one of the seven nations that dwelled in Canaan were Canaanites. They descended from Canaan, who fathered eleven sons. Elsewhere Scripture lists six Canaanite nations by their specific names and includes the remainder under the term Canaanite.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Canaan refers to the Canaanite people (Weiser).</i> In our chapter Scripture lists ten of them.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Two are included in the name Canaan.</i> At other times Scripture includes them all in the term Canaanite without enumerating them. Scripture similarly states, <i>Judah and Israel were many</i> (I Kings 4:20) even though the term Israel includes Judah.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the Bible at times is especially explicit. Similarly, although Canaanite can refer to all seven nations, the Bible mentions Canaanite and then notes a number of them.</i>

Chapter 16



Verse 1



Verse 2

IT MAY BE THAT I SHALL BE BUILDED UP. <i>Ibbaneh</i> (I shall be builded up) comes from the same root as <i>ben</i> (son).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>ibbaneh</i> (I shall be builded up) means I shall have a son.</i> It is possible that the word for son (<i>ben</i>) comes from the root <i>bet, nun, heh</i> (to build), with the <i>heh</i> dropped because, metaphorically speaking, the father serves as the foundation and the son as the building.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. comments thusly because the root of <i>ibbaneh</i> is obviously <i>bet, nun, heh</i>.</i> <i>Chai</i> (life) in the third person perfect and in the adjectival form is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>chet, yod, heh</i>.</i>
AND ABRAM HEARKENED. Abraham said yes to her.

Verse 3

AFTER ABRAM HAD DWELT TEN YEARS IN THE LAND OF CANAAN. Our sages, of blessed memory, transmitted a law that a man shall not remain married more that ten years to a woman who has not borne him a child. They used this verse as sort of a support for this law. It is a good support.

Verse 4

WAS DESPISED. The <i>tzere</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The letters added to the root to indicate that it is in the imperfect are, with the exception of the first person singular, always vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> in the <i>nifal</i>. I.E. literally reads, the missing <i>yod</i> between the prefix and the root letter. He is referring to the <i>tzere</i> which has a <i>yod</i> sound.</i> in <i>va-tekal</i> (was despised) is in place of the <i>dagesh</i> which should be placed in the <i>kof</i> to make up for one of the missing root letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>lamed</i>. The root of <i>va-tekal</i> (was despised) being <i>kof, lamed, lamed</i>. This comment is difficult. The <i>tav</i> of <i>va-tekal</i> is in reality vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> to make up for the <i>dagesh</i> that should have been placed in the <i>kof</i> to make up for the missing <i>nun</i> of the <i>nifal</i> form. Filwarg amends I.E. to read so.</i> <i>Va-tekal</i> is a <i>nifal</i>.

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

FOUND HER. <i>Va-yimtza’ah</i> (found her) is irregular.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse should have read, <i>va-yimtza’eha</i>.</i> It should have been vocalized like <i>va-yisna’eha</i> (and he hateth her) (Deut. 22:16).

Verse 8

WHENCE. <i>Ay</i> (whence) means where. <i>Ay</i> (where) in <i>Where is</i> (ay) <i>Abel thy brother</i> (Gen. 4:9) is similar. <i>Mi-zeh</i> (from this)<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. translates <i>ai mi-zeh</i> as whence. It literally reads, where (<i>ay</i>) from this (<i>mi-zeh</i>), hence I.E.’s comments.</i> is short for <i>mi-zeh makom</i> (from this place).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Weiser.</i> The meaning of <i>ai mi-zeh vat</i> is: where is the place thou camest from?
I FLEE. The <i>resh</i> of <i>borachat</i> (I flee) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because it is followed by a guttural.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The second radical of a participle in the feminine is usually vocalized with a <i>segol</i>. Compare, <i>shomeret, kotevet</i>.</i> These are similar: <i>borachat</i> (fleeth) in <i>The whole city fleeth</i> (borachat) (Jer. 4:29); <i>porachat</i> (budding) in <i>and as it was budding</i> (khe-forachat) (Gen. 40:10); <i>rachat</i> (shovel) in <i>with the shovel</i> (va-rachat) <i>and with the fan</i> (Is. 30:24); and <i>yoda’at</i> (known) in <i>that hath known man</i> (yoda’at ish) (Num. 31:17). The reason the middle letter of the root of the above words is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> is that it precedes gutturals. They are: <i>alef, chet, heh, ayin</i>. This is the rule. There is no exception.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

BEHOLD THOU. <i>Hinnakh</i> (behold thou) is the form used when a female is being addressed, because it is a preposition. It is like the word <i>im</i> (with); it follows the paradigm of <i>immakh</i> (with you).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">A word with a second person singular feminine pronominal suffix is usually vocalized with a <i>tzere</i>. Compare, <i>sifrech</i> (your book) or <i>lekhtekh</i> (your going). Thus I.E. points out that prepositional words such as <i>immakh</i> (with you), <i>lakh</i> (to you) and <i>bakh</i> (in you) are vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> in place of a <i>tzere</i>.</i>
ISHMAEL. The <i>alef</i> of Ishmael is not pronounced to simplify enunciation.

Verse 12

A WILD ASS OF A MAN. He will be free among men.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">As a wild ass is. No one controls the wild ass or places a burden on him. Similarly Ishmael shall be a free and uncontrolled person. The Hebrew has <i>pereh adam</i>, literally, wild ass-man, hence the different interpretations which follow.</i> Compare, <i>Who hath sent out the wild ass free</i> (Job 39:5). The meaning of our clause is that no stranger will rule over him.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Weiser.</i> Others say that we should render <i>perah adam</i> (a wild ass of a man) by a wild ass and a man.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">That is, a connective <i>vav</i> should be placed before <i>adam</i> (man). He will have the qualities of a wild ass and of a man.</i> It is like <i>The sun and moon stand still in their habitation</i> ((Hab. 3:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, a connective <i>vav</i> has to be prefixed to <i>yare’ach</i> (moon). The verse literally reads: the sun moon stand still in their habitation.</i> The meaning of our verse is: because he will be a wild ass <i>his hand shall be against every man</i>, but because he is a man <i>every man’s hand (shall be) against him</i>. In my opinion its interpretation is: he will be as a wild ass among men;<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion, like the first one, renders <i>pereh adam</i> as wild ass among men, but it explains it differently.</i> i.e., he will overcome men. However, ultimately <i>every man’s hand (shall be) against him</i>. This is clearly stated in the book of Daniel, for the fourth beast described therein refers to the kingdom of Ishmael.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Dan. 7:7. I.E.’s point is that at first the Ishmaelite kingdom will prevail. However, in the end it will be defeated.</i>
AND HE SHALL DWELL IN THE FACE OF ALL HIS BRETHREN. The latter being the children of Keturah.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The woman whom Abraham took after Sarah’s death (Gen. 25:1).</i> It is similarly written, <i>over against all his brethren did he settle</i> (Gen. 25:18). Also, the Midianites are of the children of Keturah. However, they are referred to as Ishmaelites in the Pentateuch<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 37:25-28.</i> and in the Book of Judges.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Jud. 8:22-24.</i>

Verse 13

A GOD OF SEEING. <i>Ro’</i> i (seeing) follows the paradigm of <i>oni</i> (affliction).<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ro’</i> i, like <i>oni</i>, is a noun (Krinsky) and both are vocalized with a <i>chataf kamatz</i> beneath the first letter.</i> Compare, <i>I am the man that hath seen affliction</i> (oni) (Lam. 3:1). The meaning of <i>a God of seeing</i> is a God who appears in visions.
HAVE I EVEN HERE. The commentaries translate <i>halom</i> as now.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser.</i> However, its correct meaning is here. <i>Halom</i> (hither) in <i>Is there yet a man come hither</i> (halom) (I Sam. 10:22) is similar. The meaning <i>ha-gam halom ra’iti achare ro’</i> i (have I even here seen Him that seeth me) is: have I even here seen an angel of God after God saw my affliction, because God constantly seeth me (<i>ro</i>’i).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, did God who always sees me (<i>ro</i>’i) really see my affliction and send an angel to me in the dessert. The clause literally reads: Have I even here seen after He seeth me. I.E. apparently views our verse as abridged or perhaps in her excitement Hagar did not complete her thoughts.</i>

Verse 14

BEER-LAHAI. <i>Beer lahai</i> means the well of him who will be alive next year.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">According to Bachya, I.E. explains <i>Beer-lahai-roi</i> as meaning the well (<i>be’er</i>) that he who is alive next year (<i>la-chai</i>) shall see me there (<i>ro</i>’i). Since the Ishmaelites met yearly at this well, they referred to it by this name.</i> Compare, <i>ko le-chai</i> (so to life next year) (I Sam. 25:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s translation of <i>ko le-chai</i> (Netter).</i> The well was so called because the Ishmaelites held annual festivities at this well. It is still in existence and is called the well of <i>zamum</i>.

Chapter 17



Verse 1

GOD ALMIGHTY. <i>Shaddai</i> is an adjective meaning mighty. <i>Shaddai</i> in <i>like a mighty voice</i> (ke-kol shaddai)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Our translation follows that of I.E. Cf. Kimchi on Ezek. 1:24. I.E.’s point is that here, too, <i>Shaddai</i> is an adjective meaning mighty.</i> (Ezek. 1:24) is similar. Also, <i>Shaddai</i> in <i>And mighty will be thy silver</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. on Job. 22:24, 25 renders <i>betzer</i> by <i>kesef</i> (silver). <i>And mighty will be thy silver</i> means you will have a great amount of money.</i> (shaddai betzarekha) (Job 22:25) is similar because the word <i>betzarekha</i> (thy silver) has the same meaning as the word <i>betzer</i> (silver) in <i>And lay thy treasure (or silver)</i> (betzer) <i>in the dust</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the verse is to be rendered: And mighty (<i>Shaddai</i>) will be thy silver. Thus <i>Shaddai</i> is an adjective meaning mighty</i> (Job 22:24). The word <i>Shaddai</i> follows the paradigm of <i>davvai</i> (faint), in <i>And my heart is faint</i> (davvai) (Lam. 1:22). Many derive <i>Shaddai</i> from the same root as <i>shoded</i> (overpowering),<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Brown, Driver and Briggs (<i>Hebrew and English Lexicon of the Old Testament</i>) define <i>shoded</i> as: deals violently with, despoils, devastates, ruins. Cf. Jer. 6:26. Thus <i>shoded</i> has the connotation of overpowering. In keeping with the concept of I.E., but more important out of respect to God, we have translated <i>shoded</i> as overpowering.</i> meaning, He is victorious and overpowering. The reason God used this name at this time was to impress upon Abraham the fear of God so that he would circumcise himself. The correct interpretation of the divine names is as follows: <i>Shaddai</i> is an adjective describing God’s power over creation. The Tetragrammaton, God’s revered and awesome name, stands in contrast to it. The world exists by virtue of these two names.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton expresses God’s essence, His eternality, and His being the cause of all existence. <i>Shaddai</i> emphasizes His power over creation. Thus these two names stand opposite each other; i.e., these names teach that there is an Eternal God who created all (Tetragrammaton) and has the power over all (<i>Shaddai</i>). Furthermore, on a more “practical” level it is via the Tetragrammaton that the world was created, and via the name <i>Shaddai</i> that nature is overcome. Others comment that the Tetragrammaton stands for creation and <i>Shaddai</i>, for destroying or limiting the creation (Krinsky). See I.E.’s comment on Ex. 3:15, 6:3.</i> Whoever understands the secret of God’s name will accept my interpretation.
AND BE THOU WHOLE-HEARTED. Do not question the reason for circumcision.

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

ABRAHAM. The new name with the addition of the <i>resh</i> means the mighty one of a multitude of nations. This is so because the new name did not come to diminish a letter from Abraham’s original name but to add one.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Prima facie</i> there is no meaning for the <i>resh</i> in Abraham. I.E. argues that it does not have a meaning, for the <i>resh</i> is an integral part of the new name. Abraham means <i>avir hamon goyim</i>, for <i>av hamon goyim</i> with the <i>resh</i> added gives <i>avir hamon goyim</i>. I.E. is in contradistinction to Rashi who comments that the <i>resh</i> in Abraham was carried over from Abram and did not signify anything. We have followed <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 in our translation, which reads, <i>Abraham im tosefet ha-resh avir hamon goyim</i>.</i> 
Sarah, unlike Sarai, is a general adjective.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Sarai connotes my princess; Sarah connotes princess over all (Cherez).</i> Blessed be the Lord before whom all actions are weighed. He commanded Abraham to circumcise himself before Sarah became pregnant so that his seed would be holy.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">By being the seed of a circumcised father.</i> 

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

[EVERY MALE AMONG YOU SHALL BE CIRCUMCISED.] <i>Himmol</i> (shall be circumcised) is to be read as if it had a <i>lamed</i> prefixed to it. It is an infinitive.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it means shall be circumcised. <i>Himmol</i> might be taken to be an imperative, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It belongs to the verbs having a <i>vav</i> as the middle letter of their root.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">It is an <i>ayin, vav</i>, its root being <i>mem, vav, lamed</i>.</i> It is like <i>va-yamal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Whose root is also <i>mem, vav, lamed</i>.</i> in <i>and circumcised</i> (va-yamal) <i>the flesh of their foreskin</i> (v. 23). It follows the paradigm of <i>le-hikkon</i> (to be prepared).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Ez. 38:7; Amos 4:12. The root of <i>le-hikkon</i> is <i>caf, vav, nun</i>. <i>Le-himmol</i> is the same form as <i>le-hikkon</i>. Both <i>le-himmol</i> and <i>le-hikkon</i> are <i>nifal</i> infinitives.</i>

Verse 11

AND YE SHALL BE CIRCUMCISED. <i>U-nemaltem</i> (and ye shall be circumcised) is similar to <i>u-shemartem</i> (and ye shall keep).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>U-shemartem</i> is a <i>kal</i>. Similarly <i>u-nemaltem</i> (and ye shall be circumcised) is a <i>kal</i>, meaning: and ye shall circumcise.</i> The <i>nun</i> of <i>u-nemaltem</i> is a root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>nun, mem, lamed</i>. There are thus two roots meaning to circumcise, viz., <i>nun, mem, lamed</i> and <i>mem, vav, lamed</i>. (See I.E.’s comments on verse 10 and note 10).</i> <i>Yadon</i> (shall be sheathed) in <i>My spirit shall not be sheathed</i> (yadon) (Gen. 6:3) and <i>nidneh</i> (sheath) (Dan. 7:15) are similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">There are two roots for the Hebrew word for sheath, viz., <i>nun, dalet, nun, nidneh</i> (Dan. 7:15) and <i>dalet, vav, nun, yadon</i> (Gen. 6:3). (Rendering Gen. 6:3 according to I.E. See I.E. on Gen. 6:3).</i>

Verse 12

SHALL BE CIRCUMCISED AMONG YOU. <i>Yimmol</i> (shall be circumcised) is a <i>nifal</i>, as are <i>himmol yimmol</i> (must needs be circumcised) (v. 13). Why does Scripture state twice, <i>He that is born in thy house…must needs be circumcised</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 seems to repeat what is in verse 12. I.E. asks why.</i> This is the answer: Scripture first states that in the future all males, those of thy seed and also those <i>born in the house or bought with money</i>, shall be circumcised on the eighth day. It then states, “ Abraham immediately circumcise all males <i>born in thy house and he that is bought with thy money</i> although they are adults.”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">It might have been thought that since the command speaks of circumcision on the eighth day, those past that age when the command was given were exempt. Thus verse 12 speaks of the future and verse 13 of the present. Thus there is no repetition.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

AND THE UNCIRCUMCISED MALE WHO IS NOT CIRCUMCISED. <i>Yimmol</i> (is circumcised) is a <i>kal</i>. It is like <i>yiddor</i> (voweth) in <i>When a man voweth</i> (yiddor) <i>a vow</i> (Num. 30:3). It comes from the same root as <i>u-nemaltem</i> (and ye shall be circumcised) in <i>and ye shall be circumcised</i> (u-nemaltem) <i>in the flesh of your foreskin</i> (v. 11).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">J.P.S. renders both <i>yimmol</i> and <i>u-nemaltem</i> as <i>nifals</i>. I.E. renders them as <i>kals</i>, as actives whose root is <i>nun, mem, lamed.</i>. Our verse should thus be rendered: And the uncircumcised male who does not circumcise the flesh of his foreskin.</i> The meaning of the verse is, a male who reaches the age when he is obligated to observe the commandments of the Torah and does not circumcise himself is subject to the penalty of <i>karet</i> (being cut off). The verse refers to an adult because while a person is yet a child, the obligation to circumcise him falls upon his father. However, should his father fail to do so, then upon reaching maturity he must circumcise himself. <i>Karet</i> (being cut off) is a penalty inflicted by God. Those who err hold that a child that dies uncircumcised does not have a share in the world to come.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">It is for this reason that Jews customarily circumcise, prior to burial, a child who dies uncircumcised. Cf. <i>Shulchan Arukh Yoreh Deah</i> 263:5. It is clear from I.E.’s refutation of the belief that an uncircumcised child does not have a share in the world to come that those who held this view based it on the verse: <i>And the uncircumcised male…that soul</i> (nefesh) <i>shall be cut off from his people</i> (v. 14). They interpreted <i>nefesh</i> as soul and cut off as referring to the world to come (Weiser).</i> However, the meaning of the word <i>nefesh</i> is not as they think, a soul<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">They translated <i>nefesh</i> as soul.</i>, but a person; it means a body containing a soul. Similarly, <i>If anyone</i> (nefesh) <i>shall sin</i> (Lev. 4:2). Some say that <i>karet</i> refers to death before the age of fifty-two. Others say it means the eradication of one’s name via the death of one’s children. Therefore Scripture states, <i>that soul shall be cut off from his people</i>, for a person who leaves children is considered to live on even after his death, and his name is not cut off.

Verse 15



Verse 16

AND MOREOVER I WILL GIVE THEE. <i>Natati</i> (I will give thee) in our verse is like <i>natati</i> in <i>I will give</i> (natati) <i>the price of the field</i> (Gen. 23:13). Observe, although both are perfects, they are to be rendered as imperfects.

Verse 17

SHALL A CHILD BE BORN UNTO HIM THAT IS A HUNDRED YEARS OLD. Abraham was amazed at being told that he would have a son because the sperm of an old man is cold<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Medieval medicine believed in four humors.</i> and therefore aged men are infertile. However, he was even more amazed that Sarah, a woman whose menstrual cycle had ceased, would bear a child, since the embryo is made and constructed from the woman’s menstrual blood. If you will reflect you will conclude that Sarah’s conceiving was a greater wonder than Abraham’s begetting a child. For we find instances of men over ninety begetting children in later generations,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">However, we do not find in Scripture any report of an aged woman bearing a child. <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, “We find that King David’s forefathers each sired a son when over 90.” Cf. I.E.’s comment on Ruth 4:17.</i> and the life span of people in Abraham’s time was much longer than in later times.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Since men of later generations whose life spans were shorter than that of Abraham sired children when over 90, it diminishes the uniqueness of Abraham’s experience. <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, “The life span of people in Abraham’s generation was longer than that of David’s generation.”</i> As soon as the angel left, Abraham immediately circumcised Ishmael and all those born in his house and those bought with money.
