Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

IN THE SELFSAME DAY. Abraham did not hesitate to carry out the commandment of circumcision. Behold, Abraham’s household consisted of three hundred eighteen males <i>born in his house</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 14:15.</i> aside from those <i>bought with his money</i>. After circumcising them, Abraham circumcised himself on that very day.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible states, <i>And Abraham took Ishmael his son, and all that were born in his house, and all that were bought with his money…and circumcised the flesh of their foreskin in the selfsame day</i> (v. 23). After stating this, Scripture notes, <i>And Abraham was ninety years old and nine when he was circumcised</i> (v. 24). Thus Abraham was circumcised last.</i> Now Ishmael his son plus all those born in his house and bought with his money were voluntarily circumcised with him (Abraham) (v. 27). For the meaning of “with him” (v. 27) is that Abraham did not have to force his household to comply with God’s commandment. They all voluntarily hurried to do and fulfill God’s will.

Verse 27

WERE CIRCUMCISED WITH HIM. <i>Nimmolu</i> (were circumcised) is a <i>nifal</i>. Its root is <i>nun, mem, lamed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Hence there is a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>mem</i> of <i>nimmolu</i> to make up for the missing <i>nun</i> of the root. The <i>nun</i> of <i>nimmolu</i> is the <i>nun</i> of the <i>nifal</i>.</i> <i>Ve-nishlo’ach</i> (were sent) in <i>And letters were sent</i> (ve-nishlo’ach sefarim) (Est. 3:13) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>cholam</i> in <i>nimmolu</i> presents a problem. When a letter having a <i>nun</i> as the first letter of its root is conjugated in the <i>nifal</i> as a <i>shelamim</i> it is not vocalized with a <i>cholam</i> (Weiser). I.E. thus points out that we find the same with <i>nishlo’ach. Nishlo’ach</i> is a <i>shelemim nifal</i> and it, too, is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>, i.e., <i>nishlo’ach</i> rather than <i>nishlach</i> (Filwarg).</i>

Chapter 18



Verse 1

AND THE LORD APPEARED. Behold, a few say that God is three men: He is one and He is three and they are inseparable.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">This comment of I.E. is cryptic. Krinsky sees in it an allusion to the Christian doctrine of trinity. According to him, <i>a few say</i> refers to the Christians. Filwarg disagrees. He insists that I.E. is merely saying that God’s revelation took the form of three angels appearing to Abraham. One can argue on behalf of Krinsky that the Christians did use this verse as “proof” of their doctrine of trinity. And indeed, I.E.’s language seems to support Krinsky. On the other hand, would I.E. refer to the Christians as <i>a few say</i>, thereby giving some credence to their trinitarian interpretation? Furthermore, Rashbam accepts this interpretation minus, of course, its trinitarian aspects. Commenting on this verse, Rashbam says, <i>And the Lord appeared to him. How? Three men who were angels came to him</i>. Thus Rashbam interprets this verse in a way similar to the phrase <i>a few say</i> quoted by I.E. Hence <i>a few say</i> may very well refer to a Jewish interpretation. However, it should be noted that Saadiah Gaon, in rejecting the doctrine of trinity, writes, “Others (finally) conjecturing about the implication of the passage, <i>And the Lord appeared unto him by the terebinths of Mamre</i> (Gen. 18:1), declare that the thing that appeared to Abraham and was designated by this name was a trinity because Scripture later on explicitly states: <i>And, lo, three men stood over against him</i> (Gen. 18:2). Let me explain, then, that these are more ignorant (than the opinions concerning God’s essence previously refuted) because they did not wait until they reached the end of the passage. For had they had patience until they heard the verse: <i>And the men turned from thence, and went toward Sodom; but Abraham stood yet before the Lord</i> (Gen. 18:22), they would have realized that the <i>men</i> had departed while the light of God remained stationary with Abraham, who was in its presence. The thought therefore that God was identical with these men is completely refuted” (<i>The Book of Beliefs and Opinions</i>, Rosenblat translation, p. 108). Reading Ibn Ezra’s comments side by side with that of Saadiah seems to leave no doubt that both deal with the same group, the Christians. Indeed, it seems that Saadiah was the source of I.E.’s comments.</i> They forget that Scripture expressly states, <i>And the two angels came to Sodom at even</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 19:1. This verse clearly shows that the three are separable and thus cannot refer to God. The <i>few say</i> state that the three are inseparable.</i> However, the commentaries tell us<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Perhaps the term <i>mefareshim</i> (commentators) is used to indicate that what they say is acceptable in contrast to the first ones quoted who are not even deemed Biblical commentators. See preceding notes.</i> that God first appeared to Abraham in a vision after which Abraham lifted up his eyes and saw three angels.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi.</i> One came to bring happy tidings to Sarah<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">That she would have a son.</i> and the other two went on to Sodom, one to destroy it and one to save Lot. 
The meaning of <i>And they did eat</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Angels do not eat.</i> (v. 8) is that the bread was consumed.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The angels caused the bread to be consumed. Thus it appeared to have been eaten.</i> Eaten, in our verse, has the same meaning as the identical word in <i>whereto the fire hath eaten</i> (consumed) (Lev. 6:3).

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

[FORASMUCH AS YE ARE COME.] <i>Ki al ken avartem</i> (forasmuch as ye are come) means the same as <i>ho’il va-avartem</i> (since you are come) in Rabbinic Hebrew.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>ki al ken</i> means the same as the Rabbinic term <i>ho’il</i> (since). The Hebrew <i>ki al ken</i> can also be explained to mean, for this reason; i.e., the verse can be read: I will fetch a morsal of bread and stay your heart…for this reason (to eat) are ye come to your servant (Netter), hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It is like <i>forasmuch as</i> (ki al ken) <i>as they are come under the shadow of my roof</i> (Gen. 19:8).
SO DO, AS THOU HAST SAID. They responded politely and said to him that a morsel of bread would suffice.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">We would expect them to say: We will do as thou hast said, rather than <i>So do</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>

Verse 6

KNEAD IT. <i>Lushi</i> (knead it) is like <i>va-talash</i> (and kneaded it) (I Sam. 28:24).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>lushi</i> means to knead, as in I Sam. 28:24. Since the root <i>lamed, vav, shin</i> is not often found in Scripture, I.E. quotes an additional verse to illustrate its meaning (Filwarg). Cherez explains that since <i>lushi</i> is a transitive verb we would expect to find the object “dough,” i.e., knead the dough, as in <i>and the women knead the dough</i> (Jer. 7:18). Hence I.E. points out that occasionally the word dough is left out, as in I Sam. 28:24.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

WHEN THE SEASON COMETH ROUND. <i>Ka-et</i> (when the season) means next year, at this time, and <i>chayyah</i> (cometh round), that Sarah will then be alive.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ka’et chayyah</i> is not to be rendered as J.P.S. does, but rather, next year at this season and Sarah will then be alive (Weiser, Netter).</i> It is like <i>ko le-chai</i> (so to life next year) (I Sam. 25:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 16:14 and the notes to it.</i>
WHICH WAS BEHIND HIM.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>ve-hu acharav</i>, which is rendered by I.E.: and he (the angel) was behind it (the tent).</i> The angel who spoke to Abraham was behind the tent. Abraham sat in the tent door and consequently could not see Sarah. Others say that the door of Sarah’s tent was behind the tent of Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>ve-hu</i> is to be rendered: and it. The “it” (<i>ve-hu</i>) refers to the door of Sarah’s tent. The verse thus reads: and it (the door of Sarah’s tent) was behind it (Abraham’s tent) (Cherez).</i>

Verse 11

AND WELL STRICKEN IN AGE. They lived many days.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: coming into the days.</i>

Verse 12

SHALL I HAVE. <i>Hayetah li</i> means shall I have.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hayetah li</i> literally means I had. I.E. explains that <i>hayetah</i> is to be taken as an imperfect even though it is a perfect.</i>
PLEASURE. The word <i>ednah</i> means pleasure and enjoyment. <i>Va-yitaddenu</i> (and luxuriated) in <i>and luxuriated</i> (va-yitaddenu) <i>in Thy great goodness</i> (Neh. 9:25) is similar. The meaning of our verse is: How can the enjoyment and pleasure of youth be renewed in me, seeing that I have waxed old and aged and my husband, too, is old.
[WITHIN HERSELF.] In her mind. God revealed Sarah’s inner thoughts to the angel.

Verse 13

WHOM AM OLD. This explains <i>After I am waxed old</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Sarah said, <i>achare viloti</i> (after I am waxed old). The angel quoted her as saying, <i>ani zakanti</i> (I who am old). I.E. points out that <i>zakanti</i> means the same as <i>viloti</i>.</i> The angel spoke the truth.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Baba Metzia</i> 87a and <i>Yebamot</i> 65b, which state that Scripture changed Sarah’s actual words for the sake of peace so that Abraham would not take offense. They interpret <i>ani zakanti</i> (I whom am old) as referring to Sarah’s statement of <i>va-adoni zaken</i> (my lord being old also). I.E. disagrees with this interpretation (see note 17).</i> 
The <i>mem</i> of <i>umnam</i> (of a surety) is not a root letter. It is like the <i>mem</i> of <i>shilshom</i> (the day before yesterday) (Gen. 31:5). Other commentators maintain that Abraham’s three guests were prophets. If one should argue, why would God send a message via a prophet to Abraham who himself was a prophet,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">God could have revealed his prophecy to Abraham directly, as he did to the three prophets who visited him. What need was there to send a prophet to him?</i> since it is only when one prophet is greater than the other, as in the case of Moses who was sent with a prophesy to Aaron,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Ex. 4:14-16, 28.</i> that God transmits his intentions to a prophet through another prophet,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham was obviously the greatest prophet in his generation.</i> then they would answer that the three prophets came not to Abraham but to Sarah. Indeed, Scripture explicitly states, <i>And they said unto him: Where is Sarah thy wife</i> (v. 9).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">This indicates that the message was for Sarah.</i> After one of the prophets delivered the message to Sarah, the other two went on to Sodom. Also, do not be troubled by the clause <i>for we will destroy this place</i> (Gen.19:13),<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">A prophet cannot destroy a city. An angel can. Therefore, this clause implies that they were angels.</i> as we find a similar expression with regard to Moses and Aaron: <i>And Moses and Aaron did all these wonders before Pharaoh</i> (Ex. 11:10). In reality God did the wonders and they were attributed to Moses and Aaron because they were the agents by which the miracles were performed. Now according to this interpretation, <i>and they did eat</i> (v. 8) is to be taken literally. Similarly, according to this interpretation, the term <i>Adonai</i> (Lord) in <i>My lord</i>, (Adonai) <i>if now I have found favor in thy sight</i> (v. 3) does not refer to the Deity, but means my lords. Hence there is a <i>pattach</i> beneath the <i>nun</i>, and it is not vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> as would be the case if it referred to God.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Adonai</i> with a <i>pattach</i> means my lords; with a <i>kamatz</i>, it means Lord.</i> However, in those copies of the Pentateuch where <i>Adonai</i> is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> the term must be interpreted as: O prophet of God.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In our copies of the Pentateuch, <i>Adonai</i> is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>.</i> Also (according to the aforementioned interpretation), the reason Abraham said, <i>if now I have found favor in thy sight</i> (v. 3)<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">If Abraham addressed three prophets why did he employ the singular <i>be-enekha</i> ? He should have used the plural <i>be-enekhem</i>.</i> is that he first addressed the most important of the three and then the other two.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky. He then said the same to each one of the others.</i> Those who maintain that the three who visited Abraham were prophets<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 19:1 refers to them as angels and so must be explained.</i> point out that the prophet Haggai is referred to in Scripture as an angel.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Haggai 1:13.</i> Others say that <i>Adonai</i> means Lord and that Abraham respectfully requested that God wait until he had attended his guests. There are still others who say that the verses are not in order of their occurrence.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., Abraham first saw the angels (v. 2-16) and then God appeared to him (v. 1). According to this interpretation the Bible introduces the chapter with a statement that God appeared to Abraham. It then tells us that before God appeared to Abraham angels visited him. Scipture then records what God told Abraham when He appeared to him (v. 17-21). According to the earlier interpretation God first appeared to Abraham and then Abraham saw the angels.</i> According to this interpretation, <i>And he lifted up</i> (v. 2) is to be interpreted: and he had already lifted up his eyes and looked and done so and so. After this, God appeared to him and said, <i>Shall I hide from Abraham that which I am doing</i>, etc. (v. 17), and <i>Verily the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great</i>, etc. (v. 20). <i>But Abraham stood yet before the Lord</i> (v. 22) when the two angels who left for Sodom arrived there. In any case,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Whichever of the above interpretations we adopt.</i> <i>And the Lord said: Shall I hide from Abraham that which I am doing</i>, etc., relates either to what God directly revealed to Abraham or to what He told the angels to relate to Abraham. However, all opinions agree that <i>And the Lord said: Verily the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great, and verily their sin is exceedingly grievous</i>, etc. (v. 20 and 21), definitely records God’s words to Abraham. Upon hearing this, Abraham drew near and said, <i>Wilt thou indeed sweep away the righteous with the wicked</i>, etc. (v. 23-32).<i>And the men turned from thence, and went toward Sodom; but Abraham stood yet before the Lord</i>, (v. 22) is a parenthetical statement noting that at the very moment that the men came to Sodom, God told Abraham, <i>Verily, the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great</i>. This is similar: <i>As they were going down at the end of the city, Samuel said to Saul: ‘Bid the servant pass on before us - and he passed on - but stand thou still at this time, that I may cause thee to hear the word of God’</i> (I Sam. 9:27).<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And he passed on</i> is a parenthetical statement. I.E. points out that such statements are found in the Bible. Similarly verse 22 is parenthetical.</i> There is no need to assume that the scribes changed the original reading of our verse<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Midrash verse 22 originally read: But the Lord yet stood before Abraham. However, out of respect for God the Scribes reversed the passage to read: <i>But Abraham stood yet before the Lord</i>. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 49:7; <i>Va-yikra Rabbah</i> 11:5. For the reason that the Midrash assumed the verse originally read: but the Lord yet stood before Abraham; see Rashi and Krinsky. I.E. claims that there never was, in fact, any scribal emendation, as the literal meaning of the text does not support such an assumption (Filwarg).</i> from <i>but the Lord stood yet before Abraham</i> to <i>but Abraham stood yet before the Lord</i>. Indeed, the verse <i>And Abraham got up early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the Lord</i> (Gen. 19:27) proves that there was no scribal emendation.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">This verse clearly states that it was Abraham who stood before the Lord.</i> I will allude to my own beliefs with regard to the appearance of the angels in my commentary on the first Torah portion of Exodus.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Following Krinsky. Cf. I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 3:15.</i>

Verse 14

[IS ANYTHING TOO HARD FOR THE LORD?] <i>Ha-yippale</i> (is it too hard) means is it hidden.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation, <i>ha-yippale me-adonai davar</i> (is anything too hard for the Lord) means is anything hidden from God. Cf. Rashi, “is anything too hidden…or concealed from me, that I cannot do it.”</i> <i>Fele</i> (hidden things) in <i>oseh fele</i> (doing hidden things) (Ex. 15:11)<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The manner in which God works miracles is hidden to man.</i> is similar. Others say the meaning of <i>ha-yippale me-adonai davar</i> is: it is not a wonder in God’s eyes to do such a thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">They interpret <i>ha-yippale me-adonai davar</i> to mean: is anything wondrous from God?</i> However, if this were so, then a <i>mem</i> would not be prefixed to God’s name.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The text reads, <i>ha-yippale me-adonai davar</i>. <i>Me-adonai</i> means from God, and cannot imply, in God’s eyes. Otherwise Scripture would have written, <i>la-adonai</i>, meaning: is anything wondrous to the Lord? “Wondrous from” is not used in Hebrew. Therefore the correct meaning of our phrase is: is anything hidden from the Lord?</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

SHALL BE BLESSED IN HIM. <i>Ve-nivrikhu</i> (shall be blessed) is a <i>nifal</i>. It means that they shall be blessed because of Abraham. However, <i>ve-hitbarekhu</i> (Gen. 22:18) has a different meaning. It means: they shall bless themselves in him.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">They shall bless themselves by invoking his name. That is, all the nations of the earth shall pray that they, too, be blessed as Abraham’s seed (Krinsky, Netter).</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

[VERILY THE CRY OF SODOM.] Either the cry of its blasphemy or the cry of those victimized by its violence.
AND, VERILY, THEIR SIN IS EXCEEDINGLY GRIEVOUS. And the earth cannot bear it.

Verse 21

[I WILL GO DOWN NOW, AND SEE WHETHER THEY HAVE DONE ALTOGETHER ACCORDING TO THE CRY OF IT.] Some say this verse is to be interpreted as follows: If they have done so then I will destroy them (<i>kalah</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>kalah</i> (altogether) means destruction. <i>If they have done so</i> is I.E.’s paraphrase of <i>whether they have done according to the cry of it, which is come unto me</i>.</i>
AND IF NOT, I WILL KNOW. <i>Eda’ah</i> means I will have pity upon them. They similarly interpret <i>va-yeda Elohim</i> (and God took cognizance of them)<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">That <i>va-yeda Elohim</i> means God pitied them.</i> (Ex. 2:25). However, I believe that this verse is to be explained as follows: I will go down and see if all of them (<i>kalah</i>) have done this evil.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>kalah</i> (altogether) is to be rendered as all, as in Ex. 11:1 (Krinsky). <i>Have done this evil</i> is a paraphrase of <i>according to the cry of it, which is come unto me</i>.</i> For in truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The reason that Scripture relates that God went down to see if they all did according to the cry that came before him.</i> God who is All knows the individual in a general rather than in a detailed manner.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra seems to be saying that “Ordinarily…God does not know the particular individual as such. He knows him only as implied in the whole” (Husik, p. 193). Thus it was necessary for God to <i>go down and see</i>. Nachmanides criticized Ibn Ezra on this point for introducing alien philosophical concepts into Judaism. Cf. Nachmanides’ commentary on the Pentateuch, on this verse. Other commentaries could not accept the literal implication of Ibn Ezra’s words and harmonized his comments to conform to traditional thinking. See Krinsky. Some argue that this comment did not come from I.E.’s hand but was inserted in the text by a misguided student.</i> Proof that this interpretation is correct, although it is a great mystery, is Abraham’s plea, <i>Wilt thou indeed sweep away the righteous with the wicked</i> (v. 23).<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham asked God not to judge Sodom by his general knowledge but to look upon each of the city’s inhabitants as an individual.</i> The <i>heh</i> of <i>ha’af</i> (wilt) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">An interrogative <i>heh</i> is vocalized with a <i>chataf pattach</i>.</i> even though it is an interrogative <i>heh</i>, because it is followed by an <i>alef</i>, which is a guttural, and it is the rule in Hebrew to elongate the vowel before gutturals.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Hence an interrogative <i>heh</i> preceding the gutturals <i>alef, heh, chet, ayin</i> is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>, rather than with a <i>chataf pattach</i>. When the preceding letters are vocalized with a long <i>kamatz</i>, the interrogative is vocalized with a <i>segol</i>.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23

THAT WILT SWEEP AWAY. <i>Tispeh</i> (thou wilt sweep away) is a transitive verb. It means is thou wilt destroy (or finish). <i>Aspeh</i> (finish) in <i>I will finish</i> (aspeh) <i>evils upon them</i> (Deut. 32:23) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">I will spend (finish) all evil upon them. That is, there will be no further evil left to bring upon them. Cf. I.E. on Deut. 32:23 (translated according to I.E.).</i> Both words (<i>tispeh</i> and <i>aspeh</i>) mean the same thing even though they belong to different conjugations.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tispeh</i> is a <i>kal, aspeh</i> a <i>hifil</i>.</i>

Verse 24

AND NOT FORGIVE THE PLACE. <i>Tissa</i> means forgive. Compare, <i>nose</i> (forgiving) in <i>forgiving iniquity</i> (nose avon) (Ex. 34:7).
[THE PLACE.] Sodom. For it was on account of Sodom that Abraham approached God in prayer. He did so to save Lot.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. takes issue with those who maintain that Abraham pleaded for the other cities as well. Cf. <i>Targum Jonathan</i> and Rashi.</i>

Verse 25

THAT BE FAR. <i>Chalilah</i> (that be far) means it is not possible. Others say that <i>chalilah</i> (that be far) is to be connected to the word <i>chalul</i>, which means empty.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The first explanation interprets <i>chalilah</i> in context. The second connects it to the word <i>chalul</i> (Weiser).</i>
THAT SO THE RIGHTEOUS SHOULD BE AS THE WICKED. When two <i>cafs</i> are prefixed to two words following each other<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>ve-haya kha-tzadik ka-rasha</i> : that so the righteous should be as the wicked.</i> we are dealing with an abridged statement. Hence our verse should be understood as follows: that so the righteous should be as the wicked and the wicked be so as the righteous. Similarly, <i>for thou art even as Pharaoh</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ki kha-mokha ke-faroh</i> is to be understood as if written: for thou art even as Pharaoh, and Pharaoh is even as thou.</i> (Gen. 44:18); <i>my people as thy people</i> (I Kings 22:4);<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ke-ammi khe-ammekha</i>, which should be understood: my people as thy people, thy people as my people.</i> and <i>The darkness is even as the light</i> (Ps. 139:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ka-chashekhah ka-orah</i> : And the darkness is even as the light, and the light even as the darkness.</i> The thrust of Abraham’s appeal is: How is it possible for the Judge of all the earth to act unjustly?

Verse 26

[WITHIN THE CITY.] That is, who publicly<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Fifty righteous within the city</i> means 50 people who are publicly righteous.</i> revere My name. <i>Run ye to and fro through the streets of Jerusalem, And see now, and know, And seek in the broad places thereof, If ye can find a man, If there be any that doeth justly, and seeketh truth; And I will pardon her</i> (Jer. 5:1) is similar.

Verse 27

[I HAVE TAKEN UPON ME.] <i>Ho’alti</i> (I have taken upon me) does not mean I began; it means I wanted. <i>Ho’il Moshe</i> (took Moses upon him) (Deut. 1:5) is similar. The <i>caf</i> of <i>anokhi</i> (I) is superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Anokhi</i>, meaning I, is a variant of <i>ani</i>. J.P.S. renders <i>va-anokhi</i> (literally, and I) as <i>who am</i>.</i> On the other hand, it is possible that there are two different words for I in Hebrew.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ani</i> and <i>anokhi</i>, and the two are not related.</i>
[WHO AM BUT DUST AND ASHES.] For dust I was and ashes I will be. Abraham was speaking only about the body’s foundation, i.e., its skeletal frame.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Man’s spirit does not turn to ashes (Weiser). Hence I.E. explains that dust and ashes refer to man’s bones, which are made out of earth (Krinsky). Cf. I.E.’s comment on Gen. 3:18.</i>

Verse 28

PERADVENTURE THERE SHALL LACK FIVE. Perhaps a tenth of the number will be lacking.
[WILT THOU DESTROY ALL THE CITY FOR LACK OF FIVE.] Will you destroy the city because of the five who are missing from the fifty?<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>bet</i> of <i>ba-chamishah</i> means because, i.e., because of five. I.E. makes this comment because <i>bet</i> usually means in.</i> Abraham then repeated his request and said, “Will you destroy the city if a ninth are missing from the number (forty-five) concerning which you stated that if there be found there that many righteous men I will not destroy them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">That is, if there are 40 righteous people in Sodom.</i> 

Verse 29

[I WILL NOT DO IT FOR THE FORTY’S SAKE.] <i>I will not do it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">The text literally reads: I will not do for the sake of the 40. I.E. interprets it as: I will not do a destruction; i.e., I will not bring destruction. Cherez explains, God says, <i>I will not destroy</i>, and at other times, <i>I will not do</i>. I.E. points out that they mean the same thing.</i> means I will not bring destruction. And so as not to prolong his prayers Abraham combined the two previous subtractions.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">That is, from 50 to 45, from 45 to 40. Then Abraham asked if the Lord would destroy the city if 10 were missing from the number to which God had acceded. He no longer asked concerning five.</i> Thus Abraham asked if one quarter of the forty was missing would God destroy the city. He then asked if a third of the thirty were missing, would God destroy it. He concluded by asking if God would destroy the city if half of the twenty righteous men were missing. Some say that Abraham did not ask God to spare for less than ten people because there were five cities and thus less than two righteous per city. However, they are mistaken, for Scripture expressly tells us that Abraham spoke only of Sodom.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">According to Cherez and Krinsky. Cf. I.E.’s comment on verse 24. Perhaps we should render for God only promised with regard to Sodom as: <i>If I find in Sodom</i>, etc. (v. 26). Thus only the men of Sodom are to be counted in the total.</i> Now even though our sages, of blessed memory, transmitted as mere tradition the law that there can be no public prayer when fewer than ten men are present,<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Berakhot</i> 7b, 47b; <i>Megillah</i> 21b.</i> this verse may be taken as a support of our faith in the law which they passed on to us.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that the rabbis could have used this verse as a support for the <i>halakhah</i> concerning the necessity of 10 men for public prayer.</i>

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

AND ABRAHAM RETURNED UNTO HIS PLACE. To Hebron. This vision took place at the spot where Abraham went to accompany the angels on their way.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. accepts the opinion that God revealed himself to Abraham after he sent the angels on their way (cf. I.E.’s comments on v. 13). This vision took place on the day prior to Sodom’s destruction. After Abraham finished pleading for Sodom he returned to Hebron (Cherez).</i> From this spot Abraham looked out toward Sodom. <i>And he (Abraham) looked out toward Sodom and Gomorrah, and toward all the land of the plain, and beheld, and lo, the smoke of the land went up as the smoke of a furnace</i> (Gen. 19:28) took place after sunrise. This is so even though the preceding verse opens with <i>And Abraham got up early in the morning</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Which implies that Abraham looked upon Sodom before sunrise. See I.E. on Gen. 1:18 where he explains that morning comes before sunrise.</i> This is so because Sodom was not destroyed at night. The latter is clearly noted in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 19:23,24. Ibn Ezra implies that Abraham got up early in the morning to go to the place from which he could see Sodom. By the time he got there the sun had already risen and Sodom was destroyed (Weiser).</i>

Chapter 19



Verse 1

[AT EVEN.] The term <i>ba-erev</i> (at even) will be explained in the chapter dealing with the Passover observed by the Israelites in Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Ex. 12:6.</i>
AND HE FELL DOWN ON HIS FACE TO THE EARTH. Until his nose touched the earth. <i>Appayim</i> (his face) refers to the nostrils which protrude from the face.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Af</i> means a nostril; hence <i>appayim</i> (his face) means nostrils or nose. I.E. renders <i>and he fell down on his face to the earth</i> as: <i>and he fell down on his nostrils to the earth</i>.</i>

Verse 2

BEHOLD NOW, MY LORDS. <i>Adonai</i> is to be rendered my lords. It does not refer to God.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">It is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> beneath the <i>nun</i>. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 18:13.</i> When the word <i>sur</i> (turn aside) is followed by a <i>mem</i> it means to turn away from.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>sur mera</i> (turn aside from evil) (Ps. 34:15).</i> When it is followed by the word <i>el</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Either <i>el</i> itself or <i>el</i> plus a pronominal suffix. Cf. Krinsky. We have translated according to <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. The printed editions read <i>alef</i> with a <i>pattach</i>. The meaning is the same.</i> (to) it means turn from your place and come here, or turn from your place and go to a designated place. Compare, <i>surah elai</i> (turn in to me) (Jud. 4:18).
AND THEY SAID: “NAY.” Unless you urge us to do so.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">That is why Lot did not take their refusal as final. According to Krinsky, I.E. was bothered by the angels apparently changing their mind. Thus I.E. interpreted that the tone of their voices indicated that, if pleaded with, they would change their minds (Weiser).</i> The word <i>va-yiftzar</i> (and he urged) indicates the use of many conciliatory words. <i>Haftzar</i> (stubbornness) in <i>And stubbornness</i> (haftzar) <i>is as idolatry and teraphim</i> (I Sam. 15:23)<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Which I.E. renders: pleading with God to change a prohibition is like idolatry and teraphim (Weiser).</i> is similar.

Verse 3



Verse 4

COMPASSED. <i>Nasabbu</i> (compassed) is a <i>nifal</i>.
ALL THE PEOPLE FROM EVERY QUARTER. Those who did not live in the vicinity of Lot’s house.

Verse 5

THAT WE MAY KNOW THEM. A euphemism for sexual intercourse.

Verse 6

TO THE DOOR. <i>Ha-petchah</i> means to the door.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>heh</i> at the end of the word <i>petach</i> means to.</i> The <i>tav</i> of the word <i>delet</i> (door) is the sign of the feminine.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">It is not a root letter.</i> The word <i>delet</i> is also found spelled without the <i>tav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Keep watch at the door</i> (dal) of <i>my lips</i> in Ps. 141:3.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

KNOWN MAN. The third person plural perfect is the same in both the masculine and feminine when not written with a <i>vav</i> conversive which is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>yade’u</i> (have known) is used both for the masculine and the feminine. However, when <i>have known</i> is written with a <i>vav</i> conversive, which is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>, then the masculine and feminine have different forms. The masculine in this case is <i>va-yede’u</i> and the feminine <i>va-tedanah</i>.</i>
THESE. <i>Ha-el</i> (these) means the same as <i>ha-eleh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ha-eleh</i> is the usual term for these.</i> Saadiah Gaon claims that Scripture used the term <i>ha-el</i> because one of the three angels was missing.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">According to Saadiah, had all three angels been present then Lot would have said <i>ha-eleh</i>.</i> However, his comment is far-fetched, for the Aramaic translation of the Pentateuch renders both <i>ha-el</i> and <i>ha-eleh</i> by the same word.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders both <i>ha-el</i> and <i>ha-eleh</i> by <i>ha-illen</i>. If they had different nuances Onkelos would have used a different word for each.</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

WITH BLINDNESS. <i>Sanverim</i> (blindness) has a quadriliteral root. This term is also found in the account of Elisha (II Kings 6:18). It refers to physical and intellectual blindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Netter. Had they only been blind they still could have found the door.</i>

Verse 12

HAST THOU HERE ANY BESIDES? SON-IN-LAW. If you have a son-in-law here.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The angel was not asking a question; he was making a statment: “If you have a son-in-law here…take him out” (Krinsky).</i>
AND THY SONS, AND THY DAUGHTERS. Or sons-in-law who are considered as your sons and daughters.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Lot had no sons (Krinsky). The words “or sons-in-law” have to be supplied by the reader. It is implied in the text. The <i>vav</i>, usually translated as and, here is to be rendered as <i>as</i> (<i>vav ha-dimuy</i>). Cf. Weiser.(</i> We have here a refutation of the opinion that maintains that one of the two angels was sent to save Lot.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i>, Chap. SO, states that each of the two angels sent to Lot had a separate task, one to save him, the other to destroy Sodom.</i> For behold, both angels spoke to Lot. Furthermore, they said to him, <i>for we will destroy this place</i> (v. 13).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Which shows that both angels destroyed Sodom.</i> Also, Lot later said to the angel, <i>behold now, thy servant hath found grace in thy sight, and thou hast magnified thy mercy, which thou hast shown unto me in saving my life</i>, etc. (v. 19). Now that very angel replied to Lot, <i>Hasten thou, escape thither, for I cannot do anything till thou be come thither</i> (v. 22).<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the very angel who saved Lot was also involved in the destruction of Sodom.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

WHO MARRIED HIS DAUGHTERS. Lot had two other daughters who perished in Sodom. This is clear from Scripture’s statement: <i>Arise, take thy wife, and thy two daughters that are here</i> (v. 15).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Which implies that he took the two daughters who were with him in the house. The term “here” implies that there were others. As to the number two, I.E. probably arrived at it as follows: Scripture speaks of <i>sons-in-law, who married his daughters</i> (v. 14). Thus Lot had married daughters. Daughters implies at least two.</i>

Verse 15

AND WHEN THE MORNING AROSE. Rabbi Jonah, the Spanish grammarian,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Janah.</i> said that it is ungrammatical to say <i>u-khemo alah ha-shachar</i> (and when arose the morning).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>u-khe-mo ha-shachar alah</i> (and when the morning arose). The usual Biblical syntax for a clause such as ours is verb, noun, <i>alah ha-shachar</i>, rather than <i>ha-shachar alah</i> (Krinsky). Hence Ibn Janah’s comments that <i>kemo</i> cannot come before a verb in the perfect.</i> However, Rabbi Jonah seems to have forgotten the verse <i>ve-ravu kemo ravu</i> (and they shall increase as they have increased) (Zech. 10:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kemo</i> is connected to <i>ravu</i>, a verb in the perfect.</i>
THEN THE ANGELS HASTENED. <i>Va-ya’itzu</i> (hastened) means they pressured. Compare, <i>And the taskmasters were urgent</i> (atzim), <i>saying</i> (Ex. 5:13).

Verse 16

[BUT HE LINGERED.] I am amazed by Ben Ephraim’s<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">A Kariate Biblical commentator.</i> commentary. He claims that <i>va-yitmahmah</i> (but he lingered) is derived from the same root as <i>mah</i> (what).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">It is written twice. S.D. Luzzato explains this as follows: When one rushes his companion, the latter replies, <i>mah, mah</i>, i.e., what do you want from me, why are you rushing me? Cf. Luzzato’s commentary on Gen. 19:25.</i> However, he seems to have forgotten that both <i>hehs</i> of <i>va-yitmahmah</i> are pointed.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>heh</i> is silent in <i>mah</i> (what). However, it is pointed in <i>va-yitmahmah</i> (but he lingered). I.E.’s comment is difficult. Only the last <i>heh</i> in <i>va-yitmahmah</i> is pointed. Filwarg explains that what I.E. means is that the first <i>heh</i> has a <i>sheva</i> beneath it, while the final <i>heh</i> has a <i>mapik</i>. Hence <i>va-yitmahmah</i> cannot be derived from <i>mah</i>.</i> In reality <i>va-yitmahmah</i> means lingered. It comes from a triliteral root<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>mem, heh, heh</i>. This root means to linger.</i> with the first letter written twice.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>mem</i> is written twice in the word <i>va-yitmahmah</i>.</i>
AND THE MEN LAID HOLD UPON HIS HAND. The verse notes that Lot was overcome with fear and had no strength to flee on his own.

Verse 17

[WHEN THEY HAD BROUGHT THEM FORTH.] <i>Ke-hotzi’am</i> (when they had brought) is an infinitive. <i>Ke-hotzi’am</i> should not be confused with <i>le-hotzi’am</i> (to bring them out), in <i>to bring them out</i> (le-hotzi’am) <i>of the land of Egypt</i> (Jer. 31:32), for in our verse the <i>mem</i> suffix stands for the subject, i.e., the angels.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">While in <i>le-hotzi’am</i> the <i>mem</i> suffix stands for the object.</i> The object of the sentence, Lot and his family, are indicated by the word <i>otam</i> (them).
LOOK NOT BEHIND THEE. Neither you nor any that belong to you.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Al tabbit</i> (look not) is in the singular. I.E.’s point is that <i>al tabbit</i> did not only apply to Lot, but to his entire household.</i> <i>Thou shalt not eat of it</i> (Gen. 2:17)<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Thou shalt not eat of it</i> is a singular. This command did not only apply to Adam. It also applied to Eve. Its meaning is thus: Neither you nor any of yours shall eat of it. Otherwise why would Eve have been punished?</i> is similar.

Verse 18

OH, NOT SO MY LORD. <i>Adonai</i> (my lord) does not refer to God. It is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> only because it comes at the end of the verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Adonai</i> with a <i>kamatz</i> usually refers to God. Here it does not. It means my lords. It is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> because the <i>pattach</i> changes to a <i>kamatz</i> at the end of a verse.</i> Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid the Spaniard, of blessed memory, said that <i>al</i> (not so) in <i>al na</i> (Oh, not so) is derived from the same root as <i>ho’il</i> (wanted, was willing).<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rabbi Samuel the Nagid the word <i>al</i> is an imperative from the root <i>yod, alef, lamed</i>, meaning to want or to be willing (Krinsky). Lot’s reply to the angels was: My lords, please accept (want, show willingness to) my request.</i> However, I believe that <i>al</i> means no. The meaning of our verse is as follows: When the angels told Lot, <i>escape to the mountain</i>, Lot replied, “Oh, not so my lords.” 

Verse 19

He then turned to one of the angels and said, <i>behold now, thy servant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avdekha</i> (thy servant) is in the singular. Hence I.E. says that this was addressed to the angel whom Lot considered to be the most important of the two.</i> <i>hath found grace in thy sight</i>, etc. (v. 19). He did so because he considered this angel to be the more important of the two. The truth is that even among angels there are superiors who lord it over other angels. The <i>tav</i> of the root of <i>mavet</i> (death) is dropped in the word <i>va-matti</i> (and I die). The reason for this is that in the first person perfect a <i>tav</i> and a <i>yod</i> are added to the root. When the <i>tav</i> of the stem and the <i>tav</i> of the suffix come together, the <i>tav</i> of the root is lost in the pronunciation.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise <i>and I die</i> would be written with two <i>tavs</i>, rather than with one. The <i>tav</i> of the root is dropped (swallowed is the term used by I.E.) because it is difficult to pronounce two <i>tavs</i> in succession.</i> The word <i>ve-kharatta</i> (and cut down) in <i>them thou mayest destroy and cut down</i> (ve-kharatta) (Deut. 20:20)<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">If the <i>tav</i> were not lost, <i>ve-kharatta</i> (and cut) would have two <i>tavs</i>, rather than one, for in the second person singular perfect a <i>tav</i> is added to the root.</i> is similar.

Verse 20

A LITTLE ONE. The meaning of <i>mitzar</i> (a little one) is small. It comes from the same root as <i>tza’ir</i> (young, little). It is an adjective.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Modifying city, which is not in the text. Hence the text should read <i>mitzarah</i>, rather than <i>mitzar</i>.</i> Even so, it is written without a <i>heh</i> at its end.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">City is feminine. Therefore the adjective modifying city should be feminine. A <i>heh</i> at the end of an adjective or noun indicates that the word is in the feminine.</i> Compare, <i>shegal</i> (consort).<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">A consort is of course a female. Yet the noun <i>shegal</i> (consort) is written without a <i>heh</i> at its end.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

FROM THE LORD. This is a poetic way of saying from Himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads: <i>Then the Lord caused to rain upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire from the Lord out of heaven</i>. The second <i>from the Lord</i> is redundant. The line should have read: then the Lord caused rain…from Himself out of heaven. I.E. points out that it is poetic to repeat “the Lord” twice. The term I.E. uses for poetic is <i>tzachot</i> (elegant). Weiser interprets it to mean, in our context, precise. The Bible wanted to be precise.</i> We similarly find Scripture repeating the term the children of Israel five times in one verse (Num. 8:19).

Verse 25

AND THAT WHICH GREW UPON THE GROUND. The trees growing there were consumed.

Verse 26

FROM BEHIND HIM. From behind Lot.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">In contradistinction to <i>Targum Jonathan</i>, who interpreted the word to mean from behind her.</i>
A PILLAR. <i>Nitziv</i> (pillar) means the same as <i>matzevah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Matzevah</i> is the term usually used for pillar, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> Her bones were burned by brimstone and she was encrusted in salt,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Weiser suggests translating: she became a pillar of salt. He believes <i>im melech</i> (with salt) to be an error for <i>ammud melech</i> (a pillar of salt).</i> for it is written, <i>brimstone, and salt…like the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that salt as well as brimstone descended upon Sodom.</i> (Deut. 29:22). This verse also shows that Zoar was not destroyed.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 29:22 lists the following cities as being overthrown: Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah and Zaboiim. Zoar is not mentioned.</i> The latter is also borne out by the words of the angel.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Who said, <i>that I will not overthrow the city of which thou hast spoken</i> (v. 21).</i>

Verse 27



Verse 28

AS THE SMOKE OF. <i>Ke-kitor</i> means as the smoke of. <i>Kitor</i> is derived from the same root as <i>ketoret</i> (incense).<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Incense produces a lot of smoke.</i>
A FURNACE. A place where fire is continually burning.

Verse 29

WHEN HE OVERTHREW THE CITIES IN WHICH LOT DWELT. In one of which Lot had been living.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Lot did not dwell in all of the overthrown cities. He dwelt only in Sodom.</i> Each of these is similar: <i>Then died Jephthah the Gileadite, and was buried in the cities of Gilead</i> (Jud. 12:7);<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Its meaning is: and was buried in one of the cities of Gilead.</i> <i>Even upon a colt the foal of she-asses</i> (Zech. 9:9);<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Its meaning is: Even upon a colt the foal of one of the she-asses.</i> and <i>And if a man take with his wife also her mother, it is wickedness: they shall be burnt with fire, both he and they</i> (Lev. 20:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>They</i> does not mean both women. It is only the second one who is burned. If a man is married to a woman and sleeps with her daughter, the daughter is burned. If he is married to the daughter and sleeps with her mother, then it is the mother who is burned. See I.E. on Lev. 20:14. Hence, although the plural is used, it means one of them.</i>

Verse 30



Verse 31

AND THE FIRST-BORN SAID. Lot possibly had a wife who predeceased the wife who turned into a pillar of salt.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible mentions that Lot had married daughters (v. 14) in addition to the ones whom he had at home (v. 8). It is unlikely that any of the unmarried daughters was older than any one of the married ones. I.E. therefore concludes that the married daughters were from a wife other than the mother of the first-born mentioned in our verse. Since the “elder” (literally, the first-born) was younger than the married daughters, she was from the second wife. In view of that fact that Scripture refers only to one wife in the account of Lot’s fleeing from Sodom, I.E. assumes that Lot’s first wife was then no longer alive.</i> Lot’s daughters thought that the world was destroyed by fire and brimstone in the same manner that it had previously been destroyed by the flood.

Verse 32



Verse 33

WHEN SHE LAY DOWN. <i>Be-shichvah</i> (when she lay down) is an infinitive even though it is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> beneath the <i>shin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">We would expect a <i>kamatz katan</i> beneath the <i>shin</i>.</i> <i>Be-shivri</i><sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">It, too, is an infinitive and is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> beneath the first letter of the root.</i> in <i>When I break</i> (be-shivri) <i>your staff of bread</i> (Lev. 26:26) is similar.

Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36



Verse 37

MOAB. Moab is the same as <i>me-av</i> and means from a father.
[UNTO THIS DAY.] No other people were intermingled with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Moab is still the ancestor of the Moabites because all of them are his descendants.</i> <i>Unto this day</i> may also signify that the incestuous origin of the Moabites is known to this day.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The time that the Torah was written.</i>

Chapter 20



Verse 1



Verse 2

OF SARAH HIS WIFE. The word <i>el</i> in <i>el Sarah</i> (of Sarah) should be rendered <i>al</i> (of, concerning).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>El</i> is usually rendered to. Thus our phrase would ordinarily be translated: And Abraham said to Sarah she is my sister. However, this makes no sense. Therefore I.E. points out that <i>al</i> also has the meaning of, concerning.</i> <i>El</i> in <i>For</i> (el) <i>this child I prayed</i> (I Sam. 1:27) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">If we translated <i>el</i> to mean to, this verse would read: to this child I prayed. This would be an impossible rendering.</i> 

Verse 3

The angel appeared to Abimelech in a dream because of God’s regard for Abraham’s honor.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Abimelech was no prophet and consequently would not experience prophetic visions. He did so only because God wanted to safeguard Abraham’s wife. It should be noted that Scripture says God appeared to Abimelech. I.E. explains that God came to him via an angel.</i> Scripture tells us that both Abimelech<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">With regard to Abimelech it is written, <i>And Abimelech King of Gerar sent, and took Sarah</i> (v. 2).</i> and Pharaoh<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>So I took her (Sarah) to be my wife</i> (Gen. 12:19).</i> took Sarah;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Hence both committed the same sin.</i> nevertheless, God brought upon Pharaoh and his house great plagues,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 12:17.</i> while the plagues brought on Abimelech and his house were of a lesser nature. The reason for this is that Abimelech was more righteous than Pharaoh.

Verse 4

[LORD, WILT THOU SLAY EVEN A RIGHTEOUS NATION?] The term <i>nation</i> includes Abimelech, his household and his kingdom. That this is so can be seen from Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9, in which we read, <i>What hast thou done unto us…that thou hast brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin?</i> Thus Abimelech was worried about his kingdom.</i> Pay no attention to the dreamer<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">A term used by I.E. for one who comes up with a far-fetched interpretation. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 2:11. According to Weiser the allusion is to Saadiah. Saadiah renders our verse, “Lord, wilt thou slay even a righteous man?”</i> who changes the terms used in Scripture. The latter explains <i>goy</i> (nation) to mean <i>ish</i> (a person). I will elaborate a bit upon this in my comments on the verse <i>to sell her unto a foreign people he shall have no power</i> (Ex. 21:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Saadiah renders people as person. Cf. I.E.’s comment on Ex. 21:8.</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6

TO TOUCH. <i>Li-nego’a</i> (to touch) means the same as <i>la-ga’at</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse employs <i>li-nego’a</i>. The root of <i>li-nego’a</i> is <i>nun, gimel, ayin</i>. In <i>la-ga’at</i> the <i>nun</i> is dropped; in <i>li-nego’a</i> it remains. The point is that in this <i>peh nun</i> the <i>nun</i> is not dropped in one form of the infinitive. It is treated as a <i>shelemim</i>, a root that does not drop a letter. We find the same with the root <i>nun, tet, ayin</i> (to plant).</i> The same is true<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The word can be expressed in two ways.</i> with <i>li-neto’a</i> (to plant)<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Is. 51:16.</i> and <i>la-ta’at</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Eccles. 3:2.</i> All of the above are infinitives.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">They are also <i>kal</i> forms.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

WHAT HAST THOU DONE UNTO US? <i>Meh</i> (what) is vocalized with a <i>segol</i> because it precedes a guttural.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ayin</i> of <i>asita</i> (thou hast done) is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>. I.E. points out that the Hebrew word for “what” is always vocalized with a <i>segol</i>, (<i>meh</i>) whenever it comes before an <i>ayin</i> vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>. The usual vocalization of “what” is with a <i>pattach</i> (<i>mah</i>), hence I.E.’s comment.</i> This is the rule in Hebrew grammar.

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

AND MOREOVER SHE IS INDEED MY SISTER, THE DAUGHTER OF MY FATHER. Some say that this verse is to be understood in the same way as <i>O God of my father Abraham</i> (Gen. 32:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">That <i>daughter of my father</i> is short for the daughter of my brother, the son of my father, in the same way as <i>O God of my father Abraham</i> is short for O God of my father’s father Abraham (Weiser). Some identify Sarah with Iscah, the daughter of Haran. I.E. rejects this identification. Cf. I.E.’s commentary on Gen. 11:29. Krinsky suggests that what I.E. means is that grandchildren are considered as children. Thus Sarah, the daughter of Haran, was considered Terah’s daughter and hence Abraham’s sister. Similarly Jacob is considered Abraham’s son.</i> However, I believe that Abraham put Abimelech off with a timely excuse. When we come to the verse <i>I am Esau thy first-born</i> (Gen. 27:19), I will offer other examples of the same.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob also was not telling the full truth.</i>

Verse 13

WHEN GOD CAUSED ME TO WANDER. The word <i>Elohim</i> is to be rendered as God.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hitu</i> is the plural. Hence at first glance <i>Elohim</i> cannot refer to God since there is only one God. I.E. points out that even so, <i>Elohim</i> here refers to God. It should be noted that Onkelos apparently took <i>Elohim</i> as referring to idols. See also Rashi’s note on this verse. Cf. M. Adler’s commentary on Onkelos, <i>Netivat Ha-Ger</i>, Israel, 1968.</i> The meaning of <i>hitu oti Elohim</i> (God caused me to wander) is that God made Abraham journey from place to place without Abraham knowing where he would go next. <i>To’eh</i> (wandering) in <i>and, behold he was wandering</i> (to’eh) <i>in the field</i> (Gen. 37:15) is similar. <i>Hitu</i> (caused me to wander) in our verse is not to be translated as caused me to err.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders <i>to’eh</i> as err. He explains <i>when God caused me to wander</i> as meaning: when the nations erred and followed idols, God drew me near to his service; i.e., <i>ka-asher hitu</i> (when the nations erred), <i>oti Elohim</i> (God took me).</i> We find the Bible using the word <i>to’eh</i> in the sense of erring<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">According to Cherez. For an alternate interpretation see Krinsky.</i> in <i>O Lord, why does Thou make us to err</i> (tatenu) <i>from thy ways</i> (Is. 63:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The root of err is <i>tav, ayin, heh</i>, the same as the root for wander. The word can therefore mean wander or err. Erring is an intellectual wandering.</i>
SAY OF ME. <i>Imri li</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>li</i> usually means to me, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> is to be rendered: say of me. <i>And Pharaoh will say of the children of</i> (le-vene) <i>Israel</i> (Ex. 14:3)<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, the <i>lamed</i> means of, not to.</i> is similar.

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

BEHOLD, IT IS FOR THEE A COVERING OF THE EYES. Some say that this alludes to the dimming of her son’s (Isaac’s) eyes.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 27:1.</i> However, the latter is a Midrashic interpretation.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Talmud (<i>Megillah</i> 15a; <i>Baba Kama</i> 93a), Abimelech cursed Sarah for deceiving him. The Talmud states, “Abimelech cursed Sarah and said, may your eyes be covered…The curse took effect on her seed as it is written, <i>And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old, and his eyes were dim</i>.”</i> I believe that the phrase <i>kesut enayim</i> (a covering of the eyes) is to be read as if written twice.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 2:8 and the note thereto. The verse should be read as follows: Behold, I have given thy brother a thousand pieces of silver; behold, he is for thee a covering of the eyes; and he is also a covering of the eyes to all that are with thee. The Hebrew word <i>hu</i> can mean either he or it, Hebrew having no neuter term. I.E. translates the word <i>hu</i> in our verse as he and explains that it refers to Abraham.</i> It is similar to the word not (<i>al</i>) in <i>O Lord, rebuke me not in Thine anger, and chasten me in Thy wrath</i> (Ps. 38:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The word not (<i>al</i>) in Ps. 38:2 is to be read as if written twice: O Lord rebuke me not in thine anger, chasten me not in thy wrath.</i> There are many other such examples in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In which a word written once is to be read as if written twice. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 14:3.</i> Our verse is to be interpreted as follows: Behold, he, viz., Abraham thy husband, is for thee as a covering of the eyes, i.e., no one will dare lift up his eyes to thee.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Because Abraham is your husband. What I.E. seems to be saying is that <i>covering of the eyes</i> refers to other men’s eyes, i.e., because of Abraham it is as if other men’s eyes are covered.</i> He is similarly a covering of the eyes to all that are with thee, namely, the handmaidens who are married to his servants.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">No one will molest any of the handmaidens; i.e., because of Abraham no one will dare lift up his eyes to Sarah or her handmaidens (Filwarg). Weiser explains I.E. as meaning that the handmaidens will honor Sarah and not treat her with disdain.</i> Furthermore, the <i>vav</i> of <i>ve-nokhachat</i> (thou are righted) is rather like the Arabic <i>fa</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>vav</i> is not a connective but is similar to the Arabic <i>fa</i> which serves as a particle introducing the principal part of the sentence (Friedlander).</i> There are thousands of similar <i>vavs</i> in Scripture, an example being <i>On the third day Abraham lifted up</i> (va-yissa) <i>his eyes</i> (Gen. 22:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">If the <i>vav</i> of <i>va-yissa</i> were a connective <i>vav</i>, the verse would read: On the third day and Abraham lifted up his eyes.</i> <i>Ve-nokhachat</i> (thou are righted) is a comment by Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">And not spoken by Abimelech. Abimelech would not first apologize and then reprimand Sarah; hence <i>and after all this Sarah was chastened</i> (ve-et kol nokhachat) is a comment by Moses on the affair. It should be noted that I.E. interprets <i>ve-nokhachat</i> (thou art righted) as chastened, and <i>ve-et kol</i> (and before all man) as: and all, which he explains to mean, and after all this.</i> who added that Sarah did not ever again claim that Abraham was her brother. The meaning of <i>ve-et kol</i> (and before all men) is: after all this; i.e., after all this Sarah was chastened.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. interprets <i>ve-et kol ve-nokhachat</i> as: and after all of this, and after this incident, she was chastened. Netter interprets I.E. as saying: even with all this honor done to her, Sarah was chastened. If the <i>vav</i> of <i>ve-nokhachat</i> were a connective <i>vav</i>, the phrase would read: and after all this and she was chastened, a very awkward construction.</i> Others explain that <i>behold, it is for thee</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See note 27. According to this interpretation <i>a covering of the eyes</i> means a garment appealing to the eyes.</i> refers to money which Abimelech gave for the purchase of a garment, and it is the word <i>natati</i> (I have given) that is to be read as if written twice. The verse is to be interpreted as follows: Behold, I have given thy brother a thousand pieces of silver to buy thee a covering (<i>kesut</i>), meaning a garment, that is appealing to the eye (<i>enayim</i>) and I have also given gifts to all that are with thee, and I have also given Abraham sheep, cattle, man and maidservants.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">This is implied in <i>ve-et kol</i> (and all). It is to be interpreted <i>ve-et kol asher natati</i>, plus everything that I have already given. It should be noted that this third <i>natati</i> is implied in <i>ve-et kol</i> and does not pertain to the <i>natati</i> which is to be taken as if written twice.</i> However, my above quoted interpretation is better. It means that Abraham is a covering of the eyes to thee, before the servants that you had prior to coming here and before the servants that I have given you. class="footnote">According to I.E. the root of <i>ve-nokhachat</i> is <i>yod, caf, chet</i>, meaning to chasten, show (Weiser). For alternate interpretations of I.E.’s comment on this verse, see Filwarg.</i>
Similarly <i>ve-et kol</i> (and before all men) means, and before all men Abraham is your <i>covering of the eyes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">That the <i>covering of the eyes</i> refers to Abraham.</i> 
According to this interpretation only <i>ve-nokhachat</i> (and she was chastened)<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation Abimelech’s statement concludes with: and before all men Abraham is your covering of the eyes.</i> are the words of Moses. Hence the <i>vav</i> of <i>ve-nokhachat</i> is a connective <i>vav</i> as it is normally. Saadiah Gaon says that <i>ve-nokhachat</i> comes from <i>nokhach</i> (in front of).<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">It comes from the root <i>nun, caf, chet</i>, meaning in front of; i.e., you are now able to stand before anyone without shame (Weiser, Cherez).</i> However, he is wrong.<sup>41</sup><i 

Verse 17

AND THEY BORE CHILDREN. That is, Abimelech’s wife and maidservants. It does not refer to Abimelech.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture says: <i>and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maid-servants, and they bore children</i>. As to how <i>and they bore children</i> can apply to Abimemech, see note 48.</i> The following are similar: <i>and shed the blood of war in peace</i> (I Kings 2:5);<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>In peace</i> refers only to Abner, not to Amasa, although both are mentioned in the verse.</i> <i>He spoke unto them in the pillar of cloud</i> (Ps. 99:7);<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">This refers only to Moses and Aaron but not to Samuel even though all three are mentioned in the previous verse.</i> <i>These are the sons of Adah</i> (Gen. 36:12);<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>These are the sons of Adah</i> refers only to Eliphaz and his descendants. It does not refer to Reuel or Amalek. The former was the son of Basemath and the latter the son of Timna. This is so even though both Eliphaz and Reuel are mentioned prior to <i>These are the sons of Adah, Esau’s wife</i> (Weiser).</i> <i>for whom I have served thee</i> (Gen. 30:26),<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to Jacob’s wives not his children. This is so even though both are mentioned in Gen. 30:26.</i> and <i>the father of Abraham, and the father of Nahor; and they served other gods</i> (Josh. 24:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And they served other gods</i> refers to Tereh and Nahor, not to Abraham, even though all are mentioned in the verse (Weiser).</i> That <i>and they bore children</i> does not apply to Abimelech is obvious from the fact that Abimelech per se is omitted from the verse which follows, <i>For the Lord had fast closed up all the wombs of the house of Abimelech, because of Sarah Abraham’s wife</i> (v. 18). I dwell on this point because there are commentators who insist that Abimelech’s bowels were closed up and he could not eliminate.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">See also Rashi who says, “Their bowels were opened and they eliminated. This is what Scripture means by <i>and they bore</i>.”</i> 

Verse 18

However, the presence of the phrase <i>all the wombs</i> (v. 18) clearly refutes their interpretation. The term <i>va-yeledu</i> (and they bore children) is used when referring to women even though it is a masculine form. Compare, <i>va-yechemu ha-tzon</i> (and the flocks conceived) (Gen. 30:39).<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is the females who conceived, Scripture should have read, <i>va-techamnah ha-tzon</i>, rather than <i>va-yechemu ha-tzon</i>. In the same manner Scripture says, <i>va-yeledu</i> (and they bore), which is a masculine form, rather than <i>va-teladnah</i>, which is a feminine form.</i>

Chapter 21



Verse 1



Verse 2

AT THE SET TIME OF WHICH GOD HAD SPOKEN TO HIM. The reference is to the angel who had asked, <i>Where is Sarah thy wife?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 18:9.</i> The same angel also returned to Abraham, for he had promised to do so.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>I will certainly return unto thee when the season cometh round; and, lo, Sarah thy wife shall have a son</i> (Gen. 18:10). I.E. points out that the angel kept his word even though this is not recorded in Scripture.</i> 

Verse 3

[ISAAC.] God never added any letter to Isaac’s name; neither did He ever change it, for God Himself commanded Abraham to call his son Isaac.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham’s name received an additional letter (Gen. 17:5). Jacob’s name was changed to Israel (Gen. 32:29). Isaac was the only one of Israel’s three patriarchs not to have his name changed.</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

MAKING SPORT. Ishmael was acting as a boy is wont to act. Sarah was jealous because he was older than her son.

Verse 10



Verse 11

ON ACCOUNT OF HIS SON. <i>Odot</i> means account of.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND A BOTTLE OF WATER. <i>Chemet</i> (bottle) is a vessel. It is possibly made out of skin or wood. <i>Chamatekha</i> (thy venom) in <i>That puttest thy venom</i> (chamatekha) <i>thereto</i> (Hab. 2:15)<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. renders <i>chamatekha</i> (thy venom) as thy vessel.</i> is analogous. Many are amazed at Abraham’s behavior. They ask, how could Abraham chase his son out of his house? How could he send away mother and child empty handed? Where was his kindness? However, I am amazed at those who are amazed at Abraham, for Abraham acted according to God’s dictates.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">God had told Abraham, <i>in all that Sarah saith unto thee, hearken unto her voice</i> (v. 12).</i> Had he acted contrary to Sarah’s wishes and given money to Hagar, then he would have transgressed God’s command. However, ultimately, after Sarah’s death, he gave gifts to Ishmael’s children.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 25:6. The children of the concubines included Ishmael. As long as Sarah lived Abraham was bound to obey her with regard to Ishmael. After her death he was free to show his concern for Ishmael, and he did.</i>
BREAD AND A BOTTLE OF WATER. He gave the bread and bottle of water to Hagar and placed them upon her shoulder. He then told her, “Take your son with you,” and he sent her away. It is possible that Abraham gave Hagar some gold and silver, although this is not mentioned in Scripture. Abraham at that time lived in Gerar. He gave Hagar enough bread and water to last her till she reached Beersheba.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. assumes that Beersheba was Hagar’s destination and that Abraham gave her enough provisions to last her till she got there. He did not simply cast her out into the desert (Weiser).</i> However, Hagar did not know the way and strayed in the wilderness of Beersheba. Ishmael became ill from lack of water. She took him to her bosom<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. previously noted that Hagar did not carry Ishmael. He therefore has to explain <i>and she cast the child</i> (Cherez).</i> and when she saw that he was dying of thirst, she cast him under one of the shrubs.

Verse 15

UNDER ONE OF THE SHRUBS. One of the trees.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">To provide him with shade (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 16

AS IT WERE A BOWSHOT. <i>Ki-metachave</i> (as it were a shot) is not found elsewhere in the Bible. Its definition is known.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Weiser.</i> It means the distance an arrow travels after being shot.

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

AN ARCHER. Compare, <i>Call together the archers</i> (rabbim) <i>against Babylon</i> (Jer. 50:29). Although <i>roveh</i> (archer) in our verse and <i>rabbim</i> (archers) (in Jer. 50:29) come from different roots, they mean the same thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The root of archer in our verse is <i>resh, bet, heh</i> ; in Jeremiah it is <i>resh, bet, bet</i>.</i> We find a similar case with the words <i>sarar</i> and <i>sarah</i> (ruled over),<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">In Es. 1:22 <i>sorer</i> (bear rule) comes from the root <i>sin</i>, <i>resh, resh</i> ; in Hos. 12:4 <i>sarah</i> (he strove or ruled over) comes from the root <i>sin, resh, heh</i> (Krinsky).</i> also the words <i>ravah</i> and <i>ravav</i>, both of which mean increased.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>ravah</i> is <i>resh, bet, heh.</i> The root of <i>ravav</i> is <i>resh, bet, bet.</i></i>
ARCHER. <i>Kashat</i> (archer) is an adjective. Compare, <i>gannav</i> (thief).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Keshet</i> is a bow, <i>kashat</i> an archer. That this is the case can be seen from its vocalization of a <i>pattach kamatz.</i> This vocalization indicates an adjective, as seen from the word <i>gannav.</i> Hence <i>roveh</i> is not in the construct with <i>kashat.</i> The verse is to be read: he was a shooter, an archer (Krinsky).</i> 
HAVE I EVEN HERE SEEN HIM THAT SEETH ME?<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">This phrase is taken from Gen. 16:13. Some suggest that there is a scribal error in our text and that this comment has been misplaced from 16:13. However, see next note.</i> The angel first appeared to her here.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">That is, she came to the same place where the angel had first appeared to her after she had been cast out by Sarah when pregnant with Ishmael (Chap. 16). Perhaps the original reading in I.E. was: and he dwelt in the wilderness, the place where she (his mother) once said, “Have I even here seen Him that seeth me” (Weiser).</i>

THAT THOU WILT NOT DEAL FALSELY WITH ME. <i>Tishkor</i> (thou wilt deal falsely) is a <i>kal</i>. This is the only place in the Bible that this word appears in the <i>kal</i>.
MY SON’S SON. <i>Nechdi</i> is to be rendered the son of my son.

Verse 29

WHAT MEAN THESE. <i>Hennah</i> (these) is feminine.
BY THEMSELVES. <i>Levaddanah</i> (by themselves) is spelled with a <i>heh</i> at the end of the word. This is the only place in Scripture where the word is so written.

Verse 30

A WITNESS. <i>Le-edah</i> means a witness. It should be noted that the word for oath (<i>shevu’ah</i>) comes from the word for seven (<i>shivah</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The number seven has a mystical meaning. An oath is somehow connected to this mystery. It is for this reason that Abraham took seven ewe lambs (Weiser). Since <i>shevu’ah</i> comes from <i>shivah</i>, Abraham called the place <i>be’ersheva</i>, rather than <i>be’er shevu’ah.</i></i> I will elaborate on this point in my comments on the term <i>oh hishavah shevu’ah</i> (or sweareth an oath).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">For some reason I.E. did not elaborate on this in his comments on Num. 30:3. See Weiser. Also see I.E.’s comments on Zech. 4:10.</i>

Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

A TAMARISK-TREE. <i>Eshel</i> (a tamarisk tree) is a tree.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I Sam. 22:6. Some of the Talmudic sages interpret <i>eshel</i> to mean an inn (<i>Sotah</i> 10a), hence I.E.’s comment.</i> The word <i>va-yitta</i> (and he planted) which precedes it is also proof of this.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Aside from the fact that we know from other sources that <i>eshel</i> is a tree, our verse also indicates the same.</i>

Chapter 22



Verse 1

THAT GOD DID PROVE ABRAHAM. Some say that the word <i>nissah</i> (did prove, tested) is a variation of <i>nissa</i> (lifted up),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The problem which some commentators found in a literal translation of <i>nissah</i> as prove is that it seemed to imply that God did not know what Abraham’s response to his request would be. They thus interpreted <i>nissa</i> as coming from <i>nun, sin, alef</i>, meaning lifted up; i.e., God exalted Abraham by showing him to be a paragon of absolute obedience to the Lord’s will. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 80:55.</i> with the <i>sin</i> replacing the <i>samekh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nissah</i> is spelled <i>nun, samekh, heh</i> ; <i>nassah</i> is spelled <i>nun, sin, alef</i>.</i> and the <i>heh</i> replacing the <i>alef</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>heh</i> in <i>nissah</i>, like the <i>alef</i> in <i>nasa</i>, is silent.</i> However, the plain meaning of the entire chapter contradicts this interpretation.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The chapter deals with a test, a trial. Hence <i>nissah</i> means proved, tested, not exalted.</i> The word <i>nissah</i> is thus to be taken literally. The philosophers teach that there are two kinds of knowledge, knowledge of events prior to their occurrence, and knowledge of what is presently in existence. The latter is the meaning of <i>God did prove,</i> and <i>for now I know</i> (v. 12).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">God knew (now I know) what Abraham would do if tested. However, until Abraham offered Isaac, God’s knowledge was knowledge of the potential or possible. He tested Abraham (did prove) to actualize His knowledge (Krinsky). He now knew what Abraham did, not only what Abraham would do.</i> Saadiah Gaon says that <i>did prove</i> means that God tested Abraham in order to demonstrate his piety to mankind; furthermore, he interprets <i>for now I know that thou art a God-fearing man</i> (v. 12) to mean that now I have made known to all that thou art a God-fearing man.
