But didn’t Saadiah know that even Abraham’s young men were not present when he bound Isaac and placed him on the altar?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. verse 5. In other words, no one was there to witness his act.</i> Others say that <i>and offer him there for a burnt offering</i> is to be interpreted as: bring him up to the mountain; this will be considered as if you brought him up as a burnt offering.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The word translated as offer him { <i>ve-ha’alehu</i>) literally means bring him up.</i> However, Abraham did not understand his prophetic vision<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">He thought that God actually wanted him to offer his son as a burnt offering.</i> and hurried to sacrifice Isaac. God then told him, “I did not ask you to slay Isaac.”Still others say that God told Abraham: act as if you were bringing him up as a burnt offering. We find a similar occurrence in connection with the prophet Jeremiah, who was commanded to <i>Go unto the house of the Rechabites…and give them wine to drink</i> (Jer. 35:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The Rechabites were foresworn by Rechab from drinking wine (Jer., Chap. 35). When God told Jeremiah, <i>and give them wine to drink</i> he did not intend that Jeremiah actually make them drink. Similarly God’s intention was not that Abraham actually sacrifice Isaac. He wanted Abraham to make all the preparations necessary for the sacrifice, i.e., to bind Isaac, lay him on the altar, etc. He was to do everything as if he were offering him as a sacrifice.</i> Now these geonim offered the above interpretations because they held that it is not possible that God would issue a command and then take it back.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">God is unchangeable; hence his mind, too, is unchangeable. Therefore they offered the latter two interpretations.</i> However, they overlooked the fact that God took the firstborn to serve Him and after a year replaced them with the Levites.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The first-born were at first sanctified to God to minister before him (Ex. 13:2). However, the next year the Levites took their place. Cf. Num. 3:40-44.</i> In reality all questions are removed by Scripture’s first stating <i>that God did prove Abraham</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">God did not change His mind. He never intended for Abraham to sacrifice Isaac.</i> The reason God tested Abraham was in order to reward him.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">For his willingness to sacrifice his son in obedience to His will. I.E. now backsteps and explains why God, who is all-knowing, tested Abraham. He had earlier insisted that “prove” is to be taken literally. He now explains why. He similarly alludes to the meaning of <i>for now I know</i>.</i> 
The meaning of <i>for now I know that</i> (v. 12) is the same as <i>and if not, I will know</i> (Gen. 18:21).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 18:21.</i> I will also explain, if God who knows all hidden things will help me, the secret meaning of this term in my comments on <i>I know thee by name</i> (Ex. 33:12).

Verse 2

UPON ONE OF THE MOUNTAINS. The temple was later built on this mountain. This is explicitly stated in Scripture: <i>So Solomon built the house on Mount Moriah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I Kings 6:14 and II Chron. 3:1. The verse quoted by I.E. does not appear anywhere in the Bible. It is a composite of these two verses.</i> It was not a very tall mountain. The threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite was on it.

Verse 3

AND HE CLEAVED THE WOOD FOR THE BURNT-OFFERING. And placed them on his ass.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. derives this from Scripture’s stating that after Abraham left his young men with the ass (v. 5), he placed the wood on Isaac (v. 6). This implies that until then the wood was on the ass (Weiser).</i>

Verse 4

ON THE THIRD DAY. That he set out from Beersheba. 

Verse 5

Some ask, how could Abraham say, <i>and (we will) come back to you</i> (v. 5)?<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">When he knew that only he would return. He should have said, “and I will return.”</i> Others answer them by saying that Abraham intended to return with Isaac’s bones, and he disguised his intentions so that his young men would wait for him till he returned and Isaac would not know what was about to happen and flee.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A prophet may tell an untruth if necessary. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 20:12; 27:19.</i> Our sages, of blessed memory, say that Isaac was thirty-seven years old at the time of his binding.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 56:11.</i> If this be a tradition, we will accept it. However, from a strictly logical point of view it is unacceptable. If Isaac was an adult at this time, then his piety should have been revealed in Scripture and his reward should be double that of his father for willingly having submitted himself to be sacrificed. Yet Scripture says nothing concerning Isaac’s great self-sacrifice. Others say that Isaac was five years old at the time of his binding. This, too, is unacceptable, since Isaac carried the wood for the sacrificial pyre.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">A child of five would be unable to carry that much wood.</i> It thus appears logical to assume that Isaac was close to thirteen years old and that Abraham overpowered him and bound him against his will. Proof of this can be seen from the fact that Abraham hid his intention from Isaac and told him, <i>God will provide Himself the lamb for a burnt-offering, my son</i> (v. 8). Abraham knew that if he said, “You are to be the burnt-offering,” Isaac would quite possibly have fled.

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

ABRAHAM, ABRAHAM. The repetition of the name expresses urgency.

Verse 12



Verse 13

BEHIND HIM A RAM CAUGHT IN THE THICKET. Abraham beheld a ram after (<i>achar</i>) it had been caught in the thicket by its horns.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture reads: <i>achar ne’achaz</i>. This is ungrammatical. I.E. suggests that it be interpreted as if written, <i>achar she-ne’echaz</i> (after it had been caught). J.P.S. renders <i>achar</i> (after) as behind him.</i> If the <i>chet</i> of <i>ne’echaz</i> (caught) is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>, then the word “was” is missing from the text and the meaning of the phrase is, after it was yet caught in the thicket.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In our texts the word <i>ne’echaz</i> (caught) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>. When <i>ne’echaz</i> is so vocalized it is a third person perfect, meaning it was caught. However, there are texts in which <i>ne’echaz</i> is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>. In this instance <i>ne’echaz</i> is a participle, meaning it is caught. If this be the case, then the word “was” has to be inserted in the text to make sense out of the verse, as “was” followed by a participle is proper Hebrew.</i> There are many other similar instances.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">“Was” followed by a participle indicates a continuous action. Compare, in Rabbinic literature, <i>hu hayah omer</i> { <i>Aboth</i> 1:2), literally translated, he was saying; i.e., he used to say.</i> Others say that <i>achar</i> is connected to <i>And Abraham lifted up his eyes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of our verse being: and Abraham lifted up his eyes after this and saw a ram caught in the thicket by its horns. Until now I.E. explains <i>achar</i> (after) as being connected to caught. This new interpretation suggests that <i>achar</i> concludes the first clause in our verse. This is the opinion of Rashi and Onkelos. According to them our verse reads: And Abraham lifted up his eyes after this.</i> But if this were so, the word <i>achar</i> would have been followed by <i>ken</i> or <i>zot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 and Filwarg. Our text is probably corrupt. The word <i>achar</i> is always in the construct. When <i>achar</i> is not in the construct it is written, <i>achar ken</i> or <i>achar zot</i>. Hence our verse should read <i>achar ken</i>. Since it does not, <i>achar</i> cannot be connected to the preceding clause but rather to what follows.</i> as is the case whenever the word <i>achar</i> (after) indicates a pause.

Verse 14

[IN THE MOUNT WHERE THE LORD IS SEEN.] The meaning of this clause can be ascertained in my comments on <i>These are the words</i> (Deut. 1:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. implies in his commentary on Deut. 1:1 that certain phrases in the Pentateuch, among them this phrase, were added later.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16

BY MYSELF HAVE I SWORN. <i>By Myself</i> indicates a great and eternal oath.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">An irrevocable oath.</i>
BECAUSE. <i>Ya’an</i> (because) is similar in meaning to <i>anah</i> (testify or bear witness).<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ya’an</i> is spelled <i>yod, ayin, nun</i> ; <i>anah</i> is spelled <i>alef, nun, heh. Anah</i> means to respond, answer, bear witness.</i> The meaning of the term is: this act will testify and bear witness.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The primary meaning of <i>ya’an</i> is, what is going to happen will bear witness that, etc. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Is. 7:15 and Friedlander’s comment thereto.</i>

Verse 17

THE GATE OF HIS ENEMIES. Cities surrounded by walls having gates.

Verse 18

BECAUSE. <i>Ekev</i> (because) means a reward that is granted at the end.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ekev</i> means heel. The heel is the bottom of a person; hence it means the reward ultimately given (at the end) for a deed (Krinsky, Weiser, Cherez). Thus the clause should be rendered: as a reward for thou hast harkened to my voice.</i>

Verse 19

SO ABRAHAM RETURNED. Isaac is not mentioned because he was under Abraham’s care. Those who say that Abraham slaughtered Isaac and left him on the altar and following this Isaac came to life are contradicting Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture explicitly tells us that God told Abraham not to slay Isaac (v. 12).</i>

Verse 20

BEHOLD, MILKAH, SHE ALSO HATH BORNE. This is stated to inform us of Rebekah’s pedigree.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The purpose of verses 20-23 is to inform us of Rebekah’s pedigree.</i>

Chapter 23



Verse 1

THE LIFE OF. The word life (<i>chayyim</i>) is always encountered in the plural. We never find it in the singular. [A HUNDRED AND SEVEN AND TWENTY YEARS.] Hebrew usually first lists the larger numbers and then the smaller ones.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1 literally reads, <i>And the life of Sarah was a hundred and twenty and seven years</i>.</i> But we also find the opposite, an example being Scripture’s enumeration of Jacob’s years<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 47:28 literally reads, <i>So the days of Jacob, the years of his life were seven years and forty and a hundred years</i>. Here Scripture lists the smaller numbers first.</i> (Gen. 47:28).

Verse 2

KIRIATH-ARBA. Arba was the name of one of the great men of the Anakim.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Now the name of Hebron beforetime was Kiriath-arba, which Arba was the greatest man among the Anakim</i> (Josh. 14:15); <i>even Kiriath-arba, which Arba was the father of Anak</i> (Josh. 15:13).</i> The identification of Arba with Abraham is homiletical,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 14:6.</i> as Abraham was not of that race. When Sarah died Abraham was elsewhere; hence Scripture states, <i>and Abraham came</i>.
AND TO WEEP FOR HER. The word <i>livkotah</i> is to be rendered <i>to weep for her. And bewail her father</i> (Deut. 21:13)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Livkotah</i> is made up of two words, <i>livkot</i> (to weep) and the object <i>otah</i> (her). This combination of pronoun and object can only be made with a transitive verb. However, <i>livkotah</i> is intransitive. The meaning of <i>livkotah</i> is thus to weep her, an impossible rendering. Hence I.E. comments that the meaning of our word is to weep for her. He points out that the same is true in Deut. 21:13 (Krinsky).</i> is similar.

Verse 3

BEFORE HIS DEAD. This alludes to the body.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">His dead (<i>meto</i>) is in the masculine. However, Sarah was a woman. Thus Scripture should have used the feminine (<i>metato</i>). I.E. explains that dead refers to the body, <i>guf</i>, which is a masculine word (Cherez).</i> [SAYING.] The explanation of this term is found elsewhere in this commentary.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ex. 19:3, or perhaps in his comments on verse 17 (Weiser).</i>

Verse 4

I AM A STRANGER. When the word stranger (<i>ger</i>) stands by itself, it refers to a transient stranger. 
<i>And a sojourner</i> (ve-toshav) means a resident stranger.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, when sojourner (<i>toshav</i>) is coupled with stranger (<i>ger</i>) it means a resident stranger (Krinsky). Cherez disagrees. He thinks I.E. is only commenting on the word sojourner (<i>toshav</i>).</i> Abraham said to them, “I am a sojourner among you. We are all mortal, I do not have a possession (<i>achuzah</i>) i.e., an inherited or bought piece of land<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">It comes from the root <i>alef, chet, zayin</i> (to hold). One holds on to land by inheritance or acquisition. <i>Achuzah</i> thus means a holding, the idea being a piece of property with a title.</i> for use as a burial plot.”

Verse 5



Verse 6

MY LORD. Not our lord.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture states, <i>And the children of Heth answered Abraham, saying…Hear us, my lord</i>. Since they apparently all spoke we would expect the use of the term our lord.</i> One man spoke. He employed the term my lord because it is impolite to include others when one is speaking as a subordinate.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>And the children of Heth answered</i> does not mean they all spoke in unison. One man spoke on behalf of all. Had they all spoken, Scripture would have read <i>adonenu</i>. It should be noted that the entire verse, with the exception of <i>adoni</i>, is in the plural.</i>
A MIGHTY PRINCE. Because thou art a prophet. The term <i>elohim</i> (mighty) is used in the sense of great.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>elohim</i> (translated by J.P.S. as mighty) usually means God.</i>
SHALL WITHHOLD. <i>Yikhleh</i> means shall withhold.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>caf, lamed, heh</i> means to finish (see Gen. 2:1). The root <i>caf, lamed, alef</i> means to withhold (see Gen. 8:2; Ps. 40:12). <i>Yikhleh</i> is spelled with a <i>heh</i> in our verse. Hence I.E. points out that <i>caf, lamed, heh</i> can also mean to withhold.</i> It can be spelled either with a <i>heh</i> or an <i>alef</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi makes the same point.</i> 

Verse 7

[AND BOWED DOWN.] I have given the grammatical explanation of this word in <i>The Book of Foundation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 2:17 and the notes thereto.</i> Those who say that Abraham bowed down to God speak nonsense.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">They are troubled by Abraham bowing before another human being.</i> Scripture explicitly states that Abraham bowed to the children of Heth. Bowing means a bending of the head.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham did not prostrate himself. The latter is done in prayer and only before God. He merely bowed his head as a sign of respect.</i> It is a way of showing reverence. Moses also bowed before his father-in-law.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Ex. 18:7.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9

THE CAVE OF MACHPELAH. A cave within a cave.
FOR THE FULL PRICE. The opposite of <i>male</i> (full) is <i>chaser</i> (lacking).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>kesef male</i> (the full price). The word <i>male</i> means full. The opposite of full is empty (<i>rek</i>). I.E. points out that in our case this does not apply. One cannot say, <i>kesef rek</i> (empty money). However, one can say, <i>chaser kesef</i> (money is lacking). Hence <i>male</i> in our verse means the full amount and it is the opposite of <i>chaser</i>, rather than of <i>rek</i> (Filwarg). Thus <i>kesef male</i> means the full price.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

NAY. Not so, <i>my lord,</i> only hear me.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nay, my lord, hear me</i>, could conceivably be taken to mean: My lord should not hear me, hence I.E.’s comment (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 12

BEFORE THE PEOPLE OF THE LAND. Abraham bowed before Ephron in the presence of the people of the land in order to honor him.

Verse 13

BUT IF THOU WILT, I PRAY THEE, HEAR ME. If you will do this<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>if thou wilt</i> is short for thou wilt do this, i.e., give me the field. The verse should be interpreted as follows: But if thou wilt give me the field, I pray thee, hear me, I will give the price of the field; take it of me.</i> I pray thee, hear me. Or it may mean, if you will do this, I pray thee, when I will give the price of the field, take it of me.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>I pray thee</i> (lu) is connected to <i>I will give</i> rather than to <i>hear me</i> as it is in the first explanation. The verse should be interpreted as follows: But if thou wilt give me the field, hear me, I pray thee, when I give the price of the field, take it of me (Cherez).</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

CURRENT MONEY WITH THE MERCHANT. Merchants accept only the best currency.

Verse 17

WERE MADE SURE. The field was made sure and passed permanently into Abraham’s possession. This verse and the one that preceded it are to be read as one verse. Similarly the verse opening with <i>I am a stranger and a sojourner</i> (v. 4) and the verse which precedes it are to be read as one verse. The ten pairs of verses that Saadiah Gaon listed as being in reality one verse are in fact not to be read as one verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Saadiah Gaon lists 10 pairs of Biblical verses that are to be interpreted as one verse. I.E. disagrees with him. Saadiah’s 10 pairs of verses are enumerated by Krinsky.</i> 

Verse 18

[IN THE PRESENCE OF THE CHILDREN OF HETH.] The local inhabitants.
[BEFORE ALL THAT WENT IN AT THE GATE OF HIS CITY.] Those who happened to be passing by.

Verse 19

AND AFTER THIS, ABRAHAM BURIED SARAH HIS WIFE. After the burial of Sarah the field was made sure as a burial ground possession belonging to Abraham and his descendants.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. points out that verse 20 does not repeat verse 17. The latter states that the field was made sure as a possession, the former that it was made sure as a burial ground for Abraham and his descendants (Filwarg).</i> Scripture tells of the purchase of the field of Machpelah to teach us of the superiority of the land of Israel over all countries, both for the living and the dead. Moreover, it informs us that God’s word to Abraham that he would possess the land as an inheritance was fulfilled.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham now began to take actual possession of the land of Israel (Filwarg).</i>

Chapter 24



Verse 1

AND THE LORD HAD BLESSED ABRAHAM IN ALL THINGS. With length of days, wealth, honor and sons, these being all the things that men desire to have. If the interpretation that Abraham had a daughter named Bakkol<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, and the Lord had blessed Abraham <i>ba-kol</i> (in all things). According to the Talmud <i>ba-kol</i> is a proper noun. Cf. <i>Baba Batra</i> 16b, “He (Abraham) had a daughter named Bakkol.”</i> were correct, then Scripture should have read: and the Lord blessed Abraham “with” Bakkol.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>ba-kol</i> is a proper noun then the preposition “with” is missing. Rather than reading <i>ba-kol</i>, the verse should have read, <i>be-vakkol</i> (with Bakkol).</i>

Verse 2

PUT, I PRAY THEE, THY HAND UNDER MY THIGH. Some say that <i>my thigh</i> alludes to Abraham’s circumcised member.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">One who takes an oath must take hold of a holy object. The circumcised member is such an object. Cf. <i>Shebuot</i> 38b and Rashi.</i> However, if this were the case, then Abraham should have made him swear by the covenant of circumcision, and not by the Lord.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">One swears by the holy object that one is holding.</i> I believe that it was customary in those days for a person to place his hand under the thigh of his master, its meaning being, “If you are subject to my authority, place your hand under my thigh.” The lord then sat on his servant’s hand. By doing so the servant, as it were, said to the master, “My hand is under your authority to do your will.” This custom is still followed in India.

Verse 3

[THE GOD OF HEAVEN AND THE GOD OF THE EARTH.] God is so described in our verse because it is ordained in heaven who here on earth will be united in matrimony. This thing is a secret.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">It is one of the secrets of creation (Krinsky). Or the one so ordained is a secret and man must pray that God send him his destined one. Abraham noted this so that his servant would take with utmost seriousness the task laid upon him (Weiser).</i>
OF THE CANAANITES. This includes all of the eleven Canaanite peoples.

Verse 4

BUT THOU SHALT GO UNTO MY COUNTRY. To Haran where he had once dwelt.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 12:1.</i>
AND TO MY KINDRED. Ur of the Chaldees.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 11:31 and I.E.’s comments on Gen. 11:26.</i>

Verse 5

PERADVENTURE. <i>Ulai</i> (peradventure) has many meanings in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In our verse it means, and if (Weiser). It has a similar meaning in Hos. 8:7.</i> <i>If so</i> (ulai) <i>be it yield, strangers shall swallow it up</i> (Hos. 8:7), is similar. 
The <i>heh</i> of <i>he-hashev</i> (must I needs bring back) is vocalized with a <i>segol</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>heh</i> interrogative (<i>heh ha-she’elah</i>) is generally vocalized with a <i>chataf pattach</i>, a furtive <i>pattach</i>. Before <i>heh, alef, chet, ayin</i> it is vocalzed with a <i>pattach</i>. However, here in <i>he-hashev</i> it is vocalized with a <i>segol</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> because the <i>heh</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that before the letters <i>heh, alef, chet, ayin</i> vocalized with a long <i>kamatz</i>, the <i>heh</i> interrrogative is vocalized with a <i>segol</i>, hence the vocalization <i>he-hashev</i>.</i> of the <i>hifil</i> which follows it is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hashev</i> comes from the root <i>shin, vav, bet</i>. The <i>heh</i> of <i>hashev</i> is the sign of the <i>hifil</i>.</i> If the first <i>heh</i> of <i>he-hashev</i> were vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>, it would be difficult to pronounce both <i>hehs</i> in succession.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">That is, if the <i>heh</i> preceding <i>heh, alef, chet, ayin</i> vocalized with a long <i>kamatz</i> were to be vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>, it would be hard to pronounce both <i>hehs</i> in succession. Therefore it is vocalized with a <i>segol</i>.</i>

Verse 6

[BEWARE.] When the word <i>hishamer</i> (beware) is penultimately accented it is related to the word <i>shemirah</i> (watching, guarding).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Thus when <i>hishamer</i> is penultimately accented it means be on guard, beware. This is the usual meaning of <i>hishamer</i> in Scripture. Cf. Deut. 8:11.</i> However, when it is ultimately accented it is related to the word <i>shemarim</i> (lees).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">In this case it means keep calm. Krinsky points out that Is. 7:4 is the only place in Scripture where <i>hishamer</i> is accented on the last syllable.</i> Compare, <i>hishamer</i> (keep calm) in <i>Keep calm</i> (hishamer), <i>and be quiet</i> (Is. 7:4), which has the same basic meaning as <i>shemarav</i> (his lees) in <i>And he hath settled on his lees</i> (shemarav) (Jer. 48:11).

Verse 7

HE WILL SEND HIS ANGEL BEFORE THEE. This is a prayer. If it were a prophecy Abraham would not have said, <i>And if the woman be not willing to follow thee</i> (v. 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">There would have been no need to make contingent plans if God had told Abraham that he would appoint a girl for Isaac from his kindred and country.</i>

Verse 8

THOU SHALT NOT BRING MY SON BACK THITHER. He must remain in the land of Israel. Abraham said, <i>thou shalt not bring my son back</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Isaac never dwelt in the place where the servant was being sent. How, then, could Abraham say, <i>thou shalt not bring my son back thither</i> ? One cannot bring back what was never there. Abraham should have said: thou shalt not bring my son thither.</i> because he (Abraham) was the root.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">And Isaac, as it were, was the tree. If Abraham was the root, then it is as if Isaac were there. Thus on Seder night we read, <i>We were Pharaoh’s bondmen in Egypt</i> (Deut. 6:21). If our ancestors were there it is as if their children were there (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

AND HE MADE THE CAMELS TO KNEEL DOWN. He made them kneel upon their knees.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yavrekh</i> (and he made kneel) is a denominative of <i>berekh</i> (knee) (Weiser).</i>

Verse 12

SEND ME, I PRAY THEE. Its meaning is, prepare for me what I desire.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The object (what I desire) is missing and must be supplied by the reader (Weiser).</i> <i>Because the Lord thy God sent me</i> (Gen. 27:20) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Here, also, the object is missing and is to be supplied by the reader.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

SHE THAT THOU HAST APPOINTED. The servant relied on the efficacy of the prophet’s<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham.</i> prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Thou hast appointed</i> implies that God had already chosen a bride for Isaac. How did the servant know this? I.E. suggests that the servant believed that God had accepted Abraham’s prayer (Krinsky). Or I.E.’s point is that the servant did not set up a test to see if the Lord set aside a damsel for Isaac. He trusted that God had because he relied on Abraham’s prayer (Filwarg). Throughout this section I.E. refers to the servant as “the servant.” He apparently was uncertain as to whether to identify him with Eliezer, as the Midrash and other medieval commentators did.</i> He was certain that God accepted it and sent an angel, the latter being God’s very own messenger, to help him by appointing a damsel in a dream.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s comment is vague. Weiser suggests that an angel appeared to Rebekah and directed (appointed) her to go out to the well. According to Krinsky the angel appeared to Rebekah’s family in a dream and told them to appoint a damsel for Isaac.</i> The servant reasoned that there was no family as charitable as his master’s.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Hence a girl saying, <i>Drink, and I will give thy camels drink also</i> would most probably be of Abraham’s family (Krinsky).</i> Many are perplexed <sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taanit</i> 4a.</i> because they say that the servant expressed his request improperly.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">In other words they claim that the servant selected an improper omen as proof of God’s choice. “What would the servant have done if a lame or a blind girl would have offered to give him and his flocks water? What would he have done if she was not of Abraham’s family and kindred” (<i>Taanit</i> 4a)?</i> I, however, do not see anything wrong in what he said, for had it been another damsel, one not of Abraham’s family, who offered to give him drink and water his camels, he would have left her and nothing would have been lost, for the verse <i>and said; Whose daughter art thou</i> means he had previously said, before he gave the ring and bracelets to Rebekah, <i>whose daughter art thou</i> ?<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 22 and 23 state that the servant first gave Rebekah a golden ring and two bracelets and then said, <i>Whose daughter art thou</i> ? This implies that he took Rebekah for Isaac before he knew who she was. This contradicts what I.E. has just said, hence his interpretation.</i> Scripture similarly states, <i>And I asked her, and said: Whose daughter art thou? And she said: The daughter of Bethuel…And I put the ring upon her nose, and the bracelets upon her hands</i> (v. 47). The sum of the matter is the servant prayed that God would appoint for Isaac a young lady from the family of his master, the sign of God’s choice being that the damsel would act graciously as a woman of noble character should.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Cant. 7:2 (<i>bat nadiv</i>).</i> God heard his prayer. However, the case of Jonathan is totally different.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that the servant did not really set up a test to determine God’s will. He merely offered a prayer that God send him what he was looking for. His choice was not dependent on what the girl would do. If she acted in a certain way then he would investigate further. However, Jonathan set up a test. If such and such would happen he would act thus; if it did not, he would act differently. Jonathan’s test related to his attacking the Philistines. Jonathan said, <i>If they say thus unto us: Tarry until we come unto you; then we will stand still in our place, and will not go up unto them. But if they say thus: Come up unto us; then we will go up; for the Lord hath delivered them unto our hand; and this shall be the sign unto us</i> (I Sam. 14:9, 10).</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16

NEITHER HAD ANY MAN KNOWN HER. It is extremely unlikely that Scripture speaks of abnormal intercourse.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi’s comment on this verse.</i> The verse rather refers to a certain intercourse method wherein it is possible to sleep with a virgin and even to impregnate her without deflowering her. However, it is unseemly to describe how this can be done.

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

AND THE MAN LOOKED STEADFASTLY ON HER. <i>Mishta’eh</i> (looked steadfastly) means the same as <i>mishtomem</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Both <i>mishta’eh</i> and <i>mishtomem</i> come from roots meaning wasted and themselves mean astonished, perplexed or awe-struck.</i> (astonished, awe-struck). It comes from the same root as <i>sha’u</i> and <i>tisha’eh</i> (waste) in <i>Until cities be waste</i> (sha’u) (Is. 6:11),<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishta’eh tisha’eh</i> and <i>sha’u</i> come from the root <i>shin, alef, heh</i>.</i> and <i>And the land become utterly waste</i> (tisha’eh shemamah) (Is. 6:11). 
The meaning of <i>lah</i> (on her) is because of her.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>lah</i> usually means to her. However, it cannot be so translated in our verse. The servant was not astonished to her; he was astonished because of her.</i> <i>Then Daniel…was appalled</i> (eshtomam) <i>for a while</i> (Dan. 4:16) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel was perplexed or astonished. In this verse, too, a word (<i>eshtomem</i>) from a root meaning waste (<i>shin, mem, mem</i>) is used to describe one who is awe-struck or astonished. See note 31.</i> The <i>tav</i> of <i>mishta’eh</i> is not part of the root of the word but is the sign of the <i>hitpa’el</i> conjugation. It is like the <i>tav</i> of <i>nitra’eh</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>nitra’eh</i> is <i>resh, alef, heh</i>. The <i>tav</i> of <i>nitra’eh</i> is the <i>tav</i> of the <i>hitpa’el</i>.</i> in <i>let us look</i> (nitra’eh) <i>one another in the face</i> (II Kings 14:8). <i>Mishta’eh</i> definitely does not come from the root <i>shin, tav, heh</i> (drink).<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Some versions of Onkelos read, <i>and the man was drinking</i>. See Krinsky. According to this interpretation the man acted as if he was drinking, but he was really looking at Rebekah (Cherez).</i>

Verse 22

A GOLDEN RING. <i>Nezem</i> (ring) can refer either to a nose ring<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">See verse 47.</i> or to an earring.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">See Gen. 35:4.</i> The one worn on the nose is attached by a string which is tied around the forehead.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky suggests that I.E. was not aware of the fact that nose rings are inserted in the pierced nostril.</i>
HALF A SHEKEL. <i>Beka</i> means half a shekel. It comes from the same root as <i>nivka</i> (was cleft).<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">See Gen. 7:11. A <i>beka</i> is thus a split shekel, i.e., half a shekel.</i>
AND TWO BRACELETS. <i>Tzemidim</i> (bracelets) comes from the same root as <i>tzamid</i> (cover of a vessel) in <i>covering</i> (tzamid) <i>close-bound</i> (Num. 19:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tzemed</i> means a pair. Cf. <i>a couple of asses</i> (tzemed chamorim) (Jud. 19:10). According to I.E. a <i>tzamid</i> (Num. 19:15) is a cover made up of two parts. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Num. 19:15. Hence a <i>tzemed</i> is a bracelet made of two parts.</i> A bracelet is called a <i>tzamid</i> because each bracelet worn on the hand is made up of two parts.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">For a different interpretation see Filwarg.</i> The form of this ornament is well known.

Verse 23

TO LODGE IN. <i>La-lin</i> (to lodge in) is in the <i>hifil</i>. If it were a <i>kal</i> it would read <i>la-lun</i>.

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

AND PROVENDER. <i>Mispo</i> (provender) is a general term for cattle feed. The Bible could have used barley in its place.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Barley was used as animal feed. See I Kings 5:8 and <i>Sotah</i> 14a.</i>

Verse 33

AND THERE WAS SET. <i>Va-yusam</i> (and there was set) is in the <i>hofal</i>. It is like <i>va-yushav</i> (brought) in <i>And Moses and Aaron were brought</i> (va-yushav) (Ex. 10:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yushav</i> is a <i>hofal</i>.</i> 

Verse 34

Some say that the statement <i>I am Abraham’s servant</i> is connected to <i>I will not eat</i>, the meaning of the verse being: I am Abraham’s servant and there are certain foods which we are prohibited from eating. However, I believe that the meaning of the servant’s words are self-evident.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Since God sent him good speed he did not want to eat till he had completed his task (Krinsky). It is proper to take care of one’s obligations first and then to eat (Weiser).</i>

Verse 35



Verse 36



Verse 37



Verse 38



Verse 39



Verse 40



Verse 41

THEN SHALT THOU BE CLEAR FROM MY OATH. The servant did not say, from my <i>shevu’ah</i> (oath).<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">He said, from my <i>alah</i>. However, in verse 8, Scripture employs the term <i>shevu’ah. Alah</i> is an oath which has a curse attached to it. Cf. Num. 5:21. The servant thus emphasized that the oath he took had a curse attached to it; i.e., a curse would fall upon him if he violated the oath (Weiser).</i> What he meant was, “I fear my master and his curse.”

Verse 42



Verse 43



Verse 44



Verse 45



Verse 46



Verse 47



Verse 48



Verse 49

KINDLY. <i>Chesed</i> (kindly) denotes an act which one is not obligated to perform.
AND TRULY. <i>Emet</i> (truly) denotes keeping the promise to deal kindly. The word <i>emet</i> comes from the same root as <i>emunah</i> (steadfastness).<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The root being <i>alef, mem, nun</i>.</i> The <i>tav</i> of <i>emet</i> is the sign of the feminine.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">If the root of <i>emet</i> is <i>alef, mem, nun</i>, where does the <i>tav</i> come from? I.E. points out that it is the sign of the feminine. The word should read <i>amenet</i>. However, the <i>nun</i> of the root is dropped (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 50



Verse 51

AS THE LORD HATH SPOKEN. As the Lord hath decreed. <i>By the word of the Lord were the heavens made</i> (Ps. 33:6)<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew <i>bi-devar adonai</i>. I.E. renders this verse: By the decree of the Lord were the heavens made.</i> is similar. On the other hand, it may mean: as the Lord hath appointed in a dream.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on verse 14 and the notes thereto.</i>

Verse 52



Verse 53

PRECIOUS THINGS. <i>Migdanot</i> (precious things) comes from the same root as <i>megadim</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>mem, gimel, dalet</i>. In this case the <i>nun</i> of <i>migdanot</i> is not a root letter.</i> (precious) (Cant. 4:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Cant 4:13 reads, <i>precious fruits</i> (magadim). He thus gave them precious or sweet fruits.</i> On the other hand, it may mean expensive garments. In the latter case the <i>nun</i> of <i>migdanot</i> is part of its root,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Its root being <i>gimel, dalet, nun</i>. In this case the <i>mem</i> is not a root letter and the word is a <i>hapax legomenon</i> (Filwarg).</i> and the word <i>migdanot</i> follows the paradigm of <i>mitpachot</i> (cloaks).<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Is. 3:22. Here, too, the <i>mem</i> is not a root letter but is the <i>mem</i> of the paradigm.</i>

Verse 54



Verse 55

AND HER BROTHER AND HER MOTHER SAID. They received the gifts and Bethuel was silent.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. disagrees with the Midrash, which states that an angel slew Bethuel for trying to prevent the marriage. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 60:12, and Rashi.</i> It is possible that Laban was wiser and more respected than his father, for we find, <i>Then Laban and Bethuel answered</i> (v. 50).<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Since Laban is mentioned before Bethuel we may surmise that he was more respected than Bethuel, or else he would not have dared to speak before his father.</i>

Verse 56



Verse 57



Verse 58



Verse 59

AND HER NURSE. In former days.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Rebekah, being of marriageable age, had no need for a nurse. I.E. disagrees with the Midrashic statement that Rebekah was three years old at that time. See <i>Seder Olam</i>, Chap. I.</i>

Verse 60



Verse 61

AND THEY RODE UPON THE CAMELS. That the servant brought with him.
AND WENT HIS WAY. <i>Va-yelakh</i> (and went his way) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> rather than a <i>kamatz</i> even though it closes a verse,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>pattach</i> usually changes to a <i>kamatz</i> at the end of a verse. We would thus expect <i>va-yelakh</i> to be vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>.</i> the reason for this being that this word is normally vocalized with a <i>segol</i>, and a vowel cannot go up two steps.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And he went</i> is usually written with a <i>segol</i> (<i>ya-yelekh</i>). However, since here it closes a verse, the <i>segol</i> changes to a <i>pattach</i>. It cannot change to a <i>kamatz</i> because it would then be going up two steps, that is, from a <i>segol</i> to a <i>kamatz</i>, skipping the step of <i>pattach</i>. The normal sequence of the vowels followed by I.E. is <i>segol pattach, kamatz</i>.</i> The same principle applies to the word <i>va-yomar</i> (and he said).<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yomer</i> (and he said) is vocalized <i>va-yomar</i> with a <i>pattach</i> and not a <i>kamatz</i>, at the close of a verse.</i> 
The meaning of <i>And the servant took Rebekah, and went his way</i> is that he took Rebekah under his personal care until Isaac came up toward them and did not experience any hardship in caring for her.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The servant did not assign any of the people with him to take care of Rebekah. He did so himself and did not consider it a burden, so devoted was he (Weiser).</i>

Verse 62

AND ISAAC CAME FROM THE WAY OF BEER-LAHAI-ROI. Beer-lahai-roi has two names.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Bo and Beer-lahai-roi. The Hebrew reads, <i>ba mi-bo be’er-la-chai ro’i</i>. If the Bible meant Isaac came from Beer-lahai-roi it should have read, <i>ba mi-be’er-la-chai-ro’i</i>. The word <i>mi-bo</i> thus presents a problem. This interpretation suggests that the verse be translated: Isaac came from Bo-beer-lahai-roi, the latter being a combination of both names (Cherez).</i> Others say that <i>ba mi-bo</i> (came from the way) means came from the inside of.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., <i>mi-bo</i> means from inside. They explain our verse to mean that Isaac came from inside (<i>mi-bo</i>) of Beer-lahai roi. The latter was a town in which the well by that name was located. The town took the name of the well. Isaac had some business in this town and was leaving it when he met Rebekah (Weiser).</i> They similarly explain the word <i>mi-bo</i> in <i>Every house is shut up, that none may come in</i> (mi-bo) (Is. 24:10). However, I believe that <i>mi-bo</i> is an infinitive<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">That is, it consists of the infinitive <i>bo</i> (come) plus the prepositional <i>mem</i>. Thus <i>mi-bo</i> means from the way.</i> and <i>ba mi-bo be’er-la-chai-ro’i</i> means came from the way leading to Beer-lahai-roi.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Isaac was returning from a visit to Be’er-lahai-roi.</i>
FOR HE DWELT IN THE LAND OF THE SOUTH. For at the time he dwelt there (in the Negev). The latter is in the southern part of the land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Isaac lived in the Negev. He happened to be coming from Beer-lahai-roi on that day (Weiser).</i>

Verse 63

AND ISAAC WENT OUT TO MEDITATE. The word <i>la-su’ach</i> (to meditate) means to walk among the trees.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">See Gen. 2:5, <i>si’ach ha-sadeh</i> (shrub of the field).</i>
AT THE EVENTIDE. Close to sunset. The opposite of <i>li-fenot erev</i> (at the eventide) is <i>lifnot boker</i> (before the dawning of the day). I will give a full explanation of these terms in the Torah portion <i>Ki Tetze</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 21:10 - 25:19. Cf. I.E.’s comment on Deut. 23:12, where he notes <i>li-fenot erev</i> means before evening.</i>

Verse 64

[SHE ALIGHTED FROM THE CAMEL.] Of her own free will.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads <i>va-tippol</i> (she fell). Krinsky explains that I.E. translates she fell as she willingly fell from the camel. Weiser explains that she came off the camel in order to bow; that is, she alighted.</i> Compare, <i>he fell upon his face</i> (Num. 16:4). What is reported in the following verse took place before, for the meaning of <i>va-tomer el ha-eved</i> is: And she had said unto the servant.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The sequence of events was as follows: And Rebekah lifted up her eyes and saw Isaac (v. 64) and she said unto the servant, “What man is this that walketh in the field to meet us?” And the servant said, “It is my master.” And she took her veil and covered herself (v. 65). And she alighted from the camel (v. 64) (Cherez).</i>

Verse 65

AND COVERED HERSELF. <i>Va-titkas</i> (and covered herself) is in the <i>hitpa’el</i>. The first <i>tav</i> is the sign of the third person feminine, and the second <i>tav</i>, the <i>tav</i> of the <i>hitpa’el</i>.

Verse 66



Verse 67

INTO HIS MOTHER SARAH’S TENT. This is short for the tent, tent of Sarah his mother.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads <i>ha-ohelah Sarah immo</i>. Now a word with the emphatic <i>heh</i> cannot be in the construct Hence the verse literally reads: the tent Sarah his mother. I.E. maintains that an additional word, tent, has to be added to the text. The text should be read as if written, the tent, tent of Sarah his mother. More literally, the tent, Sarah his mother’s tent.</i> <i>Even the prophecy of Oded the prophet</i> (II Chron. 15:8)<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The text literally reads: <i>ve-ha-nevu’ah Oded ha-navi</i> (even the prophecy, Oded the prophet). I.E. suggests, for the reasons given in note 67, that the word <i>nevu’at</i> (prophecy of) is to be supplied by the reader. The verse should thus be read: the prophecy, Oded the prophet’s prophecy, more literally, even the prophecy, prophecy of Oded the prophet.</i> and <i>Thy throne given of God</i> (Ps. 45:7)<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">A word ending in the suffix <i>kha</i> cannot be in the construct. The verse literally reads: Thy throne, God. I.E. suggests the word <i>kisseh</i> be inserted after thy throne. The verse is to be explained: Thy throne, God’s throne, more literally, Thy throne, throne of God.</i> are similar.

Chapter 25



Verse 1

KETURAH. Keturah is not to be identified with Hagar<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 61:4; also Rashi’s comments.</i> because Scripture explicitly states, <i>But unto the sons of the concubines</i> (pilagshim), <i>that Abraham had, Abraham gave gifts</i> (v. 6).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">“Concubines” indicates that Abraham had more than one concubine. If Keturah and Hagar were one and the same person the verse would have read concubine. I.E. goes on to note that <i>pilegesh</i> (concubine) refers exclusively to a handmaid to forestall the argument that verse 6 refers to male slaves (<i>pilagshim</i> has a masculine ending) and therefore negate his argument that Abraham had more than one concubine.</i> The meaning of <i>pilegesh</i> (concubine) is a handmaid. This term cannot refer to a male. We can explain <i>upon concubinage</i> (Ezek. 23:20) as referring to females.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The printed editions have, “We can explain on concubines as women.” If we accept this reading the point that I.E. is apparently making is that even though the word <i>pilagshim</i> has a masculine ending it refers to females (Weiser). However, Filwarg and Krinsky, as well as Weiser himself, point out that I.E. may be alluding to Ezek. 23:20, <i>And she doted on concubinage</i> (pilagshehem) <i>with them, whose flesh is as the flesh of asses, and whose issue is like the issue of horses</i>. The words <i>be-saram</i> (whose flesh) and <i>zirmatam</i> (whose issue) are masculine; hence the concubines spoken of in this verse appear to be males. Indeed, Kimchi in his comments on Ezek. 23:20 quotes an opinion which maintains that the concubines referred to in this verse are male slaves. Therefore I.E. points out that <i>pilagshim</i> refers only to females. Filwarg suggests amending our texts of I.E. to read <i>pilagshehem</i>, as in Ezek. 23:20. In this case the allusion to Ezekiel would be unmistakable. The fact of the matter is that <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads <i>al pilagshehem</i>, and we have translated accordingly.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

ASSHURIM. Some say that <i>asshurim</i> means those who know the roads<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Caravaneers. This interpretation connects <i>asshurim</i> with <i>ashur</i> (step or going). See Job 31:7; Prov. 14:15.</i> and <i>letushim</i>, those who see from afar.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 16:9, <i>yiltosh enav</i> (sharpeneth his eyes). This term, too, pertains to their occupation as caravaneers.</i> However, I believe that <i>asshurim</i> and <i>letushim</i> are proper nouns and not adjectives.

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

GIFTS. He gave them money.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">That is, movable possessions, in contrast to real estate (Weiser).</i>
EASTWARD. <i>Kedemah</i> (eastward) means <i>unto the East country. And it shall come to pass, that the nation and the kingdom which will not serve him, Nebuchadnezzar King of Babylon</i> (Jer. 27:8)<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">This is the literal reading of the verse. J.P.S. translates, <i>And it shall come to pass, that the nation and the kingdom which will not serve the same Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon</i>.</i> is similar. East means east of the land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Eastward refers to the entire eastern compass point, be it northeast or southeast (Weiser). According to this interpretation <i>unto the east country</i> is an explanation of <i>eastward</i> in the same way that <i>Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon</i> is an explanation of <i>him</i>.</i> Others say that <i>kedemah</i> (eastward) means to the place where the son of Ishmael dwelt.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">This explanation is that <i>kedemah</i> means to Kedemah. Kedemah was a son of Ishmael (v. 15). According to this interpretation the verse is not redundant in stating <i>unto the east country</i>, for it is telling us where Kedemah dwelt.</i> The first of these two interpretations is the correct one.

Verse 7



Verse 8

[AND ABRAHAM EXPIRED.] Expired refers to a death wherein the soul leaves the body in a moment, without pain or delay. Proof of this is <i>he (Jacob) gathered up his feet unto the bed</i> and then immediately expired (Gen. 49:33).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that <i>gava</i> refers to a quick and painless death.</i> Every expiration (<i>gevi’ah</i>) is a death, but not every death is an expiration (<i>gevi’ah</i>). Hence Scripture states, with regard to those who perished in the flood, <i>And all flesh expired</i> (Gen. 7:21). <sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E., Gen. 7:12 teaches that the flood killed swiftly (Weiser).</i> 
The meaning of, <i>and (Abraham) died</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">There was no need to state “and Abraham died” after stating “and he expired,” since expired means he died quickly.</i> is that he died at a ripe old age.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And Abraham died</i> is not redundant since it is not connected to expired but to what follows, i.e., <i>and Abraham died in a good old age</i> (Filwarg).</i>
AND WAS GATHERED TO HIS PEOPLE. Some say that this refers to the soul of life which, even while functioning<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. uses the term <i>kevod ha-nefesh</i> literally, the glory of life. The “glory” refers to man’s soul which gives life to the body.</i> in the body, is a separate entity. When it separates from the body it returns to its source.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. man’s soul is derived from a universal soul. While in the body the soul does not share the former’s corporeal properties. It has its own existence and can function independently of the body. It is thus a “separate entity” (Levine, p. 13).</i> Others say that <i>and was gathered to his people</i> is a mere idiom.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation there is no philosophical implication in the verse.</i> One who follows in the footsteps of his ancestors is said, as it were, to be joining them. <i>But thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace</i> (Gen. 15:15) is similar.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

AND BY THEIR ENCAMPMENTS. <i>Tirotam</i> (encampments) means palaces. Compare, <i>a turret of silver</i> (tirat kasef) (Cant. 8:9).
ACCORDING TO THEIR NATIONS. We find Scripture employing <i>ummot</i> (nations) and <i>ummim</i> (nations),<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Num. 25:15 (<i>ummot</i>); Ps. 117:1 (<i>ummim</i>). The former has a feminine ending, the latter, a masculine ending. Our verse (<i>le’ummatam</i>) employs the former.</i> both of which are vocalized with a <i>shuruk</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Actually a <i>kubbutz</i>. I.E. refers to both a <i>kubbutz</i> and a <i>shuruk</i> by one term, <i>shuruk</i>. Cf. L. Prijs, <i>Die Grammatikalische Terminologie Des Ibn Ezra</i>, Basel, 1950, p. 136.</i> The <i>lamed</i> of <i>le-ummatam</i> (according to their nations) is a preposition,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">It is not a root letter. It means according to.</i> similar to the <i>lamed</i> of <i>le-goyehem</i> (after their nations). It is not the same as the <i>lamed</i> of <i>ba-le’ummim</i> (upon the peoples) (Ps. 149:7) which is a root letter like the <i>lamed</i> of <i>le’om</i> (people) in <i>And the one people</i> (u-le’om) <i>shall be stronger than the other people</i> (mi-le’om) (v. 23). Whether spelled with a <i>lamed</i> or not, it has the same meaning. However, they come from different roots.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">That is, both <i>om</i> and <i>le’om</i> mean the same, but come from different roots. The root of <i>om</i> is <i>alef, vav, mem</i> and that of <i>le’om, lamed, alef, mem</i> (Cherez, Krinsky).</i>

Verse 17



Verse 18

OVER AGAINST ALL HIS BRETHREN. Zimram and Jokshan.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i>
HE DID SETTLE.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: <i>upon the face of his brethren he (or it) fell</i>. I.E. points out that fell must refer to Ishmael’s portion or to Ishmael himself. It may also mean settled.</i> The meaning of <i>nafal</i> (fell) is that his portion or his lot fell among his brethren. Or it refers to the fact that most of the Ishmaelites journeyed from place to place. In this case <i>nafal</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">That is, it means passed over.</i> is like <i>nofel</i> in <i>Thou fallest away</i> (nofel) <i>to the Chaldeans</i> (Jer. 37:13). However, this is a bit far-fetched in view of the fact that his brethren were in the east (v. 6), and Egypt and Asshur are west<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">This comment presents a problem in view of the fact that Assyria (Asshur) lies east of the land of Israel. Krinsky suggests that Asshur does not refer to the Assyrians but rather to the children of <i>dedan</i> who were Asshurim (v. 3).</i> of the land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">It is hard to believe that they had so large an inheritance. I.E.’s comment applies to all the interpretations of <i>nafal</i> offered up to this point.</i> It is possible that this verse deals with Ishmael’s death. He died during the lifetime of his brethren, after he fell.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">He fell off a roof or out of a tree and died (Krinsky). This interpretation is possible because we do not know any of the causes of his death. Cohen, on the other hand, suggests that I.E. held that fell means fell dead.</i> We do not know the cause of Ishmael’s death.

Verse 19

AND THESE. After recording the generations of Ishmael, Scripture returns to record the progeny of Isaac, Esau and Jacob. Some say that <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i> means that Isaac resembled his father, and all who looked upon him could tell that he was Abraham’s son.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Baba Metziah</i> 87a and Rashi.</i> Others say that <i>holid</i> (begot) means raised and brought up, as in <i>were born</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. renders <i>yulledu</i> as: were brought upon Joseph’s knees. They obviously were not born on his knees.</i> (yulledo) <i>upon Joseph’s knees</i> (Gen. 50:23). This interpretation is substantiated by <i>And he sent them away from Isaac his son</i> (v. 6).<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">He did not raise the sons of the concubines but he raised Isaac.</i>

Verse 20

OF PADDAN. <i>Paddan</i> means a field. It has the same meaning in Arabic.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Similarly Rashi.</i>
THE SISTER OF LABAN. Laban is mentioned because he was better known and more revered than her father. <i>Elisheba…the sister of Nahshon</i> (Ex. 6:23), is similar.

Verse 21

AND ISAAC ENTREATED. <i>Va-yetar</i> (entreated) is in the <i>kal</i>. However, <i>hatiru</i> (entreat) in <i>Entreat the Lord</i> (Ex. 8:4) is in the <i>hifil</i>. Its meaning is that Isaac appeased<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Vocalizing the <i>resh, tzadi, heh</i> with a <i>chirik</i> and reading the word <i>ritzah</i>, as in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38.</i> God with his prayers.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Reading <i>bi-devarim</i> as in <i>Vat. Ebr. 3</i>8, rather than <i>bi-divrehem</i> as in the printed texts. The latter reading is extremely difficult. It reads: <i>ratzah</i> (he wanted)…<i>bi-divrehem</i> (their words). Krinsky tries to justify this reading by maintaining that I.E. explains why entreat is here in the <i>kal</i> and in Ex. 8:4 in the <i>hifil</i>. It is here in the <i>kal</i> because God wanted their prayers. However, He really did not want to hear prayers on behalf of Pharaoh, hence the <i>hifil</i> form in Exodus. The latter being in the causative form implies that Moses burdened God with his prayers on behalf of Pharaoh. Krinsky also suggests that the text be read: he appeased God (vocalizing <i>ritzah</i> rather than <i>ratzah</i>) with their prayers, that is, with Isaac and Rebekah’s prayers. This is a bit forced. <i>Vat. Ebr.’s</i> reading is superior and has been followed.</i>
AND THE LORD LET HIMSELF BE ENTREATED. <i>Va-ye’ater</i> means and He was appeased. It is a <i>nifal</i>.

Verse 22

AND THE CHILDREN STRUGGLED TOGETHER. <i>Va-yitrotzatzu</i> (and they struggled) comes from the word that means running.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The root of run is <i>rash, vav, tzadi</i>. According to I.E., <i>And the children struggled…within her</i> is to be rendered: and the children ran within her, that is, moved quickly within her.</i> The <i>tzadi</i> is doubled.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">As is the rule when an <i>ayin vav</i> is conjugated in the <i>hitpa’el</i>.</i> Its parallel is found in <i>They run to and fro</i> (yerotzetzu) <i>like the lightnings</i> (Nahum 2:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yerotzetzu</i> (run to and fro) is from the root <i>resh, vav, tzadi</i>. The <i>tzadi</i> is doubled in keeping with the rule that the last letter of an <i>ayin vav</i> is doubled when conjugated in the <i>pi’el</i>.</i> The Bible refers to the fetuses as children<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Banim</i> (children) always refers to born children. A fetus is not a child (Krinsky).</i> because that is what they ultimately became.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads: <i>nekre’u banim al shem sofam</i>.</i> <i>And stripped the naked of their clothing</i> (Job 22:6)<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">One cannot strip the naked.</i> is similar. Rebekah asked women who had children if they had had a similar experience. They responded that they did not. 
Rebekah then said, <i>if it</i>, namely, the manner and custom of pregnancy, <i>be so</i> as they said, <i>wherefore do I</i> undergo such an abnormal pregnancy.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Lammah zeh anokhi</i> (Wherefore do I live) literally reads: why, then, am I, which I.E. interprets to mean: why, then, am I undergoing an abnormal pregnancy. It should be noted that according to I.E., Rebekah’s questioning of the other women is not stated in the text but is implied by her saying, <i>im ken lammah zeh anokhi</i>.</i>

Verse 23

AND THE LORD SAID UNTO HER. Via a prophet, or through Abraham himself, for Abraham did not pass away until her sons were fifteen years of age.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham begot Isaac at the age of 100 (Gen. 21:5). Isaac was 60 when he begot Jacob and Esau. Abraham lived 175 years (Gen. 25:7). Thus Jacob and Esau were 15 when Abraham died.</i>
THE ELDER. Elder is the subject.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Et</i>, the indicator of the direct object, is missing in our verse. I.E. points out that even so, <i>elder</i> is the subject and <i>younger</i> the object, the meaning of our verse being the elder shall serve the younger. <i>Ve-rav ya’avod tza’ir</i> is the same as <i>ve-rav ya’avod et hatza’ir</i>. One can argue that since this verse is poetic it has placed the object first and the subject last and that its intention is to teach that the younger shall serve the elder, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> <i>A son honoureth his father</i> (Mal. 1:6) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, <i>et</i> is missing. However, it is obvious that it is the son who honors the father and not the reverse. We thus see that the Bible at times omits <i>et</i>. Nevertheless, the syntax of the sentence remains subject (son), object (father). Similarly in our verse the subject (elder) is stated first and the object (younger) afterward.</i> I will explain our verse later.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E. on Gen. 27:40.</i>

Verse 24

TWINS. The root letter <i>alef</i> is missing in the word <i>tomim</i> (twins). <i>Tomim</i> in this regard is like the word <i>sheritikha</i> (release thee)<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">This is the J.P.S. translation. I.E. renders it your remnant. <i>She’erit</i> is usually spelled with an <i>alef</i>, which is missing in our verse. Thus <i>tomim</i> is like <i>sheritikha</i> in that the root <i>alef</i> is missing in both words. <i>Tomim</i> should have been written <i>te’omim</i> and <i>sheritikha, she’eritkha</i>.</i> in <i>Verily I will release thee</i> (sheritikha) <i>for good</i> (Jer. 15:11), the meaning of which is: I will deal well with thy last years (<i>she’erit</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Your last years, your <i>she’erit</i>, will be happy years. Cf. Kimchi’s comment on this verse.</i>

Verse 25

[RUDDY.] The <i>yod</i> of <i>admoni</i> (ruddy) is superfluous. It is similar to the <i>yod</i> of <i>akhzari</i> (cruel).<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Akhzar</i> and <i>akhzari</i> mean the same thing, cruel. Hence its <i>yod</i> is superfluous. Similarly <i>admoni</i> and <i>admon</i> mean the same thing and Scripture could have read <i>admon</i>.</i>
[LIKE A MANTLE.] <i>Ke-adderet</i> (like a mantle) is not in the construct with <i>se’ar</i> (hairy).<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the text is not to be interpreted as <i>kullo ke-adderet se’ar</i> (all over like a hairy mantle) but as <i>kullo se’ar ke-adderet</i> (all over hairy; like a mantle). In other words, <i>kullo</i> (all over) refers to <i>se’ar</i> (hairy) even though the word <i>ke-adderet</i> (like a mantle) separates the two (Krinsky).</i> The verse is to be read as follows: all over hairy, like a mantle. However, others say that <i>ke-adderet</i> is in the construct with <i>se’ar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In this case the verse reads: all over like a mantle of hair.</i>
AND THEY CALLED HIS NAME. Those who saw him called him thus. The name Esau possibly connotes a unique occurrence (<i>ma’aseh</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky maintains that I.E., like Rashi, explains Esau to mean <i>asui</i>, a participle meaning made, the idea being that Esau was born a complete man. Filwarg explains that Esau’s birth was a unique event (<i>ma’aseh</i>) in that unlike all other children he was born hairy.</i> This birth was extremely wondrous. Every human being leaves the womb in a placenta which covers him.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Jacob and Esau were each in a separate placenta. The fact that Jacob and Esau’s individual placentas opened simultaneously made their birth exceptional.</i> However, in this instance the two placentas opened simultaneously.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This is obvious since Jacob was born grasping Esau’s heel.</i>

Verse 26

AND HIS NAME WAS CALLED. Someone, or Isaac his father, called him Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, he called his name. The subject (he) is not identified, hence, I.E.’s comment.</i>

Verse 27

A CUNNING HUNTER. Esau was constantly practicing deception, for most animals are trapped through trickery.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture’s purpose in telling us at this point that Esau was a hunter is to inform us that Esau was a cunning and deceptive individual (Weiser).</i> Jacob was his antithesis, because he was a man of integrity.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew <i>ish tam</i> is translated by J.P.S. as <i>a quiet man</i>. However, according to I.E., as Jacob was the antithesis of Esau, the deceiver, the term <i>tam</i> should be rendered as honest, sound, as in <i>that man was whole-hearted</i> (tam) <i>and upright, and one that feared God</i> (Job 1:1).</i> They also differed in that Esau was <i>a man of the field</i> and Jacob a man <i>dwelling in tents</i>. It is possible that the meaning of <i>dwelling in tents</i> is like <i>dwell in tents and have cattle</i> (Gen. 4:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">It does not meant that Jacob was a homebody, but that he was a keeper of herds and flocks. Jacob set up tents in order to be close to the flocks (Weiser).</i>

Verse 28

BECAUSE HE DID EAT OF HIS VENISON. He brought him game to eat.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads: <i>ki tzayid be-fiv</i>, literally, because game in his mouth. I.E. points out that the word <i>me-vi</i> (brought) has to be inserted into the text. The verse should be read as if written: he brought game into his mouth; i.e., he brought him game to eat.</i>

Verse 29

AND HE WAS FAINT. <i>Ayef</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>ayef</i> (faint) may imply faint from exertion or faint from lack of food or water. Here it means the latter (Krinsky). However, Weiser maintains that I.E. holds that <i>ayef</i> applies only to faintness due to lack of food and water.</i> (faint) means hungry and thirsty, as in <i>be-eretz ayefah</i> (in a weary land) (Is. 32:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>A weary land</i> is a land lacking in food and water.</i>

Verse 30

LET ME SWALLOW. This is the only place in Scripture where the word, <i>haliteni</i> (let me swallow) is encountered.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky.</i> Its meaning is <i>feed me</i>. 
<i>Nazid</i> (pottage) means a cooked dish. However, <i>va-yazed</i> (sod) is an <i>ayin vav</i>. They are two roots with one meaning.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>nazid</i> is <i>nun, zayin, dalet</i>. The root of <i>va-yazid</i> is <i>zayin, vav, dalet</i>. Both relate to cooking. The meaning of <i>va-yazed ya’akov nazid</i> is: And Jacob cooked a cooked dish.</i> <i>Yadon</i> (shall abide) in <i>My spirit shall not abide</i> (yadon) (Gen. 6:3) and <i>nedanah</i> (the sheath thereof) (I Chron. 21:27)<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 6:3.</i> are similar.

Verse 31

SELL ME. <i>Mikhrah</i> (sell me) is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mikhrah</i> (sell me) is an elongated imperative, the usual imperative of sell being <i>mekhor</i>. The rule in Hebrew grammar is that when a word in the <i>kal</i> follows the <i>efol</i>, vocalization of its elongated imperative is written with a <i>kamatz katan</i>, i.e., <i>zekhor</i> (remember) is elongated like <i>zokhrah</i> (Neh. 5:19), and <i>shemor</i> (keep) to <i>shomrah</i> (Ps. 25:20). Hence <i>mekhor</i> should become <i>mokhrah</i>. I.E. points out that even though <i>mekhor</i> follows the <i>efol</i> conjugation, it is elongated as an <i>efal</i>. In the latter, the elongated imperative is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> (Cherez).</i> like <i>shilchah</i> (send) in <i>Send</i> (shilchah) <i>the lad</i> (Gen. 43:8) and <i>shikhvah</i> (lie) in <i>Lie</i> (shikhvah) <i>with me</i> (Gen. 39:7.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">These words are conjugated in the <i>efal</i> and are thus vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> in the elongated imperative.</i> The birthright refers to the double share of the father’s wealth which belongs to the first born.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Deut. 21:17.</i> Others maintain that the first born is always superior to his younger siblings in that they must rise before him and serve him as a son serves his father.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">In other words Jacob did not buy the birthright because he wanted a double share but because the birthright had honorary significance. I.E. offers this interpretation either because he believes that Isaac was poor at this time and the double share was insignificant, or because the law of the double share of the first-born took effect only after the revelation at Sinai.</i>

Verse 32

[BEHOLD, I AM AT THE POINT TO DIE.] He was daily exposed to danger when he went out hunting, as an animal might kill him. Thus there was a possibility that he would predecease his father.

Verse 33



Verse 34

SO ESAU DESPISED. Esau also despised the birthright<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The opening line of I.E. is difficult to comprehend. It literally reads: also this birthright because… Weiser, Filwarg, and Krinsky suggest that the text is corrupt. We have followed Filwarg’s reconstruction since it involves adding only one letter, viz., emending <i>gam zot</i> (also this birthright) to <i>gam baz et</i> (he also despised the birthright). The point is that in addition to selling the birthright because he was weary, he also despised the birthright because his father had no wealth to leave him (Weiser).</i> because he saw that his father had no wealth. Many are amazed at this because Abraham left Isaac a vast amount of money?”<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 24:34, 37.</i> Have they never seen a man very rich in his youth and poor in his old age? Proof that Isaac was poor is the fact that he loved Esau because of his need.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. verse 28. The reading of Nachmanides is: because of his game (<i>tzedo</i>). The printed texts read: because of his need (<i>tzorko</i>).</i> Had there been ample food in Isaac’s house and Esau the honorable one in his father’s sight,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Is. 43:4.</i> he would not have sold his birthright for a dish of food. Furthermore, why did Isaac have to tell Esau, <i>Bring me venison</i> (Gen. 27:7), if he had savory meat at home for his daily meals? Additionally, why did Jacob not have choice garments <sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 27:15.</i> and why didn’t Rebekah give Jacob gold and silver for his journey (when he fled to Haran), seeing that Jacob was so poor that he had to say, <i>“If God will…give me bread to eat, and raiment to put on”</i> (Gen. 28:20). Also, why did Rebekah, who loved him so much, not send him money in view of the fact that he was so impoverished that he had to tend Laban’s flock? As to the verse which states, <i>And the man waxed great…And he had possessions of flocks, and possessions of herds, and a great household</i> (Gen. 26:13, 14), it refers to the period prior to Isaac’s old age. Now, those who are intellectually blind think that wealth is a great distinction for the righteous. However, the prophet Elijah shows that the opposite is the case.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 17:6, where Elijah’s poverty is described.</i> They further ask, why did God withhold wealth from Isaac? Let them tell us why God withheld sight from Isaac’s eyes. Let them not put us off with a poor answer based upon a Midrashic homily,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The allusion is either to an aggada which ascribes Isaac’s blindness to a curse put on him by Abimelech (<i>Megillah</i> 15a) or as a result of the incense which Esau’s wives offered to the idols (<i>Tanchuma</i> 20:20). Additional Midrashic reasons for Isaac’s blindness are quoted by Krinsky in his comments on Gen. 27:1.</i> for there is a secret meaning in the matter<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Either for Isaac’s blindness (Weiser, Krinsky) or to the Midrash (Filwarg).</i> and we must not probe into it, for the thoughts of God are deep and beyond the ken of man. Similarly others say, behold Isaac had sheep,<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">If Isaac had sheep then he was not poor. The contradicts I.E.’s assertion that Isaac was poor.</i> for Rebekah told Jacob, <i>Go now to the flock</i> (Gen. 27:9). However, it is possible that he had a few sheep remaining. It is also possible that <i>Go now to the flock</i> means go to the place where sheep are sold.

Chapter 26



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

AND KEPT MY CHARGE. <i>Mishmarti</i> (my charge) is a general term for all that Abraham was obligated to observe from the commandments (<i>mitzvot</i>), statutes (<i>chukkim</i>) and laws (<i>torot</i>). It is possible that the commandments spoken of in our verse refer to <i>Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred</i> etc. (Gen. 12:1), and <i>Take now thy son…even Isaac…and offer him there for a burnt-offering upon one of the mountains</i> etc. (Gen. 22:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that <i>My commandments</i> refers to Gen. 12:1 and Gen. 22:2, as these were commandments. <i>Statutes</i> pertain to Abraham’s emulating God’s ways and laws. It should be noted that I.E. explains <i>chok</i> to mean a logical law. This is in contradistinction to Rashi, who explains <i>chukkim</i> as irrational laws. I.E seems to imply that Abraham did not observe all the laws, statutes and commandments contained in the Torah. This is contrary to the Rabbinic sage Rav, who held that Abraham observed the entire Torah, as seen from the verse <i>because that Abraham hearkened to My voice, and kept My charge</i> etc. (<i>Yoma</i> 28b).</i> 
The statutes spoken of in our text pertain to the works of God that a man should uphold. These statutes are based on logic.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that Abraham, before the revelation on Mt. Sinai, was able to ascertain God’s statutes.</i> I will elaborate on this term (<i>chukkim</i>) in my comments on the verse dealing with the prohibition of wearing <i>a garment of two kinds of stuff mingled together</i> (Lev. 19:19). The <i>torot</i> (laws) mentioned in our verse relate to Abraham’s circumcision of himself, his children and his servants. I will fully explain the meaning of the terms <i>torah</i> and <i>mitzvah</i> in my comments on the verse <i>and the law and the commandment</i> (Ex. 24:12).

Verse 6

AND ISAAC DWELT IN GERAR. Isaac did as God had commanded him. <sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sojourn in this land</i> (v. 3).</i>

Verse 7

OF HIS WIFE. The word <i>le-ishto</i> (of his wife) should be rendered: about his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>lamed</i> here means about. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 20:13. <i>Le-ishto</i> might be rendered to his wife, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> We find a similar meaning for this word in <i>that men say not of me</i> (li) (Jud. 9:54).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Here too the <i>lamed</i> means about. Thus <i>li</i> should be rendered about me, not to me.</i>
FOR HE FEARED. <i>Yare</i> (he feared) is a perfect,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yare</i> can also be a participle, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> as is the word <i>zaken</i> (old) in <i>And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old</i> (zaken) (Gen. 27:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zaken</i> can also be a participle.
