However, in this verse it cannot be so, for the verse opens with a perfect viz., <i>va-yehi</i> (and it came to pass).</i> The words “because he said” have been omitted before <i>lest the men of the place should kill me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads: <i>for he feared to say ‘My wife:’ lest the men of the place should kill me</i>. According to I.E. this is an abridged verse and should be read as if written: for he feared to say my wife, “because he said” lest the men of this place, etc.</i> We find this phrase similarly omitted in <i>for God hath made me fruitful</i> (Gen. 41:52).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">It should be read: “because he said” for God hath made me fruitful.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

A HUNDREDFOLD. The word <i>sha’ar</i> means the same as the Rabbinic term <i>shi’ur</i> (estimate, reckon). The meaning of <i>me’ah she’arim</i> (a hundredfold) is that Isaac was blessed in that the earth produced one hundred times more than what he sowed was estimated to produce. The word <i>she’arim</i> comes from the same root as <i>sha’ar</i> in <i>For as one that hath reckoned</i> (sha’ar) <i>within himself</i> (Prov. 23:7).

Verse 13

AND GREW. <i>Ve-gadel</i> (and grew) is a perfect.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The word grew is written twice in the second part of the sentence. The first time it is written <i>gadel</i>, the second time <i>gadal</i>. Hence I.E. points out that both are perfects and mean the same. I.E.’s comment is pertinent because <i>gadel</i> can also be a participle (Krinsky, Weiser).</i>

Verse 14

AND A GREAT HOUSEHOLD. Isaac had man and maidservants to serve him. <i>Avuddah</i> (household) is an adjective.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>avuddah</i> is an adjective, with the noun which it is modifying missing. Scripture should have read: <i>adamah avuddah</i>, ground worked by man and maidservants (Cherez, Weiser). I.E. interprets thus because the form <i>avuddah</i> looks like an adjective.</i> On the other hand, it may be a noun following the paradigm of <i>segullah</i> (treasure).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">A collective noun, following the paradigm of <i>segullah</i>, or <i>kedushah</i>, the point being we find nouns with this vocalization. Hence <i>avuddah</i> does not have to be an adjective. In this case the meaning of <i>avuddah</i> is simply servants, both male and female.</i>

Verse 15

[WELLS.] When the word <i>be’erot</i> is in the construct it can be vocalized in one of two ways.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>be’erot</i> (wells) in our verse is in the absolute. In such cases it is always vocalized <i>sheva, tzere, cholam</i>. However, when in the construct it can either be vocalized <i>sheva, tzere, cholam</i>, as in verse 18, or <i>segol, chataf segol, cholam</i> as in Gen. 14:10.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

LIVING WATER. Water that is always bursting forth.

Verse 20

ESEK. This word is not encountered elsewhere in Scripture. However, its meaning can be ascertained from Rabbinic literature.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>esek</i> in the Talmud means strife, cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 8:5. It should be noted that in Rabbinic literature <i>esek</i> is spelled with a <i>samech</i>, in our verse with a <i>sin</i>.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

DIGGED. <i>Va-yikhru</i> means digged. <i>Kariti</i>, in <i>in my grave which I have digged</i> (kariti) <i>for me</i> (Gen. 50:5); <i>yikhreh</i> in <i>or if a man shall dig</i> (yikhreh) <i>a pit</i> (Ex. 21:33); and <i>koreh</i>, in <i>whoso diggeth</i> (koreh) <i>a pit shall fall therein</i> (Prov. 26:27), are similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">They all come from the root <i>caf, resh, heh</i> and mean to dig.</i>

Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

BETWIXT US. Our verse contains two synonymous plurals in succession.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads: Let there be an oath <i>benotenu</i> (betwixt us) <i>benenu u-vennekha</i> (even betwixt us and thee). I.E. points out that <i>benotenu</i> and <i>benenu</i> are both plurals from the same root and mean the same. However, they belong to different paradigms. These two forms were employed by Scripture to avoid redundancy (Weiser). According to Filwarg what I.E. is saying is that one of these phrases could have been left out since they mean the same; i.e., <i>benotenu</i> (betwixt us) means the same as <i>benenu u-venekha</i> (even betwixt us and thee) Scripture repeated itself for emphasis.</i>

Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

BEER-SHEBA. There were two reasons why the city was so called.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In Gen. 21:30 Abraham tells Abimelech, <i>Verily, these seven ewe-lambs shalt thou take of my hand, that it may be a witness unto me, that I have digged this well</i>. Scripture then adds, <i>Wherefore that place was called Beer-Sheba because there they swore both of them</i>. However, here we are told that Beersheba was so called because of the oath (<i>shevu’ah</i>) taken by Isaac and Abimelech (cf. Rashi). I.E. points out that Beersheba was so called because of the oaths taken by Abraham and Isaac. Or possibly the two reasons for the name are: Abraham’s setting aside the seven (<i>shevah</i>) lambs and his oath (<i>shevu’ah</i>). Isaac merely repeated Abraham’s oath (Weiser). Or Abraham called the place Beersheba because of the setting aside of the seven lambs and Isaac called it thus because of the oath (Cherez).</i> On the other hand, it is possible that this Beersheba is not to be identified with the Beersheba previously mentioned (Gen. 21:28-31).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">This would explain the two accounts for the name Beersheba in Scripture. According to this interpretation the two reasons given for Beersheba are the two oaths, viz., Abraham’s and Isaac’s. Each took place in a different city.</i>

Verse 34

JUDITH. Judith is a proper name.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yehudit</i> (Judith) can be taken to be an adjective, viz., <i>Yehudi</i>, hence I.E.’s comment (Krinsky).</i> She did not bear Esau any children.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">In chapter 36 Scripture lists Esau’s wives and children. Judith is not mentioned. I.E. explains that this is due to the fact that Judith did not bear any children.</i>
BASEMATH. Basemath is to be identified with Adah.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In our verse we read, <i>Basemath, the daughter of Elon, the Hittite</i>. However, in Gen. 36:2 we read, <i>Adah, the daughter of Elon, the Hittite</i>. I.E. explains the discrepancy by saying that she had two names.</i> She had two names. There are hundreds of similar instances in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 13:7 and 15:19.</i>

Verse 35

A BITTERNESS OF SPIRIT. Each one of Esau’s wives<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And they were</i> is in the plural; <i>morat</i> is a singular. Scripture should have used the plural <i>morot</i>. Hence I.E.’s comment.</i> was a <i>morat ru’ach</i> (bitterness of spirit) to Isaac and Rebekah. Some say that <i>morat</i> (bitterness) is similar to the word <i>moreh</i> (rebellious) in <i>If a man have a stubborn and rebellious</i> (moreh) <i>son</i> (Deut. 21:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation the verse reads: and each one of them was rebellious (<i>morat</i>) against the wishes of (<i>ru’ach</i>) Isaac and Rebekah.</i> However, I believe that <i>morat</i> comes from the same root as <i>marah</i> (bitter) in <i>bitter (marah) as wormwood</i> (Prov. 5:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>morat</i> is not a verb meaning rebellious but a noun meaning bitter. The meaning of <i>morat ru’ach</i> is: they were a bitterness of the spirit; i.e., Isaac and Rebekah were displeased with having Canaanite daughters-in-law. In this case one does not have to interpret <i>morat ru’ach</i> as each one was a <i>morat ru’ach</i>, because it can be interpreted as both were a bitterness of spirit. Thus there is no problem with <i>And they were</i> being in the plural and <i>morat ru’ach</i> in the singular (Krinsky).</i> Indeed, it is explicitly written, <i>and Esau saw that the daughters of Canaan pleased not</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: were evil in the eyes of Isaac his father; that is, Isaac did not like them. In other words, they were a bitterness of spirit to him because they were Canaanites, not because they rebelled against him.</i> <i>Isaac, his father</i> (Gen. 28:8). The account of Esau’s wives was recorded so that the Israelites would keep themselves from taking Canaanite women.

Chapter 27



Verse 1



Verse 2

BEHOLD NOW. The word <i>na</i> means now.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 12:11.</i>

Verse 3

THY WEAPONS. <i>Khelekha</i> (thy weapons) is possibly a general term, the particulars being <i>thy quiver and thy bow</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The verse should be understood as follows: take, I pray thee, thy weapons, namely thy quiver and thy bow.</i> <i>Telyekha</i> (thy quiver) is a sheath hanging<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>tav, lamed, heh</i> means to hang.</i> from its bearer wherein arrows are placed. On the other hand, <i>khelekha</i> may refer to a sword.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The translation follows the <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 text. The printed texts have <i>telyekha</i> referring to a sword. If this reading is accepted, why does I.E. say a <i>vav</i> should have been placed before <i>telyekha</i>? The first particular following a general term does not require a <i>vav</i>, as I.E. himself implies in his comment on Gen. 26:5. Furthermore, why should a <i>vav</i> be placed before <i>telyekha</i> if it means a sword and not if it means a quiver? For an attempt to explain the printed texts see Krinsky and Cherez. However, for the impossibility of the printed versions see Filwarg. The reading of <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 seems correct.</i> However, in this case a conjunctive <i>vav</i> should have been placed in front of <i>telyekha</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Since Scripture is listing three separate items, sword, quiver and bow, a conjunctive <i>vav</i> should be placed before quiver as it is before bow. The verse should read: take thy sword and thy quiver (<i>ve-telyekha</i>) and thy bow.</i> Nevertheless, it does not refute the latter interpretation, for we find a similar instance in <i>Adam, Seth, Enosh</i> (I Chron. 1:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, we find three separate individuals listed without a <i>vav</i> before the final two. The text should have read: Adam and Seth and Enosh. We thus see that Scripture at times leaves out the conjunctive <i>vav</i>.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND REBEKAH HEARD. <i>Shoma’at</i> (heard) should be translated, “was listening.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shoma’at</i> is a participle. It literally means listening. Hence, the word “was” has to be added and the verse should be understood: Rebekah was listening when Isaac spoke to Esau his son.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7

BEFORE MY DEATH. Before I die.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>li-fene</i> (before) means in the presence of. It might conceivably be rendered immediately before (in the presence of) my death, hence I.E.’s comment. For the same reason Filwarg explains I.E.’s comment as meaning: while I yet live.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

HAIRY. The word <i>sa’ir</i> means hairy. The opposite of <i>sa’ir</i> is <i>chalak</i> (smooth) (v. 11). Someone without hair on his body is possibly so called (<i>chalak</i>) because all parts of his body (<i>chalakav</i>) are the same.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chelek</i> means a part, <i>chalak</i> one whose entire body appears to be one part. The idea is that a hairy person has some non-hairy parts on his body; hence his body is not all the same. The smooth man’s skin is the same all over his body (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 12

WILL FEEL ME. <i>Yemusheni</i> (will feel me) is similar to <i>yesubeni</i> (compasseth me about)<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yesubeni</i>, too, has a root (<i>samech, bet, bet</i>) whose second and third letters are the same (Weiser). <i>Yemusheni</i> follows the paradigm of <i>yesubeni</i> (Cherez).</i> (Ps. 49:6). It belongs to those roots whose second and third letters are the same.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>yemusheni</i> root is <i>mem, shin, shin</i>.</i>
AS A MOCKER. The root of <i>ki-metate</i>’a (as a mocker) is doubled.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>tav, ayin, heh</i>. The <i>heh</i> drops out and the <i>tav ayin</i> are doubled making for a quadriliteral (Weiser, Cherez).</i> It comes from the same root as <i>to’eh</i> (err). The meaning of <i>ki-metate</i>’a is: as one who misleads his fellow man.

Verse 13

UPON ME BE THY CURSE. Don’t be afraid that your father might curse you. If he does, the curse will be upon me, not on you. This is the way women talk.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">A mother is willing to have any trouble that is destined to fall upon her son fall upon her.</i> However, Saadiah Gaon explained <i>Upon me be thy curse</i> to mean: it is upon me to remove the curse.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">I will intercede with your father to annul any imprecation that he may curse you with (Weiser).</i> 

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

[I AM.] Some say, Heaven forbid that a prophet should lie. We must therefore interpret Jacob’s words to his father as follows: I am who I am and Esau is thy first born.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi. “I am he who brings to you and Esau is your first born.”</i> Others say that Jacob quietly said, I am, and then loudly said, <i>Esau is thy first-born</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Hence he said two things; I am; Esau is thy first born.</i> Now these interpretations are nonsence. Prophets are divided into two groups. One group consists of God’s messengers concerning commandments;<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser and <i>Biblical Encyclopedia</i> (Heb.) Vol. 8, p. 678. An example of God’s messengers with regard to commandments are Moses and Aaron.</i> the other, those who foretell the future. If the latter have to say something that is not quite so,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A messenger who reveals God’s laws never stretches the truth. Prophets who foretell the future occasionally do (Weiser and <i>Biblical Encyclopedia</i>). According to Filwarg, what I.E. says is that prophets do not lie when they act as God’s messengers. At other times they may tell an untruth.</i> there is no harm done.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">It is no blight on the prophet’s reputation <i>qua</i> prophet.</i> However, a prophet whose task is to reveal commandments never lies. We thus find that King David, whom Scripture calls <i>the man of God</i> (II Chron. 8:14) and who said, <i>The spirit of the Lord spoke by me</i> (II Sam. 23:2), perverted the truth out of need of the hour when he spoke to Abimelech and said, <i>Of a truth women have been kept from us about these three days, when I came out, the vessels of the young men were holy</i> (I Sam. 21:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">When David asked for the holy bread, he had no young men with him. Cf. I Sam. 21 and Weiser.</i> Also, the prophet Elisha did not speak the truth when he said to Hazael, <i>Go, say unto him, thou shalt surely recover</i> (II Kings 8:10), even though what he meant was, go say unto him that thou shalt recover from this illness; however, God has shown me that he will be killed.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 8:10 reads <i>lo</i> spelled with an <i>alef</i>. Thus the verse may be read: thou shalt not recover. However, the <i>kere</i> spells the <i>lo</i> with a <i>vav</i> meaning: say unto him thou shalt recover. I.E. points out that the <i>kere</i> is the correct meaning of the verse. Thus Elisha misled the king of Aram. He told him that he would live although he knew that he would be killed (Netter). For a description of the incident see II Kings 8:7-15.</i> Similarly the prophet Micaiah uttered a vain prayer out of deference to King Ahab when he told him, <i>Go up and prosper; and the Lord will deliver it into the hand of the king</i> (I Kings 22:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">King Ahab inquired of the prophet if he would succeed in his attempt to regain Ramoth-Gilead from Aram. Cf. I Kings 22.</i> Similarly Daniel said to King Nebuchadnezzar, <i>My lord, the dream be to them that hate thee</i> (Dan. 4:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Nebuchadnezzar’s dream signified that he would live as a beast for seven years. Since Nebuchadnezzar destroyed the Temple the prophet could not really have meant that the events in the dream should fall on Nebuchadnezzar’s enemies.</i> Those who explain that <i>My lord</i> refers to God are indulging in Midrash.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Talmud what Daniel really meant was: O Lord, may this dream fall upon your enemies, that is, Nebuchadnezzar. Cf. <i>Shavuot</i> 35b.</i> Similarly Abraham said unto Abimelech, <i>And moreover she is indeed my sister</i> (Gen. 20:12);<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See I. E. on this verse.</i> and unto his young men, <i>and I and the lad will go yonder and we will worship and come back to you</i> (Gen. 22:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Since Abraham intended to offer Isaac as a burnt offering, he really was not telling the truth when he said, <i>And I and the lad will…come back to you</i>.</i>
AND EAT OF MY VENISON. <i>Okhlah</i> (eat)<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Okhlah</i> (eat) is an elongated imperative. The usual form is <i>ekhol</i>. Thus <i>okhlah</i> is similar to <i>zokhrah</i> which is also an elongated imperative.</i> is similar to <i>zokhrah</i> (remember)<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The normal imperative for remember is <i>zekhor</i>.</i> in <i>Remember</i> (zokhrah) <i>unto me, O my God, for good, all that I have done for this people</i> (Neh. 5:19). The <i>alef</i> of <i>okhlah</i> is a root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">It is not the <i>alef</i> prefix of the first person imperfect. I.E. makes this point because in verse 25 the <i>alef</i> of <i>okhelah</i> is the <i>alef</i> prefix of the first person imperfect. See I.E.’s comment on verse 25 and the note to it.</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21

THAT I MAY FEEL THEE. There is no <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>shin</i> of <i>va-amushekha</i> (that I may feel thee) in order to simplify the enunciation of this word.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>va-amushekha</i> is <i>mem, shin, shin</i>. One of these <i>shins</i> is missing is <i>va-amushekha</i>. When a root letter is missing a <i>dagesh</i> is placed in one of the remaining root letters; thus we would expect a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>shin</i> of <i>va-amushekha</i>. I.E. points out that since a <i>dagesh</i> doubles the letter in which it is placed, the verse would have to be pronounced <i>va-amushshekha</i>. The <i>dagesh</i> was left out to avoid this.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

AND I WILL EAT OF MY SON’S VENISON. The <i>alef</i> of <i>ve-okhelah</i> (and I will eat) is a first person imperfect prefix. It is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i> to compensate for the missing <i>alef</i> of the root.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>akhal</i> (eat) is <i>alef, caf, lamed</i>. The <i>alef</i> prefixed to a verb in the first person imperfect is usually vocalized with a <i>segol</i>. I.E. points out that in <i>okhelah</i> the <i>alef</i> is a first person imperfect prefix and is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i> rather than a <i>segol</i> to make up for the missing root letter.</i> We find the same in the word <i>omerah</i> in <i>I will say</i> (omerah) <i>unto God my Rock</i> (Ps. 42:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>amar</i> (say) is <i>alef, mem, resh</i>. In <i>omerah</i> the <i>alef</i> is the <i>alef</i> of the first person imperfect prefix and it, too, is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i> to make up for the missing <i>alef</i> root letter.</i> 
The <i>nun</i> of <i>tevarakhanni</i> (may bless me) (v. 19) receives a <i>dagesh</i> to make up for the missing <i>nun</i><sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. when a verb is combined with a pronominal suffix, a <i>nun</i> is added to the end of the root. Since <i>ni</i> is the sign of the first person pronominal suffix, <i>tevarakhanni</i> should have been spelled with two <i>nuns</i> (we have spelled it with two <i>nuns</i> because of the <i>dagesh</i>. In the Hebrew it has one <i>nun</i>). It should be noted that I.E.’s comment is misplaced as it pertains to verse 19.</i> which should have been in our word, as we find in <i>yesovevenhu</i> (He compassed him about) (Deut. 32:10) and similarly in <i>yeshacharuneni</i> (they will seek Me) (Hos. 5:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>yesovevenhu</i> we see that a <i>nun</i> is added to the root when a verb is combined with a pronominal suffix. In <i>yeshacharuneni</i> we see that when a verb is combined with a first person pronominal suffix, two <i>nuns</i> are added to the root.</i> 

Verse 26



Verse 27

[AND KISSED HIM.] When the word kiss is followed by a <i>lamed</i> it means to kiss upon the hand, shoulder or neck; when it is not followed by a <i>lamed</i> it indicates a mouth to mouth kiss.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. offers no proof for this statement (Weiser).</i>
AND HE SMELLED. The <i>resh</i> of <i>va-yarach</i> (and he smelled) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because it precedes a gutteral.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yarach</i> is an <i>ayin vav</i> in the <i>hifil. Ayin vavs</i> in the <i>hifil</i> are usually vocalized with a <i>segol</i>. Compare, <i>va-yashev, va-yarem</i> (Cherez).</i> <i>Va-yana</i> (was moved) and <i>va-yanach</i> (and rested), in <i>And his heart was moved</i> (va-yana) (Is. 7:2) and <i>and rested</i> (va-yanach) <i>in all the borders of Egypt</i> (Ex. 10:14),<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yana</i> and <i>va-yanach</i> are vocalized with <i>pattachs</i> because they end in gutturals, <i>va-yana</i> with an <i>ayin, va-yanach</i> with a <i>chet</i>.</i> are similar. All of the above come from roots whose middle letter is a <i>vav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">They are <i>ayin vavs. Va-yarach</i> comes from the root <i>resh, vav, chet, va-yana</i> from <i>nun, vav, ayin</i> and <i>va-yanach</i> from <i>nun, vav, chet</i>.</i>
SEE. Isaac said this to himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">So Weiser. Krinsky suggests that “see” is to be understood as perceive, since it is impossible to see smell.</i> The garments gave off a pleasant odor when Isaac thought in his heart that it was Esau before him and that Esau had just come in from the field.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Part of Isaac’s pleasant sensation was psychological.</i> The garments gave off the scent of trees in blossom since it is possible that this episode took place in the first month.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The month of Nisan. Hence the trees were in bloom and the garments absorbed their scent and gave off the smell of the field.</i> 

Verse 28

[OF THE DEW.] The <i>mem</i> of <i>mi-tal</i> (of the dew) is also to be prefixed to <i>mishmane</i> (of the fat places).<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the word for fat is <i>mishman</i>. The particle <i>mem</i>, which means from, is thus missing. The word should have read <i>mi-mishmane</i>, hence I.E.’s comment (Cherez).</i> <i>Shall I give my first-born for my transgression</i>? (Micah 6:7) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">There, too, the <i>bets</i> of <i>be-alfe</i> (with thousands) and <i>be-rivevot</i> (with ten thousands) are to be read as if prefixed to <i>pishi</i> (my transgression) and <i>chattat</i> (the sin of). Micah 6:7 reads, <i>Will the Lord be pleased with thousands</i> (be-alfe) <i>of rams, With ten thousands</i> (be-rivevot) <i>of rivers of oil? Shall I give my first born for my transgression</i> (pishi), <i>The fruit of my body for the sin</i> (chattat) <i>of my soul</i>. However, its literal reading is: Shall I give my first born my transgression, the fruit of my body, sin of my soul? This makes no sense. Hence I.E. points out that the <i>bet</i> of <i>be-alfe</i> is to be applied to <i>pishi</i> (my transgression) and that of <i>be-rivevot</i> to <i>chattat</i> (sin of). Thus <i>pishi</i> is to be translated, for my transgression (<i>be-fishi</i>) and <i>chattat</i>, for the sin of (<i>be-chattat</i>) (Weiser). Our verses are thus similar in that letters prefixed to one word also apply to other words.</i>

Verse 29

THY BRETHREN. The children of the concubines.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham’s concubines (Gen. 25:6). I.E. interprets brethren in the sense of relatives (Weiser). Or I.E. assumed that Isaac had concubines.</i>
THY MOTHER’S SONS. Esau and his children.
CURSED BE EVERYONE THAT CURSETH THEE. Each one of those that will curse you.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: Those who curse you is cursed. Those who curse you (<i>orerekha</i>) is a plural, is cursed (<i>arur</i>) is a singular. Hence, I.E.’s explanation that a plural followed by a singular means each one of the plural (Weiser).</i> <i>But the righteous are secure as a young lion</i> (Prov. 28:1)<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>The righteous</i> is in the plural; <i>will be secure</i> is in the singular. The verse literally reads: And righteous people he will be secure as a young lion. I.E. interprets this: each one of the righteous will be as secure as a young lion.</i> is similar. There are many other analogous expressions in Scripture. <i>And blessed be everyone that blesseth thee</i> is also similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, and those who bless you (<i>u-mevarakhekha</i>, a plural) is blessed (<i>barukh</i>, a singular). It means each one of those who blesses you will be blessed.</i>

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

WHO THEN IS HE. <i>Mi efoh hu</i> (who then is he?) should be interpreted as follows: who is he and where is he?<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The phrase should be read as follows: <i>mi hu</i> (who is he) and <i>efo hu</i> (where is he). The <i>hu</i> following <i>efoh</i> also applies to <i>mi</i> (Krinsky, Cherez). <i>Mi efo hu</i> literally means who where is he. Hence I.E.’s comment.</i> The word <i>efoh</i> (then) is made up of two words.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Efoh</i> is made up of <i>ayeh</i> (where) and <i>poh</i> (here) (Weiser).</i> 
The <i>vav</i> of <i>va-varakhehu</i> (and have blessed him) is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> because <i>va-avarakhehu</i> is a perfect. Had the <i>vav</i> been vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>, then <i>va-avarachehu</i> would be an imperfect.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avarakhehu</i> means I will bless him. The <i>vav</i> vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> is a <i>vav</i> conversive and changes <i>I will bless him</i> to <i>I blessed him</i>. If the <i>vav</i> were vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> it would be a connective <i>vav</i>, and <i>va-avarakhehu</i> would mean, and I will bless him.</i>

Verse 34



Verse 35

WITH GUILE. He did not speak the truth.

Verse 36

IS NOT HE RIGHTLY. <i>Ha-khi</i> is to be rendered as truly. <i>Ha-khi</i> in <i>Thou art truly</i> (ha-chi) <i>my brother</i> (Gen. 29:15) is similar.
NAMED. Someone named him Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The subject of <i>kara</i> (named) is omitted. Hence <i>kara</i> should be rendered, someone named him. According to I.E. <i>ha-khi kara shemo ya’akov</i> (is he not rightly named Jacob) means, someone truly named him Jacob. Cf. Kimchi.</i>
FOR HE HATH SUPPLANTED ME. <i>Va-yakeveni</i> (for he hath supplanted me) is to be rendered: for he hath deceived me. <i>Ve-okbah</i> (in subtlety) in <i>But Jehu did it in subtlety</i> (ve-okbah) (II Kings 10:19) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. it should be translated: But Jehu acted with deceit.</i> It is possible that it comes from the same root as <i>akov</i> (deceitful) in <i>The heart is deceitful</i> (akov) (Jer. 17:9). <i>Akov</i> is the opposite of <i>mishor</i> (straight).<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Is. 40:4, <i>ve-hayah he-akov le-mishor</i> (and the rugged shall be made level). We thus see that <i>akov</i> is the opposite of <i>mishor</i>.</i>
RESERVED A BLESSING FOR ME. Kept with yourself (<i>etzlekha</i>) a blessing for me. <i>Atzalta</i> (reserved) comes from the same root as <i>ve-atzalti</i> (and I will take) in <i>And I will take</i> (ve-atzalti) <i>of the spirit which is upon thee</i> (Num. 11:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Etzel</i> means near. <i>Ve-atzalti</i> literally means: I will take from that which is near thee. <i>Atzalta</i> (reserved) means kept near you. Cf. I.E. on Num. 11:17.</i>

Verse 37

BEHOLD, I HAVE MADE HIM THY LORD. Via my blessing. Similarly <i>have I given to him</i> (v. 33) also means I have verbally given. Some say that <i>efo</i> (then) spelled with an <i>alef</i> at the end is one word meaning now.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">This comment is in contradiction to I.E.’s note on verse 33.</i>

Verse 38



Verse 39



Verse 40

AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS WHEN THOU SHALT BREAK LOOSE. <i>Tarid</i> (thou shalt break loose) has the same meaning as <i>tirdeh</i> (thou shalt rule) (Lev. 25:43). However, <i>tarid</i> and <i>tirdeh</i> have different roots.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>tarid</i> is <i>resh, vav, dalet</i>. The root of <i>tirdeh</i> is <i>resh, dalet, heh</i>. According to this interpretation <i>tarid</i> means thou shalt rule, and the meaning of <i>And it shall come to pass when thou shalt rule</i> is, when the time that thou shalt rule shall come (Weiser).</i> Others say that <i>tarid</i> is similar to <i>arid</i> (I cry out) in <i>I cry out</i> (arid) <i>in my complaint</i> (Ps. 55:3). According to this interpretation the meaning of our clause is: and it shall come to pass when thou shalt cry out, then God will pity you.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>tarid</i> means thou shalt cry out.</i>
THAT THOU SHALT SHAKE HIS YOKE. <i>U-farakto</i> (that thou shalt shake) comes from the same root as <i>mefarek</i> (rent) in <i>rent</i> (mefarek) <i>the mountains</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>peh, resh, kof</i>. It means to break apart, to rend. Hence <i>u-farakta</i> (that thou shake) means that thou shalt break.</i> (I Kings 19:11). The word <i>mafrakto</i> (his neck) (I Sam. 4:18) is derived from the same stem.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mafrakto</i> is derived from the verb meaning to break, i.e., for it is easily broken (Rabbi Solomon Ha-Kohen).</i> These blessings present a number of great difficulties. If the blessings were prophecies how is it possible for Isaac not to know whom he was blessing? The wise men of our generation respond to this problem by explaining that when Jacob entered the room, God told him, “Bless this one.”<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The revelation did not include any name.</i> However, if this was the case Isaac would have told Esau, “God commanded me to bless Jacob.”<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than telling him, <i>Thy brother came with guile, and hath taken away thy blessing</i> (v. 35).</i> Furthermore, if God told Isaac to bless Jacob, why did Isaac bless Esau because he cried?<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible implies that Isaac blessed Esau because he pitied him for having his blessing stolen by his brother.</i> Others say that Isaac was no prophet and his blessings did not come to pass.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Isaac prophesied that Esau would be subservient to Jacob. We do not find it to be so.</i> However, they are also mistaken. Scripture explicitly tells us, <i>And the Lord appeared unto him (Isaac</i>) (Gen. 26:2, 24).<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The verse refers to the patriarchs. See I Chron. 16:13-22.</i> Moreover, King David in referring to the patriarchs says, <i>And do My prophets no harm</i> (I Chron. 16:22). Others ask, what efficacy could there be in Isaac’s blessings since he thought that he was blessing Esau? The truth of the matter is that Isaac was in doubt as to who was really before him. Indeed, he said, <i>The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau</i> (v. 22). What Isaac did was bless the one in his presence without regard to whether it was Esau or Jacob, the reason being that both were his sons. Some ask, how could God say (Gen. 25:23) <i>And the elder shall serve the younger</i>? Similarly how could Isaac say, <i>and thou shalt serve thy brother</i> (v. 40)?<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">When in fact we do not find that Esau was subservient to Jacob.</i> Saadiah Gaon superficially answers this question by pointing to Scripture’s statement, <i>And Esau took his wives, and his sons, and his daughters, and all the souls of his house, and his cattle, and all his beasts…and went unto a land away from his brother Jacob</i> (Gen. 36:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that Esau was subservient to Jacob.</i> However, the Gaon seems to have forgotten that the Bible relates, <i>and (Jacob) bowed himself to the ground seven times until he came near to his brother (Esau</i>) (Gen. 33:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Which clearly shows that Esau was not subservient to Jacob.</i> It appears to me that the prophet’s<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Isaac.</i> blessing was akin to a prayer, and God accepted his prayer,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">A blessing does not take effect immediately. See Rashbam’s commentary on Deut 7:12 (Krinsky). Thus Isaac’s blessing was a blessing and not a prophecy. If it had been a prophecy he would have been directed by God whom to bless.</i> for Isaac’s prayer was mainly concerned with the offspring of Jacob and Esau.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">And the latter were subject to the former.</i> Those who have as yet not awakened from their foolish sleep think that we are in the exile of the Edomites (Esau).<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion identifies the Romans (hence Christianity) with the Edomites. If this is so, then how could Scripture say that Jacob would rule over Esau when in fact Esau destroyed the Temple, exiled the Jews and ruled over them?</i> However, this is not so. Edom (Esau) was subject to Judah.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">From the time of King David until the reign of King Jehoram.</i> Scripture thus states, <i>In his (Jehoram’s) days Edom revolted from under the hand of Judah</i> (II Kings 8:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Which indicates that till that time Edom (Esau) was subject to Judah.</i> We are also told that Joab<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">King David’s general.</i> <i>cut off every male in Edom</i> (I Kings 11:16). It is because of their subjugation to Judah that they rejoiced on the day of Judah’s calamity<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The day that Jerusalem was taken.</i> and told the Babylonians, <i>Raze it, raze it even to the foundations thereof</i> (Ps. 137:7). The taunts of the Edomites on the day of Jerusalem’s fall was harder for the Judeans to bear than the afflictions visited upon them by the Babylonians. This is also the meaning of <i>Rejoice and be glad, O daughter of Edom</i> (Lam. 4:21),<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">A sarcastic statement Rejoice while you still are able to, for your happiness will not long endure. Indeed, the verse concludes, <i>The cup shall pass over unto thee also; Thou shalt be drunken and shalt make thyself naked</i>.</i> and <i>Neither shouldest thou have rejoiced over the children of Judah in the day of their destruction</i> (Obad. 1:12). Also, Hyrcanus the elder<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">John Hyrcanus the Hasmonean. He ruled Judea from 135 to 104 B.C.E. He conquered the Edomites and forced them to embrace Judaism.</i> made the Edomites (Esau’s descendants) guard Jerusalem and had them circumcised. Also, in the days of Agrippa<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Agrippa II, last king of the House of Herod. When the Jews revolted against Rome in 66 C.E. he went to Jerusalem and tried to restore calm.</i> when Jerusalem was taken,<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">That is, during the Roman-Jewish War.</i> troops of Edomites<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">During the Roman-Jewish War the Edomites came to the aid of the Jews.</i> came to Judah’s aid.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Thus it is clear that the Romans are not to be identified with the Edomites.</i> The Romans<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Some printed editions read, <i>the nation</i>.</i> who exiled us are from the seed of Kittim. Onkelos similarly explains Kittim to mean Rome in <i>But ships shall come from the coast of Kittim</i> (Num. 24:24).<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders Kittim as Rome.</i> The Kittim are the very kingdom of the Greeks as I have explained in my commentary on the Book of Daniel.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Dan. 2:38 and 37:14.</i> [At first<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. goes on to explain why the Romans are referred to as Edomites.</i> there were only a few people who believed in the man that was made into a god. The Romans accepted the belief in this man in the days of Constantine who introduced this new religion to the Romans upon the advice of an Edomite priest and placed upon his flag an image of this man. At that time there was no one in the world aside from a small group of Edomites who followed the new religion.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. It was removed by the censor and does not appear in the <i>Mikra’ot Gedolot</i> edition. Some of the printed editions read; “At first there were only a few people who believed in the new religion. When the Romans accepted the new religion in the days of Constantine who adopted it as the state religion there was no one in the world who kept the new religion except for the Edomites.”</i> ] Similarly the contemporary inhabitants of Egypt, Sheba<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">An allusion to the Moslems living in the vicinity of the Red Sea (Weiser).</i> and the land of Elam<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">An allusion to the Moslems in Mesopotamia (Weiser).</i> are called Ishmaelites even though only a tiny minority of the people living there are true decendants of the Ishmaelites.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The people of these places are called Ishmaelites because they accepted the religion of the Ishmaelites (Islam).</i>

Verse 41

AND ESAU HATED. <i>Va-yistom</i> (and he hated) is to be rendered: and he harbored hatred. <i>Va-yistemuhu</i> (and hated him) (Gen. 49:23) is similar.
AND ESAU SAID IN HIS HEART. It is possible that Esau confided this thought to one of his friends.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise how could Rebekah know that Esau plotted to kill Jacob?</i> Others say that Rebekah knew this through prophecy.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Hence she knew that Esau planned to kill Jacob after Isaac’s death.</i> The first interpretation appears correct.

Verse 42

DOTH COMFORT HIMSELF. <i>Mitnachem</i> (doth comfort himself) comes from the same root as <i>nechamah</i> (consolation).<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">It comes from the root <i>nun, chet, mem</i> and thus means to comfort or console.</i> The meaning of our clause is: Esau’s sole consolation is that he will be able to kill you. However, the Gaon says that <i>mitnachem</i> means to set a time and is similar in meaning to the Arabic <i>wa’ad</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Which may mean to set a time. The phrase should thus be rendered: Esau doth set a time to kill you. This interpretation is problematic. For the problems inherent in it, see Weiser’s notes on I.E.’s comments on Gen. 6:6.</i>

Verse 43



Verse 44

A FEW DAYS. <i>Yamim achadim</i> (a few days) is to be translated as a few years. Compare <i>yamim</i> in <i>for a full year</i> (yamim) <i>shall he have the right of redemption</i> (Lev. 25:29). <i>Achadim</i> (a few) means less than ten.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Echad</i> means one, <i>achadim</i> is its plural. Thus <i>achadim</i> can refer to any number up to ten.</i>

Verse 45

WHY SHOULD I BE BEREAVED. Rebekah was anxious lest they kill each other,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Hence Rebekah’s statement, <i>why should I be bereaved of you both in one day</i>.</i> or that Esau would be killed for murdering Jacob. There is a Midrashic opinion that both Jacob and Esau died in one day.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Thus her words came true.</i>

Verse 46

I AM WEARY OF MY LIFE. <i>Katzti</i> (I am weary) has the same meaning as <i>tzakti</i> (I am distressed).<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. literally reads: <i>katzti is similar to its opposite</i>; that is, <i>katzti</i> is similar to <i>tzakti</i>, the <i>kof</i> and <i>tzadi</i> changing places. Thus the root <i>kof, vav, tzadi</i> has the same meaning as the root <i>tzadi, vav, kof</i>.</i> Compare <i>U-nekitzennah</i> (and vex it) in <i>Let us go up against Judah and vex it</i> (u-nekitzennah) (Is. 7:6). Scripture similarly says, <i>the land whose two kings thou hast cast a horror of</i> (katz)<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the land which causes you distress (Weiser).</i> <i>shall be foresaken</i> (Is. 7:16).

Chapter 28



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

[SO ESAU WENT UNTO ISHMAEL.] When Esau learned that Isaac blessed Jacob a second time and charged him not to <i>take a wife of the daughters of Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1. This comment forms the conclusion of I.E.’s notes on Gen 27:46.</i> he went unto his uncle Ishmael and married his daughter Basemath, who was also called Mahalath.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse tells us that Esau married <i>Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael</i>. However, Gen. 36:3 tells us that Esau married <i>Basemath, Ishmael’s daughter</i>. I.E. solves the discrepancy by explaining that the daughter of Ishmael whom Esau married had two names.</i> She, like Jethro, had two names, for I believe that Jethro and Hobab are one and the same person.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Ex. 18:1, and Num. 10:29. In the former, Moses’ father-in-law is called Jethro, in the latter, by the name Hobab. In his comments on Ex. 2:18, I.E. says that they refer to one and the same person, as he had two names.</i>
THE SISTER OF NEBAIOTH. He was the most important of all his brothers.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore Mahalath is identified as the sister of Nebaioth.</i> It is also possible that Ishmael had many wives and that Mahalath was Nabaioth’s sister from the same mother.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Sister here means sister from the same mother. Hence Scripture tells us that Mahalath was the sister of Nabaioth. The Bible mentions one wife of Ishmael (Gen. 21:21). Hence I.E.’s uncertainty.</i>

Verse 10

[AND JACOB WENT OUT FROM BEER-SHEBA.] Saadiah Gaon is of the opinion that <i>va-yelekh charanah</i> (and went toward Haran) is to be interpreted as, to go to Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 literally reads: And Jacob went out of Beersheba and went to Haran. The verse thus tells us that Jacob arrived in Haran. If this is the case, why then do the verses that follow tell us what happened to Jacob on the way to Haran? Saadiah solves the problem by claiming that the Bible employs a perfect (<i>va-yelekh</i>) in place of an infinitive (<i>la-lekhet</i>), with the perfect having the meaning of an infinitive. Saadiah thus translates our verse: Jacob went out of Beersheba to go to Haran.</i> However, this is not so. <i>Va-yelekh charanah</i> is to be interpreted literally.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">That is, and he went to Haran.</i> After telling us that Jacob left Beersheba and went to Haran, Scripture returns and tells us what he encountered on the way to Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, verse 10 is a general statement The particulars then follow.</i> Jacob did not arrive in Haran on the day he left Beersheba,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Contrary to the Midrash <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 68:9 which states that Jacob arrived in Haran on the same day that he left Beersheba.</i> because Scripture explicitly tells us that he spent a night on the way.

Verse 11

[AND HE LIGHTED UPON THE PLACE.] The reason the <i>bet</i> of <i>ba-makom</i> (the place)<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">There is a difference between <i>be-makom</i> and <i>ba-makom</i>. The former means in a place, the latter, in the place. “The place” implies a specific, well known place. When Jacob came to Beth-el there was as yet nothing significant about the place. Why then does Scripture say that Jacob alighted upon the place?</i> is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> is that Moses in writing the Torah did so in order to indicate <i>the place</i> that was well known in his time.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. suggests that after this incident Beth-el was “the place” and Moses wrote accordingly.</i> Similarly the prophet Hosea said, <i>And there</i> (at Beth-el) <i>he would speak with us</i> (Hos. 12:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that from the days of Moses onward, Beth-el was known as a holy place (Netter).</i> Hosea said this because he prophesied in Beth-el concerning Jeroboam the son of Joash.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea prophesied there because Beth-el was known as a holy place where an angel appeared to Jacob (Weiser). Cf. I.E. on Hos. 12:5. It was for the same reason that King Jeroboam set up a royal shrine there. Cf. Am. 7:13, <i>Beth-el…is the king’s sanctuary and it is a royal house</i>.</i> Hosea used the term “with us” because Amos, too, prophesied in Bethel.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Am. 7:13.</i> It is clear from the Book of Amos that Beth-el was a holy place. According to the plain meaning of the text, <i>va-yifga</i> (and he lighted) is not to be translated as, and he prayed, as in <i>neither make intercession</i> (tifga) <i>to Me</i> (Jer. 7:16),<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads: <i>va-yifga ba-makom</i> (and he lighted upon the place). The Talmud states that <i>va-yifga</i> means, and he prayed (<i>Berakhot</i>. 26b; <i>Ta’anit</i> 7b; <i>Sotah</i> 14a; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 95b). According to I.E., if <i>va-yifga</i> is interpreted as, and he prayed, <i>ba-makom</i> must be interpreted to mean God. However, this is not necessarily so. Indeed, the Talmud interprets <i>va-yifga ba-makom</i> to mean, he prayed in the place.</i> because we never find in the entire Bible the word <i>makom</i> (place) meaning God.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The Rabbinic sages refer to God as <i>Ha-makom</i>. I.E. points out that this a Rabbinic not a Biblical term for God. Hence <i>va-yifga ba-makom</i> cannot be translated as, and he prayed to God, and <i>va-yifga</i> cannot be rendered, and he prayed.</i> Do not pay any attention to the Midrashic interpretation that explains <i>makom</i>, in <i>makom acher</i> (Es. 4:14), as referring to God,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The Book of Esther does not mention God. In his introduction to Esther I.E. quotes an opinion that God is mentioned in this book in 4:14. I. E. rejects this interpretation as being Midrashic.</i> because it most certainly does not. Proof of this is found in the word <i>acher</i> (another) which follows <i>makom</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">For then Es. 4:14 would read: then will relief and deliverance arise to the Jews from another God (<i>mi-makom acher</i>), an impossible rendition.</i>
OF THE STONES OF THE PLACE. Its meaning is: one of the stones of the place.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">“Of the stones” can be taken to mean that Jacob took a number of stones. However, verse 18 indicates that it was one stone (Cherez).</i>
UNDER HIS HEAD. <i>Me-ra’ashotav</i> (under his head) is a plural.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">It is a plural having a singular meaning. This is so because this form does not appear in the singular (Weiser).</i> It is similar to <i>margelotav</i> (his feet) (Ruth 3:4; 14).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">This form does not appear in the singular; the plural is used for singular and plural.</i> It is surprising that Rabbi Samuel Ben Hofni confused the dreams of common men with prophetic dreams.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s introduction to the Pentateuch where he notes that Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni, in commenting on this verse, wrote on dream interpretation. Rabbi Samuel thus treated this dream as non-prophetic and interpreted it along those lines (Cherez).</i>

Verse 12

[AND HE DREAMED, AND BEHOLD A LADDER SET UP ON THE EARTH.] Those who say that the ladder seen by Jacob refers to a statue,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Rearranging the letters of <i>sulam</i> (ladder) gives us <i>semel</i> (statue). According to the Midrash God showed Jacob the statue that Nebuchadnezzar would erect and the statue that King Manasseh would erect and place in the Temple. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 68: 19-21.</i> or that it refers to Sinai because it is numerically equivalent to it,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Both <i>sulam</i> and Sinai are numerically equivalent to 130. According to this interpretation it was prophetically shown that Jacob’s descendants would receive the Torah at Sinai. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 68:16.</i> are indulging in Midrash. Rabbi Solomon ibn Gabirol, the Spaniard, says that Jacob’s “ladder” alludes to man’s heavenly soul,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">For Ibn Gabirol’s concept of the human soul, see P.D. Bookstaber, <i>The Idea of Development of the Soul in Medieval Jewish Philosophy</i>, p. 39.</i> and that “the angels of God” signify thoughts of wisdom.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s introduction to his commentary on the Torah, “man’s intelligence is the angel which mediates between him and his God.”</i> Rabbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">A Karaite scholar. See note 15 to I.E.’s introduction to his commentary on the Pentateuch. <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 does not have the title rabbi prefixed to Joshua. It appears that <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 is correct, as it is highly unlikely that I.E. would call a Karaite scholar rabbi. The title rabbi was probably inserted by a scribe who was unaware that the reference is to a Karaite. Some of the editions omit Joshua’s interpretation <i>in totto</i>.</i> explains the dream of the ladder to mean that Jacob’s prayers ascended the Heavens via the ladder and in response to his supplications salvation was sent down to him. These commentators have apparently not studied<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">A sarcastic barb. The scholars with whom I.E. takes issue obviously did study the prophets.</i> the prophecies of Zechariah, Amos and Jeremiah.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that the prophets spoke in parables. Cf. Zech. 1:4-11; 4; 5; 6; Am. 7:1-9, 8:1-2, 9:1; Jer. 1.</i> The way to interpret Jacob’s dream is to view it as a parable. It teaches that nothing is hidden from God and that what happens below is contingent on the decree from above.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">It is hard to understand I.E.’s point. The other commentators also interpret the vision as a parable. It thus appears that I.E.’s main argument is from the Book of Zechariah which speaks of God sending angels to roam the earth. Amos and Jeremiah are mentioned for purposes of embellishment.</i> There is thus, as it were, a ladder linking heaven and earth by which angels ascend to inform God what they have seen on earth after going over it. Scripture also states that other angels come down to fulfill God’s commands. The imagery presented is that of a king and his servants.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">According to Filwarg the reference is to verse 12. According to Krinsky the reference is to Zech. 6:7.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

AND THOU SHALT SPREAD ABROAD. <i>U-faratzta</i> (and thou shalt spread abroad) is to be rendered: and thou shalt multiply. <i>Va-yifrotz ha-ish</i> (and the man increased) is similar (Gen. 30:43).

Verse 15



Verse 16

SURELY THE LORD IS IN THIS PLACE. The meaning of Jacob’s statement is that there are places where miracles are seen.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that there are some places where God’s presence is more manifest than in others. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Ex. 25:40.</i> I cannot explain why this is so because it is a deep mystery.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">It is beyond human comprehension (Weiser). Levine (Introduction to <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38) suggests that when I.E. says, I cannot explain, he means, I am not permitted to explain.</i>

Verse 17

THIS IS NONE OTHER THAN THE HOUSE OF GOD. This is a chosen place where a man in time of need will pray and his supplications will be accepted. Many ask, how could Jacob set up a pillar?<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 16:22 prohibits setting up a pillar.</i> However, they have forgotten that Moses set up twelve pillars.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Ex. 24:4.</i> Scripture does not prohibit a pillar set up to honor the Lord. Scripture merely states, <i>Neither shalt thou set thee up a pillar, which the Lord thy God hateth</i> (Deut. 16:22). I will explain the latter verse when I come to it.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra on Deut. 16:22 explains that Scripture only prohibits <i>A pillar which the Lord…hateth</i>, i.e., a pillar set up to an idol.</i>

Verse 18

AND POURED OIL UPON THE TOP OF IT. So that he would recognize it when he returned.

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

[THEN SHALL THE LORD BE MY GOD.] The Lord that shall be my God is the One known by the Tetragrammaton. Scripture clearly states, <i>And, behold the Lord</i> (spelled with the tetragramaton) <i>stood beside him</i> (v. 13). You will find an explanation of this name of God in my comments on the first Torah portion of Exodus.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments to Ex. 3:15.</i> 

Verse 22

[GOD’S HOUSE.] The meaning of <i>shall be God’s House</i> is: it will be a fixed place for my prayers and for my tithing; for out of all the money <i>that thou shalt give me</i>, I will give a tithe out of respect for God to one who is fit to receive it.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Such as Melchizedek. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 14:20.</i> Those who say that the tithe refers to Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Midrash Jacob set aside his son Levi as a tithe to God. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 70:7 and <i>Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer</i>, Chap. 37.</i> are indulging in Midrash. This is so because we do not find anywhere in the Torah that a man shall tithe his children. The only tithes that we find in the Pentateuch are cattle, sheep and produce.

Chapter 29



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND HE LOOKED. <i>Va-yar</i> (and he looked)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>resh, alef, heh</i>, meaning to see.</i> is an irregular form, for though a <i>kal</i>, its <i>yod</i> is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> notwithstanding the fact that it is not followed by a guttural, in which case the preceding letter is normally vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Compare, <i>va-ya’al</i> (and he went up) from the root <i>ayin, lamed, heh</i>; <i>va-ya’as</i> (and he made) from the root <i>ayin, sin, heh</i>.</i> Furthermore, this form (<i>va-yar</i>) cannot drop the conversive <i>vav</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">One cannot say <i>yar</i>.</i> nor come with any conjugational prefix but the <i>yod</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">One says, <i>va-ere</i> (and I saw), <i>va-tere</i> (and you saw), <i>va-nere</i> (and we saw). One does not say, <i>va-ar, va-tar, va-nar</i>. Thus <i>va-yar</i> is not vocalized like the rest of the forms in its conjugational paradigm wherein the prefixes are vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> rather than a <i>pattach</i>.</i> I believe that when one wants to conjugate the root <i>resh, alef, heh</i> in the third person according to the paradigm of <i>va-yishb</i> in <i>and took some of them captive</i> (va-yishb) (Num. 21:1),<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>va-yishb</i> is <i>shin, bet, heh</i>. The third person masculine perfect of this form is <i>yishbeh</i>, with a <i>vav</i> conversive, <i>va-yishbeh</i>; in the shortened form, <i>va-yishb</i>. Similarly <i>va-yar</i> is short for <i>va-yireh</i>.</i> the <i>heh</i> would be dropped<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">As in all cases of the abridged form.</i> and the <i>alef</i> unsounded.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>va-yishb</i> the second root letter receives a <i>sheva</i>, however, this cannot be done in <i>va-yar</i> as the <i>alef</i> cannot receive a <i>sheva</i>.</i> Nevertheless, the <i>chirik</i> would remain beneath the <i>yod</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">As in <i>va-yishb</i>.</i> The word would thus be pronounced <i>va-yir</i> and it would follow the paradigm of <i>va-yif</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">From the root <i>yod, peh, heh</i>.</i> (thus was it fair) in <i>va-yif be-godlo</i> (thus was it fair in its greatness) (Ez. 31:7) and would be thought to mean, and he threw, from the root <i>yod, resh, heh</i> (throw). To avoid this possibility our word (<i>va-yar</i>) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> beneath the <i>yod</i>.

Verse 3

AND THEY ROLLED THE STONE. The shepherds rolled the stone.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads: <i>And thither were all the flocks gathered; and they rolled the stone. And they rolled</i> appears to refer to the flocks. However, this is impossible; hence I.E. points out that the subject (shepherds) is missing in the verse. The verse is thus abridged (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 4

WHENCE. <i>Me-ayin</i> (whence) means what place are you from. The word <i>ayin</i> without the <i>mem</i> prefixed to it could not be used for whence, for <i>ayin</i> means nothing.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ayin</i> means nothing; <i>me-ayin</i> whence.</i> Nevertheless, we find the word <i>me-ayin</i> also used for nothing, as in <i>Behold, ye are nothing</i> (me-ayin) (Is. 41:24).

Verse 5



Verse 6

AND, BEHOLD, RACHEL HIS DAUGHTER COMETH. The accent is on the last syllable in the word <i>ba’ah</i> (cometh) because it is a participle. It is similar to words in the <i>po’el</i> form.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Po’el</i> is the participle form of whole roots (<i>shelamim</i>) in the <i>kal</i>. The term used by I.E. for participle is <i>shem to’ar</i>, which literally means adjective. I.E. is of the opinion that all participles are also adjectives (Weiser). For an explanation of the participle in Biblical Hebrew, see <i>Biblical Hebrew</i> by R.K. Harrison. Filwarg renders this passage: “<i>ba’ah</i> is an adjective, adjectives having the same meaning in Hebrew as participles.”</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

RACHEL CAME. <i>Ba’ah</i> (came) is pentultimately accented. It is a verb in the perfect.

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

AND JACOB TOLD RACHEL. <i>And Jacob told Rachel</i> should have been written before <i>And Jacob kissed Rachel</i> (v. 11). Its meaning is: And Jacob had already told Rachel that he was her father’s brother before he kissed her.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">He would not have kissed her before this (Filwarg). Hence <i>And Jacob said</i> is a pluperfect.</i> There are many such instances in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E. comments on Gen. 1:9; 2:8.</i>

Verse 13

ALL THESE THINGS. The account of the blessings.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">That his father blessed him and on account of this he was forced to flee from his brother’s wrath (Weiser).</i>

Verse 14

THE SPACE OF A MONTH. I have already explained the meaning of <i>chodesh yamin</i> (the space of a month).<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. it means a full month. Cf. I.E.’s comments to Gen. 4:4.</i>

Verse 15

THY WAGES. <i>Maskurtekha</i> (thy wages) follows the paradigm of <i>matkonet</i> in <i>And the tale</i> (matkonet) <i>of the bricks</i> (Ex. 5:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Matkonet</i> with the second person pronominal suffix is <i>matkuntekha</i>; i.e., the <i>cholem</i> changes to a <i>kubbutz</i> when pronominal suffixes are added to <i>matkonet</i>. The same is true with <i>maskoret</i>. Also, like <i>matkonet</i>, a <i>tav</i> is added to the root (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17

WEAK. <i>Rakkot</i> is to be taken literally.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">It means weak (Krinsky, Weiser).</i> Some ask, why were Leah’s eyes weak? They raise this question because they believe God’s thoughts are like their thoughts,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">A play on Is. 55:8.</i> and they think that all people have to be formed alike.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Hence they ask, why were Leah’s eyes different? I.E. obviously disagreed with the Midrashic interpretation to the effect that Leah’s eyes were weak from crying because she had been told that she was destined to marry Esau. Cf. <i>Baba Batrah</i> 123a; <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 70:16; 71:2.</i> Ben Efraim said that an <i>alef</i> is missing in the word <i>rakkot</i> (weak), its meaning being <i>arukhot</i> (long).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In other words <i>rakkot</i> is short for <i>arukhot. Arukhot</i> minus the <i>alef</i> spells <i>rakkot</i>.</i> However, Ben Efraim himself was missing an <i>alef</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Efraim minus the <i>alef</i> spells <i>parim</i> (cows). <i>Aluf</i> also means wisdom. Perhaps I.E. means Efraim lacked wisdom (Krinsky, Weiser).</i>
OF BEAUTIFUL FORM. <i>To’ar</i> (form) is similar to <i>ta’ar</i> (drawn) in <i>And the border was drawn</i> (ve-ta’ar) (Jos. 15:9). The meaning of <i>beautiful form</i> is that each organ of her body such as her nose and mouth were beautifully drawn (formed).
[AND FAIR TO LOOK UPON.] Her whole body was fair to look upon,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>to’ar</i> refers to the shape of the individual body parts and <i>mareh</i> to the body as a whole.</i> or <i>And fair to look upon</i> refers to the complexion of her face.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">This is also Rashi’s opinion.</i>

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

AND JACOB SERVED SEVEN YEARS FOR RACHEL. <i>Be-rachel</i> (for Rachel) should be rendered because of Rachel.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The prefix <i>bet</i> usually means in.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

FULFILL THE WEEK OF THIS ONE. The seven days of the marriage feast. <i>Zot</i> (this one) refers to Leah.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads <i>shevu’a zot</i>. One might think that <i>zot</i> refers to <i>shevu</i>’a, i.e., fulfill this week; hence I.E.’s comment that <i>zot</i> refers to Leah. The reason for the preceding is that <i>shevu</i>’a is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>; hence it is in the construct with <i>zot</i>, i.e., the week of this one. If it meant this week it should have read: <i>shavu’a zot</i>. Furthermore, the Hebrew word for week is masculine; if the Bible wanted to say this week it would have read <i>shavu’a zeh</i> since <i>zot</i> is feminine (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

WILL LOVE ME. <i>Ye’ehavani</i> (will love me) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than with a <i>tzere</i>. In such forms the last root letter is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i>; compare, <i>yishmereni</i>. Hence I.E.’s comment that there are exceptions.</i> beneath the <i>bet</i>. It is similar to <i>tidbakani</i> (overtake me) in <i>lest the evil overtake me</i> (tidbakani) (Gen. 19:19).

Verse 33



Verse 34

WILL MY HUSBAND BE JOINED UNTO ME. <i>Yillaveh</i> (will be joined) is similar to <i>ve-nilvu</i> (and they shall be joined) in <i>And they shall be joined</i> (ve-nilvu) <i>unto thee</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>yillaveh</i> comes from the root <i>lamed, vav, heh</i>, meaning to join. Hence, <i>yillaveh</i> means will be joined.</i> (Num. 18:4).

Verse 35

THIS TIME WILL I PRAISE THE LORD. <i>Ha-pa’am</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ha-pa’am</i> literally means the time, which makes no sense, hence I.E.’s comment that <i>ha-pa’am</i> is short for <i>ha-pa’am ha-zot</i>.</i> should be explained as if written <i>ha-pa’am ha-zot</i> (this time). Its meaning is, now that I have four sons I will give thanks to the Lord for I will not desire any more children. One can paraphrase <i>This time will I praise the Lord</i> by: I will praise the Lord because he has given me all this and has satisfied me. Therefore <i>she left off bearing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">God punished her by having her leave off from bearing for saying this (Krinsky). It was only after Leah prayed to God for children (Gen. 30:17) that she conceived again.</i>

Chapter 30



Verse 1

GIVE ME CHILDREN. Pray to God as your father did.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Pray to God as your father did when your mother could not conceive. Cf. Gen. 25:21. This is what Rachel meant by give me children. Rashi explains similarly.</i>

Verse 2

AM I IN GOD’S STEAD. Am I in God’s place. It is possible that Jacob prayed on behalf of Rachel but the time for the acceptance of his prayer on her behalf had not yet arrived.

Verse 3

AND I ALSO MAY BE BUILDED UP. I have explained the word <i>ve-ibbaneh</i> (and I also may be builded up) in my comments on Sarah’s use of the same term.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s commentary on Gen. 16:2.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

JUDGED ME. The second <i>nun</i> of <i>dananni</i> (judged me) has a <i>dagesh</i> to compensate for a missing suffixal <i>nun</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The suffix “me” is sometimes written with two <i>nuns (nni</i>). To make up for this missing <i>nun</i> a <i>dagesh</i> is placed in the suffix <i>ni</i> (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

WRESTLINGS. <i>Naftule</i> (wrestlings) is a noun in the <i>nifal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">It is a noun from the root <i>peh, tav, lamed</i> following a <i>nifal</i> paradigm. From this root we get the verb <i>niftalti</i> (I wrestled). The same is the case with the proper name Naphtali (Weiser). Krinsky and Cherez maintain that what I.E. means is that <i>naphtali</i> is an infinitive.</i> Its meaning is I strove, as a man who, when wrestling<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Naftulai</i> thus means twistings of (Weiser). I.E. uses twistings in a specific sense, twisting while fighting.</i> with another, twists (<i>yiftol</i>) in his effort to overpower his opponent in order to throw him to the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that Rachel did not actually wrestle with her sister. She strove with her with the determination of a person trying to overpower his opponent. However, the literal meaning of <i>naftule</i> is twistings (wrestlings).</i> The word <i>tittappal</i> (Thou dost deal tortuously) (II Sam. 22:27) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The point of the verse is that God deals with a person measure for measure, viz., <i>With the pure Thou dost show thyself pure, And with the twisted</i> (ikkesh) <i>Thou dost deal tortuously</i> (tittappal). In the latter verse <i>tittappal</i> (tortuously) is parallel to <i>ikkesh</i> (twisted). Hence <i>tittappal</i> implies crookedness or twisting. <i>Tittappal</i> is a variation of <i>titpattal</i> (Kimchi), and Ps. 18:27 which has the identical theme reads <i>titpattal</i>. Thus it seems that the root <i>peh, tav, lamed</i> and its variation <i>tav, peh, lamed</i> mean to twist (Weiser).</i> The reason Rachel mentioned God, (<i>naftule Elohim</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Naftule Elohim</i>, wrestlings of God.</i> is either that out of respect for the Lord she had given her handmaiden to her husband,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Naftule Elohim</i> (with mighty wrestlings) is to be rendered: Godly wrestlings.</i> or that God helped her in her struggle.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>naftule Elohim</i> means wrestlings with God’s help.</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

FORTUNE IS COME. <i>Bagad</i> (fortune is come) is really two words<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">It is a combination of two words <i>ba</i> (spelled <i>bet, alef</i>) and <i>gad</i> (Weiser). Thus, <i>bagad</i> is spelled <i>bet, gimel, doled</i>. Hence the <i>alef</i> of <i>ba</i> has been dropped.</i> with the <i>alef</i> missing. Similarly, <i>bavel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 and many of the printed editions. Some editions read <i>ba-kol</i>. The latter is incorrect (Filwarg, Weiser). See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 11:9.</i> Also, <i>bamah</i> as is clearly explained in Ezekiel (20:29). 
The meaning of Gad is a troop. Leah said this because she now had a “troop” of sons.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bagad</i> thus means: a troop has come.</i> Others say that <i>gad</i> means good fortune as in the Arabic; and <i>that prepare a table for Fortune</i> (gad) (Is. 65:11), with the latter meaning Jupiter,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Jupiter was believed to control men’s fortune. Cf. I.E.’s commentary on Is. 65:11. This proves that Gad means Fortune, and <i>bagad</i>, Fortune has come.</i> is similar. Actually, however, <i>gad</i> in the latter verse refers to the troops of heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The stars and planets. Therefore, Is. 65:11 does not contradict I.E.’s interpretation that <i>bagad</i> means a troop has come.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13

HAPPY AM I. <i>Be-oshri</i> means, on account of my happiness.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>bet</i> of <i>be-oshri</i> is the <i>bet ha-sibbah</i> (Weiser). Filwarg renders it: so that I may be called happy, the thought expressed by our verse being, this one was born so that the women may praise me by calling me happy (<i>for the daughters will call me happy</i>).</i>

Verse 14

MANDRAKES. Onkelos renders <i>dudaim yavruchin</i> (Aramaic for mandrakes). They are similarly called in Arabic. Mandrakes give off a pleasant scent. Thus it is written, <i>The mandrakes give forth fragrance</i> (Cant. 7:14). The mandrakes are shaped like humans. They have the shape of a head and hands.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The roots of the mandrakes have this shape (Nahmanides).</i> I do not know how they can help a woman conceive since their nature is cold.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">According to medieval medical theory there are four humors, hot, cold, moist and dry. The body was believed to function according to the balance of these four humors. The humor that was hot was thought to stimulate sexual activity and cold to depress it Cf. Maimonides, <i>Guide To the Perplexed</i>, Part I, Chap. 34.</i>

Verse 15

FOR THY SON’S MANDRAKES. <i>Tachet</i> (for) is to be rendered: in place of and as a reward for.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The primary meaning of <i>tachet</i> (for) is beneath. However, this translation does not fit here, hence I.E.’s comments: that <i>tachet</i> is here to be rendered in place of and as a reward for (thy son’s mandrakes).</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

GOD HATH ENDOWED ME. The meaning of <i>zevadani</i> (hath endowed me) is: has given me a portion. The word <i>zevadani</i> is not found elsewhere in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Hence its meaning can only be ascertained from the context.</i>
WILL DWELL WITH ME. <i>Yizbeleni</i> means will dwell with me;<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ni</i> suffix at the end of a verse stands for <i>oti</i>. Hence <i>yizbeleni</i> should be translated: will dwell me, an impossible construction. Therefore I.E. points out that <i>ni</i> here does not have the meaning of <i>oti</i> (me) but <i>immi</i> (with me). Since the suffix <i>ni</i> means <i>oti</i> (me), it is usually combined only with a transitive verb, compare, <i>zevadani</i> (endowed me); <i>hikkani</i> (smite me), <i>yahargeni</i> (will kill me) and others (Weiser).</i> i.e., his dwelling (<i>zevulo</i>) will always be with me. Compare, <i>I have surely built Thee a house of habitation</i> (bet zevul) (I Kings 8:13). <i>Yetza’uni</i> (are gone forth from me), in <i>banai yetza’uni</i> (my children are gone from me) (Jer. 10:20), and <i>vi-yevo’uni</i> (also come unto me) (Ps. 119:41) are similar. All of these are intransitive verbs with the pronominal suffix <i>ni</i>.

Verse 21

AND AFTERWARDS SHE BORE A DAUGHTER. Some say that Dinah was Zebulun’s twin.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible omits “and she conceived” with regard to Dinah (Weiser). “And afterwards she bore a daughter” implies one birth (Kimchi).</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23

GOD HATH TAKEN AWAY MY REPROACH. <i>Asaf</i> (taken away) is to be rendered cut off. Compare, <i>And gladness and joy are taken away</i> (ve-ne’esaf) (Is. 16:10). Others interpret what Rachel said as, God saw the insults which the women hurled at me because I was barren and by giving me a son He, as it were, gathered (<i>asaf</i>) and collected the insults.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>asaf</i> means gathered rather than cut off.</i> It is clear from Scripture that Jacob’s twelve children were born in seven years.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Seder Olam</i> 2, “Jacob spent 20 years in Laban’s house. Seven before marrying the matriarchs, and seven after marrying them and six years after the birth of the eleven tribes and Dinah. We thus find that the tribes with the exception of Benjamin were born in seven years, each one every seven months.” That is, six months and some days (Weiser). The point is that Jacob had acquired eleven sons and Dinah by the time he had finished serving his 14 years for his wives (v. 25). The first seven years he had no wife (v. 20).
