Hence all his children, with the exception of Benjamin who was born after he had left Laban, were born during seven years.</i> When the ancients numbered them they could only explain how this was possible by saying that each was born six months and some days after conception.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture tells us that Jacob’s children were born in sequence; Reuben, Simon, Levi, etc. Since Jacob had twelve children in seven years, he had to have had a child every seven months since there are 84 months in seven years and 84 divided by 12 is 7. The reason I.E. says that Jacob’s sons were born six months and some days following conception is to allow for the days of “uncleanliness” following childbirth during which Jacob abstained from intercourse with those wives who conceived twice in one year (cf. <i>Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer</i>, Chap. 36). The <i>Seder Olam</i> quoted above employs a round number (Cherez).</i> However, this was not necessarily so. It is posssible that Leah gave her handmaiden to Jacob before Naphtali was born, that Rachel conceived before the birth of Zebulun,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Zilpah could have conceived Gad while Bilhah was pregnant with Naphtali, and Rachel could have conceived before Zebulun was born. The fact that Scripture tells us that Leah gave Zilpah to Jacob after Naphtali was born does not mean that that was the sequence of events. Cf. Cherez and Weiser. The point is there is no reason to assume that Jacob’s children were born seven months apart.</i> and that we do not know when Dinah was born.

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

FOR WHOM I HAVE SERVED THEE. This refers to <i>my wives</i>, not <i>my children</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>Give me my wives and my children for whom I have served thee. For whom I have served thee</i> can conceivably apply to <i>my children</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It is similar to <i>and shed the blood of war in peace</i> (I Kings 2:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See notes to I.E.’s comments on Gen. 20:17.</i>

Verse 27

I HAVE OBSERVED THE SIGNS. <i>Nichashti</i> (I have observed the signs) means I have divined,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">So according to Weiser.</i> for Laban was an enchanter and had teraphim.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Instruments of sorcery. Cf. Gen. 31:34.</i>

Verse 28

APPOINT. <i>Nokvah</i> (appoint) is an imperative.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The usual imperative form is <i>nekov. Nokvah</i> is an elongated form.</i> It follows the paradigm of <i>zokhrah</i> (remember) in <i>Remember</i> (zokhrah) <i>me, O my God, for good</i> (Neh. 13:31). The meaning of <i>nokvah</i> (appoint) is, clearly state, as we see from <i>Which the mouth of the Lord shall mark out</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Or clearly state.</i> (yikkovennu) (Is. 62:2). The <i>dagesh</i> of <i>yikkovennu</i> (shall mark out) compensates for the missing <i>nun</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>nokvah</i> and <i>yikkovennu</i> have the same root, <i>nun, kof, bet</i> and mean the same, viz., clearly state.</i> We find the same with the word <i>yiddevennu</i> (make them willing) in <i>whose heart maketh him willing</i> (yiddevennu) (Ex. 25:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yiddevennu</i> has a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>dalet</i> to make up for the missing <i>nun</i>. Thus <i>yikkovennu</i> and <i>yiddevenu</i> are similar. Both have a <i>nun</i> as a first root letter and the <i>nun</i> drops out in the imperfect and is replaced by a <i>dagesh</i>.</i>

Verse 29



Verse 30

WITHERSOEVER I TURNED. <i>Le-ragli</i> (withersoever I turned) is to be rendered: because of my foot.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ragli</i> literally means my foot. The <i>lamed</i> prefixed to it is a causal <i>lamed</i>, in Hebrew, <i>lamed ha-sibbah</i> (Weiser).</i> It is the custom of people to say so and so has a good foot.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">So and so brings good fortune (Weiser).</i> What Jacob was saying was: you have been blessed ever since I came to your house. The <i>heh</i> of <i>me’umah</i> (aught in v. 31) is superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it is penultimately accented.</i> The word is also found spelled without the <i>heh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mum</i> in Job 31:7.</i>

Verse 31



Verse 32

STREAKED.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The words upon which I.E. comments, i.e., <i>akuddim, nekuddim, beruddim</i> are found in Gen. 31:10. I.E. inserted it here because he wanted to clarify the type of marks that the Bible refers to before proceeding to comment on the account of Jacob’s hire.</i> The streak was on the animal’s foot. <i>Akuddim</i> (streaked) refers to a cord-like mark that bound the foot<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>ayin, kof, dalet</i> means to bind. <i>Akuddim</i> is a mark resembling a cord going around the foot of the animal at the place where it is normally bound. This is what I.E. means by “a mark that bound the foot.”</i>
SPECKLED. <i>Nekuddim</i> means speckled.
GRIZZLED. <i>Beruddim</i> (grizzled) comes from the same root as <i>barad</i> (hail). It means having white spots.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Like hail.</i>
[SPOTTED.] <i>Talu</i> is a general term for all type of spots.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">At various places in the body (Weiser).</i> It comes from the same root as <i>u-metulla’ot</i> (and clouted) in <i>and worn shoes and clouted</i> (u-metulla’ot) <i>upon their feet</i> (Josh. 9:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>tet, lamed, alef</i>.</i> The meaning of <i>u-metulla’ot</i> is marked.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The patches (clouts) marked the shoes. We thus see that <i>talu</i> is a general term for spotted.</i> The term <i>seh</i> (v. 32), refers to he-goats.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. this clause should be translated: removing from thence every speckled and spotted he-goat. I.E. explains that <i>seh</i> refers to he-goats because the sheep were not speckled and spotted but were <i>chum</i> (dark) and the she-goats are mentioned in the final part of the verse. Hence <i>seh</i> must refer to he-goats (Cherez).</i> It is similarly written <i>the sheep</i> (seh kevasim) <i>and the goat</i> (seh izim) (Deut. 14:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The term <i>seh</i> can thus apply to both goats and sheep. In the first part of our verse it applies to he-goats.</i> Now since <i>talu</i> (spotted) is a general term for all type of spots, the meaning of <i>every speckled and spotted</i> (talu) <i>one</i> is: every he-goat speckled, streaked and grizzled.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that <i>nakod</i> means speckled and <i>talu</i> includes the other types of spots, i.e., a mark around the ankle, <i>akuddim</i> (streaked), and hail like spots, <i>beruddim</i>.</i>
AND EVERY DARK ONE AMONG THE SHEEP. <i>Chum</i> means black. It is possible that <i>chum</i> means black because it is affected by heat (<i>chom</i>), for a black object gets hotter than a white object.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">What I.E. probably means is that black objects absorb heat from the sun more than do white objects. This shows that heat causes blackness.</i>
AND THE SPOTTED AND SPECKLED AMONG THE GOATS. Streaked, grizzled and speckled.

Verse 33

EVERY ONE THAT IS NOT SPECKLED AND SPOTTED AMONG THE GOATS. Speckled, grizzled and streaked.
AMONG THE GOATS. He and she-goats.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Since goats stand in contradistinction to sheep in our verse, it refers to all goats, both male and female.</i> 

Verse 34



Verse 35

AND HE REMOVED THAT DAY THE HE-GOATS THAT WERE STREAKED AND SPOTTED. Spotted (<i>telu’im</i>) means speckled and grizzled.
[AND ALL THE SHE-GOATS THAT WERE SPECKLED AND SPOTTED.] The interpretation of <i>telu’ot</i> (spotted) is streaked and grizzled.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Speckled is mentioned in the verse; hence <i>telu’ot</i> (spotted) refers to the other types of marks.</i> This is what Scripture means by <i>everyone that had white in it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The verse should be read as follows: speckled and spotted, that is, every one that had white in it (Weiser). The spots were white. “Every one that had white in it” explains speckled and spotted (Weiser).</i>
AND ALL THE DARK ONES AMONG THE SHEEP. The black sheep. <i>Chum</i> (dark, black) is an adjective similar to a <i>pa’ul</i>. It follows the paradigm of <i>sug</i> (dissembler) in <i>The dissembler</i> (sug) <i>in heart</i> (Prov. 14:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. calls it similar to <i>pa’ul</i> because only transitive verbs come in the <i>pa’ul. Chum</i> is intransitive. Nevertheless, it is similar to <i>pa’ul</i> in that it is an adjective. The same is true of <i>sug</i> (Cherez). Weiser translates: It is an adjective in the <i>pu’al</i>, following the paradigm of <i>sug</i>; that is, it is an <i>ayin, vav</i> in the <i>pu’al</i>.</i> A great grammarian explained the word <i>haser</i> (removing)<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Haser</i> can be either an infinitive or an imperative. The grammarian explained it as an infinitive because of the difficulty of coordinating <i>I will pass</i> with the imperative remove.</i> in <i>removing</i> (haser) <i>from thence</i> (v. 32) as an infinitive, meaning to remove. The meaning of the aforementioned verse according to this scholar is: I will pass through all thy flock today to remove from thence every…and that which I remove will be my hire.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This is the meaning of: and of such shall be my hire.</i> He further explained <i>And gave them into the hands of his sons</i> (v. 35) as referring to Jacob’s sons.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Since according to this interpretation Jacob did the removing, he is the subject of verse 35 which reads: <i>And he removed</i>; and <i>his sons</i> refers to Jacob’s sons.</i> However, he said that <i>he set three days journey betwixt himself and Jacob</i> (v. 36) pertains to Laban.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">This is obvious.</i> This comment is wrong in view of the fact that Jacob had no son older than Reuben, and he was not yet seven years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The events described in our passage took place after the close of Jacob’s 14 years of service to Laban. Reuben, his oldest, was then not yet seven years old. How, then, could Jacob give the sheep to his small children to keep?</i> This is the way our passage is to be explained: <i>haser</i> (v. 32) is, as its form indicates, an imperative meaning “remove” and the meaning of <i>and of such shall be my hire</i> (v. 32) is: such as these which you now remove will in the future be my hire.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32 does not tell us that Jacob removed the sheep and kept them as his hire and then gave them to his children to keep (v. 35). Rather, it tells us that Jacob told Laban, “Remove the spotted…sheep and goats from your flock and keep them. However, in the future such as these shall be my hire.” Verse 35 tells us that Laban removed them and gave them to his (Laban’s sons) to keep.</i>
SO SHALL MY RIGHTEOUSNESS WITNESS AGAINST ME. My righteousness shall testify for me <i>before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. connects <i>before thee</i> with <i>so shall my righteousness witness against me</i>, rather than with <i>my hire</i>, which precedes it (Krinsky, Cherez).</i> when you come and look over my hire, viz., the flock that I have separated for myself. If you find among the latter a he and she-goat that is not streaked, speckled and grizzled or a sheep that is not black, then it <i>shall be counted stolen</i>. Behold you have already removed from the flock all goats streaked, speckled and grizzled and all black sheep.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Hence all such animals found with me must be mine.</i>
AND LABAN SAID: BEHOLD. <i>Hen</i> (behold) is identical in meaning to <i>hinneh</i>, the <i>heh</i> being superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. makes this comment because the usual term for behold in Scripture is <i>hinneh</i>.</i> It is similar in this regard to <i>ha-eleh</i> (these) and <i>ha-el</i> (these).<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 19:8. Both <i>ha-el</i> and <i>ha-eleh</i> mean the same, the <i>heh</i> being superfluous.</i>
AND HE REMOVED. Laban removed.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. makes this point because according to the grammarian quoted above, <i>And he removed</i> refers to Jacob.</i>

Verse 36

AND HE SET. Here, too, Scripture speaks of Laban.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">According to the grammarian quoted above, <i>And he removed</i> refers to Jacob and <i>And he set</i> refers to Laban. Hence I.E. points out that both refer to Laban.</i>

Verse 37

RODS OF. <i>Makkal</i> (rods of) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because it is in the construct.
POPLAR…ALMOND…AND PLANE TREE. <i>Livneh</i> (poplar), <i>luz</i> (almond) and <i>armon</i> (plane tree) are names of trees. However, <i>lach</i> (fresh) is an adjective.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture reads, <i>livneh lach, ve-luz ve-armon</i>. Conceivably <i>lach</i> could be taken to be the name of a tree. Hence I.E. points out that <i>lach</i> is an adjective modifying <i>livneh</i>, i.e., fresh</i> Saadiah Gaon says that <i>luz</i> means almond since that is its meaning in Arabic, and Arabic, Hebrew and Aramaic belong to the same family.
MAKING THE WHITE APPEAR. He peeled the bark. Compare, <i>The Lord hath made bare</i> (chasaf) <i>His holy arm</i> (Is. 52:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the root <i>chet, sin, peh</i> means to lay bare. Hence <i>machsof ha-lavan</i> means he laid bare the white (Weiser). He did this by peeling the bark. I.E. makes this point because the root <i>chet, sin, peh</i> can also mean to strip. Hence <i>machsof ha-laven</i> might be translated, stripping off the white.</i>

Verse 38

PEELED. The word <i>pitzel</i> (peeled) means he made small cuts.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The verb <i>pitzel</i> is found in Scripture only in verses 37 and 38. According to I.E. it does not exactly mean to peel. See S.D. Luzzato’s commentary on this verse.</i>
IN THE GUTTERS. Pools containing water for the sheep to drink from.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. apparently interpreted <i>rehatim</i> (gutters) as being synonymous with <i>shikatot ha-mayim</i> (watering troughs) (Weiser).</i>
AND THEY CONCEIVED. <i>Va-yechamnah</i> (and they conceived) is a combination of masculine and feminine forms.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The feminine form third person plural is <i>va-techamnah</i>. The <i>yod</i> is a masculine prefix. Hence <i>va-yechamnah</i> combines the masculine (the <i>yod</i>) with the feminine.</i> We find the same in the word <i>va-yisharnah</i> (and took…the straight way) in <i>And the kine took the straightway</i> (va-yisharnah) (I Sam. 6:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The correct feminine form is <i>va-tisharnah</i>. See note 69. The feminine should have been used since <i>kine</i> is feminine.</i>

Verse 39

AND THE FLOCKS CONCEIVED. <i>Va-yechemu</i> means: and they conceived.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">It comes from the root <i>yod, chet, mem</i>, meaning to be hot, that is, hot with sexual desire and by extension to conceive.</i> This word is irregularly vocalized because of the <i>chet</i> which is a guttural. It should have been vocalized as <i>va-yeshevu</i> (and they sat down) in <i>And they sat down</i> (va-yeshevu) <i>to eat bread</i> (Gen. 37:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the root of <i>va-yechemu</i> is <i>yod, chet, mem</i>. Being a <i>peh yod</i> it should follow that paradigm. Thus the <i>yod</i> should be vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> as the <i>yod</i> of <i>va-yeshev</i>. However, since the <i>chet</i> is a guttural and is vocalized with a <i>chataf segol</i>, the <i>yad</i> is vocalized with a <i>segol</i> (Cherez).</i> Don’t be surprised at Scripture’s use of the masculine<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yechemu</i>. Females conceive, hence Scripture should have stated <i>va-techamna hatzon</i> rather than <i>va-yechemu hatzon</i>.</i> when referring to female sheep. Hebrew is strict in differentiating between the masculine and feminine forms only in the singular and not in the plural.
AT THE SIGHT OF THE RODS. <i>El ha-maklot</i> should be rendered at the sight of the rod. Many are amazed at what is reported in our verse<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">That the sheep’s fetuses were influenced by what the sheep looked at.</i> and say that it can only be described as an out of the ordinary phenomenon. Really, what Scripture describes is indeed one of the wonders of nature. However, it is a natural law. Even a woman who is created in the image of the angels affects her fetus by what she looks at while she is pregnant.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. believed that it is a law that applies to all females. Hence what is described in our verse is not a supernatural phenomenon.</i>
AND SPOTTED. Grizzled. This is so because <i>telu’im</i> (spotted) is a general term for all types of spots.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>telu’im</i> is a general term for speckled, streaked and grizzled, and speckled and streaked are specifically mentioned in our verse, <i>telu’im</i> can only refer to grizzled (Krinsky). The Bible sometimes uses a general term for the particular (Weiser).</i>

Verse 40

AND JACOB SEPARATED THE LAMBS. Jacob also did one more thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">In addition to peeling the sticks and having the goats face them while coupling.</i> He separated the lambs and chose the streaked and the dark ones and set the faces of the flocks toward the streaked and dark ones so that they would produce similar offspring. This resulted in his having his own droves<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Cherez.</i> which he did not <i>put unto Laban’s flock</i>. Others say that Jacob separated the lambs from his own flock and that <i>and put his own droves apart</i> should have preceded <i>and Jacob separated the lambs</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The verse should be read as if written: And (Jacob) put his own droves apart and put them not unto Laban’s flock, and Jacob separated the lambs (from his own droves) and set the faces of the flocks (of Laban) toward the streaked and all the dark (of Jacob’s flock), he did this to all the flocks of Laban. It should be noted that according to this interpretation the meaning of <i>be-tzon lavan</i> (in the flock of Laban) is, he did this to all of Laban’s flock. See Filwarg and Cherez.</i>

Verse 41

WHENSOEVER THE STRONGER OF THE FLOCK DID CONCEIVE. In the month of Nisan,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Those born in the month of Nisan (Krinsky, Weiser).</i> so that all those born would be strong and healthy.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The sun is strong then and the sheep born in this month are healthier.</i>

Verse 42

BUT WHEN THE FLOCK WERE FEEBLE. In the month of Tishri.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Born in Tishri.</i> Jacob did this so that Laban would not know that he was employing the sticks to produce spotted goats.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Had Jacob not done this, all the sheep would have been black and all the goats spotted and Laban would have known that something was wrong. Thus Jacob had to produce sheep for Laban. He did so when the offspring would be of inferior quality.</i>
FEEBLE. <i>Atufim</i> means feeble; compare, <i>Their soul fainted</i> (titattaf) <i>in them</i> (Ps. 107:5).

Chapter 31



Verse 1

THE WORDS OF LABAN’S SONS. Laban had sons as Scripture explicitly tells us, <i>and (Laban) gave them into the hand of his sons</i> (Gen. 30:35).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 30:35.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

YOUR FATHER’S COUNTENANCE. I can tell by looking at your father’s countenance that he is not (<i>ennenu</i>) toward me as beforetime.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads: <i>Ro-eh anokhi et pene avichen ki enennu elai kitmol shilshom. Pene</i> (countenance) is a plural. The word <i>enennu</i> can be translated: he is not or it is not. If <i>enennu</i> is connected to <i>pene</i> the Bible should have employed <i>enam</i>, which is a plural, rather than <i>enennu</i> which is a singular. Hence <i>enennu</i> cannot refer to <i>pene</i>. It is rather connected to <i>avikhen</i> (your father) (Filwarg, Cherez). The verse is thus to be rendered: I see by your father’s countenance that he is not toward me as beforetime.</i> On the other hand, <i>enennu</i> (he is not) may refer to countenance (<i>pene</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In this case the meaning of the verse is: I see your father’s countenance that it (the countenance) is not toward me as beforetime.</i> Compare, <i>The anger</i> (pene) <i>of the Lord hath divided them</i> (chillekam) (Lam. 4:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Where we find <i>pene</i>, a plural, connected to a singular. In this verse the verb pertaining to <i>pene, chillekam</i> (hath divided them) is in the singular. We thus see that while <i>pene</i> is a plural, it can be treated as a singular (Filwarg, Cherez). Hence <i>enennu</i> can refer to face. Weiser explains that <i>pene</i> is not really treated as a singular. It is a plural but a singular follows it for emphasis.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7

HATH MOCKED ME. <i>Hetel</i> is irregular in that it lacks a <i>dagesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>dagesh</i> should have been placed in the <i>tav</i>. According to I.E. <i>hetel</i> is a <i>pi’el</i>. The middle root letter of a <i>pi’el</i> perfect receives a <i>dagesh</i>, and the first root letter is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i>. Thus “mocked” should have been vocalized <i>hittel</i>. Hence <i>hetel</i> is irregular (Filwarg).</i> It should have a <i>dagesh</i> like the word <i>va-yehattel</i> (and he mocked) in <i>that Elijah mocked</i> (va-yehattel) <i>them</i> (I Kings 18:27).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yehattel</i> is a <i>pi’el</i>, has a <i>dagesh</i> and follows the normal <i>pi’el</i> paradigm.</i> The meaning of <i>hetel</i> is mocked.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">It means to mock by deceiving.</i>
TEN TIMES. The word <i>monin</i> (times) is akin to the word <i>meneh</i> (number) in <i>Go number</i> (meneh) <i>the people</i> (II Sam. 24:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">There is no such verse in the Bible. The reference is obviously to II Sam. 24:1. The text there reads, <i>Go, number Israel and Judah</i>. This is either a scribal error in the text of I.E., or it indicates that the author quoted verses from memory.</i> The meaning of our verse is: your father deceived me ten times. Or ten signifies many times.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Cohen. Ten is a round number (Friedlander).</i> 

Verse 8

From the statement, <i>The streaked shall be thy wages</i>, it is clear that Laban changed Jacob’s hire so that it was limited only to streaked goats.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob’s wages were to consist of speckled, spotted and streaked goats. Laban, as this verse indicates, changed his original conditions and gave Jacob only one of this kind rather than all three.</i> At other times Laban limited Jacob’s hire to speckled goats.

Verse 9

THUS GOD HATH TAKEN AWAY. <i>Va-yatzel</i> (hath taken away) is similar in meaning to <i>va-yenatzelu</i> (and they despoiled) in <i>And they despoiled</i> (va-yenatzelu) <i>the Egyptians</i> (Ex. 12:36).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">They both mean to take. However, there is a difference in nuance between them. In our verse the word is in the <i>hifil</i> and it connotes taking what rightfully belongs to one. In Ex. 12:36 it is in the <i>pi’el</i> (the intensive) and it means to take highhandedly, to despoil (Weiser).</i> Both (<i>va-yatzel</i> and <i>va-yenatzelu</i>) come from the same root as <i>hatzileni</i> (deliver me)<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The root being <i>nun, tzadi, lamed</i>.</i> (Gen. 32:12), although in the latter case the meaning of the word is a bit different from the first two examples.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Here it means to save from death, take away from danger, to deliver.</i> What Jacob told his wives was also true.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Not only is what Jacob reported concerning Laban’s cheating true, but the report of the dream is also true. The Bible often omits events in a narrative but later reports what has been omitted in its recapitulation of the events (Weiser).</i> Jacob dreamed that God would aid him so that his sheep would increase and be strong even without the use of the peeled sticks.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">At those times God saw to it that the goats were born strong, streaked, speckled and spotted.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13

I AM THE GOD OF BETH-EL. Its meaning is: I am the God, God of Beth-el.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">A word with the definite article prefixed to it cannot be in the construct. Since <i>ha-el</i> has the definite article prefixed to it, it cannot be in the construct with Beth-el. Hence what we are dealing with is an abridged phrase. See notes to I.E.’s comment on Gen. 2:9.</i> The same is the case with <i>and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil</i> (Gen. 2:9), which is to be interpreted as if written: and the tree of the knowledge, knowledge of good and evil.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 2:9.</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15

FOR HE HATH SOLD US. It is as if he sold us<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Laban did not actually sell them, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> in that he did not do with us what a father normally does with his daughters. What he did was to say to you, “Guard my flock and take my daughters as your hire.”

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

HE HAD GATHERED. <i>Rakhash</i> (he had gathered) comes from the same root as <i>rekhush</i> (substance).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rakhash</i> is a denominative of <i>rekhush</i> (Weiser).</i>

Verse 19

NOW LABAN WAS GONE TO SHEAR HIS SHEEP. That were in the care of his sons who were three days journey away, as is reported by Scripture (Gen. 30:35, 36). Hence, <i>it was told Laban on the third day that Jacob was fled</i> (v. 22).<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">I.E’s point is that since Laban was three days journey from Jacob, it took that long for him to learn that Jacob had fled.</i>
THE TERAPHIM. Some say that the teraphim are copper objects used to tell time.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">A copper sun dial that was also used for divination (Weiser).</i> Others say that astrologers have the power to make an image that speaks at certain times.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads: to make an image of certain known stars, and this image speaks.</i> They offer proof from <i>For the teraphim have spoken vanity</i> (Zech. 10:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the teraphim speak.</i> However, this is not the meaning of the aforementioned verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is not to be interpreted as meaning that the teraphim actually speak. It means that the signs they give are false. Speak is used figuratively, as in what do the cards say (cf. Krinsky).</i> I believe that the teraphim are human images made to draw power from above.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on Ex. 20:20.</i> I am not permitted to explain this any further.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Lest people learn to make them.</i> Proof that the teraphim are human forms can be found in the teraphim which Michal, the daughter of Saul, placed in David’s bed thereby fooling the guards into thinking that the teraphim were really David.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I Sam. 19:13-17.</i> As to the verse which states, <i>For the children of Israel shall sit solitary many days without king, and without prince, and without sacrifice, and without pillar, and without ephod or teraphim</i> (Hos. 3:4),<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">This verse implies that there is nothing wrong with teraphim. Quite the contrary, it is juxtaposed with the ephod, a garment used in the service of the Lord.</i> it can be explained in two ways. One, the prophet says, <i>Israel shall be without king, and without prince</i> because God chose only members of the Davidic family to be kings over Israel. Therefore the verse which follows says, <i>afterward shall the children of Israel return, and seek the Lord their God, and David their king</i> (v. 5). The verse continues, <i>and without sacrifice, and without pillar</i>; this refers to sacrifices and pillars to the idols. In a similar manner, <i>and without ephod</i> also refers to idolatry, because the worshippers of Baal made an imitation of the ephod that Moses made.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The two interpretations of Hos. 3:4 are: A. The verse deals with idol worship, hence the juxtaposition of ephod and teraphim. B. The verse deals both with the worship of God and with idolatry. According to the latter interpretation <i>and without ephod or teraphim</i> means neither the worship of God nor idolatry.</i> Hence Scripture reads <i>ephod</i> and not “the ephod” as in <i>Bring hither the ephod</i> (I Sam. 23:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. ephod means <i>an</i> ephod. <i>The</i> ephod, with the definite article prefixed to it, is the ephod made by Moses.</i> Therefore <i>an ephod in his hand</i> (<i>Ibid</i>. v. 6) does not refer to the ephod made by Moses. I will explain the ephod and offer irrefutable proofs for my interpretation concerning it in the proper place if God will be kind to me and grant me life.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s “long commentary” on Ex. 28:6.</i> The second interpretation is that <i>and without ephod or teraphim</i> means, they will neither serve God (<i>without ephod</i>) nor idols (<i>or teraphim</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation the ephod mentioned in Hos. 3:4 refers to the one used in the worship of the Lord.</i> That teraphim are idols can be ascertained by Laban’s referring to them as gods (v. 30).<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the teraphim were used in idol worship although they were not originally made for that purpose. This validates I.E.’s interpretation that the teraphim refer to idol worship. In Hosea I.E. explains this second interpretation as follows: <i>and without sacrifice</i> to God, <i>and without pillar</i> to Baal, <i>and without ephod</i> to God <i>or teraphim</i> to Baal.</i> Some say that Rachel stole the teraphim in order to keep her father from idolatry.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi.</i> If this were the case, why did she take them with her and not bury them on the way?<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">As Jacob did with the idols his children had on them. Cf. Gen. 35:2-4.</i> The most likely reason that Rachel stole the teraphim was that Laban, her father, was an astrologer, and Rachel feared that he would look at the stars and discover which way they fled.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The teraphim, which were in human form, drew powers from the stars and revealed hidden things to Laban. Krinsky and Weiser suggest that I.E. is of the opinion that the teraphim had images of stars on them and through them Laban could divine hidden things.</i>

Verse 20

AND JACOB OUTWITTED LABAN. Jacob stole nothing from Laban save his “wits.” Scripture uses the term heart for wits because the heart is the seat of man’s intelligence.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 literally reads: And Jacob stole the heart of Laban the Aramean. I.E. points out that unlike Rachel, who stole the teraphim, Jacob stole only Laban’s heart; i.e., he fooled him.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

AND GOD CAME TO LABAN THE ARAMEAN. This occurred before <i>he overtook him</i> (v. 23). Therefore its (v. 4) meaning is, and God had already come to Laban the Aramean. I have already pointed out many similar instances. <sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Of the use of the pluperfect. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:9. Would Laban spend the night doing nothing after overtaking Jacob, thereby give him a chance to escape? Thus we must assume that upon overtaking Jacob, he confronted him and that <i>And God came to Laban…in a dream</i> means, and God had come to Laban…in a dream.</i> God appeared to Laban out of respect for Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Laban was no prophet. It was only out of God’s regard for Jacob that He appeared to Laban.</i>
EITHER GOOD OR BAD. Do not speak to Jacob about returning even if you think it is for his good.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">This is what Scripture means by good. Laban obviously spoke to Jacob. Indeed, Scripture records their conversation. What God meant was, do not try to convince him to return by threats, or by promises, even if the latter are sincere (Weiser).</i>

Verse 25

AND LABAN WITH HIS BRETHREN PITCHED. <i>Et echav</i> is to be rendered: with his brethren.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Et</i> is the sign of the direct object Hence <i>et echav</i> means his brethren. The verse thus might conceivably be rendered: Laban pitched his brethren. However, this is impossible since pitched refers to tents, hence I.E. points out that <i>et</i> here is not the sign of the direct object but is to be rendered with.</i> 
The word tent written in reference to Jacob also carries over to Laban.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The object following pitched with reference to Laban is missing, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> That is, now Jacob had pitched his tent in the mountain, and Laban pitched his tent with his brethren in the mountain of Gilead.

Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

NOW HAST THOU DONE FOOLISHLY. <i>Aso</i> (done) is an infinitive.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The infinitive of the root <i>ayin, sin, heh</i> is <i>asot. Aso</i> is short for <i>asot</i> (Weiser), or the <i>vav</i> of <i>aso</i> takes the place of the <i>tav</i> (Cherez).</i> It is in the construct<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ayin</i> of <i>aso</i> is vocalized with a <i>chataf pattach</i>. This is the construct vocalization. Had it been in the absolute, it would have been vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> (Weiser).</i> with either this or so. However, they are missing.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The text is abridged. It should have read <i>hiskalta asot zeh</i> or <i>hiskalta asot ken</i>. I.E. thus renders <i>Now thou hast done foolishly</i> as: thou hast acted foolishly in doing this (deed) or, thou hast acted foolishly in doing so.</i>

Verse 29

IT IS IN THE POWER. <i>El</i> is to be rendered power. Compare, <i>I am become as a man that hath no help</i> (eyal) (Ps. 88:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Eyal</i> (help) is rendered by I.E. as strength.</i>

Verse 30

LONGEST. <i>Nikhsof</i> (longest) is an infinitive in the <i>nifal</i>. It is similar to <i>nilchom</i> (fight) in <i>or did he ever fight</i> (nilchom) <i>against them</i> (Jud. 11:25). 
The word <i>nikhsafta</i> means thou longest. <i>Yikhsof</i> (eager) in <i>He is like a lion that is eager</i> (yikhsof) <i>to tear in pieces</i> (Ps. 17:12) is similar.

Verse 31



Verse 32

HE SHALL NOT LIVE. Because I will put him to death. Some say that this was a prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob prayed, “May God strike the one who stole the teraphim dead.” This interpretation is offered by Rashi. It is found in the Talmud, <i>Berakhot</i> 56a; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 90b.</i> and it was because of this utterance that Rachel died on the way.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In childbirth. <i>In the way</i> is a quote from Gen. 48:7.</i> If this be so, let them tell us who prayed and thus caused the death of Phinehas’ wife?<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">She, too, died in childbirth. Cf. I Sam. 4:19, 20.</i>

Verse 33

AND LABAN WENT INTO JACOB’S TENT, AND INTO LEAH’S TENT, AND INTO THE TENT OF THE TWO MAID-SERVANTS. Both maid-servants shared one tent. Or it (v. 33) means into the tent of each one of the two maid-servants.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And into the tent of the two maid-servants</i> is short for: into the tent of each of the two maid-servants (Weiser).</i> Afterward<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">After searching the tents of Jacob, Leah and the two maid-servants.</i> Laban entered Leah’s tent a second time. Proof of this is Scripture’s statement, <i>And he went out of Leah’s tent</i>. It is also possible that Jacob’s tent was between Leah’s and Rachel’s tents.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The question which I.E. deals with here is: Why did Laban search Rachel’s tent last? We would expect him to search her tent after that of Leah. I.E. suggests that Jacob’s tent was in the middle, between that of Rachel and Leah, and that to the side of Leah’s tent stood the tent (or tents) of the maid servants. After searching Jacob’s tent, Laban decided to search the tent of his older daughter first. Coming out of Leah’s tent he found the tent of the maid servants and searched it On his way back he stepped another time into Leah’s tent, found nothing there and proceeded to search Rachel’s tent He did not search Rachel’s tent after that of Leah because it was not next to it (Cherez).</i> However, it appears to me that the Bible tells us what happened in abridged form<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">It omits telling us that the search of Rachel’s tent took place after the search of Leah’s tent. Scripture first tells us about those tents where Laban found nothing. It then tells us what happened when Laban searched Rachel’s tent.</i> and puts off the mention of Rachel’s tent for last. The sequence of events was as follows. Laban searched Jacob’s tent, then Leah’s tent, then Rachel’s tent and then the tent of the two maid-servants. The meaning of our verses (33 and 34) is that Laban searched Jacob’s tent, Leah’s tent and the tent of the two maid-servants and found nothing because there was nothing of his there. Scripture then tells us that when Laban went out of Leah’s tent and into Rachel’s tent where the teraphim had been, Rachel had by then taken them and put them in the saddle of the camel.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture puts off telling what happened when he searched Rachel’s tent in order to be able to elaborate.</i>

Verse 34

[IN THE SADDLE.] Some say that <i>kar</i> (saddle) is a kind of saddle cloth.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Weiser.</i> However, I believe that the term <i>kar ha-gamal</i> (saddle of the camel)<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains <i>kar ha-gamal</i> as a double word and that Scripture uses two words having the same meaning even though one word would suffice. See I.E.’s comment on Gen. 8:11 and the notes thereto.</i> means a camel, as in <i>Send ye the camel</i> (kar) <i>for the ruler of the land</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Translated according to I.E. According to I.E. a <i>kar</i> is a noble and especially swift species of camel. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Is. 16:1; 66:20.</i> (Is. 16:1); and <i>u-va-kirkarot</i> (and upon the camels) (Is. 66:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Translated according to I.E.</i> I further hold that the driver or rider of the <i>kar</i> (camel) is called the <i>kari</i> (II Kings 11:19). Rachel took the teraphim and put them in the place where the camel (<i>kar ha-gamal</i>) was kept.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than: And she put them in the saddle of the camel.</i>
AND SAT UPON THEM. She was not in the tent.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">She was not in her tent but rather where the camel was. The reason I.E. does not interpret <i>kar</i> to mean cushion, or saddle, is that the word <i>kar</i> is not so used in Scripture. It is only so used in Rabbinic literature (Cherez).</i>

Verse 35



Verse 36

THAT THOU HAST HOTLY PURSUED. <i>Dalakta</i> means pursued. <i>Yidlak</i> in <i>the poor is hotly pursued</i> (yidlak) (Ps. 10:2) is similar.

Verse 37



Verse 38



Verse 39

I BORE THE LOSS OF IT. If any of the flock was torn by beasts, I bore the guilt<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. points out that <i>achatennah</i> (I bore the loss of it) is a denominative of <i>chet</i> (sin). Hence <i>achatennah</i> means I was guilty for it, the sin, was on me and I thus had to make it up and replace it.</i> and I gave you its equivalent.
STOLEN BY DAY. The <i>yod</i> of <i>genuveti</i> (stolen) is superfluous. It is similar to the <i>yod</i> of <i>mele’ati</i> (full of) (Is. 1:21).<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Genuveti</i> has the same meaning as <i>genuvat. Mele’ati</i> has the same meaning as <i>mele’at</i>.</i> The meaning of our verse is: whether stolen by day or by night,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads <i>genuveti yom u-genuveti layelah</i> (stolen by day and stolen by night). I.E. points out that the <i>vav</i> does not mean “and” but that it means “or” or “whether.” That is, it made no difference to you whether it was stolen during the day or night.</i> <i>of my hand didst thou require it</i>.

Verse 40



Verse 41



Verse 42

AND THE FEAR OF ISAAC. Isaac’s fear of the Lord aided me, for the merits of a father help his son.
[EMPTY.] The <i>mem</i> of <i>rekam</i> (empty) is not a root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>resh yod kof</i>.</i> The word is a noun.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">It is an adverb, but I.E. included it among the nouns (Weiser).</i> The Bible employs this form (<i>rekam</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Hebrew nouns change according to gender and are written differently in the singular and the plural. However, since this word is an adverb, although I.E. classifies it as a noun, it is treated as an adverb.</i> with the masculine,<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">In our verse, <i>rekam shillachtani</i>.</i> feminine<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 1:21.</i> and the plural.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Ex. 23:15.</i> The <i>mems</i> of <i>omnam</i> (verily, truly)<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 19:17, Job 34:12. The root of <i>omnam</i> is <i>alef, mem, nun</i>. The final <i>mem</i> is not a root letter.</i> and <i>chinnam</i> (for nothing, gratis) are similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 29:15, Ex. 21:2, 11. Its root is <i>chet, nun, nun</i>, thus the final <i>mem</i> is not a root letter.</i>

Verse 43

AND WHAT CAN I DO THIS DAY FOR THESE MY DAUGHTERS. Laban was being especially explicit.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>These</i> is unnecessary. The text should have read, for my daughters.</i> The verse should be understood thus: and to these my daughters, what can I do to them?<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">How could I think of doing harm to these my daughters. The Hebrew literally reads: And to my daughters, what can I do to these. Hence I.E.’s explanation as how the verse should be understood.</i>

Verse 44



Verse 45

A PILLAR. Because he set it up.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob called the pillar a <i>matzevah</i> because he set it up (<i>hitziv otah</i>) (Weiser). Cherez explains that a pillar is so called because it is set up.</i>

Verse 46

A HEAP. A <i>gal</i> (heap) is so called because it is formed by rolling stones together.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the noun <i>gal</i> (heap) comes from the verb <i>galal</i> (to roll) (Weiser).</i> He also called it Mizpah.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. verse 49. Weiser points out that the suffix of <i>kare’ah</i> (he called it) is feminine and cannot refer to <i>gal</i> (heap) which is masculine. <i>It</i> must therefore refer to <i>matzevah</i> (pillar) which is feminine. Weiser claims that I.E.’s comment was transposed from verse 49 by a scribe who mistakenly thought that <i>it</i> referred to the heap. What I.E. is saying is that the heap was called Galeed and the pillar Mizpah. Cherez claims that <i>it</i> refers to the place. He called the place by two names, Galeed and Mizpah (place here being treated as feminine).</i>

Verse 47



Verse 48



Verse 49

[THE LORD WATCH.] The meaning of <i>yitzef adonai</i> is : the Lord will watch. <i>I have appointed thee a watchman</i> (tzofeh) (Ez. 3:17) is similar.
[WHEN WE ARE ABSENT.] <i>Ki nissater</i> (when we are absent) is to be read as if written: <i>ki nissater anachnu</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The text reads: <i>ki nissater ish me-re’ehu</i>. I.E. says that this should be read as if written: <i>ki nissater “anachnu” ish me-re’ehu</i>. The reason for inserting <i>anachnu</i> is that the context requires a first person plural pronoun (<i>anachnu</i>) following <i>nissater</i> (a verb in the first person plural imperfect) since what follows (<i>ish me-re’ehu</i>) is in the third person.</i> We will be distant one from another and will not be able to see each other. Nevertheless, God will see each one of us.
[FOR HE SAID.] This refers to Laban. Jacob called it<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The pillar (Weiser). According to Cherez, the place.</i> Mizpah because Laban said to him, the Lord will watch, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And Mizpah for he said: The Lord…</i> should be understood as follows: <i>and Mizpah</i>, i.e., Jacob called it (the stone) Mizpah because <i>and he said</i>, i.e., Laban said to him, <i>the Lord watch</i>, etc.</i>

Verse 50

IF THOU SHALT AFFLICT MY DAUGHTERS. Saadiah Gaon explains this to mean: if you will not cohabit with your wives.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">So also <i>Yoma</i> 77b and Rashi.</i> Now this is a strange rendition of afflict. Nowhere in Scripture does afflict have this connotation.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">It may mean to rape. Cf. Gen. 34:2. It is never used in the sense of withholding relations.</i> What problem is there in interpreting the term according to its plain sense?<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Causing pain.</i> Its meaning is: do not do anything evil to my daughters or force them to do things against their will.<i>Jagar-sahadutha</i> is Aramaic for Galeed.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">This comment has been misplaced. Its proper place is in verse 47 (Weiser).</i>

Verse 51

WHICH I HAVE SET UP. Laban and his brethren.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that <i>yariti</i> (which in Hebrew means I have cast) refers to the heap of stones since the pillar was set up by Jacob alone (v. 45). Laban said, <i>I have cast</i>, because it was Laban and his brethren who made the heap, for we read, <i>And they took stones and made a heap</i> (v. 46).</i> They cast stones and formed the heap. <i>Yariti</i> comes from the same root as <i>yarah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>yod, resh, heh</i> and it means to cast.</i> (cast) in <i>hath He cast</i> (yarah) <i>into the sea</i> (Ex. 15:4). He cast them into one place.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. is explaining what to cast a heap means. It means to cast many stones in one place until a heap is formed.</i>

Verse 52

THAT I WILL NOT PASS OVER. The covenant made on this heap.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">This heap thus means the covenant made on this heap.</i> <i>E’evor</i> (pass over) in our verse has the meaning of violate,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>ayin, bet, resh</i> means to pass over, hence to violate, to “pass over the law, or agreement.” The meaning of our verse thus is: that I will not violate the covenant made on this heap.</i> as in <i>they have transgressed</i> (averu) <i>the statute</i> (Is. 24:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Averu chok</i> (they have violated the statue) is not found in the Bible. The reference is probably to Is. 24:5, <i>they have transgressed the laws</i> (averu torot), <i>violated the statute</i> (chalefu chok). For an explanation of the misquote, see above note 8.</i>
[FOR HARM.] To do harm. Others say that it means, thou shalt not pass over this heap to harm me and I will not pass over this heap to harm thee.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">In this case the root <i>ayin, bet, resh</i> has its primary meaning of to pass over, and heap does not mean the covenant made at the heap but rather the heap which will serve as a border.</i>

Verse 53

[THE GOD OF THEIR FATHER.] Each one said: the God of our Father <i>judge betwixt us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible says, <i>The God of Abraham, and the God of Nahor, the God of their Father, judge betwixt us</i>. One might thus think that both took the same oath and swore by the same Deity. I.E. points out that this is not so. Nahor served idols; hence his god was an idol.</i> However, Jacob referred to <i>the God of Abraham</i> and Laban <i>to the god of Nahor</i>, his grandfather who worshiped idols as is attested by Joshua.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Josh. 24:2, <i>Your fathers dwelt of old time beyond the River, even Terah, the father of Abraham, and the father of Nahor; and they served other gods</i>. I.E., in his comments on Gen. 20:17 points out <i>that they served</i> refers to Terah and Nahor. We thus see that Nahor served idols.</i>
AND JACOB SWORE BY THE FEAR OF HIS FATHER. <i>Fear of his father</i> means the One whom his father feared. Others say that this alludes to the day when Jacob’s father Isaac was bound on the altar. The latter interpretation is not far-fetched.

Chapter 32



Verse 1

HIS SONS. His grandsons, the sons of his daughters.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Laban was not bidding his sons adieu; hence <i>his sons</i> must refer to his grandsons.</i>

Verse 2

AND THE ANGELS OF GOD MET HIM. To assist him on the way. Only Jacob saw the camp<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture says <i>he saw them</i>; i.e., only Jacob saw them (Krinsky).</i> of angels surrounding his camp. He called the name of the place <i>Mahanaim</i> (two camps), because of the two camps there, his and the angels’.

Verse 3



Verse 4

AND JACOB SENT. This verse teaches us that the land of Edom lies between Haran and the land of Israel. This disproves Saadiah Gaon’s contention that Sinai, Seir and Paran are next to each other.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Since Jacob was on the way to the land of Israel from Haran, why did he send messengers to Edom? We must assume that Edom is between Syria (Haran) and Israel, and Jacob thus had to reconcile his brother before he passed through his territory. This disproves Saadiah’s contention that Seir (Edom) is near Sinai, for Sinai is located southwest of Israel while Haran lies northeast of the land of Israel. The problem with I.E.’s note is that Edom was located southeast of Israel, while Haran, as just noted, lies northeast. This is another example of I.E.’s lack of knowledge concerning the geography of the Holy Land and its environs.</i> [MESSENGERS.] From among his servants.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. takes issue with the Midrash <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 75:3 and Rashi who interpret <i>malakhim</i> to mean angels rather than human messengers.</i>

Verse 5

THUS SHALL YE SAY UNTO MY LORD. Jacob used this language so that it would be clear to them that Esau was his lord and they should address him as a servant addresses his master.
AND STAYED UNTIL NOW. The <i>alef</i> of <i>echar</i> (and stayed) is a first person imperfect prefix. It is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> to make up for the missing <i>alef</i> of the root.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>echar</i> is <i>alef, chet, resh</i>. In the first person imperfect an <i>alef</i> vocalized with a <i>segol</i> is prefixed to the root. Our word thus should have been written <i>e’echar</i> (two <i>alefs</i> respectively vocalized with a <i>segol</i> and a <i>chataf segol</i>). However, it is written <i>echar</i> and has only one <i>alef</i> and is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i>. I.E. points out that this <i>alef</i> is not a root letter. It is a first person imperfect prefix vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> rather than a <i>segol</i> to make up for the missing root letter.</i> <i>Ehav</i> (I love) in <i>I love them</i> (ehav) <i>that love me</i> (Prov. 8:17) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>ahav</i> (love) is <i>alef, heh, bet</i>. Thus the first person imperfect should be <i>e’ehav</i>. However, the verse has <i>ehav</i>, one <i>alef</i> vocalized with a <i>tzere</i>. See above note.</i> The <i>alef</i> of the root is dropped because it is extremely difficult to pronounce two <i>alefs</i> back to back. <i>Echar</i> is a <i>kal</i>.

Verse 6

OXEN AND ASSES. These are nouns referring to the respective species.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew has an ox and an ass, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>
AND I HAVE SENT TO TELL MY LORD. That I wish to do whatever he commands me.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The verse does not say what they were to tell Esau. I.E. points out that following <i>to tell my Lord</i>, we must insert: that I wish to do whatever he commands me.</i> This is the meaning of <i>that I may find favor in thy sight</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Once we insert that I wish to do, etc., in the text, the meaning of <i>so that I may find favor in thy sight</i> becomes clear.</i>

Verse 7

AND MOREOVER HE COMETH TO MEET THEE. He was told that you are coming.

Verse 8

AND WAS DISTRESSED. This thing distressed him.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">According to Filwarg. Others interpret slightly differently.</i> <i>Va-yetzer</i> (and he was distressed) is in the <i>hifil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>va-yetzer</i> is a <i>hifil</i> the word does not mean and he was distressed, but rather, it distressed him. Hence I.E. comments “this thing distressed him”; i.e., his brother’s coming distressed him. Others maintain that <i>va-yetzer</i> is a <i>nifal</i> meaning and he was distressed. Filwarg asks, “If <i>va-yetzer</i> is a <i>hifil</i> why isn’t it vocalized <i>va-yatzer</i> as is the rule with a double root (<i>tzadi, resh, resh</i> is the root of <i>va-yetzer</i>) in the <i>hifil</i>?” He suggests that <i>va-yetzer</i> is irregular. Weiser suggests that perhaps I.E.’s text of the Bible was vocalized <i>va-yatzer</i>. For a discussion of the problems concerning this comment of I.E., see Filwarg, Weiser and Cherez.</i> It is similar to <i>ve-hetzar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Which is in the <i>hifil</i>.</i> (and he shall besiege) in <i>and he shall besiege</i> (ve-hetzar) <i>thee</i> (Deut. 28:52).
AND HE DIVIDED. The <i>yad</i> of <i>va-yachatz</i> (and he divided) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because it precedes a guttural. <sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>va-yachatz</i> is <i>chet, tzadi, heh. Va-yachatz</i> is an abridged <i>kal</i> imperfect with a conversive <i>vav</i>. In such cases the <i>yod</i> is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i>. Compare, <i>ve-yifen</i> and <i>va-yiven</i>. Hence I.E.’s comment.</i> Compare, (<i>va-ya’al</i>) in <i>And Moses went up</i> (va-ya’al moshe) (Ex. 19:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, we have an abridged imperfect with the <i>yod</i> vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> rather than a <i>chirik</i>. The reason is also that it precedes a guttural (the <i>ayin</i>). The root of <i>va-ya’al</i> is <i>ayin, lamed, heh</i>.</i>

Verse 9

CAMP. The word for camp (<i>machaneh</i>) can be either masculine or feminine<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. makes the point because the word is found in both the masculine and the feminine in our verse. <i>Machaneh ha-achat</i> (one camp) is feminine. However, the suffix of <i>ve-hikkahu</i> (smite it) is masculine, as is <i>machanah ha-nishar</i> (the camp which is left).</i> like the word for house (<i>bayit</i>) and place (<i>makom</i>).
THEN THE CAMP WHICH IS LEFT SHALL ESCAPE. Perhaps<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that the <i>vav</i> of <i>ve-hayah</i> does not indicate certainty, for how could Jacob be certain one camp would escape? Its meaning is perhaps. Thus rather than translating our verse: then the camp which is left shall escape, it should he rendered: perhaps the camp that is left shall escape.</i> the camp that is left shall flee, or perhaps my brother’s anger shall be assuaged after smiting one of the camps, or perhaps God will send them relief and deliverance. <i>If the Arameans be too strong for me, then thou shalt save me</i> (II Sam. 10:11) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, there was no certainty. What Joab said was, if the Arameans be too strong for me perhaps you will be able to save me. Thus <i>ve-hayita li li-shu’ah</i> (II Sam. 10:11) does not mean, then thou shalt save me.</i> Rabbi Solomon’s<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i> comment, to the effect that <i>then the camp that is left shall escape</i> means that the camp will be saved despite Esau’s intention, is Midrashic.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi apparently interpreted <i>ve-hayah</i> as indicating certainty, then (<i>ve-hayah</i>) the camp that is left shall escape, i.e., despite Esau’s will, it shall be saved. I.E. claims that this is not the literal meaning of the verse (Cherez).</i> Although God promised Jacob, <i>And thy seed shall be as the dust of the earth</i> (Gen. 28:14),<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This verse indicates that Jacob’s children would not be destroyed. I.E. now argues that one cannot substantiate Rashi’s interpretation that Jacob was certain, on the basis of God’s promise to him in Gen. 28:14, that at least one of his camps would escape (Cherez).</i> Jacob did not know whether it referred to the children he now had, or to children he would have in the future.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">How could Jacob be sure that one camp would escape, since the promise may not have applied to the children he now had (Cherez).</i> A prophet does not know hidden things unless God reveals them to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that Jacob was a prophet does not mean that he knew that God’s promise recorded in Gen 28:14 applied to his present children.</i> Jacob was alive when Joseph was sold into slavery and yet was unaware of it.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">He thought Joseph was dead and was unaware that he had been sold into slavery.</i> Similarly Elisha said, <i>and the Lord hath hid it from me</i> (II Kings 4:27). The above also answers those who ask, why was Jacob afraid considering that God promised that he would protect him, viz., God’s assurance, <i>and I will be with thee</i> (Gen. 31:3)? The latter is also the promise referred to by Jacob when he said, <i>And thou saidest I will surely do thee good</i> (v. 13).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">We do not find God saying, <i>I will surely do thee good</i>. Hence when Jacob said, <i>And Thou saidest: I will surely do thee good</i>, he was restating, <i>and I will be with thee</i>.</i> Jacob was afraid because of the possibility that he alone would escape. Furthermore, we know that the personality of the individual is taken into account when his sins are considered, be they major or minor transgressions. Therefore, a minor sin committed by a great personality is considered a major transgression. Jacob was afraid that he may have sinned or inadvertently transgressed in his mind and as a result of this God no longer would be with him. Do not be amazed at what I write, for behold, Moses the greatest of men, whom God himself sent to bring Israel out of Egypt erred and God sent an angel to kill him.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Moses erred in not immediately circumcising his son. As a result God sent an angel to kill him (Ex. 4:24-26). God acted in this manner because a minor sin committed by a man of Moses’ stature was considered by the Almighty to be a major transgression. Similarly Jacob was afraid that he might have committed a minor sin resulting in God’s removal of His divine protection, hence his anxiety.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

I AM NOT WORTHY. <i>Katonti</i> (I am not worthy) is vocalized like <i>yakholti</i> (I have prevailed) in <i>gam yakholti</i> (Gen. 30:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>kal</i> in the perfect is usually vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> beneath the middle root letter. However, <i>katonti</i> and <i>yacholti</i> are vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>.</i> The meaning of our verse is: I am insignificant and of little worth for you to have done all these merciful deeds for me.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: I am small. I.E. interprets this to mean I am insignificant. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 76:4: <i>Katonti</i>. Rabbi Abba says, “This means I am not worthy.”</i> I have already explained the meaning of mercy and truth.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 24:49.</i>

Verse 12

AND SMITE ME. <i>And smite me</i> applies to two phrases.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ve-hekkani</i> is in the singular and <i>prima facie</i> refers only to Jacob. Thus nothing is stated about what Esau will do to the mother and the children.</i> It is similar to <i>And Saul’s son had two men that were captains of bands</i> (II Sam. 4:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: And two men, captains of bands were son of Saul. I.E. says that captains of should be read as if written twice, i.e., And two men, captains of bands, were captains of Saul’s son. Cf. Kimchi’s comment on this verse.</i> Our verse should be read as follows: and smite me and smite the mother and the children.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

TWO HUNDRED SHE-GOATS. Jacob sent ten females for every male of the flock,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Ten she-goats for every he-goat and 10 ewes for each ram.</i> four bulls for each cow, and two she-asses for every foal. He did this because he knew their nature.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">He sent as many males as were needed to service the females.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17

AND PUT A SPACE. The word <i>revach</i> means a space. <i>Harevachah</i> (respite) in <i>That there was respite</i> (harevachah) (Ex. 8:11) is close in meaning to it. The meaning of the latter is, there was a separation between one plague and the other. It is similar to <i>ve-ravach</i> (found relief) in <i>so Saul found relief</i> (ve-ravach le-sha’ul) (I Sam. 16:23).<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Saul had space. Figuratively speaking, he went out of his straits to an open space. Thus the root <i>resh, vav, chet</i> can refer to physical space, or space in time, to relief.</i>

Verse 18

AND ASKETH THEE SAYING. <i>U-she’elekha</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">when a <i>kal</i> in the third person has the suffix <i>kha</i> added to it, the second root letter is usually vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> (and asketh thee) is vocalized the same as <i>ahevekha</i> (he loveth thee).<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 15:16. It, too, is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> rather than with a <i>kamatz</i> beneath the second root letter (the <i>heh</i>).</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

AND ALL THAT FOLLOWED. Scripture says this because there were five groups.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Goats, sheep, camels, cattle and asses. Scripture notes that Jacob commanded the foremost, the second and the third group, <i>and all that followed</i> what to tell Esau because there were five groups and each group was instructed what to say.</i>
WHEN YE FIND HIM. The <i>tzadi</i> of <i>be-motza’akhem</i> (when ye find) is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> because it precedes a guttural.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">When an infinitive is combined with a pronominal suffix, the second root letter is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>, as in <i>be-shovbekha</i> (Deut. 6:7) or <i>tofsekhem</i> (Josh. 8:8). However, in our case rather than being vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>, the second root letter is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>. We thus read, <i>motza’akhem</i> rather than <i>motzakhem</i>. I.E. explains that this is so because the <i>tsadi</i> precedes a guttural (the <i>alef</i>) (Cherez).</i> This is so even though we do not find another example of this in the Bible.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In all other similar cases, i.e., even preceding a guttural, the second root letter is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>. Compare, <i>shomakhem</i> (Deut. 5:20), where the <i>mem</i> is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i> even though it precedes an <i>ayin</i>, a guttural (Cherez). Thus I.E. notes that while his explanation is correct with regard to our word it does not hold for similar words in Scripture.</i>

Verse 21

FOR HE SAID. He said in his heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob thought this. He did not instruct his messengers to say this to Esau, as one might gather from the verse.</i> These are the words of Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Moses in writing the Torah explained what motivated Jacob to send these gifts to Esau.</i>
[I WILL APPEASE HIM.] <i>Akhapperah</i> (I will appease him) means I will cover or hide.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>akhapperah</i> is <i>caf, peh, resh</i>, which means to cover.</i> <i>Panav</i> (him)<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Panav</i> usually means face or countenance. Here it means anger. Jacob said, “I will cover his anger”; i.e., I will appease him. Weiser suggests that since anger is expressed in the face, face is, by extension, occasionally used as a synonym for anger.</i> means his anger. <i>Peneha</i> (her countenance) in <i>and her countenance</i> (u-faneha) <i>was no more sad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. this should be rendered: her anger was no more, i.e., she was pacified.</i> (I Sam. 1:18) is similar.

Verse 22



Verse 23

AND PASSED OVER THE FORD OF THE JABBOK. Jacob passed over first.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture reads: <i>And he rose up that night and took his two wives, and his two handmaids, and his eleven children, and (he) passed over the ford Jabbok</i> (v. 23). <i>And he took them, and sent them over the stream</i> (v. 24). This is difficult to understand. Why interrupt the sequence of the narrative with <i>and (he) passed over the ford Jabbok</i>? Furthermore, if Jacob passed over the ford by himself, how could he take his wives and children over? Hence I.E. interprets that Scripture tells us that Jacob took his wives and children over but prior to this he had gone over himself (to see if it was safe for the others to pass-Nachmanides). Scripture then resumes the narrative by relating, <i>And he took them and sent them over the stream, and sent over that which he had</i> (Cherez).</i> He then returned and took his wives and children and brought them over the ford. Thus the meaning of <i>and passed over</i> is and he had already passed over. He then went back for a final look to see if anything was forgotten.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">After taking his family across the river Jacob went back for a final look. Hence he was left alone.</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25

AND THERE WRESTLED A MAN. <i>Va-ye’avek</i> (and there wrestled) comes from the same root as <i>avak</i> (dust). They struggled so that dust arose between them.
UNTIL THE BREAKING OF THE DAY. <i>Ad alot ha-shachar</i> (until the breaking of the day) means until the darkness of the night went away.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. interprets <i>alot</i> (breaking) to mean go up, i.e., to depart, and <i>shacher</i> (dawn) to mean darkness, for this is what the root of <i>shachar</i> means.</i> Others say that <i>shachar</i> (dawn) refers to the image of light that appears in the clouds before sunrise.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>shachar</i> means dawn and <i>alot</i> the rising. <i>Alot ha-shachar</i> thus means the breaking of dawn.</i> <i>Shacher</i> (light) in <i>wherein there is no light</i> (shacher) (Is. 8:20) is similar.

Verse 26

THAT HE PREVAILED NOT AGAINST HIM. The angel against Jacob.
HE TOUCHED THE HOLLOW OF HIS THIGH. Jacob’s thigh.
WAS STRAINED. <i>Va-teka</i> (was strained) is similar to <i>teka</i> (be moved)<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">It comes from the root <i>yod, kof, ayin</i> and means was moved (Cherez, Weiser). J.P.S. renders it as alienated.</i> in <i>Lest My soul be moved</i> (teka) <i>from thee</i> (Jer. 6:8). The hollow of Jacob’s thigh moved out of its place.

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

THE SINEW OF THE THIGH-VEIN. The meaning of the term <i>gid ha-nasheh</i> (the sinew of the thigh-vein) is known from the tradition received and transmitted to us by the Talmudic sages.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chullin</i> 91a. The rabbis interpret <i>gid na-nasheh</i> to mean the sinew that slipped from its place.</i> No one but those lacking in understanding and knowledge of nature have any doubt as to its definition. The latter interpret <i>gid</i> (sinew) to refer to the penis and hold that <i>nassheh</i> (thigh-vein) comes from the same root as <i>nashim</i> (women).<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">There was an anti-Rabbinic interpretation that explained the prohibition against eating the <i>gid ha-nashah</i> as follows: Therefore the children of Israel do not engage (eat) in abnormal intercourse with women (<i>gid ha-nasheh</i>). According to Krinsky it is this interpretation which I.E. negates.</i> Note, the angel that appeared to Jacob was corporeal.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This translation follows <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. It reads, <i>ve-da</i> (note). The printed text reads, <i>la-da’at</i> (to know).</i> This will be explained to you, if God will enlighten you, in the chapter that begins, <i>for My name is in him</i> (Ex. 23:21).

Chapter 33



Verse 1



Verse 2

[AND RACHEL AND JOSEPH HINDERMOST.] He placed Rachel and Joseph last so that they might possibly escape. Jacob did this because of his great love for them.

Verse 3



Verse 4

[AND KISSED HIM.] The Midrashic interpretation concerning the dots on <i>ve-yishakehu</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yishakehu</i> has dots over it According to a Midrashic opinion this indicates that Esau did not kiss Jacob wholeheartedly. Cf. <i>Yalkut Shimoni</i> on this verse.</i> (and kissed him) is good for <i>them that are drawn from the breasts</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">That is, children. The term used by I.E. is taken from Is. 28:9.</i> It is obvious from the plain meaning of the text that Esau did not intend to harm Jacob, the proof being <i>and they wept</i>, as Joseph did with his brethren.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">He kissed them and cried (Gen. 45:15). An alternate interpretation is, as Joseph did with his brother Benjamin (<i>Ibid</i>. v. 14).</i>

Verse 5

WHO ARE THESE WITH THEE. <i>Mi eleh lakh</i> can be interpreted as meaning who are these with thee, or who are these who are yours.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">That is, who are these who are obviously yours. I.E. points out that <i>lakh</i> can be interpreted as meaning <i>immekha</i> (with you) or <i>shellekha</i> (yours). Esau knew that these women and children belonged to Jacob. What he wanted to know was their relationship to him; were they servants or children (Cherez).</i>
GRACIOUSLY GIVEN. <i>Chanan</i> means gave graciously.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chanan</i> usually means to show favor to, to be gracious to. Hence I.E. explains that here <i>chanan</i> means gave graciously.</i> <i>Grant them graciously</i> (channunu) <i>unto us</i> (Jud. 21:22) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, <i>chanan</i> has the meaning of to graciously give.</i> The word <i>chinnam</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading of <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. Most of the printed texts have <i>chanan</i>. This reading is impossible to interpret. I.E.’s point is that <i>chinnam</i> comes from the root <i>chet, nun, nun</i> and means something gotten gratis (Filwarg, Weiser).</i> (gratuitously) comes from the same root.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chanan</i> and <i>chinnam</i> both come from the root <i>chet, nun, nun</i>. See note 7.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

WHAT MEANEST THOU. The word <i>mi</i> (what)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mi</i> (what) usually means who.</i> always refers to a person. The meaning of our clause<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mi le-khah kol ha-machneh ha-zeh</i> literally means: who to thee all this camp? This lends itself to the two interpretations offered by I.E.</i> is: to whom did you send this gift, or whom were you thinking of when you sent this gift.

Verse 9



Verse 10

NAY, I PRAY THEE. I pray my lord not to so speak.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Al na</i> (nay, I pray thee) is short for <i>al na yomar adoni ken</i> (I pray my lord not to so speak) (Weiser).</i> I have previously noted Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid’s interpretation of the term <i>al</i> (nay).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 19:18.</i>
AS ONE SEETH THE FACE OF GOD. The face of an angel. Many of the commentators explain that the angel with whom Jacob wrestled came to encourage him not to lose heart and fear Esau. For if an angel could not overcome him, certainly no human could. The word <i>sarita</i> (thou hast striven), in <i>thou hast striven</i> (sarita) <i>with</i> (im) <i>God</i> (Gen. 32:29),<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">It does not mean prince over. It means thou has become a prince. I.E. does not interpret <i>sarita</i> to mean strove. Since Jacob alluded to the angel in his comments to Esau, I.E. now goes back and concludes his comments on that incident which is reported in the previous chapter.</i> does not mean the same as <i>va-yaser</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Although both roots are related. Cf. D.B.G., <i>Hebrew and English Lexicon of the Hebrew Language</i>, Oxford, 1968.</i> (was prince) in <i>And Abimelech was prince</i> (va-yasar) <i>over</i> (al) <i>Israel</i> (Jud. 9:22), because <i>im</i> (with) is not the same as <i>al</i> (over). Our phrase (Gen. 32:29) means that you are considered a prince among the angels, and also among human princes.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. interprets <i>sarita</i> as, you have become a <i>sar</i>, a prince; <i>im Elohim</i>, among angels; <i>ve-im anashim</i>, and among human princes.</i> Some ask, what does Scripture mean by <i>And the sun rose upon him</i> (Gen. 32:32) when the sun rises all over the world at the same time?<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew implies it shone upon him but not upon other places.
