Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 78:8, “Did the sun rise only for him?”</i> This is a nonsensical question because the sun rises at different times in different places. For example, there is a difference of one and a third hours in sunrise and also twelve degrees in latitude between Jerusalem and the place where I wrote this commentary, namely the city of Lucca.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">A northern Italian city and capital of a Lombard duchy. Its Jewish community was among the most important in northern Italy, and it was one of the three northern Italian communities mentioned by Benjamin of Tudela (c. 1165). See Introduction.</i> This thing is certain and beyond doubt. The meaning of <i>tzole</i>’a (and he limped) (Gen. 32:32) is, he walked on one side.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains <i>tzela</i> as a side (see his comments on Gen. 2:21). <i>Tzole</i>’a is a denominative. A healthy person walks straight, a sick person leans on one side (Cherez).</i> The meaning of <i>al ken</i> (therefore) (Gen. 32:33) is, in commemoration of this thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In commemoration of Jacob’s victory over the angel, or of God’s saving Jacob from being overcome by the angel (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12

LET US TAKE OUR JOURNEY. Some say that <i>nisah</i> (let us take our journey) is an imperative.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>nisah</i> (let us take our journey) means, take your journey. The usual form for let us take our journey is <i>nissa</i> with a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>samakh</i>, not <i>nisah</i> which does not have a <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>samekh</i> and has a <i>heh</i> at the end. The usual imperative form for take your journey is <i>sa</i>. The commentators quoted by I.E. point out that in the elongated imperative the first letter of the root is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> and the last with a <i>kamatz</i>, as in <i>shilchah</i>. Cf. Rashi.</i> It is similar to <i>shilchah</i> (send) in <i>Send</i> (shilchah) <i>the lad</i> (Gen. 43:8)<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">An elongated imperative. The usual form of the imperative for send is <i>shelach</i>.</i> and <i>niflu</i> (fall) in <i>Fall</i> (niflu) <i>on us</i> (Hos. 10:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Most roots having a <i>nun</i> as their first root letter drop the <i>nun</i> in the imperative, thus the imperative of <i>nun, samekh, ayin</i> is <i>sa</i>. I.E. points out that in <i>nun, peh, lamed, the nun</i> does not drop in the imperative. Hence while in <i>nasa</i> the <i>nun</i> normally drops out in the imperative, it does not in the elongated imperative. Hence <i>nisah</i> is similar to <i>niflu</i>.</i>
AND LET US GO. All of us.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">In contradistinction to <i>nisah, ve-nelekhah</i> (and let us go) which is a plural. I.E. further points out that the meaning of <i>and I will go before thee</i> is: I will not move away from thee (Weiser). Compare Rashi, <i>and I will go before thee</i>, equally with thee. Krinky suggests that I.E.’s interpretation is: even if I perchance go before thee, I will not go far from thee but will keep up with thee.</i> <i>And I will go before thee</i>; i.e., I will not move away from you. However, it is possible that <i>nisah</i> is similar to <i>va-nissse’ah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nissse’ah</i> in Ezra 8:31 is an elongated first person plural imperfect meaning: we will depart, we will take our journey. The <i>vav</i> prefixed to it changes it to a perfect. Hence <i>va-nisse’ah</i> means: then we departed. I.E. now says <i>nisah</i> in our verse, too, is a first person plural imperfect meaning: let us take our journey. However, he does not explain why there is no <i>dagesh</i> in the <i>samekh</i>.</i> (then we departed) in <i>Then we departed</i> (va-nisse’ah) <i>from the river of Ahava</i> (Ezra 8:31). The meaning of our verse thus is: Let us all take our journey,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>nisah</i> is a first person plural imperfect. According to the first interpretation our verse reads: Take your journey, and let us go, and I will go before thee; according to the second: Let us take our journey, and let us go, and I will go before thee.</i> and I will go before thee.

Verse 13

THE CHILDREN ARE TENDER. The oldest was twelve years and some days old.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob spent 20 years in Laban’s house. He was unmarried for the first seven years, after which he married Leah. Thus Reuben, Jacob’s eldest son, could not have been much older than 12.</i>
GIVING SUCK. <i>Alot</i> (giving suck) is similar to <i>alot</i> (pregnant) in <i>and gently leadeth those that are pregnant</i> (alot) (Is. 40:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">This is how I.E. renders <i>alot</i>. The usual translation of <i>alot</i> is: those that give suck.</i> It means pregnant cattle. They are called <i>alot</i> because the he-goats went up (<i>alu</i>) on them.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Mounted them. This applies to the other kinds as well. I.E. is merely using the language of Scripture, viz., <i>the he-goats which leaped (mounted) upon the flock</i> (Gen. 31:10). The point is that pregnant animals are called <i>alot</i> because they were mounted by male animals.</i> 
The meaning of <i>alai</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: upon me.</i> (are a care to me) is that I have to care for them that no harm befall them.
AND IF THEY OVERDRIVE THEM. If the drivers<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The “they” is not identified in the text Hence I.E. points out that it refers to the drivers.</i> overdrive them, then all the flock will die.

Verse 14

AND I WILL JOURNEY ON. This is to be understood as, and I will journey on with them.
GENTLY. The <i>yod</i> of <i>le’itti</i> (gently) is either superfluous<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The word for gently or slowly being <i>le’at</i>. Hence the <i>yod</i> of <i>le’itti</i> is superfluous.</i> or is a first person pronominal suffix.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning at my ease or at my slow pace.</i>
ACCORDING TO THE PACE OF THE CATTLE. Because of the cattle, whose care is my work.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Melakhah</i> usually means work. I.E. explains why it refers to cattle here.</i> I believe that the meaning of <i>melakhah</i> is what a person can do by himself or through his agent.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. does not disagree with his original point that <i>melakhah</i> here refers to cattle. He now expands on the meaning of the word (Filwarg). According to the first interpretation “work” refers to cattle because Jacob’s work was taking care of cattle. According to the second interpretation “work” can refer directly to cattle, for one’s possessions are one’s work.</i> Also, one’s property is called <i>melakhah</i>, as in <i>whether he have not put his hand unto his neighbor’s goods</i> (melekhet) (Ex. 22:7). The word messenger (<i>malakh</i>) comes from the same root. A <i>malakh</i> (messenger) is so called because he is under the control of the one who sends him. The meaning of the word <i>regel</i> (the pace) is the same as <i>le-ragli</i> (because of me),<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Le-regel</i> (according to the pace) means because. Although the basic meaning of <i>melachah</i> is changed in the second interpretation, the meaning of <i>le-regel</i> (because) remains unchanged.</i> as in <i>and the Lord hath blessed thee because of me</i> (le-ragli) (Gen. 30:30).<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s interpretation of Gen. 30:30.</i> However, it is possible that <i>le-regel</i> should be taken literally, since Jacob led the animals on foot.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>melakhah</i> means cattle, why not interpret <i>regel</i> literally as meaning feet, since the animals walked, viz., according to the pace (foot) of the cattle.</i>

Verse 15

[WHAT NEEDETH IT?] I have no need of it.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads, <i>lammah zeh emtzah chen be-ene adoni</i>. This can be rendered: why then shall I find favor in the eyes of my lord? I.E. explains that this is not the way to interpret the verse. <i>Lammah zeh</i> is not to be connected to <i>emtza chen</i>, etc. The verse is to be interpreted: <i>lammah zeh</i>, why this? That is, why do this when I have no need of it? <i>Emtza chen be-ene adoni</i> is another clause meaning: I merely want to find favor in your eyes (Weiser, Krinsky). Cf. Rashi.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

AND JACOB CAME IN PEACE. <i>Shalem</i> (peace) is an adjective.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shalem</i> can be taken to be the name of a place, Salem. Hence I.E.’s comment.</i> The meaning of our clause is, Jacob came in peace to Shechem; i.e., no misfortune befell him on the way. Scripture notes this because it is about to tell of what happened to Dinah.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">That is why Scripture notes that up to now no misfortune befell him.</i>

Verse 19

THE PARCEL OF GROUND. A portion in the field.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that Jacob did not buy the <i>parcel of ground where he had spread his tent</i>. He rather bought a portion in the field <i>where he had spread his tent</i>.</i> Scripture mentions this<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">That Jacob bought, not rented, a parcel of land.</i> to inform us of the greatness of the land of Israel. Whosoever has a portion in it is as though he had a portion in the world to come.

Verse 20

[AND CALLED IT EL-ELOHE-ISRAEL.]<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">God, the God of Israel.</i> Saadiah explained that <i>and called it El-elohe-Israel</i> means, He called to the Lord, “El-elohe-Israel.”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>lo</i> can mean either it or him. Saadiah had difficulty in accepting that Jacob called the altar God, the God of Israel. Hence he did not interpret <i>lo</i> as meaning it, i.e., the altar, but rather as Him, i.e., God. He interprets our verse as: And called to Him, God, God of Israel (Krinsky). For a slightly different interpretation see Cherez.</i> However, the correct interpretation is that he called the altar El-elohe-Israel (God, the God of Israel). Moses similarly called the altar he erected <i>Adonai-nissi</i> (the Lord is my banner) (Ex. 17:15) because of the miracle God performed in that place. Similarly, when the Divine Presence will once again return to Jerusalem, the city will be called <i>Adonai-shammah</i> (the Lord is there) (Ezek. 48:35). Jacob similarly called the altar whereupon he served the Lord, El-elohe-Israel (God, the God of Israel) because God came to his aid. The name <i>El</i> (God) means the One who is powerful and mighty.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">God thereby demonstrated His might Therefore, Jacob called him El, mighty and powerful.</i>
ELOHE-ISRAEL. He saved him on the way and ensured his safe arrival in Canaan, where Succoth<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> and Shechem are located.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Where Jacob now camped.</i> I believe that Jacob spent many years in the city of Shechem, for at the time of Jacob’s arrival in Shechem, Dinah was less than seven years old and also Simeon and Levi were yet small children.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob stayed in Laban’s house for 20 years. He married Leah and Rachel after seven years, and with the exception of Benjamin, all of his children were born in the next seven years (cf. I.E. on Gen. 30:23). Reuben, his eldest, was a little over 12. Simeon and Levi, the next two in order, a bit younger. Dinah, who was born in the 14th year of Jacob’s service to Laban, had to be under seven. The question thus arises, could what is described in Chapter 34 apply to such a little girl? Dinah is described as a young lady of age. Furthermore, could children of Simeon and Levi’s age, preadolescents, overcome and slay a city? Could pre-adolescents act and talk the way Jacob’s sons are described as doing in Chapter 34? I.E. thus suggests that many years passed between the end of Chapter 33 and Chapter 34. During these years Jacob’s children had grown. It should be noted that in putting forth this interpretation I.E. is taking issue with the Midrash which states that Simeon and Levi were 13 when they destroyed Shechem. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 80.</i>

Chapter 34



Verse 1

AND DINAH WENT OUT. Of her own accord.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">She did not ask her parents’ permission (Krinsky). Filwarg asks, “How does I.E. know this?”</i>

Verse 2

AND HUMBLED HER. He had normal intercourse with her.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Contra Rashi who interprets humbled as sodomized.</i> Scripture uses the term <i>va-ye’anneha</i> ( and humbled her)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The root <i>ayin, nun, heh</i> means to afflict. Thus <i>va-ye’anneha</i> (and he humbled her) means he afflicted her. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.</i> because she was a virgin.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Intercourse was thus painful, hence the term afflicted her.</i>

Verse 3

AND SPOKE COMFORTINGLY UNTO THE DAMSEL. He spoke tenderly and comfortingly to her.

Verse 4



Verse 5

THAT HE HAD DEFILED. That Shechem had defiled.

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

A REPROACH. It will be a reproach for generations.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Cherez interprets I.E. to mean that future generations will look down upon us. They will ask, how could they give their sister to an uncircumcised man?</i> This is the meaning of <i>because he had wrought a vile deed in Israel</i> (v. 7).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the vile deed refers to having intercourse with an uncircumcised male (Weiser). Israel in verse 7 refers to a later time when there was a people of Israel. It was then shameful to recall that Dinah had slept with an uncircumcised man (Joseph ben Eliezer Ha-Sephardi).</i> 
[13. AND SPOKE BECAUSE HE HAD DEFILED.] And spoke to Shechem who had (<i>asher</i>) defiled their sister.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads: <i>va-yedabberu, asher timme et dinah achotam</i> which literally means: and they spoke who had defiled Dinah their sister. This makes no sense. Hence I.E. points out that Shechem, who is mentioned in the first part of the verse (<i>et shechem</i>), is also the object here. We should thus read it as if it were written: <i>va-yedabberu et shechem asher timme et dinah achotam</i>, viz., and spoke to Shechem who had defiled their sister. It should be noted that according to this interpretation, <i>asher</i> means who.</i> We may interpret our verse in this manner because we find Scripture stating, <i>dabbero le-shalom</i> (Gen. 37:4), which is to be rendered: speak peaceably unto him (Gen. 37:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. claims that <i>dabber et Shechem</i> is grammatically similar to <i>dabbero</i>. For an explanation of their linguistic similarity see Filwarg. See also notes to Gen. 37:4. For alternate interpretations see Weiser, Cherez and Krinsky.</i> On the other hand <i>asher</i> may mean because. In this case the Bible is telling us that they answered with guile because (<i>asher</i>) he had defiled Dinah their sister.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Cherez.</i>
TO ONE THAT IS UNCIRCUMCISED. One whose sexual member is uncircumcised.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: to one who has an <i>orlah</i>, hence I.E.’s interpretation.</i> The meaning of the term <i>orlah</i> (uncircumcised) is something which is heavy. <i>Aral</i> (uncircumcised), in <i>uncircumcised</i> (aral) <i>lips</i> (Ex. 6:12), and <i>arelah</i> (dull), in <i>their ear is dull</i> (arelah) (Jer. 6:10), are similar. An <i>orlah</i> is something which lays heavy because it is an unnecessary appendage.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky. In the case of the foreskin the heaviness is physical. In the case of lips and ears, metaphoric. I.E. renders “uncircumcised lips” as heavy lips. There is, as it were, a burden on the lips which makes speaking difficult. The same applies to the ears.</i> Those who say that Abraham blemished himself by undergoing circumcision, and thereby violated God’s charge to him, <i>and be thou whole</i> (Gen. 17:1), err. The opposite is true.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">By circumcision Abraham became “whole.” His impediment was removed. So Cherez and Filwarg. For an alternate interpretation see Weiser.</i> Proof of this can be offered from the animal kingdom. <sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Animals have no foreskin. We thus see that it is an unnecessary appendage.</i> As to their query, why remove that which God created, we respond that God also created the umbilical cord.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that God created appendages that require removal (Weiser).</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

OUR DAUGHTER. They spoke thus because she was a minor.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Since Dinah was a minor they could threaten, <i>then we will take our daughter, and we will be gone</i>.</i> They referred to Dinah as our daughter because they spoke on behalf of Jacob.

Verse 18



Verse 19

DEFERRED NOT. <i>Echar</i> (deferred) is not of the same grammatical form as <i>va-echar</i> (and stayed) in <i>and stayed</i> (va-echar) <i>until now</i> (Gen. 32:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Both words look alike and are identically vocalized.</i> Our word is a third person <i>pi’el</i> perfect following the paradigm of <i>berakh</i> (did curse) in <i>Naboth did curse</i> (berakh) <i>God and the King</i> (I Kings 21:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">However, <i>echar</i> in Gen. 32:5 is a first person <i>kal</i> imperfect (Weiser). Here the <i>alef</i> is a root letter. In Gen. 32:5 the root <i>alef</i> is missing, for the <i>alef</i> therein is a first person <i>kal</i> prefix (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21

PEACEABLE. They are at peace.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>shelemim</i> (peaceable) is an adjective (Weiser, Krinsky).</i>
LARGE ENOUGH. <i>Yadayim</i> (enough)<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. renders <i>rachavat yadayim</i> (large enough) as large places, i.e., the land is large enough for both of us.</i> is to be rendered places, as in <i>Thou shalt have a place</i> (yad) (Deut. 23:13).

Verse 22

WILL THE MEN CONSENT. <i>Ye’otu</i> (consent) comes from the same root as <i>ya’atah</i> (befitteth) in <i>For it befitteth</i> (ya’atah) <i>Thee</i> (Jer. 10:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. its root is <i>yod, alef, tav</i> (Krinsky).</i> The <i>yod</i> prefix is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than a <i>chirik</i> (Cherez).</i> to compensate for the missing first root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>yod</i>.</i>
BE CIRCUMCISED. The word <i>be-himmol</i> (be circumcised) has already been explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 17:10.</i> Shechem and Hamor had evil designs on Jacob and his sons for they said, <i>Shall not their cattle and their substance and all their beasts be ours</i> (v. 22)?<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">They had intentions of later robbing them of their possessions. Thus both sides plotted against each other (Weiser).</i>

Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

ON THE THIRD DAY. The third day is always a difficult day because it is half of a monthly quarter.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">It is half a week which is a quarter of the month (Weiser). The astrologers count the days from the afternoon. Hence the fourth day begins after the noon of the third day has passed. The time between noon and sunset of the third day is called half the monthly quarter (Krinsky).</i> Simeon and Levi acted with the full consent of their brothers. This is clear from <i>And the sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father with guile</i> (v. 13). The “sons of Jacob”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is to verse 13 (Krinsky, Cherez). Weiser suggests that the reference is to verse 27 wherein it is stated, <i>The sons of Jacob came upon the slain and spoiled the city</i>.</i> refers to all of the brothers. Jacob spilled his anger on Simeon and Levi because they killed the men of Shechem<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">While the others merely looted the city, Simeon and Levi killed its male inhabitants (Weiser). Cherez explains that the others merely wanted to save Dinah. They did not intend to kill the men of Shechem.</i>

Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

EVEN ALL THAT WAS IN THE HOUSE. This refers either to the house of Shechem or Hamor.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">“House” is in the singular, hence I.E.’s comment (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 30

FEW IN NUMBER. <i>Mete</i> (few) means men. Anything that can be numbered is deemed a few.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. renders <i>mete mispar</i> (few in number) as men of number, i.e., few men.</i> Hence Rabbi Aaron Ha-Kohen, dean of the Yeshiva,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Head of the academy in Pumpeditha. Hai Gaon was among his students (Weiser).</i> errs in rendering literally <i>vi-yehi metav mispar</i> (in that his men became few) (Deut. 33:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Aaron renders Deut. 33:6, and let his men be numbered. I.E. renders this verse: and let his men not be men who can be numbered.</i>
TO MAKE ME ODIOUS.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, to make me stink, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> They will hate me as one loathes something which gives off a horrible odor.

Verse 31

AND THEY SAID. Simeon and Levi.
SHOULD ONE DEAL WITH OUR SISTER AS WITH A HARLOT. Should Shechem deal with our sister as with a harlot.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The subject is missing in the sentence, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>

Chapter 35



Verse 1



Verse 2

PUT AWAY THE STRANGE GODS. Heaven forbid that the prophet would live with women who served strange gods.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads: <i>Then Jacob said unto his household, and to all that were with him, “Put away the strange gods that are among you</i>.” This implies that his wives had strange gods.</i> The explanation of this verse will be found in the Torah portion <i>va-yelekh moshe</i> (And Moses went).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Deut. 31:16.</i>
AND PURIFY YOURSELVES. Wash your bodies.
AND CHANGE YOUR GARMENTS. From this verse we learn that an Israelite must have a clean body and spotless garments when he goes to pray in a place set aside for worship.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

A TERROR OF. The <i>tav</i> of <i>chittat</i> (terror of) receives a <i>dagesh</i> to compensate for the missing root letter, the <i>tav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>chittat</i> is <i>chet, tav, tav</i>, but it is spelled with one <i>tav</i>. The <i>dagesh</i> compensates for the missing letter.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7

[BECAUSE THERE GOD WAS REVEALED TO HIM.] <i>Elohim</i> (God) refers to angels.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Revealed (<i>niglu</i>) is in the plural. If <i>elohim</i> meant God then revealed would be in the singular (Cherez).</i> Compare, <i>And behold the angels of God ascending and descending on it</i> (Gen. 28:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Elohim</i> in our verse refers to the same angels whom Jacob saw in Beth-el (Gen. 28:12).</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

THY NAME SHALL NOT BE CALLED ANYMORE JACOB. You shall no longer be called only Jacob but also Israel.

Verse 11

BE FRUITFUL AND MULTIPLY. This is a blessing as in the account of the Creation.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:26.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

[AND JACOB SET UP A PILLAR.] This may be a pluperfect meaning Jacob had already set up a pillar.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 28:18, 22.</i> On the other hand, Jacob may now have set up a pillar a second time. I prefer the first interpretation.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. prefers to believe that Jacob used the pillar which he had set up previously in Beth-el.</i>
AND HE POURED OUT A DRINK-OFFERING THEREON. He poured wine or water on the pillar. Jacob first washed the pillar with wine or water<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s interpretation of <i>and poured out a drink-offering thereon</i>.</i> and then <i>poured oil thereon</i>. Here at Beth-el Jacob kept his vow<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 28:20. This is not explicitly stated in Scripture. I.E. assumes that it must have been so.</i> and gave a tithe of his wealth in honor of God to a contemporary who was worthy to receive it.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 28:22.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16

SOME WAY. It is possible that the <i>caf</i> of <i>kivrat</i> (some way) is a preposition meaning similar to<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>kivrat</i> (some way) is to be interpreted <i>ki-verat</i>, as a <i>brat</i>.</i> and that <i>brat</i> is a distance measured by walking.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">This is the reading in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. The printed editions read: a king’s measure.</i> The word does not appear elsewhere in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>kivrat</i> does appear in II Kings 5:19. Krinsky suggests that I.E. means it doesn’t appear elsewhere in the Pentateuch. Cherez maintains that I.E. means that the word <i>berat</i> is not found in Scripture.</i>

Verse 17

WHEN SHE WAS IN HARD LABOR. <i>Be-hakshotah</i> (when she was in hard) is a <i>hifil</i>. The meaning of <i>be-hakshotah be-lidtah</i> (when she was in hard labor) is: the delivery caused her pain.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hifil</i> is a causative form. If this is the case then <i>be-hakshotah</i> must be transitive, hence I.E.’s comment that it means caused her hardship. Cf. Kimchi.</i> <i>Va-tekash</i> (and she had hard labor, in v. 16) is similar. <sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">It, too, is an active form and is to be explained as in note 15.</i> However the latter is a <i>pi’el</i>. <i>Va-tekash</i> is similar to <i>va-tekhal</i> (and she was done) in <i>And when she had done</i> (va-tekhal) <i>giving him drink</i> (Gen. 24:19).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Both words are shortened forms of the <i>pi’el. Va-tekash</i> is short for <i>va-tekasheh</i> as <i>va-tekhal</i> is short for <i>va-tekhalleh</i>.</i>

Verse 18

BEN-ONI. <i>Ben-oni</i> means the son of my mourning. <i>Onim</i> (mourners) in <i>as the bread of mourners</i> (onim) (Hos. 9:4) and <i>be-oni</i> (my mourning) in <i>I have not eaten thereof in my mourning</i> (be-oni) (Deut. 26:14) are similar.

Verse 19



Verse 20

HER GRAVE. <i>Kevuratah</i> (her grave) and <i>kivrah</i> (her grave) mean the same.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kever</i> means a grave, <i>kevurah</i> a burial, and <i>kevuratah</i> her burial. Thus our verse should have read <i>kivrah</i> (her grave) and not <i>kevuratah</i> (her burial) since Jacob erected a monument over Rachel’s grave. I.E. points out that <i>kevuratah</i> can also have the same meaning as <i>kivrah</i> (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22

THAT REUBEN WENT. Our sages explained this beautifully;<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">According to the rabbis Reuben did not actually lay with Billah but rather removed his father’s couch from her tent and placed it in the tent of his mother Leah. Scripture considers this act of audacity as if he had actually slept with her. Cf. <i>Sabbath</i> 55b.</i> for <i>a prudent man concealeth shame</i> (Prov. 12:16).

Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

THAT WERE BORN TO HIM IN PADDAN-ARAM. Actually only eleven sons were born to Jacob in Paddan-aram<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The problem is that our verse states that all of Jacob’s sons were born in Paddanaram, when in fact this was not so.</i> for Benjamin was born in the land of Canaan. Scripture speaks of the majority of his sons.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>These are the sons of Jacob, that were born to him in Paddan-aram</i> refers to the majority of his sons.</i> I will in the future point out many similar cases.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 47:27.</i>

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

AND ISAAC EXPIRED. When Isaac died and was gathered to his people Easu and Jacob buried him.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Chronologically speaking Isaac did not die at this point for he lived until Joseph was 29 years of age (see I.E. on Gen. 37:35). Scripture notes the death of Isaac here because it will no longer deal with him (Filwarg). Thus <i>And Isaac expired, and died</i> should be rendered: And when Isaac expired and died, etc. (Krinsky).</i> Scripture mentions Esau<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Even though Esau sold his birthright to Jacob and was no longer technically the eldest.</i> before Jacob because the Pentateuch follows the order of their birth. However, in relating the burial of Abraham the Bible reads, <i>And Isaac and Ishmael</i><sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">If the Torah follows the order of birth then Ishmael should be mentioned first.</i> <i>his sons buried him</i> (Gen. 25:9) because Ishmael was the son of a handmaid.

Chapter 36



Verse 1

THE SAME IS EDOM. He is the father of Edom.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads, <i>he is Edom</i>, which I.E., based on verse 9, interprets as, he is the father of Edom (Krinsky). Filwarg interprets it as, both Esau and his descendants are called Edom. Our verse teaches that Esau is Edom and verse 9 (which reads, <i>Esau the father of the Edomites</i>) that Esau’s descendants are called Edom.</i> Do not be surprised that Scripture here calls <i>the daughter of Elon the Hittite</i> whom Esau married Adah, while earlier it refers to her by the name of Basemath (Gen. 26:34), for she had two names.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 26:34.</i> We find the same with the mother of Abijah.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 15:2 and II Chron. 11:20 gives her name as Maacah; II Chron. 13:2 gives her name as Micaiah.</i> Indeed, Abijah himself (II Chron. 11:20) is called Abijam in the Book of Kings (I Kings 15:1) and Abijah in Chronicles (II Chron. 11:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">According to Krinsky. For an alternate interpretation see Weiser and Cherez.</i> The Bible refers to them by two different names because both Abijah and his mother had two names each.
<i>These are the names of Esau’s sons</i> (v. 10) refers to his grandchildren.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Esau’s children are listed in verses 4 and 5, his descendants in verses 10-18. Hence the introduction to this list, viz., <i>These are the names of Esau’s sons</i>, must refer to his grandchildren. Krinsky suggests that there is a scribal error and that the reference is to <i>And these are the generations of Esau</i> in verse 9.</i>

Verse 2

AND OHOLIBAMAH THE DAUGHTER OF ANAH, THE DAUGHTER OF ZIBEON THE HIVITE. We find in our chapter a man called Anah who is the brother of Zibeon (v. 20). We further read that Zibeon had a son called Anah (v. 24). Our verse thus relates that Zibeon and his son Anah, or perhaps Zibeon and his brother Anah, slept with the same woman and the offspring did not know who their father was.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the Bible lists two men, Anah and Zibeon, as being Oholibamah’s father.</i> However, it is also possible that Oholibamah was the daughter of Anah the son of Zibeon, and Scripture lists her as being the daughter of Anah and Zibeon in order to distinguish between Anah the son of Zibeon and Anah the brother of Zibeon.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Had Scripture merely said, “Oholibamah daughter of Anah” we would not know which Anah the Bible is talking about. Cherez explains that Scripture could state that Oholibamah was Zibeon’s daughter, when in fact she was his granddaughter because grandchildren are considered children.</i> Some say that our chapter speaks of a Korah the son of Adah<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 15 and 16 list the chiefs of the sons of Esau from his wife Adah, among them <i>the chief of Korah</i>. Thus Korah must be Adah’s son.</i> and Korah the son of Oholibamah.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In verse 14 it is related that Oholibamah bore Korah. Thus our chapter speaks of two Korahs.</i> However, I believe that both are one and the same person. Korah was the son of Oholibamah. The reason he is listed among the chiefs of Eliphaz<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Adah’s son. See note 8.</i> is that he lived among them. It is also possible, since he was Oholibamah’s youngest son, that his mother died when he was still a child and that Adah raised him along with her own family and Scripture includes him with her children. Our case is similar to <i>the five sons of Michal</i> (II Sam. 21:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The five sons of Michal were really the children of Merab. Cf. <i>San</i>. 19b., “Michal bore these five children? Did not Merab give birth to them?” The Talmud answers, “Merab bore them but Michal raised them. Hence they are called her children.”</i> Korah thus became Adah’s son. Scripture similarly says that Amalek was a son of Adah<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 lists the chief of Amalek among the children of Adah. However, verse 12 states, <i>And Timna was concubine to Eliphaz Esau’s son and she bore to Eliphaz Amalek</i>. Thus Amalek was the son of Timna, not the son of Adah.</i> because he was the son of the handmaid of her husband.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">This comment presents a problem. Verse 12 state that Timna was Eliphaz’s concubine, not Esau’s concubine. Cherez posits a scribal error; i.e., in place of <i>her husband</i>, read her son. Weiser suggests that I.E. had a tradition that Timna was first Esau’s concubine and then Eliphaz’s concubine, hence I.E.’s statement, “concubine of her husband.” The Bible lists Amalek among Adah’s children because Adah helped raise him (Weiser).</i>
[CHIEF.] The meaning of <i>alluf</i> is a prince or chief. However, this is not the meaning of <i>alluf</i> (docile)<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. translates <i>alluf</i> as ox. <i>Ke-kheves alluf</i> does not mean like a great sheep, but rather like a lamb or like an ox.</i> in <i>ke-kheves alluf</i> (like a docile lamb) (Jer. 11:19). In the latter verse the <i>caf</i> prefixed to <i>keves</i> (lamb) also pertains to <i>alluf</i>; i.e., the verse is to be read as if written <i>ke-kheves ke-alluf</i> (like a lamb, like an ox). The latter is normal Hebrew usage,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">It is normal Hebrew usage to place two <i>cafs</i> in succession, meaning like this or like that.</i> as can be seen in <i>I went about as though it had been my friend</i> (ke-re’a) <i>or my brother</i> (ke-ach) (Ps. 35:14).

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

SEIR. We do not know his pedigree. Scripture lists the children of Seir to inform us that they were of a different lineage from the children of Esau. The Bible notes this because Israel was prohibited from contending with the children of Esau.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Deut. 2:4-5. This prohibition did not apply to the Seirites. Both nations inhabited the same country. However, the children of Esau displaced them (Deut. 2:22).</i>
THE HORITE. <i>Chori</i> (Horite) means nobles. It is similar to <i>chore</i> (nobles) in <i>the nobles</i> (chore) <i>of Judah</i> (Jer. 27:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>These are the sons of Seir the Horite</i> (ha-chori) should be translated: These are the sons of Seir the noble (the chief).</i> It is possible that <i>chori</i> (Horites) comes from the same root as <i>chorai</i> in <i>And they that weave cotton</i> (chorai) (Is. 19:9), in which <i>chorai</i> means white stuff. Onkelos similarly renders white by <i>chivvar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">So Cherez. Weiser renders I.E. as follows: the Targum (Jonathan) similarly translates <i>chore</i> to mean nobles.</i> Nobles are called <i>chorim</i> (the white ones) because they are metaphorically speaking, like the color white,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">It is the most beautiful color.</i> a color which resembles light.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">A symbol of good and purity.</i> In contrast to <i>chorim</i>, mean men are called <i>chashukkim</i> (dark ones), as we read in <i>He shall not stand before mean men</i> (chashukkim) (Prov. 22:29).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In Prov. 22:29 <i>chashukkim</i> is the antithesis of <i>kings. Chashukkim</i> comes from the word <i>choshekh</i> (black or dark). We thus see that white is a symbol of <i>nobility</i>, and black of poverty (Cherez) or of non-nobility, of meanness (Weiser).</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

AIAH AND ANAH. The <i>vav</i> prefixed to Aiah has the same meaning as the Arabic <i>fa</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew has a <i>vav</i> before Aiah. If this <i>vav</i> is a connective <i>vav</i> we should translate: And these are the children of Zibeon and Aiah and Anah. I.E. points out that the <i>vav</i> before Aiah is not to be translated. It is superfluous and is placed for emphasis (Weiser).</i> We have a similar clause without a <i>vav</i> prefixed to Aiah<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">I Chron. 1:40 reads, <i>And the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah</i>.</i> in Chronicles (I Chron. 1:40).
THE HOT SPRINGS. Onkelos renders <i>yemim</i> (hot springs) mighty men as in <i>The Emim dwelt therein aforetime, a people great, and many, and tall</i> (Deut. 2:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The Emim were mighty men. Onkelos identifies the <i>Yemin</i> with them.</i> It is possible to compare the two because we find the <i>yod</i> and <i>alef</i> interchanging<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>yemim</i> equals <i>emim</i>. Nachmanides explains that Onkelos held that Anah was attacked by Emem, who wanted to rob his father’s asses, and overcame them. Thus he found the Emim in <i>the wilderness as he fed the asses of Zibeon, his father</i>.</i> as with the word <i>yityammeru</i> (bear themselves loftily) (Ps. 94:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">There is no such word in Scripture. However, we do find <i>tityammaru</i> (shall ye revel) (Is. 61:6). Either we have a scribal error (Krinsky) and what I.E. is saying is that <i>tityammaru</i> could have been written <i>titammeru</i> since Ps. 94:4 employs the term <i>yitammeru</i> (bear themselves loftily), or I.E. is saying that Ps. 94:4 could have read <i>yityammeru</i> since Is. 61:6 reads <i>tityammaru</i> (Weiser). Spelled with a <i>yod</i> or an <i>alef</i> it means to exalt.</i> However, Saadiah Gaon translates <i>yemim</i> as mules. He interprets <i>who found</i> to mean who crossbred.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">He crossbred a horse and an ass and “found” mules. This is also the opinion of the Talmud. Cf. Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Berakhot</i> 8:5.</i> It is also possible that <i>who found</i> means who first discovered the technique of crossbreeding, since two different species cannot produce offspring.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Hence crossbreeding was a new discovery.</i> The latter interpretation is substantiated by Scripture’s stating, <i>as he fed the asses of Zibeon his father</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Since he was occupied with taking care of the asses, he experimented and discovered this technique.</i> If the meaning of <i>yemim</i> is plants, as is maintained by many commentators, why should Scripture mention <i>as he fed the asses of Zibeon his father</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">If the Bible wants to tell us that Anah found a certain type of plant (<i>yemim</i>) in the desert, what need is there to tell us that he did this <i>as he fed the asses of Zibeon his father</i>?</i>

Verse 25

AND THESE ARE THE CHILDREN OF ANAH: DISHON AND OHOLIBAMAH THE DAUGHTER OF ANAH. Anah the father of Oholibamah is not the same Anah mentioned in the first part of our verse,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">If they are one and the same person Scripture should have read: And these are the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah.</i> because if he is, there would be no need to mention him again. He is rather to be identified with the Anah mentioned in the preceding verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Anah the son of Zibeon mentioned in verse 24. The Anah mentioned in the first part of our verse is Anah the brother of Zibeon mentioned in verse 20. Thus Oholibamah was Zibeon’s granddaughter (Krinsky). Cf. I.E.’s comments on verse 2.</i>

Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31

AND THESE ARE THE KINGS. Some say that this chapter records a prophecy.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>before there reigned any king over the children of Israel</i>. Saul was Israel’s first king. Thus our chapter appears to deal with the post Mosaic period. These commentaries explain that Moses wrote our chapter as prophecy.</i> However, Yitzchaki<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Some identify him with Isaac ben Solomon Israeli (c. 850-950). He was a philosopher, Biblical commentator and court physician to the caliphs in Egypt and Kairouan.</i> claims in his book that this chapter was composed during the reign of King Jehoshaphat.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">A ninth-century king of Judah. Jehoshaphat was the eighth Hebrew king to reign starting from Saul. In his days the Edomites no longer had kings for they were subject to Judah. This is the reason that once the eighth Hebrew king ascended the throne it was written that the Edomites, too, had eight kings.</i> He explained the generations as he saw fit. Was he not rightly named Yitzchak?<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">A play on Gen. 27:36.</i> Everyone that heareth his interpretation will laugh at him.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">A play on Gen. 21:6.</i> For he identified Hadar (v. 39) with Hadad the Edomite (I Kings 11:14)<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">A contemporary of King Solomon.</i> and also said that Mehetabel (v. 39) is to be identified with the sister of Tahpenes the queen of Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Pharaoh gave his wife Tahpenes’ sister to Hadad in marriage.</i> Far be it for one to believe that our chapter was written in the days of Jehoshaphat as Yitzchaki maintains. Indeed his book is fit to be burned. Why did Yitzchaki maintain that it is impossible for eight Edomite kings to have reigned before Moses<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Yitchaki claimed that there were too few years between the establishment of the Edomite kingdom and Moses for eight Edomite kings to reign, for from Esau’s death, when the Edomite kingdom was established, until the Revelation at Sinai, when Moses reigned, only 193 years passed. The computation of the 193 years is as follows: The Israelites spent 210 years in Egypt, starting with Jacob’s descent to Egypt. Jacob lived there 17 years before he died. Esau died on the very day that Jacob did (<i>Sotah</i> 13a). We thus subtract 17 from 210 and we get 193 (Cherez).</i> when we find double the number of kings in Israel in about the same number of years?<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The kingdom of Israel lasted for 241 years during which time Israel had 19 kings (Krinsky). I.E. says that Israel had double the number of kings of the Edomites. Either he uses a round number or does not count Zimri (I Kings 16:15) who reigned seven days; Zechariah (II Kings 15:8) who reigned six months; and Shallum who reigned a month (<i>Ibid</i>., v. 13). Thus Israel had 16 kings in 241 years. Why, then, is it so hard to believe that eight Edomite kings reigned in 193 years (Krinsky)? Cherez explains that the first 16 kings of Israel reigned 210 years. Thus Israel had 16 kings in 210 years.</i> Furthermore, there were also proportionally many more kings of Judah in the same time period than the eight Edomite kings who reigned till the age of Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Judah had 21 kings in 500 years (Krinsky). Hence why couldn’t the Edomites have eight kings in 193 years.</i> The truth is that king, in <i>before there reigned any king over the children of Israel</i>, refers to Moses who was king over Israel, and so it is written, <i>And there was a king in Jeshurun</i> (Deut. 33:5).

Verse 32

AND BELA THE SON OF BEOR. Bela is not to be identified with Balaam the son of Beor,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Num. 22:5. Adding a <i>mem</i> to Bela spells Baalam. Because of this and their father having the same name, some consider them to be the same. Cf. <i>Targum Jonathan</i> on this verse.</i> and neither is Baalam the son of Laban the Aramean.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbis identify Beor with Laban. Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 105a.</i> The Midrash which states that Baalam is the son of Laban is probably based on the fact that both were sorcerers<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">So Cherez. The point is that since Baalam was a sorcerer and Laban was one, too, Balaam was a “son” (spiritual not actual) of Laban. For an alternate interpretation see Krinsky.</i> because “none of the words of our sages of blessed memory ever fall to the ground.”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">A paraphrase of I Sam. 3:19.</i> We cannot identify Baalam with Bela because Bela was an Edomite and Baalam an Aramean.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">According to Cherez.</i> We are also not to identify Jobab the son of Zerah (v. 33) with Job, as Yitzchaki<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">This is the same Yitzchaki mentioned in I.E.’s comments on verse 31 (Weiser).</i> the windbag does.

Verse 33



Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36



Verse 37



Verse 38



Verse 39

MEHETABEL THE DAUGHTER OF MATRED, THE DAUGHTER OF ME-ZAHAB. This is to be explained<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture lists her as having two fathers, Metrad and Me-zahab.</i> in the same manner as we interpret <i>Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon</i> (v. 2).<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on verse 2. Metrad was her father and Me-zahab her grandfather (Krinsky).</i> On the other hand Scripture may be listing Mehetabel’s mother and father.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. does not identify which one was the father and which one the mother (Krinsky).</i>
ME-ZAHAB. This was his name.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Me-zahab is a proper name.</i> However, Saadiah Gaon says that Me-Zahab means a goldsmith.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse should thus be rendered: Mehetabel the daughter of Matred, the daughter of a goldsmith. Cf. Onkelos.</i> Others say Me-zahab alludes to those who make gold out of copper.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Me-zahab means an alchemist.</i> However, the latter is sheer nonsense.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The interpretation is nonsense (Cherez) or the belief in alchemy is nonsense (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 40

[AND THESE ARE THE NAMES OF THE CHIEFS THAT CAME OF ESAU…AFTER THEIR PLACES] This means that their territories are well-known today (in the days of Moses). These are the words of Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">That is, verses 40-43. Until now Moses reported what had been Divinely revealed to him concerning Edom’s past. In verses 40-43 he turns to his own generation and in <i>his own words</i> adds that the 11 chiefs of Edom (enumerated in verses 40-43) are now ruling each in his own territory.</i> Those now mentioned are the offspring of the chiefs mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 15-18 (Cherez).</i> Only those that had their own territories are mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">In verses 15-18, 14 chiefs are mentioned. In verses 40-43, 11 chiefs are mentioned. The names in verses 40-43 are not the same as those in 15-18. Hence I.E. points out that they were their sons. To explain why only 11 are mentioned in 40-43, I.E. posits that only those with a territory of their own are mentioned. After the death of the 14 mentioned in 15-18 their sons, mentioned in 40-43, became chiefs. Another possibility is that after the 14 mentioned above died, eight kings reigned and then the 11 mentioned in 40-43 became chiefs (Cherez). If the latter is correct, then when I.E. says that those in 40-43 are the offspring of those in 15-18 he means their descendants.</i>
TIMNA. Here it refers to a male.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Timna was the name of Eliphaz’s concubine (v. 12); hence it is a female name. However, <i>the chief of Timna</i> was a male. Hence Timna can be either a male or female name.</i> For we have many names which are used both for male and females. The same holds true for Oholibamah.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Oholibamah was the name of one of Esau’s wives (v. 2). Hence it is a female name. However, <i>the chief of Oholibamah</i> was a male.</i> It is also possible that the word chief is superfluous,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Timna is a female name and refers to Timna, Eliphaz’s concubine. The superfluous <i>chief</i> refers to the word <i>chief</i> prefixed to Alvah and Jetheth. The verse should thus be read: the chief of Timna, Alvah and Jetheth. The same applies to Oholibamah (Krinsky) or the word <i>chief</i> prefixed to Timna is superfluous. The verse should be read: Timna, the chief of Alva, the chief of Jetheth. The same applies to Oholibamah (Weiser).</i> the interpretation of <i>the chief of Timna, the chief of Alvah, the chief Jetheth</i> being, the following are the chiefs of Timna, Eliphaz’s concubine, Alvah and Jetheth. Alvah and Jetheth were chiefs of Amelek.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Timna <i>bore to Eliphaz Amalek</i> (v. 12). Hence the chiefs of Timna, Alvah and Jetheth were chiefs of Amalek.</i> There were seven chiefs of Oholibamah in the day of Moses. Each of these chiefs had his own territory. Hence Moses was explicit and added, <i>according to their habitations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Each of these chiefs had territories which bore their names and this was noted by Moses.</i>

Chapter 37



Verse 1

AND JACOB DWELT. The Bible tells us<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In the previous chapter, verse 8.</i> that the chiefs of Esau dwelt on the mountain of Seir but that Jacob dwelt in the chosen land.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The purpose of our verse is to teach us that Jacob, in contrast to Esau, dwelt in the land of Israel.</i> 

Verse 2

The meaning of <i>These are the generations of Jacob</i> is: these are the events which befell him and the incidents which came upon him. <i>Toledot</i> (generations) comes from the same root as <i>yeled</i> (bring forth) in <i>What a day may bring forth</i> (yeled) (Prov. 27:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Toledot</i> is not rendered generations but events, as evidenced by the word of the same root, <i>yod, lamed, dalet</i> in Prov. 27:1.</i>
BEING STILL A LAD, EVEN WITH THE SONS OF BILHAH, AND WITH THE SONS OF ZILPAH. The sons of the concubines (the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah) made Joseph their attendant (servant) since he was their younger brother. This was the <i>evil report of them</i> which he brought unto their father. Had the children of Leah, the mistress of the house, made Joseph their attendant, then no wrong would have been done.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph would thus not have had any <i>evil report</i> of his brothers to bring unto their father.</i> The view that <i>evil report</i> pertains to limbs torn from living animals is a Midrashic interpretation.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Midrash Joseph told his father that his brothers ate limbs torn from living animals. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 84:7.</i> That Joseph did not bring an evil report to Jacob concerning Leah’s children is clear from the fact that Scripture only mentions the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah in our verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse mentions only the sons of Zilpah and the sons of Bilhah. Hence the pronominal suffix of <i>dibbtam</i> (report of them) must refer to Zilpah and Bilhah’s sons. This comment is either a proof of what I.E. wrote above, viz., that Joseph spoke only about the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah (Krinsky), or its purpose is to negate a Midrashic statement to the effect that Joseph spoke ill only of Leah’s children, viz., that he told Jacob that Leah’s children refer to the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah as the children of slave girls (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 3

BECAUSE HE WAS THE SON OF HIS OLD AGE. This is to be taken literally since Joseph was born to Jacob when the latter was ninety-one years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph was 30 when Pharaoh appointed him vizier over Egypt. Jacob came to Egypt nine years later, after the seven years of plenty and two of famine (Gen. 45:11). At that time Jacob was 130 years old (<i>Ibid</i>., 47:9) and Joseph 39. Thus Jacob was 91 years older than Joseph (Cherez). I.E. notes that <i>ben zekunim</i> is to be taken literally, viz., son of old age, because the Midrash and Onkelos interpret it to mean a wise son. Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 84:8 and Rashi.</i> Also, Benjamin, his brother, is referred to by Scripture as <i>a child of his</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Jacob’s.</i> <i>old age</i> (Gen. 44:20). After Joseph and Benjamin no other children were born to Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Hence these two are referred to as children of his old age (Krinsky).</i>
A COAT OF MANY COLORS. <i>Ketonet passim</i> means an embroidered coat.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads: a coat made of embroidered parts. Some texts omit <i>embroidered coat</i>. According to I.E. <i>passim</i> means parts. The coat was made up of embroidered parts (strips) each of which was of a different color (Filwarg). For an alternate interpretation see Cherez.</i>
[MANY COLORS.] The word <i>passim</i> (many colors) is similar to the Aramaic word <i>pas</i> (part) in <i>part of</i> (pas) <i>a hand</i> (Dan. 5:5).

Verse 4

SPEAK UNTO HIM. <i>Dabbero</i> is to be rendered speak unto him.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Dabbero</i> is the verb <i>dabber</i> (speak) plus the pronoun <i>oto</i> (him). However, they cannot be combined since one cannot say speak him. Hence I.E.’s comment that <i>dabbero</i> should be interpreted <i>dabber lo</i> (speak to him) (Filwarg). Cherez suggests that what I.E. means is that <i>dabbero</i> is not a combination of <i>dabber oto</i> but <i>dabber immo</i> (speak with him). See notes to Gen. 34:14.</i>
[PEACEABLY.] Even peaceably.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">They did not speak to him concerning things about which they agreed (Weiser) or they did not even say how are you, to him (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

BINDING. <i>Me’allemim</i> (binding) comes from the same root as <i>alummim</i> (sheaves). The noun sheave is also found in the feminine,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Alummim</i> (sheaves) is masculine.</i> compare, <i>bearing his sheaves</i> (alummotav) (Ps. 126:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Alummotav</i> (his sheaves) is feminine.</i>
CAME ROUND ABOUT. <i>Tesubbenah</i> (came round about) comes from a root whose second and third letters are identical.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>samekh, bet, bet</i>.</i> The <i>bet</i> receives a <i>dagesh</i> to compensate for a missing <i>bet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tesubbenah</i> is spelled with one <i>bet</i>. Thus a root letter is missing. The <i>dagesh</i> doubles the letter and thus compensates for the missing letter.</i>

Verse 8

SHALT THOU INDEED REIGN OVER US? OR SHALT THOU INDEED HAVE DOMINION OVER US? Shall we set thee up as a king over us?<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">A king is chosen by the people. Hence I.E.’s comment (Krinsky).</i> Or shalt thou rule over us by force.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A ruler is not chosen, he seizes power. Hence I.E.’s comment (Krinsky).</i> 

Verse 9



Verse 10

AND HIS FATHER REBUKED HIM. When the word <i>ga’ar</i> (rebuked) is followed by a <i>bet</i> it means to rebuke.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads <i>va-yigar bo aviv</i> (and his father rebuked him). In our verse <i>ga’ar</i> thus precedes a <i>bet</i> and henceforth is to be translated as rebuked.</i> When it is not followed by a <i>bet</i> it means to destroy. Compare, <i>Behold, I will destroy</i> (go’er) <i>the seed for your hurt</i> (Mal. 2:3). On the other hand, it is possible that the word <i>go’er</i> is used metaphorically in the aforementioned verse, its meaning being God will rebuke the seed and it will become frightened and not arise out of the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">In other words the term <i>ga’ar</i> always means to rebuke.</i>
I AND THY MOTHER. Thy mother refers to Bilhah his mother’s handmaiden who raised him.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Rachel was dead by then.</i>

Verse 11

KEPT THE SAYING. In his mind. This is also the correct meaning of <i>kept</i> in <i>They kept His testimonies</i> (Ps. 99:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of Ps. 22:7 is that they kept the testimonies in mind so that they would at the appropriate time teach them to the children of Israel.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13

HERE AM I. I will do as you say.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">If Jacob called Joseph then the proper response would be here am I, as in <i>Here am I, for thou didst call me</i> (I Sam. 3:6). However, in our verse it comes as a response to Jacob’s command. Hence I.E.’s point that in our verse it has the meaning of: I am at your service (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15

AND A CERTAIN MAN FOUND HIM. According to the plain meaning of the text a passer by found him.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Midrash it was an angel. Some Midrashim identify the angel as Gabriel. Cf. <i>Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer</i>, Chap. 38; <i>Targum Jonathan</i>, and Rashi.</i>

Verse 16

WHERE THEY ARE FEEDING THE FLOCK. If you know.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>If you know</i> either is implied or was actually said by Joseph and is left out of the text, our verse being abridged. The above has to be the case because otherwise why did Joseph asssume the man knew where his brothers were keeping the sheep?</i>

Verse 17

TO DOTHAN. Dothan is spelled both with and without a <i>yod</i> in our verse. In either case it refers to one and the same place.

Verse 18

THEY CONSPIRED. <i>Va-yitnakkelu</i> (they conspired) means they had evil designs. <i>Nokhel</i> (dealeth craftily) in <i>But cursed be he that dealeth craftily</i> (nokhel) (Mal. 1:14) is similar.

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

LET US NOT TAKE HIS LIFE. Our verse is similar to<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse literally reads: <i>lo nakkennu nefesh</i> (let us not take his life) which literally means, let us not strike him life. I.E. holds that this is short for, let us not strike him (<i>lo nakkennu</i>) a mortal blow (<i>makkat nefesh</i>).</i> <i>but his minister Joshua, the son of Nun, a young man</i> (Ex. 33:11), the meaning of which is: but his minister Joshua, the son of Nun, did the ministry<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">This has to be added to the text.</i> of a young man. The aforementioned verse must be so understood because Joshua was not at that time a young man.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Thus a <i>young man</i> is short for: did the service of a young man.</i> Similarly our verse should be read as if written: let us not strike him a mortal blow thus taking his life.

Verse 22



Verse 23

THAT THEY STRIPPED. <i>Va-yafshitu</i> (that they stripped)<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yafshitu</i> is a <i>hifil. Hifil</i> is the causative form. Hence I.E. renders it: and they caused him to strip (Krinsky, Weiser and Cherez). For an alternate interpretation see Filwarg.</i> is a causative. They told him to take the coat off by himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Hence they caused him to strip.</i> <i>Ketonet</i> (coat) in Hebrew refers to a garment worn next to the skin. The brothers thus stripped Joseph of his garments and threw him naked into the pit.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">According to Cherez, I.E. interprets the verse as follows: that they stripped Joseph of his coat (<i>ketonet</i>), i.e., of the garment worn next to the skin, and also of the coat of many colors. Joseph was thus left standing naked (Cherez). Cf. Rashi. However, Cherez’s interpretation seems forced. It appears that I.E. identified the <i>ketonet passim</i> with the garment worn next to the skin.</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25

AND THEY SAT DOWN TO EAT BREAD. The nine brothers.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Neither Reuben nor Benjamin was there.</i>
A CARAVAN OF ISHMAELITES. <i>Orechat</i> is to be rendered caravan as Onkelos does. A caravan is so called because it travels on the roads (<i>orechot</i>).
SPICERY. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen the Spaniard<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">See notes to I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:26.</i> explains <i>nekhot</i> (spicery) to mean a precious thing. <i>Bet nekhoto</i> (his treasure house) in <i>and showed them all his treasure-house</i> (bet nekhoto) (II Kings 20:13) is similar. <i>Nekhot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Spelled <i>nun, caf, alef, tav</i>.</i> and <i>nekhoto</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Spelled <i>nun, caf, vav, tav</i>. The problem is that the word is not so spelled in II Kings 20:13. Krinsky and Cherez suggest that since the word is pronounced <i>nekhoto</i>, it is as if a <i>vav</i> is placed after the <i>caf</i>.</i> are similar because the <i>vav</i> and the <i>alef</i> are interchangeable since they are quiescent letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>alef</i> and <i>vav</i> in <i>nekhot</i> are not pronounced. Hence they are quiescent. I.E. refers to the <i>alef, vav, heh, yod</i> as quiescent letters (<i>otiyot ha-nach</i>) because they are not always enunciated.</i>
AND BALM. The word for balm is encountered in Scripture vocalized with a quiescent <i>sheva</i> beneath the <i>tzadi</i> (<i>utzri</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">It is so found in our verse but not so found elsewhere in Scripture. I.E.’s basic point is that balm is spelled with a <i>sheva</i> in our verse, <i>tzeri</i>. However, there is an important grammatical aside in this note. I.E. calls our <i>sheva</i> a quiescent <i>sheva</i>, a <i>sheva nach</i>. However, according to standard grammatical usage a <i>sheva</i> following a long vowel is vocal. Thus our <i>sheva</i> should be a vocal <i>sheva</i>, a <i>sheva na</i>, and not a quiescent one. Therefore our word should be read <i>u-tzeri</i> and not <i>utzri</i>. William Chomsky points out that the vocal pronunciation of the <i>sheva</i> following a long vowel was introduced by the Kimchis and that the pre-Kimchi grammarians had no such concept. I.E.’s note seems to bear this out. Cf. W. Chomsky, “The pronunciation of the Sheva,” <i>The Jewish Quarterly Review</i>, Vol. LXII, October, 1971. For an alternate interpretation see Cherez.</i> We also find it vocalized with a <i>chataf kamatz</i> beneath the <i>tzadi</i>, viz., <i>Is there no balm</i> (ha-tzori) <i>in Gilead</i>? (Jer. 8:22). It also appears with the <i>tzadi</i> vocalized with a <i>cholem</i>, viz., <i>and honey, and oil, and balm</i> (ve-tzori) (Ezek. 27:17). Saadiah Gaon explained that <i>tzeri</i> (balm)<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">He said that it is identical to an Arabic medicine called <i>triak</i> (Weiser).</i> is a mixture of 75 roots. Others say that <i>tzeri</i> is a type of fruit. Still others say that it is either a fruit or the oil of a tree<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Balsam (Weiser).</i> that, according to Joseph ben Gurion,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Jossipon. A medieval work based on Josephus.</i> was brought from Jericho to Egypt. However, Rabbi Ishmael<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Kritot</i> 6a; <i>Shabbat</i> 26a. However, in the Talmud this opinion is quoted in the name of Rabbi Simeon. Either there is a scribal error in our text or I.E. was quoting from memory.</i> says that it means resin. We will rely on the latter opinion.
AND LADANUM. Saadiah Gaon says that <i>lot</i> (ladanum) is the same fruit that in Arabic is similarly called with the addition of a <i>bet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Belut</i> (Weiser).</i> Perhaps it is so.

Verse 26

WHAT PROFIT. <i>Mah betza</i> means what profit. <i>Betza</i> (profit) is close in meaning to <i>chefetz</i> (desire). <i>What profit</i> (betza) <i>is there in my blood</i> (Ps. 30:10) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Ps. 30:10 continues, <i>Shall the dust praise Thee? Shall it declare Thy truth</i>? Hence what desire (<i>mah betza</i>) is there in my death? Similarly the meaning of <i>mah betza</i> in our verse is: what desire is there in slaying our brother.</i>

Verse 27

HE IS OUR BROTHER OUR FLESH. He is as our flesh<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">They obviously were not all one flesh. Hence what Judah meant was: he is as our flesh, even though he did not use the word as (Weiser).</i> since we all came from one flesh.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">We all come from the same parents who became one flesh, as in I.E.’s comment on Gen. 2:22 (Weiser). However, they did not all have the same mother. Therefore the interpretation must be as follows: we all came from the same father.</i>

Verse 28

AND THERE PASSED BY. When the Ishmaelite merchantmen passed by them.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>vav</i> of <i>va-ya’avru</i> (and there passed by) is to be rendered when rather than and. The meaning of the verse is: when the Midianite (Ishmaelite) merchantmen passed by, they drew and lifted Joseph out of the pit (Krinsky). I.E.’s point is that the Midianites in our verse refers to the caravan of Ishmaelites of verse 25. Thus <i>va-ya’avru</i> does not introduce new material. Hence I.E.’s paraphrase: when, etc. (Filwarg).</i> Scripture refers to the Ishmaelites as Midianites because the Midianites are called Ishmaelites. The Book of Judges similarly says concerning the kings of Midian, <i>because they were Ishmaelites</i> (Jud. 8:24).

Verse 29



Verse 30

AND AS FOR ME, WHITHER SHALL I GO? <i>Ani</i> (I) is used twice in this clause<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: And I, whither shall I go.</i> even though one <i>ani</i> would have sufficed.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture could have read: and whither shall I go.</i> The latter is in keeping with Hebrew style.

Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

WITHOUT DOUBT TORN IN PIECES. <i>Toraf</i> (torn) is a <i>pu’al</i>. The <i>tet</i> is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i><sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than a <i>kubbutz</i> as is the rule in the <i>pu’al</i>. Hence the reading <i>toraf</i> rather than <i>turaf</i>.</i> because it precedes a <i>resh</i> which cannot receive a <i>dagesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">All middle root letters in the <i>pu’al</i> receive a <i>dagesh</i>. However, the <i>resh</i> cannot receive a <i>dagesh</i>; thus the preceding vowel changes from a <i>kubbutz</i> to a <i>cholam</i>.</i> <i>Morak</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">It, too, is a <i>pu’al</i>, and because the middle letter is a <i>resh</i> the preceding letter is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>.</i> (scoured) in <i>it shall be scoured</i> (u-morek), <i>and rinsed in water</i> (Lev. 6:21) is similar.

Verse 34



Verse 35

AND HIS FATHER WEPT FOR HIM. Our sages interpreted this as referring to Isaac.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 84:19. According to the Midrash <i>his father</i> refers to Jacob’s father. Isaac was overcome with grief over Jacob’s trouble.</i> The truth is that Isaac did not die until Joseph reached the age of twenty-nine.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Thus from this point of view the Midrashic interpretation is possible. I.E.’s accounting is as follows: Isaac was 60 when Jacob was born (Gen. 25:26). Jacob was 91 when Joseph was born (see note 7). Thus Isaac was 151 when Joseph was born. Isaac died at the age of 180 (Gen. 35:28), at which time Joseph was 29 years old as Isaac was 151 years older than Joseph. Joseph was 17 when he was sold. Thus Isaac lived 12 years past the year in which Joseph was sold (Weiser).</i> Some say that the prophetic spirit was removed from both Jacob and Isaac because of their mourning.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The question arises, why didn’t Jacob and Isaac, two prophets, know that Joseph was alive?</i> They offer proof from Elisha.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">That a prophet cannot prophesy when in a state of depression. Cf. II Kings 3:15. Before Elisha, who was then depressed (see Kimchi, <i>ad hoc</i>), prophesied he said, <i>But now bring me a minstrel. And it came to pass, when the minstrel played that the hand of the Lord came upon him</i>.</i>
AND ALL HIS DAUGHTERS. His daughter and granddaughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Dinah his daughter and Sarah the daughter of Asher, as grandchildren are considered children. I.E. comments so because Jacob had only one daughter.</i>
[TO THE GRAVE.] <i>She’olah</i> means down below, i.e., to the grave. Here the one who translated the Bible for those who err<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Jerome who translated the Bible into Latin for the Christians.</i> erred in translating <i>she’olah</i> as to hell.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Jerome renders <i>she’ol</i> as inferno. However, see Rashi who writes, “The Midrashic interpretation of <i>she’ol</i> is gehenna.”</i> Proof of his mistranslation is, <i>For the nether-world</i> (she’ol) <i>cannot praise Thee…They that go down into the pit cannot hope for Thy truth</i> (Is. 38:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In this verse pit is parallel to <i>she’ol. She’ol</i> thus must mean pit.</i> Also in Ps. 139:8, heaven is the antithesis of <i>she’ol</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>she’ol</i> is the opposite of heaven (sky); it refers to a place on the earth, i.e., the grave.</i> viz., <i>If I ascend up into heaven, Thou art there; If I make my bed in the nether-world</i> (she’ol) <i>behold Thou art there</i>. Similarly Job states, <i>The nether-world</i> (she’ol) <i>is naked before Him</i> (Job 26:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The verse concludes, <i>And destruction (the grave) hath no covering</i>. Now <i>she’ol</i> is parallel to destruction (grave). Hence it, too, must mean grave.</i> There are many other verses which prove that <i>she’ol</i> does not refer to hell.

Verse 36

THE CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD. The term <i>tabbach</i> (guard) is used both with reference to killing<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Dan. 2:14, <i>The captain of the king’s guard</i> (rav tabbachyya) <i>who was gone forth to slay the wise men of Babylon</i>.</i> and with reference to cooking.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I Sam. 9:24 where the term <i>tabbach</i> means cook, viz., <i>And the cook</i> (ha-tabbach) <i>took up the thigh</i>.</i> Onkelos’ rendition is correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders <i>sar ha-tabbachim</i> as the chief executioner.</i>

Chapter 38



Verse 1

AND IT CAME TO PASS AT THAT TIME. This does not refer to the time that Joseph was sold.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">As the sequence of chapters would tend to indicate.</i> It refers to the events that happened prior to that time. <i>From thence they journeyed unto Gudgod…At that time the Lord separated the tribe of Levi, to bear the ark of the covenant of the Lord, to stand before the Lord to minister unto Him, and to bless in His name, unto this day</i> (Deut. 10:7, 8) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The two events described in the latter verse did not take place at the same time even though Deut. 10:8 says, <i>At that time</i>.</i> The tribe of Levi was chosen to minister unto the Lord in the second year while Israel journeyed to Gudgod in the fortieth year.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Following the Exodus.</i> I will explain the latter verses in their proper place. Why, then, did Scripture insert this chapter (Chap. 38) at this point when logic dictates that <i>And Joseph was brought down to Egypt</i> (Gen. 39:1) should follow <i>And the Midianites sold him (Joseph) into Egypt</i> (Gen. 37:36)?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Chap. 39 should follow Chap. 37.</i> The Bible placed this chapter (38) here to contrast the behavior of Joseph vis-a-vis his master’s wife with that of Judah toward his daughter-in-law.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph controlled his passions. When Potiphar’s wife said to him, <i>Lie with me</i> (Gen. 39:7) he refused. On the other hand when Judah saw the harlot in the entrance to Enaim he said to her, <i>Come, I pray thee, let me come in unto thee</i> (Gen. 38:16).</i> What forced me to offer this interpretation is the fact that only twenty-two years passed between the sale of Joseph and the descent of our ancestors into Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph was 17 when sold. He was 30 when appointed vizier over Egypt. Jacob came to Egypt after seven years of plenty and two of hunger passed. Thus a total of 22 years passed from the sale of Joseph to Jacob’s descent into Egypt (Cherez). It is impossible for the events described in Chap. 38 to have occurred in such a short time.</i> Now we learn in this chapter of the birth of Onan, Judah’s second son,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that not only does Scripture tell of the birth of Er, the eldest son of Judah, it also tells of the birth of and marriage of his second son, Onan, as well. Er was at least close to a year older than Onan. Thus at least 13 years had to pass between the sale of Joseph and the marriage of Onan and Tamar.</i> and his reaching the age of procreation, which at the very earliest starts at the age of 12. Scripture goes on to state, <i>And in the process of time</i> (v. 12).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads, <i>and the days became many</i>.
