That is, following Onan’s death Tamar, his widow, dwelt in her father’s house for a long time.</i> The chapter then tells us that Tamar conceived and gave birth to Perez. This same Perez came to Egypt with two sons of his own (Gen. 46:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">We thus have to allow at least 13 years for the birth and marriage of Onan. We have to allow for the years that Tamar spent in her father’s house. We have to allow 12 years for Perez’s coming of age and two each for the birth of his sons. All of this could not have happened in 22 years, even assuming the above minimum figures.</i> Do not be disturbed by the question of Bezalel,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Talmud the early generations produced children at the age of eight. If this is the case then it is possible for all of the above to have taken place in 22 years: namely, Er was married in the ninth year after Joseph’s sale. A year later Onan married. Tamar then stayed for many days in her father’s house. We can interpret many days to mean a year. Eight years later Perez gave birth to a son and a year later to a second one. Thus it is possible for all that is reported in Chap. 38 to have taken place between the sale of Joseph and the descent into Egypt.<br>The Talmud concludes from the account of Bezalel that the early generations had children at the age of eight We read in <i>Sanhedrin</i> 69b: “Whence do we know that the first generations produced children at eight years? This is to be inferred from the following: <i>Bezalel the son of Uri, the son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah</i> (Ex. 35:30), and it is written:..<i>And Caleb (the son of Hezron) took unto him Ephrath, who bore him Hur. And Hur begot Uri, and Uri begot Bezalel</i> (I Chron. 2:19, 20). When Bezalel was engaged in building the Tabernacle he was at least 13 years old as it is written, <i>came every man from his work which they wrought</i> (Ex. 36:4) and one is not called a man before the age of 13. And there is a Baraitha which states: The first year Moses prepared all that was necessary for the Tabernacle, and in the second year he erected it and sent the spies. And it is written: <i>And Caleb the son of Jephunneh said…Forty years old was I when Moses the servant of the Lord sent me from Kadesh-barnea</i> (Josh. 14:6, 7) Now deduct 14, the age of Bezalel, from the age of Caleb when he was sent as a spy and there remains 26. Deduct two years for the three pregnancies with Uri and Hur and Bezalel, and there remains 24. Hence each of them produced children at the age of 8.” It should be noted that the above is based on identifying Caleb ben Hezron (I Chron. 2:18-20) as Caleb ben Jephunneh (Josh. 14:6, 7). However, according to I.E. these two Calebs were not the same. Hence, the entire Talmudic passage quoted above is Aggadic and not in keeping with the plain meaning of the text.</i> for I will explain it when I come to it.

Verse 2

A CERTAIN CANAANITE. Some say that <i>kena’ani</i> (Canaanite) means a merchant,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The commentators were bothered by Judah marrying a Canaanite woman. Hence their interpretation.</i> as in <i>As for the trafficker</i> (kena’an), <i>the balances of deceit are in his hand</i> (Hos. 12:8) and in, <i>and in that day there shall be no more a trafficker</i> (kena’ani) <i>in the house of the Lord of Hosts</i> (Zech. 14:21), wherein the word trafficker is spelled with a <i>yod</i> as in our verse. However, it is possible that the word <i>kena’ani</i> is to be taken literally.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">It means a Canaanite.</i> Our sages said, <i>that Judah went down</i> (v. 1) means that Judah was demoted from his leadership.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">He thus went down from his exalted position. Cf. <i>Soteh</i> 13b.</i> However, this is a Midrashic interpretation. The Bible says that Judah went down because whoever goes from north to south is going down.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">North is above south. I.E. was of the opinion that Jacob and his family dwelt north of Adullam (Weiser).</i> Those acquainted with science will understand that what I say is correct.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

AT CHEZIB. Chezib is the name of a place.

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

AND PERFORM THE DUTY OF A HUSBAND’S BROTHER UNTO HER. This means, since you are her husband’s brother, show yourself to be a husband’s brother<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>ve-yabbem</i> (and perform the duty of a husband’s brother). A brother-in-law is called a <i>yavam</i>. <i>Yabbem</i> is its verbal form. It does not make sense to translate <i>ve-yabbem</i>, and be a husband’s brother, when in fact he is a husband’s brother. Thus <i>ve-yabbem</i> has to be rendered, show yourself to be a husband’s brother (Filwarg).</i> by going <i>unto thy brother’s wife</i>. I will expound a little on levirate marriage when I come to the portion, <i>If brethren dwell together</i> (Deut. 25:5), if God prolongs my life till then.

Verse 9

THAT THE SEED WOULD NOT BE HIS. The seed would not be called by his name,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The child would be called the son of Er (Krinsky).</i> as we find in <i>And it shall be, that the first-born that she beareth shall succeed in the name of his brother that is dead</i> (Deut. 25:6).
THAT HE SPILLED IT ON THE GROUND. He destroyed<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: <i>ve-shichet</i> (and he destroyed) <i>artzah</i> (to the ground). I.E. interprets this to mean he destroyed his semen by pouring it on the ground.</i> the seed of his semen by pouring it outside of the vagina, on the ground. I am shocked by Ben Tamim Ha-Mizrachi<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Adoniyahu ben Tamim Ha-Mizrachi, a grammarian and Bible commentator who lived in Iraq. He is also mentioned by I.E. in Eccles. 12:5.</i> who interpreted <i>ve-shichet artzah</i> (that he spilled it on the ground) to mean that Onan had unnatural intercourse with Tamar so that she would not conceive.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">He had anal intercourse with her.</i> Onan thus <i>shichet artzah</i> (corrupted her ground),<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Ben Tamim renders, <i>ve-shichet artzah</i>, he dealt corruptly with her ground.</i> i.e., the place upon which she sits on the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Ground is a euphemism for anus (Weiser).</i> This interpretation is sheer madness.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Artzah</i> means toward the ground. If there was a <i>mappik</i> in the <i>heh</i> it would mean her ground. But there is no such <i>mappik</i> in the <i>heh</i> (Krinsky).</i> Heaven forbid that the holy seed become defiled with such filth.
GIVE SEED. <i>Neton</i> (give) is here conjugated according to the paradigm of a regular verb.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>neton</i> is <i>nun, tav, nun</i>. In the infinitive the first and last <i>nuns</i> are usually dropped; i.e., the infinitive of this root is <i>tet</i>, as in Gen. 4:12. However, in <i>neton</i> the <i>nuns</i> are present. Hence in this case the root <i>nun, tav, nun</i> is conjugated as a <i>shelamim</i>, a regular verb.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

REMAIN A WIDOW IN THY FATHER’S HOUSE. The prepositional <i>bet</i> has been omitted from before the <i>bet</i> of the word <i>house</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse literally reads: Remain a widow, your father’s house. I.E. points out that the prepositional <i>bet</i> is omitted from before the word <i>bet</i> (house) and has to be supplied by the reader. Thus <i>bet</i> (house of) had to be read as if written <i>be-vet</i> (in the house of).</i> We find the same type of omission in <i>that was found in the house</i> (bet) <i>of the Lord</i> (II Kings 18:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: that was found house of the Lord. Here, too, the prepositional <i>bet</i> has to be supplied by the reader and the word to be read as if written <i>be-vet</i>.</i>

Verse 12

AND JUDAH WAS COMFORTED. After Judah received condolences<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. apparently explains comforted in a technical rather than an emotional sense. Following his wife’s burial Judah’s friends expressed condolences and comforted him. Judah was thus comforted.</i> for his wife’s death he <i>went up unto</i> (al) <i>his sheep shearers.</i> 
<i>Al</i> is to be understood as <i>el</i> (unto).<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Al</i> means on. Our verse literally reads: And went up on (<i>al</i>) his sheep-shearers, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

AND COVERED HERSELF. <i>Ve-tekhas</i> is a transitive verb. It means and covered herself.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">An intransitive verb is not followed by the object. In our verse <i>va-tekhas</i> (covered) is not followed by the object. I.E. points out that even though <i>va-tekhas</i> is not followed by the object it is transitive and the object has to be supplied by the reader, i.e., translate <i>va-tekhas</i>, and she covered herself.</i>
AND WRAPPED HERSELF. The meaning of <i>va-titallaf</i> (she wrapped herself) is she hid her face. <i>Va-yitallaf</i> (Jonah 4:8) is similar. Its meaning is, Jonah hid his face in his garments. Similar in meaning both to our verse and Jon. (4:8) is the word <i>me’ullefet</i> (overlaid) in <i>Overlaid</i> (me’ullefet) <i>with sapphires</i> (Cant. 5:14).
IN THE ENTRANCE OF ENAIM. Enaim is the name of a place. Others say that there were two springs with a door-like entrance on the road which Judah had to pass on his return to his home.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>enaim</i> is the plural of <i>ayin</i> (a spring) and <i>petach enayim</i> should thus be rendered: at the entrance of the wells.</i>

Verse 15

FOR SHE HAD COVERED HER FACE. This explains the meaning of <i>va-titallaf</i> (and wrapped herself) (v. 14).<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">We can ascertain that the meaning of <i>va-titallaf</i> means to cover the face from our clause, as it is the manner of Scripture to explain later a previously used term (Weiser).</i> Someone who explains <i>for she had covered her face</i> to mean that she covered her face with a variety of colored cosmetics and brought proof of this from his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">She wore cosmetics (Filwarg). His daughter put so much cosmetics on her face that she was unrecognizable. Tamar acted similarly.</i> is speaking nonsense, for one ought not to offer proof from fools.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">If she put on so much make up that she was unrecognizable then she was a fool and one is not to bring proof from her.</i> That which our sages say concerning Tamar’s chastity in her father-in-law’s house is also correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sotah</i> 10b: “She covered herself in her father-in-law’s house.” Judah thus had never seen her face and therefore could not now recognize her (Nahmanides).</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

THY SIGNET. Because of Judah’s great lust he gave three objects as a pledge for something insignificant. I will explain the meaning of <i>kedeshah</i> (harlot) (v. 21) in my comments on <i>There shall be no harlot</i> (kedeshah) <i>of the daughters of Israel, neither shall there be a sodomite</i> (kadesh) <i>of the sons of Israel</i> (Deut. 23:18).

Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

LET HER TAKE IT. Forget about her and let her keep the pledge.
LEST WE BE PUT TO SHAME. Lest I be a laughing stock, for giving a signet, cord and staff for something so insignificant.
[BEHOLD, I SENT THIS KID, AND THOU HAST NOT FOUND HER.] This is a sign that she wants to keep the pledge.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Her not making herself available for payment is a sign that she intends to keep the pledge.</i>

Verse 24

ABOUT THREE MONTHS LATER. When one speaks of three months a <i>mem</i> is prefixed to the word three.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the term <i>mishlosh</i> (three months) in our verse.</i> When one speaks of three days a <i>mem</i> is suffixed to the word three.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the term <i>shilshom</i> (three days ago) (Cherez). The Hebrew word for three is <i>shalosh</i>.</i>

Verse 25

WHEN SHE WAS BROUGHT FORTH. If the <i>alef</i> of <i>mutzet</i> was not quiescent as is the grammatical rule, the word would have followed the paradigm of <i>muda’at</i> (made known) in <i>This is made known</i> (muda’at) (Is. 12:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">If a <i>chet</i> or <i>ayin</i> would have been used then our word would be so vocalized since it is a <i>hofal</i> participle. The <i>alef</i> is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> because it is a quiescent letter (Cherez).</i>

Verse 26

FORASMUCH AS I GAVE HER NOT. The expression <i>ki al ken</i> (for as much) has the same meaning as the Rabbinic term <i>ho’il</i> (since), as in <i>forasmuch</i> (ki al ken) <i>as I have seen thy face</i> (Gen. 33:10). The meaning of our clause is: since I gave her not to Shelah my son. Or its meaning is, she did this because I gave her not to Shelah my son.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, the words <i>she did this because</i> are missing from the text. The verse should be read as if written <i>ki al ken asetah zot ki</i>, for therefore she did this thing because, etc. According to this interpretation, <i>ki al ken</i> has the meaning <i>for therefore</i> i.e., it is an idiom pleonastically emphasizing the ground for an action.</i>
AND HE KNEW HER AGAIN NO MORE. He did not sleep with her again.

Verse 27



Verse 28

THAT ONE PUT OUT A HAND. One of them put out a hand. The latter is not identified by name because he was not yet named. This birth, too,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">As the birth of Jacob and Esau were.</i> was out of the ordinary in that both placentas opened simultaneously and when this one drew back his hand, his brother came out.

Verse 29

WHEREFORE HAST THOU MADE A BREACH. <i>Mah paratzta, alekhah paretz</i> means, wherefore hast thou acted like a man who breaches a fence and goes through it. You are now responsible for the breach.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">“You are responsible for the breach” means that should any harm befall your twin because of your audacity you will bear responsibility (Krinsky).</i> Others say that <i>paratzta</i> is the same as <i>u-faratzta</i> (and thou shalt spread abroad) (Gen. 28:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of <i>mah paratzta, alekhah paretz</i> (wherefore hast thou made a breach for thyself) being, wherefore hast thou spread abroad, indeed thou wilt spread abroad (Filwarg).</i> Saadiah Gaon explains that <i>paratzta</i> is to be interpreted literally as meaning to make a breach but that <i>paretz</i> in <i>alekhah paretz</i> has the same meaning as <i>va-yifrotz</i> (it hath increased) in <i>and hath increased</i> (va-yifrotz) <i>abundantly</i> (Gen. 30:30).<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">According to Saadiah, the meaning of <i>mah paratzta, alekhah paretz</i> is, wherefore has thou made a breach, indeed thou wilt increase (Filwarg).</i>

Chapter 39



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

HE KNEW NOT AUGHT SAVE THE BREAD WHICH HE DID EAT. Some say that <i>the bread which he did eat</i> is a euphemism for a conjugal relationship.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi.</i> However, this interpretation is far-fetched. Furthermore, Potiphar was a eunuch.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. verse 1, <i>Potiphar seris paroh</i>. I.E. interprets <i>seris paroh</i> (an officer of Pharaoh) as Pharaoh’s eunuch. If he was a eunuch then <i>the bread which he did eat</i> obviously cannot refer to sexual intercourse.</i> I believe that what this verse says is that Potiphar put Joseph in charge of everything that he had except for his bread, which Joseph was not permitted even to touch because he was a Hebrew, as we see from the verse <i>because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews; for that is an abomination unto the Egyptians</i> (Gen. 43:32). Potiphar knew that Joseph was a Hebrew. Potiphar’s wife similarly said, <i>See, he hath brought in a Hebrew unto us to mock us</i> (v. 14).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Which proves that his master knew that Joseph was a Hebrew.</i>
AND JOSEPH WAS OF BEAUTIFUL FORM. Like his mother.

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

[TO LIE BY HER.] To just lie next to her,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">That is, just to lie next to her, “to lie next to her while both are fully clothed” (Nahmanides).</i> or <i>to be with her</i>, to converse with her.

Verse 11

AND IT CAME TO PASS ON A CERTAIN DAY. On the same day that she had first asked him to lay with her.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: And a day like this came to pass, i.e., a day like the one described above, that is, the day that she said, “lie with me.”</i> It was on this same day a week later, or a month later or a full year later. The latter appears correct to me.
TO DO HIS WORK. To supervise the housework or to oversee his master’s wealth, for Joseph was in charge of everything. The Midrash pertaining to <i>and there was none of the men</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: and there was no man. According to <i>Tanchuma, Va-yeshev</i>, 9, Joseph wanted to have intercourse with Potiphar’s wife but found himself impotent (Weiser and Krinsky according to one interpretation). Or the reference may be to <i>Soteh</i> 36b, that he wanted to have intercourse with Potiphar’s wife but his father’s image appeared before him and as a result Joseph refrained from sinning. Thus <i>and there was none of the men of the house there within</i> but his father’s image was there.</i> is an individual opinion.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it is not binding.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

HE HATH BROUGHT UNTO US. That is, my husband.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse is short for: my husband hath brought unto us (Weiser).</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

THAT HIS WRATH WAS KINDLED. Potiphar nevertheless did not kill Joseph because he wasn’t certain as to the truth of his wife’s accusation.

Verse 20



Verse 21

PRISON. We can not ascertain whether <i>bet ha-sohar</i> (the prison) is a Hebrew or Egyptian word in view of the fact that the Bible goes on to explain its meaning<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Were it a Hebrew word there would be no reason to explain <i>the place where the King’s prisoners were bound</i>.</i> as it does with the Persian word <i>ha-achashteranim</i> (that were used in the King’s service) which is followed by the Hebrew <i>bene ha-rammakhim</i> (bred of the stud)<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>bene ha-rammakhim</i> is Hebrew for <i>achashteranim</i>.</i> (Est. 8:10).

Verse 22

AND WHATSOEVER THEY DID THERE, HE WAS THE DOER OF IT. Some interpret this to mean that Joseph, like all the other prisoners, was engaged in work to support himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">That is, whatever they did he did.</i> However, I believe that the meaning of our verse is: and whatsoever they had to do there he was, as it were, the doer of it, because he was their supervisor. The next verse bears out the latter interpretation.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 relates that <i>the keeper of the prison looked not to anything that was under his hand</i>, which implies that Joseph did not actually do any work, but supervised the others.</i>

Chapter 40



Verse 1

OFFENDED. They committed an offense (<i>chet</i>) in a matter of state.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">According to Cherez. Weiser suggests rendering: They committed an offense punishable by the state.</i> 

Verse 2

The fact that the <i>samekh</i> of <i>sarisav</i> (his officers) retains its <i>kamatz</i> is proof that the <i>resh</i> of <i>saris</i> (officer) should have received a <i>dagesh</i>, and since it cannot the <i>samekh</i> was vocalized with a long <i>kamatz</i> to compensate for the missing <i>dagesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Words vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> beneath their first letter in the singular are vocalized with a <i>sheva</i> under their first letter in the plural; i.e., <i>nagid</i> becomes <i>negidim</i>. <i>Saris</i> does not follow this rule. Its plural is <i>sarisim</i>, not <i>serisim</i>. Hence the word presents a problem. I.E. suggests that <i>saris</i> belongs to the group of nouns vocalized <i>pattach-chirik</i>. The latter retain their <i>pattach</i> in the plural; i.e., <i>kabbir</i> becomes <i>kabbirim</i>. I.E. points out that <i>saris</i> should have been vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> beneath the <i>samekh</i> but due to the fact that a <i>resh</i> cannot receive a <i>dagesh</i> (a <i>dagesh</i> usually follows a <i>pattach</i>), the <i>samekh</i> was vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> to compensate for the missing <i>dagesh</i>. Hence <i>saris</i> retains its <i>kamatz</i> in the plural.</i>

Verse 3

AND HE PUT THEM IN WARD IN THE HOUSE OF THE CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD. A place where they would be guarded so they would not escape.

Verse 4

AND THE CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD CHARGED. When these two officers were put in a ward in the house of the captain of the guard, the latter remembered (<i>pakad</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In this interpretation <i>va-yifkod</i> (charged) is translated as remembered. Thus according to this interpretation, <i>And the captain of the guard charged</i> (va-yifkod) <i>Joseph</i> is to be rendered: And the captain of the guard remembered (<i>va-yifkod</i>) Joseph.</i> Joseph; i.e., he recalled his abilities<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">He remembered that Joseph was able to relate to nobles (Weiser). Filwarg interprets: remembered the Jospeh episode, i.e., that Joseph, like the butler and the baker, offended his master. Krinsky explains: he remembered Joseph’s words protesting his innocence and decided to place him in a prison whose conditions were better. The Hebrew reading of I.E. is <i>zakhar devarav</i>.</i> and brought him to his house<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation Joseph was originally in a different prison and was now brought to the one in the home of the captain of the guard.</i> and placed him in a dungeon<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. verse 15.</i> which is the ward spoken of in our verse. The latter is the opinion of the great grammarian.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Jonah Ibn Janah.</i> However, I believe that the prison was in the house of the captain of the guard and Joseph was there to begin with. Proof of this is Scripture’s explicit statement, <i>And he put them…into the prison, the place where Joseph was bound</i>. What our verse relates is that the captain of the guard commanded (charged)<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. so translates <i>va-yifkod</i> as charged.</i> Joseph to be with the butler and baker and serve them because they had high status in Pharaoh’s palace insomuch as they were officers of the king.

Verse 5

AND THEY DREAMED. The meaning<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Reading <i>ta’am</i> rather than <i>ke-ta’am</i> (Filwarg, Krinsky). The aforementioned is borne out by <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 which reads, <i>ve-ta’am</i>.</i> of <i>each man according to the interpretation of his dream</i> is that each one of them saw in his dream details that could be interpreted to foretell what would happen in the future.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">There was no part of the dream that did not allude to something. There was no nonsensical part in the dream. Every part of the dream had a meaning and was interpretable (Filwarg based on the reading of I.E. quoted by Nahmanides which is borne out by <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38). Our printed texts read, “Each one saw the interpretation of the dream and what happened to him” The problem with this reading is, if they saw the interpretation of their dream in their nocturnal vision why, then, did they turn to Joseph for its interpretation? Hence we have translated according to <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38.</i>

Verse 6

SAD. <i>Zo’afim</i> (sad) means agitated, as is the meaning of the word <i>zapo</i> (its rage) in <i>and the sea ceased from its raging</i> (mi-zapo) (Jon. 1:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Both words come from the same root.</i>
AND JOSEPH CAME IN UNTO THEM. It is possible that Joseph used to sleep in the dungeon at night.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The prison had a number of levels. Joseph’s quarters were in the lowest. He spent his nights in the dungeon and his days with the other prisoners (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

[DO NOT INTERPRETATIONS BELONG TO GOD.] Its meaning is that the interpretations of dreams belong to the Lord because He knows the future. He has revealed what is going to come to pass in a dream to one whom He selected and it therefore makes no difference whether I interpret the dream for good or ill. Since this is so, and all interpretations belong to God, do not be concerned about telling me your dreams.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The point is, only God knows the future and what He knows will come to pass. Hence my interpretation can in no way influence the outcome of your dream. What will be, will be.</i> The Rabbinic statement that all dreams follow the interpretation is the opinion of an individual sage.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Elazar in <i>Berakhot</i> 55b. According to the latter a dream’s meaning depends on its interpretation. This contradicts I.E. Hence, I.E. says that Rabbi Elazar’s opinion is not binding.</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10

ITS BLOSSOMS SHOT FORTH. <i>Nitzah</i> (its blossoms) is the same as <i>henetzu</i> (be in flower) in <i>And the pomegranates be in flower</i> (hanetzu) (Cant. 7:13).
AND THE CLUSTERS THEREOF BROUGHT FORTH RIPE GRAPES. <i>Hivshilu</i> (brought forth ripe) is the oppposite of <i>boser</i> (sour grapes).<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. could not find a synonym for ripe. The only way he could define it was by contrasting it with its opposite.</i> <i>Bashal</i> (is ripe) in <i>For the harvest is ripe</i> (bashal) (Joel 4:13) is similar. The two words are similar even though <i>hivshilu</i> in our verse and <i>bashal</i> belong to different conjugational paradigms.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hivshilu</i> is in the <i>hifil, bashal</i> is in the <i>kal</i>. Both mean ripened.</i>

Verse 11

AND PRESSED THEM. <i>Va-eschat</i> (pressed) is similar to <i>shochate</i> (slay) in <i>That slay</i> (shochate) <i>the children in the valleys</i> (Is. 57:5). Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation of <i>va-eschat</i> is wrong.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">This is a very difficult comment to unravel. The most acceptable interpretation is offered by Filwarg. According to Filwarg, I.E. maintains that <i>va-eschat</i> does not mean to press or squeeze as Saadiah Gaon says (this interpretation is accepted by J.P.S. and all others) since the word is not found elsewhere in the Bible. The word <i>sachat</i>, meaning to squeeze, is found in Rabbinic literature, but there it is spelled with a <i>samakh</i> and not with a <i>sin</i>. I.E. notes that the word <i>shachat</i> spelled with a <i>shin</i> or <i>sachat</i> spelled with a <i>sin</i> as in our verse means the same, to cut, hence to slay by cutting the throat. Thus our verse should be rendered: And I cut the grape so that its juice ran. It is also possible that in I.E.’s copy of Isaiah <i>shochate</i> was spelled with a <i>sin</i>, i.e., he read <i>sochate</i>, and what I.E. is doing is noting that <i>va-eschat</i> is like <i>sochate</i>. For additional interpretations see Cherez and Weiser.</i>

Verse 12

THE INTERPRETATION OF IT. <i>Pitrono</i> (the interpretation of it) means its explanation. The term <i>pitrono</i> is not found in Scripture except in reference to a dream.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it means the interpretation of a dream. It cannot he used in any other context (Cherez).</i> 
Some ask, how did Joseph know that the three branches refer to three days and not to three months or three years? Because <i>yom hulledet et paroh</i> (v. 20)<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Translated according to Filwarg, Weiser and Cherez. According to Krinsky the question raised in I.E. is not answered. The way Krinsky read I.E. is: I.E. asks, “How did Joseph know that the three branches refer to three days?” He then goes on to explain the meaning of the clause <i>yom hulledet et paroh</i>.</i> possibly means the day on which Pharaoh was born.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph knew that Pharaoh’s birthday would be in three days and it was obvious to him that the branches referred to this festive event (Filwarg, Weiser, Cherez).</i> For today there are kings who make a party on their birthday and invite their servants and distribute gifts to them. It is also possible that the queen was pregnant.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">And that <i>yom hulledet et paroh</i> means the day that a child was born to Pharaoh. It was known that the queen was in her ninth month and Joseph reasoned that the “three branches” referred to the days left till she delivered.</i> The first interpretation appeals to me.

Verse 13

SHALL PHARAOH LIFT UP THY HEAD. <i>Yissa</i> means shall lift up.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Pharaoh will raise the chief butler from his fallen state.</i> In its correct sense, <i>yissa</i> means to lift up by counting. <sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See note 25.</i> Proof of this is Scripture stating, <i>and he lifted up</i> (va-yissa) <i>the head of the chief butler and the head of the chief baker among his servants</i> (v. 20).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Here the term <i>va-yissa</i> must mean and he counted because Pharaoh did not exalt the chief baker.</i> I will explain this term in my comments on the Torah portion <i>Ki Tissa</i> (Ex. 30:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In his short commentary on Ex. 30:12, I.E. points out that one who counts people lists them in a row and places the most important at the top. Thus when Pharaoh will count his servants he will have a list of his butlers and bakers made. The name of the chief butler will head the list of butlers and that of the baker the list of bakers. Thus to “lift up” means to count. However, it does so only in a specific sense. It is not a mere synonym for counting. It should be noted that some commmentaries maintain that I.E. is of the opinion that to lift up is another way of saying to count. Cf. Krinsky and Cherez.</i>
THINE OFFICE. <i>Kannekha</i> means thy previous station, thy place,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Hebrew <i>mekhunatekha</i>. Compare, <i>mekhunatah</i> in Zech. 5:11.</i> thy state.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Hebrew <i>matkuntekha</i>. Compare, <i>matkunto</i> in II Chron. 24:13. I.E. is saying is that <i>kannekha</i> (thine office) is similar to <i>mekhunatah</i> and <i>matkunto</i>. However, I.E. changes the pronominal suffixes.</i> <i>Kannekha</i> most likely comes from the same root as <i>ken</i> (a base, a pedestal) (I Kings 7:29). The word <i>kanno</i> (in his place) in <i>Then shall stand up in his place</i> (kanno) (Dan. 11:20) is analogous.

Verse 14



Verse 15

OUT OF THE LAND OF THE HEBREWS. I will explain this in my comments on <i>If thou buy a Hebrew servant</i> (Ex. 21:2). When the term <i>hinneh</i> (behold) is found in Scripture following a dream, its meaning is <i>as it were</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hinneh</i> (behold) applies to something real. However, when used to describe what one saw in a dream it means: as it were, as if. Cf. Gen. 28:12; 37:7-10; 41:2-6, 18-23.</i>

Verse 16

THREE BASKETS OF WHITE BREAD. Saadiah Gaon says that <i>chori</i> means white bread, as in <i>the nobles</i> (chore)<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comment on Gen. 36:20 where he writes, “Nobles are called <i>chorim</i> (literally, the white ones) because they are metaphorically speaking as the color white which resembles light.”</i> <i>of Judah</i> (Neh. 6:17).

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

WITHIN YET. <i>Be’od</i> (within yet) is to be translated before again.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Od</i> means again. The <i>bet</i> prefixed to it means before. Thus <i>be’od</i> means before again (within yet), and the meaning of <i>be’od sheloshet yamim</i> (within yet three days) is before three days again pass. I.E. makes this point because Onkelos translates <i>be’od</i>, after yet. Thus Onkelos renders <i>be’od sheloshet yamim</i> at the end of three days.</i> Its meaning is: such a time<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Three days.</i> will not again pass without this happening.
SHALL PHARAOH LIFT UP THY HEAD FROM OFF THEE. He will lift it up from its place. It means he will remove it or raise it up on a pole.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that the Hebrew word <i>yissa</i> may mean to remove or to raise up (Cherez).</i>

Verse 20

BIRTHDAY. <i>Hulledet</i> (birth) is an infinitive in the <i>hofal</i>.

Verse 21

UNTO HIS BUTLERSHIP. <i>Mashkehu</i> (his butlership) here is a noun.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Here <i>mashkehu</i> means his drink. The meaning of our verse is: And he restored the chief butler back to being in charge of his drink. In verse 13 it means, gives him to drink.</i> However, <i>mashkehu</i> in <i>when thou wast his butler</i> (mashkehu) (v. 13) is a verb.

Verse 22



Verse 23

YET DID NOT THE CHIEF BUTLER REMEMBER JOSEPH. He did not verbally mention him to Pharaoh.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>zakhar</i> (usually translated remembered) here means mentioned, as in <i>make mention of me</i> (ve-hizkartani) <i>unto Pharaoh</i> (v. 14).</i> The words <i>tizkeru</i> (shall ye mention) and <i>zakhar</i> (he remembered), in <i>And the burden of the Lord shall ye mention</i> (tizkeru)<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, shall ye remember.</i> <i>no more</i> (Jer. 23:36) and <i>he remembered</i> (zakhar) <i>Vashti</i> (Est. 2:1), are similar.
BUT FORGOT HIM. In his heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the verse tells us that the butler not only failed to mention Joseph to Pharaoh, he totally forgot about him.</i>

Chapter 41



Verse 1

AND IT CAME TO PASS AT THE END OF TWO FULL YEARS. Scripture does not indicate the point from which these two years are reckoned. <i>And it came to pass at the end of forty years</i> (II Sam. 15:7), <i>And within threescore and five years</i> (Is. 7:8), and <i>Now it came to pass in the thirtieth year</i> (Ezek. 1:1)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In all these verses Scripture doesn’t indicate the point from which the reckoning starts.</i> are similar. However, it is possible that Scripture’s point of reckoning is the chief butler’s release from prison or the day that Joseph was put into prison.
[FULL.] I have already explained the meaning of <i>yamim</i> (full).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 4:4.</i>
THAT PHARAOH DREAMED. That is, was dreaming. Compare, <i>And Rebekah heard</i> (Gen. 27:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: that Pharaoh dreams (<i>u-faroh cholem</i>), hence I.E.’s comment. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 27:5 and the notes thereto.</i>

Verse 2

IN THE REED-GRASS. Some say that <i>achu</i> (reed-grass) means a valley with plants.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Hence our phrase is to be rendered: they fed in the growth covered valley.</i> Others say that <i>achu</i> is the name of a certain type of plant and<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">So <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38.</i> the <i>bet</i> of <i>ba-achu</i> is superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">If we interpret <i>achu</i> as valley then the <i>bet</i> of <i>ba-achu</i> serves a purpose; it stands for “in the.” Thus <i>ba-achu</i> means in the growth covered valley. However, if <i>achu</i> is the name of a plant then the <i>bet</i> is superfluous, for one cannot say they fed in the plant (whatever plant <i>achu</i> might be). According to the latter interpretation our verse is to be translated: and they fed upon <i>achu</i>.</i> It is similar to the <i>bet</i> of <i>va-merorim</i> in, <i>He hath filled me with bitterness</i> (va-merorim) (Lam. 3:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Hebrew usage requires the verse to read <i>merorim</i> rather than <i>va-merorim</i>.</i> According to both of these interpretations <i>achu</i> here and <i>achim</i> in <i>For though he be fruitful among the reed-plants</i> (achim) (Hos. 13:15) are related and come from one root.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. literally reads, “It (<i>achim</i> in Hosea) is its brother (<i>achiv</i>) the son of his mother.” I.E. plays with <i>achim</i> (valley or plant) and <i>ach</i> (brother). His point is that both come from the same root, that our word is in the singular, and that in Hosea it is in the plural (Cherez).</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

EARS OF CORN. <i>Shibbolim</i> (ears of corn) is a feminine plural even though it ends in a <i>mem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Which ordinarily indicates that a word is a masculine plural.</i> It is similar to <i>nashim</i> (women) and <i>pilagshim</i> (concubines).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Both of which are feminine plural nouns with masculine endings.</i>

Verse 6

AND BLASTED. <i>U-shedufot kadim</i> means they were blasted by a wind coming from the east for <i>kadim</i> means east. East is so termed because the sun rises there first.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kedem</i> means first. Cf. Is. 23:7; Ezek. 38:17. I.E. makes this point because <i>kedem</i> can also mean front. However, a circular object (the earth) has no front (Krinsky). <i>Shedufot kadim</i> can be rendered as blasted by the east. Hence I.E. points out that east refers to an east wind.</i>

Verse 7

<i>Ha-mele’ot</i> (full) has the same meaning as <i>ha-beri’ot</i> (rank).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 reads <i>beri’ot ve-tovot</i> (rank and good). Similarly verse 7 reads, <i>ha-beri’ot ve-ha-mele’ot</i> (rank and full). I.E. points out that <i>beri’ot</i> when referring to ears of corn means full because the term <i>bari</i> (rank), which means fat, can only be used when referring to animals; i.e., one cannot speak of a fat plant. Hence I.E. points out that here <i>bari</i> means full (Filwarg). Thus <i>beri’ot ve-tovot</i> means the same as <i>mele’ot ve-tovot</i>. On the other hand I.E.’s comment may pertain only to verse 7. In this case I.E. is pointing out that the Bible there uses two synonyms, <i>mele’ot</i> and <i>beri’ot</i>, for full (Weiser).</i>

Verse 8

THAT HIS SPIRIT WAS TROUBLED. <i>Va-tippa’em</i> (was troubled) is a <i>nifal</i>. It is similar to <i>nifamti</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Which is a <i>nifal</i>. The <i>nun</i> of the <i>nifal</i> is missing in <i>va-tippa’em</i> because it is an imperfect with a conversive <i>vav</i>, and the <i>nun</i> of the <i>nifal</i> is dropped in the future and is compensated by a <i>dagesh</i> in the first letter of the root.</i> in <i>I am troubled</i> (nifamti) <i>and cannot speak</i> (Ps. 77:5). Others say<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The “others” do not dispute what has been said until now. They explain the meaning of the word, whereas the first interpretation gave the conjugation of the word (Cherez).</i> that both <i>va-tippa’em</i> and <i>nifamti</i> come from the same root as <i>pa’am</i> (anvil)<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of <i>va-tippa’em rucho</i> (that his spirit was troubled) thus is: that his spirit was beaten.</i> in <i>that smiteth the anvil</i> (pa’am) (Is. 41:7). Its meaning is that his spirit was like a beaten body.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">It was pained and troubled. Spirit is immaterial and cannot be beaten. However, it may be compared to a beaten body. His spirit was beaten as if it were a body (Weiser). Hence the verb <i>va-tippa’em</i> (was beaten) can govern <i>rucho</i> (his spirit).</i>
MAGICIANS OF. <i>Chartume</i> (magicians of) comes from a quadriliteral root.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Its root being <i>chet, resh, tet, mem</i>.</i> However, it is possibly an Aramaic or Egyptian word. It means a scientist.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Weiser.</i>
AND ALL THE WISE MEN THEREOF. Men learned in astrology and dream interpretation.

Verse 9

MY FAULTS. Even though I will recall my faults.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">It is not fitting to recall one’s offenses before the king. Nevertheless, in this case I must (Krinsky). I will tell you of an interpreter, even though I have to recall my faults (Cohen).</i>

Verse 10

PHARAOH WAS WROTH WITH HIS SERVANTS. I believe that Pharaoh is an adjective<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">What I.E. means by “adjective” is an adjectival noun, a descriptive term like <i>melekh</i> (king). Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:1 and the notes thereto.</i> and not a proper name. It is an Egyptian word. It is a title as Hiram in Tyre.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E., Hiram is not a proper noun. It is a term like Pharaoh or <i>melekh</i>. We thus find a Hiram in the days of David (II Sam. 5:11) and in the days of Solomon (I Kings 5:15) (Krinsky).</i> Similarly in our day all great Arab kings are called “prince of the believers.” Hence we find a Pharaoh in the days of Abraham and a Pharaoh in the days of Joseph.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">They obviously were not the same person.</i> We also read that a Pharaoh died and a new Pharaoh arose.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Ex. 1:8.</i> Similarly we find a Pharaoh in the days of Jeremiah.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Jer. 44:30.</i> Do you not see that Scripture itself explains that Pharaoh is a term for the king of Egypt,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible in a number of places explains that Pharaoh is a king of Egypt. Cf. Ex. 6:13, 29; Jer. 44:30. Filwarg questions this reading and suggests emending it. According to Filwarg we should translate, “Do you not see that Scripture does not explain the term Pharaoh. It does not do so because Pharaoh is a title for the kings of Egypt.” According to Filwarg, I.E.’s point is that the Bible usually does not identify the Pharaoh because it is known to be a title for the king of Egypt. If Pharaoh was a proper name, king of Egypt would follow it.</i> as evidenced by the terms Pharaoh Hophra and Pharaoh Neco,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Jer. 44:30; 46:2.</i> wherein Hophra and Neco are proper nouns.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore Pharaoh must be an adjective.</i> Do not raise any objection from the Midrash concerning Solomon’s throne,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Midrash, <i>Va-yikra Rabbah</i> 20, Pharaoh Neco means Pharaoh the lame. Thus <i>Neco</i> is an adjective. According to the Midrash this Pharaoh tried to sit on Solomon’s throne, which had been brought to Egypt by an earlier Pharaoh named Shishak, and had his leg bitten and broken by a lion, hence the name Pharaoh Neco, Pharaoh the lame.</i> for the king of Egypt did not take it to Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">King Solomon’s throne was never brought to Egypt as it is not included among the spoil taken by Shishak. Cf. I Kings 14:25, 26.</i> Additional proof<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">That Pharaoh is not a proper noun.</i> is found in the statement of the chief butler, <i>Pharaoh was wroth</i>, and in Joseph’s statements, <i>God will give Pharaoh an answer of peace</i> (v. 16); <i>He hath shown unto Pharaoh</i> (v. 28); and <i>Let Pharaoh do this</i> (v. 34).<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Thus these verses prove that Pharaoh is not a proper noun.</i> It is not in keeping with proper etiquette to mention the king by name.
ME AND THE CHIEF BAKER. The word me is mentioned twice in this verse in keeping with Hebrew usage. Compare, <i>and as for me, whither shall I go</i> (Gen. 37:30).<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 37:30 and the notes thereto. Our verse reads, <i>and put me…me and the chief baker</i>.</i>

Verse 11

EACH MAN ACCORDING TO THE INTERPRETATION OF HIS DREAM. I have previously explained this.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains the meaning of <i>each man according to the interpretation of his dreams</i> in his comments on Gen. 40:5.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13

I WAS RESTORED. By Pharaoh.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: me he restored (<i>oti heshiv</i>), him he hanged (<i>oto talah</i>). The question is, to whom does “he” refer. According to the first interpretation it refers to Pharaoh, according to the second, to Joseph.</i> Or its meaning is, Joseph’s word<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Since Joseph said it, it was as if he had done it (Filwarg). Or Joseph’s saying it was the cause of it (Krinsky).</i> or Joseph’s interpretation restored me and hanged him.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph, by so interpreting, caused it to happen (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 14

AND THEY BROUGHT HIM HASTILY. Pharaoh’s messengers.
AND HE SHAVED HIMSELF. Someone shaved him.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>va-yegakkach</i>. If Joseph shaved himself Scripture would have used the <i>hitpa’el va-yitgallach</i> rather than the <i>pi’el va-yegallach</i> (Cherez), the meaning of which is, and he shaved. However, <i>va-yegallach</i> presents a problem. The subject is missing. Hence I.E. notes that it should be rendered: and someone shaved him. According to Krinsky, I.E. is of the opinion (for the aforementioned reasons) that our verse is abridged and the reader has to supply the subject. Our verse should thus be rendered: and the shaver shaved him. I.E.’s note consists of one word, <i>ha-megalle’ach</i> (the shaver).</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16

IT IS NOT IN ME. <i>Biladai</i> (it is not in me) is a compound of two words.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">It is a compound of <i>bal</i> (not) and <i>ade</i> (unto).</i> <i>It is not in me</i> refers to <i>And I have heard say of thee that when thou hearest a dream thou canst interpret it</i> (v. 15). When Joseph heard Pharaoh say this he replied, <i>it is not in me, but God will give Pharaoh an answer of peace via my interpretation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The problem is what does <i>biladai</i> (it is not in me) refer to. According to this explanation <i>biladai</i> refers to the power to interpret dreams. The power to interpret dreams is not in me, it comes from God (Cherez).</i> Others say that when Joseph heard Pharaoh say, <i>thou canst interpret dreams</i>, Jospeh replied, I am not (it is not in me) the interpreter; God is, and He will give the king an answer of peace.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>biladai</i> means not I, and refers to the interpreter (Cherez). It should be noted that I.E. is vague and that Krinsky, Kaputa and others interpret differently.</i>
[WILL GIVE AN ANSWER.] The meaning of <i>ya’aneh</i> (will give an answer) is, He will always provide. Compare, <i>ma’aneh</i> in <i>for God answereth him</i> (ma’aneh) <i>in the joy of his heart</i> (Eccles. 5:19), and <i>ta’aneh</i> in <i>And the earth shall respond</i> (ta’aneh) (Hos. 2:24). Nevertheless, the word is close to its primary meaning.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Its primary meaning is to answer. When one provides, he, as it were, answers (Cherez). For an alternate translation see Weiser.</i> 

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

[POOR AND VERY ILL-FAVORED.] In relating the dream Pharaoh added the word <i>dallot</i> (poor), and in place of <i>mareh</i> (favored) he used the term <i>to’ar</i> (favored) because their meanings are similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">In verse 3 we read that Pharaoh saw <i>ill-favored</i> (ra’ot mareh) <i>and lean fleshed</i> kine in his dream. In our verse Pharaoh describes them as <i>poor and very ill-favored</i> (ve-ra’ot to’ar me’od) <i>and lean fleshed</i>. I.E. says there is no discrepancy in the descriptions because adding a word or using a synonym does not change the meaning. He further expands on this point in his comments on Ex. 20:1 where he uses this argument to explain why there are two different versions of the Ten Commandments in the Pentateuch.</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21

BUT THEY WERE STILL ILL-FAVORED. Each one of the kine was ill-favored.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Marehen</i> (favored) is a plural; <i>ra</i> (ill) is a singular. Thus <i>marehen ra</i> is a combination of singular and plural. I.E. explains this by noting that it means each one of the kine was ill-favored. This is how the medieval grammarians explained this type of combination (Weiser).</i> Here Pharaoh expanded in his description of his dream and added that after the ill-favored kine had eaten the fat kine, <i>they were still ill-favored as at the beginning</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">When the dream was first described in verse 4, it was not indicated that after swallowing the seven fat kine, the seven lean ones <i>were still ill-favored as at the beginning</i>. Here, unlike verse 19, the addition is significant. The entire verse consists of Pharaoh’s elaboration of his dream.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23

WITHERED. The word <i>tzenumot</i> (withered) is not found elsewhere in Scripture. Its meaning is the same as that of <i>rekot</i> (empty).<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph in verse 27 refers to the ears as <i>rekot</i> (empty). In our verse they are described as <i>tzenumot</i>. According to I.E., Joseph substituted a synonym. I.E. explains these substitutions in his comments on verse 19.</i> Others say that <i>tzenumot</i> means images,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">In a manner of speaking images are imitations. Similarly applying this concept these things were in the shape of ears but empty on the inside (Krinsky). Or images have no practical use, neither did these ears (Cherez). Weiser suggests that what I.E. says is that images are hard; these, too, were hard and could not serve as food. According to the latter interpretation I.E. agrees with Rashi who interprets <i>tzenumot</i> as hard.</i> for that is its meaning in Arabic.

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

GREAT PLENTY. <i>Sava</i> (plenty) is a noun. It is like <i>ra’av</i> (famine).<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Both <i>sava</i> and <i>ra’av</i> are nouns.</i> Hence the one who says in his Sabbath prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In the <i>nishmat</i> prayer.</i> <i>u-ve-sova kilkaltanu</i> errs because <i>sova</i> spelled with a <i>vav</i> is an infinitive.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The prayer reads, <i>during famine</i> (ra’av) <i>thou didst feed us, and didst sustain us in plenty</i> (p. 419, <i>The Authorized Prayer Book</i>, trans. by J. H. Hertz). Plenty is parallel to famine. As <i>ra’av</i> is a noun so its parallel must be a noun. Hence the correct reading is <i>sava</i> and not <i>sova</i>.</i> The correct way to read this prayer is without a <i>vav</i>, viz., <i>u-ve-sava</i> (and in plenty) <i>kilkaltanu</i> (thou sustained us).

Verse 30



Verse 31

[AND THE PLENTY SHALL NOT BE KNOWN IN THE LAND.] Joseph based this on <i>but they were still ill-favored as at the beginning</i> (v. 21).

Verse 32

AND FOR THAT THE DREAM WAS DOUBLED. <i>Hishanot</i> (was doubled) is a <i>nifal</i>. It comes from the same root as <i>shenayim</i> (two). Its meaning is the dream coming twice, once with kine as its symbol and then with ears of corn as its symbol, also attests<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Not only do the kine and the ears allude to seven years of plenty and famine, they also indicate that the decree is established by God; i.e., it is unchangeable.</i> that <i>the thing is established by God</i>. Furthermore, the occurrence of the two dreams in one night is proof that <i>God will shortly bring it to pass</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The dream could have come on two different nights. The fact that it occurred twice in one night is proof that God is bringing it about soon. Our verse reads: <i>The dream was doubled…twice</i>. This appears redundant; hence I.E. explains <i>was doubled</i> came in two versions, <i>twice</i>, twice in one night. <i>It is because the thing is established by God</i> corresponds to <i>was doubled</i>; and <i>and God will shortly bring it to pass</i> corresponds to <i>twice</i>.</i>

Verse 33



Verse 34

LET PHARAOH DO THIS. <i>Ya’aseh paro</i> (literally let Pharaoh do) is short for let Pharaoh do according to the following council. Or <i>ya’aseh</i> (do) means get, like <i>asah</i> in <i>My power and the might of my hand hath gotten</i> (asah) <i>me this wealth</i> (Deut. 8:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>ya’aseh paro</i> means let Pharoah get. Also according to this interpretation the object is missing. It should be read: Let Pharaoh get wheat (Weiser).</i>
AND TAKE UP THE FIFTH PART OF THE LAND. Let him buy a fifth of the produce of the land.

Verse 35

AND LAY UP CORN. The overseers. Some say that <i>bar</i> (corn) refers to corn in its ears.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Grain that has not been purified from its stubble (Weiser).</i> However, I think that <i>bar</i> is the term applied to the corn after it has been fanned and cleansed.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Grain whose impurities have been removed. I.E. is paraphrasing Jer. 4:11. Our texts read, fanned or cleansed. <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, fanned and cleansed. We have followed the latter.</i> To the one who says that the Egyptian air is damp because of the Nile and it is impossible for corn to last there for seven years, we reply that it is possible to mix corn with preservatives.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">According to <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 90:5 this is precisely what Joseph did.</i>

Verse 36



Verse 37



Verse 38

CAN WE FIND SUCH A ONE AS THIS. <i>Nimtza</i> (we find) is a <i>nifal</i> perfect and the meaning of <i>ha-nimtza kha-zeh ish</i> (can we find such a one as this) is, was such a one as this ever found in the world. It is also possible that the <i>nun</i> of <i>nimtza</i> is a first person plural prefix.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>nun</i> is prefixed to the Hebrew root in the first person plural imperfect. According to this interpretation <i>nimtza</i> is a <i>kal</i>.</i> In this case the word <i>ha-nimtza</i> (can we find) relates to what Pharaoh said to his servants.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of the phrase is, can we find such a one as this. The point is that <i>nimtza</i> can either be a third person singular <i>nifal</i> perfect or a first person plural <i>kal</i> imperfect. In the first instance it means was found, and relates to <i>kha-zeh ish</i> (such a one as this); in the second, it means we will find, and it relates to Pharaoh and his servants.</i>

Verse 39



Verse 40

THOU SHALT BE OVER MY HOUSE. Thou shalt be chief over my house.
SHALL BE RULED. The <i>shin</i> of <i>yishak</i> (shall be ruled) has a <i>dagesh</i> to compensate for the missing <i>nun</i> of <i>neshek</i> (arms),<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yishak</i> is a denominative of <i>neshek</i> (arms), and means will be armed.</i> its meaning being Joseph will be commander of the army.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. translates <i>and according unto thy word shall all my people be ruled</i> as, and according unto thy word shall all my people be armed. Hence Joseph will be chief of the army.</i> Others say that <i>yishak</i> is related to <i>neshikah</i> (kiss).<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">All the people will pay homage to Joseph by kissing him on the mouth (<i>pikha</i>) (Filwarg). Krinsky suggests translating it, thy word shall all my people kiss. Literally, <i>pikha</i> means thy mouth.</i> However, the latter is far fetched.
ONLY IN THE THRONE WILL I BE GREATER THAN THOU. It is known that <i>egdal</i> (I will be greater) is an intransitive verb. The meaning of <i>rak ha-kisse egdal mi-mekka</i> is, I will not be greater than you except for the dignity of the throne.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Egdal</i> being intransitive refers to Pharaoh and not the throne.</i> The word <i>gedelani</i> (he grew up with me) in <i>Nay from my youth he grew up with me</i> (gedelani) <i>as with a father</i> (Job 31:18) is not a transitive verb<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, brought me up. If <i>gedelani</i> was transitive it would disprove I.E.’s contention that <i>egdal</i> is intransitive since they are both <i>kals</i>.</i> but an intransitive verb meaning he grew up with me. The juxtaposition of an intransitive verb (<i>egdal</i>) with the direct object (<i>kisse</i>) is found elsewhere in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">That is, found elsewhere in Scripture with a similar meaning, i.e., meaning, with regard to (Weiser, Krinsky). Usually only a transitive verb is connected to a direct object (Weiser). Hence I.E. points out that our verse is not unique.</i> Compare, <i>For ye shall be as a terebinth whose leaf fadeth</i> (ke-elah novelet aleha) (Is. 1:30);<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Novelet</i> (fadeth) is intransitive, <i>aleha</i> (its leaves) is the object. I.E. renders <i>novelet alehah</i> as, which is withering with regards to its leaves.</i> and <i>and ye perish in the way</i> (ve-tovedu derekh) (Ps. 2:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ve-tovedu</i> (you shall perish) is intransitive. <i>Derekh</i> (way) is the object. According to I.E. the meaning of <i>ve-tovenu derekh</i> is, and you shall perish with regard to the way. Similarly the meaning of our verse is, I will be greater than you with regard to the throne (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 41

SEE, I HAVE SET THEE OVER ALL THE LAND. I have set thee above all the land of Egypt.

Verse 42

VESTURES OF FINE LINEN. I have explained the meaning of <i>shesh</i> (fine linen) in my comments on the Torah portion <i>ve-yikchu li terumah</i> (that they take for me an offering).<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. in Ex. 25:4 writes that <i>shesh</i> is white linen made from a type of flax which grows in Egypt.</i>
A GOLD CHAIN. <i>Revid</i> (chain) is like <i>marvadim</i> (coverlets) in <i>I have decked my couch with coverlets</i> (marvadim) (Prov. 7:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains <i>revid</i> (chain) to mean a coverlet (Krinsky, Weiser).</i>

Verse 43

THE SECOND. <i>Mishneh</i> (the second) comes from the same root as <i>shenayim</i> (two). The king is like the numeral one, next comes the <i>mishneh</i> which means second to him, and afterward the <i>shalish</i> (adjutant) which means the same as <i>shilishi</i> (third).<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. points out that <i>mishneh</i> means second in rank and <i>shalish</i> third in rank (Netter). <i>Mishneh</i> can be taken to refer to the chariot, as Rashi interprets. Hence I.E. points out that <i>mirkevet ha-mishneh</i> (the second chariot) is to be rendered: the chariot of the second in rank (Cherez).</i>
CHARIOT. A wooden chariot pulled by four horses,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Some interpret <i>mirkevet</i> (chariot) to mean a horse or mule. Cf. Rashi.</i> as is evidenced by the chariot of Solomon.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">We read in I Kings 10:29, <i>And a chariot</i> (merkavah) <i>came up and went out of Egypt for six hundred shekels of silver, and a horse for a hundred and fifty</i>. Now four times 150 gives 600. Hence each chariot had four horses.</i>
ABRECH. Every man called before him, I will bend the knee (<i>avrekh</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avrekh</i> is a first person singular. However, the verb preceding it, <i>va-yikre</i>’u (and they cried), is a plural. Thus rather than <i>avrekh</i> we would expect <i>navrekh</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> and I will bow down. The word <i>avrekh</i> is a <i>hifil</i>. However, the word <i>va-yivrakh</i> in <i>and kneeled down</i> (va-yivrakh) <i>upon his knees</i> (II Chron. 6:13) is a <i>kal</i>. Both words come from the same root, <i>birkayim</i> (knees).<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>bet, resh, caf</i>.</i> Rabbi Jonah, the Spanish grammarian,<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Janah.</i> said that <i>avrekh</i> is an infinitive, with an <i>alef</i> taking the place of the <i>heh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>avrekh</i> is a variant of <i>havrekh</i>. This answers the question raised in note 70. According to this comment <i>avrech</i> is not a first person singular but rather an infinitive. The verse thus reads: and they cried before him, bend the knee (<i>havrekh</i>). This is also the opinion of Kimchi.</i> as we find in the word <i>ashkem</i> in <i>sending them betimes</i> (ashkem) <i>and often</i> (Jer. 25:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Wherein <i>ashkem</i> is to be interpreted as if written <i>hashkem</i>. I.E. quotes Jer. 25:4, <i>sending them betimes and often</i>. However, in this verse the word for betimes is written <i>hashkem</i> with a <i>heh</i>. The reference therefore must be to Jer. 25:3 (speaking betimes and often) where the word for betimes is written <i>ashkem</i> with an <i>alef</i>. Either we have a scribal error or I.E. quoted from memory and erred.</i> However, I believe that the <i>alef</i> of <i>ashkem</i> is a first person future prefix.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">In other words a <i>heh</i> has not been substituted for an <i>alef</i>, its meaning being: I arose and spoke (Krinsky). Hence we cannot use Jer. 25:3 as an analogy for a <i>heh</i> being substituted for an <i>alef</i>.</i>

Verse 44

I AM PHARAOH. I alone am king and aside from you no one is permitted to act freely.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">I remain king. However, everyone else will be subservient to you (Cherez).</i>
[HIS FOOT.] The meaning of <i>his foot</i> is permission to go any place.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. The same applies to <i>his hand</i>; i.e., no one may do anything without your (Joseph’s) permission (Weiser).</i> It may also be a figurative expression.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">His hand or his foot is not to be taken literally but means do anything significant or insignificant (Weiser).</i> The latter is its correct meaning.

Verse 45

ZAPHENATH-PANEAH. If this is an Egyptian word then we don’t know what it means.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Since we don’t understand ancient Egyptian we cannot unravel its meaning.</i> On the other hand, if this is a Hebrew translation of Joseph’s Egyptian name then we don’t know what Joseph’s Egyptian name was. In the latter case<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>Zaphenath-paneah</i> is Hebrew.</i> the meaning of <i>paneah</i> is in accordance with Onkelos’ translation,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders <i>paneah</i> as revealed. He renders <i>zaphenath-paneah</i>, a man before whom all secrets (<i>tzefunot</i>) are revealed.</i> and it is a quadriliteral.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Its root being <i>peh, ayin, nun, chet</i>.</i>
PRIEST OF ON. The term <i>kohen</i> (priest) can be applied to one who serves the Lord or to one who serves idols, for I believe that when this term is used in Scripture it means one who ministers.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that <i>kohen</i> does not mean a priest of the Lord; it means any priest. Hence <i>kohen on</i> means priest of On.</i>
AND JOSEPH WENT OUT. His name went out, as in <i>And thy renown went forth among the nations</i> (Ezek. 16:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Joseph was renowned throughout the land. Literally: And thy name went forth among the nations. “Thy name” meaning thy renown.</i> Or it means he went out and traveled throughout the land and they announced who he was that he might become known.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Taking <i>And Joseph went out</i> literally and not applying it to his name.</i>

Verse 46



Verse 47



Verse 48

ALL THE FOOD. All is not to be taken literally, for if it were, then all should have starved to death. <i>All</i> in <i>And all countries came</i> (v. 57) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">It is not to be taken literally. It doesn’t mean each and every individual came.</i> The meaning of <i>And he gathered up all the food</i> is: and Joseph gathered as much of the food as he could.

Verse 49



Verse 50



Verse 51

FOR GOD HATH MADE ME FORGET. Its meaning is, because he said <i>God hath made me forget</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">This is an abridged statement as “because he said” has to be added between <i>Manasseh</i> and <i>for God</i> etc. Cf. I.E.’s comment on Gen. 26:7.</i> Rabbi Judah, the first Hebrew grammarian,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Judah ibn Hayyuj (c. 940-1010), the first Hebrew grammarian to put forth the idea that all Hebrew words come from a three letter root. He is considered the father of the science of Hebrew grammar (Weiser).</i> says that <i>nashani</i> (made me forget) follows the paradigm of <i>channani</i> (dealt graciously with me) (Gen. 33:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Channani</i> comes from the root <i>chet, nun, nun</i>. Similarly <i>nashani</i> comes from the root <i>nun, shin, shin</i>. They are both <i>kals</i>.</i> However, Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen, the Spaniard, says that (in <i>nashani</i>) a <i>pattach</i> has been substituted for the <i>chirik</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">According to this opinion, <i>nashani</i> is a <i>pi’el</i> coming from the root <i>nun, shin, heh</i>. Compare, <i>tzivvani</i> whose root is <i>tzadi, vav, heh</i>. The problem is that the first letter of a <i>pi’el</i> perfect is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i>, and <i>nashani</i> is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i>, hence Rabbi Moses’ explanation that a <i>pattach</i> has been substituted for a <i>chirik</i>. Thus <i>nashani</i> is a variant of <i>nishani</i>.</i>

Verse 52



Verse 53



Verse 54

AND THE SEVEN YEARS OF FAMINE BEGAN. <i>Va-techillenah</i> is a <i>kal</i> and comes from a root whose second and third letters are identical.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>chet, lamed, lamed</i>. This comment presents difficulties. <i>Techillenah</i> is obviously a <i>hifil</i>. If it were a <i>kal</i> it would be vocalized <i>techullenah</i>. Futhermore, this word is never encountered in the Bible in the <i>kal</i>. The entire comment is missing in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. Similarly S.D. Luzzato had manuscripts of I.E. which omitted this comment. For an attempt to justify this comment see Krinsky.</i>
IN ALL LANDS. All the lands adjacent to Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 90:6, <i>the hunger was in three lands, Phoenecia, Arabia and Palestine</i>. The point is that if the hunger was in lands far from Egypt, how did they survive since they couldn’t come to Egypt to buy food?</i>

Verse 55



Verse 56

AND JOSEPH OPENED ALL. The storehouses which they had.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: And Joseph opened what was <i>ba-hem</i> (in them). I.E. interprets <i>ba-hem</i> to mean, had with them, i.e., their storehouses.</i>
AND SOLD UNTO THE EGYPTIANS. It means he gave corn (<i>shever</i>) to the Egyptians.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yishbor</i> (and sold) is a denominative of corn or grain.</i> <i>Va-yishbor</i> refers to a corn purchase.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The Egyptians purchased the corn. Hence Joseph sold it. Thus <i>va-yishbor</i> means, and he sold (Krinsky). <i>Va-yishbor</i> usually means, and he bought corn. This is the sense in which this root is used throughout Chap. 42 and in Is. 55:1. However, here <i>va-yishbor</i> seems to mean, and he sold corn. I.E.’s apparent solution to the problem is to explain that <i>va-yishbor</i> can apply either to the seller or to the buyer as the transfer of corn (<i>shever</i>) is effectuated by two individuals, the one giving (selling) the corn and the other buying it. The aforementioned is how Kimchi explains <i>va-yishbor</i> and it appears to be the meaning of I.E.’s comment (Cherez).</i>

Verse 57

TO JOSEPH TO BUY CORN. The clause is inverted<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">It literally reads: to buy corn to Joseph.</i> and must be understood as: And all the countries came into Egypt to Joseph to buy corn.

Chapter 42



Verse 1

NOW JACOB SAW. Scripture interchanges<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture occasionally uses hear for see and see for smell.</i> the way the senses<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The five senses.</i> are referred to because they are all perceived in one central place.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. in his commentary on Eccles. 11:7 says that there is a place on the forehead where the senses are perceived.</i> Thus Scripture says, <i>See the smell of my son</i> (Gen. 27:27);<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than smell the smell of my son.</i> and <i>And the light is sweet</i> (Eccles. 11:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Even though light cannot be tasted.</i> <i>Now Jacob saw</i> is similar,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Now Jacob saw means, now Jacob heard.</i> for afterward Scripture states, <i>Behold I have heard that there is corn in Egypt</i> (v. 2).
WHY DO YOU LOOK ONE UPON ANOTHER. <i>Lammah titra</i>’u (why do you look one upon another) means, don’t show yourselves as having an abundance of food.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi, “Why do you show yourselves before the children of Ishmael and the children of Esau as having plenty to eat?” Why do you show yourselves is thus short for, why do you show yourselves as having an abundance of food.</i> Or it may mean, do not quarrel with each other, as in <i>Come, let us look one another</i> (nitra’eh) <i>in the face</i> (II Chron. 25:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. translates <i>nitra’eh</i> in II Chron. 25:17 as fight. Thus the root <i>resh, alef, heh</i> which usually means to see, at times also means to fight or quarrel. Hence <i>titra</i>’u is similar to <i>nitra’eh</i>, i.e., it means to quarrel.</i>

Verse 2

AND BUY FOR US. <i>Ve-shivru lanu</i> means, and buy corn for us.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. notes that <i>shivru</i> means to buy grain. He points this out because in Gen. 41:56 it means to sell grain.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4

HARM. Death.

Verse 5



Verse 6

THAT SOLD. <i>Ha-mashbir</i> (that sold) comes from the same root as <i>shever</i> (corn). It means the seller. It is a causative verb.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">That is, it is a <i>hifil</i>. He caused the wheat to be sold (Weiser).</i>

Verse 7

BUT MADE HIMSELF STRANGE UNTO THEM. <i>Va-yitnakker</i> (but made himself strange) comes from the same root as <i>nokhri</i> (stranger). Its meaning is, he showed himself to be a stranger.
ROUGHLY. <i>Kashot</i> (roughly) is an adjective. Its meaning is rough words.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The word “words” has to be added to the text Thus rough (<i>kashot</i>) is short for rough words (Weiser). The Hebrew literally reads: and spoke rough (<i>kashot</i>) with them.</i> <i>Answereth impudent</i> (Prov. 18:23) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, the word “words” is missing in the Hebrew. The verse should be understood as if written, answereth impudent words.</i>
AND HE KNEW THEM. When Joseph first saw the group he recognized them as his brothers. <sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">This is the meaning of <i>and he knew them</i>.</i> He then looked at each one of them and recognized them individually. The latter is the meaning of <i>And Joseph knew his brethren</i> (v. 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>And He knew them</i>. Verse 8 states, <i>And Joseph knew his brethren</i>. I.E. interprets our verse as referring to the brothers as a group and verse 8 to each individual brother.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9

THE NAKEDNESS OF THE LAND. Nakedness is a figure of speech for shame, since it is customary to hide one’s nakedness because of its unseemliness.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Nakedness thus means shame. Weiser takes I.E.’s comment at face value and explains that shame refers to the shame of the country. Cherez explains that shame refers to the areas of the country open to invasion. Be that as it may, according to this interpretation, the nakedness of the land means the shame of the land.</i> Or nakedness refers to secrets, since one’s nakedness is covered. Joseph thus said to them, “You have come to learn the secrets of the land.” I prefer the latter interpretation.

Verse 10



Verse 11

WE. <i>Nachnu</i> (we) is spelled without an <i>alef</i>. This is the correct form of the word.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>nachnu</i> is primary, <i>anachnu</i> secondary, as the <i>alef</i> of <i>anachnu</i> is superfluous (Filwarg, Weiser, Cherez). Cf. I.E. on Lam. 3:42.</i>
UPRIGHT. <i>Kenim</i> means truthful. It is possible that <i>kenim</i> comes from the same root as <i>ken</i> (so) in <i>So</i> (ken) <i>do, as thou hast said</i> (Gen. 18:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of <i>kenim anachnu</i> (we are upright men) is we are so, we are as we appear, that is, people who came to buy grain.</i> Or <i>kenim</i> comes from the same root<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">“Comes from the same root” means akin to or the same.</i> as <i>ken</i> (truth) in <i>The daughters of Zelophehad speak right</i> (ken) (Num. 27:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>kenim anachnu</i> means, we are truthful men.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

AND YE SHALL BE BOUND. <i>He’aseru</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>He’aseru</i> is an imperative meaning bind yourselves. Now one cannot bind oneself, that is, put oneself in prison (Krinsky). Also, Simeon was bound, he did not bind himself (Filwarg). Hence I.E. points out that even though <i>he’aseru</i> is an imperative, here it has the meaning of an imperfect.</i> should be rendered: ye shall be bound. It is similar to <i>u-mot</i> (and die) in <i>and die in the mount</i> (Deut. 32:50).<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Die</i> is an imperative, but it has the meaning of an imperfect; i.e., it means you will die. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:22.</i>

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

FAMINE OF YOUR HOUSES. Needed because of the famine of your houses.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads, <i>shever ra’avon</i> (com famine). This makes no sense, so I.E. interprets, com because of the famine.</i> The meaning of <i>havi’u shever ra’avon batekhem</i> (carry corn for the famine of your houses) is, carry to your houses the corn needed because of the famine.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads, <i>havi’u shever ra’avon batekhem</i> (carry com famine your houses). I.E. says that <i>havi</i>’u (carry) is to be connected to <i>batekhem</i> (your houses).
