Thus the meaning of the clause is: carry to your houses the com needed because of the famine (Krinsky, Cherez).</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21

VERILY. <i>Aval</i> (verily) has the same meaning as <i>aval</i> in <i>Verily</i> (aval) <i>Sarah thy wife shall bear thee a son</i> (Gen. 17:19). It means verily (Gen. 28:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>aval</i> also means but, however. Hence I.E. points out that here it means verily.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23

THE INTERPRETER. <i>Ha-melitz</i> means the interpreter. It is related to <i>melitzah</i> (figure of speech) (Prov. 1:6). 
Joseph imprisoned Simeon because when many sin, the oldest is punished more severely than the others. He did not punish Reuben because he (Reuben) saved him.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Reuben was the eldest. However, he saved Jospeh and Joseph had no reason to imprison him. Hence he punished Simeon who was second to the eldest.</i> 

Verse 24



Verse 25

Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the words <i>zahav</i> (gold) and <i>kesef</i> (silver) are never encountered in the plural.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The reference must be to Scripture since we find plurals for gold and silver in Rabbinic literature. See <i>Baba Metzia</i> 42a; <i>Shemot Rabbah</i> 35.</i> However, he forgot that Scripture employs the term <i>kaspehem</i> (money) (v. 25).<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The singular would be <i>kaspam</i> (Filwarg).</i> 

Verse 26

[AND THEY LADED THEIR ASSES WITH THEIR CORN.] Which they had bought.

Verse 27

AND AS ONE OF THEM OPENED. <i>Va-yiftach ha-echad</i> means, and one of them opened. The reference is possibly to Reuben, as he was the first born. In this case <i>ha-echad</i> (one of them) means the first in number.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The term one (<i>ha-echad</i>) has the definite article prefixed to it. Thus it means the number one or the first one, that is, the eldest. If Scripture had meant one of them, it would have read <i>echad</i>.</i>

Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

THE FAMINE OF YOUR HOUSES. Needed for the famine that is in your houses.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comment on verse 19 and the notes thereto.</i>

Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36

ALL THESE THINGS. AU these troubles.

Verse 37

[THOU SHALT SLAY.] Some say that <i>thou shalt slay</i> means thou shalt punish.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Thou shalt slay</i> is hyperbolic. Reuben did not expect Jacob to kill his grandchildren.</i> Others say that this was a prayer to God.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Reuben directed the words <i>Thou shalt slay</i> to God, as if to say, Lord strike my sons dead <i>if I bring not him to thee</i> (to Jacob). This interpretation, too, seeks to get around the problem of Reuben telling his father to kill his grandchildren if he fails to return Benjamin safely.</i> The sum of the matter is this, if Reuben would have spoken correctly Jacob would not have ignored him.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Had Reuben made sense, Jacob would have responded affirmatively to him (Weiser). Or we should render, if Reuben had spoken correctly then Jacob would not have shushed him by saying, <i>My son shall not go down with you</i> (Krinsky).</i>

Chapter 43



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

BOTH WE. It is Hebrew style to add <i>gam</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew literally reads: <i>gam anachnu</i> (also we), <i>gam attah</i> (also you), <i>gam tappenu</i> (also our little ones).</i> (also) even to the first of a series of items.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gam</i> means also. Hence it does not belong before the first of a series of items. Nevertheless, it is Hebrew style to place <i>gam</i> before the first particular in a series for purposes of emphasis (Weiser).</i> Compare, <i>Rule over us, also</i> (gam) <i>thou, also</i> (gam) <i>thy son, also</i> (gam) <i>thy son’s son</i> (Jud. 8:22).

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

DO THIS. Do according to the following counsel.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zot</i> (this) is feminine. The question thus arises, why did Jacob use the feminine <i>zot asu</i> (do this) rather than the masculine <i>zeh asu</i>? I.E.’s solution is that the word <i>zot</i> refers to <i>etzah</i> (council) which is feminine. It should be noted that <i>etzah</i> is not in the Biblical text (Cherez).</i>
OF THE CHOICE FRUITS OF THE LAND. <i>Zimrat</i> (choice fruits) refers to all types of praiseworthy things. It comes from the same root as <i>zemirot</i> (songs) (Is. 24:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Things that one sings about, things that one praises. Krinsky explains I.E. as meaning the choicest fruits because of which the land is praised.</i>
BALM AND…SPICERY. I have previously explained these terms.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 37:25.</i>
NUTS. <i>Batenim</i> does not appear elsewhere in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Hence we cannot be sure what it means.</i> Some say it means nuts.

Verse 12

DOUBLE. <i>Mishneh</i> means second.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">In addition to the money that you are returning, bring a second sum of money for the purchase of new food (Filwarg).</i>
OVERSIGHT. <i>Mishgeh</i> (oversight) is a noun whose third root letter is a <i>heh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>shin, gimel, heh</i>.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

[AND GOD ALMIGHTY.] This phrase means the one who has the power to do all these things.
IF I BE BEREAVED. As I was bereaved by the death of Joseph, I think that I will be bereaved of all my children.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">According to Krinsky. The verse reads, <i>va-ani ka’asher shakholti shakholti</i>. The literal translation of the latter is, and as for me, as I was bereaved (<i>shakholti</i>), I was bereaved. I.E. explains that the second <i>shakholti</i> although a perfect, is to be rendered as an imperfect Thus our verse reads, and as for me, as I was bereaved, so will I be (I think I will be, I fear I will be) bereaved. He explains it to mean: as I was bereaved of Joseph, I now fear that I will be bereaved of all my children. Cf. I.E.’s commentary on Es. 4:16.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

THAT HE MAY SEEK OCCASION AGAINST US. <i>Le-hitgolel</i> (that he may seek occasion) comes from the same root as <i>bi-gelal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it is similar in meaning to it He is seeking a cause, a reason.</i> in <i>that for</i> (bi-gelel) <i>this thing</i> (Deut. 15:10).
AND FALL UPON US. As a man falls intentionally upon another and then says you tripped me.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">That is, he is seeking to blame us for something we are not guilty of.</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

OH. <i>Bi adoni</i> (Oh, my lord) is a supplicatory expression. I believe it is an abridged statement. It is like, <i>bi ani adoni he-avon</i> (upon me, my lord, upon me be the iniquity) (I Sam. 25:24). <i>Avon</i> (iniquity) here<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">“Here” refers to I Sam. 25:24 and by extension to our verse which is short for <i>bi adoni he-avon</i> (Filwarg). Or “here” refers to our verse in which the word <i>avon</i> is to be inserted (Weiser).</i> has the same meaning as <i>avon</i> in <i>My iniquity</i> (avoni) <i>is greater than I can bear</i> (Gen. 4:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Where <i>avon</i> (iniquity) means punishment. Cf. I.E. comments on Gen. 4:13. Thus <i>bi adoni he-avon</i> means, upon my lord be the punishment.</i> The meaning of <i>bi adoni he-avon</i> is, do to me as you wish but first listen to me.

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

HATH GIVEN YOU TREASURE IN YOUR SACKS. It is possible that someone had a treasure in his house, hid it among the wheat in his storehouse and then forgot about it, and it was placed in your sacks by chance.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">After it was delivered to the royal granaries.</i> This must be the case because I have your money.

Verse 24

INTO JOSEPH’S HOUSE. The <i>heh</i> at the end of <i>betah</i> (into the house of) means to. The latter is Hebrew style.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>heh</i> suffixed to a noun has the same meaning as the preposition <i>el</i> (to) placed before it. Hence <i>betah yosef</i> means into Joseph’s house.</i>

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

IS YOUR FATHER WELL, THE OLD MAN. Our verse has a noun (<i>shalom</i>) in place of an adjective (<i>shalem</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>ha-shalom avikhem</i> (is your father well). I.E. argues that according to the rule of Hebrew grammar the Bible should have read; <i>ha-shalem avikhem</i> and not <i>ha-shalom avikhem</i> since the former means, is your father well (<i>shalem</i>) while the latter means, is your father peace (<i>shalom</i>), an impossible statement. His solution is to suggest that <i>ha-shalom avikhem</i> is short for <i>ha-shalom la avikhem</i>.</i> It is abridged, and should be read as if written, <i>ha-shalom la-avikhem</i> (is your father in peace). <i>Ve-attah shalom</i> (and peace be unto thee) (I Sam. 25:6) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">I Sam. 25:6 reads, <i>ve-attah shalom</i>. According to I.E. it should have read, <i>ve-attah shalem</i> (and thou art well) since <i>shalem</i> is an adjective while <i>shalom</i> is a noun. Hence here, too, the verse is abridged and should be read as if written <i>ve-attah shalom lekha</i>.</i>

Verse 28

AND THEY BOWED THE HEAD. <i>Va-yikkedu</i> (and they bowed the head) means, and they placed their head to the ground. Thus <i>va-yishtachavu</i> (and made obeisance) means, and they had bowed.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture reads, <i>va-yikkedu, va-yishtachavu</i>. I.E. interprets <i>va-yishtachavu</i> as a pluperfect, they had bowed, since the bowing obviously preceded the placing of the head on the ground.</i>

Verse 29

GOD BE GRACIOUS UNTO THEE. <i>Yochnekhah</i> (be gracious unto thee) does not fit into any paradigm.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The word comes from <i>chet, nun, nun</i>. Had it followed the paradigm of Hebrew double <i>ayin</i> roots, it would have been written <i>yechannekha</i>; compare, <i>yechannenu</i> in Ps. 67:2 (Krinsky, Cherez).</i> Perhaps it differs from the usual paradigms because of the <i>chet</i> which is a guttural.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">To simplify its enunciation the <i>kamatz</i> was transferred from the <i>chet</i> to the <i>yod</i> and the <i>dagesh</i> dropped from the <i>nun</i> (Krinsky).</i>

Verse 30

YEARNED. <i>Nikhmeru</i> (yearned) means burned and inflamed, as does <i>nikhmeru</i> (hot) in <i>our skin is hot</i> (nikhmoru) <i>like an oven</i> (Lam. 5:10).

Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33



Verse 34

AND PORTIONS WERE TAKEN. <i>Masot</i> (portions) means gifts.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Not portions of food but gifts (Cherez).</i>
TIMES. <i>Yadot</i> (times) means portions.
AS ANY OF THEIRS. Benjamin’s gifts were five times as great as the gift of any one of the brothers.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">He had five times as much as any individual, not five times as much as all of them together.</i> It is far-fetched to believe that Joseph gave Benjamin five gifts for every gift that he gave to each one of his brothers.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">For this would come to 50 gifts. I.E. comments thus because the Hebrew reads: and Benjamin’s portion was greater than the portions of all of them five times. He interprets <i>kullam</i> (all of them) as meaning, as any of them.</i>

Chapter 44



Verse 1



Verse 2

MY GOBLET. <i>Gavi</i>’a (goblet) means a cup.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

AND WHEREBY HE INDEED DIVINETH. He used this cup to test you to see if you are thieves.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. divineth means tested.</i> <i>Nachesh</i> (divineth) in our verse is similar to <i>nichashti</i> (I have observed the signs) (Gen. 30:27).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">However, in Gen. 30:27 I.E. explains <i>nichashti</i> to mean divines. Weiser explains I.E.’s comment on our verse as meaning tested by divination. However, this is not what I.E. seems to be saying. I.E. was apparently inconsistent.</i> This is also the explanation of <i>know ye not that such a man as I will indeed divine</i> (v. 15).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">That is, a man such as I will test you.</i> Its meaning is, why were you not afraid to steal my goblet? I placed the goblet before you to test you. I looked aside and you stole it.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation <i>bo</i> in <i>ve-hu nachesh yenachesh bo</i> (and whereby he indeed divineth) means whereby, the meaning of the aforementioned being, and whereby he indeed tests.</i> However, Rabbi Jonah says that <i>bo</i> (whereby) means for it. He interprets <i>nachesh yenachesh bo</i> as: he would indeed inquire of diviners for it. Similarly the meaning of <i>I will indeed divine</i> (v. 15) is: a man in my position has diviners. Some say that the cup had designs on it and that Joseph looked at the cup in the presence of his brothers and announced which of them was the oldest and which one was born next.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 92:5. The point being <i>and whereby he divineth</i> and <i>I will indeed divine</i> are to be taken literally. Joseph, of course, did not practice magic. However, his servants and his brothers had no way of knowing this. Also according to this interpretation <i>bo</i> means whereby.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

[CLEAR OURSELVES.] There is a <i>tet</i> in place of the <i>tav</i> of the <i>hitpa’el</i> conjugation in the word <i>nitztaddak</i> (clear ourselves) because the first root letter is a <i>tzadi</i>.
GOD HAS FOUND OUT THE INIQUITY OF THY SERVANTS. They spoke by way of parable.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Found implies that God was unaware of the sin till the present, and he now found it. However, nothing is hidden from the Lord. Hence <i>God found</i> is God, as it were, found (Krinsky).</i> We committed a sin and it was, as it were, lost and long forgotten, but found today. 
Or <i>the iniquity of thy servants</i> means the punishment of thy servants, as in <i>My iniquity is greater than I can bear</i> (Gen. 4:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 4:13. I.E. points out that iniquity (<i>avon</i>) at times has the meaning of punishment.</i>

Verse 17



Verse 18

FOR THOU ART EVEN AS PHARAOH. <i>Ki kha-mokha ke-faro</i> means: thou art as the king<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Pharaoh.</i> and the king is as you. This is true in all instances where two <i>cafs</i> are prefixed to two words following each other.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">As in our verse, <i>ki-kha-mokha ke-faro</i>.</i> Compare, <i>ke-ammi khe-ammekha</i> (my people as thy people) (II Kings 3:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, we have two <i>cafs, ke-ammi khe-ammekha</i> (my people as thy people) which means my people as thy people and thy people as my people.</i> The use of two <i>cafs</i> in this manner is an abridged form.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>ki kha-mokha ke-faro</i> is short for thou art as Pharaoh and Pharaoh is as you.</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

WE HAVE A FATHER, AN OLD MAN. They indicated that their father was an old man because he could have been a relatively young man in view of the fact that the oldest among them was only 45 years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph was at this time 39 years old (see I.E.’s comments on Gen. 37:3 and the notes thereto), and he was six years younger than Reuben since he was born in the 14th year of Jacob’s stay in Laban’s house while Reuben was born in the eighth year of that same stay. Reuben was thus 45 at this time.</i>

Verse 21

THAT I MAY SET MINE EYES UPON HIM. That I may see him.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>That I may set my eyes upon him</i> may be interpreted to mean, that I will take care of him, as in Jer. 24:6 and 39:12, hence I.E.’s comment. See also Nahmanides.</i>

Verse 22

FOR IF HE SHOULD LEAVE HIS FATHER, HIS FATHER WOULD DIE. Why didn’t the one who lists the five undecided verses<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Our text literally reads: For if he should leave his father, “he” would die. The “he” is vague. The Talmudic sage Isi ben Judah (<i>Yoma</i> 92a,b) lists five verses wherein it is impossible to determine concerning what or of whom the verse speaks. Our verse and Ruth 4:8 are not included. I.E. asks, why not. It should be noted that according to Nahmanides’ reading, I.E. explains that the “he” in <i>he would die</i> refers to Jacob. In that case I.E. only questions why Ruth 4:8 is not included in Isi ben Judah’s list.</i> not include our verse and <i>And he drew off his shoe</i> (Ruth 4:8) among them.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">It isn’t clear whether the “he” in <i>And he drew off his shoe</i> refers to Boaz or the near kinsman.</i>

Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

SURELY HE IS TORN IN PIECES. Proof of which is, <i>And I have not seen him since</i>.

Chapter 45



Verse 1

REFRAIN HIMSELF. <i>Le-hitappek</i> (refrain himself) means to bear.
BEFORE ALL THEM THAT STOOD BY HIM. Its meaning is, until all that stood by him left. Joseph was therefore compelled to call and have them withdrawn.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph could not bear to wait until all those in his presence left. He therefore had the hall cleared.</i>

Verse 2

AND HE WEPT ALOUD. The word reads <i>bi-vechi</i> (wept) even though it is a pausal.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">In such cases the word is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i> beneath the first <i>bet</i> and a <i>segol</i> beneath the second <i>bet</i>. Our word is vocalized <i>chirik, sheva</i> (Weiser).</i> <i>Oni</i> (affliction) in <i>I am the man that hath seen affliction</i> (oni) (Lam. 3:1) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Oni</i> in Lam. 3:1 is vocalized with a <i>chataf kamatz</i> even though it is a pausal. At such times the word is usually vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>. Cf. Deut. 16:3. We thus see that Scripture occasionally vocalizes a pausal as a non pausal.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

BUT GOD. Sent me.
A FATHER. A teacher. Father in <i>he was the father of all such as handle the harp and pipe</i> (Gen. 4:21) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Jubal obviously was not the biological father of all harp and pipe players.</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

LEST THOU COME TO POVERTY. <i>Tivvaresh</i> (come to poverty) means thou be cut off. <i>Le-horish</i> in <i>to drive out</i> (le-horish) <i>nations</i> (Deut. 4:38) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that the root <i>yod, resh, shin</i>, which usually means to inherit, can also mean to cut off, to destroy. I.E. renders Deut. 4:38 to destroy nations. He renders our verse, lest thou be destroyed (cut off).</i>

Verse 12

THAT IT IS MY MOUTH. It is well known that <i>peh</i> (mouth) spelled <i>peh, heh</i> is in the absolute. However, when it appears in the construct the silent <i>heh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>heh</i> in <i>peh</i> is not sounded.</i> changes to a silent <i>yod</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Peh</i> becomes <i>pi</i> (my mouth) or <i>fi</i> when the rules of grammar call for the omission of the <i>dagesh</i>. I.E. refers to the <i>yod</i> following a <i>chirik</i> as a silent <i>yod</i>.</i> as in <i>The mouth of</i> (pi) <i>the righteous</i> (Ps. 37:30). The same form (<i>pi</i>) is also used for the plural, as in <i>But the mouth</i> (pi) <i>of the wicked</i> (Prov. 10:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Resha’im</i> (wicked) is in the plural. Thus the <i>mouth of the wicked</i> should be rendered, the mouths of the wicked men (Cherez).</i> Now when the <i>yod</i> that takes the place of the <i>heh</i> comes together with the <i>yod</i> of the first person pronominal suffix, one of the <i>yods</i> is dropped,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">My mouth should be written <i>peh, yod, yod</i>, one <i>yod</i> serving as the first person pronominal suffix and the other substituting for the <i>heh</i>. However, one <i>yod</i> is dropped to simplify enunciation. Thus <i>pi</i> can mean either my mouth or mouth of.</i> as in <i>my mouth</i> (fi) <i>that speaketh</i>. The meaning of <i>my mouth that speaketh unto you</i> is: I speak directly to you in Hebrew without the use of an interpreter.

Verse 13



Verse 14

NECK. Scripture employs both the plural and singular forms for the neck.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The singular of neck is <i>tzavvar</i>. Cf. Is. 8:8 and Jer. 28:10; <i>tzavvare</i> is a plural. However, the plural is occasionally also used for the singular when this noun is employed.</i> We also find the word for neck spelled with a <i>nun</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>tzavveronayikh</i> (thy neck) in Cant. 4:9.</i> However, its <i>alef</i> is never dropped.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser. The problem is that there is no <i>alef</i> in <i>tzavveronayikh</i>. Filwarg suggests that in I.E.’s copy of the Bible <i>tzavveronayikh</i> had an <i>alef</i>. Also, Kimchi in his book of roots says that <i>tzavveronayikh</i> is spelled with an <i>alef</i>. Weiser suggests that what I.E. means is that <i>tzavveronayikh</i> should have been written with an <i>alef</i> but for some reason it was dropped.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

LADE. <i>Ta’anu</i> means load. The word <i>meto’ane</i> in <i>thrust through</i> (meto’ane) <i>with the sword</i> (Is. 14:19) is close in meaning to it.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. renders this, laden with wounds of the sword (Krinsky). It is noteworthy that in Isaiah, I.E. says that it is farfetched to connect <i>ta’anu</i> to <i>meto’ane</i>; therefore he connects <i>meto’ane</i> with an Arabic word meaning pierced.</i>
BEASTS. <i>Be’irekhem</i> means your cattle. <i>Be’irenu</i> in <i>we and our cattle</i> (u-ve-irenu) (Num. 20:4) is similar.

Verse 18

THE FAT OF THE LAND. Its meaning is <i>shuman ha’aretz</i> (fat of the land).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">What I.E. apparently intends to say is that since the choicest part of an animal is its <i>shuman</i> (fat), it follows that the <i>fat of the land</i> is a metaphor for the best of the land (Weiser).</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

CHANGES OF RAIMENT. Two garments, each different from the other, two being the minimum for a plural.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chalifot semalot</i> (changes of raiment) is in the plural. The minimum of the plural is two. Hence two garments are implied. Had Scripture intended more than two their number would have been listed, as in the case of Benjamin. <i>Chalifot</i> (changes) implies each garment was different from the other. He didn’t give them two identical garments (Cherez).</i>

Verse 23

[IN LIKE MANNER.] That is, of the finest changes of raiment<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ke-zot</i> (in like manner) not only applies to what follows but also to what comes before, viz., garments (Weiser). Or <i>ke-zot</i> applies only to what comes before; i.e., the verse is to be understood: And to his father he sent in like manner ten asses laden with the good things of Egypt, viz., the finest changes of raiment that were found in Egypt (Cherez).</i> that were found in Egypt.
CORN. <i>Bar</i> (corn) means grain.
AND BREAD. That is to be taken literally.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Lechem</i> (bread) can mean food, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>
AND VICTUAL. The term <i>mazon</i> (victual) refers to peas, beans, lentils, millet, spelt, figs, raisins and dates, for only these, excluding wheat<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. reads <i>dagan</i> (grain) but he means wheat (Weiser).</i> and barley, are termed <i>mazon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Wheat and barley are not deemed <i>mazon</i> but <i>bar</i> (Krinsky, Filwarg).</i>

Verse 24

[SEE THAT YE FALL NOT OUT BY THE WAY.] Don’t be angry with each other because of my being sold into slavery.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. renders <i>tirgizu</i> (fall out) as be angry (Cherez); i.e., don’t be angry and thus quarrel with each other, the idea being, don’t be angry that you sold me and thus quarrel with each other about who was responsible. It should be noted that in Ps. 4:5 I.E. renders <i>rigzu</i> as fear.</i>

Verse 25



Verse 26

AND HIS HEART FAINTED. <i>Va-yafag</i> (fainted) comes from the same root as <i>fugat</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">That is, stop.</i> in <i>Give thyself no respite</i> (fugat) (Lam. 2:18). It means his heart stopped and was still. It has the same meaning as <i>and his heart died within him</i> (I Sam. 25:37). Jacob reacted in this manner because he didn’t believe them.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob reacted in this manner because what his sons said reminded him that Joseph was dead.</i> However, when he saw the wagons, his spirit revived. Do not be surprised at the term <i>his heart stopped</i> for it is the style of the prophets to speak in hyperbole. Compare, <i>neither was there breath left in me</i> (Dan. 10:17).

Verse 27



Verse 28

IT IS ENOUGH; JOSEPH MY SON IS YET ALIVE. This happiness is enough for me.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads, <i>Enough, Joseph my son is yet alive</i>. I.E. suggests that enough is short for “this happiness is enough for me” (Weiser). What Jacob was saying was, I am not concerned with the fact that he is a ruler over Egypt; the fact that he is alive is joy enough for me (Krinsky). Cherez suggests rendering I.E., I have great happiness since Joseph is yet alive.</i>

Chapter 46



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

TO GO DOWN. <i>Me-redah</i> (to go down) is an infinitive. Its first root letter is missing.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Me-redah</i> is made up of the infinitive <i>redah</i> (go down) plus the prepositional <i>mem</i>. The root of <i>redah</i> is <i>yod, resh, dalet</i>.</i> <i>Me-redah</i> is similar to <i>tenah</i> in <i>Whose majesty is rehearsed</i> (tenah) <i>above the heavens</i> (Ps. 8:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>tenah</i> is <i>nun, tet, nun</i>. Both <i>redah</i> (whose <i>yod</i> is missing) and <i>tenah</i> (whose <i>nun</i> is missing) are infinitives whose first root letters are missing.</i>

Verse 4

[AND I WILL ALSO SURELY BRING THEE UP AGAIN.] This means you will be buried in the land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob never came back from Egypt. Hence I.E. interprets our verse as referring to Jacob’s body.</i>
AND JOSEPH SHALL PUT HIS HAND UPON THINE EYES. At the time of your death. It is customary for the living to close the eyes of the deceased upon their death.

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

HIS DAUGHTERS. This refers only to Dinah.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob had no other daughters.</i> It is possible that Dinah had maid servants of her own age who grew up with her in Jacob’s house and who because of Dinah are called Jacob’s daughters. Jacob’s “daughters” can be compared to Michal’s “children” (II Sam. 21:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Michal’s “children” were in fact the children of Merab. Scripture refers to them as Michal’s children because she raised them. Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i>. 19b. See also I.E.’s comments on Gen. 36:2 and the notes thereto.</i> The same interpretation is to be given to <i>and his sons’ daughters</i> since Jacob had only one granddaughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Serah, the daughter of Asher (v. 17). There, too, “daughters” refers to the maid-servants who grew up with her.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

THE SON OF A CANAANITISH WOMAN. This proves that Jacob’s sons married Aramean, Egyptian, Edomite and Midianite women.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that Scripture singles out Shaul as being the son of a Canaanitish woman indicates that only he was the son of a Canaanitish woman, but not the others mentioned here. That Simeon did wrong in marrying her is obvious since Abraham told his servant not to take a Canaanitish woman for Isaac, and Isaac told the same to Jacob.</i> Shaul’s mother’s nationality is singled out in order to indicate that Simeon did wrong in marrying a Canaanitish woman. It is for this reason that Scripture records the death of Er and Onan (v. 12). Scripture records their demise in order to indicate that they died because they were the sons of a Canaanitish woman (Gen. 38:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The Canaanite women were evil. Er and Onan followed in their mother’s footsteps and were punished by God. Scripture thus mentions their death as an object lesson (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

AND NAAMAN. This Naaman was a son of Benjamin. I note this because Benjamin also had a grandson called Naaman (Num. 26:40).

Verse 22



Verse 23

AND THE SONS OF DAN: HUSHIM. It is possible that Dan had two sons and one of them died and Scripture did not mention him.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture says “sons” but lists only one son, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It is also possible that the verse employs “sons” for stylistic reasons.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Since Scripture used <i>sons of</i> with regard to the other children, it employs the same form here for the sake of consistency (Weiser). Nahmanides (v. 7) writes, “It is Biblical style to refer to an individual in the plural form when mentioning the genealogy of any people. For example, <i>And the sons of Dan: Hushim</i>; (Gen. 46:23) <i>And of the sons of Palu: Eliab</i> (Num. 26:8).” This is apparently what I.E. had in mind (Krinsky).</i> 

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

[ALL THE SOULS OF THE HOUSE OF JACOB, THAT CAME INTO EGYPT, WERE THREESCORE AND TEN.] An exegate says that <i>three score and ten</i> is a round number, since in fact they numbered sixty-nine.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The names of Jacob’s descendants listed in our chapter come to 69, not 70.</i> However, this commentator erred, since we find Scripture stating, with regard to Leah’s offspring who numbered thirty-two, <i>all the souls of his sons and daughters were thirty and three</i> (v. 15). <sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 8-14 list the children of Leah and their offspring. Thirty-two individuals are listed by name. However, in giving their total Scripture says they were thirty-three. Now 70 is a round number with regard to 69. However, 33 is not a round number with regard to 32. It should be noted that it is the one person missing from the list of Leah’s offspring that is missing from our list of 70; i.e., if Leah’s thirty-three were listed here, we would have 70.</i> The Midrash tries to solve the problem by saying that Jochebed was born between the ramparts when they entered Egypt. <sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Baba Batra</i> 123a-b. The point being that when Jacob was going down to Egypt, Jochebed was yet in her mother’s womb and could not be counted as a person. However, as soon as the Israelites come to Egypt she was born. Hence 70 descendants of Jacob came to Egypt.</i> However, this, too, presents a problem, viz., why doesn’t Scripture record the great wonder of Jochebed giving birth to Moses when she was one hundred and thirty years old?<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">According to Talmudic tradition the Israelites were in Egypt for 210 years (<i>Seder Olam</i>). Moses was 80 at the time of the Exodus (Ex. 7:7); thus Moses was born 130 years after the descent into Egypt. If his mother was born at the beginning of the descent then she had to be 130 years old at the time of Moses’ birth.</i> Furthermore, why does Scripture note that Sarah was ninety when she bore a son?<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">When the Torah doesn’t see fit to note that Jochebed was 130 when she brought a child into the world.</i> And as if we didn’t have enough problems with the above, the liturgical poets composed a hymn for Simchat Torah reading, <i>Jochebed my mother will be comforted after me</i> thereby indicating that Jochebed was two hundred and fifty years old at the time of Moses’ death.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">If this is really so, why wasn’t Jochebed’s longevity mentioned in Scripture?</i> As to the Midrash which states that Ahijah the Shilonite lived for hundreds of years,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Baba Batra</i> 121b and <i>Seder Olam</i> 1. There it is stated that the prophet Ahijah, who prophesied during the reign of King Jeroboam, saw Amram the father of Moses. Ahijah thus lived close to 600 years. This is therefore a greater miracle than that of Jochebed, and yet Scripture doesn’t mention it. Hence this Midrash can serve as support for the liturgical poets that Scripture omits certain miracles (Cherez). Krinsky explains that the liturgical poets can argue that if Ahijah could live 600 years, why is it hard to believe that Jochebed was still alive at the time of Moses’ death?</i> it is an aggadic statement or an individual opinion.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">It is therefore not binding and cannot be offered as proof.</i> I believe that the way to solve our problem is by recognizing the fact that the Bible includes Jacob among the seventy who came into Egypt and starts the count of the seventy from him. The verse (15) is to be interpreted as if it read: all the souls of his sons and his daughters plus himself were thirty-three. Proof that this is the way to interpret this verse is that Scripture previously states, <i>And these are the names of the children of Israel, who came into Egypt, Jacob and his sons</i> (v. 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that Jacob is included in the number of those who came to Egypt.</i> Should one argue and say, “Does not Scripture explicitly state, <i>And all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were seventy souls</i> (Ex. 1:5)?<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob obviously cannot be included in those that came out of his loins.</i> Know that Scripture isn’t concerned with noting that one of the seventy did not come from Jacob’s loins, as it didn’t bother to leave out Benjamin when it said, <i>These are the sons of Jacob, that were born to him in Paddan-aram</i> (Gen. 35:26), even though Benjamin was not born there. We have two proofs in our own Torah portion that this is the style of Scripture. First, the Pentateuch states, <i>And these are the names of the children of Israel, who came into Egypt, Jacob and his sons</i> (v. 8). The Torah thus includes Jacob among the sons of Israel. It does so because Scripture speaks of the majority of those who came to Egypt. Secondly, Scripture states, <i>all the souls of the house of Jacob, that came into Egypt, were three score and ten</i> (Gen. 46:27). However, Manasseh and Ephraim did not come into Egypt, they were there to begin with, having been born in Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Yet Scripture lists them among those who came to Egypt (v. 20).</i> In the same vein another verse<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">So <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38.</i> reads, <i>Thy fathers went down into Egypt with three score and ten souls</i> (Deut. 10:22).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nefesh</i> has been translated as souls, in keeping with I.E.’s translation.</i> However, as noted, Manasseh and Ephraim did not go down to Egypt. This verse<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is either to verse 27 (Krinsky) or both verse 27 and Deut. 10:22 (Cherez), or possibly only to Deut. 10:22.</i> is also proof that Jacob is counted among the seventy, for he had a soul<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>All the souls of the house of Jacob, that came into Egypt, were three score and ten</i>. Since Jacob had a soul he is included in the souls that came into Egypt and similarly with Deut. 10:22.</i> and he was the most important of them all.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Hence it is unlikely that he would not be included in the number of those that went down (Weiser).</i>

Verse 28



Verse 29

AND JOSEPH MADE READY HIS CHARIOT. Joseph commanded it ready.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">A man of Joseph’s position would not personally make ready his chariot, hence I.E.’s comment. However, since he commanded that his chariot be made ready it is as if he himself did it.</i> <i>So Solomon built the house, and finished it</i> (I Kings 6:14),<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Solomon obviously did not personally build the house. He ordered it built.</i> is similar.

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33



Verse 34

FOR EVERY SHEPHERD IS AN ABOMINATION UNTO THE EGYPTIANS. This verse shows that in those days the Egyptians did not eat meat and they did not permit anyone to slaughter sheep. This is still the custom among the Indians. The Egyptians considered shepherds an abomination because they drank milk.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Although the Egyptians allowed shepherds in their country, they did not allow them to slaughter sheep. However, they permitted them to drink milk, although they detested them for it.</i> The people of India until this very day do not eat or drink anything derived from a living creature.

Chapter 47



Verse 1

IN THE LAND OF GOSHEN. The land of Goshen refers to the entire land, <i>the land of Rameses</i> (v. 11) to an area within it.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In our verse we are told that the Israelites lived in the land of Goshen. However, verse 11 tells us that they lived in the land of Rameses. I.E. solves this discrepancy by explaining that the land of Goshen was divided into a number of subdivisions one of which was called Rameses (Weiser). Thus the Israelites dwelt both in the land of Rameses and in the land of Goshen.</i> The <i>ayin</i> in Rameses is vocalized with a quiescent <i>sheva</i>. I believe that the city Raamses (Ex. 1:11) which is vocalized with a <i>pattach</i> beneath the <i>ayin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Rameses and Raamses have identical consonants. They differ only with regard to the vocalization of the <i>ayin</i>.</i> is not to be identified with the Rameses in which the Israelites dwelt, for Raamses was one of the store cities that the Israelites built for Pharaoh.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">It was not even in existence when the Israelites came to Egypt.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

RULERS OVER MY CATTLE. Such as horses and mules.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains thus because he held that the Egyptians did not keep sheep. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 46:34 (Cherez).</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13

LANGUISHED. <i>Va-telah</i> (languished) follows the paradigm of <i>va-teta</i> (and strayed) (Gen. 21:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>va-tela</i> is <i>lamed, heh, heh</i>. The root of <i>va-teta</i> is <i>tav, ayin, heh</i>. Both words drop the final root letter and are similarly vocalized.</i> Similarly <i>ke-mitlahle’ah</i> (as a madman) (Prov. 26:18) is like <i>ki-metate’ah</i> (as a mocker) (Gen. 27:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Both of these words also follow similar patterns in their quadriliteral form. In Prov. 26:18 and in Gen. 27:12 these words appear as quadriliteral; i.e., their first root letters are similarly doubled forming the stems <i>lamed, heh, lamed, heh</i> and <i>tav ayin, tav ayin</i>.</i> Its meaning is, the land was like a person who has lost his wits.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Its inhabitants couldn’t think clearly because of exhaustion (Krinsky). Thus according to I.E. <i>va-telah</i> means crazed. Cf. I.E. on Prov. 26:18 and Kimchi on our verse.</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15

WAS ALL SPENT. <i>Va-yittom</i> (was all spent) comes from a root whose second and third letters are identical.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>tav, mem, mem</i> and it is a <i>kal</i> (Filwarg).</i> It is similar to <i>va-yiddom</i> (stood still) in <i>And the sun stood still</i> (va-yiddom) (Josh. 10:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>dalet, mem, mem</i>. It, too, is a <i>kal</i> (Filwarg).</i>

Verse 16

GIVE. According to the rules of Hebrew grammar the <i>heh</i> of <i>havu</i> should have been vocalized with a <i>chataf pattach</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>havu</i> is <i>yod, heh, bet</i>. Such a word drops its first root letter in the plural masculine imperative and its second root letter is vocalized with a <i>sheva</i>. Compare, <i>yada</i> and <i>yatza</i> which in the imperative plural masculine become <i>de</i>’u and <i>tze</i>’u. Thus <i>havu</i> should have a <i>chataf pattach</i> beneath the <i>heh</i>. However, it does not. The <i>heh</i> is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i>. It is therefore irregular.</i>
IF MONEY FAIL. <i>Afes</i> (fail) is a perfect.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">A third person perfect is usually vocalized <i>kamatz, pattach</i>. However, some words are conjugated according to the paradigm of <i>pa’el</i>. These words are vocalized <i>kamatz, tzere</i> both in the third person masculine perfect and in the present tense. Thus <i>afes</i> can either be a perfect or a participle, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It is similar to the word <i>yare</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See above note. I.E. points out that <i>yare</i> is a third person masculine perfect.</i> in <i>for he feared</i> (yare) <i>to dwell in Zoar</i> (Gen. 19:30).

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

[WHEREFORE SHOULD WE DIE…BOTH WE AND OUR LAND.] One should not be surprised that the Bible employs the term death to the land. We also find the reverse in <i>Thou hast made heaven, the heaven of heavens, with all their host, the earth and all things that are thereon…and Thou givest them all life</i> (Neh. 9:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Translated according to I.E. In this verse we find life, which is the opposite of death, applied to heaven and earth.</i>
BE NOT DESOLATE. <i>Tesham</i> (be desolate) comes from the same root as <i>tishamenah</i> in <i>and the high places shall be desolate</i> (tishamenah) (Ezek. 6:6). <i>Tesham</i> follows the paradigm of <i>teda</i> (she will know).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. the root of <i>tesham</i> is <i>yod, shin, mem</i> (Filwarg). The <i>yod</i> drops out and the letters prefixed to the root which indicate that the word is an imperfect are vocalized with a <i>tzere</i>, as in the case of the imperfect of the word <i>yada</i> from the root <i>yod, dalet, ayin</i>.</i> The Midrash tells us that the hunger ceased because of Jacob’s merit.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 89:11. See also <i>Tosephta, Sotah</i> 10, “Before Jacob came down to Egypt there was a famine there…after he came there Scripture tells us, <i>Then Joseph said unto the people…Lo, here is seed for you, and ye shall sow the land. And it shall come to pass at the ingatherings</i> (Gen. 47:23-24), which indicates that the famine ceased.”</i> However, it is possible that the hunger lasted for seven years but that it was less intense in the final three years than during the first four years.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. wants to reconcile the Midrash with Joseph’s prophecy that there would be seven years of hunger. He does so by accepting the fact that there were seven years of hunger and interprets the Midrashic statement as meaning that the hunger eased. It should be noted that <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 has the reading: “The Midrash tells us that the hunger ceased because of Jacob’s merit. This is possible. It is also possible that the hunger continued during the last three years of the famine but that it was less intense than during the first four years.” According to Weiser, I.E. is of the opinion that Joseph’s collection of the money (v. 14 and 15); of the cattle (v. 16 and 17); and of buying the land (v. 18 and 19) took place successively during the last three years of the famine and that it eased during these years. For another interpretation see Filwarg, Weiser and Krinsky.</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21

AND AS FOR THE PEOPLE, HE REMOVED THEM. He uprooted each and every Egyptian from his place.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>ve-et ha-am he-evir oto le-arim</i> (And as for the people, he removed them city by city). <i>Am</i> (people) is a plural. <i>Oto</i> (him) is a singular, hence I.E.’s interpretation (Krinsky). This is the way I.E. explains the combination of singulars and plurals.</i> Some say that Scripture speaks of the people of Egypt’s main city. Joseph removed them from the capital to villages so that they would till the soil.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ve-et ha-am he-evir oto le-arim</i> literally means: And as for the people, he removed them to the cities, hence I.E.’s second interpretation.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

THE PRIESTS. This is to be rendered as Onkelos does.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders <i>kohanim</i> pagan priests.</i>

Verse 27

AND THEY GOT THEM POSSESSIONS THEREIN. They bought property with title.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The text reads, <i>va-ye’achazu vah</i> (and they got them possessions therein). <i>Va-ye’achazu</i> is a denominative of <i>achuzah</i> which means property with a title.</i>

Verse 28



Verse 29

AND JACOB LIVED. The terms <i>put, I pray thee, thy hand under my thigh</i> and <i>kindly and truly</i> have been explained in the account dealing with Eliezer.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 27:2 and 24:49.</i>

Verse 30

BUT WHEN I SLEEP WITH MY FATHERS. This is a euphemism for death.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation the verse reads, <i>But when I die (when I sleep with my fathers), thou shalt carry me out of Egypt, and bury me in their burying-place</i>.</i> Or it may mean: bury me not, I pray thee, in Egypt (v. 29), but I will sleep (be buried) with my fathers.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation, <i>ve-shakhavti im avotai</i> (but when I sleep with my fathers) means, but I will be buried with my fathers.</i> The latter will come to pass because thou shalt carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their burying place.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>But when I sleep with my fathers, thou shalt carry me out of Egypt, and bury me in their burying place</i>. If <i>ve-shakhavti im avotai</i> (but when I sleep with my fathers) means I will be buried with my fathers, then the verse is redundant, hence I.E.’s interpretation.</i>

Verse 31

AND ISRAEL BOWED DOWN. He payed homage to Joseph because he held royal position. However, I believe it means he bowed to God in praise. Our verse is different from the verse which records the bowing of Abraham (Gen. 23:7), for in the latter case it is explicitly stated that Abraham bowed to the children of Heth.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 23:7 tells us that Abraham bowed before the children of Heth. Some interpret that verse to mean that Abraham bowed before God. I.E. on Gen. 23:6 rejects that interpretation on the grounds that Scripture explicitly states, <i>And Abraham rose up, and bowed down to the people of the land, even to the children of Heth</i>. However, here Scripture does not explicitly state that Jacob bowed down to Joseph. Hence we may interpret that Jacob bowed to God. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 23:6 and the notes thereto.</i>

Chapter 48



Verse 1

THAT ONE SAID TO JOSEPH. Someone said to Joseph.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The subject of <i>va-yomer</i> (and he said) is omitted.</i> <i>Whom she bore to Levi in Egypt</i> (Num. 26:59) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture similarly omits the subject. The translation of Num. 26:59 is a literal one.</i>

Verse 2

AND ONE TOLD JACOB. Someone told Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The subject of <i>va-yagged</i> (and he told) is omitted.</i> Or it may refer to the one who said to Joseph, <i>Behold, thy father is sick</i>. On the other hand, he may have been a messenger sent by Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And he told</i> refers to a messenger sent by Jacob to Joseph requesting that he come to see him. This messenger came back <i>and he told Jacob…Behold, thy son Joseph cometh unto thee</i>.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4

[BEHOLD, I WILL MAKE THEE FRUITFUL.] According to Saadiah Gaon Jacob told Joseph: God appeared to me and told me, <i>Behold I will make thee fruitful</i>. However, following this promise I had no other children, and Rachel died. I now know that the Divine promise of <i>Behold, I will make thee fruitful</i> was said concerning your children.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>Ephraim and Manasseh…shall be mine</i> (v. 5).</i> This interpretation is totally unpalatable. What difference is there between Joseph’s children and Reuben’s children?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">How did Jacob know the promise referred to Joseph’s children and not to Reuben’s children when both are his descendants and the Divine promise, <i>Behold, I will make thee fruitful</i> could apply to both?</i> Furthermore, Benjamin was born after this prophetic vision.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The vision in which God told Jacob, <i>Behold, I will make thee fruitful</i>, is recorded in Gen. 35:9-16. Benjamin’s birth follows immediately in verse 18. Hence it may refer to him.</i> I believe that Jacob told Joseph the following: “God appeared to me and told me that the land of Canaan will be <i>an everlasting possession</i> for my children. I now give you a first born’s share<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Since the land was given to me, I may pass it on as I see fit.</i> in this land. Therefore let Ephraim and Manasseh share in the land in the same manner as Reuben and Simeon, my two eldest sons (v. 5). However, any children that will be born to you in addition to Ephraim and Manasseh<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Viz., <i>And thy issue, that thou begettest after them</i>. I.E. explains <i>holadta</i> (literally, you begat) as an imperfect, you will beget.</i> shall be called after the name of their just noted brothers, namely, they will receive their inheritance among them (v. 6).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">They will be included in the Ephraimites and Manassites.</i> I take issue with the one who interprets <i>And thy issue, that thou begettest after them</i> (v. 6) as referring to the children of Machir the son of Manasseh who <i>were born upon Joseph’s knees</i> (Gen. 50:23). If his interpretation is correct, why does Scripture say, <i>they shall be called after the name of their brethren in their inheritance</i> (v. 6)?<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Machir’s children received Machir’s share in the land. Hence Scripture should have stated “after the name of their father” in their inheritance.</i> And what if one argues, but we do not find that Joseph had any other children after Manasseh and Ephraim?<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">If Scripture tells us, <i>and thy issue, that thou begettest after them</i>, then it must be true. If we cannot apply it to Joseph’s sons other than Manasseh and Ephraim, since he had no others, then the Bible must be referring to grandchildren.</i> It is not convincing. It is quite possible that Joseph had additional children but they are not mentioned because they received their inheritance among their brothers.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Since they were included in the tribes of Manasseh and Ephraim, there was no reason to mention them.</i> There are many other such instances in Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Where names were left out because they had no significance.</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

[AND AS FOR ME, WHEN I CAME FROM PADDAN.] Rachel died suddenly and I was not able to transport her to the cave of Machpelah and inter her there, as I did with Leah. Jacob told this to Joseph so that he would not be angry with him for requesting that he do for him what he didn’t do for his mother.

Verse 8

[AND ISRAEL BEHELD JOSEPH’S SONS.] After stating in our verse, <i>And Israel beheld Joseph’s sons</i>, how could Scripture go on to say, <i>Now the eyes of Israel were dim for age, so that he could not see</i> (v. 10)? The answer is, <i>so that he could not see</i> means he was not able to see clearly and recognize their faces.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

[I HAD NOT THOUGHT.] <i>Pillalti</i> (I thought) means, my mind never judged that I would ever see you. It comes from the same root as <i>pelilim</i> (judges) (Deut. 32:31).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>peh, lamed, lamed</i>.</i>

Verse 12

AND JOSEPH BROUGHT THEM OUT FROM BETWEEN HIS KNEES. This verse should have followed <i>And he blessed them that day</i>, etc. (v. 20).<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">So Krinsky, Weiser and Cherez. The point being that Manesseh and Ephraim were between Joseph’s knees until the conclusion of the blessing. Hence our verse should have followed verse 20. However, the problem remains, why is this verse misplaced? Filwarg interprets I.E. as saying that Scripture first summarizes what transpired during the blessing and then goes into detail, that is, Scripture in verses 9-12 tells us that Joseph brought his children to Jacob and that Jacob placed them between his knees, kissed them and blessed them and that Joseph took them from between his knees, and bowed in gratitude before his father for blessing his children. Then in verses 13-20 the Bible tells us exactly what transpired during the blessing.</i>
[FROM BETWEEN HIS KNEES.] Jacob sat on the edge of the bed.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob sat on the edge of the bed with his feet on the ground and Manasseh and Ephraim were between his knees (Cherez).</i> 

Verse 13

AND JOSEPH TOOK THEM BOTH. Its meaning is: And Joseph had taken them both.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">In other words <i>va-yikkach</i> (took) is a pluperfect that means had taken. In verse 9 we are told that Jacob told Joseph, <i>Bring them (your sons), I pray thee, unto me, and I will bless them</i>. Verse 10, while stating that Jacob kissed them, does not state that Joseph brought them to his father. This is stated in verse 13. Filwarg in keeping with his interpretation of I.E., viz., that verses 9-12 summarize what happened and verses 13-20 tell in detail what occurred, interprets as follows: Scripture is about to relate the details of the blessing. It begins by telling that Joseph had brought his children to his father in the following manner, Ephraim in his right hand and Manasseh in his left hand.</i> I have already noted many other such instances.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Of the pluperfect in Scripture. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:9.</i>

Verse 14

GUIDING HIS HANDS WITTINGLY. His hands, as it were, understood what he wanted to do.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads: <i>sikkel et yadov</i>, which literally means, he imparted wisdom to his hands. Hence his hands “understood” his intentions.</i>
FOR MANASSEH WAS THE FIRST-BORN. <i>Even though</i> (ki) <i>Manasseh was the first-born</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>ki</i> (for) is to be rendered even though, i.e., Jacob placed his left hand upon Manasseh’s head even though Manasseh was the first born.</i> The word <i>ki</i> in <i>O Lord, let the Lord…go in the midst of us, even though</i> (ki) <i>it is a stiff-necked people</i> (Ex. 34:9) is similar. There are many similar instances.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Where the word <i>ki</i> has the meaning of even though.</i> 

Verse 15



Verse 16

[THE ANGEL WHO HATH REDEEMED ME.] The meaning of this will be found in the Torah portion <i>Ve-eleh shemot</i> (Ex. 23:20).
AND LET MY NAME BE NAMED IN THEM. All of Israel will be called Ephraim<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible refers to Israel as Ephraim in Hos. 7:1; 10:6; 11:3; 12:1; and Jer. 31-20. According to I.E. <i>and let my name be named in them</i> means that all of Israel will be called Ephraim. Nachmanides objects. He argues that if this were the interpretation they would also be called by the name of Manasseh since the text reads, <i>in them</i>.</i> and Joseph.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The Bible refers to Israel as Joseph in Ps. 80:2; 81:6; and Zech. 10:6.</i> Scripture also states, <i>A voice is heard in Ramah, lamentation, and bitter weeping, Rachel weeping for her children; she refuseth to be comforted for her children, Because they are not</i> (Jer. 31:15),<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The children of the other matriarchs also went into exile. However, the Bible mentions only Rachel weeping for her children. We thus see that all of Israel is called after Rachel’s children.</i> because Jacob considered Rachel to be his true mate.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads, <i>ikkar machasahvto</i>, the main one of his thoughts. Rachel was the one Jacob originally wanted to marry and the one whom he loved. It was only due to circumstances that he married Leah, Bilhah and Zilpah.</i> Hence Scripture says, <i>The sons of Rachel Jacob’s wife</i> (Gen. 46:19).<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Jacob’s wife</i> is an appellation not used with reference to any of Jacob’s other wives.</i> Similarly, as soon as Rachel bore a son, Jacob said to Laban, <i>Send me away, that I may go unto mine own place, and to my country</i> (Gen. 30:25). He also gave the birthright to Joseph because he was the first born of his true mate. When Reuben showed himself unfit for the birthright he transferred it to Joseph who was Rachel’s first born, rather than to Dan or Gad because they were sons of the handmaidens.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Dan was Bilhah’s first born (Gen. 30:6). Gad was Zilpah’s first born (Gen. 30:11). Jacob thus gave the birthright to Joseph even though Dan and Gad were older than Joseph and were first born. He did this because Joseph was the first born of Rachel and they of handmaidens.</i> [17. HIS RIGHT HAND.] The right hand is more honored and is stronger than the left.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser.</i>

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

A MULTITUDE OF NATIONS. Many nations shall descend from him<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>melo ha-goyim</i>. Its literal translation is, a fullness of the nations. I.E. points out that <i>melo</i> (fullness) is to be rendered as many, a multitude. Filwarg asks, “Who were the many nations descended from Ephraim?”</i>

Verse 20

BY THEE SHALL ISRAEL BLESS. All the Israelites.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Israel here doesn’t refer to Jacob but to all of Jacob’s descendants (Krinsky).</i>
AND HE SET EPHRAIM BEFORE MANASSEH. In the enunciation of the blessing.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Viz., “God make thee as Ephraim and as Manasseh.”</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22

ONE PORTION. Some say that <i>shekhem</i> (portion) alludes to the city of Shechem which was in the portion of the land allotted to Joseph. 
<i>With my sword and with my bow</i> refers to God, as in David’s statement, <i>The lord is my rock…My shield and my horn of salvation</i> (Ps. 18:3; II Sam. 22:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">That is, with the help of God, who is my sword and bow.</i> However, I believe that <i>shekhem</i> means a portion and <i>shekhem echad</i> is to be rendered one portion. The word <i>shekhem</i> is related to the words <i>shikhmam</i> (their shoulders) and <i>shekhem</i> (shoulder) in, <i>upon their shoulders</i> (shichmam) (Ex. 12:34), and <i>To serve Him with one consent</i> (shekhem echad) (Zeph. 3:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">A portion is called a <i>shekhem</i> (shoulder) because the shoulder is a part of the body (Filwarg).</i>
ABOVE THY BRETHREN. More than thy brethren.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is to Joseph’s receiving a double portion in the land of Canaan (Filwarg).</i>
[WHICH I TOOK.] Its meaning is: which the Israelites will take with their sword and with their bow.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob will conquer the land via his children. I.E. holds that <i>lakachti</i> (took), a perfect, is to be understood as an imperfect, viz., will take. I.E. later explains why Jacob used a perfect.</i> Jacob singled out the Amorites because there were none among the seven Canaanite nations equal in strength to them. Observe, after the two mighty Amorite kings were slain<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Sihon and Og. Cf. Num. 21:21ff.</i> Joshua said (Josh. 7:7), <i>Alas, O Lord God, wherefore hast Thou at all brought this people over the Jordan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">After defeating Sihon and Og.</i> <i>to deliver us into the hand of the Amorites</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that Joshua referred to all of Canaan as the land of the Amorite.</i> <i>to cause us to perish</i>? Jacob’s statement, <i>Which I took</i>, presents no problems<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">If Jacob was speaking of the future, why did he use the perfect <i>lakachti</i> (took)?</i> because the Patriarchs considered the land as theirs from the moment that God verbally gave it to Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Once God promised it to the patriarchs they were sure that they would inherit it. Hence it was as good as already taken (Ralbag).</i> God similarly gave it to Jacob, as we read, <i>The land whereon thou liest, to thee will I give it, and to thy seed</i> (Gen. 28:13).

Chapter 49



Verse 1

THAT WHICH SHALL BEFALL YOU. Prophecies foretelling that which shall befall you in the future. Those who base themselves on Scripture’s closing remark, <i>and this is that their father spoke unto them and blessed them</i> (v. 28), and conclude that they (Jacob’s words) are blessings, err.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Since Scripture concludes with <i>and this is that their father spoke unto them and blessed them</i> (v. 28), it implies that what precedes are blessings.</i> For if it were so, where are the blessings of Reuben, Simeon and Levi?<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">These three sons were castigated, not blessed.</i> The way to understand <i>and this is that their father spoke unto them and blessed them</i> is as follows: and this (v. 3-27) is what their father spoke unto them by way of prophecy after which he blessed them. Scripture omits the blessings.

Verse 2



Verse 3

REUBEN, THOU ART MY FIRST-BORN, MY MIGHT, AND THE FIRST-FRUITS OF MY STRENGTH. My might was first seen in thee. The first-born is called the first of one’s strength. We find an identical expression in <i>And smote all the first-born in Egypt, The first-fruits of their strength in the tents of Ham</i> (Ps. 78:51).
THE EXCELLENCY OF DIGNITY. You were suited by virtue of being first-born for the advantage of being exalted above all your brothers.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. translates <i>yeter se’et</i> (the excellency of dignity) as the advantage (<i>yeter</i>) of rank (<i>se’et</i>) and interprets accordingly. It should be noted that <i>se’et</i> comes from the root <i>nun, sin, alef</i>, meaning raised up or exalted.</i>
AND THE EXCELLENCY OF POWER. This means the same as <i>The excellency of dignity</i>. It is prophetic style to repeat the same idea in different words.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. translates our line: The advantage of rank / the advantage of power. The first in rank has dominion over those below him, hence power is parallel to rank and the advantage of power means the same as the advantage of rank. Modem scholars refer to this as synonymous parallelism. The latter is a feature of Biblical poetry.</i> The meaning of <i>oz</i> is power.

Verse 4

UNSTABLE. Because you acted unstably as water does.
HAVE NOT THOU THE EXCELLENCY. (Some say) that <i>al totar</i> (have not thou the excellency) means, you will not have the advantage.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation our line reads: Unstable as water / you will not have the advantage; i.e., because you acted unstably as water does, you will not have the advantage of rank and power.</i> However, if this were the case then our text should have read <i>al tutar</i> rather than <i>al totar</i>; i.e., the <i>vav</i> of <i>totar</i> should have been vocalized with a <i>shuruk</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Totar</i> is vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>. If <i>al totar</i> means you will not have the advantage then <i>totar</i> is a passive, i.e., a <i>hofal</i>, and should be written <i>tutar</i> and not <i>totar</i> which is a <i>hifil</i> and a causative. Cf. Filwarg.</i> Others say that our clause should be interpreted thus: you acted unstably as water that is poured out of a vessel and you gained nothing thereby (<i>al totar</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The advantage of this interpretation is that <i>totar</i> is not irregularly vocalized. <i>Al totar</i> is a <i>hifil</i> imperfect with the meaning of a perfect It literally means you will not gain. Here it means you did not gain anything; that is, you gained nothing by acting rashly. For an alternate interpretation see Krinsky.</i> However, I disagree with this interpretation. The term <i>al</i> is always used in Scripture as an imperative.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The point is <i>al totar</i> cannot be translated as you gained nothing because <i>al</i> is an imperative meaning don’t This comment also negates the first interpretation quoted by I.E. since there, too, <i>al</i> is not used as an imperative (Filwarg).</i> The latter fact is not negated by the fact that we find <i>al</i> used once in a non-imperative sense in <i>In the way of righteousness is life, And in the pathway thereof there is no</i> (al) <i>death</i> (Prov. 12:28).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that one irregular usage of <i>al</i> does not disprove his contention that <i>al</i> is always used as an imperative.</i> The correct translation of our clause is: do not seek any advantage (<i>al totar</i>) even one as insignificant as water.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">In other words <i>al totar</i> means do not seek any advantage. This comment presents a problem. I.E. reads, “even one as insignificant as water (<i>afilu pachaz ka-mayim</i>).” This reading is extremely difficult since up to now I.E. explains <i>pachaz ka-mayim</i> as referring to Reuben’s action, not to Reuben’s punishment. Filwarg suggests deleting these words. Krinsky and Cherez emend <i>afilu</i> to <i>attah</i> (you). Weiser suggests that this comment has been misplaced and that its proper place is after Saadiah’s comment. In this case I.E. amplifies Saadiah’s explanation that <i>pachaz</i> means something insignificant. However, it appears that I.E. anticipated Saadiah’s interpretation of <i>pachaz ka-mayim</i>.</i> Accordingly the <i>vav</i> of <i>totar</i> is properly vocalized with a <i>cholam</i>, and it follows the paradigm of <i>tosaf</i> (more) in <i>Think upon the battle, thou wilt do so no more</i> (al tosaf) (Job 40:32).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Totar</i> is a <i>hifil</i> and follows the paradigm of <i>tosaf</i> which is also a <i>hifil</i>. Since <i>tosaf</i> is a <i>hifil</i> the text should have read <i>tosef</i>. But as the word comes at the end of a verse the <i>tzere</i> changes to a <i>pattach</i>. Similarly <i>totar</i> should have been written <i>toter</i> but as it concludes a segment of a poetical line the <i>tzere</i> changes to a <i>pattach</i>. Cf. Rashi on Job 40:32 (Cherez). Thus <i>totar</i> is similar to <i>tosaf</i>.</i> Rabbi Saadiah Gaon explains our line as follows: you will not have any advantage over your brothers even one as insignificant as water. According to Saadiah <i>pachaz</i> (unstable) comes from the same root as <i>pochazim</i> (light, insignificant) in <i>vain and light</i> (pochazim) <i>fellows</i> (Judges 9:4), and the root of the word <i>pachaz</i> does not have to be inverted. <sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">As it must be if we interpret the word to mean unstable. <i>Pachaz</i> (unstable) comes from the root <i>chet, peh, zayin (chafaz</i>) which means to hurry. However, the root of <i>pachaz</i> is obviously <i>peh, chet, zayin</i>. By interpreting <i>pachaz</i> to mean unstable we are saying that we must invert the root <i>chet, peh, zayin</i> into <i>peh, chet, zayin</i>. However, according to Saadiah <i>pachaz</i> has its own root, <i>peh, chet, zayin</i>, and means light, insignificant.</i>
THEN DEFILEDST THOU IT. From the day that thou defiled my couch, my conjugal couch was removed.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The part of the verse under discussion reads: Then defiledst thou / my couch went up. I.E. reads “my couch went up” as if written, my couch went up from me. He interprets it to mean, my couch was taken away from me. According to I.E., in Chapter 7 of his <i>Yesod Mora</i>, Jacob ceased cohabiting with his wives after Reuben defiled his couch. His reason was: Rachel was dead, Bilhah defiled, and he was angry at Leah because of what her son did and therefore slept neither with her nor her handmaiden Zilpah. “My couch went up” thus means, my conjugal bed ceased to function. Filwarg suggests that the reference may be only to Bilhah.</i> <i>Yetzu’i alah</i> (he went up to my couch) is to be interpreted as if written <i>yetzu’i alah me’alai</i> (my conjugal couch went up from me). Furthermore, the word <i>alah</i> (went up) at times has the meaning of cut off,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">In this case <i>yetzu’i alah</i> means my couch was cut off or destroyed.</i> as in <i>O my God, take me not away</i> (al ta’aleni) <i>in the midst of my days</i> (Ps. 102:25). Our chapter is clearly explained in Chronicles where we read, <i>Reuben (was) the first-born of Israel…but, forasmuch as he defiled his father’s couch, his birthright was given unto the sons of Joseph the son of Israel, and he was not to be reckoned in the genealogy as first-born</i> (I Chron. 5:1). Chronicles then tells us that Joseph received the birthright and Judah the kingship (<i>Ibid</i>. v. 2). Some explain that <i>and he was not to be reckoned in the genealogy as first-born</i> means that the listing of the order of the twelve sons would start with Reuben.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, <i>and he was not to be reckoned in the genealogy as first born</i> refers to Joseph, not to Reuben.</i>

Verse 5

SIMEON AND LEVI ARE BRETHREN. He referred to them as brethren because of what they did to the city of Shechem.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The point is all twelve sons were brethren, Why, then, does Jacob single out Simeon and Levi as brethren? Scripture tells us that at Shechem <i>two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi…took each man his sword, and came upon the city unawares, and slew all the males</i> (Gen. 34:25). Simeon and Levi were thus brothers in council with regard to the destruction of Shechem (Weiser).</i>
THEIR KINSHIP. Some say that the word <i>mekherotehem</i> (their kinship) is similar in meaning to <i>ha-karat</i> (the show of) in <i>The show of</i> (ha-karat) <i>their countenance doth witness against them</i> (Is. 3:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">That is, one can tell by looking at them that they employ weapons of violence (Weiser).</i> However, this interpretation is grammatically impossible.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mekherotehem</i> and <i>ha-karat</i> come from different roots (Weiser).</i> Others say that <i>mekherotehem</i> is to be rendered their possessions<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Our text is thus to be rendered: weapons of violence are their possessions.</i> and is to be compared to the word <i>tikhru</i> (ye shall buy) in <i>and ye shall also buy</i> (tikhru) <i>water of them for money</i> (Deut. 2:6). However, this, too, is incorrect for the word <i>tikhru</i> means to dig.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 2:6 is thus to be rendered: ye shall dig water of them for money; that is, pay them so that they will give you permission to dig for water (Cherez).</i> Others say that <i>mekherotehem</i> is related to the word <i>mekhirah</i> (sale) and the meaning of <i>mekherotehem</i> is they sold themselves,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">That is, they sold themselves to weapons of destruction.</i> as in <i>a people that jeoparded</i> (cheref) <i>their lives unto the death</i> (Jud. 5:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Kimchi in Jud. 5:18. Although different verbs are employed in our verse and in Jud. 5:18, the idea is the same. For an alternate interpretation see Krinsky.</i> I believe that <i>mekherotehem</i> comes from the same root as <i>mekhorotayich</i> (thine origin) (Ezek. 16:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">It means in the land of their origin.</i> While the prepositional <i>bet</i> is missing from <i>mekherotehem</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>mekherotehem</i> means in their land wherein they dwelt, Scripture should have read <i>bi-mekherotehem</i>.</i> we find the same with the word <i>bet</i> (house) in <i>that was found in the house of</i> (bet)<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture should have read <i>be-vet</i> rather than <i>bet</i>. We thus see that Scripture occasionally omits the prepositional <i>bet</i>.</i> <i>the Lord</i> (II Kings 16:8) and with the word <i>ma’on</i> (habitation) in <i>which I have commanded in My habitation</i> (ma’on) (I Sam. 2:29).<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture should have read <i>be-ma’on</i> rather than <i>ma’on</i>. See above note.</i> Our text refers to the violence which Simeon and Levi committed in the land of their origin by deceitfully slaying the entire city of Shechem after making a covenant with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 34. <i>Weapons of violence their kinship</i> should thus be rendered: they employed weapons of violence in the land of their origin.</i>

Verse 6

LET MY SOUL NOT COME INTO THEIR COUNCIL. Rabbi Aaron<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Gaon of the school of Pumbedita. The great Hai Gaon was among his students.</i> explained the word <i>tavo</i> (come) in <i>Let my soul not come</i> (tavo) as having the meaning of set like the meaning of <i>ba</i> (goeth down, to set) in <i>and the sun goeth down</i> (ba) (Eccles. 1:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>ba</i> means to come. In Eccles. 1:5 the word <i>ba</i> means sets, i.e., when the sun goes down (sets) it is no longer in the sky. Similarly the word <i>tavo</i>, which comes from the same root, here means will set. Let my soul not set from their council means let my soul always be in their council.</i> He interpreted <i>let my soul not come into their council</i> as meaning, I do not want to be outside of their council.
