However, Rabbi Aaron’s interpretation inverts the meaning of the verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Aaron interpreted <i>Let my soul not come in to their council</i> to mean let my soul not set from their council. The verse means I do not want my soul to be in their council. Thus Rabbi Aaron’s interpretation is precisely the opposite of what the verse actually says.</i> If Jacob praised Simeon and Levi, why did he mention weapons of violence? Furthermore, Jacob told his sons, <i>Ye have troubled me, to make me odious unto the inhabitants of the land</i> (Gen. 34:30).<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that Jacob was angry at what his sons did to the inhabitants of Shechem and on his deathbed would not praise them for this act.</i> The truth of the matter is that Simeon and Levi placed Jacob and his household in great jeopardy by their actions in Shechem. Indeed, were it not for the <i>terror of God</i> that <i>was upon the cities that were round about them</i> (Gen. 35:5), they would have surrounded Jacob and his family and exterminated them all. He (Rabbi Aaron) similarly explained<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">That is, in a positive manner, not that Jacob castigated his sons but praised them for slaying the inhabitants of Shechem and destroying its wall. Rabbi Aaron interprets verses 6-7 as follows: Let my soul not set from their council, from their assembly let my glory not be excluded; For in their anger they slew men, and in their self-will they uprooted a cursed wall; For their anger was fierce, and their wrath it was cruel. Rabbi Aaron interprets verse 8 as follows: I will give them a good portion in Jacob (<i>achallekem be-ya’akov</i>) and may they multiply in Israel (<i>va-afitzem bi’yisra’el</i>) (Filwarg).</i> <i>Cursed be their anger</i> (v. 7) as meaning <i>and in their self will they uprooted a cursed wall</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Aaron renders <i>ikkeru shor</i> (they houghed oxen) as they uprooted a wall.</i> <i>for their anger was fierce</i>. The above explanations are unpalatable.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, cold, i.e., unpalatable as cold food (Krinsky).</i> Let my soul not come into their council.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">I reject them. I.E. takes Jacob’s words and gives them a new twist.</i> Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moses ben Samuel Gikatilla, an 11th century Bible commentator. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 and the notes thereto.</i> says that <i>kevodi</i> (my glory) is synonymous with <i>nafshi</i> (my soul). He notes that we find the two often used synonymously in the book of Psalms. Rabbi Moses’ interpretation is correct since our text repeats itself in different words,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The point is that the second half of the line repeats what the first half said but in different words. In the first half it uses <i>nafshi</i>, in the second <i>kevodi</i>. However, both mean one and the same.</i> as is the style of prophetic statements. We thus find, <i>Ask thy father, and he will declare unto thee, Thine elders, and they will tell thee</i> (Deut. 32:7), and (in Num. 23:8) <i>How shall I curse, whom God hath not cursed? And how shall I execrate, whom the Lord hath not execrated</i>? Thus <i>into their council</i> means the same as <i>unto their assembly</i>, come (<i>tavoh</i>) the same as be united (<i>techad</i>), and <i>nafshi</i> the same as <i>kevodi</i>. However, Rabbi Judah ben Balam the Spaniard<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Bible commentator and grammarian who lived in the 10th and 11th centuries. “His commentaries (in Arabic) on most of the Bible are remarkable for their philosophical method and use of comparison with Arabic.” (Cecil Roth, <i>Standard Jewish Encyclopedia</i>, p. 940).</i> says that Rabbi Moses erred. He maintains that <i>kavod</i> (glory) refers to the body because the body is the glory (<i>kavod</i>) of the soul in the same way that a necklace is the ornament to the neck,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The body is inferior to the soul, yet it is considered the soul’s glory in the same way that a necklace, although certainly less important than the neck, is nevertheless called the ornament of the neck (Cherez).</i> as we find in the verse <i>Who satisfieth thy body</i> (edyekh) <i>with good things</i> (Ps. 103:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew <i>edyekh</i> ordinarily means your ornament. J.P.S. translates it as thine old age. Rabbi Judah Balam interprets <i>edyekh</i> as referring to the body. However, I.E. in Psalms interprets <i>edyekh</i> as referring to the soul.</i> Rabbi Judah offers as a proof text,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">That <i>kavod</i> refers to the body.</i> <i>Yea, let him lay my glory</i> (kevodi) <i>in the dust. Selah</i>. (Ps. 7:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Which proves that glory cannot refer to the soul for it is impossible to lay the soul in the dust.</i> However, I say that Rabbi Judah errs, for we find Scripture saying, <i>So that my glory</i> (kevodi) <i>may sing praise to Thee</i> (Ps. 30:13),<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. interprets this verse in his commentaries on Psalms as follows: So that all that have a soul (<i>kavod</i>) may sing praise to thee. We thus see that <i>kavod</i> refers to the soul. Rabbi Judah might retort that Ps. 30:13 should be interpreted: so that my body may sing praise to thee, or all that have a human form (<i>kavod</i>) may sing praise to thee.</i> and <i>Therefore my heart is glad, and my glory</i> (kevodi) <i>rejoiceth; My flesh</i> (i.e., my body) <i>also dwelleth in safety</i> (Ps. 16:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kavod</i> must refer to the soul for otherwise body is mentioned twice in our verse. I.E. in Psalms interprets <i>my heart</i> as referring to man’s intelligence, <i>my glory</i> (kevodi) to man’s soul, and <i>my flesh</i> to the body.</i> As to the proof which Rabbi Judah offered from <i>Yea, let him lay my glory in the dust</i>, it is figurative. What the verse means is that my soul will be lowered as low as possible, i.e., to the dust. Positive proof that my interpretation is correct comes from <i>My soul</i> (nafshi) <i>cleaveth unto the dust</i> (Ps. 119:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">This verse certainly must be taken figuratively. Similarly, Ps. 119:25.</i>
BE UNITED. <i>Techad</i> (be united) is related to the word <i>yachad</i> (united).<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Its root is <i>yod, chet, dalet</i>.</i> However, according to Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen, the grammarian of blessed memory, the <i>tzere</i> beneath the <i>tav</i> of <i>techad</i> takes the place of the <i>alef</i> of <i>echad</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">That is, its root is <i>alef, chet, dalet</i>.</i> He similarly explains the word <i>tesham</i> (be desolate) in <i>and that the land be not desolate</i> (tesham) (Gen. 47:19).<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the root of <i>tesham</i> is <i>alef, shin, mem</i> and the <i>tav</i> is vocalized with a <i>tzere</i> to make up for the dropped <i>alef</i>. I.E. holds that it comes from the root <i>yod, shin, mem</i>. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 47:19.</i>
[INTO THEIR COUNCIL.] <i>Be-sodam</i> (into their council) is analogous to <i>be-hivvasedam</i> (while they took council) in <i>while they took council</i> (be-hivvasedam) <i>together against me</i> (Ps. 31:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Both words come from the root <i>samekh, vav, dalet</i> (Krinsky) and mean secret council.</i> The meaning of our verse is: since Simeon and Levi’s weapons are ones of violence (v. 5), <i>Let my soul not come into their council</i>.
THEY SLEW MEN. Scripture employs the term <i>ish</i> (man) generically as it does <i>shor</i> (ox) and <i>chamor</i> (ass) for oxen and asses (Gen. 32:6). <i>They slew men</i> alludes to the inhabitants of the city of Shechem.
OXEN. <i>Shor</i> (oxen) is to be rendered as wall. We similarly read, <i>Its branches run over the wall</i> (shur) (v. 22). I have already explained in my work <i>Moznayim</i> that the <i>cholam</i> and <i>shuruk</i> interchange.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore the fact that our verse reads <i>shor</i> and verse 22 <i>shur</i> presents no problem.</i>
[HOUGHED.] <i>Ikkeru</i> (houghed) is similar to the word <i>te’akker</i> (hough) in <i>thou shalt hough</i> (te’akker) <i>their horses</i> (Josh. 11:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>ikkeru shor</i> is to be translated, they uprooted a wall.</i> This verse shows that Shechem was a large city since it had a wall.

Verse 7

CURSED BE THEIR ANGER, FOR IT WAS FIERCE. Jacob either prophesied or offered a prayer that Simeon and Levi’s anger would (or should) diminish and that this would be for their very own good. For curse is the opposite of bless, and as a blessing means an increase, so a curse means a diminution.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>Cursed be their anger</i> means may their anger be diminished or their anger will be diminished.</i>
AND THEIR WRATH. A repetition in different words of <i>their anger</i>. The same is true with <i>I will divide them</i> and <i>And scatter them</i>. The meaning of <i>I will divide them in Jacob, And scatter them in Israel</i> is, Simeon and Levi deserve to be separated and disunited. And so it was. For we find that the lot of the tribe of Simeon fell within the inheritance of the tribe of Judah.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Josh. 19:1.</i> Simeon was thus under Judah’s dominion. Furthermore, its cities were discontiguous and scattered throughout the boundary of Judah.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">In addition to having their inheritance within the tribe of Judah, their cities were also scattered within Judah’s boundaries (Weiser).</i> Similarly the forty-eight cities of the tribe of Levi were scattered among the other tribes.

Verse 8

JUDAH. Thou art as thy name,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">That is, thy name Judah means praise.</i> and thy brethren shall so praise thee.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: Judah thou, thy brethren shall praise thee. I.E interprets thus: Judah thou art as thy name and thy brethren shall so praise thee.</i> When thy brothers shall see that <i>Thy hand shall be on the neck of thine enemies; Thy father’s sons shall bow down before thee</i> as to a king. This prophecy came to pass.

Verse 9

JUDAH IS A LION’S WHELP. Jacob compared Judah to a small lion’s whelp, to a type of whelp that grows into a lion.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads, <i>gur aryeh. Gur</i> (whelp) can be applied to any young animal. I.E. points out that <i>gur</i> (whelp) <i>aryeh</i> (lion) means a <i>gur</i> that grows up to be a lion, that is, a <i>gur</i> of the lion family (Cherez).</i> The comparative <i>caf</i> (meaning like) has been omitted,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture reads: Judah is a lion’s whelp. It should have read: Judah is as a lion’s whelp (<i>ke-gur</i>).</i> as it is in <i>When a wild ass’s colt</i> (ayir pere) <i>is born a man</i> (Job. 11:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">There, too, a <i>caf</i> should have been placed before <i>ayir pere</i> (a wild ass’s colt). We thus see that Scripture occasionally omits the comparative <i>caf</i>. However, it should be supplied by the reader.</i>
FROM THE PREY, MY SON, THOU ART GONE UP. My son, you appear to me as a lion’s whelp when thou art gone up from the prey. <i>From the prey</i> means after tearing a prey apart.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser.</i> This is its plain meaning. For us to interpret it as referring to the saving of Joseph,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">That it means: from the prey you brought up (saved) my son (Joseph). So Cherez. Judah saved Joseph by saying, <i>What profit is it if we slay our brother and conceal his blood</i> (Gen. 37:26).</i> Scripture should have written <i>he’elita</i> (thou brought up)<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>hifil</i>.</i> rather than <i>alita</i> (thou art come up) which is an intransitive verb. The rest of the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Which reads, <i>He stooped down, he couched as a lion</i>, etc. (Cherez). According to Krinsky and Weiser: the next verse, which reads, <i>The scepter shall not depart from Judah, Nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet</i>, is proof that our verse deals with Judah’s ability as a warrior and not with his saving Joseph. I.E. literally reads: “The following verse is proof.” Filwarg suggests that the word “following” is a scribal error.</i> is proof that the first part of the verse deals with Judah’s tearing of a prey and not with Judah’s saving of Joseph from being a prey. Observe the verse <i>And she brought up</i> (va-ta’al) <i>one of her whelps</i> (Ezek. 19:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">And you will see that when Scripture wants to say brought up, it employs the <i>hifil va-ta’al</i>. Cf. Kimchi on Ezek. 19:3. Also see Cherez.</i>
[HE STOOPED DOWN, HE COUCHED AS A LION.] After a lion tears its prey it sits on its knees and couches in security and no other passing animal<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The lion is not afraid of any other species of animal.</i> will cause it to get up and flee.

Verse 10

THE SCEPTRE SHALL NOT DEPART FROM JUDAH. The sceptre of greatness shall not depart from Judah until David, who inaugurated the Kingdom of Judah, comes.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The verse reads, <i>The scepter shall not depart from Judah…as long as men come to Shiloh</i> The last part of the latter quote literally reads, until Shiloh cometh. I.E. interprets <i>shiloh</i> as referring to David, hence his interpretation: the scepter shall not depart from Judah…until David comes. Later in his commentary I.E. explains why Shiloh refers to David.</i> And so it was. Observe that in Israel’s march toward the promised land, the standard of the tribe of Judah set forth in the first (Num. 10:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the tribe of Judah was pre-eminent.</i> God also said, <i>Judah shall go up first</i> (Jud. 1:1, 2).<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>After the death of Joshua,…the children of Israel asked of the Lord saying: Who shall go up for us to fight against the Canaanites, to fight against them? And the Lord said: Judah shall go up</i> (Jud. 1:1, 2). I.E. reads, “Judah shall go up first.” Either I.E. quoted from memory and erred or he amplified the Biblical verse. According to Krinsky the reference is to Jud. 20:18. There we read, with regard to the war against Benjamin, that Israel asked of the Lord, “Who shall go up to fight Benjamin first?” Scripture tells us, <i>And the Lord said: Judah first</i>. According to Krinsky, I.E. combined Jud. 1:2 and 2:18.</i>
[NOR THE RULER’S STAFF.] A scribe (<i>mechokek</i>) who will write (<i>she-yachok</i>) in a book.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. renders <i>mechokek</i> (ruler’s staff) as scribe. The root <i>chet, kof, kof</i> means to inscribe. Cf. Is. 30:8, <i>And inscribe</i> (chukkah) <i>it in a book</i>. Thus <i>mechokek</i> is an inscriber, i.e., a scribe.</i>
[FROM BETWEEN HIS FEET.] Scribes sit at the feet of the ruler.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">According to Cohen.</i>
SHILOH. Some interpret <i>Shiloh</i> as Onkelos does. They say that it means “his.”<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos renders <i>ad ki yavo shiloh</i> (literally, until shiloh cometh) as until the Messiah, to whom is the kingdom (shiloh meaning <i>shelo</i>, his) cometh. I.E. says that it is possible to so interpret the verse but to apply it to David rather than to the Messiah (Filwarg).</i> Others say that <i>Shiloh</i> comes from the same root as <i>u-ve-shilyatah</i> (and against her afterbirth) (Deut. 28:57).<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">That is, it means a child. <i>Shilyah</i> means the afterbirth, or placenta and, by extension, the child which was in the placenta. The meaning of <i>ad ki yavo shiloh</i> thus is: until the child comes, the reference being until David from the house of Judah comes (Filwarg). Krinsky and Weiser apply it to the Messiah. Filwarg’s interpretation seems to be correct in view of the fact that I.E. explicitly states that this verse applies to David.</i> Others connect it to the Rabbinic term <i>shalil</i> (embryo).<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The interpretation being the same as in the note above.</i> There is also a commentator who says that <i>shiloh</i> refers to the city Shilo. He would explain <i>yavo</i> to mean goeth down, as in <i>and the sun goeth down</i> (ba) (Eccles. 1:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See note 29. And <i>ad ki yavo shilo</i> means until Shilo goeth down (is destroyed).</i> Or he would maintain that our verse is abridged and should read as if written <i>ad ki yavo ketz shilo</i> (until the end of Shiloh comes).<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Cohen. That is, Judah’s pre-eminence will continue throughout the period of Shiloh and when that is destroyed, it will be superseded by the royal line of David.</i> For it is written, <i>And he forsook the tabernacle of Shiloh</i> (Ps. 78:60), and then, <i>He chose David also His servant</i> (Ps. 78:70). The latter interpretation is also not implausible. It is also possible that <i>Shiloh</i> means his son, with the <i>heh</i> taking the place of the <i>vav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>shiloh</i> means his son, then the word should end in a <i>vav</i> rather than in a <i>heh</i>, as the <i>vav</i> with a <i>cholem</i> suffixed to a noun is the sign of the pronoun his. I.E. here accepts the interpretation that <i>shiloh</i> means his son. However, he connects it to the words <i>tashleh</i> rather than to <i>shelil</i> or <i>shilyah</i> as was done above (Filwarg).</i> as in the word <i>oholoh</i> (his tent) (Gen. 9:21), and that the word <i>shiloh</i> comes from the same root as <i>tashleh</i> (give birth) in <i>lo tashleh oti</i> (don’t cause me to give birth) (II Kings 4:28).<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Don’t pray to God that I should give birth (Weiser, Cherez).</i>
[OBEDIENCE.] The word <i>yikkehat</i> (obedience of) is similar to the word <i>li-kehat</i> in <i>to obey</i> (li-kehat) <i>his mother</i> (Prov. 30:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">They both come from the root <i>kof, heh, tov</i> meaning obedience.</i> The <i>yod</i> of <i>yikkehat</i> is a third person imperfect prefix.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>yod</i> prefixed to a verb is the sign of the third person future.</i> The meaning of <i>ve-lo yikkehat ammim</i> is that nations shall obey him. Jacob’s prophecy came true, for we find that many nations were subservient to David and his son Solomon. Our phrase (v. 10) does not mean that the sceptre shall depart from Judah when David comes.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. our verse reads: the scepter shall not depart from Judah…until his son (David) comes. This implies that when David comes, the scepter shall depart from Judah.</i> Our verse may be compared to someone saying, so and so will not lack bread until the time that he will have many vineyards and fields. <i>For I will not leave thee, until I have done that which I have spoken to thee of</i>, viz., returning you to the land of Canaan (Gen. 28:15), is identical.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Krinsky, Weiser.</i>

Verse 11

BINDING. The <i>yod</i> of <i>oseri</i> (binding) is superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The usual form is <i>oser</i>.</i> It is similar to the superflous <i>yods</i> of <i>ha-yoshevi</i> (that are enthroned) (Ps. 123:1)<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The usual form is <i>ha-yoshev</i>.</i> and <i>le-susati</i> (to a steed) (Cant. 1:9)<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">The usual form is <i>le-susah</i>.</i> both of which are superfluous.
HIS FOAL. <i>Iroh</i> (his foal) is similar to <i>ayarim</i> (ass colts) in <i>on thirty ass colts</i> (ayarim) (Jud. 10:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The singular is <i>ayir</i> and it means a young and vigorous male ass. The <i>heh</i> of <i>iroh</i> is in place of a <i>vav</i> as is indicated by the <i>keri</i> (Krinsky).</i> 
The <i>yod</i> of <i>beni</i> (colt) in <i>beni atono</i> (his ass’s colt) is superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beni atono</i> is a variation of <i>ben atono. Beni</i> thus does not mean my son.</i> The meaning of our verse then is: Binding his foal unto the vine and binding his ass’s colt unto the choice vine, for the word binding is to be read as if written twice.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The text has “binding” once. I.E. notes that it applies both to <i>his foal</i> and to <i>his ass’s colt</i>. This translation follows <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 which reads, “<i>ve-yehi perusho oseri la-gefen…ki…</i>, and its meaning is: Binding his foal…because <i>oseri</i> is to be read as if written twice.” The printed text reads, “<i>o yehiyeh pirusho ki</i>…or its meaning is because <i>oseri</i> is to be read as if written twice.” This reading is impossible. It implies that according to the first interpretation (that the <i>yod</i> of <i>oseri</i> is superfluous) <i>oseri</i> does not apply to the second part of the verse. However, according to the first interpretation <i>oseri</i> also refers to the second part of the verse as well, for how else can we interpret <i>And his ass’s colt unto the choice vine</i>, except by: And binding his ass’s colt unto the choice vine. Both Filwarg and Cherez note that I.E.’s comment as written in the printed text is incomprehensible. They suggest their own emendation. However, the reading in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 eliminates most of the difficulties. The reading in the printed texts probably arose because a scribe omitted <i>Binding his foal</i>, etc., and a latter scribe changed <i>ve-yehiyeh</i> to <i>o yehiyeh</i> in an attempt to make sense out of the remaining fragment. However, he failed to do so.</i>
UNTO THE CHOICE VINE. Scripture repeats the same idea in different words, for <i>sorekah</i> (vine) means the same as <i>gefen</i>, and <i>ayir</i> (foal) the same as <i>aton</i>. 
Similarly, <i>And his vesture in the blood of grapes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Which means the same as <i>his garments in wine</i>.</i> Some say that <i>suto</i> (his vesture) is the word <i>kesuto</i> (his vesture) with the <i>kaf</i> missing.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Thus <i>sutoh</i> comes from the root <i>caf, samekh, heh</i> which gives us the noun <i>kesut</i> (a covering, a vesture) (Cherez).</i> However, I believe that <i>sutoh</i> comes from the same root as <i>masveh</i> (veil) (Ex. 34:33).<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">In this case the root of <i>sutoh</i> is <i>samekh, vav, heh</i>. Both opinions agree that <i>sutoh</i> means a vesture. They differ only in explaining the word’s origin.</i> The meaning of our verse is that his vineyards will produce so many grapes that Judah will bind<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Reading <i>ye’esor</i> as in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38.</i> his foal to the vine and he will not care if the animal eats of the grapes; and he will have so much wine that he will wash his garments in wine rather than in water. Scripture terms wine <i>the blood of grapes</i> because wine is red.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Prov. 23:31, <i>Look not thou upon the wine when it is red</i>.</i> The Bible speaks figuratively here, as it does in <i>And it shall come to pass in that day, That the mountains shall drop down sweet wine, And the hills shall flow with milk</i> (Joel 4:18). The land will produce so much wine that Judah will be called “red eyes” because of the great amount of wine that he will drink. <sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The verse literally reads: red eyes from wine. I.E. interprets accordingly.</i> He will be so called because the eyes of one who drinks much wine look red.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Prov. 23:29, 30, <i>Who hath redness of eyes? They that tarry long at the wine</i>.</i> Similarly Judah’s teeth will be white from the large amount of milk that he will drink.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">So <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. The printed texts have “from eating milk.” But milk is drunk not eaten. The verse literally reads: and his teeth white from milk. I.E. interprets accordingly.</i>

Verse 12

AND HIS TEETH WHITE. <i>U-leven</i> (white) is an adjective modifying <i>shinnayim</i> (teeth).<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">I.E.’s point is that <i>u-leven shinnayim</i> means white teeth not whiteness of teeth; hence he points out that <i>u-leven</i> is an adjective (Filwarg).</i> <i>Shinnayim</i> is in the dual form because the teeth are arranged in two sets.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The dual form is usually limited to nouns that come in pairs, i.e., <i>oznayim</i> (ears), <i>yadayim</i> (hands). However, there is more than one tooth in the mouth. Hence the plural of <i>shen</i> (tooth) should not be in the dual form. I.E. thus explains that <i>shinayyim</i> is in the dual form because teeth come in two sets, an upper and a lower.</i> Saadiah Gaon, of blessed memory, explains <i>His eyes shall based with wine</i> to mean that his eyes shall be redder than wine. He similarly explains <i>And his teeth white with milk</i> to mean that his teeth shall be whiter than milk.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads <i>mi-yayin</i> (with wine), and <i>me-chalav</i> (with milk). The <i>mem</i> can have the meaning more than. Thus <i>mi-yayin</i> can mean more than wine, and <i>me-chalav</i>, more than milk.</i> Others say that <i>And his teeth white with milk</i> means that he will not eat an unclean thing and will not follow what his eyes see.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">According to Krinsky the reference is to an oath that Judah took to be especially scrupulous in what he would eat and what he would look upon (women). Judah considered certain permitted foods as “unclean” and abstained from them. Judah took his oath of superpiety after the incident of Tamar (Gen. 39) as a form of penance and to ensure that henceforth he would act more saintly.</i> The latter is a ridiculous homily.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">It implies that the other brothers were not as saintly as Judah in that they did not take the same oath that Judah did (Krinsky). Or this interpretation is extremely far fetched because there is no allusion to it in the text.</i> 
Jacob at first enumerated the tribes<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob in prophesying about his children first prophesied about the sons of Leah, then about the sons of the handmaids, and finally concerning the sons of Rachel. In prophesying about the sons of Leah, Jacob followed the order of their birth. However, in prophesying concerning the sons of the handmaidens he did not follow the order of their birth. That is what I.E. means by <i>Jacob at first listed the tribes in order of their birth</i>.</i> in the order of their birth. However, he listed Zebulun before Issachar because Issachar’s inheritance fell between Zebulun and Dan.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Hence Issachar is listed between Zebulun and Dan. Cf. Josh. 19.</i>

Verse 13

AT THE SHORE OF THE SEA. This, too, is proof that Jacob prophesied.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">This verse is obviously a prophecy that Zebulun would inherit a portion which borders on the sea shore in the land of Israel. This supports I.E.’s contention that Jacob’s final words to his children recorded in Chap. 49 are prophesies. Cf. I.E.’s comments on verse 1.</i> The meaning of <i>le-chof</i> (at the shore) is, at the border of. It comes from the same root as <i>chofef</i> (covereth) in <i>He covereth</i> (chofef) <i>him all the day</i> (Deut. 33:12). The border of the sea is called <i>chof</i> because it “covers” the boats as boats cannot be anchored in places that are open to the wind.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the border or shore (<i>chof</i>) protects or covers (<i>chofef</i>) the ships. Weiser suggests that what I.E. means by border is an inlet where the ships are anchored for protection.</i>
AND HIS FLANK SHALL BE UPON ZIDON. His flank shall extend to Zidon.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">His border shall extend to Zidon (Weiser)</i>

Verse 14

ISSACHAR IS A LARGE-BONED ASS. Jacob compared Issachar to an ass whose bones are heavy.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">That is, strong (Krinsky).</i> <i>Chamor</i> (ass) is in the construct with <i>garem</i> (bones).<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chamor garem</i> thus means an ass (<i>chamor</i>) of heavy bones (<i>garem</i>), rather than a heavy-boned ass. I.E.’s point is that <i>garem</i> is not an adjective modifying <i>chamor</i> (Filwarg, Weiser).</i> Due to the heaviness of his bones, he is wont to couch.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">According to Filwarg. The point is that this type of beast carries heavy loads and therefore often couches down to rest when burdened. It should be noted that I.E. is vague and that Weiser, Cherez and Krinsky offer other interpretations.</i>
BETWEEN THE SHEEPFOLDS. <i>Ben ha-mishpatayim</i> (between the sheepfolds) means between the arranged rows.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. does not tell us what he means by “arranged rows.” The reference may be to the burdens borne by the ass which are arranged in two rows, one on the right side of the animal and one on the left (Krinsky), or to the rows of the sheep-folds (Weiser).</i> It is possible that <i>mishpatayim</i> comes from the same root as <i>tishpot</i> (arrange) in <i>Lord, Thou wilt arrange</i> (tishpot) <i>peace for us</i> (Is. 26:12).

Verse 15

FOR HE SAW A RESTING-PLACE THAT IT WAS GOOD. When Issachar saw that his land and resting-place were pleasant, he, as an ass, bowed his shoulder to bear any and all burdens and became as a servant that pays levies. Scripture says this concerning Issachar because this tribe did not consist of warriors and its men did not want to leave their homes to go to war. Moses similarly said concerning Issachar, <i>Rejoice…Issachar, in thy tents</i> (Deut. 33:18). The levy mentioned in our verse may refer to Issachar’s payment of a money levy to the king in Israel in lieu of furnishing soldiers for his army, or it may refer to a payment of money to foreign nations that they should not attack them.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, “or to foreign nations who attacked them.” The point is that the tribe of Issachar were as servants (<i>mas oved</i>) because they paid a levy either to the king of Israel or to foreign nations.</i>

Verse 16

DAN SHALL JUDGE HIS PEOPLE. Jacob hinted that Dan, although born of a handmaid, would have a standard just as the tribes born of the wives did.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">For the standards see Num. 2. The four tribes with standards were: Reuben, Judah, Ephraim and Dan. The first three were descended from Jacob’s wives, Dan was the son of Bilhah, Rachael’s handmaid.</i> Dan was thus a ruler over all the other tribes that were descended from the handmaids.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">This explains <i>Dan shall judge his people</i>, i.e., he shall be a ruler over the tribes descended from the handmaids.</i> 

Verse 17

[A SERPENT.] Jacob compared Dan in his strength to a serpent.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture says that Dan shall be a serpent in the way. I.E. points out that Jacob compared Dan to a serpent only with regard to his ability to harm his enemies.</i> It is also possible that <i>shefifon</i> (a horned snake) comes from the same root as <i>yeshufekha</i> (they shall bruise thy) in <i>they shall bruise thy</i> (yeshufekha) <i>head</i> (Gen. 3:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>shefifon</i> means a snake. It is so called because it bruises (Krinsky).</i> According to this interpretation <i>shefifon ale orach</i> (a horned snake in the path) means the same as <i>nachash ale derech</i> (a serpent in the way).

Verse 18

[I WAIT FOR THY SALVATION, O LORD.] When the serpent bites the horse’s heel, it is afraid that the rider will smash its head with his sword. Hence the prophet prayed, <i>I wait for Thy salvation, O Lord</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">When the serpent strikes (<i>that biteth the horse’s heels, so that his rider falleth backward</i>), he is not out of danger. The rider can still kill him. Hence Jacob prayed that God be with Dan so that when he struck his enemy he would escape safely.</i> The “thy” of <i>Thy salvation</i> refers to Dan.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>caf</i> of <i>li-shu’atekha</i> (for thy salvation) does not refer to God but to Dan. I.E. interprets thus because he believes our verse to be a prayer to God on behalf of Dan.</i> The meaning of our verse is: I trust to God for thy salvation. It is also possible that Scripture employs a noun (salvation) in place of an infinitive.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. interprets <i>li-shu’atekha</i> (for thy salvation) as if written <i>le-hoshi’akha</i>. The latter is a verb, the former a noun.</i> Our verse should thus be rendered: I trust that God will save thee. <i>Thy salvation</i> in <i>We will shout for joy in thy salvation</i> (Ps. 20:6) is similar.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, the “thy” in <i>thy salvation</i> does not refer to God.</i> The aforementioned is the case whether the “thy” of <i>thy salvation</i> (Ps. 20:6) refers to King David or to the anointed, his son.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The Messiah (Cherez). Any of the Judean kings descended from David (Weiser). The point is that the <i>caf</i> suffixed to <i>yeshu’ah</i> (salvation or victory) does not refer to God. The same holds true in our verse (Filwarg, Cherez). <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 reads, “Thy salvation (thy victory) is similar in that “thy” refers either to David or to the anointed his son.”</i> Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid says that the word <i>va-yomer</i> has been omitted from our clause and it should be read as if written: and he will say (<i>va-yomer</i>), I wait for Thy salvation, O Lord.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The subject of <i>va-yomer</i> is Dan, i.e., Dan after biting the horse’s heel will say, <i>I wait for Thy salvation, O Lord</i> (Filwarg). According to this interpretation “thy” in <i>Thy salvation</i> refers to God.</i> Rabbi Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">According to Weiser, the reference is to Rabbi Isaac, one of the early Gaonim of Sura.</i> explains our verse as follows: when the prophet Jacob prophetically saw his son Dan in the form of a serpent, he was overtaken by fright and exclaimed, “Save me, O Lord.”<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">“Save me, O Lord” is a paraphrase of, <i>I wait for Thy salvation, O Lord</i>. According to this interpretation also, “thy” in <i>Thy salvation</i> refers to God. The reason for Jacob’s fright was explained by I.E. at the beginning of his comment.</i>

Verse 19

GAD. Jacob prophesied that a troop (an army) would attack Gad but that he would ultimately be victorious.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">This is the meaning of <i>But he shall troop upon their heel</i>, heel meaning in the end. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 3:15.</i>
SHALL TROOP UPON HIM. <i>Yegudennu</i> (shall troop upon him) is similar to <i>yegudennu</i> (he invadeth) in <i>the people that he invadeth</i> (yegudennu) (Hab. 3:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Hence <i>Gad gedud yegudennu</i> (Gad, a troop shall troop upon him) means, Gad, a troop shall invade or attack him.</i> <i>Yagud</i> (he shall troop), like <i>gedud</i> (a troop), comes from the root <i>gimel, dalet, dalet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">I. E.’s point is that <i>gedud</i> (a troop), <i>yegudennu</i> (shall troop upon him) and <i>yagud</i> (he shall troop) all come from the same double root, <i>gimel, dalet, dalet</i>. That <i>gedud</i> comes from this root is obvious. That <i>yagud</i> and <i>yegudennu</i> (<i>yagud</i> plus the suffix <i>nu</i>) come from this root is not as apparent. Double root letters are vocalized with a <i>cholam</i> and <i>ayin vav</i> roots with a <i>shuruk</i> in the <i>kal</i> imperfect. It thus appears that <i>yagud</i> and <i>yegudennu</i> come from the root <i>gimel, vav, dalet</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i> It is vocalized with a <i>shuruk</i> in place of a <i>cholam</i> like the word <i>yarun</i> (doth sing) in <i>But the righteous doth sing</i> (yarun) <i>and rejoice</i> (Prov. 29:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yarun</i> comes from the root <i>resh, nun, nun</i>, so it should have been vocalized <i>yaron</i>. We thus see that at times a double root is vocalized as an <i>ayin vav</i> (Cherez).</i> We do not know exactly to what incident Jacob was referring because we don’t know all the tribulations that our ancestors endured.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Cherez. We do not know when the tribe of Gad was attacked by an invading army.</i>

Verse 20

AS FOR ASHER. Some say that the <i>mem</i> of <i>me-asher</i> (as for Asher) is superfluous.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">None of the other tribes have a <i>mem</i> prefixed to their names (Weiser). Our verse should thus be translated: Asher, his bread shall be fat.</i> However, I believe that what our clause means is: from the land of Asher “fat bread” will come.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Or fat food, following <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 which reads <i>lechem shamen</i>. Our texts have <i>lechem va-shemen</i> (bread and oil). However, this reading is incorrect in view of I.E.’s interpretation of <i>shemenah</i> as being an adjective of <i>lechem</i>. See next note. According to this interpretation the <i>mem</i> prefixed to Asher is a preposition meaning from.</i> Bread in our verse is in the feminine.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">The text reads, <i>shemenah lachmo</i> (his bread shall be fat). <i>Shemenah</i> is a feminine, the masculine being <i>shamen</i>. In other places <i>lechem</i> is in the masculine, i.e., Num. 4:7; I Sam. 9:7.</i> We find the same to be the case with the words house,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bayit</i> (house) is masculine in Deut. 22:8 and feminine in II Kings 15:5.</i> place,<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Makom</i> (place) is masculine in Gen. 1:9 and feminine in Job 20:9.</i> hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yad</i> (hand) is masculine in Ezek. 2:9 and feminine in Ex. 14:31. <i>Yad</i> is generally feminine.</i> fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Esh</i> (fire) is masculine in Ps. 104:4 and feminine in Num. 16:35.</i> eye,<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ayin</i> (eye) is masculine in Prov. 4:25 and feminine in Gen. 3:7. <i>Ayin</i> is generally feminine.</i> wind,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ru’ach</i> (wind) is masculine in Job 1:19 and feminine in Gen. 1:2.</i> land,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Eretz</i> is masculine in Is. 9:18 and feminine in Gen. 1:2. <i>Eretz</i> is generally feminine.</i> chest<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Aron</i> (chest) is masculine in Num. 10:33 and feminine in I Sam. 4:17. It is generally masculine.</i> and people.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Am</i> (people) is masculine in Gen. 11:6 and feminine in Ex. 5:16. <i>Am</i> is usually masculine.</i>
[ROYAL DAINTIES.] The meaning of <i>ma’adanne melekh</i> (royal dainties) is known.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of <i>ve-hu yitten ma’adanne melekh</i> (and he shall yield royal dainties) is that Asher will provide kings with food for their enjoyment. He will do so because his land is very fertile and produces the choicest foods (Cherez).</i> Moses similarly said concerning Asher, <i>And let him dip his foot in oil</i> (Deut. 33:24).<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Moses similarly said that Asher’s land would be fertile, for the aforementioned is the meaning of Moses’ blessing (Deut. 33:24).</i>

Verse 21

NAPHTALI IS A HIND LET LOOSE. The word <i>sheluchah</i> (let loose) means a gift,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 9:16, <i>and given it for a portion</i> (shilluchim) <i>unto his daughter</i>. The meaning of <i>Naphtali is a hind let loose</i> thus is: Naphtali is as beloved and as beautiful as a hind given as a gift (Weiser). Filwarg suggests rendering: Naphtali has a land which is as precious as a hind given as a gift.</i> and the one who receives such a gift responds with goodly words.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><i>He giveth</i> cannot refer to <i>ayyalah</i> (hind) which is feminine. Hence it must refer to the one receiving the gift.</i> Others say that <i>hind</i> refers to Deborah and that <i>He giveth goodly words</i> alludes to Barak who joined her in a song to God.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Jud. 5:1.</i> Scripture mentions Naphtali<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture tells us that Deborah <i>sat…in the hill country of Ephraim</i> (Jud. 4:5). The latter indicates that Deborah was not a Naphtalite. The question arises, “If Deborah was not a Naphtalite why mention her in a prophecy which pertains to Naphtali?” I.E. answers that Barak, the general whom Deborah inspired to lead Israel to victory and who joined her in song to God, came from the tribe of Naphtali. Cf. Jud. 4:6, <i>Barak…out of Kedesh-naphtali</i>.</i> because Barak came from the tribe of Naphtali.<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Filwarg suggests rendering, “Scripture mentions Naphtali because the battle in which Deborah and Barak played a key role took place in the territory of Naphtali.” The literal reading of I.E. is, <i>Scripture mentions Naphtali because of his inheritance</i>.</i>

Verse 22

JOSEPH IS A FRUITFUL VINE. <i>Ben</i> means a branch<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ben</i> means a son. Metaphorically speaking, the branch is the son of the tree. Hence <i>ben</i> can also mean a branch (Cherez).</i> and it is a feminine noun.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ben</i> is usually masculine. However, <i>porat</i> is feminine. Thus <i>ben</i> in <i>ben porat yosef</i> (Joseph is a fruitful branch) has to be feminine. If <i>ben</i> was masculine our phrase would read <i>ben poreh yosef</i>.</i> <i>Ben</i> in <i>And the branch</i> (ben) <i>that Thou madest strong for Thyself</i> (Ps. 80:16) has a similar meaning. Grammatically speaking <i>porat</i> (fruitful) is a <i>po’elet</i>. A feminine singular participle can come in two paradigms,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The two paradigms being <i>po’alah</i> and <i>po’elet</i>, examples of which are <i>oyevah</i> and <i>oyevet</i>. A more common example would be <i>kotevah</i> and <i>kotevet</i>, or <i>shomerah</i> and <i>shomeret</i>. The translation follows <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38. Our texts have <i>oyeveha</i> and <i>oyavti</i>. The latter appears to be a scribal error (Weiser, Krinsky, Cherez).</i> viz., <i>oyevah</i> and <i>oyevet</i>, and similarly <i>porah</i> and <i>porat</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Porah</i> is a <i>po’alah</i> and <i>porat</i> is a <i>po’elet</i>.</i> The word <i>porat</i> is related to the word <i>poriyyah</i> (fruitful) (Ps. 128:3). There is a commentator who connects <i>porat</i> to the word <i>porot</i> (branches) in <i>And brought forth branches</i> (porot) (Ezek. 17:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">In this case <i>ben</i> means a plant and <i>porat</i> a branch. According to this interpretation <i>ben porat yosef</i> means Joseph is a plant containing branches (Krinsky).</i> The Bible repeats the phrase <i>ben porot</i> twice in succession, for that is Hebrew style. Compare, <i>For, lo, Thine enemies, O Lord, For, lo, Thine enemies shall perish</i> (Ps. 92:10). The repetition of a phrase indicates permanence. According to the second quoted interpretation<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">That <i>porat</i> is related to <i>porot</i> (in Ezek. 17:6)</i> a <i>tav</i> has been substituted for a <i>heh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">In the word <i>porat</i>. If <i>porat</i> means a branch then our verse should have read <i>ben porah</i>, since <i>porah</i> is the singular of <i>porot</i> (branches). Thus <i>porat</i> is a variation of <i>porah</i>.</i> as in the case of the <i>tav</i> of <i>ve-shavat</i> (then it shall return) in <i>then it shall return</i> (ve-shavat) <i>to the prince</i> (Ezek. 46:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">The verse should have read <i>ve-shavah</i> instead of <i>ve-shavat</i>. Thus we see that a <i>tav</i> has been substituted for a <i>heh</i>.</i>
[ITS BRANCHES RUN OVER THE WALL.] Joseph was as a fruitful vine. He gave birth to branches, each one of which ran over the wall; i.e., the branches were so tall that they ran over fortified walls.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains <i>shur</i> (wall) to mean a wall which serves a defensive purpose (Krinsky). Such walls are high and strong. I.E. is saying that the branches grew very high (Cohen) or that the branches were so tall that they needed a mighty wall to support them (Krinsky).</i> Scripture here combines <i>banot</i> (branches) with <i>tza’adah</i> (run)<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Banot</i> is a noun in the plural, while <i>tza’adah</i> is a verb in the singular. If consistent, the text should read, <i>banot tza’adu</i>. I.E. explains that the combination of plural and singular means each one of the branches will run over the wall.</i> in a manner similar to <i>Dead flies</i> (zevuve) <i>make the ointment of the perfumer fetid</i> (yavish) (Eccles. 10:1). <sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Wherein <i>zevuve</i> is in the plural and <i>yavish</i> is in the singular. The meaning of this verse is that each one of the dead flies makes the ointment of the perfumer fetid. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Eccles. 10:1.</i>

Verse 23

HAVE DEALT BITTERLY WITH HIM. Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid explains this verse as meaning: they set his gall for a target (<i>va-yemareruhu</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mererah</i> means gall, hence Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid’s interpretation.</i> and then the archers shot at him (<i>va-robbu</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Reading <i>yaru</i>, as in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38.</i> The word <i>rabbim</i> (archers) in <i>Call together the archers</i> (rabbim) <i>against Babylon, All them that bend the bow</i> (Jer. 50:29) is similar to <i>va-robbu</i> in our verse. <sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that the word <i>rabbim</i> means archers. <i>Va-robbu</i> is its verbal form. The root of the word is <i>resh, bet, bet</i>.</i> <i>His archers compass me round about…He poureth out my gall upon the ground</i> (Job 16:13) is similar to our verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">In that it speaks of the gall as a target for archers (Cherez).</i>
AND HATED HIM. First they hated him and then they set up his gall as a target. We must thus explain <i>va-yistemuhu</i> to mean, and they had hated him.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yistemuhu</i> (and hated him) follows <i>va-robbu</i> (and they shot at him). 
Logically, <i>va-yistemuhu</i> should come first, i.e., the sequence should be they hated him, they set his gall as a target, and they shot at thim. Hence <i>va-yistemuhu</i> should be taken as a pluperfect (Weiser).</i> This<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The archers who hated and shot at Joseph.</i> alludes to Joseph’s brothers who sold him into slavery.

Verse 24

BUT HIS BOW ABODE FIRM. His bow abode in a firm place.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Be-etan</i> literally means in firm, which is short for <i>be-makom etan</i> (in a firm place) (Weiser).</i>
WERE MADE SUPPLE. <i>Va-yafozzu</i> means, and they strengthened themselves. I believe that <i>va-yafozzu</i> comes from the same root as <i>mefazzez</i> (leaping) (II Sam. 6:16).<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">One who leaps gathers up strength (Filwarg). One who leaps strengthens (tightens) his girdle (Cherez quoting Kimchi).</i> There are those who connect <i>va-yafozzu</i> to the word <i>paz</i> (pure gold).<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">They explain <i>va-yafozzu zero’e yadav</i> (and the arms of his hand were made supple) to mean, and the arms of his hand were gilded, an allusion to the golden ring Pharaoh gave him. Cf. Rashi.</i> However, their interpretation makes no sense. 
The meaning of our text (v. 23 and 24) is that the archers hated Joseph and gathered together to spill his gall. However, his adversaries were afraid of him because his bow and hands were strong. They therefore could not overcome him.
BY THE HANDS OF THE MIGHTY ONE OF JACOB. FROM THENCE. <i>The Mighty One of Jacob</i> alludes to the Lord. From the power that Joseph received from <i>the Mighty One of Jacob</i> he was able to become, and indeed became, “the shepherd of the stone of Israel.”<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><i>The Stone of Israel</i> refers to the children of Israel (Cherez).</i> And so it was, for we read, <i>And Joseph sustained his father, and his brethren, and all his father’s household, with bread</i> (Gen. 47:12). Jacob employed the term <i>Mighty One of Jacob</i> for God<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob could have employed the term, the Mighty One of Abraham or the Mighty One of Isaac (Krinsky).</i> because God knew of his deep love for Joseph.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph became “the shepherd of Israel” because of Jacob’s merit. God chose Joseph for this great honor and thereby elevated him above all his brothers because the Lord knew Jacob’s love for Joseph. Hence <i>By the hands of the Mighty One of Jacob etc</i>. means: you became the shepherd of the stone (children) of Israel from the power that came to you from the God who knew of my deep love for you.</i> 
The meaning of <i>stone</i> is the very thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Stone</i> represents essence, the very thing. The reference is to Jacob and his family. Cf. Rashi.</i> Some say<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is to Rabbi Isaac ibn Giat (Weiser, Cherez).</i> that <i>mi-sham</i> (from thence) should be interpreted from that time. However, we never find the word <i>sham</i> (there) to have this meaning anywhere in Scripture. This commentator also interprets <i>the Shepherd, the Stone of Israel</i> as meaning: the one whose heart died and was as stone,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is to Jacob whose heart died within him when he was told that Joseph was alive (Gen. 45:26,27). In I Sam. 25:37 such an experience is described as the heart turning to stone (Weiser, Cherez). According to Krinsky the reference is to Jacob and his family who would have died (their hearts would have turned to stone) had Joseph not fed them.</i> but who revived to feed (<i>ro’eh</i>), i.e., to live by eating. However, this interpretation is farfetched.

Verse 25

EVEN BY THE GOD OF THY FATHER. I believe that this verse is connected to the preceding one.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Even by God</i> literally reads, from the God (<i>me’el</i>). This term presents a problem. What came from God? I.E.’s answer is that from God refers to Joseph’s power which is referred to in the previous verse.</i> Its meaning is: the power which you possess came to you <i>from the God of thy father, who shall help thee</i>. The <i>mem</i> of <i>me-el</i> (even by God) is also to be prefixed to <i>ve-et</i> (and by).<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">That is, <i>ve-et</i> is to be read as if written <i>u-me-et</i> (and from by).</i> The <i>mem</i> of <i>me-el</i> is like the <i>bet</i> of <i>be-el</i> (as God) (Ex. 6:3) which is also to be prefixed to <i>u-ve-shemi</i> (but by my name).<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Our text is thus to be read as if written: From the God of thy father who shall help thee, and from the Almighty who shall bless thee. Ex. 6:3 literally reads: <i>and I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, as God Almighty</i> (be-el shaddai) <i>but my name</i> (u-shemi) <i>YHVH I made Me not known to them</i>. According to I.E. we should read the aforementioned as if written: and I appeared…as God Almighty (<i>be-el shaddai</i>) but with My name (<i>u-ve-shemi</i>) YHVH I made Me not known to them.</i> Thus <i>And from the Almighty, who shall bless thee</i> repeats the idea contained in <i>From the God of thy father, who shall help thee</i>. Saadiah Gaon explains the phrase <i>me-el avikha</i> to mean, I will ask of the God of thy fathers.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Saadiah, too, was bothered by the term <i>from the God</i>. He explained <i>from the God</i> not as connected to the previous verse, but as a new thought; viz., I will ask of the God of thy fathers that he help thee and of the Almighty that he bless thee (Cherez).</i> It is possible that <i>With blessings of heaven above</i> is connected to, <i>From the God of thy father</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">This interpretation, like the previous one, deals with the problem of verse 25 opening with the words <i>From the God</i>. It similarly rejects the notion that verse 25 is connected to verse 24. It, too, sees in verse 25 a new thought. It explains <i>From the God</i> as relating to the blessings mentioned in the second half of the verse, which shall come to you <i>from the God of thy father</i>.</i> The meaning of our text is explained by <i>They (the blessings) shall be on the head of Joseph, And on the crown of the prince among his brethren</i> (v. 26).<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 seems to conclude the blessing started in verse 25. The sequence thus appears to be: From God shall come to you blessings of the heavens above, of the deep that coucheth beneath, blessings of the breasts and womb. The aforementioned blessings shall be added to my mighty blessings and to the blessings of my progenitors and shall be on the head of Joseph and on the crown of the head of the prince among his brethren (Krinsky).</i>
BLESSSINGS OF THE DEEP. Moses similarly said, <i>And for the precious things of the earth and the fullness thereof</i> (Deut. 33:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">So Cherez. The point is that the blessing of the deep means that the land will be well watered and fertile, as Moses blessed the tribe of Joseph with a fertile land. Krinsky suggests that our text is corrupt and that the proof text should read: <i>For the precious things of heaven, for the dew, And for the deep that coucheth beneath</i> (Deut. 33:13). In this case I.E. is pointing out that Jacob and Moses’ blessings are identical.</i> The word <i>tehom</i> (the deep) is feminine both in our verse and in Deut. (33:16). It is similarly feminine in <i>The deep</i> (tehom) <i>made it to grow</i> (Ezek. 31:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>tehom rovetzet</i> (the deep that coucheth). Deut. 33:13 reads, <i>u-mi-tehom rovetzet</i> (and for the deep that coucheth). <i>Rovetzet</i> (coucheth) is feminine, hence <i>tehom</i> (the deep) must be feminine. Ezek. 31:4 reads, <i>tehom romematehu</i> (the deep made it to grow). Since <i>romematehu</i> is feminine, <i>tehom</i>, too, must be feminine. I.E. makes this point because <i>tehom</i> is masculine in Ps. 42:8. Thus we see that <i>tehom</i> is both masculine and feminine.</i> The meaning of <i>With blessings of heaven above, Blessings of the deep that coucheth beneath</i> is that rain will descend from the heavens above upon the land of Joseph and that the deep which coucheth beneath the earth will fill its rivers and springs with an abundance of water.
BLESSINGS OF THE BREASTS, AND OF THE WOMB. Jacob likened the breasts to heaven and the womb to the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads, <i>With blessings of heaven…Blessings of the deep…Blessings of the breasts, and of the womb</i>. According to I.E. breast and womb are similar to heaven and earth in that they produce life-giving substance and bring forth fruit. Hence they are included in the same verse.</i> its meaning being that Joseph will be blessed with many children.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">For an alternate interpretation see Krinsky and Cherez.</i> The opposite of this blessing is the curse, <i>Give them a miscarrying womb and dry breasts</i> (Hos. 9:14).

Verse 26

THE BLESSINGS OF THY FATHER. These blessings which I have blessed you with are mighty and are added to the blessing with which my progenitors blessed me.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">The point being, may you be blessed with the mighty blessings with which I bless you (<i>birkat avikhah gaveru</i>) plus the blessings with which my begetters blessed me (<i>al birkat horai</i>). Cherez explains that I.E. interprets <i>al</i> (beyond) as meaning <i>im</i> (with, plus).</i>
[PROGENITORS.] <i>Horai</i> is to be rendered my begetters.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">The root of <i>horai</i> is <i>heh, resh, heh</i> which means to be pregnant or to conceive. However, inasmuch as <i>horai</i> is in the plural it must refer to both Jacob’s mother and father. We obviously cannot explain <i>horai</i> as meaning the ones who bore me. Rather it must be interpreted to mean the ones who begot me (Cherez).</i> <i>Va-tahar</i> (and she gave birth to) in <i>and she gave birth to</i> (va-tahar) <i>Miriam</i> (I Chron. 4:17)<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, the root <i>heh, resh, heh</i> does not means to conceive or be pregnant with, for Chronicles deals with births and not with pregnancies. Thus <i>va-tahar</i> in I Chron. 4:17 means she gave birth to.</i> and <i>horah</i> (brought forth) in, <i>A man-child is brought forth</i> (horah) (Job 3:3)<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Here, too, the root <i>heh, resh, heh</i> does not mean to conceive but to bring forth, for its parallel reads <i>ivvaled</i> (I was born).</i> are similar.
UNTO THE UTMOST BOUND. <i>Ta’avat</i> (utmost bound of) comes from the same root as <i>ve-hitavvitem</i> (and ye shall mark out your line) (Num. 34:10). The meaning of our verse is: these blessings will be as high as the line marked out by the everlasting hills.
THE PRINCE AMONG HIS BRETHREN. <i>Nezir</i> (prince of) comes from the same root as <i>nezer</i> (crown).<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">It means crowned, the one who was crowned over his brethren (Krinsky, Weiser and Cherez). Filwarg suggests reading, “From the same root as <i>nazir</i> (Nazirite).” This reading fits in very well with I.E.’s comparison of <i>nezir</i> to <i>nediv</i>, for <i>nazir</i> has the same vocalization as <i>nadiv</i>, both in the absolute and in the construct. Thus in the absolute we have <i>nazir</i> and <i>nadiv</i> and in the construct <i>nezir</i> and <i>nediv</i>.</i> It is in the construct with <i>echav</i> (his brethren) and is therefore vocalized <i>nezir</i>. Compare, <i>nediv lev</i> (willing-hearted) (Ex. 35:22).

Verse 27

BENJAMIN. Jacob compared Benjamin to a wolf because Benjamin was mighty. The men of Gibeah are proof of this.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">At Gibeah 26,700 Benjamites defeated an army of 400,000 Israelites. Cf. Jud. 20.</i>
THE PREY. <i>Ad</i> (the prey) has the same meaning as the Aramaic word for spoil (<i>ada</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Reading <i>kemo targum shelal</i> as in <i>Vat. Ebr</i>. 38 rather than <i>targum shalal</i> as in the printed manuscripts. Also cf. Kimchi’s commentary on Is. 33:23.</i> Similarly, <i>ad</i> in <i>Then is the prey</i> (ad) <i>of a great spoil divided</i> (Is. 33:23) and in <i>Until the day that I rise up to the prey</i> (ad) (Zeph. 3:8); and <i>iddim</i> (a polluted garment) (Is. 64:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. on Is. 64:5 notes that a garment taken in spoil is polluted by blood. He points out that <i>iddim</i> and <i>ed</i> are similar. I.E. interprets <i>ed</i> (prey) to mean spoil.</i>.
[AND AT EVEN HE DIVIDETH.] At even he divideth among his children the prey that he has taken as spoil. Joshua says<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">A Karaite scholar.</i> that our verse alludes to King Saul who defeated the Amalekites.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Saul is likened to a wolf who takes spoil. Saul defeated the Amalekites and despoiled them. Cf. I Sam. 15.</i> He explains <i>In the morning</i> as alluding to the beginning of Israel’s kingdom<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">At the beginning of Israel’s kingdom Saul, who came from the tribe of Benjamin, despoiled Amalek. In exile, Mordecai the Benjamite despoiled Haman who was an Amalekite. Cf. Es. 8:1,2, <i>On that day did king Ahasuerus give the house of Haman…unto Esther the queen…And Esther set Mordecai over the house of Haman</i>.</i> and <i>at even</i> as referring to the period of Israel’s exile with regard to Mordecai. However, this interpretation is the way of the Midrash.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Bereshit Rabbah</i> 99:3 and <i>Tanchuma</i> 1:14; 2:15. It is hard to understand why I.E. quotes this interpretation in the name of a Karaite when it is found in the Midrash.</i> Onkelos’ interpretation of our verse is well known.<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos explains the “spoil” as referring to the portions which the priests received from sacrifices offered in the temple which was erected in the territory of Benjamin.</i>

Verse 28

EVERY ONE ACCORDING TO HIS BLESSING. The blessing which Jacob gave each one of his sons came to pass upon each one. The meaning of <i>every one according to his blessing</i> is similar in meaning to <i>each man according to the interpretation of his dream</i> (Gen. 41:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Joseph’s interpretation of the dreams came true for the butler and the baker, <i>each man according to the interpretation of his dream</i>. (Gen. 41:11).</i>

Verse 29

AND HE CHARGED THEM. He (Jacob) charged that all should go along with Joseph to bury him.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And he charged them</i> refers to <i>bury me with my fathers</i>. In the text they are not directly connected, hence I.E.’s comment. Krinsky points out that Jacob had made Joseph take an oath to bury him in the cave of Machpelah (Gen. 47:30). He now commanded all of his sons to join Joseph in his burial. Therefore, according to Krinsky, I.E. notes that the charge in our verse was to all of Jacob’s sons.</i>

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

HE GATHERED UP HIS FEET INTO THE BED. Until then he had been sitting on the bed with his feet dangling over its edge as is contemporarily the custom in Christian communities. The beds in Moslem countries are constructed differently from the beds in Christian countries.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">I.E. explains that Egyptian beds were the same as the beds used in Christian countries; hence it was possible for Jacob’s feet to dangle from his bed. However, had his bed been like those used in Moslem countries, that is, a bed that lies flat on the ground, this would have been impossible. I.E. makes this point so that readers in Moslem countries could understand how Jacob could be in bed with his feet over its side.</i>

Chapter 50



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND THE PHYSICIANS EMBALMED ISRAEL. They powdered his body with a preservative.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">This according to I.E. is the way a body is embalmed (Weiser). Krinsky holds that I.E. believes that only Jacob was embalmed in this manner so that his body would be spared the desecration that the usual embalming procedure entails.</i> It is possible, though a bit far fetched, that <i>chanetah</i> (putteth forth) in <i>The fig-tree putteth forth</i> (chanetah) <i>her green figs</i> (Cant. 2:13) is analogous to <i>va-yechantu</i> (embalmed).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I.E.’s comment on Cant. 2:13, “<i>Chanetah</i> means sweetened. Others say it means powdered, from the word <i>va-yechantu</i>.”</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

WHICH I HAVE DIGGED. <i>Kariti</i> means I have digged. <i>Kariti</i> is similar to <i>yikhreh</i> in <i>if a man shall dig</i> (yikhreh) <i>a pit</i> (Ex. 21:33).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">According to Krinsky, I.E. believes that Jacob prepared his own grave in the cave of Machpelah.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND WITH HIM WENT UP ALL THE SERVANTS OF PHARAOH. All of Egypt with the exception of Joseph are called servants of Pharaoh.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The verse speaks of <i>the servants of Pharaoh, the elders of his house</i>. If the aforementioned are elders, why does the Bible refer to them as servants? Hence I.E.’s comment. According to Cherez and Krinsky, I.E. was troubled by the clause <i>all the servants of Pharaoh</i>. If all the servants went along with Joseph to bury Jacob then no servants remained in Egypt to serve Pharaoh. This appears highly unlikely. Hence I.E. points out that <i>all the servants</i> refers to the Egyptians who accompanied Jacob’s body, for all the Egyptians are called Pharaoh’s servants.</i> 

Verse 8



Verse 9

[CHARIOTS. The word <i>rechev</i> (chariot) is similar in meaning to <i>mirkevet</i> (chariot).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Gen. 41:43, <i>mirkevet ha-mishneh</i> (the second chariot). This comment is omitted in some editions of the <i>Mikraot Gedolot</i>.</i>
HORSEMEN. The meaning of <i>parashim</i> (horsemen) is well-known.]

Verse 10

AND HE MADE A MOURNING FOR HIS FATHER SEVEN DAYS. This, as our sages of blessed memory say, took place after they interred Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">What I.E. means is, even though the actual burial of Jacob is reported in verse 13, it occurred before <i>he made a mourning for his father seven days</i>. This is so because the sages of the talmud say that mourning commences after the burial of the deceased. Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i>. 47b.</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12

AND HIS SONS DID UNTO HIM. That is: And behold his sons did as he commanded them, namely, carried him and buried him in the place that he commanded them to inter him.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Since the mourning described in verse 10 took place after the burial of Jacob we cannot interpret <i>And his sons did unto him</i>, etc., as a report of what happened after the mourning for Jacob. It is rather a report of what Jacob’s sons did for their father.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

IT MAY BE THAT JOSEPH WILL HATE US. Perhaps Joseph will harbor a hatred for us. <i>Yistemenu</i> (will hate us) is analogous to <i>va-yistom</i> in <i>And Esau hated</i> (va-yistom) <i>Jacob</i> (Gen. 27:41).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">There, too, I.E. interprets: and Esau harbored hatred toward Jacob.</i> The word <i>lu</i> (it may be) is used in Scripture in many ways.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi, “<i>Lu</i> is sometimes used to denote a request, or to denote, would that…<i>lu</i> is also used to denote if and perhaps…and <i>lu</i> is also sometimes used to denote it may be.”</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17

I PRAY THEE. <i>Anna</i> (I pray thee) is a conciliatory expression.

Verse 18



Verse 19

[FOR AM I IN THE PLACE OF GOD.] Saadiah Gaon explains this as meaning: am I in the place of God that you fall before my face and say, <i>Behold, we are thy bondmen</i>?

Verse 20

TO PASS. <i>Aso</i> (to pass) is an infinitive.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The usual form of this infinitive is <i>asot</i>, hence I.E.’s comment.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

CHILDREN OF THE THIRD GENERATION. In view of the fact that <i>bene</i> (children of) is in the construct with <i>shilleshim</i> (third), the children referred to are the fourth generation.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The children of the third generation are the fourth generation.</i>
WERE BORN. <i>Yulledu</i> (were born) means grew up.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">They weren’t actually born on his knees. Joseph raised them; that is, he hugged them and placed them on his knees as a father does when raising his children.</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

AND THEY EMBALMED HIM. The physicians.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The text doesn’t say who embalmed him. However, in view of verse 2, the reference must be to the physicians. Our text is thus abridged. It should have read: And the physicians embalmed Israel (Weiser).</i>
AND HE WAS PUT IN A COFFIN. Someone put him in a coffin.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">According to I.E. <i>va-yisem</i> is a <i>kal</i> which means, and he put However, the subject has been omitted. Hence we must interpret it as, and someone put. Similarly the word <i>oto</i> (him) is to be added to the text Hence <i>va-yisem ba-aron</i> should be rendered, and someone put him in a coffin.</i> The root of <i>va-yisem</i> is <i>yod, sin, mem</i> and follows the paradigm of <i>va-yitzer</i> (formed) (Gen. 2:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Va-yitzer</i> is a <i>peh yod, kal</i>. So is <i>va-yisem</i>.</i> However, Rabbi Jonah, the grammarian, says that <i>va-yisem</i> is vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> in place of a <i>shuruk</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rabbi Jonah ibn Janach <i>va-yisem</i> is a <i>hofal</i> from the root <i>yod, sin, mem</i> meaning, and he was put. However, if <i>va-yisem</i> was a <i>hofal</i> it would have been vocalized <i>va-yusam</i>. Hence Rabbi Jonah says that <i>va-yisem</i> has been vocalized with a <i>chirik</i> in place of a <i>shuruk</i>. According to Rabbi Jonah <i>va-yisem ba-aron</i> is to be rendered: and he was put in a coffin. The advantage of this interpretation is that one does not have to add the pronoun <i>oto</i> (him) to the text and the subject is not omitted from the verse.</i> However, I consider this interpretation to be far-fetched.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If Scripture intended to use a <i>hofal</i>, it would have vocalized <i>va-yisem</i> like a <i>hofal</i>. In his <i>Sefer Ha-Tzachot</i> I.E. sharply criticizes Ibn Janach for suggesting that Biblical words be read other than as written. I.E. writes, “Only take heed to thyself, and keep thy soul not to believe the words of the grammarian (Ibn Janach) who noted in his book (<i>Sefer Ha-Rikmah</i>) more than a hundred (Biblical) words that require change…Heaven forbid such a notion…his book is fit to be burned.”</i>
[IN A COFFIN.] The reason why <i>ba-aron</i> (in a coffin) is vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> is that it signifies the coffin which he had prepared for himself. <sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Be-aron</i> means in a coffin. <i>Ba-aron</i> on the other hand means in the coffin. Hence our verse must be referring to a specific coffin, i.e., to the coffin that Joseph prepared for himself.</i>
